1.3 Historical or etiological accounts locate the problem in how the preference was formed—through socialization, manipulation, or coercion that bypassed the agent’s critical capacities.  

This essay argues that while each approach isolates a genuine aspect of adaptive preference pathology, historical accounts best explain why such preferences, especially under oppression, are less than fully autonomous. Subjectivist and content‐based theories either license too many false positives (counting some adaptive preferences as autonomous) or impose controversial perfectionist standards that misdiagnose other cases. A historically sensitive view captures what is normatively disquieting—namely, that the preference’s causal history systematically distorts, excludes, or silences the agent’s own standpoint. The argument proceeds in six steps:  

2. Clarifying adaptive preferences and autonomy;  
3. Evaluating subjectivist accounts;  
4. Evaluating content‐based accounts;  
5. Developing the historical explanation;  
6. Addressing objections;  
7. Implications for theory and practice.  

2. Adaptive Preferences and the Idea of Autonomy  

To call a preference “adaptive” is not merely to note behavioral plasticity; it is to say that the preference arose “in response to” a limited option set in a way that makes the limitation normatively relevant. If I move to Spain and gradually come to prefer olive oil to butter, that adaptation looks problem‐free. By contrast, when a young girl denied educational opportunities comes to “prefer” domestic confinement, her preference seems saddled with a deficit. A plausible working definition is:  

Adaptive Preference: A preference φ of agent A is adaptive if (i) A initially lacked φ, or possessed a weaker φ, (ii) φ arose because available options made φ relatively easy or necessary to satisfy, and (iii) φ stabilizes A’s acceptance of her restricted circumstances.  

Autonomy, following a long liberal tradition, can be minimally glossed as self‐government: actions or preferences are autonomous when they reflect the agent’s own evaluative standpoint in a way that is substantially free from illegitimate control by others, from self‐undermining psychological mechanisms, and from ignorance. That broad notion leaves room for distinct elaborations, which the three families of theories supply. Our question is which elaboration best diagnoses the defective autonomy of adaptive preferences.  

3. Subjectivist Accounts: Frankfurt and Beyond  

Frankfurt thinks that what matters is not what a person wants but whether she wants to want it. Provided the agent reflectively endorses a desire—forms a “second‐order volition” that this desire move her to act—the desire is hers in the fullest sense. The view is attractive because it ties autonomy to recognizable agential capacities: reflection, endorsement, identification.  

3.1 Why subjectivism seems promising  

Many adaptive preference holders do disidentify from alternative possibilities. Sen’s hungry girl may sincerely say she does not want bigger meals; the docile housewife may feel revulsion at feminist exhortations; and the fox regards sour grapes with disdain. If endorsement suffices, then these desires would be autonomous—and therefore not morally problematic on that ground alone. This matches a liberal reluctance to declare people heteronomous merely because they choose differently from us.  

3.2 The endorsement‐capture worry  

Yet Frankfurtian endorsement is too cheap. Oppressive systems are adept at securing not mere conformity but internal consent. Hierarchies, ideology, and social sanctions implant higher‐order approval of exactly the first‐order desires that serve the status quo. The battered spouse who believes she deserves her partner’s violence may wholeheartedly endorse submissive desires that sustain abuse. If reflective endorsement counts as autonomy even here, the theory implausibly vindicates domination.  

One might reply that the endorsement must be formed under conditions of full information and absence of coercion. But full information is often available: wives know alternative lifestyles exist; workers know lottery winners thrive. The deeper problem is the interpretive context in which the agent evaluates reasons for endorsement. When a whole social order teaches women that obedience is virtuous, their internal deliberation is tainted although not literally coerced.  

3.3 Deep vs. shallow preferences  

An influential refinement distinguishes between merely “adapted” and “deformed” selves. Christman (1991) proposes historical constraints on endorsement: the agent must be able to reflect upon and reform first‐order preferences in a self‐directed, non‐oppressive environment. Yet once historical conditions enter, the view ceases to be purely subjectivist; it becomes a hybrid that owes its diagnostic power precisely to an etiological element.  

Conclusion for subjectivism: Without historical supplementation, subjectivist accounts risk legitimizing adaptive preferences that intuitively betray autonomy. With supplementation, they collapse into the historical family addressed below.  

4. Content‐Based Accounts  

At the opposite pole are substantive theories holding that certain desires are autonomy‐defective because of what they aim at. Autonomy is a value; if the content of a preference is servility, dependence, or self‐harm, the preference cannot instantiate that value.  

4.1 The appeal of content‐based diagnosis  

It is tempting to say that wanting malnutrition, female circumcision, or political disenfranchisement is manifestly inconsistent with governing oneself. Isaiah Berlin’s picture of the autonomous agent as a chooser who stands above immediate cravings encourages the view that capitulation to degrading roles self‐evidently undermines freedom. Martha Nussbaum, for example, argues that a capability for practical reason sets non‐negotiable thresholds; preferences that conflict with securing those capabilities indicate adaptive distortion.  

4.2 Problems of perfectionism and cultural imperialism  

But substantive theories draw autonomy boundaries with controversial substantive moral notions. They invite the charge of paternalism: who is to declare that a nun’s vow of obedience or a devotee’s hunger strike is heteronomous? Some preferences that look demeaning from the outside might express deeply held, identity‐constituting commitments. Moreover, oppression often works by re‐labeling domination as virtue; a content test may misclassify some genuinely autonomous renunciations simply because they resemble familiar patterns of servility.  

4.3 The sour grapes counter‐example  

The fox’s disdain for grapes is not intrinsically base; there is nothing morally suspect about preferring not to eat fruit. What troubles us is how the preference emerged. Content considerations alone cannot explain why the fox’s new preference seems self‐deceptive. Conversely, an oppressed activist might passionately long for political martyrdom—objectively costly and risky—and yet we may judge her preference highly autonomous because it resists domination. Thus, autonomy deficit does not track moral disvalue in content.  

Conclusion for content‐based views: While they correctly flag some disturbing cases, they over‐include and under‐include by tethering autonomy too tightly to contested ideals of the good life. The real pathology seems to lie elsewhere.  

5. Historical Accounts  

Historical accounts, by contrast, focus on the genesis of preference. A desire is autonomous only if its formation did not bypass, subvert, or silence the agent’s critical reflection. Sources include Jeremy Waldron, Allen Buchanan, and Marina Oshana. They extend Gerald Dworkin’s original “procedural independence” condition: the preference must not be the product of manipulative or coercive socialization.  

5.1 How historical etiologies capture adaptive preferences  

Adaptive preferences under oppression prototypically arise in environments that systematically distort deliberation. Scarcity trains the poor to lower aspirations; patriarchy teaches girls that ambition is unfeminine; colonial domination inculcates an inferiority complex in the colonized. What these environments share is not necessarily that the content of the eventual preferences is base, nor that the agents fail to endorse them at higher order. Rather, the preferences are shaped by pressures that circumvent the person’s ability to weigh alternatives on unconstrained terms. The causal story directly connects external limitation to internal motivational shrinkage.  

Historical accounts explain why Sen’s hungry girl is not fully autonomous: her culture of deprivation stunted the range of possibilities she could realistically deliberate about, and this antecedent deprivation is precisely what produced her present liking for small meals. Similarly, Elster’s fox hatred of grapes is unproblematic in content and (we can stipulate) endorsed, but the hatred arose from frustrated effort followed by rationalization—a psychological mechanism triggered by constraint.  

5.2 Distinctive explanatory virtues  

First, the historical approach preserves respect for agents’ current first‐order self‐conceptions. We need not paternalistically override any preference solely because it violates our substantive ideals; rather, we scrutinize whether the conditions under which it was formed were themselves freedom‐undermining. Second, the approach is sensitive to structural oppression: it shows how power operates not merely through direct coercion but by molding the very motivational repertoire of disadvantaged groups. Finally, it aligns with our remedial instincts. The proper response to adaptive preferences is not coercive re‐education but dismantling the background constraints that generated them.  

5.3 The objection of hard cases  

Critics worry that historical theories require too stark a notion of causal taint: every preference is causally dependent on some social milieu. Where, then, to draw lines? The answer lies in distinguishing ordinary social influence from domination‐based influence. A historical account must specify that only certain types of formative pressures—systematic, pervasive, and illegitimate constraints—constitute autonomy‐undermining etiology. This is no more arbitrary than Frankfurt’s demand for endorsement or Nussbaum’s threshold list; it simply locates the normative bite elsewhere.  

6. Replies to Objections and Hybrid Possibilities  

6.1 The regress problem  

One might object that an agent could retrospectively endorse a historically tainted preference after learning about its etiology. Does that second‐order ratification restore autonomy? Historical theorists can allow redemption: if the agent, situated in genuinely emancipatory circumstances, critically re‐examines and still endorses the preference, the etiological taint is neutralized. What matters is not the mere presence of distorting history but the continued absence of opportunities to repudiate or reshape it.  

6.2 Charges of elitism  

Some argue that historical accounts smuggle in substantive values by labeling certain influences “illegitimate.” Yet the standard for illegitimacy can be procedural: those influences systematically undermine the agent’s capacity for informed, critical reflection. A socialization that encourages rational deliberation about all significant life options is benign; one that forecloses such deliberation is not. The evaluative element is thus about respect for agency, not about a particular vision of the good life.  

6.3 The need for a hybrid theory  

While history does the main explanatory work, it may have to cooperate with subjectivist elements. After all, autonomy is partly about reflective self‐direction in the present. Hence the most plausible overall view is bi‐criterial: (a) a preference must be free from etiological constraints that undermine critical competencies, and (b) the agent must currently be able to identify with it upon adequate reflection. But once we add (a), subjectivist endorsement alone loses its sufficiency, and content loses its necessity. The historical component is the linchpin.  

7. Implications and Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences pose a profound challenge to any simple, ahistorical conception of autonomy. They demonstrate that domination can penetrate below the surface of choice, warping the very standards by which people judge their well‐being. When a girl says she “prefers” not to study or a worker avows that drudgery is his “calling,” it is tempting either to respect their stated wishes or to denounce them as dupes. The correct stance, I have argued, is nuanced: we respect their agency but recognize the formative role of unjust constraints.  

Subjectivist accounts capture the importance of internal endorsement but overlook how such endorsement can itself be an artifact of oppression. Content‐based accounts rightly resist relativism but risk paternalistic imposition of contested values. Historical accounts explain both why endorsement is not enough and why the substance of desire can be innocent yet still autonomy‐impaired. They reveal that what matters is whether the process that produced the preference left the agent with sufficient epistemic, imaginative, and deliberative freedom.  

Therefore, in cases of oppression it is chiefly the causal history—systematic deprivation, ideological socialization, internalized inferiority—that renders adaptive preferences less than fully autonomous. Respect for persons demands not the simple gratification of whatever they now want nor dictating what they should want, but dismantling the structures that constrained what they could come to want in the first place.
