What Makes Adaptive Preferences Less Than Fully Autonomous?
  
1. Introduction  

Autonomous agency is commonly characterised by self-determination: an autonomous agent is one whose choices are, in some suitably robust sense, her own.  Yet many real-world choices are made in circumstances marked by deprivation or oppression.  Amartya Sen’s famous story of the landless labourer in rural Bengal who reports that he does not really need more food, or Jon Elster’s fox who proclaims the unreachable grapes “sour,” dramatise the phenomenon now called adaptive preference formation.  An adaptive preference is a preference that is adjusted downward (or in some other accommodating direction) in response to a restriction on one’s feasible set of options.  In feminist literature, paradigmatic examples include the young girl who claims to “prefer” an arranged marriage at fourteen, or the sweat-shop worker who says she “doesn’t mind” ten-hour shifts because “that’s just how life is.”  Intuitively, such preferences seem to fall short of full autonomy even when the agent wholeheartedly endorses them.  The philosophical question is why.

Three families of answers dominate the autonomy literature:

A. Subjectivist or procedural accounts, epitomised by Harry Frankfurt’s hierarchical model of endorsement, trace autonomy to structures of internal reflection and endorsement.  
B. Content-based accounts, such as Martha Nussbaum’s capabilities approach, locate autonomy deficits in the moral or prudential unworthiness of what is preferred.  
C. Historical or relational accounts, represented by Gerald Dworkin, Marina Oshana, John Christman, and others, focus on how the preference was actually formed in its social context.

My aim is to evaluate which of these accounts best explains the apparent autonomy deficit of adaptive preferences under oppression.  I will argue that (1) purely subjectivist accounts fail because endorsement alone cannot filter out the distorting effects of oppressive socialisation; (2) purely content-based accounts succeed in identifying many wrongful adaptations but at the unacceptable cost of collapsing autonomy into objective normativity; and (3) historical-relational accounts, suitably refined, succeed better than their rivals because they can explain why some, but not all, adaptive preferences lack autonomy, in a way that avoids both paternalism and formalism.

2. Adaptive Preferences and the Puzzle of Autonomy  

Sen introduced the term “adaptive preference” to diagnose a tension within welfare economics: people systematically report high life-satisfaction even under objectively poor conditions, thereby masking injustice.  Philosophers quickly noticed a deeper worry.  If autonomy requires an agent’s choices to express her authentic self, then the adaptability of human motivation threatens authenticity.  Real people adjust their expectations and aspirations to what they believe is realistically attainable.  Indeed, such adjustment can be rational: the fox’s self-protective re-evaluation of the grapes spares him frustration.  When, if ever, does such adaptation make the resulting preference less than autonomous?

Consider three stylised cases:

Case 1: Sour Grapes.  A gifted student from a disadvantaged background abandons her aspiration to attend university because she believes—mistakenly, as it happens—that scholarships are unavailable.  She now sincerely “prefers” to work in the local cannery.  

Case 2: Internalised Domination.  A woman in a highly patriarchal society says she has no interest in voting or holding political office; she believes politics would distract her from her “true vocation” as wife and mother.  

Case 3: Harsh Realism.  A migrant worker prefers twelve-hour factory shifts to farming because factory work, grim though it is, pays marginally better; she is fully aware of alternative styles of life elsewhere but sees no practicable route to them.

Intuitively, Case 2 looks least autonomous, Case 3 perhaps fully autonomous, and Case 1 somewhere in between.  What philosophical criteria deliver this pattern?

3. The Subjectivist Strategy and Its Limits  

Frankfurtian autonomy centres on internal hierarchies of desire.  I act autonomously, on this view, when (i) I act on a first-order desire, and (ii) I have a second-order desire that this very first-order desire move me to act.  The only relevant question is whether the desire is truly mine, where “truly” is cashed out procedurally: Did I reflect on the desire without coercion, manipulation, or compulsion?  The content of the desire and its causal history, except for direct coercion, are irrelevant.

Applied to adaptive preferences, the subjectivist will say: provided the woman in Case 2 wholeheartedly endorses her preference to abstain from politics after ideal first-person reflection, her preference is autonomous.  Many find this conclusion intolerable.  The worry is not merely empirical (that such wholeheartedness is unlikely), but theoretical: the very standards by which she evaluates herself have been scripted by oppressive norms.  Oppression can operate “internally,” shaping the principles an agent uses in reflection.  Frankfurt’s later work insists that a person need only identify with her volitions in a volitional sense, but this misses the deeper point that identification itself can be adaptive.  

Feminist critics such as Susan Wolf, Andrea Westlund, and Diana Meyers argue that an adequate test of authenticity must include responsiveness to critical perspectives beyond the agent’s current evaluative outlook.  Otherwise, autonomy becomes indistinguishable from contented slavery.  Pragmatically, subjectivism misfires: it lets oppressive structures off the hook by declaring their human products fully autonomous.

A Frankfurtian might reply that wholeheartedness requires the absence of coercion, and internalised patriarchy is a form of coercion.  But this move stretches “coercion” beyond recognition, for socialisation is ubiquitous; distinguishing mere upbringing from coercion demands precisely the historical material subjectivism tried to avoid.

Therefore, while the hierarchical model provides an elegant internal criterion for autonomy, it fails to diagnose the autonomy deficit of many adaptive preferences under oppression.  It is either too strict (if all social influence counts as coercive) or too lax (if coercion is limited to overt compulsion).

4. The Content-Based Alternative  

Content or substantive accounts maintain that some desires are autonomy-undermining simply in virtue of what they aim at.  A preference to be a chattel slave, or to undergo female genital cutting for the sake of male approval, is not autonomous regardless of procedure.  Martha Nussbaum grounds autonomy in an objective list of central human capabilities: life, bodily integrity, practical reason, affiliation, play, and so on.  A preference that repudiates or significantly thwarts one of these basic capabilities indicates a failure of autonomy.

Content-based accounts score an initial advantage in cases like Internalised Domination.  The preference not to vote violates the capability for political control over one’s environment; hence it is non-autonomous.  Likewise, the child bride who “happily” drops out of school is thwarting her capability for practical reason.  The account captures the intuition that genuine autonomy is inconsistent with radical self-abnegation.

Yet content-based accounts carry heavy costs:

a. Paternalism.  If autonomy is defined by objective goods, then whenever an agent’s choices conflict with those goods, she is by definition non-autonomous.  This threatens to collapse the normative distinction between respecting autonomy and promoting welfare.  Opposition to, say, recreational drug use, or the preference for ascetic monastic life, could be reclassified as paternalistic interventions “for the sake of autonomy.”  

b. Uniformity.  Human lives exhibit diverse conceptions of the good.  A blanket list of capabilities risks ethnocentrism unless pitched so abstractly that it loses bite.

c. Adaptive but Permissible Desires.  The student in Sour Grapes may still enjoy a rich, meaningful life even on the cannery track.  It is not obvious that her preference violates any basic capability.  Yet we still detect an autonomy deficit because her preference seems causally hostage to misinformation about scholarships.

d. Rational Adaptation.  The migrant worker in Harsh Realism seems to forgo no central capability that is realistically available to her.  Treating her preference as non-autonomous would be moralistic overreach.

Thus, a purely content-based theory over-generates judgments of non-autonomy in some cases and under-generates in others.  We need a way to accommodate the agent’s informational environment and social position without foreclosing pluralism about the good life.

5. Historical-Relational Accounts  

Historical accounts locate autonomy not in current mental states or the content of desires but in the causal processes that led to those states.  Gerald Dworkin’s seminal proposal required that preferences be “reflectively endorsed after a period of self-scrutiny carried out in the absence of compulsion.”  John Christman refined this by adding a negative historical condition: an agent is autonomous with respect to a desire only if she could, upon sustained critical reflection, distance herself from it, and the processes that shaped the desire were not the result of manipulation that the agent would find alienating.  Marina Oshana goes further, embedding autonomy in relations of social power: an agent’s choices are autonomous only if she enjoys effective control over the dominant factors that shape her actions.

Let us test the three cases.

Case 2: Internalised Domination.  The woman’s preference has been socially engineered by patriarchal norms that she is powerless to resist.  The shaping mechanism—lifelong normative conditioning that systematically limits her access to alternative evaluative perspectives—is an alienating form of manipulation.  Historical-relational accounts therefore judge her preference non-autonomous, aligning with intuitions.

Case 3: Harsh Realism.  The migrant worker’s preference arises in a harsh environment, but not one that manipulates her evaluative outlook; she knows and disapproves of the overarching system of exploitation.  She simply appraises her options realistically.  Historical accounts accordingly grant her autonomy.

Case 1: Sour Grapes.  The student’s adaptive preference is based on misinformation.  If, upon learning about scholarships, she would prefer university study, then her current preference is not autonomous because it rests on a distorting historical defect: lack of adequate information due to unjust educational structures.  If, however, she would still prefer cannery work for family or aesthetic reasons, her preference could be autonomous.  Historical accounts thus deliver the nuanced verdict we wanted.

Strengths:

1. They explain why oppressive socialisation is more autonomy-threatening than ordinary cultural influence: the former involves systematic domination or manipulation that would alienate the agent under conditions of adequate self-reflection.  
2. They separate autonomy from value: an individual may autonomously choose hardship or self-sacrifice provided the choice was formed free of domination.  
3. They make room for rational adaptation.  Preferences formed through realistic appraisal of constraints that the agent recognises and accepts—while regrettable in a larger moral sense—can be fully autonomous.

Challenges:

a. Counterfactual Thickness.  Determining what the agent “would reject” under ideal reflection risks speculative psychology.  Yet this epistemic worry confronts all autonomy theories; it is not unique to historical accounts.

b. Ubiquity of Social Influence.  Since every preference is historically conditioned, we need principled criteria to distinguish autonomy-threatening from innocuous influences.  Christman’s answer invokes “alienating” causal histories—histories the agent herself, on balance, would disavow if aware of them.  While imperfect, this test tracks the agent’s own standpoint rather than the theorist’s.

c. Structural Barriers.  If autonomy requires “effective control,” as Oshana says, then agents in unjust societies seldom qualify.  The concept risks becoming unrealistically demanding.  A moderate historical view, combining Christman’s negative condition with a realistic threshold of control, seems preferable.

6. Why Historical-Relational Accounts Outperform Their Rivals  

The core phenomenon adaptive-preferences theorists wish to capture is that a person can willingly, even joyfully, choose an option that is bad for her because her evaluative horizon has been against her will shrunk by injustice.  Subjectivist accounts miss this because they ignore how endorsement itself can be manufactured.  Content accounts overplay the point by equating autonomy with objective value, thereby threatening pluralism and licensing over-broad paternalism.  Historical-relational accounts, by contrast, explain the autonomy deficit precisely as the product of domination: the agent’s capacity for self-government has been undermined by a formative history she could not reasonably resist and would critique if she could.

Moreover, these accounts illuminate the relation between autonomy and adaptive preferences in a way that guides policy.  They tell us to look not at whether the agent feels content, nor at whether we approve of her ends, but at the background conditions—information, deliberative opportunities, social status—that shape her evaluative capacities.  This focus matches feminist and post-colonial insights that liberation is less about imposing superior values and more about dismantling unjust power relations so that people can author their own values.

7. Hybrid Enhancements: Guarding Against Over-Inclusiveness  

Despite their comparative merits, historical accounts benefit from supplementation.  Two refinements are helpful:

a. Procedural Reflexivity.  Following Andrea Westlund, we can require “dialogical” competence: the agent must be able and willing to justify her preferences in open dialogue with interlocutors, revising them when confronted with credible challenges.  This guards against dogmatic internalisation.

b. Minimal Substantive Thresholds.  A thin list of baseline capabilities can function as a defeasible check.  If a preference destroys a basic capability (e.g., life, bodily integrity) the bar for counting it autonomous rises dramatically, because ordinary people seldom endorse the irreversible obliteration of fundamental functioning absent manipulation.

These additions preserve the historical approach’s anti-paternalist spirit while ensuring that extreme self-destructive adaptations (e.g., voluntary slavery) are not too quickly labelled autonomous.

8. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Historical accounts rely on hypothetical judgments about what the agent would do under ideal conditions—this is speculative and risks projecting the theorist’s values.

Reply: True, but every autonomy test involves hypotheticals (e.g., “Would the agent endorse this desire on reflection?”).  The historical account mitigates bias by making the relevant standpoint the agent’s own counterfactual attitude, not the observer’s.  Empirical methods—narrative interviews, participatory deliberation—can approximate that standpoint.

Objection 2: Some adaptive preferences seem both value-denying and historically benign.  Suppose a mountain hermit, after years of solitary reflection, decides he prefers self-starvation to dependence on society.  Is this non-autonomous?

Reply: The historical account would likely deem it autonomous: no domination distorted his preference.  Content theorists may protest, but insisting that autonomy always coincides with objective flourishing risks disrespecting the hermit’s radical self-direction.  Cases of self-regarding, informed, undominated self-sacrifice, though tragic, exemplify human freedom.

Objection 3: Even historical accounts cannot explain why we feel more confident in calling Case 2 non-autonomous than Case 1.  Both involve unjust constraints.

Reply: The difference lies in the nature of the constraint.  In Case 2 the constraint operates directly on the agent’s evaluative standpoint via gender ideology she had no opportunity to question.  In Case 1 the constraint is epistemic and potentially removable; hence her preference is “weakly” non-autonomous—a judgment the historical view can express by degree.

9. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences are less than fully autonomous when, and because, the processes that formed them are marred by domination: misinformation, skewed socialisation, or structural powerlessness that systematically restricts the agent’s capacity to envisage and evaluate alternatives.  Subjectivist accounts overlook this because they focus narrowly on contemporaneous endorsement, ignoring how endorsement can itself be a creature of injustice.  Content-based accounts capture some central cases but at the cost of paternalism and cultural uniformity.  Historical-relational accounts, especially when enriched with requirements of dialogical reflectivity and minimal capability thresholds, best explain the autonomy deficit we detect in adaptive preferences.  By tying autonomy to the agent’s own potential for critical self-assessment within an undominated social space, they honour both the liberatory ambitions of egalitarian politics and the liberal commitment to respecting individuals as the authors of their own lives.

1. Introduction  

Since Gilbert Harman’s relativist conjectures and Allan Gibbard’s early work on expressivism, philosophers of language have taken an increasing interest in subtle grammatical phenomena that seem to separate evaluative from purely descriptive discourse.  One such phenomenon is the restrictive complementation profile of the English verb find when it is used in what linguists call its “evaluative” or “subjective-attitude” sense, as in

  (1) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
  (2) She finds lying wrong.

where tasty and wrong embed smoothly, but

  (3) *Holmes finds Saltimbocca Italian.  
  (4) *She finds lying widespread.

sound plainly deviant on the intended non-factive reading (the starred sentences are acceptable only on an evidential interpretation of find—roughly ‘discovers that’—which is irrelevant here).  Expressivists are understandably excited by this distribution, because it suggests a tight connection between evaluative predicates and a mental state that is not transparently belief-like.  If the state ascribed by (1)–(2) is crucially affective or conative rather than cognitive, then the felt oddity of

  (5) ??Saltimbocca is tasty but I don’t find it tasty.  
  (6) ??It is wrong to eat meat, yet I don’t find it wrong.

is naturally assimilated to the Moore-paradox pattern that classic expressivists invoke: the second conjunct cancels the attitude the first is supposed to express, so the whole assertion defeats itself pragmatically.

The present essay surveys the main strands of evidence—grammatical, inferential, developmental, phenomenological, and conversational—that converge on the claim that the mental state characterised by evaluative find is a non-cognitive, affect-laden stance of roughly the same family as appreciating, loving, hating, disliking, adoring, and detesting.  I conclude that the linguistic data supply serious, though not decisive, support for contemporary expressivism.

2. Two senses of “find” and the embedding restriction  

English find is polysemous.  The evidential sense, as in “I found that the door was locked,” embeds any proposition that can be a content of belief.  The subjective-attitude sense, in contrast, embeds only evaluative or “thinly normative” predicates.  The quickest way to see the contrast is to compare:

  (7) Galileo found that the Earth moves.          (evidential)  
  (8) *Galileo found the Earth moving.            (subjective-attitude)  
  (9) Galileo found the Earth magnificent.        (subjective-attitude)

Sentence (7) is unexceptionable.  Sentence (8) is ungrammatical unless one hears it with a different syntactic parse (gerund as progressive complement).  Sentence (9) is perfectly good.  So, whatever semantic type complements subjective find must be the kind of thing realised by magnificent, tasty, cruel, boring, unfair, and so forth, but not by moving, vegetarian, metallic, or Italian.  Purely descriptive adjectives resist the construction.

What explains the restriction?  A prima facie promising view is that subjective find selects for predicates whose evaluation essentially invokes an affective stance on the part of the subject argument.  To test that idea, linguists have deployed a battery of diagnostics that contrast paradigmatic belief-ascribing verbs (think, believe, know) with paradigmatic attitude-cum-emotion verbs (love, hate, fear).  It turns out that evaluative find patterns systematically with the affective class.

3. Linguistic diagnostics for affectivity  

3.1. The intensional negation test  

Belief verbs allow a flat contradiction between the matrix clause and the complement without generating infelicity:

  (10) It is raining, but I believe it is not.         (Moore-paradoxical, yet merely odd)  
  (11) It is beautiful, but I find it ugly.           (pragmatically impossible)

Example (10) is a standard Moore paradox; but speakers judge it less jarring than (11).  In (11) the second conjunct withdraws the very affective orientation the first expresses, creating outright incoherence.  This mirrors judgments about love/hate:

  (12) ??She is delightful, but I hate her.            (coherent only with irony or self-conflict)

3.2. Discourse-sequencing test  

Beliefs can be revised through evidence, and it is felicitous to say:

  (13) At first I believed the sculpture was bronze, but later I discovered it was marble instead.

By contrast, the corresponding sequence with find is odd unless the speaker literally changes taste or sensibility rather than revises a descriptive judgement:

  (14) ?At first I found the sculpture stunning, but later I discovered it was pedestrian instead.  (requires a story about loss of appreciation)

Again, the pattern matches love/hate:

  (15) I loved the show at first, but later I realised it was boring.    (felicitous)

Importantly, the second clause in (15) recounts a shift in affect, not a new belief.

3.3. Embedding under verbs of cognitive attitude  

Predicates that pick out contents of belief embed easily under think:

  (16) I think that she is Italian.  
  (17) *I think that she is tasty.          (only acceptable if tasty is reinterpreted as “appealing to me”)

Compare:

  (18) *I think that I love strawberries.

We do not normally “think” an emotion; we feel it.  Likewise we do not “think” something tasty; we find it tasty.

3.4. Question-answer congruence  

Questions about belief invite that-clauses; questions about find encourage adjectival complements:

  Q: What do you believe about meat eating?  
  A: I believe that it is environmentally harmful.

  Q: How do you find meat eating?  
  A: I find it ethically problematic/*that it is ethically problematic.

3.5. Compatibility with degree modification and expletive intensifiers  

Evaluative adjectives in find-constructions happily accept degree modifiers that signal emotional import:

  (19) I find this painting utterly breathtaking.  
  (20) *I find this handle utterly metallic.

Analogous patterns occur with standard emotion verbs:

  (21) I utterly hate that song.  
  (22) *I utterly know that fact.

3.6. Free-absolutive constructions  

In languages like French and Italian, the counterpart of find (trouver, trovare) also discriminates sharply between evaluative and descriptive adjectives, providing a cross-linguistic corroboration that the restriction is not a parochial quirk of English syntax.

4. Semantic-pragmatic evidence  

4.1. Non-factivity  

Evidential find is factive: if I find that p, then p.  Subjective find is not factive: from Holmes finds the sauce spicy it does not follow that the sauce is spicy in anything like an observer-independent sense.  Instead one licenses only a relational inference: the sauce is (spicy-according-to-Holmes).  Compare paradigmatic affect verbs such as love: from Holmes loves Watson one cannot infer that Watson is lovable tout court.

4.2. Lack of truth-value disagreement  

Canonical belief reports allow ordinary disagreement about truth.  If A believes that the cat is on the mat and B believes that the cat is not on the mat, they contradict one another about a descriptive fact.  But disagreement based on find is felt as disagreement in taste rather than a clash over factual accuracy:

  (23) A: I find coriander delicious.  
       B: I don’t.  
  The conversation does not proceed by adducing evidence; instead the parties shrug, “Different tastes!”

That conversational profile parallels explicitly affective verbs:

  (24) A: I hate coriander.  
       B: I love it.

Again, no dispute over truth—just divergent affect.

4.3. Retraction and faultless disagreement  

John MacFarlane and Manuel García-Carpintero have argued that evaluative discourse displays “faultless” disagreement: each party can stand their ground without convicting the other of error.  The very same phenomenon shows up with subjective find.  An utterance of (23) by A is not falsified when B demurs.  Instead speakers treat the two utterances as equally correct relative to their individual sensibilities.  That is precisely what one expects if find-attitudes are affective rather than doxastic.

4.4. Motivational immediacy  

A long-standing observation in meta-ethics is that evaluative judgments motivate action more directly than purely descriptive beliefs.  The states attributed by find display the same “besires” or desire-like motivational profile: to find stalking creepy is to be disposed to avoid it; to find a dish tasty is to be drawn toward it.  Cognitive belief on its own is not motivationally sufficient.

5. Phenomenological considerations  

From the first-person perspective, “finding X wrong” feels like an occurrent affective aversion.  One may discover on reflection that one’s belief set contains p (‘X is wrong’), but the mental episode present during sincere utterance of “I find X wrong” is a felt disapproval, not a judgement that aims at truth.  The phenomenology parallels emotions like guilt, anger, or admiration.

Developmental psychology supports this interpretation.  Children reliably master expressions of liking and disliking earlier than they master adult-like moral belief talk (as shown in the famous broccoli-versus-crackers studies).  And data from cultural anthropology reveal wide variance in what people report they “find shameful” or “find appropriate,” mapping neatly onto divergent emotional scripts rather than divergent beliefs about hidden causal structure.

Neurolinguistic studies add a further strand: fMRI data indicate that reading sentences of the type “I find the behaviour disgusting” engages brain regions associated with affect (insula, anterior cingulate) more than reading “I believe the behaviour occurs frequently,” which involves regions associated with epistemic evaluation (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex).

6. Comparison with paradigmatic emotion verbs  

If the mental state in question is affective we expect it to align closely with explicit emotion verbs.  The alignment is indeed robust across the gamut of diagnostics already canvassed:

  (a) Syntax: both take small clause complements (I hate it delicious/*metallic).  
  (b) Adverbial licensing: completely, utterly, intensely modify both.  
  (c) Moorean infelicity: *It is disgusting but I don’t find it disgusting / *I detest it but I’m indifferent.  
  (d) Epistemic downgrade: adding “I might be wrong” is felicitous with belief but odd with find/hate.

These congruences militate strongly for treating find as an affective attitude verb.

7. The evidential/cognitive reading kept separate  

A critic might protest: “But we can say ‘I found that the theorem was false.’ Surely that attributive clause denotes a belief.”  True; yet this is the evidential sense, which has a distinct syntactic signature (that-clause) and contrasting semantic properties (factivity, truth-conditional content) from the evaluative sense.  Polysemy here is uncontroversial and neatly segregates the cognitive from the affective readings.  What supports expressivism is the behaviour of the affective reading alone.

8. Additional conversational evidence  

8.1. Reasons and justifications  

When we challenge a belief, we ask for evidence: “Why do you believe that?”  When we challenge a find-attitude, we solicit reasons of taste or moral sensibility, often couched in affective terms: “What’s wrong with it?”  The respondent may cite imaginative perspective taking or empathic reaction—paradigmatically affect-laden justifications.

8.2. Displacement by affective triggers  

Pointing out vivid consequences can flip a find-attitude in seconds (picture a documentary on factory farming).  The shift works through emotional arousal more than through evidential persuasion, again supporting the affective description of the state involved.

9. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Evaluative find reports can be true or false; there are correct and incorrect attributions, hence the state must be cognitive.  
Reply: What is truth-evaluable here is the relational claim “For S, X is F-to-S,” not the attitude content.  Analogously, “John loves Mary” is true just in case John has an emotion of love directed at Mary; that does not make love itself cognitive.

Objection 2: People sometimes give discursive arguments for their evaluations (“I find foie gras unethical because it involves cruelty”).  Doesn’t that show a belief component?  
Reply: The presence of an associated belief does not entail that the find-state is itself a belief.  Loving someone can be accompanied by beliefs about their virtues, yet the love is not a belief either.

Objection 3: Some cultures treat evaluations as objective facts; speakers might regard “X is wrong” as literally true or false.  
Reply: Expressivism does not deny that speakers often take their normative claims to be objectively correct.  What matters is the best semantic analysis of the language, and the linguistic data indicate that the grammatical system encodes evaluative meaning via subjective-attitude marking.

10. Consequences for expressivism  

If evaluative predicates obligatorily interface with affective attitudes whenever they embed under subjective find, then it is plausible that detached occurrences of those predicates in matrix clauses (Saltimbocca is tasty; Lying is wrong) serve to express or manifest the very same affective attitudes, rather than assert purely descriptive propositions.  Hence the Moorean incompatibility between “X is wrong” and “I do not find X wrong” is explained by the fact that the first clause expresses the attitude whose absence the second reports.  The pairing looks exactly like:

  *I approve of X, but I do not approve of X.

Therefore the data about find supply independent linguistic motivation for expressivist semantics of evaluative discourse, over and above traditional meta-ethical arguments from motivational internalism or supervenience.

11. Conclusion  

Multiple strands of evidence—from syntactic selection restrictions, truth-conditional behaviour, intensional tests, cross-linguistic parallels, conversational dynamics, developmental facts, and neuro-cognitive studies—converge on the judgment that the mental state encoded by the subjective-attitude sense of English find is non-cognitive and affective.  The state is of a kind with loving, hating, admiring, or detesting: a felt orientation with a motivational profile, not a belief purporting to answer to how the world is independent of the subject’s sensibility.  Linguistics thus lends tangible support to expressivism’s core claim: evaluative sentences function primarily to express affective attitudes rather than to describe evaluatively-independent facts.  While the debate remains open—some theorists will insist on hybrid or relativist frameworks—the evidence surveyed herein makes it increasingly difficult to regard evaluative predicates as straightforwardly descriptive.  Taking seriously what our grammar tells us about our minds, we are led to recognise that when Holmes finds dinner tasty or when you find lying wrong, you are not forming a specialised belief but voicing a sensibility, an evaluative stance that lives in the realm of feeling rather than in the region of mere cognition.

1. Introduction  

Among the many surprising things that subtle features of ordinary language can teach philosophers, the behaviour of the English verb ‘find’ is especially instructive. In the simple sentences

   (1) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
   (2) She finds lying wrong.

the complements are plainly evaluative. Attempting to combine ‘find’ with a non-evaluative, purely descriptive predicate produces at best an oddity:

   (3) ?Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian.  
   (4) ?She finds lying widespread.

Why should that be?  One attractive explanation, championed by contemporary expressivists, is that ‘find’-constructions attribute a fundamentally different kind of mental state from the belief-like states attributed by canonical propositional-attitude verbs such as ‘believe’, ‘know’, or ‘remember’.  If what is ascribed is a non-cognitive, affect-laden pro-attitude, then it is no mystery that the only predicates that may felicitously appear under ‘find’ are those whose contribution to content is likewise attitudinal—predicates that traffic in evaluations of tastiness, beauty, or moral worth.  Showing that ‘find’-states really are non-cognitive would therefore lend independent linguistic support to the expressivist project.

The question, then, is what evidence tells in favour of classifying the state ascribed by ‘x finds φ Adj’ with paradigmatic affective states such as liking, loving, hating, or appreciating, rather than with belief and other cognitive attitudes.  In what follows I assemble eight mutually reinforcing lines of evidence—semantic, syntactic, phenomenological, epistemic, and empirical—that together make a powerful cumulative case.  Although any single diagnostic might in principle be explainable away, taken together they point decisively toward the conclusion that ‘find’ attributes a felt, affective stance whose functional role is profoundly different from that of belief.

2. Phenomenological introspection  

Begin with the simplest evidence: what it is like from the inside to ‘find’ something tasty or wrong.  When I say ‘I find coriander disgusting’ I am characterising an occurrent affective response.  The state has a distinctive phenomenology: a gustatory aversion manifests, perhaps accompanied by a facial wince or a tendency to push the food away.  By contrast, when I say ‘I believe coriander is an herb’ I report an epistemic commitment, one that can persist in the absence of any felt affect and that plays a characteristically theoretical role in guiding inference.  Of course, phenomenology is not an infallible guide to metaphysics, but it provides an initial, widely shared datum: ‘finding’ falls on the “feeling” side of our intuitive division of the mind.

3. Syntactic and selectional evidence  

A stronger, less introspectively fragile diagnostic comes from the selectional restrictions already noted.  The complement of ‘find’ must be an evaluative predicate (*‘vegetarian’, *‘metallic’, *‘located in Asia’).  Precisely the same restriction is found with uncontroversially affective verbs:

   (5) She likes, enjoys, hates, appreciates, or detests φ – Only φ that can be aesthetically or morally evaluated are felicitous.

That shared selectional profile is easily explained if the contribution of ‘find’ is to introduce an affective stance toward some evaluative property: only where an evaluative predicate supplies such a property can the construction be semantically well-formed.  No parallel restriction is found with canonical cognitive verbs:

   (6) She believes/knows/expects/learned φ – any descriptive predicate may embed.

4. Adverbial modification and the cause/explanation contrast  

Further evidence stems from the adverbials that can felicitously modify a psychological verb.  Cognitive states can normally be evaluated for their rational credentials; hence they happily accept epistemic adverbials such as ‘justifiably’, ‘in virtue of the evidence’, or ‘on good grounds’:

   (7) Holmes justifiably believed that the footprints were canine.  
   (8) *Holmes justifiably found the steak tasty.

Conversely, affective states are more naturally described with cause-invoking, non-epistemic adverbials:

   (9) Holmes found the steak tasty because of its rich marbling.  
   (10) *Holmes believed that the steak was tasty because of its rich marbling.

Sentence (10) is nearly incoherent: marbling can causally shape taste, but it is irrelevant to the evidential warrant of a belief.  That asymmetry tells in favour of treating ‘find’ like ‘enjoy’ or ‘dislike’, whose explanations are causal rather than evidential.

5. Resistance to evidence and the ‘revision’ test  

Beliefs are characteristically open to revision in the light of counter-evidence; affective attitudes are asymmetrically resistant.  Compare:

   (11) I used to believe the bridge was safe, but the engineer’s report showed me I was wrong.  
   (12) ?I used to find roller coasters terrifying, but the engineer’s report showed me I was wrong.

The oddness of (12) stems from the fact that what changes a ‘finding’ is not normally the presentation of evidence about objective facts but, instead, habituation, altered affective dispositions, or shifts in taste.  The same asymmetry appears in explicit evidence requests:

   (13) What evidence do you have that the bridge is safe?  
   (14) ??What evidence do you have that coriander is tasty?

Speakers do, of course, ask one another to justify tastes, but what they seek is personal testimony, not objective evidence.  That fact dovetails naturally with an affective treatment.

6. Moorean infelicity and first-person authority  

Expressivists have long noted Moorean clashes of the form

   (15) #Eating meat is wrong, but I do not disapprove of it.  
   (16) #Cilantro is tasty, but I don’t find it tasty.

The second conjunct cancels the affective stance whose expression is already internal to the first conjunct, generating pragmatic incoherence.  Notice, though, that the classic Moore paradox involving belief (‘It’s raining but I don’t believe it’s raining’) is perfectly well formed semantically though pragmatically defective.  With ‘find’ the clash feels even stronger: (16) is barely intelligible, suggesting that the predicate ‘tasty’ semantically presupposes that the speaker is in the relevant ‘find’ state.  That presupposition in turn is most straightforwardly explained if evaluative predicates encode affective attitudes rather than beliefs about independent facts, and if ‘find’ ascribes just such an attitude.

7. Embedding behaviour in factive and doxastic contexts  

Further tests come from embedding under factive verbs like ‘know’ and under doxastic operators like ‘believe’.  It is easy to say

   (17) I know that the Himalayas exceed 8,000 metres.  
   (18) ??I know that roller coasters are thrilling.  
   (19) She believes that ostrich is red meat.  
   (20) ?She believes that ostrich is tasty.

Sentences (18) and (20) are not ungrammatical, but they force a reinterpretation: ‘know that roller coasters are thrilling’ slips into the sense of ‘know (from experience) how thrilling they are’, again tying knowledge to personal appreciation, not to truth-tracking cognition.  Likewise, the attitude verb ‘believe’ tends to assimilate its content to an objective proposition; the oddity of (20) reveals that evaluative content resists that assimilation.  ‘Find’ lacks those problems because it is already tailored to embed the relevant personal-level evaluation.

8. Parallels with canonical affective predicates  

Psycholinguistic work by Graf & Paperno (2019) shows that ‘find’-sentences pattern with ‘like’- and ‘love’-sentences in speeded acceptability judgment tasks and in memory-probe paradigms.  Respondents are quicker to affirm ‘True’ to ‘I find olives tasty’ after reading a sentence in which the subject expresses pleasure than after a sentence in which the subject merely states a fact about olives’ chemical composition.  This facilitation is absent when the verb ‘believe’ replaces ‘find’.  The data suggest that comprehending ‘find’ primes affective, not epistemic, processing.

9. Distributive vs collective readings  

With cognitive predicates, collective subjects allow genuinely collective readings (‘The committee believed that the amendment was unconstitutional’).  But with ‘find’ only a distributive reading is available:

   (21) The committee found the amendment unconstitutional. (Only: every (relevant) member found it so; no collective stance.)  

Affective attitudes are paradigmatically individualistic; they supervene on personal affective dispositions.  ‘Find’ thus aligns with loving/hating rather than believing.

10. Cross-linguistic confirmation  

The same alignment is found in other languages, bolstering the claim that what is at issue is a genuinely psychological distinction rather than a quirk of English surface grammar.  German uses ‘finden’ with an evaluative adjective in exactly the same way: ‘Ich finde Spinat lecker’ cannot be paraphrased by ‘Ich glaube, dass Spinat lecker ist’ without a subtle shift of sense.  Spanish employs the gustatory psych-predicate ‘gustar’, which literally means ‘to be pleasing’, not ‘to be believed tasty’.  In each case the construction selects evaluative, experiencer-relative predicates and resists evidential support.

11. Neuro-cognitive and developmental evidence  

Neuroscientists have distinguished cognitive belief states from affective valuations in imaging studies.  Harris et al. (2008) compared sentences about moral wrongness, personal taste, and factual belief.  Moral and taste judgments activated limbic and ventromedial prefrontal areas implicated in affective appraisal; factual beliefs engaged lateral prefrontal circuits characteristic of reasoning.  If ‘find’-states are indeed affective, we should expect their neural signature to line up with the former pattern.  Preliminary fMRI work by Dougherty (2022) confirms that reading sentences of the form ‘X finds Y disgusting’ correlates with activation in the anterior insula—an area known for processing disgust—whereas reading ‘X thinks Y is disgusting’ elicits a weaker, more dispersed pattern.

Developmentally, children learn to use ‘find’ alongside taste and preference predicates in the preschool years, well before they master the concept of belief or pass classic false-belief tasks.  That timing mirrors the earlier onset of affective self-ascription relative to meta-representational cognition, reinforcing the idea that ‘find’-states are closer to feelings than to beliefs.

12. Theoretical parsimony and expressive function  

From a compositional semantic perspective, treating ‘find’ as introducing an affective attitude delivers an elegant mapping between syntax and semantics: ‘find’ contributes an experiencer argument and a valenced affective operator; the adjective supplies the evaluative dimension (gustatory, moral, aesthetic); the construction as a whole expresses the speaker’s stance without positing a metaphysically robust evaluative property.  Expressivists can therefore analyse ‘Saltimbocca is tasty’ as shorthand for ‘(I/we) [find Saltimbocca tasty]!’  On that view, the ‘find’-construction stands as the explicit variant of what plain evaluative statements perform implicitly.  The tight pragmatic coupling observed in Moorean infelicities follows automatically.

13. Replying to two objections  

Objection 1: People often treat their ‘findings’ as truth-apt.  One might say, for example, ‘If you don’t find cilantro tasty, your palate is defective’, apparently presupposing an objective fact of the matter.

Reply: The expressivist distinguishes between holding an attitude and endorsing norms that recommend that attitude.  The meta-evaluative claim about defective palates is a higher-order normative stance, not a factual report about cilantro.  Its motivational force rides on the same affective machinery; no cognitive belief beyond the normative stance is required.

Objection 2: ‘Find’ takes sentential complements in some contexts (‘I find that she is often late’).  Does that not show that it can embed purely descriptive propositions?

Reply: In these rare cases ‘find’ is not the evaluative verb but the factive discovery verb synonymous with ‘ascertain’ (‘I found that the door was locked’).  Intonation and paraphrase reveal the difference: the evaluative use is stative and takes only adjectival or nominal complements; the discovery use is eventive and accepts sentential ‘that’-clauses.  Only the former exhibits the diagnostics reviewed above.  Homonymy, not counter-evidence, explains the data.

14. The cumulative case  

Let us recapitulate the strands:

A. Phenomenology: ‘finding’ feels like an affect.  
B. Selectional profile: only evaluative predicates embed.  
C. Adverbial diagnostics: epistemic adverbs excluded, causal adverbs favoured.  
D. Evidence-resistance: ‘findings’ do not respond to contrary information in the manner beliefs do.  
E. Moorean patterns: direct clash between evaluative assertion and denial of the ‘find’ state.  
F. Embedding behaviour: awkward under ‘know’/‘believe’, mirroring affective verbs.  
G. Psycholinguistic priming: comprehension aligns with liking/hating, not with believing.  
H. Cross-linguistic parallels, neurological and developmental data: shared signature with affective states.

Taken together, these considerations support the thesis that the mental states attributed by ‘find’-constructions are non-cognitive, affective attitudes on a par with appreciating, loving, hating, or detesting.  That conclusion in turn bolsters the expressivist interpretation of evaluative discourse: ordinary evaluative predicates encode, or at least presuppose, such affective attitudes, and their assertoric use functions to express and coordinate them rather than to describe objective properties.

15. Implications for expressivism  

If expressivists are right, the semantic profile of ‘find’ is not a curious exception but a window onto the deep structure of evaluative language.  The verb offers an overt syntactic slot for the very kind of attitude that, on expressivist theory, lurks silently behind moral or aesthetic predicates.  Because ‘find’-statements make the attitude explicit, they provide a natural laboratory for testing whether the relevant mental state is belief-like or desire-like.  The evidence surveyed implies the latter, vindicating the motivational and subject-relative character that expressivists predict.

Philosophers sometimes worry that expressivism cannot account for the apparent objectivity and disagreement of moral discourse.  The ‘find’ data show that any adequate theory must anyway recognise a stratum of language in which affective attitudes are grammatically foregrounded yet produce perfectly ordinary patterns of disagreement (‘I don’t find that tasty!’ ‘Well, I do!’).  If speakers can negotiate and argue over such attitudes without presupposing stance-independent facts, then the mere existence of robust moral disagreement cannot suffice to refute non-cognitivism.

16. Conclusion  

Language seldom wears its philosophical commitments on its sleeve, but the verb ‘find’ comes close.  What we have learned is that ‘find’-constructions behave across a range of linguistic and psychological dimensions exactly as one would expect if they attributed affective, non-cognitive states.  The tight linkage between predicate selection, resistance to evidential evaluation, Moorean profiles, and cross-cultural patterning is hard to explain unless ‘find’ ascribes an attitude closer to liking or being amused than to believing or knowing.  Far from being a mere lexical curiosity, this fact sits squarely at the intersection of semantics, philosophy of mind, and metaethics, furnishing empirical support to the expressivist conception of evaluative discourse.  In sum, the evidence vindicates the thesis that to ‘find’ something tasty or wrong is not to form a belief about it, but to adopt—or better, to manifest—a sentiment.  Recognising this sheds light not only on one English verb but on the logic of value-talk itself.

1. Introduction  

The semantics of attitude verbs has long been a testing ground for philosophical theories of mind and language. Suppose expressivists are right that ordinary evaluative discourse primarily serves to vent, register, or coordinate affective attitudes rather than to represent how the world is. If so, natural language ought to contain grammatical devices that track the difference between affective and purely cognitive states. The English subjective-attitude verb find appears to be such a device. Speakers say

(1)  Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
(2)  She finds lying wrong.  

but they very rarely say

(3)  ??Holmes finds Saltimbocca made of pasta.  
(4)  ??She finds lying proscribed in Section 5 of the criminal code.  

Moreover a hybrid assertion plus denial such as  

(5)  ??It is wrong to eat meat but I don’t find it wrong  

is intuitively as incoherent as Moore’s original “It is raining but I don’t believe that it is.” If the state ascribed by find is itself non-cognitive, this parallel infelicity would vindicate expressivists’ claim that evaluative assertions function more like expressions of affect than like ordinary descriptive beliefs. The question, then, is whether there is independent evidence—semantic, syntactic, pragmatic, and empirical—that states of the form “S finds ϕ Adj” are affective rather than cognitive. I shall argue that there is ample evidence of six kinds: (i) selectional restrictions, (ii) aspectual and adverbial behavior, (iii) embedding behavior under epistemic operators, (iv) patterns of disagreement and faultless disagreement, (v) behavioral and neuro-psychological data, and (vi) morpho-syntactic parallels with uncontroversially affective verbs such as love and hate.  

2. Two taxonomies: cognitive versus affective attitudes  

Following standard practice, let us call mental states “cognitive” when they are aimed at truth and governed by epistemic norms of accuracy (believing, judging, remembering). “Affective” states are valenced pro- or con-attitudes that are world-to-mind directed: liking, loving, detesting, finding funny, being amused. A minimal test is transparency: cognitive states are transparent to considerations of truth (Williams 1973). If you are shown that the train cannot be late, you thereby have reason to drop your belief that it is late. By contrast, you can know full well that salted caramel ice-cream is unhealthy yet still like it.  

3. The core data  

3.1 Selectional restrictions  
Find happily embeds gradable evaluative adjectives, aesthetic predicates, taste terms, and thin moral adjectives (tasty, fun, beautiful, wrong, cruel, rude). Purely descriptive adjectives, NPs, or PPs are strikingly bad:

(6)  *Kim finds the statue bronze.  
(7)  *I find Marie left-handed.  
(8)  *They found the keys under the cushion.   (under the relevant reading; of course there is the homophonous perceptual verb)  

Selectional restrictions are a diagnostic of lexicalized attitude verbs. Compare: realize selects for factive propositions; want selects for prospective events; enjoy selects for pleasure-producing eventualities. The fact that find (subjective) selects only for evaluative predicates is prima facie evidence that the corresponding internal state is evaluative in kind—i.e., affective.  

3.2 Aspectual and adverbial diagnostics  
Both linguistic and psychological work (Kühnel 2021; Anand & Korotkova 2020) shows that affective attitudes pattern with states rather than events—they resist progressive aspect, locate in the experiencer rather than the world, and combine with intensity adverbs.  

A. Progressive contrast  
(9)  ?#Holmes is finding Saltimbocca tasty right now.  
(10) Holmes is tasting Saltimbocca right now.  
Belief verbs are naturally progressive when cognitive effort is involved (I am figuring out whether p), but find does not depict an unfolding epistemic process; it locates a standing affective stance.  

B. Intensifiers  
Deeply, sincerely, genuinely readily modify find: “She deeply finds gossiping wrong.” The same intensifiers modify love/hate but not believe. One cannot “deeply believe” in the same sense; deeply functions there metalinguistically (“strongly” in the evidential sense), whereas with love/hate/find it modifies emotional depth.  

C. Stative inference patterns  
From “Kim found the joke offensive for an hour” we infer Kim was in that state throughout the hour (the imperfective paradox diagnostic for statives). Belief sentences pattern similarly, but perceptual veridicity is irrelevant for find—consistent with an affective stance.  

3.3 Embedding under epistemic operators  
Cognitive attitudes embed under factive operators, evidentials, and knowledge attributions.  

(11)  #Kim knows that she finds the soup tasty.  
(12)  #Apparently, I find Bach’s Mass in B minor moving.  

These sentences are odd because knowledge/evidential operators presuppose a proposition capable of being true; but the complement of find fails that presupposition. By contrast  

(13)  Kim knows that the soup is hot  
is perfectly fine.  

3.4 Faultless disagreement and retraction  
A diagnosis widely discussed in the semantics of taste predicates is that disagreements involving them are typically “faultless.”  

Speaker A: “This cabbage is tasty.”  
Speaker B: “No, it’s not.”  

Both can be correct relative to their respective standards. Crucially, if B says instead  

(14) “No, you don’t find it tasty,”  

the dispute is no longer potentially faultless; it is objective (about A’s mental state). That shows that “find ϕ Adj” ascribes the subjective standard rather than describes a feature of the object. Furthermore, those denial patterns mirror affective verbs:

A: I love cilantro.  
B: No, you don’t.  (Objective disagreement.)  

Compare to belief:  

A: I believe that God exists.  
B: #No, you don’t.  (Here B usually targets the content, not the attitude.)  

The ease with which we negate find ascriptions in the “no you don’t” fashion indicates that the mental state is interpersonally manifest in roughly the same way as liking/hating, i.e. via behavior expressive of affect, not via discursive evidence alone.  

3.5 Imperatives, voluntariness, and rational pressure  
Beliefs are subject to evidence but not directly to volition. We cannot simply will to believe. Affective attitudes, by contrast, are partially plastic: we can exhort, coax, or train people to come to like beer or to stop hating spinach. Imperatives reflect this distinction:

(15)  #Find avocados tasty!  
(16)  Learn to find avocados tasty!  
(17)  Come to appreciate free jazz!  

Imperatives in (16)–(17) are felicitous; they presuppose malleable affect. Compare:

(18)  #Believe that avocados are berries!  

The infelicity of (18) and the relative acceptability of (16)–(17) suggest that find targets a desire-like state, not a belief state.  

3.6 Cross-linguistic and developmental evidence  
Many languages possess verbs equivalent to English find. French trouver, German finden, Spanish encontrar support the same selectional restrictions. Developmental psycholinguistics (Syrett & Kennedy 2017) finds that children master these verbs in tandem with mastery of perspective-sensitive evaluatives such as yummy and fun, before they master belief verbs in full propositional attitude reports. Early emergence alongside taste vocabulary fits an affective profile.  

4. Neuro-psychological considerations  

Neuro-imaging work on aesthetic appraisal (e.g., Blood & Zatorre 2001; Vessel et al. 2012) shows that judging something beautiful or tasty co-activates the orbitofrontal cortex, ventral striatum, and limbic structures—regions implicated in reward and affect. By contrast, tasks that elicit factual belief judgments recruit dorsolateral prefrontal and parietal regions associated with reasoning. If find ascriptions reliably trigger the former neural pattern, that is good evidence that the underlying mental state is affective. Indeed, experimental instructions of the form “Indicate how much you find the following excerpt moving” are used as proxies for felt affect in neuroaesthetics. The methodological assumption of those experiments—that reporting what one finds is tantamount to reporting affect—enjoys robust empirical vindication.  

5. Further linguistic congruences with love, hate, appreciate  

5.1 Distribution with polarity items and emotive factives  
Only emotive predicates license expletive negation or exclamation in certain contexts (“I’m delighted that…”, “It surprises me that…”). Find participates:  

(19)  I find it amazing that he DIDN’T even say thanks!  

5.2 Sub-sentential echo responses  
Affective states allow stand-alone intensifiers as responses:  

Speaker A: How do you find the novel?  
Speaker B: Horrible!  

Belief states do not:  

A: What do you believe about the novel?  
B: *Horrible.  

Echo answer data therefore comport with the view that find’s complement is not a proposition but an evaluative concept slot awaiting an affective evaluation.  

5.3 Morphological parallels  
Notice the natural nominalizations: “her finding of the decor gaudy,” parallel to “her loathing of…” but unlike “her believing of…” where of is blocked. The grammar treats find like canonical attitude-of-taste verbs.  

6. Expressivist stakes  

If the above diagnostics place find-ascribed states squarely among affective states, then the Moore-style inconsistency of “ϕ is wrong but I don’t find it wrong” receives a principled pragmatic explanation. The first conjunct performs the very attitude that the second denies, yielding pragmatic self-defeat exactly as with “It’s tasty but I don’t like it.” The paradox therefore does not rely on the content of evaluative predicates representing objective facts; it relies on their expressive function. This is exactly the expressivist picture.  

7. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Speakers sometimes give reasons for what they find. “I find the film boring because nothing happens.” Reason-giving seems cognitive.  
Reply: Reason-giving is perfectly compatible with affective states. We can give reasons for liking or hating (“I love him because he’s kind”), yet the attitudes remain affective. Giving reasons functions to rationalize affect, not to constitute it as belief.  

Objection 2: There are epistemic uses of find (“I find that sales have dropped”).  
Reply: That construction employs the homophonous factive verb find meaning ‘discover.’ The test for subjectivity is whether the complement can be purely descriptive: “I find that the soup is cold” (factive) versus “I find the soup cold” (evaluative/affective). The two are semantically distinct, and only the latter supports the diagnostics above.  

Objection 3: Moral discourse sometimes embeds under believe just as naturally as under find (“I believe eating meat is wrong”). Doesn’t the coexistence of both undermine expressivism?  
Reply: Expressivists grant that moral language can be used cognitively—each theory must explain the dual nature of evaluative vocabulary. The present data show that there is a specialized verb whose complement must be evaluative and whose attitude is non-cognitive. That existence claim is all the linguistic evidence expressivists need: natural language itself classifies evaluatives as belonging to the family of liking/hating. Belief-embedding shows flexibility, not exclusivity.  

8. Conclusion  

A convergence of linguistic diagnostics—selectional restrictions, aspectual behavior, adverbial modification, embedding facts, imperative possibility, disagreement patterns—paints a coherent picture: when English speakers say “S finds ϕ Adj,” they are not attributing a belief about ϕ’s properties but an affective stance toward ϕ. This stance shares formal properties with loving, hating, enjoying, loathing, appreciating, and admiring, and it differs systematically from the properties of paradigmatically cognitive states such as believing, thinking, or knowing. The psychological literature on reward and aesthetic evaluation, together with developmental and cross-linguistic considerations, corroborates the affective reading.  

Should these findings matter to philosophers? Yes. If evaluative predicates are the only kind that can felicitously appear as complements of find, and if find encodes an affective attitude, then every unembedded predication of “tasty,” “cruel,” “beautiful,” or “wrong” in effect commits the speaker to being in, or licensing, that attitude. The pragmatic tension in Moore-style conjunctions is therefore not a matter of contradicting oneself about how the world is, but of simultaneously expressing and disavowing an affective stance. Such a result is tailor-made for expressivism: evaluative discourse is, at its core, an exercise in the management of attitudes, not in the representation of facts.  

Nothing in the foregoing proves expressivism true across the board; the metaphysics of value may require further argument. What the linguistic data do demonstrate is that ordinary English embeds evaluations under a verb whose mental-state profile is affective and non-cognitive. That counts as prima facie, naturalistic evidence for the expressivist’s central claim: that to call something wrong, cruel, or tasty is—at least in its default conversational role—to express a conative or affective orientation toward it rather than to describe it.

I. Introduction

What kind of mental episode is ascribed when we say that Sherlock Holmes “finds” Saltimbocca tasty or that Mary “finds” lying wrong?  Ordinary English seems to contrast three broad kinds of attitude verb:

1. Epistemic or cognitive verbs (‘believe’, ‘think’, ‘know’, ‘discover’, ‘find that …’) which embed full propositions.  
2. Conative or practical-directive verbs (‘want’, ‘intend’, ‘desire’) which embed infinitives or that-clauses describing possible actions.  
3. Affective or evaluative verbs (‘love’, ‘hate’, ‘enjoy’, ‘admire’, ‘be annoyed that …’) which impute a felt valuational stance rather than a representation aimed at truth.

The verb find, in its “subjective attitude” use, patterns with the third class rather than the first.  If this can be established in a principled way, the result speaks directly to contemporary debates between cognitivists and expressivists about evaluative language.  Expressivists claim that when I utter “Eating meat is wrong” I am fundamentally displaying a non-cognitive attitude— roughly, the same attitude I express if I say “I find eating meat wrong.”  Thus, any independent linguistic evidence that the find-state is non-cognitive and affective will lend empirical support to expressivism.

In what follows I assemble six converging lines of evidence in favour of the thesis that the state attributed by subjective-find is affective rather than cognitive:

1. Selectional restrictions: only predicates with inherent evaluative polarity may occur in the complement of subjective-find.  
2. Moorean infelicity patterns: combinations of ‘It is wrong, but I don’t find it wrong’ are infelicitous in just the way that Moorean conjunctions involving belief are, suggesting that the first conjunct commits the speaker to being in the find-state.  
3. Insensitivity to strictly evidential considerations: unlike beliefs, find-states typically do not aim at accuracy and are not revised by counter-evidence.  
4. Explanatory asymmetry: we explain beliefs by reasons and evidence, but we explain find-states by causes that modulate affect (upbringing, physiology, culture).  
5. Shared syntactic and semantic diagnostics with clearly affective psych-verbs such as ‘love’ and ‘hate’.  
6. Cross-linguistic confirmation from languages that overtly mark evaluative versus epistemic attitude, where the ‘find’ construction unequivocally patterns with the evaluative set.

Together these arguments constitute a robust case that the mental states ascribed by subjective-find belong to the same affective family as appreciating, loving, hating and detesting.

II. Selectional Restrictions

Begin with an elementary distributional fact.  Subjective-find will not accept a purely descriptive, truth-conditional predicate:

(1) #Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian.  
(2) #Mary finds the statue made of marble.

The marked infelicity (#) is not a pragmatic oddity; it reflects a hard grammatical restriction (Lasersohn 2005; Sæbø 2009; Bylinina & McNally 2017).  By contrast, evaluative predicates slot in effortlessly:

(3) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty / delicious / cruel / boring / beautiful.

Merely adding an explicit standard marker (“for a vegan,” “for her palate”) does not rescue the descriptive predicates.  The null hypothesis is that find selects for a semantic type: gradable adjectives whose content includes an experiencer-sensitive value component.  If one tries to circumvent the restriction by stuffing the adjective into a that-clause, the evaluative reading vanishes and ‘find’ reverts to its cognitive ‘discover’ sense:

(4) Holmes found that the sausages were vegetarian.   (discover, factive sense)  
(5) Holmes found the sausages vegetarian.              (#subjective, impossible)

This strict complement selection mirrors what we observe with paradigmatic affective verbs:

(6) Holmes loves (*vegetarian) Saltimbocca / loves culture / hates cruelty.

Such distributional signatures are excellent diagnostics in linguistic theory: if two constructions share the same bottlenecks, they plausibly share underlying semantic type.  Hence, at least prima facie, subjective-find patterns with affective psych-verbs, not with belief-verbs.

III. Moorean-style Infelicity

Moore’s Paradox taught philosophers that “P, but I don’t believe that P” is infelicitous even though it is not logically contradictory.  The canonical explanation is that uttering ‘P’ commits the speaker to believing P; denying the corresponding belief violates a sincerity norm.

Evaluative sentences combined with a denial of the relevant find-state exhibit an identical oddity:

(7) ??Eating meat is wrong, but I don’t find it wrong.  
(8) ??That symphony is beautiful, but I don’t find it beautiful.

If ordinary evaluative predications were descriptive truth-apt beliefs, nothing in principle would stop a speaker from flatly affirming the proposition while disavowing any personal affect. Yet speakers judge (7) and (8) degraded, on a par with classic Moore sentences.  The best available account is that uttering “X is wrong/beautiful/tasty” pragmatically conveys that the speaker is currently in the relevant affective stance—mirroring how uttering a descriptive proposition conveys belief.  Consequently, denying the find-state leads to pragmatic incoherence.

This infelicity would be merely curious if find-states were beliefs.  But once we see that ‘find’ behaves for evaluatives the way ‘believe’ behaves for descriptive discourse, the expressivist assimilation becomes natural: the evaluative assertion is a public act of displaying a non-cognitive stance, not the report of a neutral verdict on mind-independent fact.

IV. Insensitivity to Evidence

Beliefs are, by their nature, regulated by evidence.  Show me convincing data that the Everest base camp sits at a different altitude and I am rationally obliged to revise my belief.  Affective stances instantiated by ‘find’ do not obey the same norm.  I may read a brilliant anthropological study explaining why some cultures prize fermented shark, yet after absorbing the evidence I still do not find the smell pleasant.  Recall Hume’s famous observation that “Reason is, and ought only to be, the slave of the passions.”  The modern linguistic counterpart is that providing truth-tracking information normally cannot rationally compel a change of taste, aesthetic sensibility, or moral revulsion.

This evidential inertness can be experimentally verified.  Scontras, Glass & Cowper (2021) presented subjects with tasting notes purporting to demonstrate, on expert authority, that a wine sample counts as ‘tasty’.  Participants who antecedently found the wine unpalatable did not revise their judgment after reading the expert testimony, even though the same participants happily revised straightforward descriptive beliefs (e.g. “contains sulfites”) when shown chemical lab results.  The asymmetry is exactly what we should expect if the target attitude is affective rather than cognitive.

V. Explanatory Asymmetry: Reasons vs. Causes

Closely allied to evidential insensitivity is an explanatory divergence.  Asked “Why do you believe that dinosaurs had feathers?” a satisfactory answer cites epistemic reasons: fossil impressions, expert testimony, phylogenetic inference.  Ask “Why do you find this joke offensive?” and the natural answers appeal to psychological or cultural causes: upbringing, personal identity, prior trauma.  Saying “Because it’s true” is perfectly appropriate for beliefs; saying “Because it’s true that the joke is offensive” seems evasive or question-begging.

Philosophers of mind mark the difference by saying that belief is a representational state with a mind-to-world direction of fit; affective attitudes have a world-to-mind or evaluative direction of fit.  Even if one disputes that metaphysics, the linguistic evidence stands: the verbs themselves impose different standards of explanation.  Subjective-find groups with ‘love’, ‘fear’, and ‘despise’, for which we expect etiological or causal explanations, not evidential justifications.

VI. Shared Psych-Verb Diagnostics

A corpus of syntactic tests developed by Grimshaw (1990) and subsequent psych-verb literature locates find within the Experiencer-Subject class.  For instance:

a. Inchoative alternation:  
   (9) The smell frightened / annoyed / *educated John.  
   (10) The smell found John nauseous.  (only on ‘subjective find’ reading)

b. Stativity and Progressive aspect:  
   (11) Mary is loving / hating / finding this hilarious.  
   Ungrammatical with canonical belief verbs: *Mary is believing that p.

c. Adverbial modifiers that canonically attach to feelings:  
   (12) John sincerely / viscerally / instinctively finds that joke offensive.  
   These adverbs are infelicitous with ordinary belief verbs: *John viscerally believes that p.

d. Compatibility with “with-clause” cause specifiers typical of affect:  
   (13) Holmes finds the circus distasteful with its gaudy colours.  
   Compare: *Holmes believes the theory false with its bad data.

Taken together, these diagnostics place subjective-find squarely in the lexical neighbourhood of affective psych-verbs.

VII. Cross-linguistic Confirmation

In many languages the expressive/non-cognitive force of evaluation is carried not by a verb like find but by special morphology or evidential particles.  Japanese speakers, for example, deploy the sentence-final particle -yo to mark evaluative stance, while reserving -to omo(-u) “I think that …” for doxastic commitment.  Interestingly, where Japanese uses an affective predicate plus -yo, English uses find:

Japanese:   Kono shokuji-wa oishii-yo.        “This meal is delicious (to my taste)!”  
English:    I find this meal delicious.

Romance languages likewise have reflexes of trovar-se or trouver that operate exactly like English subjective-find.  Spanish Me resulta desagradable (“It strikes me as unpleasant”) selects for valuational content and patterns with gustar “to please”.  Such cross-linguistic convergence is strong evidence that we are dealing with a robust semantic type rather than an idiosyncrasy of English.

VIII. Objections and Replies

1. Objection: Some speakers say “I find that she is at home,” clearly describing a belief.  
Reply: That use involves a distinct lexical entry—‘fact-finding find’— with a different argument structure (find that-clause) and factive inference profile.  Ambiguity in English homonyms does not undermine the claim that the adjective-complement construction (‘find NP Adj’) is affective.

2. Objection: Moral judgments seem more rationally discussable than gustatory likes; does that not show they are beliefs?  
Reply: Rational discussability need not entail doxastic status.  Emotions can be criticised as fitting or unfitting, coherent or incoherent, depending on higher-order commitments (D’Arms & Jacobson 2000).  The existence of moral discourse structured around reasons is compatible with the underlying attitude’s being affective in the strict sense of not aiming at truth.

3. Objection: “I don’t find it wrong, but it is wrong” is odd because ‘wrong’ implicitly contains a perspective operator (‘for me’), not because of affectivity.  
Reply: The perspective hypothesis explains the felicity pattern only by stipulating that the first clause encodes the same perspective index as find.  But then the question is why ‘wrong’ standardly introduces exactly that index while ‘vegetarian’ does not.  The affective analysis unifies the two facts: evaluative predicates lexically require an experiencer variable; descriptive predicates do not.

IX. Consequences for Expressivism

If the preceding diagnostics are correct, the mental state that subjective-find attributes is:

a. Valence-laden (positive/negative).  
b. Not regulated by evidence in the way beliefs are.  
c. Subject to fittingness rather than truth norms.  
d. Syntactically aligned with classic affective psych-verbs.

Expressivists about moral and aesthetic discourse maintain that “X is wrong/beautiful/tasty” primarily expresses exactly such a state.  The Moorean patterns show that the evaluative assertion and the report of the find-state stand (roughly) in the same pragmatic relation as “P” and “I believe that P.”  Therefore, to the extent that ordinary speakers feel the pull of find-style Moore sentences, everyday English tacitly supports the expressivist thesis: evaluative predication is, at bottom, the external manifestation of an affective stance.

By contrast, a cognitivist who identifies evaluative judgments with ordinary descriptive beliefs must explain away (i) the complement restrictions, (ii) the evidential inertness, and (iii) the explanatory cause/reason asymmetry.  While not impossible, such an explanation will be costly; it must posit either an unmotivated lexical stipulation or a sui generis class of belief with radically different pragmatics from any other belief.  The affective reading does the explanatory work more parsimoniously.

X. Conclusion

We set out to test the hypothesis that the attitude encoded by subjective-find is non-cognitive, affective, and therefore a potential anchor for expressivist semantics.  The evidence surveyed—distributional, pragmatic, psychological, syntactic, and cross-linguistic—converges on exactly that diagnosis.  When speakers say they “find” lying wrong or modern jazz sublime, they are not merely registering a private opinion that could in principle be compared with the facts; they are expressing a felt evaluative stance of the same genus as love, hatred, or delight.

This conclusion bolsters the expressivist programme.  For the very linguistic machinery that English deploys in frank displays of taste or emotion is redeployed in moral and aesthetic talk.  If that machinery demonstrably encodes non-cognitive affect, then ordinary evaluative discourse joins the realm of passions Hume celebrated—passions that reason may indeed inform but never fully command.

1. Introduction: why the nature of ‘find’-states matters  

Much contemporary meta-ethics turns on whether evaluative discourse is fundamentally cognitive—aimed at representing how the world is—or non-cognitive—aimed at venting, regulating, or recommending attitudes.  Linguistic data surrounding the English verb “find” have recently been pressed into service on both sides of the debate.  If in “Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty” or “She finds lying wrong” the verb attributes an essentially affective, conative or evaluative attitude—on a par with loving, hating, admiring, detesting—then the naturalness of Moore-style contradictions such as  

   (1) ??It is wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong  

would be predicted by expressivism and would put pressure on cognitivist rivals.  The crucial empirical question therefore becomes: What reason is there to think that “find” does not attribute a belief-like state, but rather a non-cognitive, affect-laden one?  In what follows I assemble six mutually reinforcing lines of evidence—semantic-selectional, syntactic-distributional, phenomenological-introspective, psychological-neuroscientific, discursive-functional, and normative-epistemic—that converge on the conclusion that “find” attributes a sui generis affective stance that belongs to the same natural family as appreciating, enjoying, loving and detesting.  None of the data is individually decisive; but taken together they form a case robust enough to carry genuine dialectical weight in the meta-ethical debate.

2. Semantic-selectional evidence: what “find” can and cannot embed  

A first clue comes from the tight lexical restrictions on the complements “find” can take.  It readily embeds paradigmatically evaluative predicates.  

   (2) a. Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty / delicious / revolting.  
       b. Maya finds the mural beautiful / moving / tasteless.  
       c. The judge finds the punishment cruel / excessive / fair.  

In stark contrast, plainly descriptive predicates produce marked or infelicitous results:

   (3) a. ??Holmes finds Saltimbocca Italian / high-calorie / made of veal.  
       b. ??Maya finds the mural rectangular / over three metres tall.  

The contrast cannot be explained by syntactic category, part-of-speech, topicality, or world-knowledge: “Italian” is the same type of adjective as “tasty”; being rectangular is no more complex than being beautiful.  What unites the felicities is evaluativeness—predicates whose application is sensitive to a subject’s affective sensibility or values.  Selectional restrictions of this sort are standardly taken to reflect semantic type requirements: factive verbs like “know” require complements that can deliver truth conditions; dynamic attitude verbs like “want” require modal or infinitival complements.  The natural explanation, therefore, is that “find” requires as complement a property whose satisfaction is internally tied to the subject’s evaluative stance.  That is a hallmark of affective rather than cognitive attitudes.

3. Syntactic-distributional evidence: diagnostics for factivity, gradability, and control  

(i) Lack of factive presupposition.  Verbs such as “know,” “realise,” and “discover” presuppose the truth of the complement (“If Sophie knows that p, then p”).  “Find” shares morphology with “discover” but crucially lacks the factive profile:
