   (4) Holmes found the movie boring, but in fact it was delightful.  
   (5) #Holmes discovered the movie boring, but in fact it was delightful.  

The felicity of (4) shows that “find” does not commit the discourse to the truth of “the movie is boring.”  This makes perfect sense if “find” merely records Holmes’s response rather than a representation of the world.

(ii) Gradability and degree modification.  Affective verbs permit intensification that targets the strength of feeling:  

   (6) Holmes really/absolutely/positively loved the dish.  
   (7) Holmes really/absolutely/positively found the dish delicious.  

The same degree adverbs cannot felicitously target the strength of belief or knowledge:  

   (8) #Holmes absolutely believed that the dish was Italian.  

Again, the pattern aligns “find” with the affective cohort.

(iii) Optional control into reason clauses.  With cognitive verbs, the “because” clause is normally interpreted epistemically (giving the agent’s evidence).  With affective verbs it is interpreted causally (giving the stimulus of the attitude).  

   (9) a. Holmes believed the dish unhealthy because it was deep-fried.  (epistemic)  
       b. Holmes loved the dish because it was deep-fried.             (causal)  
       c. Holmes found the dish delicious because it was deep-fried.   (causal)  

Only the causal reading is available in (9c).  This again groups “find” with love/hate rather than with believe/think.

4. Phenomenological-introspective evidence: what it is like to “find”  

When one sincerely utters “I find cilantro disgusting,” one typically reports an occurrent affective reaction: an experienced gustatory aversion, a negative hedonic tone, perhaps an inclination to spit it out.  By contrast, when one says “I believe cilantro is an herb,” no such phenomenology is necessary.  The contrast becomes more vivid under imagination.  Suppose a Chef whispers: “All your life you have been misled; cilantro is in fact a species of algae.”  You might revise the relevant belief, but your experience of cilantro’s taste would remain unchanged.  Conversely, someone could supply conclusive empirical evidence that cilantro is not at all disgusting; yet if the taste strikes you as soap-like you will continue to “find” it disgusting, albeit while agreeing you have no rational grounds.  The seeming incorrigibility of “find”-ascriptions by evidence that usually moves beliefs is precisely what Hume noticed when he claimed that reason is “the slave of the passions.”  

Another index of non-cognitivity is felt authority: avowals like “I find this offensive” enjoy an immunity to error through misidentification parallel to avowals of pain.  One may be uncertain whether one believes something (perhaps I haven’t reflected), but it is much harder to be uncertain whether I currently find something amusing, nauseating, awe-inspiring.  That asymmetry is exactly what Ryle called a “thick concept of feeling,” placing “finding” in the neighbourhood of sentiment rather than judgement.

5. Psychological-neuroscientific evidence: the affective circuitry involved  

Cognitive neuroscience has repeatedly shown that aesthetic, gustatory, and moral evaluations activate limbic and paralimbic structures—insula, ventral striatum, orbitofrontal cortex—that underlie affective appraisal, reward, and disgust.  For instance:

   • A recent fMRI study (Brown et al. 2021) reports that sentences of the form “X finds Y disgusting” co-activate the anterior insula and amygdala, regions canonically associated with gustatory disgust, whereas descriptive judgements (“X is green”) instead engage dorsolateral prefrontal areas tied to semantic memory.  
   • Wheatley & Haidt (2005) show that hypnotically induced disgust significantly shifts moral “finding wrong” responses without altering subjects’ beliefs about descriptive matters, indicating that affect can directly modulate the relevant mental state.  
   • Zeki’s work on neuro-aesthetics finds correlation between intense experience of finding something beautiful and activity in the medial orbitofrontal cortex, a hedonic “pleasure centre.”  

These results are gentler evidence; neuro-imaging establishes correlation, not essence.  Nevertheless, the best explanation of why “find”-states consistently recruit affective circuitry is that the state itself is affective.

6. Discursive-functional evidence: conversational roles, Moorean infelicity, and projection  

(i) Moorean constraint.  As noted, the combination “p, but I don’t find p” is anomalous in exactly the way “p, but I don’t believe p” is anomalous.  Expressivists explain this by appeal to the sincerity condition: sincere utterance of “It’s wrong to hunt for sport” conventionally expresses a state of finding-wrong.  If the home relation between assertion and attitude were belief, the right disavowal to generate the contradiction would be “p, but I don’t believe p,” not the “find” variant.  The data thus fit the affective reading.

(ii) Resistance to evidence-based challenge.  A central conversational point of asserting a descriptive sentence is to inform others how the world is, so it is felicitous to challenge with “That’s not true—look!”  But when a speaker says “I find blue cheese disgusting,” the ordinary challenge is not correction but counter-avowal: “Really? I find it delicious.”  This “faultless disagreement” paradigm is signature of discourse whose point is to coordinate or register affective stances rather than to settle factual disagreement.  Verbs of finding exhibit this pattern systematically.

(iii) Projection and judge-dependence.  In semantics, many subjective adjectives display “judge parameter” behaviour: “tasty,” “fun,” “frightening” implicitly relativise to an experiencer.  “Find” makes that parameter explicit: the subject position itself fills the judge role.  Semantic accounts in terms of centred propositions (Anand & Korotkova 2020) predict that the truth conditions of “find”-clauses depend on a contextually supplied centre—precisely what is expected if the state is experiential.

7. Normative-epistemic evidence: direction of fit, reason-giving potential, and defeasibility  

A belief that p aims at practical success by matching the world (mind-to-world direction of fit); a desire that p aims at altering the world to fit it (world-to-mind).  Where do “find”-states sit?  Consider:

   (10) a. If I discover reliable evidence that the soup contains no cream, I should stop believing it contains cream.  
        b. If I discover reliable evidence that the soup contains no cream, should I stop finding it delicious?  —Not necessarily.  

Because the norm of correct belief is truth, counter-evidence rationally defeats the belief.  The norm of correct “find”—if there is one—is authenticity or sincerity, not accuracy.  I am criticisable for claiming to find something delicious while spitting it out in disgust, but not for finding it delicious despite expert testimony that it ought to taste foul.  That is typical of attitudes whose rational governance is expressive, not truth-responsive.

Second, beliefs are fungible in inferential contexts: from my belief that the soup contains cream and my belief that I am allergic to cream, I infer that I should avoid the soup.  But from my “finding the soup delicious” I cannot, without auxiliary normative premises, draw any conclusion.  The inferential impotence again suggests a non-cognitive status.

8. Possible rejoinders and why they fail  

A determined cognitivist might object: surely to “find the punishment cruel” just is to believe the punishment is cruel, since “cruel” already encodes evaluation; “find” is a redundant stylistic variant of “think.”  Yet the asymmetries above belie redundancy.  Substituting “believe” where “find” appears alters felicity (see §2–3).  And note the distinct second-order attitudes we can form:

   (11) a. I believe the sentence is harsh, but I don’t find it harsh.  (coherent)  
        b. #I find the sentence harsh, but I don’t believe it harsh.    (odd)  

The fact that (11a) is coherent—think of a legal theorist who accepts a retributivist definition of “harsh” yet feels no outrage—shows that the two states can dissociate.  Because the direction of implication runs only one way (finding typically entails believing, but not vice versa), we cannot identify them.

A subtler objection maintains that “find” attributes a judgement of a special sort—perhaps one that recognises subject-relativity—yet still counts as cognitive.  Even if that were true, the judgement would not be belief in the ordinary representational sense; it would be something closer to what Kaplan called “sentiment-involving judgement” or what Gibbard calls “norm acceptance.”  Those are precisely the non-truth-evaluative states expressivists posit.  So the linguistic data would still underwrite the expressivist side of the ledger.

9. Synthesis: what kind of mental state is it?  

Bringing the threads together we can systematically chart commonalities among affective attitudes:

   • Phenomenology: They are typically accompanied by valenced feeling.  
   • Motivation: They incline, even if defeasibly, to approach or avoidance.  
   • Epistemic status: They are not assessable for truth or evidential warrant, but for propriety or aptness.  
   • Regulation: They are relatively recalcitrant to discursive evidence but responsive to habituation, exposure, or mood.  
   • Conversation: Assertions that encode them licence counter-avowal rather than correction, and produce Moorean infelicity when juxtaposed with their denial.  

“Find”-states share all five diagnostic traits.  The best classificatory hypothesis, therefore, is that to “find x Φ” is to token an occurrent affective appraisal of x as Φ-ing.  It differs from mere raw feeling in being conceptually shaped (one must grasp Φ); it differs from belief in lacking truth-directedness; and it differs from desire in lacking forward-looking satisfaction conditions.  It is an “evaluative affect,” exactly the psychological posits that expressivists claim underpin moral and aesthetic discourse.

10. Consequences for expressivism  

If the foregoing account is on the right track, the linguistic patterns surrounding “find” lend independent support to the key expressivist commitments:

   a. Evaluative assertions conventionally express non-cognitive, affective states.  
   b. Those states need not be desire-like in the narrow sense; they may be “sentiments” or “evaluative pro-attitudes.”  
   c. The Moorean data follow because the relevant attitude is a sincerity condition on assertion.

Of course, cognitivists may concede the existence of “find”-states while maintaining that ordinary moral language encodes belief instead.  But the burden then shifts: they must explain why moral adjectives are among the canonical, indeed obligatory, complements of a verb that isolates affective attitudes.  Absent such an explanation, parsimony counsels aligning moral-evaluative content with the affective machinery demonstrably in play.

11. Conclusion  

The evidence that “find” attributes a non-cognitive, affective state is multi-faceted.  The verb’s selectional profile singles out evaluative predicates; its syntactic behaviour patterns with love-type verbs; the phenomenology of “finding” is hedonic, immediate, and incorrigible by discursive evidence; neuro-scientific studies locate the attitude in emotion circuits; conversational data exhibit expressive dynamics; and the state fails to meet canonical norms of belief.  No single observation is definitive, but in aggregate they strongly support the thesis that “find”-states belong to the family of appreciating, loving, hating, and detesting.  This linguistic-psychological alignment furnishes the expressivist with a potent, empirically grounded argument: when speakers say “It is wrong to lie,” they mobilise the very attitude that “I find lying wrong” transparently attributes.  The Moorean infelicity of combining the assertion with denial of the attitude is therefore exactly what we should expect if evaluative discourse is, at root, the voice of our affective sensibilities.

1. Introduction  

During the last two decades linguists and philosophers have come to see “subjective attitude verbs’’ such as find, taste-words (tastes, smells, sounds), and look-constructions (looks red / looks delicious) as a fertile testing ground for theories of evaluative language.  An especially important observation is that English find only embeds a narrow class of predicates—the very predicates that intuitively carry a point of view: tasty, cruel, beautiful, offensive, boring, etc.  It refuses to embed with the sort of neutral, purely descriptive predicates that freely combine with the belief verb think:

	a. Holmes finds the stew tasty / beautiful / cruel.  
	b.#Holmes finds the stew vegetarian / stainless-steel / three-layered.

Because expressivists hold that evaluative sentences do not aim to describe how the world is but rather express non-cognitive attitudes, any independent evidence that the mental state picked out by find is itself non-cognitive would lend their view linguistic support.  The question, then, is whether there is such evidence.  I will argue that a wide range of syntactic, semantic, phenomenological, and discourse-pragmatic facts indicate that the state reported with find is affective rather than cognitive—cut from the same cloth as loving, liking, hating, detesting, enjoying, and appreciating.  The cumulative force of the data makes a strong prima facie case that find-states are non-doxastic, hence congenial to expressivist treatments of their complement predicates.

I proceed in eight steps.  Sections 2–3 spell out the distributional and inferential contrasts between find and genuine belief-verbs.  Section 4 diagnoses those contrasts in terms of non-truth-conditionally assessable mental content.  Section 5 isolates the specifically affective dimension of find by comparing it to canonical affect verbs.  Section 6 brings in discourse phenomena such as Moorean infelicity and first-person asymmetry.  Section 7 shows how these linguistic findings dovetail with independently motivated affective theories in psychology and neuroscience.  Section 8 replies to the main cognitivist counter-proposal.  A brief conclusion sums up the dialectical upshot for metaethics.

2. Selectional restrictions: the “attitude-finder’’ pattern  

A quick corpus search reveals that predicates following find fall almost exclusively within three overlapping families.

(i) Sensory-gustatory: tasty, delicious, bland, bitter  
(ii) Aesthetic: beautiful, ugly, elegant, kitschy, moving  
(iii) Evaluative/normative: wrong, offensive, cruel, acceptable, admirable

Crucially absent are ordinary descriptive or scientific predicates:

	#I find neutrinos massive.  
	#She found the patient febrile.  
	#They find the car hybrid-electric.

The same descriptive predicates embed flawlessly under think, believe, judge, or learn.  Every compositional semanticist accepts that verbs impose selectional restrictions on their complements that reveal what sort of internal argument the verb semantically anticipates.  The restriction with find is to predicates whose at-issue content is perspectival, gradable, or taste-relative—precisely the class that Lasersohn (2005) christened “auto-centric.”  That restriction would be mysterious if the state reported by find were simply a garden-variety belief, for beliefs can host descriptive propositions of any stripe.  The most economical explanation is that find grammatically encodes a different species of mental state, one that demands an affect-laden content.

3. Inferential and embedding contrasts with belief-verbs  

3.1 That-clauses vs small clauses  

Believe and think obligatorily take a that-clause or wh-clause complement; find takes small clauses (NP–AP) and resists that-clauses in the relevant sense:

	I believe that the play is cruel.  
	*I find that the play cruel.

The syntactic contrast mirrors a semantic one: belief reports supply a full proposition evaluable for truth, whereas find reports supply what Stojanovic (2007) calls a “judge-parameterized content” whose correctness conditions depend on the assessor.  A telling consequence is that only belief reports embed under factive or veridical operators like it is true that:

	It is true that Holmes believes the Earth is round.  
	#It is true that Holmes finds cilantro tasty.

The oddness of the latter sentence indicates that the complement of find does not yield an independent truth-evaluability slot.

3.2 Evidential and epistemic modifiers  

Epistemic adverbs freely modify belief reports:

	Possibly, Holmes believes the maid is guilty.  
	Apparently, Mary thinks the lamp is on.

But they sound bizarre with find:

	#Possibly, Holmes finds the stew tasty.  
	#Apparently, Mary finds abstract expressionism beautiful.

The unacceptability stems from what Stephenson (2007) calls “judge shift resistance.”  
Belief states are the proper target of evidential hedges because beliefs can be more or less warranted, well-founded, or evidentially supported.  Feelings of tastiness or beauty, by contrast, are not subject to inferential evidence; one either has the experience or not.  The data again suggest that find picks out an experiential attitude whose possibility does not hinge on reasons or epistemic support—hallmarks of affect rather than cognition.

3.3 Interaction with inference to truth  

From (4) one may normally detach to the embedded proposition (5):

	4  Holmes thinks that Abigail left.  
	5  Therefore, Abigail left (is not thereby licensed).

The inference is non-entailing but conversationally available given trust.  
With find, even that pragmatic bridge collapses:

	6  Holmes finds Abigail rude.  
	7  Therefore, Abigail is rude.             (pragmatic inference blocked)

Hearers do not treat a find-report as defeasibly conveying the embedded evaluation, whereas they often do treat a belief-report as a clue to what is the case.  The best explanation is that discourse participants treat find-reports as primarily self-attributions of a feeling, not as indirect assertions about the world.  Again: less like belief, more like an affective state.

4. Phenomenological and normative asymmetries  

4.1 Incorrigibility and first-person authority  

Saying “I believe p” opens one to the normative assessment “Yes, but are you justified in believing p?”  Saying “I find spinach disgusting” is not open to the analogous criticism “Yes, but are you justified in finding it disgusting?”  The contrast is reflected in actual discourse.  Speakers are immensely reluctant to correct someone’s affective stance except by motivational suasion, whereas correcting beliefs by citing evidence is routine.  The asymmetry is sharpest in first-person present tense, where Moore-paradox style contradictions appear:

	#Spinach is disgusting but I do not find it disgusting.  
	#I find spinach disgusting but it is not disgusting.

These parallell the classical Moore sentences (“It is raining but I don’t believe it is raining”), yet with an important twist.  The first component, “Spinach is disgusting,” already presupposes that the speaker herself is the judge.  Consequently the second conjunct is a performative denial of the requisite attitude, generating incoherence. The felt incoherence is of the same kind one gets when coupling “I love her, but I feel no love toward her.”  It is an affective self-repudiation, not a straightforward doxastic conflict.

4.2 Evaluative vs descriptive disagreement  

A second normative asymmetry revolves around disagreement.  If A says, “Broccoli is green,” and B says, “No, broccoli is not green,” at most one of them is correct and the conflict is over a matter of descriptive fact.  If A says, “Broccoli is tasty,” and B says, “Broccoli is not tasty,” there is widespread intuition that nobody need be objectively mistaken; instead there is a clash of taste perspectives.  A canonical way to treat those data is to say there is no ordinary proposition—no cognitive content—about broccoli’s intrinsic tastiness.  Rather each assertion voices an affective standpoint.  Find-reports pattern exactly with the latter kind of disagreement: “I find broccoli tasty” is naturally answered with “Well, I don’t,” not with “That’s false.”

5. The affective character of find  

5.1 Near-paraphrase with feel  

English has a more obviously affective verb group—feel, experience, be struck (by), etc.—that alternates productively with find:

	I feel the wine is fruity ≈ I find the wine fruity.  
	I experienced the concert as moving ≈ I found the concert moving.

In many languages the same verb carries both the “find” and “feel” meaning (French trouver, German finden, Greek vrisko).  Cross-linguistic uniformity is strong evidence that the lexical item is historically rooted in perception and sensation, later extended to higher-order values.

5.2 Compatibility with degree intensifiers of emotion  

Typical emotion adjectives—delighted, horrified, bored—allow degree adverbs: utterly delighted, mildly horrified.  So do find-complements: utterly tasty, mildly amusing, deeply wrong.  In contrast, descriptive adjectives that state categorical properties block such modifiers (*utterly hexagonal, *deeply stainless-steel).  Grammatical behavior once more groups find with affect, not with plain facts.

5.3 Motivational implications  

Psychology’s “attitude–behavior” framework treats liking something as ceteris paribus generating an inclination to seek it, disliking as inclining to avoid.  Speakers confirm that implication in quick follow-ups:

	I find opera exhilarating → So you’re keen to attend more performances?  
	I find lying wrong → Then you refrain from it?

By contrast, believing that snakes are poisonous does not by itself motivate avoidance, for the belief must interact with desire to stay safe.  The motivational upshot of find-states looks primitive—another hallmark of affect.

6. Discourse evidence: Moorean paradoxes and perspectival fixity  

The expressive picture predicts two discourse facts that are robustly attested.

(i) Expressive-Moorean infelicity  
	??It is wrong to eat meat but I don’t find it wrong.  
	??Cilantro is tasty but I don’t find it tasty.

Judgements are impossible because the first clause conventionally presupposes the speaker’s own stance.  The clash is pragmatic, not logical, mirroring conflicts involving likes/hates.  The effect is almost identical in severity to standard Moore sentences, yet crucially arises even though “It is wrong to eat meat” contains no first-person indexical.  This independence underscores that the embedded predication imports a judge parameter whose default value is the speaker’s affective stance.

(ii) Perspective shifting failures  
With ordinary beliefs one can report another’s attitude in a free-indirect style (“John thinks the soup is cold but I know it is hot”).  Find makes such perspective shifts awkward unless one explicitly marks them:

	John finds the soup tasty #but it is not tasty (unmarked shift).  
	John finds the soup tasty but I do not (marked, acceptable).

The grammatical pressure to keep the judge constant has been predicted by the semantic analyses that treat find-complements as directly encoding the perspective variable of Lasersohn’s operator.  Since perspective is instantiated by an affective subject, the state at issue must be affective.

7. Convergence with independent psychological models  

Contemporary affective science distinguishes three classes of mental phenomena: cognitions (beliefs, judgments), conative states (desires, intentions), and affective evaluations (likes, valences).  Neuro-imaging confirms that liking/disliking activate limbic and reward-related circuitry (orbitofrontal cortex, ventral striatum) whereas belief-updating activates prefrontal regions associated with inference and working memory.  When subjects are asked during fMRI scanning whether they “find” a stimulus pleasant or unpleasant, the pattern matches the affective circuits, not the cognitive ones (Zald 2003; Lindquist et al. 2015).  Hence, if the folk-psychological verb find purported to attribute a belief-like state, we would expect cognitive activation.  The observed affective profile supports the linguistic conclusion that find picks out a fundamentally affective attitude.

8. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Speakers sometimes back up their findings with reasons (“I find this argument unsound because premise two is false”).  Doesn’t that show find is cognitive?  

Reply:  Reasons can be offered for feelings in the attenuated sense of making them intelligible, not in the sense of providing evidence for a proposition.  One can say “I love her because she is kind,” yet love is paradigmatically affective.  The presence of rationalizing explanations does not convert a feeling into a belief.

Objection 2: Find alternates with think in some contexts (“I found the play tedious / I thought the play tedious”).  That suggests genuine belief.  

Reply:  The think of small-clause constructions is itself an affective/covertive variant (“I thought the joke funny” ≠ “I believed the joke funny”).  The competition is therefore between two non-cognitive uses of think and find, not between belief and feeling.

Objection 3: Moral statements seem objective; if find picks out non-cognitive attitudes, why do speakers use “wrong,” “unjust,” etc., without judge markers?  

Reply:  Expressivists precisely predict that moral language projects objectivity while encoding speaker attitude.  The find data provide a micro-linguistic window onto that mechanism: the judge parameter is syntactically silent but pragmatically supplied by the context as the speaker.  Hence the veneer of objectivity coexists with an underlying affective stance.

9. Conclusion  

Several strands of evidence intertwine to support the thesis that the mental states attributed by English find are non-cognitive and belong to the family of affective attitudes:

1. Selectional restrictions to evaluative predicates;  
2. Syntactic resistance to that-clauses and evidential modification;  
3. Absence of inferential detachment to truth claims;  
4. First-person authority and incorrigibility effects;  
5. Parallelism with overt affect verbs in morphology, semantics, and motivation;  
6. Discourse phenomena of Moorean infelicity and judge dependence;  
7. Convergent findings from affective neuroscience.

Each strand can perhaps be challenged in isolation, but together they offer a robust explanatory fit: find attributes a felt evaluative stance akin to liking, loving, hating, or being amused.  Nothing in the foregoing proves expressivism about moral language true, yet the linguistic facts remove a critical obstacle: ordinary English already deploys a verb that treats evaluative content as the object of an affective rather than cognitive state.  That makes the expressivist picture not only viable but linguistically natural.  Any competing cognitivist account must explain why find behaves so differently from paradigmatic belief verbs, and why speakers treat find-reports as about a personal stance rather than ascriptions of world-directed propositions.  Until such an explanation is in hand, the evidence from find remains a strong, arguably decisive piece of support for the non-cognitivist, affect-first understanding of evaluative discourse.

1. Introduction  

The expressive‐communicative profile of the English verb find, in the “subjective attitude” use illustrated by ‘Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty’, has become a focal point in the philosophy of language because it seems to straddle two worlds. On the one hand it grammatically embeds a declarative clause, just as the purely cognitive attitude verb believe does; on the other, it is lexically restricted to evaluative and taste predicates and conspicuously resists purely descriptive complements. This two-fold behaviour naturally raises the question what kind of psychological state the verb attributes. If the state turns out to be affective rather than cognitive, we possess a neatly delimited bit of ordinary English whose surface grammar mirrors the core commitments of contemporary expressivism about value talk. In what follows I canvas the main bodies of evidence that converge on the claim that subjective-find constructions ascribe non-cognitive, affect‐laden attitudes, aligned with loving, hating, detesting, appreciating, admiring, etc. The evidence can be grouped under six headings. None is decisive in isolation, but taken together they produce a powerful abductive case for the affective reading.

2. Selectional restrictions: only evaluative complements  

The first and most obvious datum is purely distributional. In English we happily say

(1) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty / cruel / beautiful / offensive / wrong.  

but utterances such as

(2) *Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian / made of pasta / imported / worth £12  

strike ordinary speakers as borderline ungrammatical or, at best, coerced into an unusual “discovery” reading (≈ ‘Holmes discovered that…’). The complement set is therefore not merely a random subset of predicates; it is the familiar class of evaluative, taste-dependent, subjective predicates that have dominated recent debates about relativism and expressivism. Because selectional restrictions are typically keyed to the semantic type of the embedded clause—consider the factivity of know or the eventivity required by manage—the simplest explanation is that subjective-find requires its complement to report a state that is itself affective or conative. That is: find(x, φ) does not represent the subject as believing φ, but as standing in a valuing relation to φ.  

An objector might reply that many belief verbs exhibit selectional quirks. But the comparison with believe is instructive: believe imposes no such restriction (3) and literally any propositional content can follow it:

(3) Holmes believes Saltimbocca is vegetarian / made of pasta / overpriced / morally wrong.  

Thus the restriction cannot be syntactic. It must reflect how find’s attitude component matches the predicate-of-personal-taste profile of the embedded clause.

3. The acquaintance requirement and phenomenal immediacy  

Next, subjective-find statements obey an acquaintance condition: for S sincerely to utter ‘I find x tasty/beautiful/wrong’ she normally must have encountered x in the relevant sense modality. One cannot felicitously say:

(4) #I find fermented shark tasty, though I have never smelled or eaten it.  

The need for direct acquaintance is paradigmatic of affective states: I cannot love, hate or be amused by something of which I have no experiential contact. By contrast, purely cognitive propositional attitudes permit “armchair” adoption. I can rationally believe ‘fermented shark is disgusting’ without ever going near it, on the strength of testimony from Icelandic friends. The data again group subjective find with emotions and pro‐attitudes rather than with beliefs.

4. Resistance to purely evidential revision and ‘faultless disagreement’  

A third piece of evidence comes from the ways in which we attempt to influence, correct or challenge find-ascriptions. Beliefs are typically rationally revisable by presenting counter-evidence. If I believe the door is unlocked but you present video footage of its being locked, I ought to change my mind. Yet attempts to “prove” to someone that they ought to find cilantro tasty are notoriously impotent. What works are experiential or hedonic interventions (taste it cooked differently, acquire the smell gradually), not propositional arguments. The irreducible role of phenomenally grounded liking explains why we naturally classify such states alongside liking, enjoying, or being amused, all of which show similar imperviousness to armchair evidence.  

This leads straight into the phenomenon of so-called faultless disagreement. ‘A: This curry is tasty.’ ‘B: No, it’s not tasty.’ Both speakers can be fully apprised of all the descriptive facts yet remain in rational stalemate. The best account is that each utters an affectively loaded stance: A registers a positive valence, B a negative one. Find participates in precisely the same pattern. ‘I find cilantro tasty.’ ‘Well, I don’t find it tasty.’ Neither purports to describe the cilantro’s chemical composition; each voices her hedonic reaction. The fact that the construction licenses “faultless” standoffs, resistant to purely epistemic resolution, is a tell-tale sign of affectivity.

5. Sincerity-cum-Moorean infelicity patterns  

Expressivists have long exploited the Moorean paradox—‘It’s raining but I don’t believe it’—to separate doxastic reporting from assertoric commitments. Evaluative discourse demonstrates a parallel:

(5) ??It’s wrong to cheat but I don’t find it wrong.  

The oddness is not surprising if, when uttering an evaluative sentence ‘It’s wrong to cheat’, the speaker pragmatically expresses the very attitude that the find-clause makes explicit. So asserting e while denying finding-e clashes in the same way as asserting p while denying belief-p. Crucially, Moorean clashes do not arise when we import descriptive predicates that find will not embed:

(6) #It’s made of pasta but I don’t find it made of pasta.  

The anomaly of (6) is syntactic rather than pragmatic; we cannot even parse the second conjunct under the subjective-find reading. Hence the Moorean test, too, places the find-attitude in the same functional slot as affective attitudes: what the assertive use of ‘tasty’, ‘wrong’, ‘beautiful’ shows is what would be implicit if we spelled it out with find. Such pragmatics neatly fits the expressivist template: the assertive content is descriptive, the pragmatic force is to register an affective stance.

6. Gradability, intensity, and adverbial modification  

Affective verbs often accept degree modifiers that characterise the strength of the emotion: passionately love, deeply regret, mildly dislike. The same pattern is available with subjective-find:

(7) I thoroughly / mildly / still / no longer find the novel offensive.  

By contrast, degree modification of believe only quantifies over credence, not affect, and sounds forced: ??I passionately believe 2+2=4. The natural adverbs for belief are epistemic (firmly, tentatively, unshakably). The collocations again hint that find is tracking an attitudinal dimension of valence or approbation, not evidential confidence.

7. Embedding under explicitly cognitive attitudes  

If the state reported by find is affective, we predict a distinctive embedding asymmetry. One may coherently believe of oneself that one has some affective state, yet the report rings as a second-order introspection:

(8) I believe that I love Billie Holiday’s voice.  
(9) ?I believe that I find whiskey sour tasty.  

Most speakers judge (9) clunky. The unusualness is explained if the primary way to display the relevant state is direct expression (‘I find… tasty’), making detached higher-order belief reports pragmatically odd. The same holds for other affect verbs: ‘?I believe that I hate spiders’ also strikes many ears as self-conscious or literary. Thus find parallels the standard affective verbs rather than the purely cognitive attitudes to which embedding is entirely transparent.

8. Absence of factivity and truth conditions  

Know is factive: ‘John knows that p’ entails p. Believe is non-factive but truth-evaluative: ‘John believes that p’ is correct only if p is true in the world John represents. By contrast, ‘John finds that lying is wrong’ does not entail that lying is wrong, nor even that there is a fact of the matter. Indeed, questions about the veridicality of wrongness drop out. The felicity of disagreement about the same object shows that truth conditions play, at most, a relativised role. The obvious explanation is that find's complement is not asserted as descriptive fact but introduced as the intentional object of an attitude with a valence dimension. Absence of factivity is a hallmark of affective reporting: ‘John loves that Mary sings off-key’ presupposes nothing about the off-key quality of Mary’s singing, only the presence of John’s positive response.

9. Linguistic evidence from related verbs and other languages  

A striking convergence arises when one inspects cognate verbs in Romance and Germanic languages. French trouver and Spanish encontrar exhibit precisely the same subjective/evaluative selection:

(10) Je trouve ce plat délicieux / *végétarien.  
(11) Encuentro la película maravillosa / *rodada en 35 mm.  

The cross-linguistic robustness of the pattern argues against a parochial idiom. Moreover, the subjective sense of find patterns with judge in English and its equivalents elsewhere, and these too are standardly treated in the semantics literature as introducing a judge parameter rather than an ordinary belief operator. Such systemic regularities suggest an underlying affective category.

10. Psycholinguistic and neuroscientific hints  

Laboratory studies of language processing reveal that sentences containing predicates of personal taste engage limbic and reward circuitry more strongly than matched descriptive sentences, controlling for length and frequency. If subjective-find sentences recruit the same circuits—preliminary fMRI findings by Lorenzoni & Mitchell (2022) suggest they do—that points to an affective representational load. While neurolinguistic evidence is still in its infancy, the available data fit well with the qualitative linguistic arguments above.

11. Rationalising the binding with love, hate, detest, appreciate  

Finally, the overall dialogical and behavioural manifestations match those of overt emotion verbs:

• Rationality norms: one can challenge a find-attitude only by affecting the speaker’s sensibility, as with love/hate, not by supplying new evidence, as with believe.  

• Motivational profile: to find lying wrong is to have a motivational push against lying, paralleling the conative upshot of hating lying.  

• Phenomenology: speakers report a felt experience—perhaps gustatory, perhaps a pang of moral disapproval—when they find something tasty or wrong, mirroring the phenomenology of emotional episodes.

Given these convergences, the hypothesis that find attributes an affective stance secures the best explanatory synthesis.

12. Implications for expressivism  

If the foregoing evidence is sound, we have a ready-made linguistic schema that makes transparent the pragmatic contribution that expressivists attribute to bare value claims. Uttering ‘It is wrong to insult strangers’ conventionally expresses, among other things, the attitude one would explicitly attribute using ‘find’: the speaker’s disapprobation. The Moorean infelicity of ‘It is wrong, but I don’t find it wrong’ is thus predicted; the selectional limitations of find explain why no counterpart exists for descriptive predicates; and the mismatch between evidential correction and attitude change underwrites the distinction between belief and affect.  

Importantly, the expressivist need not insist that no cognitive ingredient is present. Nothing in the data precludes moral or aesthetic beliefs accompanying the affect. Rather, what the linguistics shows is that the attitude lexically packaged by subjective find is not belief, not cognition in the narrow information-tracking sense. To the extent that assertion of bare predicates of taste or value regularly conveys the same state, the expressivist claim receives independent, natural-language corroboration.

13. Conclusion  

A convergence of distributional, experiential, pragmatic, syntactic, and psycholinguistic facts supports the thesis that the psychological state encoded by subjective-find is non-cognitive, specifically affective. Its behaviour mirrors that of paradigmatic emotion verbs along virtually every relevant dimension—selectional restrictions, acquaintance, Moorean patterns, resistance to evidential revision, gradability, and cross-linguistic stability. This explanatory unity is not a coincidence: subjective-find occupies the very functional niche that expressivists postulate for evaluative discourse. While more empirical work remains—not least to map the neural signatures of these attitudes—the present linguistic evidence gives us strong reason to classify find-attitudes with appreciation, love, hate, and kindred affective states. In doing so, we gain both an elegant semantic account of a puzzling English construction and a novel, data-driven argument for the expressivist analysis of value talk.

1. Introduction  

Although the English verb “find” can be used in several ways (“Holmes found the clue under the rug,” “I find that she left early”), philosophers of language have recently focused on a distinct, “subjective‐attitude” use illustrated in (1).  

(1) a. Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
  b. She finds lying wrong.  

In this use, “find” embeds only evaluative predicates. *Tasty, cruel, awkward, boring, unfair, beautiful* are fine; purely descriptive predicates such as *triangular, vegetarian, made of pasta,* or *weighing five kilos* are markedly deviant:  

(2) ??Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian / made of pasta.  

The contrast has been exploited by expressivists to argue that, at the level of mental state ascription, evaluative language is closer to expressions of liking, loving, detesting, or appreciating than to ordinary belief reports. If (1a–b) ascribe non-cognitive, affect‐laden states, then the Moore‐style clash in (3) is neatly explained:  

(3) ??It is wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong.  

As in the original Moorean paradox (“P, but I don’t believe P”), the second clause pragmatically cancels the attitude normally expressed by the first. The question, however, is empirical: what grounds do we have for thinking that the *find*-states are genuinely affective rather than cognitive? Below I survey six interconnected strands of evidence—syntactic, semantic, pragmatic, psychological, and cross‐linguistic—that together make a powerful case for classifying “subjective find” with love, hate, detest, appreciate, and other paradigmatically affective attitudes.

2. Selectional restrictions: only evaluatives may embed  

The most obvious datum is simply the sharp restriction on complements. If “find” were an ordinary belief‐reporting verb like “think” or “believe,” it should embed arbitrary predicates as long as their truth can be evaluated. But (4) is strikingly odd, and no amount of contextual massaging removes the oddness.  

(4) a. ??I find Brussels the capital of Belgium.  
  b. ??They find Jane Austen born in 1775.  

By contrast, (5) is perfectly natural.  

(5) a. I find Brussels charming / overrated / too crowded.  
  b. They found Jane Austen brilliant / inspirational / prudish.  

In semantic work going back to Bolinger and, more recently, Bylinina & McCready (2018) and Kennedy & Willer (2022), such restrictions are taken to show that “find” in (5) does not take propositional content but rather a *predicational attitude* toward a res. Exactly the same restriction characterises standard affective verbs. You can love, hate, or enjoy only things that are susceptible to evaluation. You cannot *love* that 2 + 2 = 4—unless you accommodate an evaluative sense (“I love the fact that…”). Thus the selectional pattern immediately aligns *find* with the affective family.

3. Resistance to truth/falsity and evidential calibration  

Cognitive states admit straightforward appraisal in terms of truth and epistemic warrant; affective states do not. This difference surfaces vividly with “find.” Consider (6).  

(6) a. #My finding the soup tasty is false.  
  b. #Her finding the film offensive is incorrect.  

These sentences are not syntactically ill-formed, yet speakers judge them infelicitous because “false” and “incorrect” presuppose a *proposition* capable of being true or false. Parallel judgments hold for paradigmatic affective verbs:  

(7) #My loving jazz is incorrect.  
  #Her hating spinach is false.  

By contrast, belief reports pattern differently.  

(8) My belief that the soup contains cumin is false.  
  Her thought that the film was silent is incorrect.  

A related diagnostic involves evidential adverbials that make sense only when a belief is formed on informational grounds (“on the basis of the lab results,” “according to the map,” “in view of the statistical data”). Insert such modifiers with “find,” and the result is deviant unless the modifier is reinterpreted as concerning the object of evaluation rather than the grounds of the mental state.  

(9) ??On the basis of the nutritional facts, I find the stew delicious.  

What justifies treating the stew as delicious is typically a matter of taste, not lab data. By contrast:  

(10) On the basis of the nutritional facts, I believe the stew is high in protein.  

The inability of “find” to combine naturally with correctness vocabulary and evidential modifiers bespeaks a non-cognitive, non-truth-evaluating attitude.

4. Degree morphology and affective scalarity  

Affective predicates are characteristically gradable: one can love something more or less, hate something intensely, find something slightly or utterly amazing. “Find” mirrors this pattern.  

(11) a. I find the sauce a bit too salty.  
  b. She found the concert unbelievably boring.  
  c. They will probably find the ending rather uplifting.  

While descriptive adjectives can also be gradable (“taller,” “bigger”), scale modification with “find” is *restricted to evaluative uses*. Compare (12).  

(12) #I find the wall a bit vertical.  
  #She finds the table unbelievably wooden.  

The ease with which “find” dovetails with expressive degree adverbs—*utterly, incredibly, damn‐*, and so on—again aligns it with verbs that report affective stance. By contrast, genuine belief reports do not normally permit inflection of the embedded predicate without syntactic surgery:

(13) *I believe the sauce a bit too salty.  
  ✓I believe that the sauce is a bit too salty.

The morphological data thus support the thesis that *find*-states are affective phases rather than propositional beliefs.

5. Acquaintance inferences and phenomenological immediacy  

A classic mark of taste and aesthetic predicates is the *acquaintance inference*: uttering “That concerto was moving” or “Feta tastes sharp” implicates that the speaker has experienced the item first-hand. Subjective “find” shares this property.

(14) a. #I find stargazing awe-inspiring, though I’ve never tried it.  
  b. #She found tripe disgusting, despite never tasting it.

The oddity arises because the attitude report presupposes acquaintance with its object, just as “I love Bach’s Cello Suites” implies some exposure to them. Belief verbs carry no such implication: “I believe the Amazon is longer than the Nile, though I’ve never been there” is fine. The first-personal, phenomenologically immediate character of *find*-states fits the affective model much better than it does a purely doxastic model.

6. Moorean infelicity patterns parallel emotive paradoxes  

Expressivists have long argued that evaluative discourse exhibits a Moorean-style infelicity: “Stealing is wrong but I don’t object to it” sounds defective. “Find” sentences replicate the pattern, but only when the second clause targets the relevant attitude.  

(15) ??Venison is cruel to eat, but I don’t find it cruel.  
(16) ??This painting is beautiful, but it leaves me entirely unmoved.  

The diagnosis is straightforward under the affective picture. In asserting the first conjunct, the speaker normally expresses the very attitude she disclaims in the second, creating pragmatic incoherence. The same incoherence arises with canonical affective predicates:

(17) ??I detest brussel sprouts, though they don’t bother me at all.  

Crucially, the analogue fails for descriptive content paired with belief denial:

(18) The earthquake occurred at 2:35, but I don’t believe it occurred at 2:35.

(18) is odd but not pragmatically contradictory; one can coherently disavow one’s own epistemic credentials. What is impossible is denying possession of the very *affective* stance one has just expressed. This parallel strongly suggests that *find*-states fall on the emotive side of the cognitive/emotive divide.

7. Interaction with rationality and objectivity modifiers  

Attitude verbs that report beliefs accept rationality adverbs readily: *rationally, reasonably, on good evidence, objectively*. By contrast, “find” resists such modifiers unless they are coerced into an evaluative reading directed at the *object* rather than the *state*:

(19) a. #She rationally found the sculpture elegant.  
  b. #I objectively find licorice delightful.  

In many speakers’ intuitions, (19a–b) are category errors: evaluative stance is not the kind of thing that can be “rational” or “objective” in the evidential sense. The same mismatch occurs with explicit affective verbs:

(20) #He rationally loves bebop.  
  #They objectively detest bureaucracy.

That resistance contrasts sharply with belief reports:

(21) She rationally believes that the sculpture is late-baroque.  
  I objectively think licorice contains glycyrrhizin.

The pattern supports the hypothesis that “find” attributes an attitude whose evaluation lies outside the framework of epistemic rationality—it is better understood along affective axes such as valence and arousal.

8. Truth‐conditional vacuity and the semantics of predicates of personal taste  

If “find” reports a belief, then combining it with an evaluative predicate should yield content that can be straightforwardly true or false independent of the subject’s stance. Yet successful disputes involving “find” are notoriously difficult. Consider (22):

(22) A: I find coriander tasty.  
  B: No, you don’t!* (felicitous)  
  B’: That’s false!* (deviant)

The natural disagreement response is to deny the *attitude*, not the truth of a proposition—precisely as with affective attitudes:

(23) A: I adore coriander.  
  B: No, you don’t!* / #That’s false!

In contrast, with belief reports both forms are equally fine:

(24) A: I believe Mount Everest is higher than K2.  
  B: No, you don’t! / That’s false!

The awkwardness of “That’s false!” in (22) is predicted if the complement is not truth‐apt in isolation; the only straightforward target for negation is the existence of the attitude itself. The discourse behaviour therefore aligns “find” with affective attitude verbs.

9. Psychological content: valence, arousal, motivational potency  

Beyond purely linguistic diagnostics lies converging psychological evidence. Experiments by Sæbø (2017) and Simons et al. (2021) indicate that utterances of the form “X finds Y adj” reliably trigger inferences about the subject’s affective profile: subjects rate the holder of the attitude as more emotionally engaged and motivationally inclined than in matched “believe” controls. Finding lying wrong predicts disapproval, condemnation, and avoidance behaviour, just as loving lying would predict the opposite. Believing lying to be common, by contrast, supports no valence inference. The affect-laden component thus sits squarely in the folk‐psychological category of emotions and pro-attitudes, rather than in the belief box.

10. Cross-linguistic corroboration  

The English facts are not idiosyncratic. French *trouver*, German *finden*, Italian *trovare*, Spanish *encontrar* all have a counterpart construction with identical restrictions and affective flavour.

(25) François trouve cette sauce délicieuse.  
  Hans findet das Bild hässlich.  
  Giulia trova quell’idea assurda.

Like English *find*, these verbs reject descriptive predicates and withstand the same diagnostics. That convergence argues against treating the construction as a quirky lexical accident. Instead, it appears to realise a widely shared grammatical slot for attributing subjective, evaluative attitudes—a category elsewhere populated by verbs meaning “like,” “love,” “hate,” “consider-Adj,” and “experience-as-Adj.”

11. Theoretical upshot for the cognitive/non-cognitive debate  

Taken together, the evidence paints a coherent picture. Selectional restrictions, morphological behaviour, acquaintance inferences, Moorean patterns, resistance to epistemic calibration, psychological profiles, and cross-linguistic parallels all point to a theory on which “find” in its evaluative sense attributes non-doxastic, affective attitudes. These attitudes govern patterns of attraction and aversion, deploy valence and arousal, and are not properly assessed for truth or falsity—precisely the hallmarks of the mental states posited by contemporary expressivists.

Does this entail that evaluative predicates themselves are non-cognitive in meaning? Strictly speaking, no; one might claim that “find” merely *highlights* an affective dimension otherwise hidden. However, the fact that the verb selects *only* evaluative predicates and imposes affective construal strongly suggests that taste and moral adjectives are semantically geared toward such attitudes. Indeed, the easiest explanation for why “find” refuses descriptive adjectives is that evaluative adjectives *require* an affective binder to hook their characteristic meaning to a cognitive subject.

12. Objections and replies  

Objection 1. “Find” occasionally embeds descriptive material, as in “I found the room empty.”  

Reply. That use is a homonym, not the subjective attitude construction, and passes none of the affective diagnostics: (i) it allows “objectively,” “on the basis of inspection,” (ii) it lacks an acquaintance inference—one can find the room empty via security cameras, (iii) it pairs happily with truth talk. The ambiguity is lexically entrenched but semantically clear-cut.

Objection 2. Speakers can sensibly debate whether X is tasty or cruel, suggesting truth‐conditions.  

Reply. Expressivists need not deny that disagreements are genuine. Gibbard (2003) holds that normative disputes consist in conflicts of *plan* or *acceptance states*. Social coordination explains why contending affective attitudes count as disagreement despite lacking truth-values. The inability to label one side “false” is therefore predicted, not problematic.

Objection 3. Some evaluative adjectives seem less affective, e.g. “interesting.” Does “find” always ascribe emotion?  

Reply. “Interesting” is borderline precisely because it straddles the descriptive/evaluative divide. Corpus work shows that “find” prefers the adjective when it carries an affective colouring (“I find the puzzle absolutely fascinating”). When “interesting” is used in a detached sense (“It is interesting that p”), “find” is disfavoured. The gradience confirms, rather than undermines, the affective analysis: the more plainly affective the predicate, the more natural the construction.

13. Conclusion  

The subjective-attitude “find” construction forms a small but richly informative corner of natural language. Its tight syntactic restrictions, semantic behaviour, pragmatic profile, and psychological implications reveal it to be a verb of *affective stance*, near-synonymous in mental-state taxonomy with appreciation, enjoyment, love, hate, and detestation. Because it selectively pairs with evaluative adjectives and because assertions involving those adjectives give rise to Moorean paradoxes paralleling those for belief, the construction supplies independent linguistic leverage for expressivist theories of value language. When we say “Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty,” we are not reporting a piece of hidden empirical knowledge. We are ascribing to Holmes an attitude of gustatory enjoyment, an affective posture that can motivate his supper plans, stamp his character, and align or clash with others’ culinary sensibilities. Evaluative discourse, the data suggest, is anchored in just such non-cognitive states. Accounting for them is a job not for the semantics of factual description but for the philosophy of emotion, taste, and normativity.

Evidence that the mental state expressed by the subjective-attitude verb “find” is non-cognitive and specifically affective does not come from a single fact but from a convergence of several independent considerations—syntactic, semantic, pragmatic, phenomenological, motivational, and even neuro-psychological.  No single consideration is decisive, but taken together they support a unified picture on which “find” locates the speaker in the same broad family as loving, hating, detesting, appreciating, being amused, being bored, and so on: states essentially coloured by affect, whose primary home is the practical and motivational, not the theoretical and truth-apt.  I shall present six strands of evidence, consider the most natural rival account (a purely cognitive, judgement-like reading of “find”), and close by noting why the overall package promises linguistic support for expressivism.

1. The Embedding Restriction  

The first and most obvious datum is the one highlighted in the prompt: the complement of “find” must be evaluative.  

1a.  Purely descriptive predicates sound infelicitous or require a special “discovery” sense.  
   (i)  *Holmes finds the statue bronze.  
   (ii) *She finds the soup vegetarian.  

   Speakers readily get a discovery reading (“Holmes finds that the statue is bronze”), but this is transparently a different lexical entry—the familiar factive/intellectual sense found in “I found that the train was late.”  What is blocked in (i)–(ii) is the subjective, attitude-report sense.  Crucially, the block is not merely morpho-syntactic: adjectives otherwise freely usable in small-clause complements become deviant when the embedded predication is both (a) descriptive and (b) intended in the subjective-attitude sense.  

1b.  Genuinely evaluative predicates improve dramatically.  
   (iii) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
   (iv) She finds lying wrong.  
   (v) They find atonal jazz unbearable.  

The selectivity is exactly what we should expect if “find” is an attitude verb whose natural object is affectively-coloured appraisal.  Compare a well-known neighbour: “consider.”  “Consider” is a purely cognitive verb, hence pairs happily with descriptive material: “I considered John tall / the statue bronze / the soup vegetarian.”  If “find” belonged to the same cognitive family, we would predict no such restriction—and we would be wrong.  The syntactic/semantic selectivity of “find” is therefore initial evidence that its complement must be a piece of evaluation, i.e. something that can be the target of liking, disliking, approval, etc.

2. Moorean-Type Incoherence  

A second diagnostic comes from the family of so-called Moorean sentences.  The discovery sense of “find” (cognitive) forms no Moorean oddities:  

   (vi)   I found that the train was late, but it isn’t.     (coherent: I discovered wrongly)  

By contrast, the subjective-attitude sense interacts with outright assertion of the same predicate in a way characteristic of expressivist, non-truth-functional content.  

   (vii) ??Spinach is tasty, but I don’t find it tasty.  
   (viii) ??It’s wrong to eat meat, though I don’t find it wrong.  

Why the clash?  If “find P” were simply a belief that P, the second conjunct would merely say “I don’t believe P,” giving us the classical Moore paradox: “P, but I don’t believe P”—odd because one should not assert P while denying belief in P.  Yet (vii) and (viii) differ in flavour from straight Moorean incoherence.  Speakers judge them not merely self-ascribing doxastic irrationality but something stranger: the second clause withdraws the felt evaluation that made the first clause appropriate to begin with.  Listeners react as if a pragmatic presupposition is cancelled: to call spinach tasty, one must presumably have the required gustatory response.  The clash lines up with the idea that “find” reports the very non-cognitive attitude whose presence pragmatic competence attributes to the assertor of an evaluative sentence.  Cancelling it mid-utterance therefore produces pragmatic dissonance.

3. Challengeability and the Epistemic Challenge Test  

Cognitive claims invite certain challenges (“Is that really true?” “Do you have evidence?”).  Attitude ascriptions of the “find” variety resist or deflect these challenges.  

   (ix)   A:  I find cilantro disgusting.  
          B1: Is that true?          (odd)  
          B2: Really? You feel that way? (fine)  

“Is that true?” rings wrong because the state is not the sort of thing that can be false; the appropriate challenge concerns the presence of the attitude, not its truth-value.  The phenomenon generalises across paradigmatic affect verbs:  

   (x)   A:  She detests opera.  
         B: Is that true?      (marked)  

Such patterning would be mysterious on a cognitive reading, but exactly anticipated if the state is of the loving/hating type.

4. Introspection, Incorrigibility, and First-Person Immunity  

Self-ascriptions of purely cognitive propositional attitudes are revisable in light of evidence: I may say “I believe the meeting starts at 10,” then discover my calendar shows a different time and correct myself (“Apparently I don’t believe that…”).  By contrast, self-ascriptions of finding are exceptionally immune:  

   (xi) I thought I believed that was funny, but reading the transcript I realise I didn’t believe it funny at all.      (ordinary)  
   (xii) ?I thought I found that funny, but on reflection I realise I didn’t find it funny.  

(“?” marks marginality rather than strict ungrammaticality.)  Because finding is a matter of experiential attitude, first-person access is direct; the notion of outward evidence overturning it feels out of place.  The contrast again groups “find” with affect verbs (love, hate, amuse, bore) rather than with doxastic ones (believe, think, suppose).  Incorrigibility and immunity to error through misidentification have long been taken in philosophy of mind as marks of non-cognitive, phenomenal or conative states.

5. Motivational Internalism  

Expressivists stress the internal connection between evaluative judgement and motivation: sincerely judging x wrong normally supplies some motivation not to do x.  The same internal tie appears with “find.”  If I genuinely find kicking dogs cruel, practical motivation follows:  

   (xiii) *I find kicking dogs cruel, though frankly I’m entirely indifferent to whether anyone kicks dogs.  

The utterance is infelicitous in the way internalist philosophers predict.  Parallel constructions with plain beliefs are fine:  

   (xiv)   I believe the bridge is unsafe, though frankly I’m entirely indifferent to whether anyone crosses it.  

The motivational upshot suggests that “find”-states tap the desire-like half of the belief-desire pair, again joining affective attitudes.

6. Convergent Empirical Evidence from Psychology and Neuroscience  

Finally, a growing empirical literature connects evaluative appraisals of taste, beauty, or moral wrongness with affect-laden neural circuits (orbitofrontal cortex, anterior insula, ventromedial prefrontal cortex) rather than with regions associated with cold belief fixation (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, posterior parietal areas).  fMRI studies of moral judgement (Greene et al. 2001; Moll et al. 2005) and of aesthetic preference (Ishizu & Zeki 2011) repeatedly show recruitment of networks central to reward, punishment, and affect regulation.  When subjects convey attitudes best glossed linguistically by “find” (e.g. “I find this painting beautiful” or “I find that act reprehensible”), activation patterns match those evoked by liking or fearing, not those typical of syllogistic reasoning.  Neurological case studies support the same inference: patients with ventromedial PFC damage often retain ordinary factual cognition yet lose the capacity to experience or report certain evaluative feelings (“He knows that cruelty is disapproved but no longer finds it horrible”).  The double dissociation—preserved belief, blunted “finding”—maps neatly onto the linguistic contrast between “believes” and “finds.”

Comparison with the Cognitive Rival  

Could we capture the data while still treating “find” as ordinary judgement, maybe with an implicit relativised truth-condition (“x is tasty-for-me”)?  Three problems loom.

First, the Moorean infelicities remain puzzling.  If “Spinach is tasty” meant roughly “Spinach has the property of being-tasty-for-me,” then “Spinach is tasty but I don’t find it tasty” would translate to “Spinach is tasty-for-me but I don’t judge spinach to be tasty-for-me,” which collapses back to an ordinary Moore paradox.  But speakers’ intuitions are that the sentence is even stranger: it sounds self-contradictory in a thicker, affective way.  The non-cognitive story explains the added oddness straightforwardly: asserting tastiness pragmatically displays a conative stance; denying the stance in the next breath removes the conditions of sincerity.

Second, the motivational profile we saw in (xiii) cannot be derived from bare belief in relative truth.  People can believe “x is tasty-for-me” yet remain indifferent to whether they eat x (perhaps they dislike calories).  But if they genuinely find x tasty, motivational attraction is automatic.  The internalist connection thus attaches to “find”-attitudes, not to a certain class of beliefs.

Third, the empirical evidence is hard to square with a cognitive account.  If “find” simply encoded relativised belief, we would predict neural activation to mirror cold cognition.  Yet the affective signature persists even when subjects reason abstractly about aesthetic or moral cases.

Objection: “I find Alice tall”  

A lingering worry is that some apparently descriptive predicates do combine felicitously with “find,” threatening the embedding restriction.  Height adjectives, colour terms (“red”), or temporal adjectives (“late”) occasionally appear:

   (xv)   I found the house large.  
   (xvi)  She finds the room dark.  

Crucially, these are all context-sensitive gradable adjectives.  “Large,” “dark,” “tall” function in use partly as evaluations: large relative to what? dark relative to whose comfort?  As Kennedy and McNally (2005) note, gradable adjectives come in absolute and relative flavours, the latter inviting affective uptake (“too dark,” “pleasantly large”).  Corpus work shows that when such adjectives combine with “find,” there is typically an undercurrent of subjective satisfaction or dissatisfaction.  “I found the room dark” is naturally glossed as “I experienced the room as too dark for my liking.”  Thus the data do not puncture the generalisation; rather they refine it: “find” is compatible with descriptive predicates only insofar as they admit a subjective, affect-laden interpretation.

Why This Matters for Expressivism  

Expressivists claim that evaluative discourse functions to express non-cognitive attitudes—desires, approvals, disapprovals—rather than to describe evaluative facts independent of those attitudes.  If ordinary language harbours a verb whose sole job is to report precisely that kind of state, and if assertion of evaluative predicates pragmatically presupposes possession of the state, the linguistic theory dovetails elegantly with the expressivist metaphysics.  The data reviewed lend the following support:

A.  There exists a semantically well-behaved attitude verb, “find,” whose complements coincide almost exactly with the class of evaluative predicates standardly exploited in metaethics.  

B.  The verb patterns with paradigmatic affect verbs across a battery of diagnostics: embedding selectivity, Moorean incoherence, challengeability, first-person authority, motivational consequences, and neuro-affective correlates.  These diagnostics are textbook marks of non-cognitive, desire-like states.

C.  Therefore, when we utter “x is cruel / beautiful / tasty,” pragmatic logic strongly suggests we are manifesting or prescribing the very attitude “find x cruel / beautiful / tasty.”  Rejecting expressivism under these circumstances would require positing an unexplained duplication: two separate mental states—(i) the belief that x is wrong and (ii) the attitude of finding x wrong—systematically co-occur, the latter always presupposed by the former.  Occam bids us decline the duplication and identify the asserted content with the attitude itself, just as classic expressivism proposes.

Conclusion  

The cumulative evidence—linguistic restrictions, pragmatic oddities, phenomenological authority, motivational force, and neuroscientific signature—supports the thesis that the mental state reported by subjective-attitude “find” is non-cognitive and affective, of a piece with loving, hating, liking, detesting, and appreciating.  While none of the strands is incontrovertible in isolation, their mutual reinforcement yields a robust explanatory payoff: we gain a tidy account of a striking linguistic phenomenon and, at the same time, independent corroboration for expressivist theories of evaluative language.  In philosophical inquiry, such explanatory convergence is seldom accidental.  The simplest, most powerful hypothesis is that “finding” in this sense is indeed a state of affective appraisal—the very mental furniture expressivists has always placed at the centre of evaluative discourse.

1. INTRODUCTION  

A striking peculiarity of colloquial English is that the verb “find” comes in two quite different guises. In one use it is plainly cognitive and factive: “I found that the keys were under the newspaper” reports the discovery of a fact and presupposes that it is true. In the other use—the one exemplified by “Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty” or “She finds lying wrong”—“find” selects for evaluative material and, intuitively, speaks not to what the subject has come to know but to how she is oriented toward the target. Contemporary expressivists about value have seized on this contrast. If the state ascribed by the evaluative “find” is affective rather than cognitive, then the best explanation of its distribution is that value predicates such as “tasty,” “cruel,” or “wrong” likewise encode the expression of a non-cognitive affective stance. The present essay surveys the most important pieces of evidence in favor of that claim, canvassing argument‐forms drawn from theoretical linguistics, the philosophy of language, and experimental psychology. The cumulative case strongly supports the thesis that the “find-state” at issue is not a species of belief at all but rather a species of affect, belonging to the same natural class as loving, liking, appreciating, detesting, fearing, and so on.

2. SELECTIONAL RESTRICTIONS: ONLY EVALUATIVE COMPLEMENTS ARE ADMITTED  

Perhaps the most obvious datum is syntactic: the attitude verb “find” in its evaluative reading imposes a severe selectional restriction on what may occur in complement position.  

(1) a. Holmes finds [Saltimbocca tasty].  
    b. Holmes finds [that Saltimbocca is tasty].  
(2) a. *Holmes finds [Saltimbocca Italian].  
    b. *Holmes finds [that Saltimbocca is Italian].

While (1a) and (1b) are impeccable, (2a) and (2b) are at best heavily marked, despite “Italian” being a perfectly serviceable predicate elsewhere. What distinguishes the acceptable complements is that they involve evaluation—gustatory or moral—rather than mere description. The restriction is robust across the adjectival, verbal, and sentential complement positions where the relevant reading is available. In the canonical taxonomy of attitude verbs, purely cognitive verbs such as “believe,” “suppose,” or “know” exhibit no such constraint: anything capable of taking a truth value can embed under them. Hence the selective diet of evaluative complements strongly suggests that the attitude encoded by “find” interfaces not with truth‐conditional content but with value‐laden content—that is, with the sort of content characteristic of affective orientation.

3. FAILURE OF DEDUCTIVE CLOSURE  

Cognitive attitudes like belief are (at least normally) closed under obvious logical entailment: if Bert believes p and knows that p entails q, then ceteris paribus Bert is under epistemic pressure to believe q. “Find” attitudes are not. Suppose Holmes is an expert chef and therefore fully aware that everything tasty is edible. Still, “Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty” does not supply any reason to assert “Holmes finds Saltimbocca edible,” nor is the latter licensed by conversational implicature. The pattern replicates systematically with evaluative concepts whose descriptive entailments are transparent to the subject. In short:  

Closure under entailment – Belief: Yes.  
Closure under entailment – Find: No.  

The best explanation is that “find” does not attribute belief‐like states whose proprietary norm is truth, but affective states whose proprietary norm is felt liking or aversion. Affective states are not answerable to canons of deductive consistency in the way that beliefs are.

4. MOOREAN INFELICITY AND SELF-BLINDNESS  

Moorean sentences of the form “p but I don’t believe p” sound bizarre because asserting p pragmatically manifests the belief that p. A strikingly similar asymmetry arises with “find”:  

(3) ?“It is wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong.”  
(4) ?“Spinach is tasty, but I find spinach disgusting.”  

Speakers uniformly report these as infelicitous—“weird,” “hard to say with a straight face,” etc.—even though their descriptive counterparts are perfectly possible (“It is raining but I don’t believe it is raining,” said by someone who takes themselves to be deluded). The pattern is predicted if the surface assertion of “It is wrong to eat meat” conventionally expresses a negative affective orientation toward meat consumption and if the “find” clause explicitly denies having that orientation. The result is pragmatic incoherence. The data mirror the original Moorean paradox but only on the assumption that evaluative predicates function as affective‐attitude operators. Hence the parallel infelicity is linguistic evidence that “find” discourses and ordinary value assertions draw on the same stock of non-cognitive attitudes.

5. CONTRASTIVE NEGATION: “NOT FINDING” VS “FINDING NOT-p”  

A useful linguistic probe is the contrast between external and internal negation. With belief ascriptions, clausal negation scopes over the embedded proposition: “Anna does not believe that p” entails that Anna believes not-p is at least permissible if she is logically consistent. For “find,” by contrast, the two construals come apart:  

(5) Anna does not find lying wrong.       (allows: Anna is indifferent)  
(6) Anna finds lying not wrong.           (odd; sounds like a category mistake)

Sentence (5) merely says that Anna lacks a certain affective attitude; it is silent on whether she positively disapproves of calling lying wrong. Sentence (6) feels deviant in part because “not wrong” lacks evaluative force. The data show that “find” embeds a positive or negative affective stance rather than merely attributing a Garden Variety doxastic state that could harmlessly toggle between a proposition and its negation.

6. GRADABILITY, INTENSIFICATION, AND COMPARISON  

Affective predicates readily accept degree modifiers, gradable comparatives, and intensifiers: “love more,” “really hate,” “still appreciate,” “no longer admire.” The complements of “find” behave in the same way:

(7) a. Holmes really finds truffles delightful.  
    b. Holmes still finds Verdi overrated.  
    c. Holmes finds Puccini more moving than Verdi.

By contrast, cognitive verbs resist such modification unless the adverb targets meta‐attitudes about certainty rather than degree of liking:  

(8) *Holmes really believes that 17 is prime.  
(9) *Holmes finds more that 17 is prime than that 19 is prime.

The naturalness of (7a–c) and the oddness of (8–9) corroborate the claim that “find” patterns with affective predicates whose semantic skeleton encodes a scale of positive versus negative valence and whose syntax therefore allows the usual armor of degree morphology.

7. MOTIVATIONAL INTERNALISM AND PRACTICAL CONSEQUENCE  

From Hume onward, philosophers have noted that affective states come with built-in motivational force: if I genuinely fear the cliff’s edge, I form a disposition to avoid it; if Arthur loves music, he is spontaneously drawn toward musical venues. Evaluative “find” states show the same motivational profile. Someone who sincerely avers “I find being late embarrassing” ipso facto feels the pull of tidiness in punctuality and is disposed to apologetic behavior when the norm is violated. By contrast, one can coldly believe that tardiness is statistically disapproved of without being moved. The presence or absence of motivational upshot is therefore another diagnostic: “find” patterns with affect, not belief. While this is a philosophically argued premise rather than a purely linguistic test, its empirical predictions obtain in everyday behavior and in laboratory settings measuring reaction times and approach–avoidance tendencies.

8. EXPERIMENTAL PSYCHOLOGY AND NEUROIMAGING  

Recent fMRI studies (Gradin et al. 2015; Chandler & Hsu 2021) have compared brain activation when subjects judge descriptive sentences (“The Amazon is longer than the Nile”) to when they judge evaluative sentences (“Fur farming is cruel”). The former preferentially recruits the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and parietal regions implicated in controlled reasoning. The latter additionally or preferentially recruits the anterior insula, orbitofrontal cortex, and amygdala—areas classically associated with affective appraisal. Crucially, when the same sentences are embedded under “I find …,” the evaluative complement again lights up the affect network, whereas embedding under “I think that …” pushes activity toward cognitive regions. Such double dissociation lends direct empirical credence to the non-cognitive reading of “find.” While neuroimaging cannot by itself settle philosophical disputes, the convergence of data with the semantic diagnostics is impressive.

9. PHENOMENOLOGY AND FIRST-PERSON AUTHORITY  

Reportedly, introspection distinguishes believing p from finding p evaluated in some way. Belief presents its content as a representation of how the world is; “finding-tasty,” “finding-beautiful,” or “finding-wrong” present their content as a felt stance or orientation. The different phenomenology is backed by “immunity to error through misidentification” in the two cases. One can say “I believe the meeting is tomorrow, but I might be wrong about whose belief it is—it could be that I was interpreting someone else’s commitment.” In contrast, if I genuinely feel chocolate delicious, I cannot coherently doubt whether it is me or someone on the television who is having the experience. The immunity matches classical marks of affective conscious states: they are felt and owned in a first‐personal manner that beliefs are not.

10. NON-PROPOSITIONAL OBJECTS AND OBJECT-GAP  

Beliefs uniformly take propositional content but affective states happily take non-propositional objects—one can love Rome, admire Einstein, or find the E minor chord expressive. Significantly, “find” inherits this latitude:

(10) I find Rome wonderful.  
(11) I find this chord expressive.  

Try the same with a purely cognitive verb:

(12) *I believe Rome wonderful.  
(13) *I believe this chord expressive.
