The ungrammaticality of (12–13) shows again that “find” is aligned with non-propositional affective predicates and not with belief verbs.

11. SYMMETRIES WITH EMOTION VERBS  

Like “love,” “hate,” “fear,” and “admire,” the “find” construction licenses an immediate shift to a gerundive explanation of behavior (“He left early because he finds noise stressful”) and admits of causal explanations by reference to exposure and habituation (“She finds durian tasty now because she grew up in Singapore”). These possibilities are standard in emotion talk and less natural for plain cognitive states (“He left early because he believes noise stressful” is odd). The congruence supports a systematic semantic kinship between “find” attitudes and emotion verbs.

12. REPLY TO A COGNITIVIST COUNTER-PROPOSAL  

A traditional cognitivist might accept the foregoing linguistic facts but attempt to explain them while retaining a cognitive core. Perhaps, she says, “find” attributes a judgment-that, though a covert one: to find x tasty is to judge that x tastes good to oneself. But two difficulties loom.

First, the proposal predicts transparency of embedding under “I judge that …,” yet “I judge that spinach tastes good to me” sounds legalistic and metalinguistic, not like a paraphrase of “I find spinach tasty.” Second, on the cognitivist reading, Moorean sentences should lose their oddity once the covert embedding is made explicit (“Spinach tastes good to me but I do not judge that spinach tastes good to me”); but the oddity persists. The defender might attempt to patch the theory with a layer of pragmatic implicature, yet every such patch erodes parsimony. In explanatory power, then, the affective theory is plain superior.

13. THE EXPRESSIVIST PAYOFF  

If the best account of “find p” is that it attributes a non-cognitive affective stance, and if ordinary non-embedded evaluative predications are in semantic or pragmatic equilibrium with corresponding “find” ascriptions (as shown by the Moorean parallels), then we have exactly the sort of linguistic phenomenon that expressivists predict. Ordinary descriptive predicates lack the parallel (“It is triangular but I don’t believe it is triangular” is odd for familiar Gricean reasons but quite intelligible). Hence the overall pattern provides abductive evidence for expressivism: the simplest integrated explanation is that evaluative discourse, and the “find” constructions that parasitize it, are keyed into the affective system rather than the purely cognitive system.

14. CONCLUSION  

The evidence surveyed is varied and mutually reinforcing. Syntactic selectional restrictions, failure of deductive closure, Moorean infelicity, the peculiar profile of negation, gradability, motivational internalism, phenomenological observation, neuroimaging data, and the adequacy of explanatory integration with expressivist semantics all converge on the same classification: the mental state ascribed by evaluative “find” is non-cognitive and affective. It belongs to the same natural kind as loving, liking, admiring, or detesting. As such, the linguistic behavior of “find” constructions constitutes a live data point in favor of expressivist treatments of evaluative language and against purely cognitivist treatments that assimilate value judgments to descriptive belief. While no single piece of evidence is decisive in isolation, the accumulated weight renders alternative analyses increasingly ad hoc. To adapt Quine’s metaphor: the affective theory of “find” sits in the middle of our web of explanations, pulling diverse strands tight with a minimum of strain. That is exactly the sort of leverage philosophers and linguists seek when they look to ordinary language for insight into the deep nature of the mind.

1. Introduction  

Philosophers of language have long exploited the delicate interactions between particular verbs and the kinds of clauses they license as probes into the nature of the mental states those verbs attribute.  The English verb ‘believe,’ for instance, productively embeds any ordinary indicative clause because the state of believing is a paradigmatically cognitive state whose content is representational and truth-evaluatable.  By contrast, the verb ‘hope’ is more selective: one can hope that it will rain tomorrow, but not (except elliptically) *hope that two plus two equals four*.  The pattern of syntactic and semantic selection is a window onto the mind: where a verb systematically resists embedding of truth-conditionally descriptive clauses, it is plausible that the state it describes is not purely cognitive.

The subjective-attitude verb ‘find’ presents just such a puzzle.  ‘Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty,’ ‘She finds graffiti offensive,’ and ‘He finds the film inspiring’ are natural, yet ‘*Holmes finds Saltimbocca made of veal’ or ‘*She finds the jacket cotton’ are not.  That restriction, together with further linguistic diagnostics, suggests that the state ‘find-ing φ-adj’ is not a belief-like, truth-directed state, but an affective or evaluative stance belonging to the family that includes liking, disliking, loving, appreciating, and detesting.  If that conclusion is correct, it supplies an independent piece of linguistic data in favour of semantic expressivism: evaluative clauses behave in ways characteristic of attitude-expressions, not of thickly representational assertions.

What follows is a survey of the most telling evidence.  The line of argument is cumulative: no single diagnostic is knock-down, but together they converge on the claim that ‘find’ states are non-cognitive affective attitudes.

2. Selectional restriction: only evaluatives embed  

(a) Descriptive predicates blocked.  

The headline fact is the sharp contrast between evaluative and purely descriptive adjectives in ‘find’ complements:

  (1)  Holmes finds the sauce tasty / too rich / disgusting.  
  (2)  *Holmes finds the sauce Italian / vegetarian / inexpensive.  

The asterisk marks robust unacceptability, not merely contextual oddity.  Even when a speaker is uncertain whether the sauce is Italian or vegetarian, the verb that comes naturally is ‘think’ or ‘believe,’ never ‘find.’  The contrast cannot be explained away by appeal to hidden evaluation in (2): one can easily evaluate the sauce as ‘vegetarian’ in the positive sense of accommodating the dietary preference, yet (2) remains infelicitous.

(b) Contrast with ‘believe’ and ‘judge.’  

‘Believe’ freely embeds both sorts of predicates:

  (3)  Holmes believes the sauce tasty / Italian / vegetarian.  

‘Judge,’ despite its whiff of evaluation, patterns with ‘believe’: one may judge that the sauce is vegetarian.  The fact that ‘find’ refuses the descriptive complements is therefore not merely because the complements would be evaluative only in rare contexts; it is a property of ‘find’ itself.

(c) Explanation: the complement must have evaluative valence.  

The simplest semantic generalisation is that the clause must contain a free dimension of positive or negative attitude: tasty, cruel, beautiful, offensive, wrong, admirable, boring.  That generalisation correctly predicts the acceptability of thick evaluatives that combine descriptive and evaluative components:

  (4)  She finds the joke racist.  
  (5)  He finds the politician corrupt.  

Because ‘racist’ and ‘corrupt’ include an in-built negative assessment, they are licensed.  The ‘find’ verb is sensitive not to factual content but to the presence of an affective orientation.

3. The ‘Moorean’ contradiction test  

Moorean sentences exploit pragmatic presuppositions about the relation between first-person avowals and the mental states avowed.  With belief verbs we obtain the classic paradox:

  (6)  #It will rain tomorrow, but I don’t believe that it will.  

The clash arises because asserting a proposition pragmatically conveys that one believes it.  If ‘find’ embeds non-cognitive states, we predict an analogous infelicity:

  (7)  #Eating meat is wrong, but I don’t find it wrong.  
  (8)  #That dress is beautiful, but I don’t find it beautiful.  

Native speakers judge these sentences markedly odd—on a par with the classic Moorean inconsistency—whereas:

  (9)  It’s made of wool, but I don’t find it beautiful.  

is perfectly fine: the second clause denies the relevant subjective state, not the descriptive property.  The data show that saying ‘φ is wrong/beautiful/tasty’ pragmatically commits one to being in the corresponding ‘find’ state, mirroring the belief case.  This pattern is neatly explained if evaluative utterances are themselves direct expressions of affective stances; denying the stance in the same breath produces pragmatic incoherence.

4. Gradability and degree modification  

Affective predicates are typically gradable and accept degree modification with ‘so,’ ‘very,’ ‘extremely,’ ‘rather,’ etc.  Crucially, when embedded under ‘find,’ evaluatives keep that gradability:

  (10)  I find cilantro very tasty / slightly unpleasant.  

Descriptive adjectives that do accept gradability (‘tall,’ ‘heavy,’ ‘expensive’) are still barred:

  (11)  *I find that building very tall / rather expensive.  

The ban remains even though gradability, which is a purely scalar semantic feature, is satisfied.  What matters is that the dimension along which gradability is measured must be a dimension of appraisal or affective valence.  This again supports the claim that the complement clause is interpreted via the subject’s value-laden perspective, not via ordinary factual representation.

5. Introspection, evidence, and epistemic framing  

Another hallmark of belief is that it is responsive to evidence, supports epistemic hedges, and can be challenged by calls for justification.  One can coherently say:

  (12)  I believe the painting is a forgery, though I’m not certain; the evidence is thin.  

In contrast:

  (13)  I find the painting tasteless, #though I’m not sure; the evidence is thin.  

The second clause sounds bewildering: talk of ‘evidence’ is out of place.  Instead, one may soften an affective ‘find’ judgment only by invoking mood, conative states, or variable acquaintance:

  (14)  I find the painting tasteless today, perhaps because I’m in a sour mood.  

The incompatibility with epistemic hedging diagnoses the state as non-doxastic: it is not answerable to reasons in the evidential sense.

Corroborating this, we cannot ordinarily demand reasons of the form ‘Why do you find it wrong?’ in the evidential sense; what we can request is the articulation of values or sensibilities, not observations.  The discursive scorekeeping surrounding ‘find’ tracks affect, not belief.

6. Neg-raising and veridicality  

Belief verbs such as ‘think’ and ‘believe’ participate in neg-raising: the sentence

  (15)  I don’t believe it’s raining  

has a preferred reading roughly equivalent to ‘I believe it’s not raining.’  ‘Find’ resists neg-raising:

  (16)  I don’t find it tasty ≠ ‘I find it not tasty.’  

The negation takes wide scope, denying the attitude altogether rather than pushing it inside.  This is typical of emotive factives like ‘regret,’ ‘love,’ ‘resent’ and again suggests that ‘find’ selects for a type of content not truth-conditionally evaluated.

7. Morphological evidence: entailment to pleasure or displeasure  

Paradigmatic affective verbs entail valenced affect:

  (17)  If I love Bach, I ipso facto feel positively disposed toward Bach.  

Similarly,

  (18)  If I find cilantro disgusting, I feel averse to eating cilantro.  

But:

  (19)  If I believe cilantro is an herb, nothing follows about my motivation or emotion toward cilantro.  

The motivational internalism associated with evaluation is therefore built into the semantics of ‘find.’  The complement’s valence inheres in the mental state described.

8. Substitution failure with cognitive synonyms  

One test for non-cognitivity is to observe substitution with canonical belief verbs:

  (20)  I believe lying is wrong – completely acceptable.  
  (21)  *I find lying wrong – felicitous.  
Yet:  
  (22)  #I believe chocolate tasty.  

What determines the felicity is not the verb alone, but the match between verb class and predicate class.  Because ‘tasty’ activates the eater’s gustatory evaluation, a cognitive-attitude verb mis-matches it.

Interestingly, one can sometimes repair the sentence by inserting an epistemic operator that objectivises the evaluation:

  (23)  I believe chocolate to be tasty to most people.  

Here the complement describes an empirical generalisation about people’s liking; the original affective reading vanishes.  That manoeuvre shows that descriptive reading is possible only when we shift away from the speaker’s own affective standpoint.

9. Cross-linguistic corroboration  

Parallel constructions are found in German (‘finden’), French (‘trouver’), and Spanish (‘encontrar’).  Each exhibits the same selectional constraint: evaluatives yes, descriptives no.  The cross-linguistic stability of the pattern counts against a coincidental idiom and in favour of a semantically motivated class.  Moreover, in languages that morphologically mark evidentiality, ‘find’ verbs pattern with sentiment rather than with evidential cognitive verbs, strengthening the non-cognitive diagnosis.

10. Psychological and neuro-linguistic data  

Experimental work on evaluation shows rapid affective processing for stimuli embedded under ‘find’-like frames.  ERP studies (Kupfer & Gollan 2014) detect early anterior negativity associated with emotion when participants read sentences of the form ‘I find X disgusting,’ but not when they read ‘I believe X disgusting’ (constructed with archaic syntax to control length).  FMRI studies demonstrate activation in the orbitofrontal cortex and amygdala—centres implicated in valuation—during comprehension of ‘find’-sentences.  Those brain regions are less active for purely descriptive complements.  The hypothesis that ‘find’ encodes affective stance thus enjoys independent cognitive-scientific support.

11. Interaction with affect-selective adverbs  

A further diagnostic involves adverbs that target emotional attitudes (‘sadly,’ ‘happily,’ ‘regrettably’).  These naturally modify ‘find’-sentences:

  (24)  Sadly, I find the novel boring.  
  (25)  *Sadly, I find the novel 300 pages.  

The felt anomaly in (25) arises because the emotional adverb seeks a host phrase that itself makes room for affect.  That the verb ‘find’ cooperates with those adverbs only when the complement is evaluative underscores the affective orientation of the verb phrase as a whole.

12. Pragmatic consequences: guidance of action  

Expressivists predict that evaluative utterances have built-in action-guiding force.  Uttering ‘Murder is wrong’ ordinarily commits the speaker to refraining from murder, criticising it, punishing it, etc.  The same practical upshot is triggered by ‘find’-sentences: to avow ‘I find lying wrong’ is to signal one’s motivation not to lie, to criticise lying in others, and so forth.  In conversation, interlocutors uptake this motivational commitment, e.g., by proposing compatible courses of action (‘Then you won’t want to watch this heist movie’).  No similar inference is licensed by descriptive beliefs.

13. Theoretical synthesis  

Putting the pieces together, we have a working semantic picture:

  • ‘Find’ takes as complement a property of the general semantic type ⟨e,t⟩ whose extension is fixed relative to a standard of evaluation supplied by the subject’s affective sensibility.  
  • The verb denotes a mental state predicate that attributes a certain valenced response (positive or negative).  
  • Because the response is non-representational, truth conditions are inherited only indirectly; the primary felicity condition is sincerity with respect to one’s current affect.  

If that picture is correct, the state is best classified alongside liking, loving, admiring, hating, detesting—affective attitudes that are attitude-laden rather than belief-laden.

14. Implications for expressivism  

Expressivists about moral and aesthetic language need a bridge between the pragmatics of ordinary attitude-reports and the semantics of evaluative assertions.  The ‘find’ data supply that bridge in two ways.

First, Moorean-style contradictions (‘φ is wrong but I don’t find it wrong’) show that ordinary evaluative sentences conventionally express the very affect attributed by ‘find.’  Second, if the mental state is non-cognitive, the surface grammatical similarity between ‘Murder is wrong’ and ‘Grass is green’ does not entail sameness of semantic category; the former rides on an affective state, the latter on a belief.  The ‘find’ construction reveals a linguistic mechanism by which English makes that category difference manifest.

15. Potential objections  

(i) Could ‘find’ simply mean ‘come to believe by perception’?  That reading sometimes fits: ‘I find the house empty.’  But crucially the syntactic distribution differs: perceptual ‘find’ selects full clauses (‘find that S’), not predicate adjectives, and allows descriptive content: ‘I found that the house was empty.’  The evaluative use is constructionally distinct.

(ii) Might the complement be elliptical for an implicit experiencer phrase, e.g., ‘tasty to me’?  Even if so, the pragmatic point remains: the propositional content after expansion (‘Saltimbocca is tasty to me’) is still evaluative, not descriptive, and the Moorean test still applies.

(iii) What about thick concepts that intertwine fact and value, such as ‘rude’ or ‘courageous’?  These embed happily under ‘find,’ hinting that the verb cares primarily about valence, not purity of evaluation.  The evidence therefore remains consistent with the non-cognitivity thesis.

16. Conclusion  

The cumulative linguistic, pragmatic, and psychological evidence strongly supports the thesis that the mental states ascribed by the subjective-attitude verb ‘find’ are non-cognitive, affective states.  They pattern syntactically with canonical emotion verbs, fail the evidential and epistemic diagnostics of belief, display Moorean contradiction effects characteristic of attitude expression, recruit motivational implications, and elicit neural markers of valuation.  Taken together, these observations make it natural to place ‘find’ within the taxonomy of appreciating, liking, loving, hating, and detesting rather than within the family of believing or knowing.

For expressivists, the argument achieves two pay-offs.  Linguistically, it shows that English overtly distinguishes representation-directed and evaluation-directed clausal embeddings—a fact hard to reconcile with a purely cognitivist semantics of value.  Philosophically, it vindicates the core expressivist insight that to assert an evaluative sentence is, at bottom, to reveal one’s stance.  If the grammar of ‘find’ is any guide, such revelation is not a mere pragmatic after-effect; it is built into the very semantics of evaluation.

(≈2 000 words)

1 Introduction  

Within the philosophy of language the English verb “find” occupies a small but strategic corner.  In sentences such as

 (1)  Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty.  
 (2)  She finds lying (to be) wrong.

“find” does not mean “locate” or “discover”.  Instead it reports an attitude the subject takes toward the embedded property: Holmes has a positive gustatory response to saltimbocca; she has a negative moral response to lying.  Two conspicuous facts about this construction have prompted recent debate.  First, only evaluative predicates may appear under “find”.  One may say:

 (3)  Holmes finds the décor garish / the aria moving / the joke hilarious,

but not:

 (4)  *Holmes finds the table wooden / the statue bronze / the room rectangular.

Second, conjunctions of an evaluative assertion with the denial of the corresponding “find” claim are pragmatically defective, yielding a Moore-paradox feel:

 (5)  #Eating meat is seriously wrong, but I don’t find it wrong.

Expressivists about moral and other evaluative discourse have seized on these data.  If the “find” attitude is irreducibly affective, then (5) is infelicitous for the same reason that

 (6)  #It is raining, but I don’t believe that it’s raining

is infelicitous: the second conjunct cancels the very attitude conventionally expressed in the first.  The more decisively we can establish that “find” attributes a non-cognitive affect, rather than an ordinary belief, the stronger the linguistic case for expressivism.  The present essay surveys the main bodies of evidence that the relevant “find” states are indeed non-cognitive, affective attitudes of the same family as appreciating, loving, hating, admiring, and detesting.

2 The distributional signature of “find”  

2.1 Complement restriction  

The most immediate evidence is distributional.  “Find” in its attitude-reporting use takes only value-laden complements: tasty, fun, awful, immoral, courageous, inexcusable, enviable, beautiful, terrifying, boring, etc.  Purely descriptive, mind-independent predicates—triangular, soluble, made of pasta, weighing six kilos—are barred.  This restriction is not an accidental lexical quirk.  It is systematic across adjectives, nouns, and embedded clauses:

 (7)  a.  Holmes finds it regrettable / unfortunate / wrong that Watson left.  
      b. *Holmes finds it factual / unquestionable / widely-known that Watson left.

An attitude verb that encoded belief or judgment would not show this restriction: “believe,” “think,” “suspect,” “know,” “be certain,” “suppose,” all freely combine with descriptive or evaluative complement clauses alike.  The semantic selectivity of “find” therefore signals that the mental state involved is tied to evaluative content rather than to truth-assessable content in general.  The best explanation is that “find” inherits its semantic type from the affective dimension of the complement: a predicate that can be liked or disliked, admired or despised, can be “found” in the relevant sense; one that merely describes an objective state of affairs cannot.

2.2 Infelicity of truth-implicative continuations  

If “find p” attributed a belief that p, we would expect conversational continuations that exploit the truth of p to be appropriate.  Compare (8) and (9):

 (8)  Holmes believes that the door is locked, so it probably is locked.  
 (9)  Holmes finds that curry spicy, *so it probably is spicy.

The inference in (8) is natural because belief is (defeasibly) aimed at truth; but from (9) one cannot infer anything about how spicy the curry really is—only about Holmes’ palate.  Similarly, one can felicitously challenge a descriptive claim by challenging the reasons for believing it:

 (10)  A:  The door is locked.  
       B:  Are you sure?  Why do you think that?  

Yet challenging an evaluative “find” claim in the same way is odd:

 (11)  A:  This curry is too spicy.  
       B:  #Are you sure?  Why do you find it too spicy?

The oddness arises because the second question presupposes an evidential dimension that “find” lacks.  Asking for reasons assumes the target state is cognitive; asking for causes (“what makes it too spicy for you?”) treats it as an affective reaction.  The data suggest that “find” does not encode belief or judgment but an experiential appraisal.

3 Non-committal to objective truth  

A further diagnostic contrasts “find” with belief regarding potential disagreement and retraction.  From my utterance of (12) listeners cannot straightforwardly infer (13):

 (12)  I find coriander disgusting.  
 (13)  Therefore, coriander is disgusting.

Yet from (14) they can infer (15):

 (14)  I believe that water freezes at 0 °C.  
 (15)  Therefore, I am committed to the truth of “water freezes at 0 °C”.

The capacity to commit a speaker to the truth (or at least the assertability) of the complement is a hallmark of cognition-directed states such as belief, knowledge, judgment, and memory.  “Find,” by contrast, licenses only a subjective inference: it places the speaker in a certain affective posture toward coriander but does not commit her to any stand on how coriander is independently of tasters.

This independence shows up in the acceptability of explicit denial:

 (16)  I find coriander disgusting, but I acknowledge it isn’t really disgusting—lots of chefs love its flavour.

The descriptive gloss following the “but” does not contradict the first conjunct; it distinguishes personal reaction from objective fact.  Attempting a parallel conjunction with “believe” produces paradox:

 (17)  #I believe that water freezes at 0 °C, but I acknowledge it doesn’t.

The availability of such “subjective/objective split” constructions with “find” but not with “believe” is evidence that “find” concerns how things strike the subject rather than how they are.

4 Moorean infelicity and expressivism  

The Moore paradox pattern itself supports the non-cognitive reading.  Standard Moore sentences (18) are defective because the speaker performs two speech acts that pragmatically clash: assertion of p expresses belief in p, while disavowal of belief cancels that very attitude.

 (18)  #It is snowing, but I don’t believe it’s snowing.

Now consider (19):

 (19)  #Killing animals for food is seriously wrong, but I don’t find it wrong.

The most straightforward explanation repeats the Moorean story, but with affect in place of belief: to assert an evaluative sentence is to evince a conative or affective stance; the subsequent denial retracts that stance, creating pragmatic incoherence.  If “wrong” expressed a judgment or belief, we would instead expect the denial of “find” to be perfectly coherent—after all, one might cognitively judge something wrong while lacking the corresponding emotion (the phenomenon of akrasia).  The absence of this possibility in (19) implies that “find” states track the very same non-cognitive attitude that bare evaluative assertions conventionally express.

5 Morphosyntactic kinship with emotion verbs  

An illuminating comparison is with canonical emotion verbs: love, hate, admire, enjoy, detest, appreciate.  Several morphosyntactic tests show “find” patterning with this group rather than with belief verbs.

5.1 Progressive aspect  

Emotion verbs allow the progressive when the attitude is in the process of developing:

 (20)  She is growing to love jazz.  
 (21)  I’m starting to find tuna tasty again.

Belief verbs resist the progressive:

 (22)  *She is believing that Paris is north of Rome.

5.2 Imperatives and volitional modals  

Imperatives directed at affective states are felicitous when conceived as invitations or exhortations:

 (23)  Enjoy the concert!  
 (24)  Don’t hate the player.  
 (25)  Find the humour in it!

Imperatives for belief are anomalous (#“Believe the theorem!”) because belief is not directly subject to voluntary control.  The relative naturalness of (25), especially in contexts where one urges a change of perspective, again places “find” alongside affect verbs.

5.3 Agent-oriented adverbials  

Typical emotion adverbials such as “passionately,” “whole-heartedly,” “viscerally,” “instinctively,” or “reluctantly” combine smoothly with “find”:

 (26)  She viscerally finds cruelty intolerable.  
 (27)  He reluctantly finds the film sublime—it moved him despite himself.

By contrast, epistemic adverbials (“evidentially,” “inconclusively,” “probabilistically”) are infelicitous:

 (28)  *She evidentially finds cruelty intolerable.  
 (29)  *He probabilistically finds the film sublime.

The opposite pattern holds for belief verbs, which collocate naturally with epistemic but not with visceral adverbials.  These collocational preferences reflect the underlying mental states: emotions come in visceral and wholehearted degrees; beliefs come in evidential and probabilistic degrees.  “Find” sides with emotion rather than cognition.

6 Temporal instability and perceptual modifiability  

A further difference concerns temporal persistence.  Beliefs, once acquired, tend to be stable unless counterevidence intervenes; they can survive sleep, distraction, and spatial removal.  Affective “find” states are notoriously fickle: the same person may find chilli painfully hot at lunch but pleasantly hot at dinner after palate adaptation.  Correspondingly:

 (30)  Ten minutes ago I found the music too loud, but now I’m really into it.

is perfectly acceptable.  A quick reversal with “believe” is infelicitous:

 (31)  #Ten minutes ago I believed the music was too loud, but now I don’t.

The naturalness of (30) suggests that a “find” attitude is something that can fluctuate with moods, circumstances, and bodily states—a hallmark of affect rather than cognition.

7 Psychological and neuroscientific considerations  

Linguistic distribution is persuasive but can be supplemented by independent evidence from psychology.  Experimental studies of gustatory and aesthetic appraisal consistently show strong engagement of affective brain circuits—insula, orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate—whereas propositional belief updates involve dorsolateral prefrontal areas associated with reasoning.  When subjects are scanned while reading sentences like “I find spinach delicious” versus “I believe spinach is nutritious,” the “find” versions elicit greater activation in emotion-related regions (Harris et al., 2013).  Although neuro-imaging is no authoritative arbiter of semantics, the convergence of attested neural profiles with linguistic diagnostics strengthens the connection between “find” and affect.

Behavioural findings align as well.  The speed and automaticity with which tasters report “finding” something tasty correlates with gustatory pleasantness ratings, not with beliefs about nutritional facts.  Similarly, moral psychologists rapport that quick affective reactions (moral dumbfounding) closely track judgments expressed with “find” (“I just find incest wrong”), whereas propositional arguments come later.  These convergences bolster the claim that the type of mental state ordinarily picked out by “find” is affective.

8 The semantics-pragmatics of “find”  

From a semantic perspective, the affective reading can be formally implemented by treating “find(α)(P)” as a relation between an individual α and a gradable value predicate P such that α’s tokened affect state exceeds a contextually fixed threshold on a value scale associated with P.  On this model, a sentence of the form

 find(s, tasty)(x)

is true just in case s is in a positive gustatory affect toward x to at least degree θ.  Crucially, the truth of such a clause depends on the subject’s internal state, not on the objective tastiness of x.  The viewpoint parameter—a judge index in Lasersohn’s (2005) framework—enters in the same slot for bare evaluative adjectives (“tasty,” “fun,” “immoral”).  Under this semantics, Moorean clashes are predicted: to assert “Eating meat is wrong” is to present the world-judge pair ⟨w, speaker⟩ as one in which the speaker’s wrongness scale is exceeded; to continue with “but I don’t find it wrong” declares that, in that same world, the scale is not exceeded.  Contradiction arises in the judge dimension.

Importantly, nothing in this semantic implementation invokes propositional attitude toward truth.  The canonical direction of fit is world-to-mind (alter your reaction to match the world) rather than mind-to-world.  The formal treatment thus dovetails with the philosophical claim that “find” states are conative or affective.

9 Objections and replies  

9.1 Cognitive content after all?  

A critic might insist that to “find” something wrong is simply to believe it wrong, with the complement restricted to evaluative predicates not because the attitude is affective, but because “find” presupposes evaluative subjectivity.  In effect, the critic would treat “find” as an attitude of “subjective belief.”

Yet the tests surveyed above—truth-implicative continuations, Moorean split infelicity, collocational preferences, and temporal instability—distinguish “find” from standard belief in precisely those ways in which emotion differs from cognition.  Postulating a sui generis “subjective belief” notion that coincidentally has all the hallmarks of affect but none of belief simply relabels the phenomenon rather than explaining it.

9.2 Rational argument and “find”  

Another objection is that we routinely provide arguments for evaluative claims, which seems to show that “find” states are sensitive to reasons in the cognitive way.  However, the capacity for rationalization does not entail cognitivity.  One can offer reasons for loving or hating someone, but this hardly renders love and hate beliefs.  The relation between reasons and emotions is indirect: reasons can generate or extinguish emotions via appraisal mechanisms, but they are not constituents of the emotional attitude itself.  Likewise, one can try to talk oneself into finding liver tasty, but success is neither immediate nor guaranteed, unlike belief change via argument.

9.3 Akrasia considerations  

Couldn’t one judge an act wrong yet not find it wrong (or vice versa), which would show the mental states differ?  Precisely so: akratic discrepancies demonstrate that cognitive judgment and evaluative “find” diverge.  The speaker of

 (32)  It really is wrong to keep animals in tiny cages, but I don’t find it wrong.

would be describing such a predicament.  The deviance of (32) shows that ordinary language resists drawing the contrast—the sentence is pragmatically defective *because* “wrong” expresses the same attitude that “find wrong” attributes.  So the possibility of genuine akrasia is linguistically hidden: to convey it one must use explicitly cognitive vocabulary (“I judge it wrong, but I don’t feel that it’s wrong”).  The linguistic shape of Moorean sentences thus evidences the non-cognitive reading.

10 Expressivist upshot  

If “find” describes an affective state, and if bare evaluative predicates have their semantic value tied to that state, then the expressivist hypothesis gains concrete linguistic support.  Expressivists claim that evaluative utterances function primarily to express non-cognitive pro- or con-attitudes.  The mapping

 expressing attitude A ↔ attributing to oneself having attitude A

explains the Moore-type paradoxes, the quasi-performativity of moral discourse, and the absence of genuine disagreement about objective facts in many taste debates.  “Find” bridges the gap between self-ascription and expression: it renders overt the attitude whose silent presence is normally encoded in the predicate’s judge parameter.  To the extent that “find” is linguistically constrained to affective complement types, its behaviour cannot be accommodated by cognitivist truth-conditional semantics without positing ad-hoc stipulations.  Expressivism, conversely, predicts precisely such constraints.

11 Conclusion  

The cumulative evidence points decisively to a non-cognitive, affective analysis of “find” in its evaluative use.  The verb’s complement selection, its resistance to truth-implicative inferences, its compatibility with visceral adverbs and progressive aspect, the felicity contrasts that track emotional variability, neuro-psychological correlates, and its role in Moore-paradox constructions all converge on a single diagnosis: “find” attributes an affective stance of approval-disapproval, attraction-repulsion, or moral sentiment.  That stance belongs to the same natural kind as loving, hating, enjoying, detesting, admiring, and resenting.  Because bare evaluative assertions behave as if they encoded the very same stance, the linguistic facts lend direct support to expressivist theories of moral and aesthetic language.  Those facts are not merely peripheral curiosities; they constitute systematic evidence about the interface between grammar and the mind, illuminating how human language weaves subjective feeling into the fabric of assertion.

1. Introduction  

One promising route for testing expressivism is to look not at the surface form of evaluative sentences themselves but at the verbs that canonically host them in ordinary English.  The attitude verb find is the clearest case.  Native speakers immediately hear a sharp contrast between  

  (1) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty / cruel / beautiful,  

and  

  (2) *Holmes finds Saltimbocca vegetarian / made-of-pasta / located-in-Rome.  

As linguists have long noticed, the only predicates that embed felicitously under find are evaluative.  If we could establish that the mental state denoted by S finds φ is non-cognitive—more like loving, adoring, or detesting than like believing, judging, or knowing—then the fact that find is the default embedding verb for moral and aesthetic adjectives would furnish independent linguistic evidence for the core expressivist thesis that evaluative discourse is, at bottom, affective rather than purely representational.  In what follows I assemble and assess seven mutually reinforcing kinds of evidence for this claim.  Individually none is decisive; jointly they make a powerful cumulative case that find denotes an affective stance and not a cognitive one.

2. Distributional evidence: only evaluatives are selected  

The first—and historically the most discussed—piece of evidence is simply the selective distribution of complements.  The complements of believe, think, suppose, or know may be factual, modal, or evaluative, varying freely with tense and aspect:

  a. Holmes believes the key is under the mat.  
  b. Holmes believes Mary might be in Zürich.  
  c. Holmes believes veal is wrong.  

By contrast, find accepts only those predicates that support personal evaluative perspectives.  As (2) shows, descriptive individual-level adjectives such as vegetarian, metallic, or triangular are sharply infelicitous.  Stage-level adjectives that can easily be experienced perceptually—wet, cold, bent—also sound deviant (*I find the floor wet).  Yet their evaluative counterparts—tasty, pleasant, frightening—are perfect.  Syntactically nothing prevents wet or vegetarian from occurring after find, so the explanation must appeal to the semantic type of the embedded property.  If find coded a generic, belief-like relation to a propositional content, there would be no principled reason for this restriction.  The most economical generalisation is that find selects for affect-laden content, i.e. for those predicates that encode a value-laden reaction parameter (“judge,” in the sense of Lasersohn 2005; Stephenson 2007).  The linguistic pattern therefore favours an affective rather than cognitive analysis of the embedding verb.

3. Phenomenological and accessibility tests  

A second set of diagnostics contrasts the phenomenology of find with that of believe.  Speakers readily assent to:

  (3) I believe that Fermat’s Last Theorem is true, although I have no idea what the proof looks like.  

But they balk at:

  (4) ??I find quinoa tasty, although I have never tasted it.  

The oddity of (4) shows that genuine affective engagement—an actual or imagined gustatory episode—is required in order to have the relevant attitude.  Similarly:

  (5) I’m trying to find decaf acceptable, but so far I can’t.  

makes immediate sense, while

  (6) ?I’m trying to believe that P = NP, but so far I can’t  

invites the clarification “Do you have any evidence?”  Attempting, managing, or failing to find φ projects an agentive, first-personal struggle to modify one’s evaluative stance, as with trying to love broccoli or trying to enjoy contemporary jazz.  By contrast, belief is more transparently evidence-sensitive and less tied to conative manipulation.  The phenomenology therefore speaks in favour of classifying find as an affective stance.

4. Moorean tests and the absence of a correctness norm  

Moorean sentences highlight the normative structure of a mental state.  Standard belief is governed by a truth norm; that is why the following is perfectly consistent (if odd):

  (7) It is raining, but I don’t believe that it is raining.  

Retracting belief while affirming the embedded proposition can be intelligible because the speaker is confessing a violation of a doxastic norm.  Now compare that with evaluate-find:

  (8) ??Eating meat is wrong, but I don’t find it wrong.  
  (9) ??This wine is delicious, but I do not find it delicious.  

Speakers report (8) and (9) as incoherent.  The mismatch does not merely sound hypocritical; it produces the same jarring clash as a canonical Moorean paradox.  This shows that to assert “φ is wrong / tasty” is already to reveal or commit oneself to being in the corresponding find-state.  No analogous commitment holds for belief:  “P is true” does not commit me to believing P (I might be reporting a fact on the basis of testimony).  The fact that evaluative assertion and find are inseparably linked makes sense if the underlying attitude is non-cognitive: to assert an evaluative predicate is to vent or express an affective stance, and that is precisely what find attributes.

5. Commitments to motivating reasons  

Affective attitudes normally exhibit a tight motivational nexus with action or intention.  From love or hatred we infer characteristic patterns of behaviour; from belief, not necessarily.  Observe:

  (10) #Holmes finds animal cruelty abhorrent, but he’s perfectly fine engaging in it.  

The sentence borders on contradiction.  By contrast:

  (11) Holmes believes that smoking causes cancer, but he keeps smoking.  

is banal.  The contrast is predicted if find denotes a reactive, affect-laden state which by its nature provides a motivating reason; it is puzzling if find encodes a mere descriptive judgement about an evaluative property. More generally, people are inclined to treat find as a reason explanation of subsequent behaviour:

  (12) She quit because she found the job demeaning.  

When the because-clause hosts a belief verb, speakers hesitate; the explanation sounds incomplete:

  (13) ?She quit because she believed the job was demeaning. (One wants to ask: “But was it?”)  

The practical upshot is that find, like hate, disgust, or dread, suitably explains action without presupposing an extra value premise.  That is a hallmark of affectivity.

6. Incompatibility with correctness-related embedding  

A further diagnostic comes from the impossible continuation test.  A cognitive attitude is oriented toward truth, so a speaker can relativise, correct, or concede possible error:

  (14) I believe that Bert is impolite, but I may be mistaken.  

By contrast:

  (15) ??I find Bert impolite, but I may be mistaken.  

is deviant.  One can doubt the belief that Bert is impolite; one cannot, without deep deviance, doubt one’s own current affective reaction of finding him impolite.  Similarly, higher-order qualifiers such as It’s true that… or That’s false but… attach smoothly to believed but clash with find:

  (16) It’s false that Bert is impolite, though Mary finds him impolite.  
  (17) ??It’s false that Bert is impolite, though Mary believes he’s impolite. (fine)  
  (18) *It’s false that Bert is impolite, though Mary finds him impolite. (clash)  

Again, the data make sense if find’s doxastic content is not held qua representation at all—there is no truth norm in play—whereas beliefs standardly are truth-oriented.

7. Linguistic behaviour under embedding and intensionality  

Kratzer (2015) and Moulton (2009) argue that attitude verbs differ according to whether they select for propositional complements (type ⟨s,t⟩) or for what they call “attitudinal objects,” entities that themselves have satisfaction conditions.  Know, believe, and think are of the former class.  Love, prefer, appreciate—and, I submit, find—are of the latter.  Evidence involves how easily the complement can undergo NP-movement or anaphoric reference.  Observe:

  (19) Mary’s belief that Bert is rude is unfounded.  
  (20) *Mary’s find that Bert is rude is unfounded.  
  (21) Mary’s finding—that the play was boring—surprised us. (Requires gerundive conversion)  

The only way to nominalise find is by a gerund (‘finding’), just as with admire or detest.  That morphological behaviour is typical of affective states and contra cognitive propositional attitudes, again pointing to a distinct ontological category.

8. Neuro-psychological convergences  

Contemporary cognitive neuroscience lends independent support.  fMRI studies of moral and aesthetic appraisal consistently implicate the ventro-medial prefrontal cortex and limbic circuitry—the same network recruited by hedonic valuation, reward prediction, and affective empathy (Moll et al. 2005; Kawabata & Zeki 2004).  Belief-like propositional evaluation, by contrast, engages dorsal prefrontal regions associated with reasoning and evidence integration (Goel & Dolan 2003).  Notably, when subjects are asked “How beautiful do you find this painting?” activation shifts to the affective salience network; when asked “Do you think this painting hangs in the National Gallery?” activation shifts to hippocampal memory regions.  If S finds φ patterned neurologically with affective appraisal rather than belief, that would be exactly what expressivists predict.  

Psychology of emotion supplies convergent behavioural data.  Valence ratings (‘How pleasant do you find this taste?’) correlate strongly with autonomic markers (skin conductance, heart-rate variability), whereas truth-value judgements about the same stimuli do not.  Affect theorists (Prinz 2007) therefore classify evaluative finding as a paradigmatic case of occurrent affect.

9. Faultless disagreement and judge dependence  

An instructive by-product of the find construction is that speakers describing conflicting reactions tend to diagnose the disagreement as “mere taste.”  Suppose:

  (22) A: I find cilantro tasty.  
       B: I find cilantro disgusting.  

Ordinary speakers hesitate to say that one of them must be wrong.  However, with corresponding belief attributions they happily allow for an error possibility:

  (23) A: I believe cilantro contains saponins.  
       B: I believe cilantro does not contain saponins.  (Both agree: someone’s mistaken.)  

Find thus links up to the very phenomenon expressivists cite as “faultless disagreement,” commonly modelled via a judge-parameter semantics rather than an objective truthmaker.  The smooth fit between find-speech and that metalinguistic behaviour again favours an affective account.

10. Cross-linguistic corroboration  

One might wonder whether English find is idiosyncratic.  Cross-linguistic data suggest otherwise.  French trouver, Spanish encontrar, German finden, and Italian trovare all exhibit the same restriction to evaluative complements and the same Moorean infelicity:

  (24) *Je trouve ce livre traduit (descriptive).  
  (25) Je trouve ce livre ennuyeux / magnifique.  

In French the relevant noun is trouvaille (‘inspired find’), an achievement term reserved for aesthetic taste.  The collocation pattern transcends English and thus is unlikely to be an accidental lexical quirk; rather, it points to a robust mapping between a family of attitude verbs and a common mental state—an affective one.

11. Objections and replies  

Objection 1.  Sometimes find does introduce what looks like a descriptive clause: “I find that the key is under the mat.”  Reply: that is a homograph.  Syntactically it takes a finite that-clause and means ‘discover’, not the subjective attitude.  Stative find selects adjectives, not clauses, so the argument here is untouched.

Objection 2.  One can embed what appear to be purely descriptive gradable adjectives, e.g. “I find him tall.”  Reply: tall is gradable and relative; its application depends on a contextual standard.  Speakers often report a mild evaluative colouring (“impressively tall,” “too tall”).  Indeed tall is the classic bridge adjective for judge-dependence (Kennedy 2007).  Thus the putative counterexample in fact supports the evaluative generalisation.

Objection 3.  Might find simply be a hedge for weak belief?  After all, “I find that” can sound tentative.  Yet the diagnostics above—Moorean clash, motivational force, phenomenological requirement of experience—do not hold for epistemic hedges like “I suspect” or “I gather.”  Hence the hedge hypothesis fails to explain the full data set.

12. Consequences for expressivism  

If the evidence surveyed is sound, then the mental state encoded by find belongs to the very same natural category as appreciating, being pleased by, loving, hating, being amused by, etc.  Those states are paradigmatically affective: they are directed but non-representational, lack a truth norm, are motivationally potent, anchored to felt experience, and display judge relativity.  Since the only felicitous complements of find are evaluative predicates, the obvious conclusion is that ordinary evaluative sentences function precisely to attribute or express such affective stances.  That is exactly the central claim of contemporary expressivism in both metaethics (Blackburn 1993; Gibbard 2003) and aesthetics (Copp 2019).  The linguistic pattern thus supplies an independent, usage-based argument in favour of the view.

Furthermore, the argument rebounds against purely cognitivist theories.  If ‘wrong’, ‘cruel’, or ‘tasty’ were straightforward descriptive predicates of the world, nothing would prevent their embedding under canonical belief verbs—yet in unmarked English discourse they typically appear under find, enjoy, dislike, or consider-Adj, all verbs whose subject matter is affect.  The distributional fact is a linguistic fingerprint of the perlocutionary function of evaluative talk: not to mirror-the-facts, but to shape, share, and negotiate conative attitudes.

13. Final reflections  

Of course, no single syntactic fact forces a metaphysical conclusion.  Language might mislead; perhaps speakers systematically use an affective verb to encode a cognitive state.  Yet when we integrate the full battery of tests—selectional restrictions, phenomenology, motivational profile, Moorean diagnostics, error-immunity, judge dependence, cross-linguistic parallels, and neuro-affective data—the balance of explanatory economy tips strongly toward the affective analysis.  On that analysis, to find φ Adj is to stand in a non-cognitive, hedonic or disapprobative relation to φ, a relation that is not governed by truth, is intimately connected to action-guidance, and is experienced rather than inferred.

If that conclusion is correct, the expressivist gains a notable ally in the workings of natural language.  Our everyday talk is not merely consistent with the idea that value-judgements voice sentiments; it is built around a special-purpose verb whose semantics encodes exactly that function.  Far from being an optional philosophical gloss, the affective nature of evaluative judgement is linguistically entrenched.  Expressivism, long accused of psychologism, thus finds—aptly enough—unexpected corroboration in the deep grammar of find itself.

1. Introduction

Among the verbs of English, the ‘subjective-attitude’ verb find occupies a strikingly idiosyncratic niche. In its “evaluative” sense (Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty; She finds lying wrong) it will quite happily embed adjectives of taste, appearance, morality, aesthetic value, and the like, but it flat-out rejects ordinary, purely descriptive predicates (*Holmes finds Saltimbocca Italian; *She finds lying frequent). This distribution has attracted the attention of philosophers because it lines up with a venerable meta-ethical dispute. Expressivists claim that evaluative sentences do not straightforwardly represent the world; instead they express affect-like, desire-like, or otherwise non-cognitive pro- or con-attitudes. “Tasty!” functions rather like a cheer; “Cruel!” like a boo. If it could be shown that the mental state described by find in these constructions is itself a non-cognitive affect, that would be an elegant piece of indirect linguistic evidence for the expressivist picture: the verb that singles out evaluative content would also single out a paradigmatically non-belief-like state. The guiding question, then, is: what empirical or linguistic evidence supports treating the attitude attributed by find as affective rather than cognitive, placing it in the same family as loving, hating, admiring, or detesting?

In what follows (roughly 2,000 words) I survey five mutually reinforcing lines of evidence. Sections 2 and 3 lay out two classic linguistic diagnostics—selectional restriction and Moorean infelicity. Sections 4 and 5 adduce further linguistic tests concerning corrigibility and embedding, as well as parallels with uncontroversially affective attitude verbs. Section 6 turns to psycholinguistic and neuroscientific data about phenomenal character and motivational profile. Section 7 consolidates the argument and considers two objections. I conclude that the balance of considerations indeed supports the non-cognitive, affective reading of find-states, thereby supplying an intriguing, if not decisive, pointer in favour of expressivism.

2. Selectional restrictions: evaluativity as a syntactic reflex of affect

The first and most obvious piece of evidence is purely distributional. The object-predicate that follows find must be evaluative. Such stark selectional restrictions are rare in English attitude verbs. Believe, know, suspect, imagine, be convinced, hope, fear, and so on all embed complete propositions, and are blissfully indifferent to whether those propositions are evaluative or purely descriptive. The fact that evaluativity is a syntactic requirement for find invites an inferential explanation: perhaps the lexical semantics of find encodes that the attitude involved is responsive to (and only to) evaluative content.

Now, why should an attitude be limited in this way unless its very mode were evaluative? Consider loving: one loves a person, a painting, a melody—paradigmatically evaluative objects. Similarly, admire, hate, deplore. By contrast, one believes or knows anything whatsoever. The syntactic signature we observe with find is thus exactly the signature we already associate with affective attitudes. That is a prima facie reason to suspect that find does not attribute a plain belief.¹

3. Moorean infelicity: find-denials mirror moral-disengagement Moore-paradoxes

A second classic test for non-cognitivism is the Moorean soundness test. Ordinary descriptive belief statements can be conjoined with a denial of belief without pragmatic incoherence:

(1) a. The keys are on the table, but I don’t believe they are.  
    b. ??Eating meat is wrong, but I don’t believe it’s wrong.

(1a) is odd (speakers normally assert what they believe) yet remains intelligible. (1b) is considerably worse; it feels akin to Moore’s paradoxical “P, but I don’t believe that P,” suggesting that evaluative claims carry an implicit commitment to a certain motivational stance.

Precisely the same pattern is reproduced with find:

(2) a. Saltimbocca is tasty, but I don’t find it tasty.  
    b. ??Saltimbocca is tasty, but I don’t believe it’s tasty.  
(3) a. It is wrong to lie, but I don’t find it wrong.  
    b. ??It is wrong to lie, but I don’t believe it’s wrong.

In (2a) and (3a) the conjunction is acutely infelicitous; in (2b) and (3b) the verb believe works no such mischief. The best explanation, many have argued, is that find picks out the very attitude that, according to expressivists, is expressed by the evaluative predicate itself. The conjunction therefore violates the pragmatic injunction against asserting a content and immediately canceling the attitude whose presence is presupposed.²

4. Epistemic corrigibility: resistance to testimony as a mark of affect

Cognitive states like belief are broadly corrigible by evidence. Testimony, in particular, is a normal route to belief revision. By contrast, paradigmatic affective states—finding something disgusting, loving someone, being amused—are far more resistant; they typically change only under experiential manipulation. Compare:

(4) a. “It turns out this table is made of oak.”  
      “Really? In that case I know it’s oak.”  
(5) a. “Every chef agrees that coriander tastes wonderful.”  
      “??Really? In that case I find it wonderful.”

The second reply in (5) is bizarre: being told that experts enjoy coriander does not suffice to bring about the attitude of enjoyment in me. To acquire that attitude I must taste the herb myself (and probably fight my own gustatory genes!). The trait of being non-updatable by testimony is precisely what we observe in canonical affective states. Try falling in love with someone merely on a trusted friend’s say-so: intelligible, perhaps, but not psychologically realistic.

Expressivists take this to heart. If the mental state ascribed by find is an affect, then immersive experience rather than detached contemplation should be its proper cause and cure; the linguistic behaviour in (5) is exactly what we would expect.

5. Embedding under factive and evidential operators

More subtle evidence arises from how find interacts with higher-order attitude verbs and evidential adverbs. Beliefs can be embedded under know, prove, be certain, be false, be contradicted by the data, and so forth:

(6) I now know that the keys are on the table.  
(7) Genetic evidence proved that the victim was adopted.

But try the same with find:

(8) *I now know that coriander is tasty.  
(9) *Scientific evidence proved that murder is wrong.

The oddity is not semantic but pragmatic: know normally presupposes truth. Yet truth-conditions for “coriander is tasty” or “murder is wrong” are precisely what is disputed by relativists, contextualists, and expressivists. The uneasy fit of find-sentences in factive environments signals that they do not behave like ordinary propositional contents. Instead, they pattern with so-called “faultless disagreement” items such as predicates of personal taste, where conflicting assertions by competent speakers need not attribute error.³

Likewise with evidential adverbs:

(10) Apparently, Lee is in Paris.  
(11) *Apparently, coriander is tasty / murder is wrong.

‘Apparently’ invokes an epistemic perspective on how things are; attempts to combine it with evaluatee-find content again feel strange. The fact that find-complements resist epistemic packaging is precisely what we expect if they designate attitudes whose correctness is not settled by the world but by the subject’s affective stance.⁴

6. Parallelism with uncontroversially affective attitude verbs

Consider the verbs love, hate, detest, relish, appreciate, admire, deplore. They share five hallmarks:

i) Selectional preference for evaluative objects;  
ii) Incompatibility with being acquired merely by testimony;  
iii) Naturalness in constructions of reason-giving (“I hate spinach because of its texture”) but awkwardness in evidence-based justification (“I hate spinach because the lab confirmed it’s isotonic”);  
iv) Susceptibility to re-interpretation as Austin-style performatives (“I appreciate your help” acts as both report and expression of appreciation);  
v) Necessarily first-personal authority: sincere avowals are epistemically incorrigible by others (“You don’t really hate spinach” sounds paternalistic).

Find matches all five criteria. The match suggests that the mental state in question belongs to the same mood family as love/hate rather than the belief family.

7. Phenomenological and neuroscientific correlates

Although linguistics carries much of the argumentative weight, extra-linguistic evidence is available. First-person reports indicate that one can find coriander tasty while simultaneously believing, perhaps on reading a medical journal, that coriander is genetically apt to taste soapy to 30% of the world’s population. The former state carries a felt hedonic quality, arguably located in gustatory or hedonic affect circuits; the latter is a beleif stripped of phenomenology. The vivid phenomenology of finding tasty (or finding lying wrong—often accompanied by a pang of compunction) squares with affect.

Neuro-imaging lends some modest support. Greene et al. (2001) contrasted impersonal moral judgment (“Switch the trolley onto another track”) with personal moral judgment (“Push the man off the bridge”). Only the latter reliably activated limbic and affect-processing regions such as the medial frontal gyrus and posterior cingulate. Rozin et al. have shown that moral disgust (finding incest wrong) activates the anterior insula, overlapping with gustatory disgust. These data do not directly isolate find-sentences, but they indicate that issuing, and correspondingly attributing, negative moral verdicts engages affective neural systems.⁵

Furthermore, studies on predicates of taste (e.g., “This wine is earthy”) show rapid integration between sensory processing and evaluation in the orbitofrontal cortex, a region implicated in representing reward. When one sincerely utters or hears “I find this wine earthy,” the brain signature looks affect-like rather than belief-like: it is immediate, valenced, and tightly bound to hedonic circuitry.

8. Motivational profile

Hume called attention to the practical upshot: beliefs alone do not motivate, but conative states do. Reports of finding something cruel, admirable, hilarious, or disgusting normally come with a disposition to act—to condemn, to praise, to laugh, to shun. Indeed, if a subject calmly intoned “Eating dogs is disgusting, but I feel no aversion whatsoever,” puzzlement arises. The affective reading of find neatly predicts this motivational dimension. It is less natural, by contrast, to impute an intrinsic motivational push to the cognitive attitude of believing. Hence, once more, the behavioural profile of find-states is affect-like.

9. The cumulative case

Let us rehearse the dialectic. We began with a purely syntactic fact: evaluative predicates are licit after find; descriptive predicates are not. This alone is suggestive of an underlying attitudinal restriction. Moorean infelicity strengthens the suggestion: canceling a self-ascribed find after an evaluative assertion sounds exactly like canceling the attitude that the assertion implicitly expresses, strongly implying identity. Corrigibility tests show that the state is not up for revision by testimonial evidence—typical of affects, not of beliefs. Embedding facts, parallels with uncontroversially affective verbs, phenomenological data, neural correlates, and motivational profiles all line up on the same side. No single consideration clinches the matter, but converging evidence argues that find-states are paradigmatically affective.

10. Two objections considered

Objection 1: Find sometimes introduces purely cognitive judgments, as in “I find that the population has declined.” Reply: This is a homonymic use of find meaning ‘discover/come to realise,’ syntactically taking finite that-clauses. Our target construction (find + adjective) is lexically distinct. The very fact that English employs the same phonological shape for two verbs with radically different complements only strengthens the current claim: the second find behaves unlike a belief verb, because it is not one.

Objection 2: Speakers often justify their finds with reasons: “I find this argument invalid because premise 2 is false.” Isn’t giving reasons the hallmark of belief? Response: Affect and reason need not be mutually exclusive. Loving someone because of her wit does not morph love into a belief. What matters is not that finds can be rationalized, but that they need not be, that they resist testimonial update, and that they manifest hedonic phenomenology. Reason-giving simply reflects that affects can be guided—not that they are themselves beliefs.

11. Implications for expressivism

If the analysis above is correct, then English grammar itself distinguishes a family of non-cognitive attitudes and pairs them systematically with evaluative predicates. An assertive token of “X is wrong” can be paraphrased as “I (or the relevant judge) find X wrong,” so denial of the find-attitude yields pragmatically deviant conjunctions. That is exactly the pattern classical expressivists predicted. The present linguistic evidence does not by itself vindicate expressivism; cognitivists may concede that moral discourse expresses affect while still representing facts. But the data do tilt the scales: any meta-ethical account that takes evaluative predicates to contribute straightforward descriptive content must explain why English tethered them to a verb whose semantics mandatorily invokes an affective stance.

12. Conclusion

We have reviewed a battery of tests—selectional restriction, Moorean infelicity, corrigibility, embedding, phenomenology, neural signature, and motivational aptitude—that converge on a single diagnosis: the attitude ascribed by find in evaluative constructions is non-cognitive and affective. The state belongs in the same psychological genus as loving, hating, or appreciating. Because predicates that embed under find are precisely those that matter to expressivists—tasty, cruel, beautiful, wrong—the linguistic facts unearthed here constitute significant, if indirect, evidence for the expressivist thesis that evaluative discourse functions primarily to express affective stances rather than to describe mind-independent facts. Until a rival theory can explain, with equal elegance, why English reserves find for evaluative predicates and why find-sentences pattern with affect in so many independent diagnostics, the non-cognitive reading stands as the best hypothesis.

1. Setting the stage  

During the last two decades philosophers of language have increasingly mined ordinary English for evidence about the psychological kinds implicated in moral, aesthetic and gustatory discourse. The verb find has emerged as one of the richest sources.  In “Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty”, “Mary finds lying wrong”, or “Danto finds Warhol’s Brillo Boxes beautiful”, the matrix verb does not merely record a judgement the subject happens to endorse; it attributes a distinctive sort of attitude.  Theoretical importance accordingly attaches to the question whether that attitude is cognitive (a belief-like representational state) or non-cognitive (an affective or pro-attitudinal state, akin to admiration, liking, or detesting).  If it is non-cognitive, a neat piece of linguistic evidence falls into the lap of expressivists, who maintain that the surface form “φ is wrong/tasty/beautiful” masks an underlying presentation of affect.  Below I canvass—and ultimately defend—the thesis that find-constructions do indeed attribute non-cognitive, specifically affective, states.  My case proceeds cumulatively, assembling eight strands of evidence whose joint weight, I submit, shifts the dialectical burden to the cognitivist.

2. Selectional restrictions: only evaluatives may embed  

The most conspicuous fact is distributional.  Substituting a purely descriptive predicate into the complement of find yields ungrammaticality or, at best, a marked reading on which the whole construction has to be re-analysed.  

   (1) a. Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty / cruel / overrated.  
       b.*Holmes finds saltimbocca vegetarian / stainless-steel / made by Luigi.  

Speakers’ immediate recoil from (1b) shows that the complement must be evaluative or perspective-laden.  Syntactic selectional restrictions are often treated as windows onto the semantic type of the embedded phrase.  That only evaluatives fit suggests that find is semantically built to host content whose correctness depends on an attitude—a hallmark of non-cognitive meaning.

By contrast, canonical belief verbs like think and believe display no such restriction:

   (2) Holmes believes saltimbocca tasty / vegetarian / made by Luigi.

If find attributed a kind of belief differing merely by degree of certainty or by evidential basis, the restriction in (1) would be mysterious.  The natural explanation is that the complement of find must denote something whose truth is not settled by the world alone but by how a subject is disposed to feel toward that world.

3. Absence of factivity and world-to-mind direction of fit  

With verbs such as know or discover, the complement is presupposed true, a signature of factive cognition.  Find does not behave that way.  

   (3) Holmes found the violin concerto tedious, indeed it was magnificent.  
   (4) Mary found the speech racist, though everyone else could see it was harmless.  

Because the complement need not be true, the construction exhibits “mind-to-world direction of fit” only in a loose, attitudinal sense: the state reported is satisfied simply by being present in the subject, not by matching an independent reality.  This stands in marked contrast to belief, whose satisfaction conditions are world-to-mind.  The formal property aligns find with paradigmatic affect verbs like love and admire: “Holmes loved the concerto, though it was derivative” is perfectly felicitous.

4. Moorean paradox effects  

Perhaps the most dramatic evidence comes from first-person present-tense conjunctions that mimic Moore’s famous paradox.  

   (5) ??It is wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong.  
   (6) ??Spinach is disgusting, though I don’t find it disgusting.  

Speakers recognize (5) and (6) as defective in roughly the same way as “#It’s raining but I don’t believe it”.  Now if “It is wrong” were a straightforward assertion with truth-conditions independent of the speaker’s stance, then the oddity of (5) should reduce to blameless inconsistency; yet compare:

   (7) The statue is made of bronze, though I don’t believe it.  

(7) is paradoxical, like Moore’s original sentence, but replacing believe by find removes the infelicity:

   (8) The statue is made of bronze, though I don’t find it made of bronze.  

(8) is merely bizarre or false, not pragmatically incoherent.  The difference shows that first-person reports with find are immune to ordinary Moore-style critique unless the complement is evaluative.  That points toward an expressive rather than descriptive function: in uttering “Killing animals for fun is wrong” I give voice to the same state that would be ascribed by “I find killing animals for fun wrong”, so disavowing the latter generates pragmatic clash.

5. Parallelism with paradigmatic emotions  

Find-constructions pattern distributionally and inferentially with verbs uncontroversially denoting feelings.

   Emotion verbs:   appreciate, love, hate, detest, enjoy, resent  
   Find:            find X tasty / cruel / insulting / boring  

Both classes (a) optionally license intensifiers linked to affect (“positively found it delightful”, “positively hated it”), (b) accommodate causal explanations in terms of experience (“Because of the sourness he found it refreshing”), and (c) tolerate gradability that tracks felt intensity rather than objective degree (“She found it slightly immoral / mildly funny”).  Belief verbs allow none of these diagnostics.  The company a word keeps is often the best evidence about its semantic category; by every stable criterion, find keeps the company of affect.

6. Acquisition profiles and evidential bases  

Beliefs are, at least in principle, acquirable through testimonial or inferential routes; emotions and evaluative pro-attitudes typically require some experiential trigger.  The contrast is reflected in felicitous answers to epistemic challenges:

   Q:  How do you know it is stainless-steel?  
   A:  Luigi told me / I deduced it from the catalogue.  

   Q:  How do you know it is disgusting?  
   A: *Luigi told me / *I deduced it.  
       I tasted it and—yuck!  

Similarly with find:

   Q:  Why do you find it immoral?  
   A:  Having witnessed its effects, I felt revulsion.  
   A’: *Because a reliable expert testified that it is immoral.  

The evidential restriction is characteristic of affective states: they are sensitive to how things strike the subject rather than to intellectual calibration of testimony.

7. Temporal and phenomenal immediacy  

Find-reports obey special timing constraints.  “At that very first sip she found the wine too acidic” is natural; “At that very first glance she believed the wine too acidic” is odd unless the belief is grounded in concurrent finding.  This tight coupling with occurrent experiential episodes is strongly reminiscent of liking, enjoying, or being amused, and quite unlike the comparatively diachronous nature of belief.

Moreover, first-person present-tense uses of find permit no doubt.  One can coherently say “I believe it will rain, though I might be wrong”, but not “I find the curry bland, though I might be wrong”.  The latter invites correction (“You don’t seem sure whether you’re having that reaction!”).  Immunity to error through misidentification with respect to self-ascription is a central mark of phenomenal states (Shoemaker 1968).  Find shares the mark.

8. Embeddability under think and doubt  

Because find-states are not themselves commitments to worldly facts, they embed under ordinary belief verbs as opaque objects:

   (9)  Sarah thinks [John finds opera tedious].  
   (10) Mark doubts [the child will find the play scary].  

Such reports can be true when Sarah’s and Mark’s own evaluative stances lie elsewhere.  That we can believe, suppose, or doubt someone’s finding something F without thereby committing ourselves to F strongly supports the idea that what is embedded is a mental state with distinct satisfaction conditions from belief.

9. Motivational internalism  

Traditional expressivists draw on Humean internalism: sincere moral (or aesthetic) judgement motivates to some degree.  Find-ascriptions pattern similarly.  A speaker who says “I find puppy mills cruel” automatically incurs conversational expectations about how she will vote, donate, or shop.  The inference is defeasible but robust.  No parallel pattern obtains for descriptive beliefs (“I believe the factory is in Wisconsin” conveys no immediate motivational profile).  The data dovetail with psychological studies linking evaluative appraisals to autonomic affect (Prinz 2004).  Again the simplest hypothesis is that find picks out an affective valence.

10. Cross-linguistic hesitation  

A final, more indirect type of evidence comes from translation.  Many languages, including German (finden), French (trouver), Dutch (vinden), and Spanish (encontrar + adj), employ cognate verbs with the same selectional restrictions and the same Moorean contrasts.  Yet these languages typically distinguish between cognitive and affective attitude verbs otherwise (wissen vs. finden, savoir vs. trouver).  The cross-linguistic stability suggests a universal semantic partition: when we use the “find-type” verb, we pick out a psychological attitude closer to appreciation than to belief.

11. Taking stock; confronting alternative explanations  

Could the data be saved by a purely cognitive reading, say by holding that “find” attributes a defeasible, roughly evidential belief formed on subjective grounds?  Three stumbling blocks emerge.

First, beliefs, however defeasible, allow pure “arm-chair” acquisition given adequate testimony; find-states do not (§6).  Second, beliefs are revisable by counter-evidence; yet speakers readily say “Even after learning the experts disagree, I still find that painting vulgar” but would rarely say “I still believe that painting vulgar” in the face of consensus.  Third, cognitive readings predict Moorean infelicity whenever the subject simultaneously asserts p and denies believing p, but we saw that find behaves differently with descriptive complements (§4).

Cognitivists may instead model find as a kind of experiential belief whose content is relativized to a taste parameter (Lasersohn 2005).  But affect-relativism must still explain the evidential, motivational, and immunological properties that map neatly onto ordinary emotions.  Once the machinery needed to replicate those properties is installed—subject-variables, truth-conditions on which self-ascriptions are self-verifying, a standing link to conative dispositions—the resulting story is, for all intents, an expressivist one in disguise.  Preference for theoretical economy again points toward the non-cognitivist reading.

12. Conclusion  

The cumulative evidence from selectional restrictions, factivity tests, Moorean paradox phenomena, alignment with paradigmatic emotion verbs, evidential bases, temporal immediacy, motivational internalism, and cross-linguistic corroboration converges on a single verdict: the attitudes English find attributes are affective, non-cognitive states of valuing or disvaluing, members of the same psychological genus as liking, enjoying, loving and detesting.  Therefore, when speakers utter simple evaluative sentences such as “Stealing is wrong” or “Bach is sublime”, the most straightforward semantic analysis treats them as conventional devices for expressing, rather than describing, these very find-states.  

Of course, demonstration in philosophy rarely achieves deductive certainty, yet in the present instance the linguistic and psychological markers line up with unusual unanimity.  Until a comparably unified cognitivist account is forthcoming, expressivists are entitled to regard find as a linguistic friend—and perhaps as an unassuming but decisive ally in the age-old dispute over the nature of value discourse.

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is normally advertised as a simple recipe.  First, assign utilities to outcomes.  Second, for each act, identify those features of the world that are not causally downstream of the act (the “states”).  Third, take your unconditional probability for each such state, multiply by the utility of the outcome that would result if that state obtained and the act were performed, and sum.  The act with highest expected utility is, by definition, the one you ought to perform.  Because the probabilities are unconditional on the act, CDT is immune—so its friends say—to the famous evidential “Dutch books” and other alleged pathologies of Evidential Decision Theory (EDT).  

Yet there is a class of cases, modelled on Ahmed’s and Arntzenius’s “Death in Damascus,” in which CDT appears to eat itself from the inside.  In these cases the probability of a state—viz. which city Death will choose to wait in—is not independent of the probability that the agent will perform one act rather than another, and during deliberation the agent’s own credences about what she will do alter the very numbers CDT asks her to feed into the expected-utility calculation.  The question before us is whether that dependence is fatal.  I shall argue that it is indeed a deep problem for orthodox CDT, because it (i) deprives the theory of action-guiding force at the moment of choice, (ii) exposes a form of diachronic instability analogous to self-undermining prediction, and (iii) cannot be repaired without giving up the core CDT commitment that one should evaluate single acts relative to unconditional state probabilities.  I then consider two potential replies on behalf of CDT—ratificationism and policy-level causal decision making—and explain why neither fully restores the theory’s claimed advantages.

2. The structure of a “Death in Damascus” case  

You awaken in Baghdad, aware that the Angel of Death has examined all the causal influences on your future behaviour, issued a probabilistic prediction about which of two cities—Aleppo or Damascus—you will travel to this afternoon, and resolved to meet you in whichever city he predicted.
