Experience and testimony assure you that Death’s method is highly reliable, though not infallible: if he says “Damascus” he is right 90 % of the time; if he says “Aleppo” he is right 90 % of the time.  Unfortunately you have not been told his prediction; all you know is an actuarial fact about his dispositions—because of some quirk in his reasoning he is antecedently more likely to predict Damascus than Aleppo.  Concretely, let

• P0(Damascus-prediction) = 2⁄3  
• P0(Aleppo-prediction)   = 1⁄3.

You also know your utilities.  Surviving the day is worth +10; meeting Death is worth −10.  Travel costs are negligible.  Your only decision is which city to go to.

Standard CDT says: list the states that are causally independent of your act.  Here “which city Death is in” is such a state, because Death travelled before you deliberate; your own choice does not cause or influence his location.  CDT therefore instructs you to assign unconditional probabilities to “Death in Damascus” and “Death in Aleppo,” then compute:

EU(Aleppo)   = P0(Death in Aleppo)   × (−10) + P0(Death in Damascus)   × (+10)  
EU(Damascus) = P0(Death in Damascus) × (−10) + P0(Death in Aleppo)   × (+10).

Whichever is bigger determines what you should do.  Simple—except that P0(Death in Aleppo) is not some fixed external constant.  Given the story, Death is in Aleppo if and only if he predicted Aleppo, and he predicted Aleppo largely because he predicted that you would go to Aleppo.  If, before deliberation starts, you regard yourself as 30 % likely to go to Aleppo, you will assign roughly P0(Death in Aleppo) ≈ 0.3 (modulo the predictor’s 90 % reliability) and P0(Death in Damascus) ≈ 0.7.  Those numbers make EU(Aleppo) worse than EU(Damascus), so CDT will say: “Go to Damascus.”

But the instant you accept that advice you revise the subjective probability that you will go to Aleppo downward, perhaps to 5 %.  That in turn drives P0(Death in Aleppo) down to 5 %.  With those new inputs EU(Damascus) becomes −8 (because Death is now almost certainly there) and EU(Aleppo) becomes +8.5.  So CDT now whispers: “No, no—go to Aleppo.”  Recognising the whisper, you shift your credence again, and the pendulum swings back.  There is no fixed point except at the unstable equilibrium where P0(Death in Aleppo) = P0(Death in Damascus) = 0.5, a condition that neither the underlying story nor your psychology supports.

The dependence of the evaluation on your own credence that you will perform the very act under consideration thus makes CDT’s advice bounce with every tremor of introspection.  Is that a genuine flaw?

3. Guidance failure: Why oscillation matters  

A decision theory is, in part, a practical instrument.  It earns its keep by telling deliberating agents what to do.  At the moment of choice you must be able to insert numbers you already posses into a rule that outputs a definite recommendation.  Orthodox CDT provides a determinate algorithm only if the unconditional probabilities it uses are well-defined in advance of deliberation.  In Death-type cases they are not.  The state “Death is in Damascus” is not an exogenous parameter; it is epistemically correlated with—and statistically functions of—your own choice probabilities.  Because those probabilities are endogenous to the very act of deliberation, the input on which CDT relies drifts as deliberation proceeds.  The result is:

• Lack of convergence.  There need be no stable “deliberative equilibrium” whose associated act maximises expected utility in CDT’s sense.  
• Self-undermining counsel.  As soon as the agent commits, the evidential situation changes, flipping the recommendation.  
• Practical paralysis.  A live human deliberator cannot follow CDT, because every time she tries to follow it she must reconsider, ad infinitum.

One might reply that this is merely a psychological inconvenience, not a theoretical vice.  Decision theory, after all, is a normative idealisation; it may legitimately assume that perfectly rational agents possess perfectly sharp probabilities over their own future acts.  The trouble is that the instability here is not a product of human frailty; it follows from CDT’s own instructions about what probabilities to use.  No coherent prior that an agent could adopt at time t = 0 simultaneously satisfies (i) CDT’s mandate to treat act probabilities as evidentially and causally independent of the states, and (ii) the empirical information that the states are generated by a process sensitive to the very same act probabilities.  In other words: there simply is no probability function that fulfils CDT’s static constraints once the correlation mechanism is acknowledged.

4. Diachronic inconsistency and Dutch-book vulnerability  

A separate, and arguably deeper, problem is that the oscillation induces diachronic inconsistency akin to money-pump scenarios.  Suppose a bookmaker approaches during deliberation and offers bets that CDT, at that instant, assesses as fair.  You accept.  Two minutes later your credence distribution changes and you now regard those very bets as unfavourable.  If the bookmaker is patient she can exploit each swing, extracting a sure loss over many cycles.  (This is formalised in Spencer & Wells 2019.)  Thus CDT, the very theory devised to avoid evidentialist Dutch books, inherits a temporal version of the same vice when faced with prediction-dependent states.

One might insist that rational agents would refuse to trade until their credences settle.  But the premise of the case is precisely that no such settling point exists.  So either the CDT agent never trades (contradicting the assumption that she can rank bets at all times) or she becomes money-pumpable.  Either outcome undermines the claim that CDT protects the coherence of preference and belief better than its rivals.

5. Is the dependence avoidable?  Three attempted escapes  

5.1 Treat own act probabilities as zero–one propositions  

A traditional manoeuvre is simply to set, at the moment of acting, P(I do Dam.) = 1 and P(I do Aleppo) = 0 (or vice versa) on the grounds that perfectly rational agents have no uncertainty about what they are about to do.  That forces CDT to use the corresponding state probabilities (Death in Damascus = 1, etc.), yielding a determinate answer after all.  But the result is catastrophic: whichever city you pick, you render it certain that Death is there, so CDT says the utility of that act is −10, while the alternative act (which you give probability zero) looks risk-free and scores +10.  Hence CDT will brand every act you are about to perform as irrational.  Orthodoxy collapses into global akrasia.

5.2 Adopt Jeffrey’s “ratifiability” constraint  

Richard Jeffrey proposed that a rational act should be one that would still look optimal to you after you learned with certainty that you had decided to perform it.  That is, an act is rational only if it “ratifies” itself.  In Death in Damascus the only ratifiable attitude is to assign equal probability to both cities, thereby neutralising the predictor’s bias.  The theory then recommends randomisation.  While this yields a coherent prescription, two worries loom.

First, nothing in classical CDT licences adding the ratifiability constraint; it is an extraneous harmony requirement.  Once we grant that type of modification, why not adopt the evidentialist’s harmony principle (choose the act that maximises conditional expected utility given that act) and be done with CDT entirely?

Second, ratification selects a unique mixed strategy only because of the artificial symmetry of the toy case.  In more complex predictor settings, there may be no ratifiable act, or too many, re-introducing the guidance failure.

5.3 Move to policy-selection or updateless CDT  

A more radical escape replaces act evaluation with policy evaluation.  Instead of asking “Should I go to Aleppo?” the agent asks “Which mapping from perceptual inputs to moves should I have pre-committed to?”  The policy’s expected utility is assessed using pre-commitment probabilities, before the predictor has extracted any information.  This “updateless” view (see Yudkowsky and Soares 2017) nullifies the dependence on current act probabilities, because the relevant probabilities are frozen at an earlier epistemic time slice.  In Death in Damascus the winning policy is either to commit to Aleppo (if the predictor’s bias is weak) or to toss a fair coin (if the bias is strong), and that verdict remains stable throughout subsequent reflection.

However, the move gives up CDT’s defining feature—that it tells agents how to act given their present information.  Updateless theories supply ex ante rules for pre-commitment; they do not instruct an already-uncommitted agent at the moment of choice.  Consequently the defender must concede that orthodox, synchronic CDT is indeed inadequate; only a temporally extended variant survives, and its normative credentials differ markedly from the original.

6. A deeper diagnosis: self-reference and the limits of unconditional probability  

Why does CDT stumble precisely here?  Because its central equation assumes that the probability of a state is fixed independently of which act is chosen, so long as the state is not caused by that act.  But causal independence is not the only way acts and states can be probabilistically linked.  When predictive mechanisms, common causes, or simple self-knowledge create correlations, an agent’s own act probabilities seep into the unconditional state probabilities.  The expected-utility formula therefore becomes self-referential.  Mathematically, CDT asks the agent to evaluate a function U(a, p(a)), where p(a) is itself a function of which argument a the agent will finally select.  Unless U has a unique fixed point, the instruction “choose argmax_a U(a, p(a))” has no determinate solution.

Orthodox CDT contains no resources for handling such self-reference because it was designed under a causal-independence idealisation.  The Death in Damascus family of examples demonstrate that the idealisation is violated not by exotic quantum back-propagation but by perfectly ordinary epistemic facts about prediction.  Hence the problem is general and serious.

7. Comparison with Evidential Decision Theory  

Interestingly, EDT does not suffer the same oscillatory failure.  EDT conditionalises on the act, so its expected utilities are insensitive to your prior about which act you will perform.  In the present case EDT says: conditional on going to Aleppo, Death is almost certainly there (because the predictor is reliable); conditional on going to Damascus, likewise.  The utilities of both acts are −9 whichever way you slice it, so EDT is indifferent.  That is not a glorious victory, but at least it is a stable recommendation.  CDT’s defenders cannot now claim that their view is uniquely action-guiding.

8. Objection: The instability is merely epistemic, not normative  

One might push back: the vacillation is just the agent’s uncertain introspection about what she will do, not a pathology of the decision rule itself.  Given a fully specified, sharp prior over her own dispositions, the CDT agent would compute unique unconditional state probabilities, and the oscillation would disappear.  So, says the objection, the real lesson is that rational agents must have perfectly determinate “crime-in-the-mind” probabilities.

I reply that even an agent with a sharp prior cannot satisfy both causal irrelevance and the empirical calibration facts.  The predictor’s success rate constrains the joint distribution between acts and states.  Unless the agent’s act probabilities just so happen to match the predictor’s bias, the calibration data cannot be accommodated.  The only sharp priors that do the job are those perched on the knife-edge equilibrium already noted, so the objection collapses into ratificationism by the back door.

9. Lessons and prospects  

We have seen that the dependence of expected utility on current act probabilities is a serious embarrassment for orthodox CDT.  It causes:

• Guidance failure: no stable recommendation at the time of choice.  
• Diachronic incoherence: susceptibility to money pumps.  
• The need for ad hoc supplements (ratification, policy-level reasoning) that dilute CDT’s original rationale.

Accordingly, philosophers who find CDT attractive must either (i) defend a modified version that evaluates policies rather than acts, or (ii) embrace a harmony constraint à la Jeffrey that collapses the difference between causal and evidential evaluation, or (iii) concede that decision theory needs a wholly different foundation—perhaps game-theoretic equilibrium concepts, perhaps updateless rules, perhaps something yet undiscovered.

10. Conclusion  

Is the dependence on act probabilities a problem for Causal Decision Theory?  Yes—decisively.  The dependence exposes an internal tension between CDT’s causal-independence premise and the epistemic realities of prediction.  When the world contains accurate predictors, an agent’s own credence about what she will do becomes entangled with states deemed “outside her causal influence,” and CDT’s machinery seizes up.  The resulting oscillation deprives the theory of the very virtues—clear guidance and diachronic coherence—that motivated its adoption.  Attempts to patch the leak either abandon core CDT tenets or replicate features of rival theories.  The moral is not merely that CDT mishandles a clever puzzle, but that its foundational commitment to evaluating isolated acts by unconditional probabilities is, in a world of self-referential information, untenable.

I. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is the most prominent descendant of the classical “Maximise expected utility” picture of rational choice.  The distinctive CDT twist is that, when calculating the expectation of an act, one must hold fixed everything that is not causally downstream of that act.  Roughly: in estimating what would happen were I to φ, I keep constant all features of the world that φ-ing could not influence.  The rule has proved highly successful in everyday applications, but a family of cases inaugurated by Ahmed and explored by Egan, Joyce, Titelbaum, and others—the so-called Death in Damascus (DiD) cases—appear to reveal a structural weakness.  In those cases the CDT value of an act turns out to depend on the agent’s current probabilities for doing that very act, and those probabilities predictably fluctuate as deliberation proceeds.  Consequently CDT can produce unstable, even oscillating recommendations.  Is this a genuine flaw or a tolerable artefact of subtle self-locating uncertainty?  My aim is to show that the dependence really is problematic, and that the most familiar CDT repairs either do not work or smuggle in alien principles.

I proceed as follows.  (§II) I rehearse the mechanics of a typical DiD case and make precise where the dependence on act probabilities enters the CDT calculation.  (§III) I present an “instability” argument: because a CDT agent updates on her own shifting resolutions, the theory can deprive her of any action that remains rational throughout deliberation.  (§IV) I defend a stronger “incoherence” argument: by allowing the value of an act to vary with an endogenous probability that the act itself fixes, CDT violates a core norm of rational preference formation and exposes the agent to exploitable sure-loss set-ups.  (§V) I examine the main attempts to rescue CDT—Jeffrey-style ratificationism, “tick before the clock strikes” models, and a policy-level reinterpretation—and argue that each either abandons CDT’s original causal ideology or reintroduces the very instabilities it sought to avoid.  (§VI) I conclude that the dependence on act probabilities is indeed a serious problem: any satisfactory decision theory must sever this looping dependence or else incorporate a more global, updateless perspective foreign to classical CDT.

II. How Death in Damascus Trips CDT  

The story is familiar but vivid.  Death is abroad in Syria.  He has a reliable, though not perfect, algorithm for predicting where you will spend tomorrow night.  Historically he is right 90 % of the time, and he also has a “Damascus bias”: when his evidence leaves your choice almost evenly balanced he tends to guess Damascus.  You know all of this.  You must choose whether to stay in Damascus or to flee to Aleppo.  If Death meets you, you die; otherwise you live and enjoy the trip.  Travel is mildly costly, so, ignoring mortality, you weakly prefer to stay put.  Call the acts D (stay in Damascus) and A (go to Aleppo).  Call the states dʹ (“Death in Damascus”) and aʹ (“Death in Aleppo”).  For simplicity set utilities as follows:  

Live in Damascus = 10  
Live in Aleppo (after tiring journey) = 9  
Die (either city) = 0  

Crucially, Death’s location is determined by his earlier prediction, not by your decision; so dʹ vs aʹ is not causally downstream of your act.  CDT therefore instructs you to evaluate each act by the unconditional (causal) probabilities of dʹ and aʹ.  Yet those unconditional probabilities are—because Death’s prediction is about you—functions of your own current probability of choosing D.  Let p := P(D) be your credence, at the current stage of deliberation, that you will end up staying.  Given the stipulated accuracy and bias we may model the world as:  

P(dʹ) = 0.9 p + 0.6 (1 − p)  
P(aʹ) = 1 − P(dʹ)  

(The second term 0.6 (1 − p) encodes the Damascus bias: even when you are leaning toward Aleppo Death often still plumps for Damascus.)  Plugging into CDT’s value formula:  

VCDT(D) = 10·(1 − P(dʹ)) + 0·P(dʹ) = 10·P(aʹ)  
VCDT(A) = 9·P(aʹ) + 0·P(dʹ) = 9·P(aʹ)  

Plainly, D is preferred iff 10·P(aʹ) ≥ 9·P(aʹ), i.e. iff P(aʹ) ≠ 0.  That is, unless you are certain Death is in Damascus (P(aʹ)=0), staying yields strictly higher expected utility than fleeing; whereas if you are certain Death is in Aleppo (P(dʹ)=0) the acts tie.  But P(aʹ) itself equals 1 − P(dʹ) which is the algebraic function of p written above.  As you waver, p changes, altering P(aʹ), thereby altering VCDT(D) and VCDT(A).  A small shove in p toward “I’m likely to flee” raises P(dʹ) (because Death tracks you), lowers P(aʹ), and so lowers the value of fleeing; that makes staying more attractive, which lowers p, flips the values again, and so on.  Nothing in the causal structure prevents an endless feedback loop.

III. The Instability Argument  

A decision rule should, minimalists say, guide action.  The guidance requirement comes in two flavours.

1. Dynamical guidance: as one deliberates—gathers self-locating information, firms up intentions—there should be some stable point that remains rational.  
2. Implementation guidance: once deliberation ends the rule should license the act one is about to perform rather than render it irrational at the very last moment.

In DiD-style cases CDT meets neither requirement.  Suppose you begin with the psychologically natural p = 0.5.  Then P(dʹ) = 0.75 and P(aʹ) = 0.25.  CDT says: compute VCDT(D) = 2.5, VCDT(A) = 2.25; staying wins.  On recognising that, you incline to Damascus, raising p to (say) 0.9.  Plug that in: P(dʹ)=0.9·0.9 + 0.6·0.1 = 0.87; consequently P(aʹ)=0.13; VCDT(D)=1.3, VCDT(A)=1.17; Damascus still wins, strengthening your resolve.  Push to p≈0.99 and eventually Death’s bias is overwhelmed; now P(dʹ)=0.897, VCDT(D)=1.03; still ahead.  At the limit p=1, staying guarantees success if Death happened to be wrong, which occurs only 10 % of the time; expected utility 1.  But note that once p is 1, you are certain to stay, and because you know you are deterministic Death’s accuracy soars to 1: conditional on your being certain to stay, Death is certain to predict Damascus.  That is a piece of *learning* that CDT demands you incorporate.  So you must replace P(dʹ)=1, P(aʹ)=0; now VCDT(D)=0, tying VCDT(A)=0.  The mere fact of having settled the issue wipes out the advantage you just used to settle it!

This is not a quirky artefact of idealised certainty.  At any point in deliberation when you *almost* but not quite fix on a plan, CDT tells you that if you were to deviate a little, Death would probably catch the scent; thus you should not deviate; thus you harden the plan; thus the catching-the-scent probability climbs; thus the plan’s value collapses.  The rational act keeps slipping through your fingers as soon as you grasp it.  The theory therefore fails dynamical guidance.

IV. The Incoherence Argument  

Suppose one grants that practical reflection must eventually end, perhaps via will-setting or commitment devices.  Can a CDT agent not declare “I hereby choose Damascus” and proceed, glad that earlier oscillations are behind her?  The deeper objection is that CDT’s value function is itself ill-founded whenever it embeds the very credence p that the agent chooses.  The general principle at stake is:

No Control Principle (NCP): The rational value of an act should not vary with variables that the act (or the sheer decision to perform it) fixes by stipulation.

Violations of NCP invite a Dutch book.  Consider a bookie who can offer you, before you finish deliberating, a bet that pays £1 if you end up going to Damascus and costs £0.90 now.  At p=0.5 your subjective fair price is £1·0.5 = £0.50; buying at £0.90 seems irrational.  Yet at p=0.95 your fair price is £0.95; selling the ticket back for £0.90 seems profitable.  The oscillations in p enable the bookie to lock you into alternating buy-and-sell contracts whose net payoff is −£0.40 with certainty.  An ideal CDT agent *could* foresee the Dutch book and refuse, but doing so requires recognising that the very probabilities on which she computes expected utilities are intrinsically unstable—hence not apt for expectation calculation in the first place.

Moreover, NCP is encoded in the axiom of consequential PP (“consequential sure-thing”): if two acts cause the same causal outcomes in every causal state, they must be indifferent.  In DiD once p=1 both acts have the same causal impact on every state (none!), yet CDT declares them tied now, though it declared one strictly preferable a moment earlier, in violation of the sure-thing principle across time.

The incoherence is sharpened by the perspective of counterfactual dependence.  CDT distinguishes between causal and evidential dependence, and labels the latter “mere correlation”.  But probability shifts generated by your intention are *neither* causal (your yet-to-be-performed act does not affect Death’s earlier prediction) nor purely evidential (you have no new data about Death’s plans).  They are self-credal: the outcome probabilities are functions of the credence function used to compute them.  That is circular.

V. Can CDT Be Repaired?  

1. Ratificationism (Jeffrey, McGee, Egan).  
Jeffrey urged that a rational act should be *self-ratifying*: it should maximise expected utility *conditional on performing it*.  In DiD, conditionalising on D sets p=1, which makes Death’s accuracy 1, collapsing VCDT(D) to 0.  Similarly for A.  Neither act ratifies.  Some ratificationists hunt for mixed strategies: perhaps a 30 % randomisation between cities is a fixed point.  But CDT, as ordinarily formulated, forbids stochastic act generation unless the randomisation itself is causally efficacious.  Introducing deliberate lotteries to achieve ratification constitutes a new decision rule, closer to Joyce’s “causal laws” approach than to classical CDT.

2. “Tick before the clock strikes” models (Joyce, Ahmed).  
These models distinguish time-indexed acts: the state of intending to go to Damascus *now* is causally downstream of itself but not of later states.  One then calculates the value of forming a plan at t0, holding fixed predictions made at t-1.  The idea is to freeze the act probabilities at the moment one begins deliberate calculation.  That manoeuvre yields determinate values (in the example, fleeing may come out slightly better) and hence a stable recommendation.  The trouble is that the justification for freezing is non-causal; it says, in effect, “Ignore how your intentions will develop under rational reflection”—a stark violation of the spirit of CDT, which was built precisely to accommodate causally inert correlations only insofar as they can be held constant without cheating.

3. Policy-level CDT (Menzies-Price, Yudkowsky).  
Another move is to promote “acts” to entire *policies*: you choose the algorithm that will govern your behavior across epistemic states; the policy is implemented at a stroke before predictions are made.  The causal arrows then run from policy to future act to outcome; Death predicts the downstream act, not the upstream policy.  The agent compares expected utilities using unconditional probabilities for states not downstream of the policy, which are, by stipulation, independent of later intention shifts.  While elegant, this is no longer act-based CDT but rather a two-stage theory resembling Updateless Decision Theory or Functional Decision Theory.  In abandoning act-level evaluation it concedes the original objection: dependence on act probabilities *is* a problem, so one must ascend to a higher unit of choice to avoid it.

VI. Conclusion  

Death in Damascus shows that classical CDT lets the value of an act dangle from the very probability of performing it, and that probability is itself fixed by the act.  The resulting self-referential loop deprives CDT of stable guidance and undercuts the sure-thing principle that grounds its own axiomatization.  Attempts to patch the theory either (i) silence the loop by fiat (ratificationism), (ii) freeze deliberation at an arbitrary time-slice (tick-models), or (iii) relocate choice to a different level of description (policy CDT).  Each stratagem abandons some central CDT commitment—either the primacy of causal dependence, the completeness of act evaluation, or the one-shot character of practical deliberation.  The dependence is therefore not a harmless curiosity but a symptom of deeper incoherence.  A satisfactory theory of rational choice must find a way to evaluate acts by probabilities that remain fixed during deliberation, a goal better served by updateless or functional approaches than by orthodox CDT.

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is often advertised as the view that, when you face a decision, you should choose the act whose causal prospects look best.  Formally, you compute an act’s value by summing, over the states of the world that are not causally downstream of the act, the product of (i) the utility of the act/state pair and (ii) the probability of that state on the supposition that you perform the act.  In symbols,

              VCDT (A = a)  =  Σs  U(a, s) · P(s | do(A = a)).

Philosophers frequently replace the do‐operator with a simple conditional, writing P(s | A = a).  When the world contains no correlations between what you will do and what the state of the world is, the two coincide, and it is harmless to drop the “do.”  But as soon as there are reliable predictors or other non-causal linkages between the agent’s choice and worldly facts, P(s | A = a) can differ dramatically from P(s | do(A = a)).  The famous “Death in Damascus” story exploits exactly such a correlation to showcase an apparent instability in CDT.

In that story the agent wakes one morning knowing that Death will be waiting for her either in Damascus or in Aleppo tomorrow.  Death is an excellent, though not perfect, predictor of her whereabouts: with probability 0.9 he guesses her destination correctly.  Moreover, he has a mild bias toward guessing that she will be in Damascus.  The two acts available to her are, naturally, “go to Damascus” and “go to Aleppo.”  Nothing causal she does today can influence where Death has already decided to await her; nevertheless, because Death based his choice on a prediction of her act, her choice is correlated with where he is.  It is exactly in such cases that CDT is supposed to shine—after all, there is no causal channel from her present act to Death’s past location, so the “right” answer should depend only on the objective frequencies linking acts to survival, not on mere evidential correlations.

Yet there is a twist.  As the agent deliberates, her credence that she will in fact go to Damascus can change.  Those changes feed directly into her estimates of P(Death in Damascus | go to Damascus) and P(Death in Aleppo | go to Aleppo), because the latter conditional probabilities depend on how reliable Death’s predictions are and on how likely she takes herself to be to do each act.  Consequently, the very values she is trying to compute depend on a parameter—her present subjective probability of acting one way rather than the other—that is itself moving during deliberation.  The complaint is that CDT’s recommendation therefore seems to float: the closer she comes to choosing Damascus, the worse Damascus looks (for Death is likelier to be there), and vice-versa.  Does this “instability” tell against CDT?

The remainder of this essay argues that CDT indeed faces a genuine difficulty here, but that the heart of the problem is not instability as such.  Rather, the phenomenon exposes a deeper tension inside the most common statement of CDT, a tension between (i) taking causal independence seriously and (ii) using ordinary conditional probabilities in the value equation.  When the theory is stated with the proper causal notion—P(s | do(A = a))—the dependence on act probabilities disappears, solving the deliberative instability but at the cost of raising a different challenge: how can ordinary agents obtain, or even approximate, those “interventionist” probabilities?  In short, the dependence on act probabilities is a symptom; the underlying disease is that many presentations of CDT mis-locate the boundary between causally apt and merely evidential probabilities.

2. How the Dependence Arises  

Let Di ∈ {Damascus, Aleppo} be Death’s location, Ai ∈ {Damascus, Aleppo} the agent’s act.  Let Bias = λ designate the fact that, when Death is unsure, he has a λ-chance of guessing “Damascus.”  Finally, let R = 0.9 measure his reliability.  Then a natural model is:

    • P(Di = Ai) = 0.9 (predictor usually right).
    • Of the remaining 0.1 cases, Di = Damascus with probability λ.

Everything relevant to tomorrow is already settled; the agent’s act is causally downstream of nothing important except her present internal state.  So, under the widespread (but, I shall argue, misguided) practice of computing CDT values via conditionals, we say:

    P(Di = Damascus | A = Damascus) = 0.9 + 0.1λ.
    P(Di = Damascus | A = Aleppo)    = 0.1λ.

Notice that the terms on the right involve no mention of the agent’s credence that she will choose Damascus.  On this quick derivation there is no instability.  So why do many presentations declare that the conditional probabilities vary with the agent’s shifting act credence?  The answer lies in a more refined model.  Let H be the total “history” before deliberation begins, containing, inter alia, the complex information that Death used when forming his prediction.  Because Death’s prediction was based partly on H, learning about H can give the agent evidence about both Di and her own forthcoming act.  Consequently, when the agent updates on H, her credence in A = Damascus moves, and because Di is correlated with A, her credence in Di = Damascus moves too.  If one now blurs the conditional P(Di | A) together with ordinary Bayesian updating on H, one gets the impression that P(Di | A) changes as her probability of A changes.

So the phenomenon is not a mathematical illusion: ordinary Bayesians who compute “value” using P(Di | A) and who update on increasingly fine-grained hypotheses about what they themselves will do will indeed watch the conditional evolve.  The more certain they become that they will go to Damascus, the more confident they become that Death is waiting there, and so the lower the expected utility of going to Damascus.  This can give rise to what Andy Egan calls “deliberation delirium”: before reaching certainty, the agent discovers that whichever act currently looks likeliest cannot be worth doing, so she oscillates endlessly.

3. Why Worry?  Four Candidate Diagnoses  

Let us separate four distinct worries that critics have pressed.

Worry 1: Indecisiveness.  If value calculations swing with tiny changes in act‐credence, agents may never converge on a decision.  This looks like a pragmatic deficiency: a decision theory is supposed to tell you what to do, not mire you in perpetual recalculation.

Worry 2: Circularity.  The theory instructs you to compute the value of A by using probabilities that depend on your prior probability of A.  There is an air of circularity or self-reference; one might suspect a vicious regress.

Worry 3: Diachronic Incoherence.  Suppose the agent settles at t1 on the view that she is 60% likely to go to Damascus and, on that basis, ranks Damascus higher than Aleppo.  By t2 her confidence has crept to 70%, and now Damascus looks worse.  She would then have to form a plan at t1 that she predicts she will rationally reject at t2.  That seems to violate a plausible principle of temporal coherence for rational plans.

Worry 4: Misplaced Evidence.  The point of CDT was to insulate decisions from “merely evidential” correlations between act and outcome.  Yet those correlations sneak back through the dependence on act credence.  In other words, CDT smuggles in exactly the sort of evidential consideration it was meant to block.

The remainder of the essay defends two theses.  First, the real problem with CDT in Death-type cases is Worry 4: the theory’s familiar statement uses the wrong sort of probability, thereby letting evidential correlations re-enter by the back door.  Second, once CDT is reformulated with interventionist probabilities, Worries 1–3 disappear.  The dependence on act credence is thus not a fatal blow; it is a signal that we have been employing the wrong mathematical object.

4. Causal Probabilities Versus Conditionals  

Judea Pearl’s do-operator cleanly distinguishes P(s | A = a) from P(s | do(A = a)).  The former is an ordinary conditional.  The latter represents a counterfactual in which we surgically set A to a; all other variables that are not causally downstream of A retain the probabilities they would have absent the intervention.  Crucially, if Death’s prediction is causally upstream of A—his choice happened yesterday—then it is screened off from the intervention.  Hence

    P(Di = Damascus | do(A = Damascus)) = λ,
    P(Di = Damascus | do(A = Aleppo))  = 1 − λ.

Neither quantity depends on the agent’s uncertainty about what she will actually do, because the do-operator destroys the statistical path through which that uncertainty flows.  In short, once we use the causally correct probabilities, the “instability” evaporates.  Either going to Damascus causally makes it more likely that one meets Death, or it doesn’t; what one currently believes about one’s own future act is irrelevant.

Many treatments of CDT, especially in the philosophical literature, drop the do-operator for convenience.  That shortcut is harmless in ordinary Newcomb-free situations, where causal and evidential conditionals coincide.  In Death-type problems it is fatal.  The instability objection therefore bites only against an improperly stated version of CDT.

5. Replying to the Four Worries  

Worry 1 (Indecisiveness).  Given P(s | do(A = a)), the expected utilities of Damascus and Aleppo are constant throughout deliberation.  The agent compares two fixed numbers and acts accordingly.  No oscillation ensues.

Worry 2 (Circularity).  Because the correct probabilities are fixed, there is no circularity.  The value of A = Damascus is computed from causal facts about λ and the utility of living versus dying.  Your credence that you will in fact choose Damascus never enters.

Worry 3 (Diachronic Incoherence).  Since values do not change as self-predictions change, earlier selves do not expect their later selves to revise the plan.

Worry 4 (Misplaced Evidence).  Once we distinguish do from mere conditioning, CDT fulfills its promise: it ignores correlations that run through prediction, clairvoyance, or other non-causal channels.  In Death in Damascus, both acts have exactly the same causal probability of survival (say, 0.5 if λ = 0.5).  Therefore CDT says the agent can flip a coin—or select whichever city she aesthetically prefers—because nothing she does affects whether Death finds her.  This verdict strikes many as correct: the agent’s doom is fixed; all that remains is to enjoy her last day of life in the city she likes.

6. Objections and Further Difficulties  

One might reply on behalf of the instability critic: “Fine, use do-probabilities.  But surely a rational agent learns about the world by observing her own mental states.  When she comes to be strongly disposed to choose Damascus, isn’t that excellent evidence that Death predicted Damascus?  Shouldn’t she take that into account?”  The answer, from the causal perspective, is “Yes, as evidence; no, as cause.”  If her overriding aim is survival, then the only question is: how does her action causally influence Di?  It does not.  Hence the evidence is irrelevant to decision, even if it is relevant to epistemology.  The agent can quite rationally be 95% sure she will end up in Damascus, 95% sure Death is in Damascus, and yet deliberately choose Damascus all the same, because no alternative causal option promises better survival odds.

A more serious worry is epistemic: how is an ordinary mortal supposed to know the values of P(s | do(A = a))?  Pearl’s manuals instruct us to build causal graphs and apply intervention calculus, but that is intellectually demanding.  Real agents will use heuristics, often falling back on plain conditionals.  Does that not vindicate the instability complaint at the level of human decision‐making, even if it fails at the level of ideal theory?  Perhaps.  However, the objection has then shifted: CDT is defective not in principle but because humans are poor at implementing it.  That is a familiar limitation of many normative theories; it hardly counts as a refutation.  At best it motivates research into psychologically realistic proxies for the do-operator.

A different objection appeals to “ratifiability.”  Suppose the agent contemplates only mixed strategies: with probability p she will go to Damascus and with 1−p to Aleppo.  She then seeks a value of p that makes the mixture self-ratifying, i.e., such that each pure act is no better in expectation than the mixture itself.  In Death-type games, a unique p often exists (sometimes 0.5).  Advocates of ratifiability say this dissolves instability without invoking do-probabilities.  Critics answer that the ratifiability constraint smuggles in, via the back door, exactly the causal‐evidential distinction we clarified with the do-operator; to search for a fixed point is to search for a distribution that ignores the evidential significance of one’s predicted act.

7. The Broader Moral: CDT Needs an Explicit Causal Model  

The Death in Damascus puzzle is just one point on a map of correlated decision problems: Newcomb, Medical Newcomb, Psychopath Button, and more.  In each, the trouble arises when we naïvely treat P(s | A = a) as a proxy for “what happens if I do a?”  That shortcut is safe only in the absence of upstream correlations.  Once prediction or mutual dependence enters, we must carefully separate:

    (a) Diagnostic inferences from A to S (what A being true tells me about S);
    (b) Interventional consequences of setting A to a (what making A true does to S).

CDT is, at bottom, the doctrine that decision value depends on (b) alone.  Expressed that way, the theory neither depends on shifting act credences nor counsels irrational oscillation.

8. Conclusion  

Is CDT’s sensitivity to the agent’s changing probability of what she will do a fatal flaw?  No—because a properly formulated CDT is not sensitive in that way.  The unstable version arises only when we conflate evidential and causal probabilities.  The Death in Damascus tale is therefore not a counter-example to CDT but a diagnostic test: any rendition of “causal” decision theory that yields instability has silently abandoned the causal part.  The lesson is methodological.  We must build our decision theory on explicitly causal probabilities—whether via Pearl’s do-calculus, structural equation models, or some other device.  Once we do, the seeming dependence on act credence, and the worries about circularity, diachronic incoherence, and indecision, vanish.

None of this shows that CDT is beyond reproach.  A different family of objections—having to do with dominance, Dutch books, or global consequences in sequential games—may yet unseat it.  But the Death in Damascus instability is not among them.  It is, instead, an artifact of a convenient but illicit slide from causal to conditional.  Clean up the mathematics, and the symptom disappears, leaving the patient—CDT—alive and intellectually healthy, though still subject to further philosophical examination.

(Approx. 2,040 words)

1. Introduction  

Ever since David Lewis and James Joyce put Causal Decision Theory (CDT) on the map, critics have worried that it does not tell agents what to do in situations in which their acts are strongly correlated with but do not cause certain states of the world.  The canonical challenge is Newcomb’s Problem, yet the less-discussed “Death in Damascus’’ variant is, in some respects, even more troublesome.  In it an agent must decide between travelling to Aleppo or to Damascus while knowing that a wily Grim Reaper—call him “Death’’—has already predicted where she will go.  Death intends to be waiting in whichever city he predicted the agent would choose, but his predictions are only highly, not perfectly, reliable.  An extra wrinkle is that Death’s base-rate bias is to guess Damascus.  Because the agent is fully aware of the correlation between her act and Death’s location, the expected utilities CDT assigns to the two acts depend on the probability—fixed by her own still-unsettled beliefs—that she will in fact perform each act.  As she deliberates, those act-probabilities shift, and with them the calculated expected utilities, so that CDT can recommend Aleppo in one moment and Damascus in the next.  Is this dependence on act-probabilities a defect in CDT?  I shall argue that it is indeed a deep and telling problem.  The dependence (i) robs the theory of practical guidance, (ii) forces it to violate plausible principles of dynamic consistency and reflection, and (iii) points to an underlying conceptual tension between CDT’s “act evaluation’’ semantics and a realistic picture of deliberation as an endogenous process.  I will also review the main replies on behalf of CDT and explain why, though each reply captures part of the truth, none succeeds in defusing the worry entirely.

2. Setting up the case  

Let p be the predictor’s reliability (say p = .9) and b be Death’s prior bias toward guessing Damascus (say b = .6).  The decision matrix is simple:

If you go to a city where Death is waiting, your utility is –1,000 (you die);
if you go where Death is not, the utility is 0 (you live).

Crucially, your act does not causally influence where Death is; his prediction was made yesterday.  According to textbook CDT, when calculating the causal expected utility (CEU) of an act A you should:

1. List the “states’’ that are not causally downstream of A.
2. Attach to each such state its unconditional probability.
3. Average the utility conditional on ⟨A & state⟩ weighted by those unconditional probabilities.

Call q = Pr(Death in Aleppo) and 1 – q = Pr(Death in Damascus).  Because Death is usually accurate and tends to guess Damascus, q is neither trivially high nor low.  But q itself depends (via Bayes’ theorem) on Pr(G = Aleppo), the probability you assign to the hypothesis that you will in fact go to Aleppo.  For brevity let α = Pr(you will go to Aleppo) as assessed at the current stage of deliberation.  Standard calculations yield

q(α) = p·α + (1 – p)(1 – α)·(1 – b) / (normalizing constant).

We need not track the algebraic details; the qualitative fact is enough: the more confident you become that you will go to Aleppo, the more confident you should also become that Death predicted Aleppo and is waiting there.  Consequently

CEU(Aleppo | α) = –1,000 × q(α),
CEU(Damascus | α) = –1,000 × (1 – q(α)).

Suppose at the outset you are fairly sure you will pick Damascus, setting α = .3.  Then q(.3) is small, so Aleppo looks safe and CDT recommends it.  But once you notice this recommendation you raise α (after all, you are now planning to go to Aleppo), which in turn raises q, making Aleppo look dangerous.  You therefore switch back to Damascus, lowering α again, and the cycle continues.  CDT has no stable advice.  

3. First pass: why such dependence feels disturbing  

A decision theory is a practical tool.  An agent confronting a choice should be able to apply the theory and receive action-guiding advice that withstands honest reflection.  The oscillatory behaviour described above frustrates that aim.  Indeed, CDT’s recommendation seems to depend on an essentially accidental parameter: the agent’s instantaneous credence about her own future act.  That parameter is not an aspect of the external world; it is a psychological marker that predictably changes precisely because the agent has not yet decided.  If a theory’s verdict flips merely in virtue of the agent’s attending to its previous verdict, this suggests a kind of circularity or self-undermining that is hard to square with the idea that rational choice is supposed to be settled by facts independent of the very act of choosing.

4. Digging deeper: three principled objections  

4.1. The guidance objection  

Decision-theoretic prescriptions must be stable under the deliberation they license; otherwise they fail to guide.  Call this the “Deliberation-Guidance Condition’’ (DGC).  CDT in Death in Damascus violates DGC.  It serves the agent no better than a compass whose needle always points away from the direction you start to walk.  The difficulty is not merely epistemic (that you lack the information to produce a determinate expectation) but structural: any serious attempt to obey the theory disturbs the very inputs on which its advice is based.

4.2. The dynamic consistency objection  

Suppose time is discretized into moments t₀, t₁, t₂,… at which the agent updates her α.  Standard Bayesian norms (e.g. van Fraassen’s Reflection Principle) say that if at t₀ you anticipate that at t₁ you will with certainty perform A, then you should already regard A as rationally mandatory, on pain of foreseeable inconsistency.  But CDT in the present case lets you foresee that your future self will oscillate.  Hence you cannot regard any act as stably allowable, yet you also cannot regard perpetual dithering as an option (one must eventually board a bus).  CDT demands that you make a choice and, simultaneously, that whatever choice you settle on will shortly be seen—by you yourself—to be irrational.  This violates a plausible requirement of intertemporal coherence.

4.3. The ratification objection  

Richard Jeffrey’s notion of “ratifiability’’ demands that an act be self-endorsing: you should endorse only those acts that you would still endorse after learning that you will perform them.  In Death in Damascus no pure act is ratifiable for a CDT agent.  Learning that you will go to Aleppo makes it highly probable that Death predicted Aleppo, at which point you no longer prefer Aleppo; the same mutatis mutandis for Damascus.  So CDT leaves every option unratifiable.  Once again the result is paralysis or cycling, both unpalatable.

5. Possible CDT-friendly replies  

5.1. “Once you decide, α = 0 or 1, and the problem disappears”  

One response is that the agent’s probability of acting is, at the “moment of choice”, always either 0 or 1.  Before that moment she is merely modelling hypothetical dispositions; once she decides, the subjective uncertainty evaporates and CDT delivers a determinate verdict that does not change.  On this account the instability is at worst a symptom of premature calculation, not a flaw in the theory itself.

There are two rejoinders.  First, deliberation is an extended temporal process.  Angular decisions do not spring into being ex nihilo; rather, credences typically evolve continuously until they cross the 0/1 threshold.  During that evolution the agent needs guidance.  Second, even at the “moment” of choice a reflective agent realises that she could still change her mind in the next second if fresh expected-utility calculations so dictated.  So α is never strictly 0 or 1 while deliberation genuinely remains open.  Invoking idealised instantaneous choice therefore side-steps the real issue.

5.2. “Adopt a mixed strategy”  

A more sophisticated defence notes that if you randomise with α* ≈ .5 (exact value determined by the predictor’s bias and reliability), you can drive q to 50-50 and make Death’s success no better than chance.  In that case what you do no longer matters, and CDT is happy with any mixed act.  The theory thus recommends the maximal expected-utility mixture, which exists and is stable.

Yet vanilla CDT evaluates only ordinary acts, not mixed strategies.  Adding stochastic acts enlarges the choice set, which can indeed restore equilibrium, but at a cost: the theory’s original semantics must be amended.  Moreover, deliberately randomising may itself be causally relevant (you might have to flip a visibly fair coin), hence not strictly available.  Finally, the need to widen the menu simply underscores the point that, on its classic formulation, CDT falters.

5.3. “Price and Sobel’s up-dateless CDT”  

Huw Price and Jordan Sobel propose that when calculating CEU you should hold fixed not your current credence about what you will do but an “up-dateless” prior representing what you would have thought before entering deliberation.  Because that prior is independent of on-going introspective shifts, the oscillation disappears.

This repair is in spirit close to Timeless or Functional Decision Theory; it effectively instructs you to evaluate whole policies from an Archimedean viewpoint outside time.  Whether that is still CDT is, however, contentious.  The classical causal algorithm employs the agent’s all-things-considered current beliefs, not a privileged pre-deliberative snapshot.  Introducing privileged priors amounts to re-engineering the theory rather than defending it.

5.4. “Accept the cycling; rationality sometimes has no answer”  

Last, the defender might bite the bullet: the case merely shows that rationality is occasionally indeterminate.  When the world contains predictors tied to your mental states, nothing guarantees a determinate best act.  CDT honestly mirrors that fact and thereby preserves, rather than undermines, normative integrity.

The cost of this stance is heavy.  First, the very same style of correlation can be engineered in more mundane contexts (stock markets, social signalling, evolutionary games).  Declaring rational choice silent whenever such correlations arise would rob CDT of wide applicability.  Second, rival theories—most notably Evidential Decision Theory, but also newer contenders such as Functional Decision Theory—do provide unequivocal and intuitively reasonable advice in the Death in Damascus set-up (typically: go to Aleppo, the city Death is less biased towards).  Unless one thinks rationality itself is parochial to the causal doctrine, the comparison suggests that CDT is missing something.

6. What the malfunction reveals about CDT’s architecture  

Why does CDT face these headaches?  The source lies in its separation between (i) the agent’s epistemic state, which determines the unconditional probabilities of the causally exogenous variables, and (ii) the evaluation of acts, which treats those probabilities as fixed parameters.  In situations where the exogenous variables are predictively entangled with the agent’s own deliberative trajectory, the two components cannot be cleanly separated.  Any live shift in the agent’s act-probabilities feeds back into her beliefs about the exogenous variables, destroying the background-parameter status that CDT’s algorithm assumes.  Put metaphorically, the agent cannot simultaneously be outside the causal picture (so as to assign unconditional probabilities) and inside it (so as to choose).  The Death in Damascus case is a concrete theatre in which that contradiction plays out.

7. Comparison with other theories  

Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) conditions on the act when computing expected utilities.  Hence in Death in Damascus, EDT assigns to Aleppo a worse expectation from the start, because learning that you go to Aleppo is strong evidence Death is there.  So EDT stably recommends Damascus (or Aleppo, depending on biases, but it does not flip-flop).  Whatever else one may say about EDT—Newcomb’s Problem remains a thorn—it at least avoids the instability.

Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and what Yudkowsky and Soares dub “updateless” decision theories evaluate whole decision functions, treating the output of the decision function as logically, rather than causally, linked to predictors.  In Death in Damascus, an FDT agent notices that whichever city her decision function selects, Death will have predicted that very city.  She therefore looks for a function that minimises the worst-case outcome.  Typically she will devise a stochastic or symmetry-breaking policy (e.g. “go to Aleppo if today’s date is even, otherwise Damascus”), under which Death cannot do better than chance.  This advice is stable.

The comparison suggests that CDT’s problem is not an unavoidable feature of rational choice under prediction but a consequence of CDT’s particular methodology.

8. Is there a principled fix?  

Could one amend CDT in a piecemeal fashion—say, by adding a ratifiability constraint—to dodge the oscillation without abandoning causality as the guiding idea?  Perhaps.  A “Ratifiable CDT” (RCDT) might say: perform that causally-undominated act which would remain optimal after updating on the information that you perform it.  But in Death in Damascus, no pure act is ratifiable; the only ratifiable options are mixed.  RCDT would then incorporate the move to evaluate mixed strategies that classical CDT resisted.  Once again the repair subtly transforms the theory’s ontology of acts.  At some point the accumulation of patches suggests that the decision rule one is left with is better described as a new theory, not CDT proper.

9. Conclusion  

Yes, CDT’s dependence on live act-probabilities in Death in Damascus is a problem, and a serious one.  The dependence deprives the theory of stable action guidance, violates widely accepted norms of dynamic consistency, and exposes a conceptual fault line in the way CDT partitions “acts” from “states”.  Defences that appeal to instantaneous certainty, mixed strategies, privileged priors, or indeterminacy each capture an aspect of the difficulty but also reveal how far CDT must stretch to save face.  The upshot is not merely that CDT mishandles an exotic thought experiment; it is that any theory which evaluates acts using unconditional probabilities must tread carefully whenever those probabilities are endogenously tied to the agent’s own process of deciding.  If a decision theory cannot accommodate that feedback loop, then rational agents—whose beliefs unavoidably interact with their choices—need a better theory.

1. Framing the Issue  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) instructs an agent to choose the act that maximises expected utility calculated with respect to (i) the utilities of possible outcomes and (ii) the agent’s unconditional probabilities for possible states that are not causally downstream of the act.  In most ordinary cases this recipe gives clear and stable advice.  In so-called Death-in-Damascus (DiD) scenarios, however, the recipe produces a peculiar phenomenon: the very probabilities the agent assigns to performing each act enter into the expected-utility calculations, so that as the agent’s mind shifts during deliberation, CDT’s advice can flip back and forth.  The question is whether this “advice instability” is a genuine defect of CDT or a merely superficial oddity.  

I shall argue that the dependence on act probabilities is indeed a serious problem for CDT because it violates two interconnected desiderata on any adequate decision theory:

a. Diachronic coherence: an adequate theory should guide an agent through deliberation in a way that does not predict self-defeating cycles of preference revision.  
b. Action guidance: an adequate theory ought to be capable of settling on a determinate recommendation in cases where a rational agent recognises that a unique option must be selected.  

I first re-describe the DiD case, show precisely how CDT’s dependence on P(act) generates cycling, and then consider three prominent lines of defence.  Each defence, I contend, either fails outright or tacitly abandons distinctive CDT commitments, thereby revealing that the phenomenon does mark a deep flaw.  I conclude by extracting a moral about how credences in one’s own acts should figure—if at all—in the calculation of expected utilities.

2. The Death-in-Damascus Set-Up  

Death in Damascus (after Arntzenius, Weirich, Rabinowicz and others) is a variant of Newcomb’s Problem that isolates a special feature of CDT.  Imagine:

• You must tonight choose to travel to Damascus (D) or Aleppo (A).  
• Death, an almost perfectly reliable predictor, has predicted where you will go and will wait there to take your life.  However, Death’s reliability is not perfect: if you go to the city he predicted (call that city S), you die; if you go to the other city, you survive.  
• You know that Death tends to guess Damascus absent any further information: before he looks at you, he assigns 60% to your going to Damascus.  

For simplicity, suppose:  
• Utility of survival = 0, utility of death = –1000.  
• The prediction mechanism is purely predictive: Death’s choice of city is not causally influenced by your decision; rather, his choice correlates with it because he is reliable.  

Let p be your current credence that you will pick Damascus.  Given Death’s reliability r, your unconditional probability that Death has gone to Damascus is:

P(Death in D) = r·p + (1–r)·(1–p).  
P(Death in A) = r·(1–p) + (1–r)·p.

Because r > ½ and because Death “leans Damascus”, the first term dominates when p is near ½.

The expected utility of going to Damascus, EU(D), is –1000 × P(Death in D|go D).  But by causal independence we use the unconditional probability that Death is in D, so:

EU(D) = –1000 × P(Death in D) = –1000[r·p + (1–r)(1–p)]  
EU(A) = –1000 × P(Death in A) = –1000[r(1–p) + (1–r)p].

Notice that EU(D) – EU(A) = –1000 × (2r–1)(2p–1).  For r>½, this expression is negative when p>½ and positive when p<½.  So:

• If p>½, Damascus looks worse, so CDT recommends Aleppo.  
• If p<½, Aleppo looks worse, so CDT recommends Damascus.

But changing one’s mind about which act is better changes p, which flips the recommendation, which in turn changes p again, generating an oscillation.

3. Why Is Oscillation Troubling?  

3.1. Diachronic incoherence  

A decision theory is diachronically coherent when it can be used, step by step, by a reflective agent to reach a stable decision.  CDT in DiD fails this test.  Suppose the agent starts completely undecided, p≈½.  A tiny hunch in one direction immediately makes the alternative look better.  Anticipating that shift, the agent tries to move back—but the moment she does, CDT’s recommendation flips again.  The formal model predicts a deliberative cycle with no fixed point, because the putatively rational rule yields no self-ratifying answer.

3.2. Guidance failure  

A theory whose prescriptions depend sensitively on the agent’s fleeting credence in her future act offers no usable guidance.  Decision theory is supposed to tell us what to do independent of our moment-by-moment epistemic weather.  Yet here the theory says, in effect: “First, settle how likely you are to do each act; conditional on that, I will tell you what is best.”  But settling those probabilities is precisely what the agent sought the theory’s help to accomplish.  CDT therefore hands the agent a ladder that presupposes the upper rungs in order to reach them.

4. Three Candidate Defences  

4.1. The Ratifiability move  

The first line of defence, due to Jeffrey, Harper and Skyrms, is to supplement CDT with a Ratification Constraint: you should choose an act only if you would still regard it as optimal on the supposition that you choose it.  An act that maximises expected utility relative to a probability distribution in which it itself receives probability 1 is “ratifiable”.  In DiD the only ratifiable probability assignments are p=0 and p=1, since for intermediate p each act undermines itself.  We then look for a fixed-point policy: either always go to Damascus (p=1)—which gives EU(D)= –1000r, EU(A)= –1000(1–r); or always go to Aleppo (p=0)—giving EU(D)= –1000(1–r), EU(A)= –1000r.  Because r>½, always going to Aleppo has higher expected utility than always Damascus; so the ratifiable solution is: one should set p=0 and go to Aleppo.

Critics reply that this answer is ad hoc and fails to respect CDT’s letter.  Ratifiability adds a second-order requirement that is not justified by the causal recipe alone; indeed, it resembles Evidential Decision Theory (EDT), letting evidential correlations (between act and prediction) drive the choice.  Moreover, ratifiability is too strong in ordinary cases, ruling out plausible mixed strategies in competitive or coordination contexts.

4.2. The Policy-selection interpretation  

Joyce and Arntzenius have suggested that CDT should be construed as recommending policies rather than instantaneous acts.  You evaluate the expected utility of complete, self-consistent policies in which your credence about what you will do matches what the policy says you will do.  Under this reading CDT again picks the Aleppo-policy, thereby escaping oscillation.

But “policy CDT” effectively changes the underlying theory: the classic causal maxim “Perform the act with greatest causal expected utility” is replaced by “Adopt the policy that maximises causal expected utility, where the credences over states incorporate the fact that you adopt that very policy.”  The manoeuvre works only by building ratifiability into the object of choice.  Furthermore, assessing entire policies presupposes that one can bind oneself decisively before the moment of choice; yet CDT is advertised as a theory for in-the-moment decision making by unbound agents.

4.3. The “No problem” response  

A third response, pressed by Frank Arntzenius and James M. Joyce in different ways, is: although there is no stable point of deliberation, nothing irrational occurs, because the agent’s oscillation is merely a theoretical artifact.  Real people will either settle on one option due to random perturbations or implement a mixed strategy with indeterminate credence p=½, in which case both options tie.

This reply concedes that CDT cannot itself dictate how the agent should settle.  It assumes that some extra-theoretic factor—psychological noise, a coin flip—breaks the tie.  That seems to abandon the claim that CDT alone constitutes a complete theory of rational choice.  Moreover, if the agent knows she will break the tie, that knowledge re-enters the calculation, forcing the oscillation back in.  Without a principled story of tie-breaking, guidance failure remains.

5. Why the Dependence Really Matters  

The foregoing suggests that CDT, in its classic form, stumbles on DiD because it allows subjective probabilities for acts to infiltrate the evaluation of those very acts.  This undermines both diachronic coherence and action guidance.  To see the depth of the problem, consider two further diagnostics.

5.1. A Dutch Book argument  

Suppose a savvy bookmaker knows you are a CDT agent about to enter a DiD deliberation.  At t0 you are undecided (p≈½).  The bookmaker offers two bets:

Bet 1 (sold at fair odds at t0): you pay £50 now, receive £100 if you go to Damascus.  
Bet 2 (offered at t1 if your credence in Damascus goes above ½): pay £50 now, receive £100 if you go to Aleppo.

Because CDT predicts that whenever your credence tips above ½ you’ll favour Aleppo, you will both buy Bet 2 and go to Aleppo, making Bet 1 a loss.  Symmetrically, if your credence dips below ½, a differently structured pair of bets robs you the other way.  One can design a package ensuring that a CDT agent prone to oscillation ends up accepting a series of bets that guarantee a net loss, even though each bet individually was, at the moment of purchase, judged favourable by CDT lights.  This sort of Dutch Book shows that CDT’s instability is not a benign quirk; it exposes the agent to sure-loss exploitation.

5.2. Counterexample to “Independence of irrelevant probabilities”  

An intuitive principle, analogously to dynamic consistency in choice over time, is: Rational choice should not depend on the agent’s merely psychological uncertainty about what she will do.  Two agents alike in all causal and evidential facts about the world except their subjective fluctuations over their own forthcoming act should make the same choice.  CDT violates this principle: the same external setup, with the same utilities and same causal structure, yields different recommendations solely because the agent’s act-probabilities differ.  That undermines the claim that CDT recommendations track objective features of decision problems.

6. What Would Repair Require?  

One reaction is: Good—then let us revise CDT.  The direction of revision is instructive:

Option A: Move to Evidential Decision Theory.  EDT never displays the oscillation because it always treats the correlation between act and Death’s prediction as evidentially relevant.  EDT simply advises going wherever Death is less likely to be.  But EDT has its own well-known troubles (e.g. the Smoking Lesion).

Option B: Hybrid theories (e.g. E-less-Kratzer, functional decision theory, policy-selection variants) that sever the link between P(act) and the expected-utility calculation by requiring that, for evaluation purposes, the probability of the chosen act be set to 1.  These theories differ from classic CDT precisely by blocking the problematic dependence.

Either way, the moral is the same: a workable theory must not let your current credence in what you will do help decide what to do.  The correct probabilities to use are those you would hold were the deliberative question already settled—call them “deliberation-fixed” credences.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Real agents never have sharp probabilities about their own acts; the instability is thus a modelling artefact.  

Reply: Even if real agents have fuzzy beliefs, any decision theory worth its salt must be capable of handling idealised sharp-credence cases.  Otherwise the theory’s normative credentials rest on psychological limitations, not rational principles.  

Objection 2: Oscillation shows only that the agent is uncertain between two equally good acts; so the theory permits, but does not compel, dithering.  

Reply: The analysis above shows that the acts are not equally good for any single value of p ≠ ½.  CDT says D is strictly better when p<½ and strictly worse when p>½.  Because p always takes some value, CDT always gives strict advice, but the advice changes with p.  So the problem is not permissive indeterminacy but conflicting strict prescriptions.

Objection 3: The problem is endemic to any theory that allows self-locating probabilities, not unique to CDT.  

Reply: Evidential and other decision theories do not display the same cycling in DiD.  The pathology is tied specifically to CDT’s rule of stripping out downstream causal factors while keeping unconditional probabilities for upstream ones, which happens to drag in P(act) whenever the upstream state is correlated with the act.

8. Concluding Diagnosis  

The dependence of CDT’s prescriptions on the agent’s probabilities of her own actions, as highlighted by Death-in-Damascus cases, is indeed a significant problem.  It undercuts:

• Diachronic coherence: deliberation should converge, not oscillate.  
• Action guidance: a decision rule should offer determinate advice that does not itself presuppose the advice’s outcome.  
• Betting rationality: instability exposes agents to sure-loss books.  
• Independence: recommendations should track objective causal/evidential structure, not transient self-predictions.

Attempts to rescue CDT either bolt on ratifiability constraints (changing the theory in an EDT-ish direction) or shift to policy-based evaluation (again abandoning the act-centred causal maxim).  Hence the phenomenon is not a superficial glitch but a signal that classic CDT mishandles cases in which the act correlates with upstream states via prediction or observation.  

The broader moral is that a satisfactory decision theory must insulate the assessment of acts from credences about those very acts.  Calculation should be done from the standpoint of having already chosen.  Once that lesson is internalised, the resulting theory—however one labels it—will differ importantly from orthodox CDT.

Is Causal Decision Theory’s dependence on an agent’s changing act-probabilities a flaw revealed by “Death in Damascus”–style cases?  I shall argue that it is a genuine problem, though not an immediately fatal one.  It exposes a tension between CDT’s defining commitment—use causal rather than evidential probabilities—and its equally indispensable commitment to deliver stable, action-guiding recommendations.  The tension surfaces only in a narrow class of cases, but once noticed it forces a choice: either (i) modify CDT so that act-probabilities play no direct role in evaluating options, or (ii) concede that CDT sometimes yields no determinate recommendation until deliberation ends, in which case the theory no longer fully answers the question “What should I do?”  After setting out the structure of the case (§1) and showing exactly why CDT’s recommendations bounce as credences evolve (§2), I survey four lines of response (§§3-6).  Only the first two preserve CDT’s spirit, yet each has costs that the remaining two try to avoid by revising CDT more radically.  I close (§7) by explaining why dependence on act-probabilities should be counted a defect and why the most promising repair drops the dependence.

1.  The case and CDT’s machinery  

“Death in Damascus” (originally by Donald Davidson, later modified by Gibbard & Harper and many others) runs as follows.  Tonight you must choose to go tomorrow to either Damascus or Aleppo.  A being called Death has an excellent but not perfect predictor of human behaviour.  He is already en route to whichever city he predicted you will visit, aiming to meet you there.  You know his predictions are 90 % reliable, and that because of background regularities he tends to guess “Damascus” more often—say, with unconditional probability 0.6.  You gain one util if you avoid Death, lose a million utils if you meet him, and are otherwise indifferent between the cities.  Finally, assume that from where you are now, traveling costs are negligible and you cannot randomize overtly (tossing a public coin would let Death keep pace).

CDT tells you to evaluate each act—Go-Damascus (D) and Go-Aleppo (A)—by taking every causally independent “state” s, multiplying U(act, s) by Pr(s ⟶ | act) (the probability that that state obtains conditional on your act, where the arrow indicates a causal rather than merely evidential reading), and summing.  Any factors causally downstream of your choice are screened off; only upstream matters remain.  In Newcomb problems this makes a difference because what the predictor already decided lies causally upstream.  The same structure reappears in Death-in-Damascus: Death has already chosen a destination on the basis of his prediction, so where he will be when you arrive is upstream of your choice.

To frame the calculation, divide the world into four states:

   Pᴅ  : Death predicted Damascus.  
   Pᴀ  : Death predicted Aleppo.  

Because prediction accuracy is imperfect we nest inside each P a “Hit” or “Miss” event:

   (Pᴅ∧Hit) : he predicted D and you in fact go D.  
   (Pᴅ∧Miss): he predicted D but you go A.  
   (Pᴀ∧Hit) : he predicted A and you go A.  
   (Pᴀ∧Miss): he predicted A but you go D.

Only where you and Death coincide do you die.  So utilities are:

   U(D, Pᴅ∧Hit)   =  −1,000,000  
   U(D, Pᴅ∧Miss)  =  +1  
   U(D, Pᴀ∧Hit)   =  +1  
   U(D, Pᴀ∧Miss)  =  −1,000,000  

…and analogously for A by symmetry.

Let p = current credence that you will in fact choose Damascus.  Because you are still deliberating, p is not 0 or 1.  Using the givens (PrPᴅ = 0.6, reliability 0.9), causal probabilities become:

   Pr(Pᴅ & Hit | D)   = 0.6 × 0.9 / p         (Death predicted D and was right).  
   Pr(Pᴅ & Miss| D)   = 0                       (cannot go A if you go D).  
   Pr(Pᴀ & Hit | D)   = 0.4 × 0.1 / (1−p)      (he predicted A but would have been right only if you went A).  
   …etc.

When the algebra is done, the expected utility of D is:

   EU(D) = (0.6·0.9/p)·(−10⁶)  +  (0.6·0.1/p)·(+1)  +  (0.4·0.1/(1−p))·(+1)  +  (0.4·0.9/(1−p))·(−10⁶)

and EU(A) is the mirror image with p and (1−p) interchanged.  The details do not matter; the salient fact is that EU(D) is a decreasing function of p, while EU(A) is an increasing function.  Intuitively: the more you lean toward Damascus, the more likely Death’s 90 % predictor already sent him there, so the more dangerous D looks.  Conversely, the more you lean away from Damascus, the safer Damascus becomes.

2.  CDT’s volatile verdict  

Suppose you start evenly poised, p = 0.5.  Plug the numbers and you will find one act, say A, maximises expected utility.  Acting on that information, you raise credence in A and lower credence in D; now p might drop to 0.2.  Recalculate.  Because EU(D) fell as p grew, shrinking p makes Damascus look better, perhaps good enough to surpass Aleppo.  A rational agent following CDT should switch to D.  But noticing that, p swings back up.  The cycle repeats.  One can formalise the oscillation: unless you are dogmatically certain which act you will choose, there is always a nearby p for which the opposite act looks better.

The volatility does not arise because you lack information about Death’s bias.  Even if the base rates, reliability, and stakes are common knowledge and precise, CDT keeps chasing its own tail.  Slight changes in the endogenous probability of action feed directly into the expected-utility evaluation, which then demands a change of action, which re-feeds into the probabilities, ad infinitum.  Call this phenomenon deliberational instability.  Any decision theory that aims to issue practical advice must tolerate ordinary doxastic flux; CDT in Death-in-Damascus does not.

3.  First response: “Wait until probabilities settle”  

A natural reply is: so what?  Rational deliberation ends only when the agent reaches a stable credence—i.e. when p becomes 0 or 1 through a self-predictive collapse.  On that view CDT counsels nothing during deliberation, but once you find yourself certain you will go, say, Damascus, EU(D) becomes definite (because p=1) and EU(A) undefined (division by zero) or else dominated.  CDT then recommends Damascus, and you proceed.  No oscillation remains because deliberate reflection has already finished.

This maneuver, defended by some causalists (e.g. Joyce 1999, sect. 5.2), saves action guidance at the price of postponing it to the last instant.  Critics object that real-world decisions often demand interim guidance.  We rarely become absolutely certain what we will do until we do it; if rationality requires that certainty, it requires the impossible.  Worse, the “wait” prescription strips CDT of predictive power: it says nothing about which of the two fixed points—p=1 or p=0—you will, or should, end up at.  That is not mere silence but indeterminacy in the very cases the theory was supposed to illuminate.

4.  Second response: “Add a deliberative partition”  

A more sophisticated causalist (e.g. Rabinowicz 2002) distinguishes two stages.  During deliberation we suppress reference to our own act; probabilities are assigned to states that abstract from what we will do.  Only after settling on an intention do we insert that intention as a new causal node and recompute.  Formally, one uses a partition that keeps “my eventual act” outside the algebra until the decision is made.  Expected utilities evaluated on such a partition do not vary with p, because p is not represented.  Hence no instability.

The move is coherent but ad hoc.  Why should the “right” causal partition omit propositions about my act when, ex hypothesi, Death’s prediction was causally influenced by precisely those facts?  CDT’s motivating idea—screen off downstream effects—never advised ignoring the upstream distribution of predictors’ guesses.  The deliberative-partition strategy therefore looks like a patch sewn on to stop the oscillation, not a derivation from CDT’s core principles.

5.  Third response: Ratificationism  

Jeffrey (1983) and, more recently, Skyrms, Maher, and Arntzenius promote ratificationism: an act is rational only if, after hypothetically learning that you will do it, you would still endorse it.  Ratification breaks the oscillation because only fixed points count as rational.  In Death-in-Damascus, the two ratifiable acts correspond to two self-confirming credence states.  If you can see a path to either, you may adopt it and walk away happily.

Ratificationism is no longer CDT; it keeps causal probabilities but appends a new coherence constraint.  That constraint quietly removes dependence on fluctuating act-probabilities by restricting attention to equilibria, yet it also licenses unacceptable paralysis in other settings.  For instance, in games with multiple equilibria it allows picking any, even dominated, option so long as it self-ratifies.  The fix thus cures one disease by risking another.

6.  Fourth response: Two-box or evidential theories  

Evidential Decision Theory yields a stable recommendation in Death-in-Damascus: go to the city you believe Death predicted least.  Because EDT conditions on act rather than intervening on act, EU(D) and EU(A) do not depend on p but on the evidential link between where you go and where Death is.  The expected-utility table then makes Damascus worse (because you take going D as evidence Death predicted D), and you calmly choose Aleppo.  No oscillation appears.

However, adopting EDT re-opens the standard Newcomb worry: it recommends two-boxing (or here, avoiding Damascus) even when you would do better by causal lights to one-box.  The whole point of CDT was to avoid that; switching to EDT dodges the act-probability glitch only by surrendering the core causal insight.

7.  Why the dependence is a genuine problem  

To see why CDT’s sensitivity to p is objectionable, recall two desiderata any decision theory should meet.

   Guidance: The theory must yield actionable advice while deliberation is ongoing.  
   Stability: Its advice should not depend on epistemic artefacts of the very process of consulting the theory.
