CDT in Death-in-Damascus fails both.  First, there is no time during deliberation at which CDT can tell you what to do that will remain its recommendation an instant later; so it offers no usable guidance.  Second, the shifts in advice arise solely because your credence in an action is a self-referential artefact of checking what the theory recommends.  That is normatively irrelevant; whether I ought to go to Aleppo should not turn on a quiver in my introspective probability of going to Aleppo.

A helpful analogy is voting theory.  A voting rule that made the electoral outcome depend on citizens’ guesses about that very outcome would be condemned as procedurally vicious: knowledge of the rule destabilises the result.  CDT inherits a similar procedural vice when act-probabilities feed into expected utilities.

One might reply: sure, probabilities of acts are “epistemic artefacts,” but they encode genuine causal information—namely, tendencies in your choice mechanism that also influenced Death’s predictor.  If those tendencies lean Damascus-ward, then Damascus really is more dangerous.  So why call the dependence normatively irrelevant?

Because any such causal information is already contained in the objective statistics of the case (predictor reliability, base rates, etc.).  Your creedal distribution over your future act adds no new causal fact; it is only your current snapshot of the old facts.  Conditioning on that snapshot double-counts evidence, turning a static background fact (Death predicts Damascus 60 %) into a moving target.  Rationality requires basing decisions on the facts, not on your fluctuating personal confidence in what the facts impel you to do.

That is why the oscillation cannot be dismissed as a quirk of higher-order uncertainty.  If we replaced your introspective credence p by an external, causally informed probability independent of deliberation—say, a neuroscientist’s forecast of your choice—the instability would disappear: CDT would deliver a clear recommendation relative to that fixed number.  So the problem lies not in using upstream probabilities, but in letting them vary with ongoing deliberation.

8.  The best repair: Decouple evaluation from act-probabilities  

A straightforward fix is to adopt Causal Decision Theory minus the step that treats the agent’s own act as an event whose probability can be anything other than 0 or 1 at the moment of choice.  Formally, impose a Deliberative Indeterminacy Principle:

   During deliberation, set Pr( I do act a ) = 0 for every act a not yet chosen.

Intuitively, one treats the choice as an open causal question until resolved, much as classical logicians treat future contingents as neither true nor false.  Expected utilities are then evaluated under counterfactual interventions, not conditional probabilities, so p never enters.  This modification leaves CDT’s core intact—intervene causally, ignore evidential correlations—but blocks deliberative self-reference.  It tells you to compute EU(D) and EU(A) using the causal probabilities conditional on D and on A, not on some nebulous prior over which you will do.  Because those conditional probabilities are fixed by the exogenous data (Death’s base rate, reliability), EU(A) strictly exceeds EU(D).  Therefore you should go Aleppo, full stop.  The advice is stable and timely.

Critics will complain that setting Pr(I do a)=0 violates graded belief; surely before deciding I may think there is a 55 % chance I will choose Damascus.  Yet the 55 % measure is best interpreted as metacredence about how the deliberation will go, not as part of the probability model used for causal evaluation of acts.  Mixing the two levels—using first-personal metacredences inside the object-level decision problem—is precisely what triggered the instability.  CDT works once we keep them apart.

9.  Conclusion  

Dependence on act-probabilities is a problem for CDT because it undermines the theory’s ability to give stable, action-guiding recommendations whenever such probabilities are endogenous to ongoing deliberation.  In Death-in-Damascus the dependence produces an infinite oscillation: each tentative conclusion about what to do changes the inputs that generated it.  A decision theory that collapses upon being consulted fails to serve its fundamental purpose.  Various repairs exist—waiting for certainty, partition tricks, ratificationism, switching to evidential theories—but each either sacrifices guidance, adds ad hoc machinery, or abandons CDT’s causal rationale.  The most principled solution is to insulate causal evaluation from the agent’s shifting credence in her own act.  Once decoupled, CDT survives and delivers the intuitive advice: head for Aleppo.  Therefore the dependence on act probabilities is indeed a flaw, though a curable one, which teaches a general methodological lesson: keep the epistemology of deliberation separate from the causal model used in decision evaluation.

1. Introduction  
Causal decision theory (CDT) has long been sold as the theory for agents who want to act on the basis of what their choices can cause, rather than on the basis of the mere evidence their choices supply.  In simple two-stage decision problems the prescription is elegant: choose the act a that maximises  

         ∑s U(a,s) P(s)  

where s ranges over states that are not causally downstream of a, and P(s) is your unconditional probability for s.  But elegance is bought at a price.  In “Death in Damascus’’–style cases the very probabilities P(s) an agent is told to use shift as the agent’s own credence about which act she will perform shifts during deliberation.  The expected utilities of the acts therefore swirl around while the agent is still thinking, producing an appearance of unstable, even self-undermining, advice.  Is that a deep flaw or merely a quirk of presentation?  I shall argue that the dependence on the agent’s current act-probabilities is indeed a serious, though not obviously fatal, problem for orthodox CDT.  It sustains four interconnected worries: (i) deliberative instability, (ii) failure of act separability, (iii) vulnerability to domination and Dutch books, and (iv) an explanatory tension between CDT’s avowed “causal’’ spirit and the evidential role act-probabilities end up playing.

2. How the instability arises  
First recall the story.  You are certain that Death will be in whichever city he predicts you will visit tomorrow; his predictions are 90 % reliable and, ceteris paribus, he tends to guess Damascus (60 % of the time) rather than Aleppo (40 %).  If you meet him you lose a life-worth −100; if you miss him you gain 0.  Travel costs are negligible.  Today you are undecided; you assign  

     P(Damascus) = p  and  P(Aleppo) = 1–p  

to your own eventual choice.  Because Death’s location D is correlated with that choice C through his prediction mechanism, your unconditional probability for the state “Death in Damascus’’ is

     P(DamascusDeath) = 0.9 p + 0.4 (1–p),  

while

     P(AleppoDeath)    = 0.1 p + 0.6 (1–p).  

CDT instructs you to evaluate expected utilities using those unconditional state probabilities.  The expected value of going to Damascus is therefore

     EU(Damascus) = –100 × P(DamascusDeath)  
                  = –100 [0.9 p + 0.4 (1–p)],

whereas

     EU(Aleppo)   = –100 × P(AleppoDeath)  
                  = –100 [0.1 p + 0.6 (1–p)].  

These are linear in p.  When p < 0.5, Damascus looks safer; when p > 0.5, Aleppo looks safer; and when p = 0.5 they are tied.  Thus CDT says: “If right now you lean (even slightly) toward Damascus, go to Damascus; if you lean toward Aleppo, go to Aleppo.’’  But of course your leanings are a product of the very deliberation you are performing.  If at t1 you find yourself with p = 0.6, CDT says “Aleppo!”; recognising that advice, you tilt further toward Aleppo, raising p still more; but as p rises, P(AleppoDeath) rises, eventually flipping the verdict back to “Damascus!”, and so on.  Nothing external to the problem cuts the oscillation, so the agent can be caught in perpetual vacillation or end up picking an act for no reason other than arbitrary decision fatigue.

3. Deliberative instability  
A plausible norm of rational deliberation is stability: once you have taken full account of everything you regard as relevant, the theory’s recommendation should not change merely because you are reflecting on it.  CDT plus the Death-style correlation violates that norm.  It is no comfort to say, as some causalists do, that the advice becomes determinate “at the last moment’’ when p collapses to either 0 or 1, because the theory will have spent the whole course of deliberation pushing you around without converging on a plan.  Practical decision theories are supposed to guide finite cognisers with limited time; a method that does not stably converge fails that guiding role.

4. Failure of act separability  
The instability is a symptom of a deeper structural feature: under CDT the expected utility of an act is not separable from credences about the agent’s disposition to perform that very act.  Yet many regard separability as a basic rationality constraint.  Analogously, a bet should not become more attractive simply because you are more likely to place it.  The Death case renders that constraint false for CDT: betting on Damascus gets worse the surer you are that you will bet on Damascus.  This looks conceptually backward.  A normative theory should rank the possible acts in a way that is independent of the agent’s eventual choice; otherwise guidance collapses into a form of self-fulfilling prophecy.

5. Domination and Dutch books  
Because each act’s value can be driven down by the probability of performing it, the CDT agent can simultaneously regard each act as conditionally dominated “if I were going to do it’’.  That exposes her to a variant of the Dutch book.  Consider a bookie who offers, before the agent’s vacillation starts, a sure way to avoid Death at a small cost ε: “Pay ε now and I guarantee transport to whichever city you deem safer after you finish deliberating.’’  The agent foresees that for any p she will later regard that city as safer, so paying seems strictly better than refusing.  Yet an identical argument can be mounted at each later stage, exposing a chain of sure-loss payments.  The mere fact that CDT lets the value of acts sink when their probability rises fuels the exploitability.  A fully separable decision rule would not allow such a pattern of individually appealing but jointly dominated trades.

6. Causal–evidential tension  
A slogan of CDT is: only causal consequences matter.  But in Death in Damascus the only causal consequences of boarding the bus to Aleppo concern where you end up, not where Death goes.  Nevertheless CDT’s value calculation for Aleppo depends on P(AleppoDeath), and that probability shifts when your own credence in boarding the bus shifts.  What explains the shift?  Pure evidence.  Learning that you are likely to go to Aleppo makes it more likely that Death predicted Aleppo.  But if CDT is really concerned only with causal consequences, evidential shifts that are unconnected to new causal information should be irrelevant.  The dependence of EU on p therefore undermines CDT’s philosophical motivation: it re-admits the very evidential considerations the theory was designed to exclude.

7. A defender’s reply: the “snapshot’’ view  
Causalists often respond that what matters is the agent’s credence snapshot at the instant of choice.  True, p moves during deliberation, but rationality is evaluated only at the final instant.  At that instant p is 1 for the act chosen, 0 for the other, so the unconditional probabilities collapse to those values and the recommendation is well-defined.  Where is the problem?  

There are three difficulties with the snapshot reply.  First, the theory then loses explanatory power: it can pronounce only after the fact.  Second, if p = 1 for Damascus, then P(DamascusDeath) = 0.9, making the chosen act foreseeably worse than the unchosen alternative (which would then have P(AleppoDeath)=0.1).  Acting on a knowingly worse option is at least puzzling.  Third, the reply ignores the role of deliberation in settling p.  Rational agents are entitled to use their theory to shape their credences; if the theory offers no stable advice while credences are open, the guidance deficit re-emerges.

8. Ratificationism and equilibrium ideas  
One natural repair is Joyce’s and Harper’s “ratification’’ demand: an act is rational only if it would remain optimal even after the agent conditioned on the fact that she is about to do it.  Because conditioning drives p to 1, neither act in Death in Damascus is ratifiable: Damascus is best given low p but not given p≈1, and vice versa.  Ratificationists conclude that in such cases CDT issues no verdict; the decision problem is ill-posed.  That saves CDT from instability at the cost of silence, and silence is not obviously acceptable as a general decision rule.  

A different repair, advocated by Price, Ahmed, and Menzies under the banner “evidential symmetry’’ or “policy selection’’, directs the agent to treat her entire decision policy, not the momentary act, as the causal unit.  The policy “always go to Damascus’’ has a fixed expected utility, independent of deliberational vacillation, and likewise for “always go to Aleppo’’.  One can then pick the better-scoring policy and implement it as a self-binding commitment.  That move, however, jettisons the core act-based architecture of CDT and brings the theory close to functional decision theory, showing again that orthodox CDT struggles on its own.

9. Is the dependence unavoidable?  
Why doesn’t the same worry afflict every decision problem, given that your acts are always correlated in some way with states that predict those acts?  The answer is that in most everyday problems the correlations are either negligibly weak or vanish once we restrict the state space to factors lying outside your causal “light-cone’’.  Death in Damascus is engineered to highlight a perfect predictor who sits just outside that cone; the resulting strong correlation makes the instability visible.  CDT’s advocates could bite the bullet: “Yes, in such exotic situations CDT is awkward, but the theory is meant for ordinary life.’’  That response is diminished, though, by Newcomb and Smoking Lesion scenarios, which are arguably less contrived yet show similar tensions.

10. Comparative diagnosis: EDT and FDT  
Evidential decision theory (EDT) accepts correlations as legitimate guides, so it walks straight into Death’s embrace: seeing that going to Aleppo is evidence of Death’s being there (and with a higher multiplier than for Damascus), EDT recommends Damascus with no vacillation.  The stability of EDT illustrates that dependence on act-probabilities is not an inevitable feature of revisable-belief theories.  Functional or updateless decision theories (FDT/UDT) likewise avoid the instability by evaluating whole algorithms rather than point actions.  The contrast sharpens the charge against CDT: the very problem that plagues it is not a necessary evil but the product of a specific modelling choice.

11. The domination argument revisited  
Suppose we enrich the Death case with a third option: “stay home”, guaranteeing survival but yielding utility −1 for forgoing the trip.  CDT says the expected disutility of either destination can be driven arbitrarily close to −90 by slight credence tweaks, but “stay home’’ remains fixed at −1.  As p wanders, there will be stretches where CDT ranks “stay home’’ top.  Yet on any commonsense view a one-in-ten chance of death versus a negligible travel cost should not rationally push you to sacrifice the holiday.  The fact that CDT can recommend the dominated compromise illustrates how the dependence on act-probabilities permits pathological rankings that violate intuitive dominance principles.

12. Lessons for agency and self-locating belief  
What the Death story really dramatises is the recursive nature of self-locating belief: I know that what I do provides information about what sort of deliberator I am, and external predictors may tap that information.  The orthodox CDT framework, hinging on a static set of values P(s), is too coarse-grained to accommodate this recursion without oscillation.  A theory that allows the agent to treat her own decision as a random variable subject to choice cannot at the same time require her to treat probabilities concerning that variable as fixed input.

13. Is the problem fatal?  
Sceptics may urge that every decision theory faces some pathology once exotic predictors are admitted; after all, EDT is stable here but notoriously exploitable in Medical Newcomb cases, and FDT pays hefty costs in certain pre-commitment games.  True.  However, what is distinctive about CDT’s plight is that the instability appears even before external incentives are applied: it is generated purely internally by the theory’s own instruction to use unconditional probabilities that in fact are not independent of the act.  That looks like a mismatch between formal machinery and conceptual aims, not merely an unfortunate trade-off.

14. Conclusion  
The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities in Death in Damascus is more than a cosmetic irritation.  It forces CDT to issue oscillating or undefined guidance, reveals a breach of separability, enables domination traps, and blurs the boundary between causal and evidential considerations that the theory purports to respect.  Philosophers can respond by (i) restricting the scope of CDT, (ii) supplementing it with ratification or policy-selection principles, or (iii) abandoning it in favour of alternative frameworks that take algorithmic or evidential correlations as fundamental.  Whichever response one favours, the lesson is the same: a viable theory of rational choice must insulate the ranking of options from arbitrary shifts in self-prediction, or else supply an account of how deliberation converges despite those shifts.  Orthodoxy causal decision theory, in its bare form, does neither, so the dependence on act-probabilities is indeed a genuine problem.

Causal Decision Theory, Deliberation, and the “Death in Damascus’’ Puzzle  

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is the most widely defended descendant of the classical “expectation–maximising” picture of rational choice.  Yet beginning with Gibbard and Harper’s pioneering work in the 1970s, critics have pressed a series of cases—Newcomb’s Problem, the Predictor variants, and most recently “Death in Damascus’’—that appear to put CDT under strain.  What is striking about the Death in Damascus family is that the challenge arises even if we grant CDT its preferred causal‐expectational framework.  The worry is not about confusing evidential with causal dependence; it is about the role of the agent’s own probabilities for her future actions in the very computation CDT prescribes.  As the agent deliberates, those “act-probabilities’’ shift, and with them the theory’s recommendation can seesaw from one act to another.  The question before us is whether this sensitivity is an embarrassment for CDT or an innocuous artefact of careful deliberation.  

My answer is that the dependence is indeed a serious problem because it undermines three central desiderata for any theory of rational choice:

a) Stability under deliberation: recommendation should not flicker merely because I am thinking things through.  

b) Publicity and guidance: the theory should be able to issue advice the agent can follow from the first-person point of view.  

c) Diachronic coherence: the theory should not counsel plans that predictably lead the agent to regret her decision once she settles on it.

The discussion proceeds as follows.  Sect. 2 briefly rehearses CDT and the structure of Death in Damascus.  Sect. 3 diagnoses the dependence on act-probabilities and shows how it yields unstable advice.  Sect. 4 considers three lines of defence on CDT’s behalf—ratification, policy selection, and conditionalising on unrevealed “switch settings’’—and argues that each either fails or concedes too much.  Sect. 5 draws wider morals about the importance of decision theories that are “deliberation-proof,’’ concluding that the dependence really is a blemish on orthodox CDT.

2. CDT and the Death in Damascus set-up  

2.1 CDT in outline  

On the simplest presentation, CDT tells an agent to choose the act A that maximises causal expected utility:

CEU(A)=∑s P(s|do A) U(A,s).

Here s ranges over states of the world not causally downstream of A, do A is the “surgical’’ intervention operator imported from causal modelling, and U is the agent’s utility function, defined over act–state pairs.  In ordinary cases, the probabilities P(s|do A) are fixed by external causal structure and the agent’s background credence; the agent’s probability of performing the act is irrelevant.

2.2 The Death in Damascus story  

Ahmed’s modern formulation is vivid.  Death, an uncanny but fallible predictor, has vowed to find and kill you tomorrow.  Tonight you must choose whether to wake up in Damascus or Aleppo.  You know:

i) Death will be in whichever city he predicts you will be in;  
ii) Death’s predictions are correct with probability p<1 (so sometimes he guesses wrong);  
iii) Death has a bias: if his algorithm is unsure, it defaults to Damascus.

We can capture ii) and iii) by stipulating concrete numbers: say there is a 60 % chance Death correctly predicts your destination and, independently, a 10 % “default’’ chance he picks Damascus when his algorithm falters.  Utilities are extreme: survival is +1000, meeting Death is −1000.  

Crucially, Death’s prediction is made tonight, before you decide—but his bias makes Damascus objectively more dangerous.  Your worries should therefore depend on how likely you are to go to each city, because that influences how likely Death is already waiting in one spot.

2.3 Why expected utility now depends on act-probabilities  

Let q=Cr(Aleppo) be your current credence that you will choose Aleppo.  Conditional on do Aleppo, Death is in Aleppo with probability 0.6 and in Damascus with 0.4 (the coin of Death’s predictive success).  Conditional on do Damascus, those numbers swap.  But Death’s bias enters via the “prediction failure’’ branch: if Death failed to predict you, the 10 % default applies.  One finds, after a small calculation, that:

CEU(Aleppo)=1000·(1−p)+(−1000)·p,  
where p is itself a linear function of q (because the more likely you are to go to Aleppo, the more likely Death predicted Aleppo).  Hence CEU(Aleppo) is literally a function of q, and symmetrically CEU(Damascus) is a function of 1−q.

The moment you change your mind a little—tipping q from 0.45 to 0.55—the relative ranking of CEU(Aleppo) and CEU(Damascus) can reverse.  Deliberation about where to go thereby alters the very utilities used in deliberation.  The feedback loop threatens to make CDT “spin’’: as you edge toward Aleppo, Damascus starts to look better, prompting a shift back, which flips the recommendation again, and so on.

3. Why the dependence looks unsettling  

3.1 Instability and Dutch book-like cycles  

Suppose you begin with q=0.5.  Consulting CDT, you compute CEU(Aleppo)=CEU(Damascus)=0.  You shrug.  But the merest tilt—because you cough, remember a childhood memory, anything—nudges q to 0.51.  The causal calculation now says Aleppo scores −10, Damascus +10, so Damascus is strictly better.  Acting on that advice forces q to fall (you now think you’ll almost certainly go to Damascus), which makes Death’s predictor more likely to have anticipated Damascus, lowering CEU(Damascus) until Aleppo again is favoured.  There is no fixed point except extreme credences of 0 or 1, and reaching either boundary requires arbitrarily sensitive psychological shifts.  

An ideal Bayesian might converge to a mixed equilibrium, but a realistic deliberator cannot occupy a superposition of acts; she must eventually implement one.  CDT appears to give guidance as mercurial as the second hand of a clock.

3.2 Publicity and guidance  

Rational decision theory is supposed to be action-guiding.  To follow CDT, the agent must be able to consult her current credences and perform the maximisation.  If the act of consulting predictably disturbs those very credences, CDT delivers advice that effaces itself the moment it is issued—a kind of performative incoherence.  Imagine a GPS that, upon speaking the words “Turn left,” recalculates and insists, “No, turn right,” then recalculates again, ad infinitum.  Such a device is useless precisely because it is too responsive to its user’s epistemic state.

3.3 Diachronic regret  

In more formal terms, an agent using CDT in Death in Damascus will violate Ratifiability: an act she is about to perform will be one she would wish, even at that moment, to cancel if she could credibly pre-commit to cancelling.  The presence of predictable regret signals a failure of dynamic consistency.  For example, having ended deliberation with certainty she will go to Aleppo, she should, by her own lights, pay significant resources to re-open the choice, because she knows that conditioning on that certainty flips the utilities.

4. Three attempted CDT defences  

4.1 The ratification fix  

Jeffrey and Harper proposed that a rational act must be one that “ratifies’’ itself: it remains utility-maximising conditional on being chosen.  The idea is to outlaw acts whose desirability flows solely from the probability they will not be performed.  Applied here, only the mixed strategy of assigning your acts exactly the equilibrium probabilities (call them q*) ratifies.  But q* is not an act; at most, it is a lottery or behavioural disposition.  If CDT incorporates ratifiability, it tacitly becomes a theory of which dispositions to form, not which actions to take.  That is a radical revision: standard CDT bills itself as a one-shot act evaluator, not a second-order policy selector.

Moreover, implementing q* is psychologically infeasible.  You cannot simultaneously be 73 % confident you will pick Aleppo and 27 % confident you will pick Damascus if the deliberation is settled and you are moments away from acting.  Ratifiability therefore displaces rather than resolves the dependence issue.

4.2 “Take your probability as given’’  

Another move is to treat the agent’s own act-probabilities as exogenous parameters, fixed throughout deliberation.  From the third-person angle—say, a scientist on Mars—q really is an objective feature.  Why not require the agent to use those “objective’’ probabilities?

Because the agent does not know them.  She only has her subjective degrees of belief, and those are precisely what evolve as she determines what to do.  Requiring her to hold them fixed is tantamount to demanding perfect self-knowledge of an already-decided intention prior to deciding: a blatant circularity.  In epistemic terms, the agent’s act choice is self-locating; the correct credence is discovered only when the intention is formed.  CDT’s prescription must rely on the first-personal probabilities actually accessible to the deliberator.

4.3 Appeal to updateless or policy CDT  

Finally, some sympathisers suggest that CDT’s core insight survives if we shift from act evaluation to policy evaluation: choose the decision-rule that would have the highest causal expected utility upstream of any deliberation.  This “updateless’’ variant (closely related to Yudkowsky’s UDT) instructs the agent to adopt once-and-for-all policies that ignore later learning about their own choice.  In Death in Damascus, the winning policy is arguably “flip a fair coin now; go where it lands.”  Since Death’s prediction is made before the coin is tossed, his advantage is neutralised.

But that manoeuvre concedes the question.  The charge was that standard CDT, as formulated, falters; introducing updatelessness effects a new theory.  And it is not obvious that policy-selection and single-act choice always coincide.  We cannot count the success of the former as vindicating the latter.

5. The deeper moral: deliberation-proofness  

The cases teach a broader lesson: a satisfactory decision theory must be robust under the epistemic dynamics of deliberation.  Its advice should be fixed-point stable: learning what the theory recommends should not predictably make the recommendation self-defeating.  CDT fails that test in any domain where the evidential relevance of one’s own action cannot be cleanly screened off by causal intervention surgery.  Death in Damascus is merely the clearest case because the evidential back-link is mediated by a predictor whose accuracy is known.

Curiously, Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) performs better here.  EDT’s expected utility for an act is conditioned on the evidential event of performing that act.  Because action‐probabilities cancel on both sides, EDT delivers a static recommendation: go to Aleppo, the marginally safer city once Death’s bias is factored.  Whatever other liabilities EDT has (doctor-pills, smoking lesion, etc.), in this context it provides guidance that is stable, publicity-friendly, and regret-free.

One might object that CDT’s instability is confined to fanciful predictor cases.  But similar feedback loops arise whenever an opponent has predictive insight into my behaviour, including real-world competitive markets and strategic negotiations.  Humans routinely model one another’s likely moves.  Hence a fundamental theory of rationality cannot declare the phenomenon out of scope.

6. Conclusion  

The dependence of causal expected utility on the agent’s own act-probabilities in Death in Damascus is not a mere curiosity; it exposes a fundamental tension between CDT’s act-level causal-conditional recipe and the fact that deciding is itself an epistemically revelatory act.  Because CDT’s recommendation oscillates as those probabilities shift during ordinary deliberation, the theory fails three core demands: stability, guidance, and diachronic coherence.  Proposed repairs either change the subject (ratification, policy selection) or rest on inaccessible information (objective act-probabilities).  Unless a new, principled revision of CDT can insulate it from this feedback loop, we should conclude that the dependence is indeed a problem—one that calls for either a rival decision theory or a reconceptualisation of rational choice that is, in Ahmed’s phrase, “deliberation-proof.”

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is often presented as the sober-minded heir to Humean orthodoxy: choose the act whose causal consequences you most prefer, weighting each possible consequence by the probability that the act will bring it about.  Because the probabilities that appear in the CDT calculation are meant to be ‘‘causal’’ rather than ‘‘evidential,’’ the theory instructs the agent to hold fixed any facts that are not causally downstream of the contemplated act.  That instruction is intuitively compelling in many ordinary choice situations: when I decide whether to carry an umbrella, I should treat the chance of rain as independent of my decision, since taking an umbrella cannot causally influence the weather.

In the celebrated ‘Death in Damascus’ story (a variant of versions originally due to Ahmed, Arntzenius and others), the very feature that looks innocent in the umbrella case—holding fixed the probabilities of act-independent states—turns out to make an agent’s expected utilities depend on her own, shifting, credences about how she will act.  As one comes to feel more inclined to go to Aleppo, one must at the same time raise one’s unconditional probability that Death is waiting in Aleppo, for the simple reason that Death is a reliable predictor.  That fact opens the door to a striking form of decision-instability: wher­ever you currently lean seems the more dangerous city, so whichever city you currently regard as less likely to be chosen looks, by CDT’s lights, safer.  The recommendation flips back and forth in lock-step with your moment-to-moment inclinations.

Is this dependence a deep problem for CDT?  I shall argue that it is.  The dependence undermines CDT’s ability to guide action; it conflicts with plausible requirements of dynamic rationality (ratifiability and stability); and it opens the theory to a new species of ‘Dutch book’ in which an agent can be forced to pay for mere indecision.  I close by reviewing two well-known CDT responses—policy selection and the ratifiability fix—and explain why neither fully cures the patient.  The upshot is that Death in Damascus reveals an instability at the heart of causal decision theoretic reasoning that should lead us either to modify CDT significantly or to prefer a rival theory.  

2. The Case More Precisely  

Let the utilities be simple.  If you and Death end up in the same city, you lose one util; if you choose the other city you break even.  Suppose you have no intrinsic preference between Damascus and Aleppo.  Let q be your current subjective probability that you will go to Damascus when the moment to act arrives.  Death is a near-perfect forecaster, correct with accuracy α (0.9, 0.99, 0.999—any value less than 1 will do) and, when he errs, he has a bias β toward guessing Damascus.  Formally:

P(Death guesses D | you will go D) = α  
P(Death guesses A | you will go A) = α  
When he guesses wrong, P(he says D) = β.

Because Death positions himself in the city he names, the unconditional probability that Death will be waiting in Damascus is:

P(D* ) = αq + (1-α)β,

where D* abbreviates ‘Death in Damascus’.  Crucially, q occurs in that expression; as your opinion about your own future act changes, your probability for Death’s whereabouts must change, even though Death’s whereabouts are not causally influenced by your eventual bodily motion.  

CDT instructs you to compute:

EU(go D)  = −1 · P(D*) + 0 · P(A*) = −P(D*)  
EU(go A)  = −1 · P(A*) = −[1 − P(D*)].

Hence

EU(go D) − EU(go A) = −P(D*) + [1 − P(D*)] = 1 − 2P(D*).

So Damascus looks better exactly when P(D*) < 0.5, i.e. when

αq + (1-α)β < 0.5.                                            (★)

But (★) is a condition on q.  Whenever your degree of confidence that you will go to Damascus is small enough to make (★) true, EU(go D) exceeds EU(go A).  Yet the moment you recognise that fact you should raise q—after all, you have just concluded that Damascus is where you ought to go.  Raising q may push the left side of (★) above 0.5, reversing the ranking and motivating you to plan for Aleppo, at which point q drops, and so on.  Nothing in the causal set-up of the case forces oscillation; the oscillation is generated purely by CDT’s dependence on q.  

3. Three Reasons That This Dependence Is Troubling  

3.1  Guidance Failure  

A decision theory is supposed to tell agents what to do.  But a recommendation that flips as quickly as the agent can contemplate it cannot guide.  You could try to overcome the see-saw by deliberately acting contrary to whichever city CDT currently favours, but that contrarian policy is itself CDT-irrational: at the moment of action you would be knowingly selecting an option with lower causal expected utility.  So CDT leaves you with only two live possibilities:

a) Suspend deliberation arbitrarily at some time-slice, choosing the city that then maximises EU.  
b) Continue deliberating indefinitely, never acting.

Neither is a plausible ideal of rational guidance.  (a) reduces CDT to the principle “pick a moment at random and do what CDT then says,” which inherits the randomness of the stopping rule; (b) is paralysis.  A theory that delivers guidance only if one declines to think too hard is, at best, incomplete.  

3.2  Dynamic Inconsistency and Ratifiability  

Jeffrey proposed that a rational plan ought to be ratifiable: after you learn that you are going to perform the act, you should still endorse performing it.  In Death in Damascus there is no act that meets this requirement for any non-degenerate prior over your own acts.  For suppose you could somehow discover that you will in fact go to Damascus (so that q=1).  Then P(D*) = α + (1-α)β > 0.5 (given α>0.5); CDT would immediately tell you that Aleppo would have been better.  Symmetrically, if you found out you were headed to Aleppo you would wish you were not.  So whichever act you perform, you expect that, upon learning you will perform it, you will regret it on CDT’s own terms.  CDT therefore violates a plausible norm of diachronic rationality: you can foresee, before acting, that your future self will regard the act as irrational—yet present-CDT still regards the act as rational relative to the earlier probability q.  

3.3  Exploitability (a Dutch-Book-like Worry)  

Consider a cunning bookmaker who knows you use CDT and who can sell you last-minute escape insurance: a ticket costing ε that pays out 1 util if Death is predicted to be in the city you actually enter.  Whenever you start leaning toward Aleppo, CDT makes you think Damascus is safer and Aleppo dangerous; you are liable to buy a Damascus ticket.  Moments later, the evaluation flips and you buy an Aleppo ticket for another ε; the swings can be repeated until the cost of tickets drains any surplus utility regardless of where you end up.  The bookmaker is exploiting only your shifting CDT valuations, not adding any causal influence over Death’s position.  Some defenders will object that rational agents would notice the pattern and refuse further bets.  But noticing the pattern just is noticing that your decision rule creates oscillations; if that is sufficient ground to ignore CDT’s current recommendation on the next bet, why not also on the next action?  The exploitability worry is therefore parasitic on the underlying instability; patching one without the other seems unlikely.  

4. Three CDT Responses  

4.1  The “Ignore Your Own Act-Probabilities’’ Rejoinder  

One might insist that while entertaining an act A you should set P(A)=1 “for the purposes of the causal calculation.’’  Then q disappears from the expectation; Death’s location receives the unconditional probability it had prior to deliberation, call that r.  If r > 0.5 you ought to go to Aleppo and the instability never arises.

Two difficulties plague this manoeuvre.  First, it is ad hoc: CDT explicitly instructs us to use “unconditional’’ probabilities for states not downstream of the act, and the unconditional probability of Death’s choice is sensitive to q. Replacing it by the probability conditional on A without modifying the rest of CDT is a theoretical graft, not a derivation.  Second, the manoeuvre conflicts with the very motivation for ignoring evidential links: the reason I withhold umbrellas from influencing the chance of rain is that my taking an umbrella does not cause rain; but my taking Damascus also does not cause Death’s past prediction.  On standard CDT principles, conditioning on the act when evaluating the act is exactly the evidential move CDT forbids.  So the graft changes the theory.  

4.2  The Policy (or Hierarchical) Strategy  

Joyce, Skyrms and others have suggested that what CDT really tells an ideally rational agent to choose is a complete conditional policy: a mapping from possible observation histories to actions.  In Death in Damascus, one is to pick between two policies: “always go to Damascus’’ or “always go to Aleppo.”  Because the policy choice is made at t0, Death’s earlier prediction is causally downstream of it, so CDT permits conditioning on the policy when computing expected utility.  The agent therefore compares:

EU(policy D) = −α − (1−α)β  
EU(policy A) = −αβ − (1−α),

and whichever is larger stays larger; no oscillation ensues.

Although the policy move tames the instability, it achieves safety by reshuffling the causal relation between prediction and action.  We are now supposing that Death reacts to the policy choice, not the concrete act.  But in the original informal statement, Death reacted to your dispositions; those dispositions include whatever higher-level policy you covertly adopt.  So the hierarchical solution may succeed for a rational god who can fix an entire policy in one timeless stroke, but the everyday agent planning at noon where to spend the evening still faces shifting expectations unless she can time-slice herself into a policy-selecting earlier self who is not herself subject to the same CDT calculus.  Furthermore, real-world predictions (think of human psychologists or machine-learning algorithms) are sensitive to multiple features of us; some of those features may evolve during deliberation and scratch out the neat policy boundary.  CDT then inherits the original instability inside every policy-slice.  In short, the policy dodge works only if one attributes to the agent a degree of self-binding that CDT alone does not provide.  

4.3  The Ratifiability Fix  

Another thought is to impose a ratifiability constraint externally: an act is rational by CDT only if, upon discovering that one is about to perform it, one does not expect a different act to have had higher causal expected utility.  In Death in Damascus there is no act that satisfies the constraint given realistic α and β (in the limiting case α=β=0.5 both acts tie).  Consequently, the ratifiability fix declares the problem cases to be ones in which no rational act exists.  Some may live with that verdict, treating the case as a ‘forced error’ situation where any move is irrational because the world is vicious.  But the stance abandons CDT’s pretension to be complete; worse, it collapses guidance again.  Agents still have to do something—Death is coming—and a theory that responds “nothing is rational, so good luck’’ is not an acceptable practical guide.  

5. Why The Problem Runs Deeper than a Technicality  

So far I have pointed out that CDT suffers from guidance failure, dynamic inconsistency, and exploitability in Death-like cases, and that the three standard repairs abridge CDT’s principles or jettison completeness.  That catalogue already suggests a serious theoretical cost.  But the problem is deeper because the dependence on one’s own act-probabilities conflicts with the motivational core of CDT itself.

CDT was born of dissatisfaction with Evidential Decision Theory (EDT).  EDT, critics argued, sometimes rewards actions merely because they correlate with good outcomes, even when those correlations are purely evidential.  CDT avoids that mistake by rewriting the expected utility formula so that correlations that are not causal are ignored.  Yet in Death in Damascus the dependence on q is not a mere evidential correlation; it arises because the unconditional probability of Death’s presence in a city just is mathematically equal to the probability that you will go there, a fact that remains true whether or not any causal link obtains.  CDT therefore cannot simply ignore q without resurrecting its criticism of EDT—selectively blind to inconvenient correlations.  The dilemma is stark: either accept q-dependence, in which case rational choice becomes an unstable self-referential dance; or disallow it, in which case CDT must give up the principle that only causal relations matter.

One might hope that ideal Bayesian agents would not in practice exhibit oscillations: their probabilities might converge smoothly to 0 or 1, at which point CDT’s recommendation stabilises.  But convergence is not guaranteed.  Jeffrey’s randomisation is compatible with Bayes; a perfectly rational mind may assign non-degenerate act-probabilities at arbitrarily late stages of deliberation.  Indeed, the agent may intentionally mix when she anticipates that any pure decision will be exploited—precisely the intuition Newcomb-style cases teach.  So the problem cannot be wished away by an appeal to idealisation.  

6. What Should Replace CDT?  

If one concludes that dependence on act-probabilities is a fatal flaw, two broad directions suggest themselves:

1. Decision theories that allow evidential considerations, e.g. a carefully constrained EDT or the ‘functional decision theory’ recently proposed by Yudkowsky and Soares, which explicitly embraces the idea that your decision is evidence about logically (though not causally) connected events like predictions.

2. Hybrid theories that retain CDT’s causal core but insert a global fixed-point requirement: the expected utility of an act must be computed at a probability vector that is itself stable under CDT choice.  Such theories blend the ratifiability idea with a constructive rule to pick a fixed point when several exist.

Both options go beyond this paper’s remit.  What matters for present purposes is that, given Death in Damascus, sticking with orthodox CDT is not cost-free; one must either swallow serious guidance and consistency worries or rewrite the theory’s operating rules.

7. Conclusion  

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting credence about her own future behaviour is not a benign curiosity.  It

• deprives CDT of the capacity to stably guide rational choice,  
• violates plausible diachronic coherence norms (no act is ratifiable), and  
• exposes the agent to exploitative betting systems that capitalise on predictable oscillations.  

Attempts to rescue CDT by ignoring self-probabilities, elevating the unit of choice to policies, or annexing an external ratifiability test either change CDT’s foundations or abandon its claim to completeness.  The upshot is that Death in Damascus poses not just a puzzle but a genuine theoretical challenge: the very feature that insulates CDT from evidential “spooky-action-at-a-distance’’—the use of act-independent probabilities—turns CDT against itself when those probabilities are, in virtue of reliable prediction, mathematically tethered to the agent’s own states of indecision.

One can, of course, insist that rational choice is occasionally impossible; perhaps the universe sometimes puts us in no-win situations.  Yet it would be surprising if mere knowledge of a predictor’s bias could by itself deprive rational agents of any defensible choice function.  The more plausible moral is that our decision theory should allow us to treat correlations with our act as informationally and pragmatically relevant even when those correlations are not mediated by ordinary causation.  How best to articulate such a theory remains the subject of lively debate, but on this point Death in Damascus speaks clearly: CDT, unrevised, is not the last word.

1. Introduction  

A fully satisfactory decision theory should do at least three things.  First, it should tell an agent, here-and-now, which option she ought to take.  Second, it should do so in a way that is dynamically stable: once the agent sincerely follows the theory’s advice her grounds for action should not immediately evaporate or reverse.  Third, the advice should depend only on facts that rational deliberation need not treat as open to arbitrary manipulation.  Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is widely thought to satisfy all three demands.  It recommends the option with the highest causal expected utility, i.e. the expected utility obtained by weighting the causal consequence-profile of each act by the agent’s unconditional probabilities for events not causally downstream of that act.  

The family of “Death in Damascus” cases, however, appears to expose a serious fissure in CDT.  In these cases the unconditional probability that matters to CDT is itself a function of the very probability that the agent assigns to performing each act while deliberating.  As the agent’s self-probabilities waver, CDT’s rankings move with them; what is recommended at one moment ceases to be recommended the next.  Does this show that CDT is defective?  I shall argue that it does.  The dependence on act probabilities makes CDT (i) dynamically unstable, (ii) normatively indeterminate, and (iii) hostage to what William Harper called an “illusion of control.”  I then consider and reject three attempts to defend CDT: the “probabilities must be 0 or 1” reply, the appeal to ratifiability equilibria, and a suggestion that the difficulty is not unique to CDT.  The upshot is that the phenomenon really is a deep problem for orthodox causal decision theory.

2. Death in Damascus – the structure of the case  

Suppose you know that tomorrow you will meet Death, who intends to keep an appointment with you in the city he predicts you will visit.  Death’s predictions are not perfect, but they are quite reliable: whatever city he names is the one you actually choose with probability 0.9.  Further, you have a mild preference for Damascus over Aleppo in the absence of Death (say, utility 10 instead of 0), while meeting Death gives utility –1000.  

Timeline.  (i) Tonight you must choose Damascus (D) or Aleppo (A).  (ii) Earlier today Death formed a prediction about which city you will pick.  (iii) Your act does not causally influence Death’s earlier prediction; but of course your act is correlated with his prediction, since his reliability is high.  

CDT tells you to evaluate each act by holding fixed the causal past—particularly Death’s already fixed prediction—and taking the unconditional probabilities of the bad event “Death is in the same city as me.”  Let GD be the event “Death predicted Damascus,” GA the event “Death predicted Aleppo.”  Let δ be your present (deliberation-time) probability that you will go to Damascus.  Because Death is 0.9 reliable,  

P(GD) = 0.9δ + 0.1(1−δ) = 0.1 + 0.8δ  
P(GA) = 0.9(1−δ) + 0.1δ = 0.9 − 0.8δ.  

Expected utilities:  

EU(D) = (−1000)·P(GD) + 10·(1−P(GD))  
EU(A) = (−1000)·P(GA) + 0·(1−P(GA)).  

Because P(GD) and P(GA) are linear in δ, both EU(D) and EU(A) are functions of your present credence about your own future action.  As δ varies from 0 to 1, the preferred act flips twice:  

• If you are almost sure you will go to Aleppo (δ near 0), Death probably predicted Aleppo; Damascus looks safer, so CDT recommends Damascus.  
• As δ rises, P(GD) rises and EU(D) falls; a point comes where Aleppo looks safer, so CDT recommends Aleppo.  
• If you become nearly certain you will go to Damascus (δ near 1), Death almost certainly predicted Damascus, making Damascus terrible; but Aleppo is then almost certainly safe, so CDT again recommends Damascus.  

Thus the act with maximal causal expected utility depends sensitively on δ; yet δ is precisely the state of indecision you are trying to resolve.  That dependence generates three inter­related difficulties.

3. Dynamic instability  

A decision rule is dynamically stable if an agent who sincerely applies it will not immediately find herself with new grounds to change her mind.  CDT in Death-style cases fails this test.  Suppose you begin with δ = 0.3.  A quick calculation shows EU(D) > EU(A), so CDT tells you to go to Damascus.  The moment you resolve to do so, however, δ jumps to 1; plugging δ = 1 into the same formulas now makes Aleppo look overwhelmingly safer.  If you are fully rational and keep applying CDT you should now switch to Aleppo.  But resolving on Aleppo drives δ back toward 0, restoring Damascus as the better option.  You are caught in an endlessly repeating pendulum of deliberation.  

Importantly, nothing external changes.  The only moving part is your inner credence about what you will do.  A respectable decision theory should not produce such self-defeating feedback loops.  The instability reveals that CDT’s advice is not robust under the very process of following it, thereby violating the second desideratum stated in the introduction.

4. Normative indeterminacy  

Because CDT’s ranking oscillates with δ, the theory does not deliver a unique answer to the question “What ought I to do?” unless there is some antecedent principle fixing the “right” δ.  But δ is not something the agent finds in the world; it is part of her current epistemic state.  Two agents with identical information about everything except their fleeting self-probabilities receive opposite prescriptions from CDT.  Worse, a single agent may run through every real value between 0 and 1 while thinking the question over; by CDT’s lights each of those fleeting credences supports a different “ought.”  Hence the theory fails our first desideratum: it does not give determinate guidance.

One might try to reply that the correct decision for an ideal agent is the limit of this process, but there is no convergent limit.  Unless special parameter values conspire to create a fixed point (we consider that possibility in section 6), the theory simply refuses to settle.

5. The illusion of control  

A third problem is epistemic.  What rational reason could you have for letting your unconditional probability P(GD) change just because you decide to go to Damascus?  After all, Death’s prediction was made yesterday on evidence that does not include the causal effect of your present resolution.  If you are genuinely following CDT you treat Death’s act as causally independent of yours.  So why should your current self-probability δ make any difference to P(GD)?  The answer is: it makes a difference only given the background antecedent that links Death’s reliability to the act you will in fact perform.  But that link exploits exactly the correlation CDT insists we must ignore when computing causal expected utility.  The agent is, in effect, taking her own mixed strategy as evidence about an earlier, causally independent event.  That is an evidential move, not a causal one.  Harper dubbed this the “illusion of control”: the agent treats internal shuffle of credences as if it could preview or influence an external fact that is, ex hypothesi, beyond her causal reach.  A causal decision procedure ought to be immune to such illusions.  Yet CDT’s value-function is built out of them.

6. The ratifiability gambit  

CDT’s defenders often invoke Gibbard and Harper’s notion of ratifiability.  A plan is ratifiable when, conditional on intending to follow it, one still prefers to follow it.  In the Death in Damascus setup, the only ratifiable plans are (i) mixed strategies that set δ at a fixed point of the EU comparisons, or (ii) the “value-irrelevant” act of randomising with exactly the reliability-matching probability that makes both cities equally bad.  Technically, there is indeed a mixed strategy δ* ≈ 0.5 such that EU(D|δ*) = EU(A|δ*).  If the agent could peg her self-probability at that value and carry through, CDT would stop oscillating.

Two objections.  

a. Ratifiability has to be added to CDT; it is not entailed by the orthodox formulation.  Any theory can be mended ad hoc by tacking on equilibrium conditions, but that masks rather than solves the underlying difficulty.  

b. Even granting the ratifiability fix, the prescription it yields is counter-intuitive.  Why should it be rational to decide by coin-flip to avoid an omnipotent foe when you know he is 90% reliable?  On any intuitive reading of “rational,” one ought to get as far away as possible from the predicted spot.  The ratifiability solution therefore violates ordinary practical wisdom; it is a desperate measure to salvage formal coherence, not a satisfying resolution.

7. “Probability 1” reply  

Another way to defend CDT is to insist that a perfectly rational agent, at the act-selection moment, must assign probability 1 to the act she is about to perform.  If δ is always 0 or 1, EU(D) and EU(A) become constant (in fact Damascus is always terrible, Aleppo is always terrible), so no oscillation.  

This maneuver fails on two counts.  First, real-world agents are frequently uncertain about how they will decide.  A theory purporting to guide human deliberation cannot simply legislate that such uncertainty is irrational.  Second, even the idealised picture breaks down in games of chance or intentional randomisation devices, which orthodox CDT recognises as sometimes utility-maximising.  In those situations the agent quite deliberately maintains a non-degenerate probability over her own acts.  So the “probability one” move is both descriptively false and normatively unmotivated.

8. “The problem is general”  

A final line of defence says that any decision theory using expected utility must feed on the agent’s credences, including credences about her future behaviour; therefore the dependence discovered here is not peculiar to CDT.  But this is mistaken.  Evidential Decision Theory (EDT), for instance, conditions on the act itself and therefore does not treat the unconditional probability of Death’s location as a function of fluctuating δ.  Functional Decision Theory and policy-selection approaches likewise avoid the loop by treating the entire output of the decision algorithm as a single object of evaluation, not each possible act in isolation.  The instability we diagnosed arises from CDT’s unique pairing of unconditional probabilities with act-by-act evaluation during an ongoing process of deliberation.

9. Why the dependence is a genuine flaw  

Putting the pieces together, the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on deliberation-time self-probabilities is a flaw because:

1. It violates dynamical stability: faithfully following CDT can lead to an infinite regress of changing preferences with no action ever ratified.  
2. It deprives the theory of determinate practical guidance, since the deliverance “choose X” is relativised to arbitrarily malleable probabilities.  
3. It roots causal expected-utility calculations in evidential correlations that CDT officially disavows, thereby undermining the conceptual motivation for the theory.  

These points are not merely technical.  They show that the standard presentation of CDT cannot simultaneously respect its own causal scruples, deliver clear advice, and remain stable under reflection.  That is precisely the sort of failure that justifies searching for alternatives—whether a refined version of CDT that works at the level of policies rather than single acts, a shift to a fully counterfactual decision theory, or abandonment of the causal-evidential picture altogether.

10. Conclusion  

The Death in Damascus puzzle brings into sharp relief a weakness that is usually hidden in less exotic contexts: CDT’s expected-utility numbers can turn on nothing more than the agent’s flickering self-conception.  Any theory that makes rational choice hostage to such ephemera mislocates the normative centre of gravity.  Because the dependence generates instability, indeterminacy, and a subtle evidential slide, it is indeed a serious problem for Causal Decision Theory.

The lesson is not that causal information is irrelevant to rational choice but that using unconditional probabilities act-by-act is a blunt tool.  Rational agency is better modelled by looking at whole deliberative policies or by integrating causal constraints differently.  Until CDT is modified to block the dependence on act probabilities, it cannot claim to be the final word on rational decision-making.

I. Introduction   

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is often advertised as the sober, clear–headed alternative to the allegedly “witch-doctor’’ reasoning of evidential decision theory.  An act, on the CDT picture, is to be chosen because of what it would causally bring about, not because of what it would be evidence for.  The policy is simple in form:

    For each available act A,
        EU(A) = Σs  P(s)  U(A, s),
    choose the act with highest EU.

Here s ranges over “states of the world not causally downstream of A’’.  In garden-variety choice problems those states are exogenous: facts about the weather, the stock market, the opponent’s card, and so on.  Ordinarily they do not depend on what the agent is currently leaning toward doing.  

Death in Damascus (first floated by Donald Davidson and later popularised by Andy Egan, Jim Joyce, and others) is not an ordinary problem.  Where one travels seems to be exogenous, but it is not: an uncanny Predictor, Death, forms a fairly reliable belief about your destination and goes there to collect you.  That predictor’s activity is not causally influenced by your act, but it is exquisitely correlated with it.  As a result, the unconditional probability of each state—Death waits in Aleppo, Death waits in Damascus— depends on your current credence about what you will do.  And because during deliberation that credence can fluctuate, the CDT ranking of acts can fluctuate with it, apparently giving the agent no stable advice.

Is this dependence on the agent’s own mixed state of mind a real defect in CDT?  Below I argue that it is.  The instability is not a harmless curiosity but reveals a deeper tension between CDT’s formal recipe and the practical standpoint of a deliberating agent.  After presenting the structure of the Damascus case (Section II) and showing explicitly how CDT’s expected-utility numbers depend on evolving act probabilities (Section III), I consider three strategies a causal decision theorist might adopt (Section IV).  Each strategy, I contend, either (i) abandons a core motivation for CDT, (ii) tacitly imports an evidential element, or (iii) leaves the agent without usable advice.  I close (Section V) by extracting a more general moral: if a decision rule makes the value of an option turn on the very probabilities that the rule is meant to fix, the rule risks practical incoherence.

II. The death in Damascus scenario made precise  

Let the two cities be A (Aleppo) and D (Damascus).  The agent must, at noon, board a taxi bound for one of them.  Death has already formed a prediction of the agent’s choice using a method that is:

    Reliability:  P(Death predicts city X | you go to X) = r  (where ½ < r < 1).
    Bias:         In the limiting case of no information, Death weakly prefers to guess D.

For concreteness let r = .9 and let the bias work as follows: when the predictor’s algorithm registers indifference, it flips a weighted coin that lands D 60 % of the time.

The utility profile is simple:

    You meet Death:      U = –1000
    You avoid Death:     U =  +  10    (life goes on, slightly enriched by travel)

Your prior subjective probabilities at the start of deliberation (call this t0) include:

    p0(A) = probability you’ll choose Aleppo,
    p0(D) = 1 – p0(A) = probability you’ll choose Damascus.

Given those, you can compute:

    P0(Death in A) =   r·p0(A) + (1–r)·p0(D)·(bias towards D fails)
    P0(Death in D) =   r·p0(D) + (1–r)·p0(A)·(bias towards A fails)

Notice that if p0(A) changes, so do both unconditional probabilities of Death’s location.  And CDT, being governed by those very probabilities, will recalibrate its advice whenever your own preferences wobble.

III. CDT’s sliding recommendations  

Compute EU of going to Aleppo at generic time t (when your current credence that you will, in the end, go to A is pt(A)):

   EUt(A) = [P_t(Death in A)](–1000) + [P_t(Death in D)](+10).

By symmetry,

   EUt(D) = [P_t(Death in D)](–1000) + [P_t(Death in A)](+10).

Subtract to see which is better:

   EUt(A) – EUt(D) = (P_t(Death in D) – P_t(Death in A))·(–1010).

Because –1010 < 0, Aleppo is strictly preferred just in case P_t(Death in D) < P_t(Death in A).  But inspection of the formulae shows that

   P_t(Death in A) – P_t(Death in D) = r·(pt(A) – pt(D)) + (1–r)·(pt(D) – pt(A))
                                    = (2r – 1)(pt(A) – pt(D)).

Since r > ½, (2r – 1) > 0.  So

   EUt(A) – EUt(D) = –1010·(2r – 1)(pt(A) – pt(D)).

Hence:

   • If pt(A) > pt(D), the difference is negative, so EU(A) < EU(D); CDT says “Go to Damascus.”
   • If pt(A) < pt(D), CDT flips and says “Go to Aleppo.”
   • If pt(A) = ½, the agent is knife-edged indifferent.

The moment you feel the slightest lean toward Aleppo, CDT tells you that Damascus has the higher causal expected utility; acting on that advice moves your lean toward Damascus, and—as the algebra shows—the advice flips back.  You oscillate, and no fixed point exists unless r = ½ (archaic, purely random predictor) or the utilities are exactly balanced (meet Death costs 0, which trivialises the case).

IV. Is this instability a defect?  Three lines of defence and their limits  

1. “Stick to the prior” defence.  

   A resolute causalist may say: CDT was never intended as an algorithm for mid-stream deliberative updating.  One is to enter the decision problem with settled subjective probabilities about exogenous states.  Plug those into EU, pick the maximiser, and execute.  If your credences change while you ponder—which they arguably should not, given that no new information arrives—then the fault lies in your vacillating doxastic policy, not in CDT.

   Reply: This response sidelines the very phenomenon that generates the puzzle: that ordinary agents do find their credences in their own future acts shifting as they entertain different arguments.  Saying “don’t do that” is like telling a seasick passenger “don’t feel queasy.”  More seriously, CDT’s formal statement makes no reference to a privileged “prior.”  The recipe says “calculate expected utility using unconditional probabilities that you hold.”  It does not specify a freeze-frame.  Unless the theory is supplemented with an independently motivated norm forbidding updates in light of one’s own tentative inclinations—an awkward add-on—the Damascus oscillation resurfaces.

2. “Deliberation screen-off” defence.  

   Joyce has suggested that rational agents should impose the following principle: conditionalise on the proposition that you are now deliberating between A and D.  Once you have done so, the unconditional probability of Death’s location should no longer depend on your subsequently favouring one act over the other; the very process of rational deliberation screens it off.  Thus pt(A) is removed from the P_t(Death in A) calculation, breaking the feedback loop.

   Reply: To make this manoeuvre work you must treat your eventual act as causally determined by whatever causal factors you already regard as fixed at the onset of deliberation.  That collapses the gulf between evidential and causal evaluation: learning that you deliberate in a certain cool and collected way gives you evidence about your act and hence about Death’s destination.  To bar such information from your calculus is to redact evidence for purely evidential reasons, which looks ad hoc from CDT’s purportedly causal perspective.  So the screen-off rule either restates EUT (expected utility theory) in evidential dress or adds a pragmatic rule that your initial, still-unsettled degree of belief in A is to be treated as causally inert henceforth—again an ad hoc rider.

3. “Mixed-strategy / commitment” defence.  

   A third move invites the agent to adopt a mixed strategy: publicly randomise with a fair coin, announce the result, and go where the coin directs.  Because Death cannot foresee the outcome of the coin toss, the correlation between act and prediction breaks down.  Conditional on commitment to randomisation, CDT gives stable advice (indeed EU becomes symmetrical).  So the instability infects only pure strategies, not the rational recommendations of a sophisticated causalist who sees the value of commitment devices.

   Reply: It is true that commitment or randomisation can dissolve the predictor’s edge.  But the need for commitment underscores exactly what is at issue.  The raw choice between A and D, unaccompanied by an external randomiser, is ill-posed for CDT because the act’s expected utility lacks a determinate value until the agent steps outside and ties her hands.  Commitment is rational precisely because the base-level rule is incoherent.  The causal decision theorist may claim victory—“CDT advises commitment!”—but that is not an answer to why CDT cannot guide the agent prior to commitment.  Decision rules are supposed to underwrite the rationality of commitment, not presuppose it.

V. The deeper problem: reflexive dependence  

Philosophical accounts of rational choice must ultimately speak to an agent situated in real time, whose mental states are not exogenous but part of the evolving system.  A rule that takes as input the agent’s own credence about what she is about to do is therefore treading on dangerous ground.  Those credences are precisely what the rule is meant to help fix.  When the value it assigns to an act is a monotone function of that very credence, two things happen:

   (a) No equilibrium is guaranteed.  Our algebra above shows that, short of knife-edge indifference, the rule forever chases its own tail.
   (b) Practical guidance evaporates.  A rational directive must be stable on reflection; if following the directive rationally changes the probabilities that figure in the directive, it does not converge on an answer.

Contrast evidential decision theory (EDT).  EDT, too, uses unconditional probabilities, but they do not depend on the deliberating agent’s current credence in the act because EDT conditions on the act when computing value:

   EU_EDT(A) = Σs P(s | A) U(A,s).

Since P(s | A) is by stipulation independent of how probable you think A is before deciding, EDT survives the reflexivity test.  One may dispute whether EDT gets Newcomb problems right, but at least it speaks with a single voice while you ponder.

Could CDT be patched by replacing unconditional P(s) with the probabilities at some earlier time-slice prior to the onset of deliberation?  That would amount to hard-wiring “Use the true prior.”  Alas, in Death-type cases your earlier self may have little idea what her own later deliberations will favour; nor does she know the shape of argument she will find persuasive.  We would be giving normative significance to an arbitrary temporal boundary, which is no more satisfying than telling the seasick passenger “Trust how you felt two minutes ago.”

The diagnosis, then, is that CDT’s dependence on act probabilities is a real defect, at least in environments where predictors key their actions to your choice.  The dependence undermines a basic desideratum for a decision rule: independence from the very psychological factor it is designed to settle.  Where that factor is labile, as it normally is in deliberation, CDT cannot guarantee action-guidance.

VI. Conclusion  

Death in Damascus exposes a fragility in causal decision theory’s core prescription.  Because the theory evaluates acts using unconditional probabilities of correlated but non-causally-downstream states, and because those probabilities shift with the agent’s own evolving self-prediction, the theory can deliver no stable recommendation.  Attempts to save CDT either (i) freeze credences by fiat, (ii) smuggle in evidential considerations, or (iii) fall back on commitment devices whose rationality the theory cannot underwrite without circularity.  The upshot is not that CDT is worthless—its causal scruples capture something important about manipulability and control—but that its canonical formulation is incomplete.  Any adequate decision rule must insulate the valuation of an act from the very credences that deliberation is meant to resolve.  Until CDT finds a way to do so, the Damascus oscillation remains a genuine problem.

1. Introduction  

Since its canonical formulation by David Lewis and Brian Skyrms, Causal Decision Theory (CDT) has been the leading attempt to reconcile two seemingly obvious claims about rational choice: first, that rational agents should maximise expected utility, and second, that only what an act causally influences should matter to that calculation. CDT therefore tells an agent to evaluate each available act A by
EUCDT(A) = Σs P(s) · U(outcome produced when A is performed in s),
where the sum ranges over “states of the world” s that are not causally downstream of A.  In ordinary cases—choosing coffee rather than tea, buying insurance rather than gambling—CDT coincides with common-sense deliberation.  When we move to cases in which predictors, correlations, or signalling link our choice to events our act does not causally affect, things become complicated.  ‘Death in Damascus’ (first introduced by Gibbard and Harper, and refined by Ahmed, Joyce, and others) is a paradigmatic complication.  In such cases the utility of what we do depends, in part, on our current credence that we will do it.  That dependence threatens to make CDT’s prescriptions eerily unstable; a small fluctuation in self-predicted behaviour can flip the expected-utility ordering of acts, producing a deliberative oscillation with no stable end-point.  The question is whether this instability should be regarded as a defect of CDT, and if so, why.

I shall argue that it is a genuine problem, because (i) the norm of deliberation implicit in CDT cannot survive when an act’s expected utility itself feeds back on the probability of that act, (ii) attempts to cure the instability—ratification, mixed strategies, or separating “ex ante” from “ex interim” evaluations—either abandon CDT’s core idea or leave the problem untouched, and (iii) we can articulate a clear rational requirement that is violated by any decision rule that allows its recommendations to shift merely because the agent’s credence about her own future act wobbles during reflection.  The upshot is that CDT, at least in its standard form, is incomplete; to remain defensible it needs supplementation by principles that break the feedback loop, and once those principles are added CDT ceases to be a purely causal theory.

2. CDT and the role of unconditional probabilities  

The central tenet of CDT is sometimes summarised as “evaluate acts by imagining that the physical mechanism that issues the act is held fixed but everything causally downstream is recomputed.”  Formally, CDT requires unconditional probabilities for states that are causally independent of the act in question.  What matters, then, is P(s), not P(s|A).  Yet in any realistic deliberation the agent’s degrees of belief are not static: they evolve as she reflects on what she is likely to do.  Usually that evolution is irrelevant, because the probability of an upstream state (tomorrow’s weather, say) does not change as I agonise over whether to carry an umbrella.  But if a predictor uses my dispositions to forecast my choice, upstream facts correlate with my eventual act, and my changing opinion about what I will do is ipso facto a changing opinion about what the predictor has done.  

Suppose that Death, whose predictions are only 90 % reliable, will meet me in the city he predicts I will choose; if he guesses wrong I survive wherever I go.  There is also a small bias: independently of the facts favouring prediction, Death has a tendency to guess Damascus.  To keep numbers concrete, let  
• U(survive) = 1, U(die) = –1.  
• P(Death predicts Damascus | I go Damascus) = 0.9  
• P(Death predicts Damascus | I go Aleppo) = 0.8.  
Before deliberation begins, I assign some prior probability p that I will go to Damascus.  From symmetry I might start at p = 0.5, but nothing in CDT fixes that number; it is an endogenous part of the deliberative process.  

3. Computing expected utilities  

Let D be the act of going to Damascus, A the act of going to Aleppo.  CDT tells me to treat Death’s prediction as fixed, because the prediction is not causally downstream of what I now decide.  Taking the 90 % reliability into account, I obtain:

EUCDT(D) = P(Death predicts Damascus)·U(die) + P(Death predicts Aleppo)·U(survive)
          = (0.9p + 0.8(1–p))·(–1) + (0.1p + 0.2(1–p))·1
          = –0.7 + 1.0p.

EUCDT(A) = P(Death predicts Damascus)·U(survive) + P(Death predicts Aleppo)·U(die)
          = (0.9p + 0.8(1–p))·1 + (0.1p + 0.2(1–p))·(–1)
          = 0.7 – 1.0p.

A moment’s inspection shows that
EUCDT(D) > EUCDT(A) just in case p > 0.5.

So if in the course of deliberation I come to regard Damascus as the likelier destination (p > 0.5), CDT recommends Damascus; if I come to regard Aleppo as the likelier destination (p < 0.5), CDT recommends Aleppo.  The expected utilities of the two acts cross exactly at p = 0.5, where the agent is indifferent.  The utilities are thus fully symmetric around the point of equipoise.

At first this might look benign; one could hope that deliberation converges on p = 0.5, giving the agent freedom to randomise or to settle by tie-breaker on either city.  But that hope is misplaced.  For suppose I start with p = 0.6, making Damascus preferable.  Once I notice that fact I will shift my intention further toward Damascus, perhaps to p = 0.7.  Yet that increases EUCDT(D) by 0.1 and decreases EUCDT(A) by the same margin, reinforcing the preference.  All good—until I reflect on the situation once more.  Seeing that Death now almost certainly predicts Damascus, I may grow anxious and begin to doubt whether I really will go there, tilting back toward Aleppo.  Any such back-and-forth jitter flips the expected utilities again.  In the limit of perfect deliberative transparency, no stable probability emerges; the agent bounces indefinitely between options or freezes.  CDT seems to offer no determinate advice.

4. Why instability is alarming  

Two related norms of practical rationality are put at risk.

a. Deliberative stability.  A rational decision procedure ought, given fixed beliefs about the world, to deliver a unique maximal act or (in the case of ties) a stable set of equally good acts.  It should not produce recommendations that change solely because the agent momentarily shifts credence about her own future behaviour in response to the very recommendation the theory just supplied.  CDT violates that norm: the mapping from credences to recommendations is not a contraction but an anti-contraction; the feedback pushes beliefs away from fixed points rather than toward them.

b. Independence of irrelevant internalities.  A decision rule’s verdict should not hinge on arbitrary features of the agent’s internal deliberative path.  When the acts, causal structure, and utilities are held constant, the prescription of rationality should be path-independent.  Under CDT, however, two epistemically identical agents whose only difference is what probability they currently assign to their choosing D can be given opposite advice.  That looks like a violation of the idea that rationality should supervene on the situation, not on transient self-doubts.

Moreover, the instability opens the door to predictable losses.  Suppose a wily third party offers a bet that pays 0.4 util if I commit to whichever city is currently disfavoured by CDT and costs nothing otherwise.  Because my preference oscillates, the bettor can expect to win half the time, extracting expected utility from me.  In more elaborate setups, one can Dutch-book a CDT agent by exploiting the moment-to-moment slides in her self-probabilities.  The mere possibility of sure-loss sequences signals normative trouble.

5. First repair attempt: ratification  

Jeffrey and later Skyrms proposed a “ratification” constraint: an act is rational only if, on the supposition that you will choose it, you would still choose it.  Formally, A is ratifiable when EUCDT(A) ≥ EUCDT(B) for every alternative B, computed on the assumption that P(you choose A) = 1.  In Death in Damascus, no pure act is ratifiable, because if you assume you will choose Damascus, Aleppo comes out better and vice versa.  Nevertheless, a mixed strategy—choosing Damascus with probability 0.5, Aleppo with 0.5—ratifies itself: conditional on using that very randomising device, neither pure deviation raises expected utility.  

Two problems arise.
