First, introducing deliberate randomisation already stretches CDT, which was articulated for acts, not lotteries over acts.  Once we allow mixtures, the causal linkages that motivated CDT become murkier: does Death predict the outcome of the randomiser or the underlying act disposition?  The story has to change.  

Second, the ratifiability filter merely hides the instability by declaring unstable options “irrational” post hoc.  It does not tell the agent how to get to the mixed-strategy equilibrium from an arbitrary starting credence, nor does it explain why it is irrational to step away from that mixture once there.  The same oscillatory push-and-pull operates within the mixed strategy: should I tilt the wheel of the roulette table slightly toward Damascus?  Slight departures are always tempting.  Ratification gives an existence theorem, not a dynamic solution.

6. Second repair attempt: deliberation fixed-points  

Joyce and others propose that rational deliberation must search for a fixed point p* such that CDT’s recommendation, computed at p*, delivers an act whose probability is p* itself.  The requirement is: choose a p that makes your intending-to-p a self-fulfilling prophecy.  In Death in Damascus the unique fixed point is p* = 0.5, reproducing the earlier mixed-strategy solution.  Yet this approach tacitly adds a norm that is not present in unadorned CDT: a norm linking beliefs about one’s future act to intentions in a consistency-seeking manner.  Without that supplement CDT does not insist on fixed points; it happily tolerates cyclical deliberation so long as each momentary calculation respects causal conditioning.  The supplement may be attractive, but it is not part of the causal core—it is an extraneous equilibrium selection rule.  Once we accept that rule, CDT ceases to be the whole of decision theory.

Furthermore, fixed-point existence is fragile.  In Death in Damascus we are fortunate that symmetry furnishes p* = 0.5, but in other prediction-based paradoxes no fixed point exists.  Ahmed’s “Psychopath Button” and Price’s “Nuisance Coin” create discontinuities that preclude equilibrium; adopting the fixed-point requirement therefore condemns agents to stalemate, unable to act even though causally beneficial options lie open.

7. Third repair attempt: ex ante versus ex interim evaluation  

Advocates of CDT sometimes respond that the only probability an agent needs is the one she will have at the end of deliberation, so intermediate swings are irrelevant.  The expectation should be taken relative to the final, settled distribution, which is unaffected by the calculation itself because deliberation is already finished.  On this view CDT is “deliberation insensitive”; instability is merely artefactual.

The reply misses the target.  “Final” credences are not fixed by anything outside the deliberative process; they have to be produced by that very process.  If CDT supplies no convergent dynamic, there may never be a final credence.  The agent cannot simply stipulate a settled probability; she must earn it by some pattern of reasoning that accords with the norms the theory lays down.  Since CDT abjures evaluating downstream influence of acts, it has no resources to shape such reasoning.  The worry, therefore, is precisely that CDT does not, by itself, deliver the convergence assumed in the ex ante/ex interim distinction.

8. Why the dependence is a genuine flaw  

We can frame the core complaint in terms of diachronic coherence.  A rational agent’s preferences over acts at time t should be connected to her preferences at time t + ε in such a way that they could jointly guide action through time without self-sabotage.  CDT’s recommendations in Death in Damascus make that impossible: the agent who follows CDT at t stands committed to altering her plan at t + ε.  No coherent plan can be formed, hence no act can be issued.  Because acting is a necessary element of practical rationality, any decision rule that blocks action where action is possible is defective.

There is also a structural reason for disquiet.  CDT’s foundational idea is that causal independence shields us from Newcomb-type evidential entanglements.  But the Death in Damascus feedback arises through a causal pathway the theory overlooked: the causal impact of deliberation on belief, and of belief on act.  By treating the agent’s act probability as “exogenous” to expected utility while simultaneously letting that probability be altered by utility calculations, CDT fractures the causal model it presupposes.  In effect, CDT misclassifies the agent’s own emerging intention as an upstream variable, when in fact the intention is part of the causal nexus generating the final act.  The misclassification is exactly what drives the oscillations.  A revised CDT would have to endogenise intentions, acknowledging that some “states of the world” are partially constituted by the very deliberation now under way.  Once that concession is made, the boundary between “upstream” and “downstream” blurs, undermining the neat causal/evidential dichotomy the theory was meant to preserve.

9. Comparison with alternative theories  

Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) in the same scenario tells you to maximise EUEDT(A) = Σs P(s|A)·U(outcome).  Because the conditional probability P(Death predicts Damascus|go Damascus) is high, EDT recommends Aleppo outright, independent of act probabilities.  EDT thereby avoids instability but pays the familiar price in Newcomb’s problem.  Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and Timeless Decision Theory (TDT) aim to capture the attractive features of both CDT and EDT by treating the agent’s decision as the output of a mathematical function; they recommend Damascus (since choosing Damascus implies Death predicted Damascus), again without instability.  The contrast shows that the instability is not inevitable for any decision theory confronted with predictors—it is specific to CDT’s combination of causal conditioning with act-probability dependence.

10. Summing up objections  

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the very probability of acting to which deliberation is supposed to lead is a problem because:

1. It deprives CDT of deliberative stability; no algorithmic agent following CDT is guaranteed to converge on a choice.  
2. It makes rational prescriptions hinge on arbitrary psychological starting points, violating path-independence.  
3. It gives rise to exploitable sure-loss sequences, betraying the money-pump test for irrationality.  
4. Attempted repairs either graft on extraneous principles (ratification, fixed-points) or dissolve into other theories.  
5. The underlying cause—treating self-predicted intentions as exogenous—contravenes CDT’s own causal picture.

11. Could the dependence be harmless?  

Some defenders claim that real agents are never perfectly self-transparent; they reach a settled intention under uncertainty about their own future choice, and once settled, further deliberation ceases.  The small amount of psychological “noise” then prevents oscillations.  Even if this is descriptively plausible, it does not rescue CDT’s normative status.  A theory of ideal rationality must succeed in the limit of increased clarity; appealing to psychological friction is an excuse, not a justification.  Moreover, introducing opaque self-ignorance resurrects an evidential component: if I lack privileged access to my future act, the probability of that act becomes evidence about upstream states, returning us to the evidential entanglements CDT wanted to avoid.

12. A proposal: augmenting CDT with deliberative causal nets  

One promising direction is to model deliberation itself causally, adding nodes for beliefs, intentions, interim calculations, and so forth.  Once the deliberative network is explicit, we can distinguish variables truly upstream of the final act from variables partially constituted by the agent’s reasoning.  That richer picture would indeed block oscillations: the probabilities that enter the expectation would be conditional on a fully specified decision procedure, not on the act’s naked description.  But such a theory would no longer be the lean, act-centred CDT of Lewis; it would be a hybrid marrying causal modelling with procedural rationality—closer, perhaps, to FDT.  Recognising the need for such augmentation is tantamount to conceding that CDT, unadorned, is insufficient.

13. Conclusion  

Death in Damascus reveals an internal tension in Causal Decision Theory.  By instructing agents to evaluate acts using unconditional probabilities, CDT treats their own act probabilities as fixed parameters.  Yet those probabilities are simultaneously determined by the very evaluation CDT commands.  The resulting feedback destabilises deliberation: wherever the agent’s credence hovers, CDT nudges it elsewhere, so its recommendations chase the moving target instead of guiding it.  This instability is not a curious quirk but a normative failure, for it violates the coherence and path-independence we expect of a theory of rational choice.  Patching the leak requires either extraneous principles that abandon CDT’s causal purism or a wholesale re-engineering of the decision-theoretic framework.  Hence the dependence of CDT’s advice on act probabilities is indeed a problem—and it points toward the need for a more robust hybrid theory capable of handling self-referential prediction without sacrificing causal insight.

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) enjoys the reputation of being the most natural heir to the classical expected-utility picture.  It says, roughly, that a rational agent should choose that act A whose causal expected utility

     CEU(A) = Σs P(s) U(outcome(A,s))

is highest, where the sum ranges over states of the world that are not causally downstream of A.  The probabilities are the agent’s unconditional, “non-backtracking’’ credences about how the world is prior to the intervention constituted by her act.  In ordinary choice situations—buying strawberry rather than vanilla ice-cream, taking a taxi rather than the bus—this recipe delivers crisp, stable recommendations.  Oddities emerge, however, as soon as there is tight predictive correlation between what the agent does and how the world already is.  Death in Damascus, made famous by Nozick (1969), is the most vivid illustration:

 Death, a reliable but fallible predictor, consults his crystal ball on Tuesday and decides in which of the two cities, Damascus or Aleppo, to await you on Wednesday.  Because he slightly favours Damascus, the prior probability that he will choose Damascus is high—say .9.  On Wednesday morning you know all this and must decide where to go.  If you and Death end up in the same city you die (utility –1); if you miss him you survive (utility +1).

The twist is that the location in which Death already waits is highly correlated with what you will in fact choose, though it is not a causal consequence of that choice.  According to standard CDT you should compute the causal expected utilities of “Go to Damascus’’ and “Go to Aleppo’’ using unconditional probabilities for Death’s location—and those probabilities, in turn, depend on your current credence that you will go to Damascus.  As you lean toward Damascus the probability that Death is there increases; lean toward Aleppo, and the probabilistic shadow falls on Aleppo instead.  The moment your self-probability shifts, the causal expected utilities shift with it, sometimes reversing the ranking and sending your deliberation lurching in the opposite direction.  The worry is that CDT’s verdicts are hostage to a moving target: your own fluctuating beliefs about what you are about to do.  Is that a genuine flaw in the theory?

I will argue that it is a serious problem—a problem of dynamic instability and of decision-theoretic indeterminacy—and that the most prominent CDT-based replies either lapse into ad hoc qualifications or ultimately concede the need for a quite different decision rule.  I end by sketching what a satisfactory fix would have to look like.

2. How dependence on act-probabilities enters the picture  

Let Pr(A) be your current subjective probability of choosing Damascus (call the act D; let A stand for Aleppo).  Suppose you are perfectly confident in CDT and fully rational, so your only source of uncertainty about your act is ordinary psychological unpredictability: at t0 your credence in D is, say, .6 because you have not yet settled the matter.

Because Death’s crystal ball is 90 % reliable, the conditional probabilities are  

 Pr(D eath waits in Damascus | D) = .9  
 Pr(D eath waits in Damascus | A) = .1  

By the law of total probability, the unconditional probability that Death is in Damascus is

 Pr(D eath in D amascus) = .9 Pr(D) + .1 Pr(A)  
                         = .9 Pr(D) + .1 (1 − Pr(D))  
                         = .1 + .8 Pr(D).

Thus the causal expected utilities are

 CEU(D) = (–1)·Pr(Death in D) + (+1)·Pr(Death in A)  
         = –Pr(Death in D) + (1 – Pr(Death in D))  
         = 1 – 2 Pr(Death in D)  
         = 1 – 2 ( .1 + .8 Pr(D) )  
         = 0.8 – 1.6 Pr(D).  (1)

 CEU(A) = 0.8 – 1.6 Pr(A).  (2)

Notice that CEU(D) and CEU(A) are linear in Pr(D) and Pr(A) = 1 − Pr(D).  Setting Pr(D) = .6 in (1) yields CEU(D) = 0.8 − .96 = –.16.  Plugging the same number into (2) (with Pr(A) = .4) yields CEU(A) = 0.8 – 0.64 = 0.16.  So when you start the deliberation, CDT tells you to go to Aleppo.  But the moment you begin inclining toward Aleppo your self-probability of going there creeps up, driving Pr(Death in A) upward, lowering CEU(A) and raising CEU(D).  At some point the balance tips and the prescription flips back to Damascus, whereupon the same feedback cycle starts anew.  Unless your credence in each act gets pinned at exactly .5 (the unstable equilibrium obtained by setting CEU(D) = CEU(A) = 0), the computation chases its own tail.

3. Why this looks troubling  

Dependence on act-probabilities is not automatically irrational.  In mixed-strategy games, rational players deliberately randomise among moves, and expected pay-offs depend on those randomisation probabilities.  But the Death case is different in three respects.

a) No incentive to randomise.  Randomisation only helps if the opposing mechanism reacts to the random seed.  Death has already guessed and acted; your subsequent dithering cannot influence his earlier relocation.  From an ordinary causal perspective you face a fixed lottery: either he is in Damascus or he is in Aleppo.  Rational choice should therefore collapse to a pure strategy once the probabilities of the states are settled.

b) Self-undermining deliberation.  The agent’s mere act of estimating which city she is about to choose changes the very numbers she is supposed to plug into the CEU formula.  Deliberation becomes self-referential in a way that prevents convergence on a stable recommendation.  A decent decision rule ought not to turn on such ephemera as one’s transient state of indecision.  (Contrast utility, which should of course matter.)

c) Normative ambiguity.  At any instant CDT can produce a recommendation; yet infinitesimal perturbations in an epistemically irrelevant magnitude—Pr(D)—make it recommend the opposite.  Two agents who are alike in every respect save a 0.001 difference in their earlier hunch about what they will c-do are given opposite advice.  That looks less like rational counsel and more like flipping a coin.

These phenomena are not restricted to Death in Damascus.  They spring up wherever (i)   the pay-off achieved by act A correlates strongly with whether you choose A, yet (ii) that correlation is not mediated by a causal link from A to the state.  Newcomb’s Problem, Retro Blackmail, and Parfit’s Hitchhiker all share the structure.  If CDT’s instability in Death in Damascus is acceptable, we must be ready to embrace it in every such case.

4. Two attempted CDT replies  

4.1  The “ignore small probabilities’’ maneuver  

One could insist that a rational agent should treat her deliberative probabilities about her own future act as 0 or 1.  “Right now, before the moment of choice, you do not yet intend either city; therefore Pr(D) should be undefined or neutral.’’  But CDT’s recipe explicitly calls for unconditional probabilities; at the point of evaluation you do have a sharp credence for each state of the world, including facts about your disposition.  Declaring them irrelevant is an ad hoc stipulation rather than a principled component of CDT.

Moreover, even if we artificially set Pr(D) = Pr(A) = 0.5, that is exactly the unstable knife-edge at which CEU(D) = CEU(A).  The theory still fails to single out an act.

4.2  Ratificationist CDT  

Jeffrey (1983) and Skyrms (1990) propose that a rational act must “ratify’’ itself: you should choose A only if A maximises expected utility on the supposition that you will choose A.  Formally, A is rational iff A = argmaxA′ CEU(A′) computed under the conditional probabilities Pr(· | You choose A).  In Death in Damascus, ratification collapses the above instability: because Pr(Death in D | D) = .9, CEU(D | D) = –.8; because Pr(Death in D | A) = .1, CEU(A | A) = .8.  Thus only Aleppo ratifies; Damascus does not, so Aleppo is rational.

Behaviourally, then, ratificationist CDT sides with Evidential Decision Theory (EDT), which also recommends Aleppo.  But notice the cost.  (i)  The modification is no longer purely causal: it lets evidential correlations between acts and prior states determine choice.  (ii)  It abandons one of CDT’s central selling points, the rejection of dominance-violations in Newcomb-style scenarios.  In the one-box variant of Newcomb, ratificationist CDT one-boxes, contrary to orthodox causalists.  So either we must swallow the instability or concede that CDT as originally advertised is untenable.

5. Dynamic instability and the norms of deliberation  

Suppose an agent literally follows CDT’s algorithm over micro-time steps, updating her act-credence as she discovers which act would maximise expected utility given her current credence, then recomputing, and so on.  The process forms a non-convergent oscillation unless started exactly at the fixed point .5.  A decision theory that counsels a deliberative strategy known to diverge is arguably pragmatically self-defeating.  Joyce (2012) calls this “deliberational incoherence’’: the agent cannot reach a decision by faithfully implementing the theory.

Someone might object: rationality norms are about what the agent should do, not about the mechanical feasibility of an algorithm for finding out what she should do.  Perhaps a fully ideal reasoner would instantaneously leap to the correct recommendation.  But the normative output of CDT still has to be well-defined in that ideal limit, and in Death in Damascus it is not: there is no unique act that maximises CEU across logically possible assignments of Pr(D) in (0,1).  The best the theory can supply is a set of undominated “mixed’’ actions, and CDT is silent about whether and how a deterministic agent ought to realise a mixture.  When a decision rule refuses to provide a unique answer in so simple a case, that looks like an explanatory failure.

6. Global versus local choice criteria  

One response is to retreat to a “global’’ criterion.  Rather than ask which act would maximise expected utility conditional on the local information available at the last moment, ask which policy would maximise expected utility across the entire deliberative tree.  A policy is a mapping from information sets to acts.  In Death in Damascus the only non-degenerate policies are:

P1: Always go to Damascus.  
P2: Always go to Aleppo.  
P3: Randomise with probability p of Damascus.

Because the state in which Death is waiting is determined before the policy is executed, the expected payoff of P3 is 0 for any p; P1 and P2 yield –0.8 and +0.8, respectively.  Thus the globally optimal policy is P2, which matches the intuitions of EDT and ratificationist CDT without the unstable feedback.  That move, however, embeds CDT inside a broader “upstream’’ framework in which the agent chooses causal policies, not particular acts—exactly the fix adopted by Yudkowsky’s Updateless Decision Theory (UDT) and by many functional decision theorists.  Once again: to evade the instability you must leave home.

7. Why dependence on act-probabilities is a structural flaw  

The foregoing reflections suggest four reasons to deem the dependence a real problem.

1.  Sensitivity to arbitrary credences.  A rational prescription should not flip merely because of a marginal shift in how likely you think you are to press button L rather than R five seconds from now.

2.  Deliberative non-convergence.  For any real agent who updates her psychological probability of acting as deliberation proceeds, CDT yields a forever-changing target and so cannot guide action.

3.  Failure of public counsel.  If you tried to give advice to another rational agent, you would have to ask, “By the way, what’s your current subjective chance of visiting Damascus?’’  Advice that depends on such introspective trivia is practically useless.

4.  No unique ideal-pragmatic answer.  Even under ideal computation the CEU functions (1)–(2) are perfectly symmetric and therefore fail to designate one act as uniquely rational.  A theory that produces ties in paradigmatic choice problems needs supplementation.

8. Could the problem be patched from within CDT?  

Several authors attempt tweaks: adopt “deliberation-proof’’ equilibria, require fixed-point consistency, disregard evidential correlations below a threshold, etc.  But each tweak either (i) quietly reinstates evidential decision-theoretic reasoning, or (ii) introduces extra-theoretical parameters (a rule for resolving indifference, a default mixing distribution, …) whose justification lies outside core CDT.  The original attraction of CDT was its purportedly simple, mechanistically interpretable formula.  Once one starts bolting on caveats to accommodate Death in Damascus, that virtue evaporates.

9. Broader stakes  

If CDT falters in predictive-correlation cases, its claim to be the unified theory of rational choice—covering personal decisions, game-theoretic coordination, bargaining with predictors, anthropic puzzles—also falters.  Alternative frameworks such as EDT, Functional Decision Theory (FDT), or Policy Selection CDT (a.k.a. “updateless’’ CDT) yield stable prescriptions in all those contexts without recourse to self-dependent probabilities.  Hence the case rigorously isolates a tension between causal purism and deliberative stability; resolving the tension, I have argued, requires sacrificing the purism.

10. Conclusion  

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on an agent’s fluctuating probabilities of her own acts is not an innocuous quirk.  In Death in Damascus it produces dynamic instability, normative ambiguity, and advice that is sensitive to introspectively evanescent numbers.  Attempts to neutralise the problem either smuggle in evidential reasoning (ratification) or enlarge the choice domain from acts to policies, thereby abandoning the original CDT dictum.  The deeper moral is that a decision rule must respect not only causal independence but also deliberative robustness: its recommendations should be defined in a way that is insensitive to the agent’s moment-by-moment uncertainty about her own eventual act.  Classical CDT, restricted to local act evaluation, fails that test.  To the extent that we find stability and clear guidance essential virtues of a decision theory, the dependence on act-probabilities is indeed a serious problem for CDT.

Causal Decision Theory, Deliberative Unrest,  
                                and the Probability–Dependence Objection  

1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is often marketed as the sober-minded heir to classical expected-utility theory.  It tells an agent to choose the act that maximises expected utility when expectations are taken with respect to the probabilities of states that are not causally downstream of the act.  Because the act itself is presumed to have no causal influence on those states, the unconditional probabilities of the states are, according to CDT, the only probabilities that matter for choice.  In most familiar decision problems this recipe is unproblematic.  In Newcomb-type cases, however—or in the structurally similar “Death in Damascus” cases—the recipe appears to malfunction in an intriguing way.  The malfunction does not arise because CDT ignores correlations between acts and states; to the contrary, the unconditional probabilities CDT uses fully reflect whatever correlations are expected.  The difficulty is rather that those unconditional probabilities can be sensitive to the *deliberating agent’s own credences about which act she will end up performing*.  As those self-referential credences evolve during deliberation, CDT’s recommendation can oscillate and even fail to converge.  The question is whether this oscillatory dependence reveals a genuine flaw in CDT, or whether it can be dismissed as a harmless, perhaps inevitable, artefact of decision making under prediction.  

In what follows I argue that the dependence is indeed a serious problem for CDT.  First, I lay out a regimented version of the Death in Damascus story and show explicitly how the expectation assigned to each act is a mathematical function of the agent’s current probability of performing that act.  Second, I show that during ideal deliberation the agent cannot settle on a stable act: any shift in self-prediction immediately changes the utilities in such a way that the currently preferred act flips.  CDT thus fails the *action-guidance* test—it does not reliably tell a deliberating agent what to do.  Third, I defend the normative significance of this failure against two prominent replies: (i) that the agent should simply randomise; and (ii) that the expectations should be evaluated at a pre-deliberative “ratification point.”  Finally, I argue that the problem is symptomatic of a deeper tension in CDT between causal independence and epistemic self-location: once correlations with one’s own future act can rationally affect beliefs about non-causal states, unconditional probabilities cannot be treated as exogenous data.  

2. Setting up the death trap  

Let the two available acts be A (go to Aleppo) and D (go to Damascus).  Suppose Death, who has an excellent but not perfect track record of predicting travellers’ choices, has some bias favouring Damascus.  Formally, let  

   p := Pr(choose Aleppo)                        (1)  

be the agent’s current *self-probability* of choosing Aleppo.  (We may think of p as the probability the agent assigns, at this moment in deliberation, to her eventually going to Aleppo.)  Death’s method is: first form a prediction about where you will go; then travel to that city and wait for you.  Call q the reliability of Death’s predictions, 0.5 < q < 1.  To model the bias toward Damascus, assume that Death uses the following prediction rule.  Let p be as above; then  

   Pr(Death predicts Aleppo)   =  (1 − b)·p,  
   Pr(Death predicts Damascus) =  1 − (1 − b)·p,            (2)  

where 0 < b < 1 represents the bias parameter.  When Death predicts correctly you die (utility −1); when the prediction fails you live (utility +1).  Travel itself carries no intrinsic utility difference.  

Applying CDT, the expected utility of each act is computed with respect to the unconditional probability that Death is currently waiting in that city.  Those probabilities, however, are functions of p, because Death’s prediction is trained on your choice propensity.  Concretely:  

   Pr(Death in Aleppo)   =  Pr(predicted Aleppo & correct)  
                         =  q·(1 − b)·p.  

   Pr(Death in Damascus) =  q·[1 − (1 − b)·p].             (3)  

Hence  

   EU(A) = (−1)·Pr(Death in Aleppo)  +  (+1)·[1 − Pr(Death in Aleppo)]  
         = 1 − 2·q·(1 − b)·p.                               (4)

   EU(D) = 1 − 2·q·[1 − (1 − b)·p].                        (5)

We immediately see that both expected utilities are affine functions of p.  As the agent’s credence p changes, the ranking of EU(A) and EU(D) can change.  

3. The deliberation loop  

Suppose, at the outset, the agent has no particular leaning, so p = 0.5.  If b > 0, the bias term makes Pr(Death in Damascus) slightly larger than Pr(Death in Aleppo); so, evaluating (4) and (5), EU(A) > EU(D).  CDT therefore recommends Aleppo.  But the moment the agent takes that recommendation seriously, p rises (after all, she now thinks she will probably go to Aleppo).  As p increases, Pr(Death in Aleppo) increases as well, lowering EU(A).  There is some critical value p* at which EU(A) = EU(D); beyond p*, EU(D) becomes the maximiser.  CDT now flips its recommendation to Damascus.  On acknowledging this flip, the agent’s self-probability p abruptly falls, sending her back to the situation in which EU(A) is higher.  Deliberation thus generates an endless loop:  

   Step 1: p  = 0.5  → choose Aleppo  → p rises  
   Step 2: p  > p*    → choose Damascus → p drops  
   Step 3: p  < p*    → choose Aleppo  → p rises  
   … ad infinitum.  

Nothing in the theory tells the agent where to stop.  The vivid form of the loop is “Damascus looks dangerous because that is probably where I am going”, followed by “But now that I plan Aleppo, Aleppo looks dangerous”, and so on.  CDT, interpreted as a decision procedure *for a deliberating agent*, simply fails to issue a stable directive.  

4. Why this is a problem  

A decision theory is supposed to serve at least two roles.  First, it should encode correct *choice principles* that a perfectly rational agent would endorse at a reflective equilibrium.  Second, it should be *action-guiding* for finite cognisers whose deliberation approximates that ideal.  The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on self-probability jeopardises both roles.  

4.1. Violation of Dynamic Coherence  

Standard versions of CDT endorse *dynamic coherence*: once an agent updates on new causal information, the act that maximises expected utility should remain the same—or at least not flip back and forth—when the only changing element is the agent’s information about her own current deliberative state.  In Death in Damascus, the flipping occurs with no new *exogenous* information.  The agent’s brain does not receive fresh data about the world; she merely reflects on what she is now disposed to do.  Yet that purely introspective shift makes CDT’s value estimates change.  That undermines coherence: the agent’s preferences at t1 are inconsistent with her preferences at t2, even though all non-agential facts remain fixed.  

4.2. Undermining Action Guidance  

Suppose, realistically, that the agent must catch a 10 p.m. train to whichever city she chooses.  CDT’s oscillation means there is no guaranteed time by which her deliberation will settle on a recommendation.  In many runs it may never settle.  A decision rule that reliably leaves a rational agent stuck on the platform until the trains depart is normatively defective.  

This is not an artefact of idealisation.  Even if we end deliberation at some arbitrary cut-off—say, at 9 : 59 p.m.—CDT tells the agent to implement whichever act currently has higher EU.  But that higher EU is itself fixed by the agent’s current self-probability, a probability that self-referentially depends on the act she will pick at 10 p.m.  Thus the rule cannot be applied without epistemic circularity.  

4.3. The Transparency Principle  

Many philosophers endorse a “transparency” norm: if you rationally *decide* to A, you thereby set your credence that you will A to (practically) 1.  Conversely, while you treat both options as open, you should not be certain which one you will pick.  If CDT’s recommendations are sensitive to those very credences, CDT ends up hostage to the agent’s own act of endorsement.  That violates the transparency principle because it makes rational deliberation non-transparent: you cannot know whether A is rational unless you first know whether you will decide to A, but you cannot know that without already deciding.  

5. Objection 1: “Just randomise”  

A natural rejoinder is that the agent ought to employ a *mixed strategy*.  Suppose she flips a fair coin: heads means Aleppo, tails Damascus.  Before the flip, p is locked at 0.5.  Given (4)–(5), EU(A) then exceeds EU(D), so CDT endorses Aleppo—seemingly re-igniting the loop.  But the defender might say that *the act* is not “go to Aleppo,” but “flip a coin and obey.”  Because Death cannot perfectly predict the coin, coin-flipping secures survival with probability 1−q, which maximises expected utility.  CDT, it is claimed, therefore does give clear guidance: “employ a randomising device.”  

Two difficulties attend this reply.  

a) Implementation regress.  Whether the agent *will* actually obey the coin determines how reliable Death’s conditional prediction of the coin outcome is.  If, in the very moment after the coin lands heads, the agent deliberates anew about going to Aleppo, the unstable loop re-emerges.  So the prescription demands not merely that the agent randomise, but that she pre-commit to treating the random outcome as binding.  CDT on its own lacks the resources to explain why such pre-commitment is rationally mandatory.  

b) Moving the bump under the rug.  Treating “flip-and-obey” as a single act works only because we *exogenously* stipulate that the agent can treat her probability of performing that composite act as settled.  But the original problem was precisely that CDT’s expectations change as the agent updates her self-probabilities.  If the agent can settle her probability of “flip-and-obey” merely by fiat, she could equally well settle her probability of “go to Aleppo.”  The move therefore adds no explanatory power; it relies on the very capacity—the rational fixing of act probabilities—that CDT’s oscillation calls into doubt.  

6. Objection 2: Ratificationism  

Joyce (1992) and others have suggested a ratificationist modification of CDT: an act is rational only if, after hypothetically learning that one is about to perform it, one would still prefer it.  Formally, choose A only if  

   EU(A | about-to-A) ≥ EU(D | about-to-A).  

In Death in Damascus, conditioning on “about-to-A” drives Pr(Death in Aleppo) up so high (because Death is usually right) that EU(A | about-to-A) < EU(D | about-to-A), and symmetrically the reverse holds when conditioning on “about-to-D.” Consequently, no pure act ratifies itself; only a mixed strategy does.  CDT’s waffling is thereby replaced by a straightforward prescription: play the unique self-ratifying mixture.  

This manoeuvre introduces two costs.  

First, ratificationism eliminates CDT’s signature appeal to *causal* independence.  When we condition on “about-to-A,” we condition on something that is causally downstream of deliberation.  If such downstream information can rationally alter choice, the principle that only *causally antecedent* probabilities matter has been surrendered.  The theory ceases to be recognisably CDT.  

Second, even if we welcome ratificationism, the practical worry resurfaces.  For a real deliberator to compute the ratified mixture, she must already know the conditional probabilities of Death’s location given each possible downstream fact about her mental state.  That is psychologically unrealistic and deprives the theory of its supposed advantage in epistemic tractability.  

7. The deeper lesson: Endogeneity of unconditional probabilities  

Both objections share the same flaw: they ignore the fact that, in problems like Death in Damascus, the unconditional probability distribution over states is *endogenous* to the agent’s deliberation.  Death’s prediction is sensitive to how the agent’s mind is apt to move; any rational change in that mental motion feeds back into Death’s distribution; hence, by CDT’s own lights, feeds back into expected utilities.  The unconditional probabilities cannot be treated as fixed inputs.  

Once we concede endogeneity, CDT’s methodology collapses.  To evaluate the expected utility of A, the agent must first know her final probability of A; yet that probability depends on the comparative expected utilities she is in the middle of calculating.  The calculus is circular.  A decision theory that cannot break this circle without ad-hoc patches fails as a foundational theory.  

8. Comparison with Evidential Decision Theory  

Interestingly, Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) handles the case better.  EDT conditions on the act itself: it advises computing EU(A) with Pr(state | A).  Because going to Aleppo strongly indicates Death is in Aleppo, EDT stably recommends Damascus, and this recommendation does not change as the agent’s self-probabilities change.  Whatever else one thinks about EDT, it passes the action-guidance test here that CDT fails.  That contrast bolsters the charge that CDT’s instability is not a trivial quirk of decision making under prediction but a systematic weakness in CDT’s causal criterion.  

9. Can CDT be repaired?  

Various proposals attempt to salvage CDT by importing devices such as *policy selection*, *logical causal decision theory*, or *updateless decision theory*.  What all share is the recognition that an agent’s algorithmic specification—not merely her final bodily motion—can bear decisive counterfactual relevance to correlated events.  These innovations move CDT beyond its classical focus on physical causation and treat the hypothetical variations in the agent’s *decision procedure* as the relevant points of intervention.  Whether one finds these proposals successful or not, they effectively concede that *plain vanilla* CDT, as originally formulated, is inadequate.  And inadequacy is precisely what the dependence problem is meant to expose.  

10. Conclusion  

In Death in Damascus–style problems the expected utilities that CDT assigns to acts are linear functions of the agent’s real-time probability of performing those acts.  Because those probabilities are themselves shaped by the agent’s ongoing deliberation, CDT’s recommendations flip back and forth without settling.  This violates dynamic coherence, undermines action guidance, and conflicts with the transparency of rational deliberation.  Attempts to deflect the objection by appealing to randomisation or ratification either re-introduce the instability at a higher level or abandon CDT’s defining commitment to causal irrelevance.  

Therefore, the dependence of CDT’s verdicts on self-probabilities is not a harmless curiosity; it is a symptom of a deeper theoretical gap.  Any satisfactory decision theory must accommodate the endogeneity of state probabilities to the agent’s epistemic position, especially in worlds in which predictors (human, mechanical, or Bayesian) can exploit correlations between decision processes and outcomes.  Classical CDT, as it stands, fails that test.

1. Introduction

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is built around a simple‐sounding injunction: choose the act whose expected causal utility is largest.  To compute that expectation, one begins with a probability distribution over “states of the world” that are not causally downstream of the act under evaluation; one then weights each state by the utility the agent would obtain were she to perform the act and that state obtained.  So long as the states are unaffected by the act, CDT promises immunity to the “Newcombish” temptation to act on mere evidential correlations.  

Yet the slogan conceals a delicate question: what exactly counts as “causally downstream”?  In Jeffrey’s original formulation the relevant states are described prior to the agent’s choice, but in Newcomb’s Problem any fixed description of the past still correlates with which box is full, because the predictor has excellent evidence about the agent’s future action.  CDT’s official response is: ignore the correlation, because the fullness of the opaque box is already settled when you act.  

Death in Damascus (first presented by Gibbard and Harper, but popularised by Arntzenius and Ahmed) pushes on a different seam.  Here, the correlation between what you do and what befalls you is mediated not by the world’s past but by the reliability of Death’s prediction.  What matters, crucially, is not only which act you finally perform but how probable you take that act to be while you deliberate.  Because those credences can vary moment by moment, the expected utilities assigned by CDT fluctuate in lockstep.  The question is whether this sensitivity to “act probabilities” is an embarrassment for CDT.

I shall argue that it is a genuine problem.  First, the dependence forces CDT to give recommendations that shift merely because the agent’s deliberation shifts, so the theory violates a natural stability desideratum.  Second, the dependence threatens to make CDT’s prescriptions circular: to know which choice is rational you must first know how (probable it is that) you will choose, but that probability itself is supposed to be fixed by what you ought to choose.  Third, remedies proposed on behalf of CDT either abandon the core causal exclusion principle or collapse into something closer to Evidential Decision Theory (EDT).  After developing these points, I consider two ways of defending CDT and explain why neither resolves the underlying difficulty.

2. The Case Described

The set‐up is familiar but worth rehearsing in quantitative form.  The agent must decide whether to travel to Aleppo (A) or Damascus (D).  Death wants to meet her and is a good but imperfect predictor: with accuracy 𝜖 = 0.9 he predicts which city she will enter tomorrow; with probability 1 – 𝜖 he guesses wrongly.  In addition, Death has a mild bias for Damascus; ceteris paribus, if prediction is hard he is slightly more likely to guess D than A.  (That bias replaces the “dominant strategy” element in Newcomb’s original story: without the bias, randomising would break the correlation trivially.)

Let the utilities be:

Lives (no meeting): +10  
Dies (meeting Death): –1000  
Travel cost: –1 (always incurred)

An act’s causal expected utility (CEU) must be calculated using the unconditional probability that Death will be in each city, conditional only on facts not affected by the act.  But Death’s whereabouts is fixed by his prediction, and the predictor’s evidence is—plausibly—upstream of the agent’s ultimate movement yet downstream of the information encoded in her current deliberative state.  The upshot is that the unconditional probability of Death’s appearing in Damascus, P(Death in D), depends on the current probability the agent assigns to her own ending up in Damascus, P(D).  Let us formalise that dependence:

P(Death in D) = 𝜖·P(D) + (1 – 𝜖)·(1 – P(D)) + β,

where β > 0 captures the symmetric “Damascus bias”.  Suppose β = 0.05 for concreteness.  The mirrored expression gives P(Death in A).

Now compute CEU for each act:

CEU(A) = (1 – P(Death in A))·(10 – 1) + P(Death in A)·(–1000 – 1).  
CEU(D) = (1 – P(Death in D))·(10 – 1) + P(Death in D)·(–1000 – 1).

Because P(Death in A) and P(Death in D) each contain P(D), both expected utilities are functions of P(D).  Hence, as the agent revises her confidence in travelling to Damascus—something she rationally does precisely while deciding—the values that CDT attaches to A and D oscillate.

3. The Instability

Begin deliberation with an even credence, P(D) = 0.5.  Plugging numbers in (𝜖 = 0.9, β = 0.05) yields

P(Death in D) = 0.9·0.5 + 0.1·0.5 + 0.05 = 0.55.  
P(Death in A) = 0.45.

CEU(A) ≈ 0.55·(–1001) + 0.45·9 ≈ –551.0.  
CEU(D) ≈ 0.45·(–1001) + 0.55·9 ≈ –441.0.

Damascus currently looks better (less bad).  Acting on CDT, the agent begins to form an intention to go to Damascus.  That intention drives P(D) above 0.5—say to 0.9—because, after all, once she settles on Damascus she becomes very nearly certain that she will in fact go there.

Recalculate:

P(Death in D) = 0.9·0.9 + 0.1·0.1 + 0.05 = 0.86.  
CEU(D) now ≈ 0.86·(–1001) + 0.14·9 ≈ –859.  
P(Death in A) = 0.14.  
CEU(A) ≈ –139.

Aleppo is now decisively preferable.  The agent therefore flips, forming the intention to go to Aleppo.  But if so her credence P(D) plummets, returning CEU(A) to a disastrous level and CEU(D) to the lesser evil.  The cycle continues.  CDT provides no stationary recommendation unless the agent hits exactly the credence at which CEU(D) = CEU(A).  Yet that fixed point is itself unstable: infinitesimal perturbations push deliberation into the same oscillation.

4. Why Dependence on Act Probabilities Is Worrisome

4.1 Violating Deliberative Stability  
A plausible requirement on normative decision rules is Deliberative Stability: an act that is rational when one is perfectly undecided remains rational after one “makes up one’s mind”.  The Death in Damascus dynamics show CDT fails this.  The theory cannot give a time‐independent injunction; it issues successively conflicting commands as the agent traverses an ordinary path of reflection.  Every choice endorsed at t₁ is condemned at t₂.

Some will object that the instability is merely psychological: an ideally rational agent would jump directly to the equilibrium credence.  But what is that credence?  As shown, the equality CEU(D) = CEU(A) pins down one and only one probability value.  That value isn’t dictated by facts external to the agent; it is determined by the expected‐utility equations themselves.  Since the equations depend on the credence, and the credence depends on what the equations recommend, circularity looms.

4.2 Normative Circularity  
Suppose an oracle asks: “What ought you to do?”  CDT instructs: calculate expected utilities.  But to calculate them you must plug in P(D).  Where should you get P(D)?  The natural answer—by reflecting on your propensity to choose D—already presupposes some provisional verdict about what you will (hence may) decide.  A norm of practical reasoning should not take its own output as input.  CDT’s dependence thus resembles an epistemic circularity akin to the liar paradox: the content to be evaluated depends on the evaluation.

The circularity isn’t purely logical; it is pragmatic.  In principle one could search for a fixed point of the CEU equations, but as Arntzenius (2008) argues, nothing guarantees that a fixed point exists, or that it is uniquely rational if it does.  Here one exists but is unstable.  CDT therefore mandates a form of self‐fulfilling prophecy without delivering a reason to pick one prophecy over another.

4.3 Deference to “How Things Would Go”  
CDT prides itself on limiting attention to causal pathways.  Yet the Delphi‐like dependence on P(D) is not causal—it is evidential.  The more I judge I will go to Damascus, the more I judge Death will be waiting there; but my merely thinking I’ll go to Damascus doesn’t cause Death to select that destination.  The correlation arises because both events have a common informational ancestor—Death’s prediction algorithm.  Therefore CDT reinstates exactly the evidential correlations it was designed to ignore, though covertly via P(D).  The theory becomes hostage to its enemy.

4.4 Conflict with Ratifiability  
Jeffrey (1965) defined an act as ratifiable when, conditional on intending it, the agent would still consider it optimal.  Rational decisions, he proposed, must be ratifiable.  In Death in Damascus no pure act is ratifiable: intending A makes D preferable and vice versa.  That can be seen as a reductio of ratifiability, but it can equally be viewed as a reductio of any theory that, like CDT, refuses to recommend mixed or stochastic strategies in such cases.  A mixed strategy—e.g. flip a fair coin—would break the symmetry and is ratifiable with respect to its own probabilistic profile.  CDT, however, has no place for mixed acts unless they are causally implemented, so it remains stuck.

5. CDT Replies and Why They Fail

5.1 “The Probability of My Act Is Objective and Unchanging”  
Joyce (1999) suggests that from the God’s‐eye perspective there is a single correct unconditional probability distribution over acts, reflecting the objective indeterminacy of a chancy world.  On that view, the agent’s credence P(D) should equal that objective chance, so it need not vary with deliberation.  The apparent instability is thus blamed on the agent’s failure to appreciate her own propensities.  

Objection: even granting objective chances of choice, the agent typically lacks precise knowledge of them.  Rational credence is guided by subjective evidence, and that evidence is exactly the flow of reasons acquiring shape during deliberation.  Any decision rule that requires perfect foreknowledge of its own output to generate its output is epistemically infeasible.  Moreover, if the objective chance happens to be, say, 0.73, there is still the normative question why acting as though one is certain to choose Aleppo (or Damascus) is mistaken.  CDT supplies no argument beyond “that isn’t what you in fact will do”, sliding again into descriptivism.

5.2 “Adopt a Mixed or Randomised Strategy”  
Skyrms (1990) and Arntzenius urge that agents may rationally randomise: e.g. flip a coin, go to the city it dictates.  Conditional on such a mixed act, the probabilities of Death’s location equilibrate and the CEUs converge, yielding stability.  

But standard CDT treats “flip‐a‐coin‐then‐follow‐it” as a two‐stage act.  Once the coin lands heads (say), going to Aleppo is now certain, and the earlier instability reasserts itself.  To salvage the manoeuvre one must treat the probabilistic mix as a primitive act, not analysable into later acts.  That requires CDT to abandon its principled insistence that causal consequences be evaluated act by act.  Effectively CDT must admit probabilistic acts as basic, a move that makes it indistinguishable from a sophisticated form of EDT, which already allows such mixtures.

5.3 “Ignore the Predictor’s Bias”  
Some writers note the bias toward Damascus is what generates oscillation.  Without it, a 50/50 mixed strategy maximises utility.  The bias can be handled, they say, by treating it as downstream of Death’s caprice, hence excluded from the CEU calculation.  But that conflicts with the story’s stipulation that the bias is upstream of the choice.  To shave it off is to modify the case rather than solve the problem.  Indeed, any residual imperfection in Death’s accuracy will revive the dependence.

6. Does EDT Do Better?

Evidential Decision Theory calculates expected utility conditional on the act itself rather than on the act’s causal ancestors.  In Death in Damascus, EDT simply asks: conditional on going to Damascus, how probable is that I die?  The answer exfoliates the full predictive correlation, leading EDT to prefer Aleppo unconditionally in the biased variant (or to be indifferent in the symmetric variant).  EDT thereby reaches a stable recommendation, but at a cost: in Newcomb’s Problem EDT endorses one‐box, whereas many—including proponents of CDT—find that irrational.

One could seize the moral: no single‐criterion theory delivers intuitively correct results across all exotic cases.  Yet the point remains that EDT does not suffer from the deliberative instability unique to CDT in this context.  Therefore, if one takes stability to be a minimal requirement on normative reason, CDT is disqualified.

7. The Deeper Lesson: Decisions as Algorithms

A growing literature (e.g. Rathbone, Spencer 2022) views decision problems as games between “algorithms” realised in agents and “environment simulators” realised in predictors.  From that vantage, the choice between A and D is not about two primitive acts but about selecting a decision procedure—perhaps a stochastic one.  If CDT insists on evaluating only downstream causal consequences it adopts too coarse a grain: the content of the decision rule (including how it responds to predictions) is upstream of Death’s placement, so there is unexploited causal influence after all.  But recognising that influence amounts to letting the evidential back in through the causal front door.  CDT dissolves into a higher‐order evidential theory.

8. Conclusion

Is CDT’s dependence on act probabilities a problem?  Yes, for three interconnected reasons.

1. Procedural instability: CDT’s advice whipsaws as the agent rationally updates the very probabilities that enter its calculation.  This violates the expectation that a decision theory delivers consistent guidance across the deliberative process.

2. Normative circularity: to apply CDT one needs prior knowledge of what it will output, undermining its status as an autonomous standard of rational choice.

3. Covert evidentialism: because the dependence piggybacks on non‐causal correlations, CDT betrays its foundational ban on using mere information links in computing expected utility.

Attempts to rescue CDT by postulating fixed objective chances, by permitting unanalysed mixed acts, or by amputating the predictor’s bias each compromises essential CDT commitments.  Evidential rivals do not face the same instability, though they court other controversies.  The upshot is that Death in Damascus reveals a structural weakness in CDT’s treatment of self‐locating belief and predictive feedback: any theory that denies those links causal relevance yet still allows them to influence utilities through shifting act probabilities ends in contradiction.  A satisfactory decision theory must instead integrate causal and evidential considerations in a unified calculus—or accept, pace CDT, that the direction of causation is not the only compass by which rational agents should steer.

Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? I shall defend an affirmative answer. The core of my proposal is this: an agent whose “sole motive” is the de dicto desire to do what is right can nevertheless be (i) epistemically attuned to the concrete right-making features of her situation, (ii) practically responsive to them in the right way, and (iii) disposed to care about them once she apprehends them. When the de dicto motive is epistemically sophisticated and stably integrated with a general concern to conform her life to morality, it gives rise to the very kind of sensitivity to others’ welfare, fairness, or dignity that critics regard as indispensable. In such cases dutiful action is not fetishistic or alienated; it is an expression of an agent’s practical identity as someone who is resolved to live up to what morality, whatever it turns out to require, actually requires. Because that identity is itself a robust value—analogous to a scientist’s identity as a truth-seeker—actions issuing from it can possess moral worth, even when no further, more “concrete” motive is operative.

The argument will proceed in four stages. Section I reconstructs the main case against the sufficiency of the duty motive. Section II offers a conceptual model of the de dicto desire to do the right thing that distinguishes it from the caricature presupposed by critics. Section III shows how such a model evades the charges of fetishism and alienation. Section IV defends the claim that, once so understood, the duty motive can ground full moral worth.

I. The orthodox objection: fetishism and alienation  
--------------------------------------------------

Most contemporary versions of the worry descend from Michael Smith’s “moral fetishist” critique of Kantian internalism and Susan Wolf’s influential discussion of “moral saints.”

1. Fetishism. According to Smith (1994), the dutiful agent—the agent moved only by the thought that an act is morally right—treats rightness as a “brute” triggering property. She cares not about the fact that her neighbor is in pain or that promises have been made and relied upon; she cares only that “helping now is right.” If we replace “right” with “fashionable,” we see the fetish: the agent is obsessed with a label rather than the underlying qualities that imbue an act with value. Such obsession appears shallow, perhaps pathological.

2. Alienation. Wolf (1982) emphasizes that morality’s point is to foster flourishing relationships and human goods. The person whose entire motivational structure is dominated by the single-minded desire to do the right thing risks estrangement from activities and attachments that make life worth living. Others may not wish for such a person’s company; her love and friendship seem conditional or derivative, never spontaneous.

3. The wrong kind of reasons. A more recent formulation (e.g., Markovits 2010) employs the distinction between right-making reasons and flights from moral error. To possess moral worth, one must be “reactive” rather than “defensive”: one must be moved by the very considerations that render the act right, not by the second-order desire to avoid wrongdoing.

Together these complaints form a cumulative case: de dicto morality-seeking is motivationally impoverished, affectively cold, and normatively misaligned with the reasons that truly justify the action. Surely, the argument concludes, we should prize the Samaritan motivated by the victim’s suffering, not the bureaucratic Kantian who intervenes only because a maxim of beneficence commands it.

II. Rehabilitating the de dicto duty motive  
-------------------------------------------

The critic’s image of the de dicto motive is incomplete. “A desire to do what is right” can be thin or thick, empty or rich, inert or investigatory. The key is to differentiate three dimensions of the state:

A. Intentional content: The agent desires that she φ because φ-ing is morally right.  
B. Epistemic component: The agent is concerned to determine, as accurately as she can, whether φ is in fact right.  
C. Practical orientation: The agent is disposed, upon judging that φ is right, to φ, ceteris paribus.

Dimension B is crucial. A purely mechanical duty-bot who instantly performs the act once told that it is “right” has, at best, a truncated version of the state. A full-blooded duty motive includes an interest in understanding why the act is right. That interest ramifies into deliberative habits: seeking relevant empirical information, consulting those affected, reflecting on principles, and revising one’s beliefs in light of argument. Call this enriched state the reflective duty motive (RDM).

RDM is akin to what epistemologists term an “epistemically responsible” doxastic attitude. Just as the responsible inquirer values truth and therefore engages in careful inquiry, the reflective moral agent values right action and therefore attends to the facts that bear on rightness. The desire is second-order in form—“act rightly”—but first-order in its practical effects: it pushes the agent toward the very considerations that matter for evaluating acts.

We can now explain why someone moved solely by RDM need not be indifferent to concrete moral goods. Suppose Jan hears a cry for help. She wonders: is assisting obligatory? Her RDM triggers an inquiry: “The person sounds injured; perhaps assistance is necessary to prevent serious harm; I can help at little cost.” Recognizing those features, Jan acts. Her motivational narrative does mention only “do what is right,” but the internal structure of that desire ensures that she sees suffering as making a moral claim. The concern for rightness is a portal through which other-regarding motives are dynamically acquired.

III. Defusing fetishism and alienation  
--------------------------------------

1. Why it is not fetishism  
A fetish depicts a fixed, context-insensitive attraction to an object whose deeper properties are ignored. RDM is context-sensitive and deeply interested in the underlying reasons. Indeed, RDM mandates that one attend to them—otherwise one cannot be confident that the act is right. The fetishist wants the label; the reflective dutiful agent wants the reality the label purports to track. Just as a dedicated scientist cares about obtaining sound evidence rather than securing the social status of being “correct,” the reflective dutiful agent cares about acting in ways that withstand moral scrutiny.

But what if, counterfactually, the reasons that make the act right shifted? Then the dutiful agent’s behavior would track the shift, because her concern is indexed to whatever the true right-making reasons are. The fetishist would remain glued to the accidental surface.

2. Why it is not alienating  
It is sometimes thought that if one helps a friend merely out of duty, one’s regard is impersonal. Yet the charge presupposes that duty crowds out affection. RDM need not. The agent can, contingently, lack a distinct altruistic sentiment in a given case; still, her action flows from a standing commitment to treat her friends’ interests with equal weight. That commitment is itself a form of respect—indeed, Kant thought it the highest form. Moreover, RDM’s epistemic imperative encourages the agent to appreciate what matters about her friend’s situation. This appreciation can awaken direct sympathetic feelings. Even if it does not, the friend can still rightly interpret the help as an expression of deep regard, precisely because it was delivered on the basis of moral recognition rather than caprice.

Consider a parallel in friendship: I might honor my friend’s autonomy by refraining from unsolicited advice, not because I feel like it but because I recognize her capacity for self-direction. She may value that principled restraint more than a gush of meddling affection.

3. “The wrong kind of reasons” revisited  
Markovits argues that the dutiful agent is like someone who gives ten pounds merely to avoid guilt; the donation is right for the wrong reasons. Yet RDM is oriented toward exactly the right reasons: the duty theorist donates because she believes the recipient’s need gives rise to an obligation. The fact that the content of her desire is “to do what is right” does not imply that the psychological explanation of her act ignores the recipient’s need; rather, the need figures in the explanation, mediated by her conception of rightness.

The mistake lies in equating “being moved by x because x makes the act right” with “having x as a standalone, de re desire.” These are not equivalent. One can be moved by x because one sees x as right-making, even if the form of one’s desire is de dicto.

IV. Why reflective dutiful action has moral worth  
-------------------------------------------------

So far I have argued that the reflective duty motive is not fetishistic or alienating. I now make the stronger claim: actions flowing solely from RDM can be fully praiseworthy.

A. The control condition  
Many accounts of moral worth require that the agent’s response express the agent’s moral agency, i.e., be under her rational control. RDM satisfies this excellently. Because it is principle-driven and because the agent endorses that principle upon reflection, the resulting act is paradigmatically her own. Even if she feels no spontaneous sympathy, the choice to align herself with moral standards articulates her will.

B. The reasons-responsiveness condition  
Neil Levy and others insist that moral worth attaches to dispositions that are suitably responsive to moral reasons across possible cases. A person who happens to save a drowning child merely because she likes swimming lacks this robustness. RDM, however, tracks moral reasons across a wide domain precisely because it aims at rightness itself. Granted, successful tracking requires epistemic competence. But that is no objection; it shows why a well-exercised de dicto motive is praiseworthy—its reliability depends on the agent’s sustained intellectual effort.

C. The credit condition: effort and sacrifice  
We often praise agents when they overcome contrary desires. Acting from RDM can involve such overcoming. Imagine Bernard, who is tempted to lie to protect his reputation but refrains solely because he judges it wrong. His respect for morality costs him social standing. The moral credit he earns derives from his will to do the right thing in the face of countervailing inclinations. Once more, no separate warm-hearted motive is needed.

D. The value of moral integrity  
Acting from a de dicto commitment to morality exemplifies integrity: the alignment between one’s principles and actions. Integrity is itself a moral virtue, prized in both Aristotelian and Kantian traditions. When an agent’s behavior is an immediate expression of that virtue, the action inherits moral worth.

V. Two objections considered  
----------------------------

Objection 1: “Your view collapses into the orthodox view: once the agent understands the concrete reasons, she is also motivated by them. So the duty motive is not sufficient after all.”

Reply: The sufficiency claim is that no additional, psychologically independent motive is required beyond the enriched duty motive. When the RDM is the sole standing motive, the agent’s coming to apprehend particular right-making facts effectively produces subsidiary desires (e.g., to relieve suffering) but not as separate axiological sources. They are sub-intentions generated by the higher-order aim. In this sense RDM alone suffices: nothing needs to be antecedently present except the desire to act rightly plus normal cognitive capacities.

Objection 2: “What about supererogation? Doesn’t the motive of duty rule it out?”

Reply: The critic assumes that duty fixes a threshold of minimal decency, whereas supererogatory acts go beyond. But on many moral theories, including demanding consequentialism, what is right may already require extraordinary sacrifice; if so, duty fully explains heroism. Alternatively, if one believes in a realm of the morally optional good, one can incorporate a permission into one’s conception of rightness: “Although not required, giving my kidney would be an excellent thing to do; I judge that in the circumstances giving is overall morally best.” The RDM thus grounds, rather than prohibits, supererogatory motivation.

VI. Relationship to Kant  
------------------------

The canonical defender of duty’s moral worth is, of course, Immanuel Kant. Critics often read Kant as privileging the absence of inclination. But contemporary Kant scholarship (e.g., Velleman 1999; Korsgaard 1996) reveals a richer picture. For Kant, acting “from duty” means acting from respect for the moral law, which imposes a form on maxims; the moral law’s content already encodes concern for humanity, fairness, and autonomy. Kant’s point is not that emotions are irrelevant but that moral motivation must be anchored in a principle that any rational agent could endorse. My defense of RDM echoes this Kantian insight while allowing that principled motivation can coexist with, and even foster, concrete sympathetic feelings.

VII. The broader lesson: meta-reasons and first-order reasons  
-------------------------------------------------------------

Finally, the debate illuminates a general meta-ethical phenomenon: higher-order motives can ground praiseworthy responsiveness in a domain even when detached from any particular first-order concern. Scientists can value truth per se and consequently care about statistical rigor; judges can value impartial justice and thus heed precedent; environmentalists can value ecosystem integrity and therefore examine carbon cycles. In each case, a de dicto orientation—seek truth, uphold justice, protect nature—guides attention to domain-specific facts that justify action. We do not accuse the scientist of epistemic fetishism because she conducts an experiment “only to find the truth.” We admire her for caring about what really matters in her domain. Morality is no exception.

Conclusion  
----------

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth. The key is to interpret the duty motive as reflective, epistemically engaged, and action-guiding. So construed, it is neither fetishistic nor alienating. It embodies a form of moral integrity that is reliably responsive to the very considerations that make actions right. Far from being an impoverished substitute for concrete motives, the desire to live up to morality’s demands is an architectonic commitment through which all concrete moral considerations are recognized, weighed, and honored. When an agent acts from that commitment, her conduct is fully praiseworthy—and rightly earns our moral admiration.

Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice for morally worthy conduct? My answer is Yes.  In what follows I defend that verdict in five steps.  

1. Clarifying the distinction between de dicto and de re moral motivation.  
2. Presenting the “moral fetishism” objection and explaining why it looks forceful.  
3. Arguing that a purely de-dicto desire can itself display the features the objection claims to be missing—namely, (a) sensitivity to the reasons that make an action right and (b) an attractive moral orientation to others.  
4. Showing how the de-dicto motive uniquely realises a value Kant called Selbstgesetzgebung (self-legislation) and why that value grounds moral worth.  
5. Responding to three residual worries: coldness, epistemic luck, and motivational fragility.  

Although I focus on Kantian texts for historical illumination, my aim is not exegetical but evaluative: I want to show that the abstract motive of duty can, in the real world, make an action fully praiseworthy.

--------------------------------------------------
1. De dicto versus de re moral motivation
--------------------------------------------------

Philosophers distinguish between two ways an agent can be “motivated by morality.”

• De re (of the thing): The agent’s desire fixes on a concrete property that is in fact morally right-making.  E.g. “I want to help because you are in need.”  
• De dicto (of the dictum): The agent’s desire fixes on the fact that the action is morally right, whatever concrete property realises that status.  E.g. “I want to do this because it’s the right thing to do.”

Both motives can coexist in a single psychology; what worries critics is the possibility of the second operating alone.  Imagine Greta confronts a drowning child.  She saves him, explaining afterwards, “I didn’t feel particular concern for the child.  I simply knew saving him was morally required.”  Is Greta’s action diminished in worth?  The challenge insists the answer is Yes, because Greta is alleged to lack appreciation of the very features that matter morally—namely, the child’s peril and value.  

--------------------------------------------------
2. The fetishism charge
--------------------------------------------------

The objection, pressed notably by Michael Smith, David Hume (in embryo), and, outside analytic ethics, by Bernard Williams’s idea of “one thought too many,” has three layers:

a. Epistemic layer:  Moral rightness is not a natural property perceivable in the world.  To act for that abstract property alone looks suspiciously like treating morality as a mysterious magnet—i.e. “fetishising” it.  

b. Affective layer:  The moral life, they say, centrally involves concern for humans and animals, not an “external law.”  An agent who saves a stranger “only because duty demands” seems cold or alienated.  

c. Explanatory layer:  If the goodness of the act is explained by, say, the child’s being in danger, then that consideration should move the agent.  Otherwise her motivation is disconnected from the very reasons that make the act right.

This triune charge is powerful.  But it presupposes a picture of the de-dicto motive that is, I contend, too thin and juridical.  Let us enrich that picture.

--------------------------------------------------
3. How a de-dicto motive can incorporate substantive reasons
--------------------------------------------------

Start with an analogy drawn from theoretical reasoning.  A good scientist has a standing desire “to believe what the evidence supports.”  That desire is de dicto with respect to truth: she wants to believe propositions insofar as they are true, whatever their contents.  Yet, when she endorses a specific hypothesis, her motivation must become sensitive to the particular evidence.  The general desire functions as a structural commitment that *activates* attention to concrete data.  Nothing about its abstract form prevents the scientist from appreciating those data in all their richness; indeed, it *requires* her to.  

Morality works similarly.  A pure desire to “do what is morally right” cannot be action-guiding unless the agent brings under that description concrete facts about others: their needs, vulnerabilities, claims, projects.  In practice, then, the de-dicto motive drives the agent to ask, “What matters here?  What’s at stake for the child?”  The very logic of the motive forces the agent into contact with the right-making grounds, because without identifying them she does not yet know what morality requires.  Far from being disconnected, the de-dicto desire is a *second-order* directive whose satisfaction criterialy depend on first-order sensitivities.  

Let us revisit Greta.  Suppose she operates with the maxim: “Whenever I can, I will do what is morally required.”  Faced with the drowning child, she quickly recognises that the child’s life, his future, and his family’s loss are all morally weighty.  Those are not mere instrumental beliefs; they are what her dutiful maxim *says* to regard.  If she lacked any feeling for them, she would fail to understand the situation as morally requiring.  Hence the fetishism charge rests on an empirical misdescription: authentic de-dicto resolve typically *imports* concern for right-making considerations rather than sidelining them.

One might reply that Greta could, in principle, defer to duty without grasping any of these grounds—for example, by consulting a priest or moral oracle.  True, but cases of blind deference are possibilities for *any* motive.  Someone could assist the child “out of love,” yet know nothing of his circumstances—she might just feel generic warmth.  We do not therefore dismiss love as a basis for worth.  We demand that motives, whatever their type, be *appropriately* hooked up to reasons.  When that condition holds, a de-dicto motive passes muster.

--------------------------------------------------
4. Self-legislation and the distinctive value of duty
--------------------------------------------------

Even if the argument above shows that de-dicto motivation need not be morally deficient, why think it can ever be *especially* praiseworthy?  Kant’s answer, which I adapt, is that it expresses autonomy—acting under a law one gives oneself *because it is a law of reason*.  Let me spell out the contemporary significance of that claim.

4.1. Non-heteronomous orientation.  
When I rescue the child solely because I sympathise with him, my act is governed by an affective attachment that might or might not track what morality demands in other cases.  Sympathy is contingent and partial.  In acting from duty I appeal to a standard that transcends my particular affections.  The value realised is that I acknowledge *the authority of moral reasons as such*.

4.2. Reliability and universality.  
Because the de-dicto desire ranges over “whatever is right,” it generates a stable disposition to do the right thing across contexts that my natural motives might not cover (distant victims, unpopular minorities, future generations).  That reliability is a moral achievement.  We honour civil-rights activists who helped strangers *as a matter of principle* not because they lacked compassion but because their principle enabled them to extend concern far beyond natural familiarity.

4.3. Respect.  
Kant sometimes speaks of duty as “practical respect for law,” but what is respected via the law are persons as ends in themselves.  To treat your claim on me as a *duty* is to recognise its normative force; I do not merely *like* satisfying you.  People want their claims acknowledged, not merely indulged.  That is why apologies couched in moral terms (“I wronged you; I had an obligation to act otherwise”) often feel more respectful than apologies that mention only affection.  

These three aspects—autonomy, reliability, respect—confer a distinctive moral worth on dutiful conduct.  They are not in competition with the value of benevolence; rather, they add another dimension to it.  

--------------------------------------------------
5. Answering residual worries
--------------------------------------------------

5.1. Coldness  
The critic may say: “Even if duty entails recognition of right-making reasons, it is still motivationally second-best because it leaves out warm concern.”  I grant that warmth is valuable.  But moral worth is multi-dimensional.  We already praise agents for *courage* even when they do not act from love; we praise *honesty* even when it is inconveniently scrupulous.  Why should dutifulness, which manifests respect for persons and principled agency, be excluded?  Moreover, nothing prevents duty from cohabiting with warmth.  The claim I defend is sufficiency, not exclusivity.

5.2. Epistemic luck  
Suppose Angela’s sole aim is “do the right thing,” but through poor moral reasoning she misidentifies her duty and by chance does what is right.  Is she praiseworthy?  My account says No, because moral worth requires that the agent’s success be *appropriately explained* by her motive.  The de-dicto desire gives her a reason to reason carefully; if she is negligent, her failure of care undermines worth.  So the sufficiency thesis operates only where the duty motive is *competently executed*—exactly the competence condition we impose on any virtue.

5.3. Motivational fragility  
Finally, the critic notes that one can endorse an abstract standard yet falter when costs rise.  True again, but this shows not that the motive type is defective but that its *strength* may be insufficient.  An agent who folds under pressure is less praiseworthy, no matter her motive’s content.  Kant, tellingly, thought the only sure sign of acting from duty is steady performance “contrary to all inclination.”  That standard is demanding, but the fragility worry attacks human willpower, not the de-dicto motive per se.

Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------

We can now answer the governing question.  Yes: acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth.  The de-dicto motive (1) necessarily brings the agent into cognitive and emotional contact with the concrete right-making considerations; (2) uniquely embodies respect, universality, and autonomy; (3) satisfies ordinary criteria of moral worth so long as it is competently and steadfastly executed.  Far from being fetishistic or alienating, the dutiful stance is a morally admirable posture toward the world and toward others.  

Indeed, in societies where sympathy is often parochial and partial, the abstract motive of duty may be the best hope for inclusive moral progress.  We should not denigrate it as second-best; we should cultivate it alongside the natural affections, celebrating every occasion on which a person acts—purely and steadfastly—for no other reason than that it is, simply, the right thing to do.

1. Introduction  

Ought -motivated action is the paradigmatic case of moral rectitude in many ethical theories.
