Yet a venerable line of thought—traceable from Hume through Aristotle and rediscovered by twentieth-century writers such as Michael Stocker, Samuel Scheffler, and Michael Smith—insists that sheer devotion to “doing the right thing” is not enough for moral worth.  One must also care about the concrete values, persons, or goods at stake.  Otherwise the agent is charged with “moral fetishism,” “alienation,” or “schizophrenia” between motives and reasons.  

In what follows I defend the contrary view that acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can, under certain conditions, suffice for morally worthy conduct.  I argue, first, that the fetishism/alienation criticisms rest on an impoverished picture of what a de dicto desire to do the right thing involves.  Second, I show that once we specify the cognitive demands built into conscientious agency, the motive of duty is neither empty nor fetishistic, but intrinsically connected to the very considerations critics say it neglects.  Third, I respond to three prominent objections: (i) the emotional impoverishment charge; (ii) the over-intellectualisation worry; and (iii) the concern that bare duty breeds fanatical or ruthless behaviour.  I conclude that morally worthy dutiful action is praiseworthy because it manifests the agent’s practical rationality—the capacity to respond appropriately to moral reasons—and that such rational responsiveness can be fully realised through the de dicto desire to do the right thing even in the absence of additional, more particularistic motives.

2. Two Ways of Wanting the Right  

We must begin by distinguishing two conceptions of the motive of duty.

A. Thin or procedural duty motive: “I want, come what may, to do whatever is stamped ‘morally permissible’.”  This motive is silent about why actions have that stamp or what makes them worth doing.  

B. Thick or reasons-sensitive duty motive: “I want to comply with the set of reasons that make an action morally required.”  On this richer reading, the content of the desire already includes a commitment to the right-making considerations, albeit under the description ‘the considerations that make it right’.  

Many critics attack only version A and then infer that any de dicto duty motive is morally defective.  But the proponent of dutiful moral worth typically espouses version B.  Kant, for example, writes that an action has moral worth when it is done “from duty” and “because the maxim of the action includes the representation of the law in itself.”  That representation is not a vacuous law-token but a recognition of the reason-giving features that make the act necessary “without any further motive.”

Hence the dispute reduces to whether an agent motivated by B, yet lacking any independent affective pull toward the objects of moral concern, behaves in a way that merits praise.  I argue that she does.

3. Why Duty Need Not Be Fetishistic  

Michael Smith’s (1994) classic “fetish” objection alleges that an agent who helps others only because it is “the morally right thing to do” is interested in morality’s label rather than in people’s suffering.  The beneficiary’s welfare plays no direct motivational role, so the agent’s concern, Smith claims, is misplaced.  

This argument presupposes that motive content must match the surface description of the right-making feature.  But that is false.  To see why, consider an epistemic analogue: a mathematician who says, “I want to prove only what is true.”  Her desire is de dicto with respect to truth, yet in seeking a proof she must pay meticulous attention to the concrete logical relations that make the theorem true.  The de dicto desire guides her to track whatever de re properties constitute truth in the given domain.  No one would call her intellectually fetishistic.

Similarly, conscientious moral agency requires sensitivity to (e.g.) another’s pain, the unfair distribution of burdens, or the promise one has made.  An agent motivated by duty cannot identify which act is right unless she grasps such considerations; if she fails to register them, she is simply unable to satisfy her own de dicto desire.  So there is an internal link, built into the practical reasoning process, between the abstract motive and the concrete values it directs her to.

4. Moral Worth as Rational Responsiveness  

Arpaly and Schroeder (2014) suggest that moral worth lies in “praiseworthiness,” which in turn consists in acting from good motives—motives that are appropriately sensitive to moral reasons.  They allow a variety of good motives (compassion, fairness, friendship) but do not rule out the possibility that a de dicto desire counts, provided that it is reason-responsive.

My account elaborates this view:

(1) X’s action has moral worth insofar as  
(2) X deserves credit for correctly responding to the moral reasons that in fact render the action right.

Condition (2) is met when (a) X’s motivational set includes a desire whose satisfaction-conditions are keyed to the moral reasons, and (b) X’s deliberation tracks those reasons with sufficient reliability.

The thick duty motive satisfies (a) by definition.  Whether it also meets (b) depends on the agent’s epistemic and deliberative competence, not on the presence of additional sentimental motives.  Hence, acting solely from duty can be enough for praiseworthiness when the agent’s conscientious deliberation reliably aligns with the right-making factors.

5. Addressing Three Objections  

5.1 Emotional Impoverishment  

Stocker (1976) claims that the dutiful friend is not really a friend: if I visit you in hospital solely out of duty, my motive lacks the warmth friendship requires.  This proves, he thinks, that duty-only acting is deficient even when it hits the right note from a moral standpoint.

Reply. First, our present question concerns moral worth, not whether the agent perfectly exemplifies the virtue of friendship.  One can be morally deserving of praise for visiting while still falling short of the highest ideal of loving friendship.  Second, the thick duty motive can coexist with affective concern in many agents, and nothing about my defence forbids such coexistence.  The claim is merely that extra concern is not necessary for moral worth.  Finally, even where affection is absent, the sufferer benefits from my visit; my reliable responsiveness to his moral claim shows respect for him as a person, which is itself a valuable form of recognition.

5.2 Over-Intellectualisation  

A different worry is that morality becomes an abstract game for duty-bound agents: they coldly compute moral laws, alienated from their emotions.  This resonates with feminist critiques that reason-centred ethics marginalises care.

Two replies.  (a) The conception of practical reason involved here is not disembodied calculation.  Rational sensitivity includes noticing salient features in concrete contexts—a skill steeped in emotions such as empathy and anger.  But these emotions function epistemically: they help reveal morally relevant facts.  Once the right-making facts are grasped, the de dicto desire to “do what morality requires” can carry the motivational burden.  (b) Even if emotions often facilitate reliable moral tracking, it does not follow that they must be the proximate motive conferring moral worth.  They may play a subsidiary epistemic role without being the direct drive behind the action.

5.3 Fanaticism and Ruthlessness  

Some critics fear that a pure duty motive can spawn fanaticism: if morality recommends extreme sacrifice, the agent will pursue it without regard for legitimate partial concerns.  The Kantian counterpart is the allegation that duty leaves no room for inclination, producing “moral robots.”

However, fanaticism arises only if the agent misidentifies what morality requires.  A properly informed de dicto desire incorporates limits—respect for persons’ autonomy, proportionality, etc.—that rule out fanatic extremes.  To the extent that an agent is willing to override these limits, she betrays, rather than exemplifies, the duty motive correctly understood.  The problem is thus epistemic, not motivational.  

6. A Positive Model of Dutiful Moral Worth  

Consider Rowan, who discovers that a co-worker’s livelihood depends on an accurate performance review.  Rowan personally dislikes the co-worker but recognises that the evidence supports a positive report.  Motivated solely by the thought “I ought to tell the truth because that is what morality requires,” Rowan submits the honest appraisal.  There is no compassion, no fondness, perhaps even mild resentment.

Is Rowan praiseworthy?  Yes, because:

(1) She accurately identified the relevant moral reasons (truthfulness, fairness, the co-worker’s legitimate expectations).  
(2) Her action reliably tracks those reasons; a counterfactual test shows that were the evidence worse, she would write a negative review.  
(3) She overcomes contrary inclinations—dislike of the colleague, desire to please management—and does so for the reason that it is the right thing.

Rowan’s motive exemplifies practical rationality.  Her success cannot be credited to luck: it flows from a stable aspect of her character, namely conscientiousness.  The absence of affection may mean she does not manifest certain virtues (benevolence), but it does not nullify the moral worth of what she does.

7. Kant Revisited  

Kant is often caricatured as embracing the thin duty motive.  But the Groundwork specifies that an action has moral worth when the agent’s maxim contains the law-giving form as its determining ground.  The content is not empty: it is a principled commitment to treat rational nature as an end, to respect universal law, etc.  Kant’s paradigmatic examples (the honest shopkeeper, the benefactor dulled by his own sorrow) illustrate agents who grasp the right-making factors but whose empirical inclinations fail to assist them.  Kant’s claim is not that inclination is bad, but that worth supervenes on duty where inclination is silent or adverse.

Critics sometimes ask why Kant forbids the shopkeeper’s motive of self-interest for moral worth but permits the motive of duty.  The answer is that only the latter constitutes a reverent acknowledgment of the normative authority of the moral law.  Moral worth lies in that acknowledgment, i.e., in the agent’s self-legislation as a rational being.  My account supplements this with a reasons-responsiveness condition: the self-legislation must in fact hook onto the right-making properties in the world.

8. Comparative Advantages over Particularistic Theories  

Jonathan Dancy and other particularists argue that moral virtue requires direct sensitivity to the moral reasons themselves, not to an abstract property like rightness.  But on closer inspection, their sensitivity criterion converges with mine; the difference is merely semantic.  For a duty-motived agent to know that φ-ing is right is just for her to know that φ-ing has the reasons particularists celebrate.  The route of access passes through a higher-order description (“rightness”), yet it does not bypass or ignore the first-order facts.

Moreover, the duty motive has distinctive virtues:

a. Unity: It provides a single, stable practical identity across disparate contexts, facilitating integrity.  
b. Guidance: In novel situations where emotional dispositions misfire, conscientious deliberation can still orient the agent.  
c. Impartiality: It explains why we ought to extend concern beyond the circle of those we love.

9. Are Additional Motives Redundant?  

None of this implies we should eschew compassion or friendship.  Multiple good motives can overdetermine moral worth, and human agents typically require a division of motivational labour for psychological efficiency.  But from a normative perspective, the presence of extra motives is supererogatory relative to what is needed for moral praise.  The bar for moral worth should not be set so high that only saints clear it.  Conscientiousness is a virtue available to ordinary agents and should be recognised as such.

10. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct, provided the desire is of the thick, reasons-sensitive variety.  Such action is praiseworthy because it manifests the agent’s rational responsiveness to the very factors that make the act right.  

Contrary to the fetishism and alienation charges, conscientious agents are not fixated on a moral label detached from substantive value.  Their abstract commitment functions as a regulative aim that both requires and ensures engagement with those substantive values.  While richer sentimental motives can embellish moral life, they are not necessary for moral credit.  A world of dutiful Rowans would be a world in which promises are kept, injustices rectified, and truth respected—surely a world we can admire.

Can the naked, de dicto desire to “do what is morally right”—the motive Kant called duty—suffice for genuine moral worth? Or must praiseworthy agents also be moved by a more concrete affection, such as empathy for the beneficiary or love of justice itself? In the last half-century a well-known critique, voiced by Bernard Williams, Michael Stocker, Samuel Scheffler, Julia Annas and others, claims that the purely dutiful agent is at best morally defective, at worst fetishistic. The person who helps a friend merely because it is morally required, we are told, fails to value that friend “for her own sake” and exhibits a chilling estrangement from what morality is really about. Yet a counter-tradition reaching back to Kant (and more recently defended by Barbara Herman, Mark Schroeder, and Julia Markovits) insists that the duty-bound agent can be perfectly admirable. In what follows I argue that acting solely from duty can indeed be enough for moral worth, provided that (i) the agent’s de dicto desire is substantively informed, rather than content-less moral fetishism; (ii) the desire is integrated with a reliable capacity to recognise and respond to the relevant first-order moral reasons; and (iii) the agent’s success is non-accidental, issuing from a form of practical self-governance that merits esteem. These conditions explain why the dutiful action is praiseworthy and also dissolve the charge of alienation.

1. The intuitive pull of the anti-duty objection

Begin with an everyday example. Louisa returns a lost wallet, although doing so requires missing her train. She does so, let us stipulate, entirely because “it is the right thing to do.” She feels no particular sympathy for the owner, whom she will never meet; she is not motivated by a thrill of generosity or by any desire to see another’s happiness increased. She is moved solely by the thought: “I ought to return lost property.” Many philosophers find Louisa morally wanting. Williams speaks of the “one thought too many”: if my partner is drowning, the appropriate motive is love, not a calculation that rescues partners are morally obligatory. Stocker argues that modern moral theories which recommend such motives produce moral schizophrenia: an in-theory devotion to impartial rightness, in-practice humanly impoverished feelings. The underlying worry is this: morality is about people’s needs, sufferings and flourishing. To act from duty while remaining untouched by these concrete considerations is to miss morality’s point.

2. Two kinds of de dicto motivation

A good deal of confusion arises from running together two very different species of duty-orientation:

a) The empty de dicto desire: “I want to do whatever morality demands,” where the agent possesses only a dim or mechanical grasp of what morality actually demands or why. Here the desire is a mere placeholder, detached from any substantive moral understanding.

b) The enlightened de dicto desire: “I want to do whatever morality demands, and I competently grasp morality’s demands through reasoned appreciation of the considerations that make them right.” Such an agent’s sole ultimate desire is to do the right thing, but she reliably recognises that the right thing in a given context is, say, helping the wounded or keeping a promise. She therefore acts from the concrete considerations, albeit mediately.

Only the first kind deserves the label “fetishistic.” Critics often tacitly target (a) but treat it as the only possible de dicto motive. Yet there is nothing in the bare grammar “desire to do the right thing” that commits us to the empty form. Thus the first task for defenders of duty is to show that form (b) is possible and, when realised, morally impressive.

3. How an enlightened duty motive incorporates first-order reasons

Imagine again Louisa. Suppose she has internalised a set of practical deliberative skills: she notices the wallet, imagines the distress its loss will impose on its owner, recalls the general principle that people’s property rights ground pro tanto obligations, weighs the minor cost to herself, arrives at the judgment “Returning is required,” and then acts. The ultimate impetus—the element she would cite to answer “Why act?”—is indeed “because it is right.” Nevertheless, both cognitive and motivational contact with the first-order reasons (respect for property, concern for another’s loss) plays an indispensable role. They are ingredients in the practical syllogism through which she concludes that returning is right. If her deliberation somehow convinced her that no one would be harmed, or that the wallet’s owner was evil, her dutiful motive would not require returning it. This shows that the enlightened duty motive is not indifferent to concrete moral features; it is structured by them.

The point can be sharpened using Mark Schroeder’s work on “desire as belief” and Barbara Herman’s notion of “deliberative field.” A fully rational agent identifies “what morality requires” only by representing the considerations that make the act right. The de dicto desire is thus, so to speak, a motivational umbrella whose ribs are de re sensitivities: concern for persons, fairness, trust, and so on. If the ribs were absent, the umbrella would collapse. Therefore, the accusation that de dicto motivation is alienated from morality’s grounds presupposes a separation that rational agency itself forbids.

4. Autonomous self-governance and praiseworthiness

Why, though, is a successful action from enlightened duty deserving of praise? Three interrelated features ground its moral worth:

i) Rational self-governance. Kant thought that only actions done from duty manifest “the moral law within.” The more contemporary, de-Kantian thought is this: acting from the settled practical commitment to do what is right expresses an agent’s capacity to guide her conduct by impartial, reflectively endorsed principles rather than by impulse, accident, or parochial attachments. Such guidance honors the ideal of autonomy—living in accord with reasons one can in principle justify to any affected party. Agents who act this way realise a central moral ideal, and that realisation is (pro tanto) worthy of esteem.

ii) Reliability and counterfactual robustness. Motives such as sympathy or friendship, while often admirable, can be unstable across contexts: fatigue, bad mood, unfamiliarity, or prejudice may dampen them. A governing desire to do what is right, by contrast, tends to be more stable. Because the agent’s ultimate allegiance is to rightness, she will act correctly even when affective motivations are silent. This reliability makes her a trustworthy moral partner. Praise tracks not only what agents actually do but also the quality of character they manifest; stability is one dimension of that quality.

iii) Respect for persons. It might appear paradoxical to say that an abstract de dicto desire shows respect, but consider its implications: the agent treats each individual’s claims as morally weighty independently of her personal feelings toward them. In returning the wallet, Louisa treats its unknown owner as a person with legitimate claims, not as a mere occasion for the exercise of warm sympathy. The duty motive thus embodies an equal respect that certain partial motives do not guarantee.

5. Replies to the alienation objection

Objection 1: The dutiful agent takes an impersonal property, rightness, as her end; therefore she fetishises that property and fails to care about the underlying goods.

Reply: Fetishism would indeed be objectionable. But as argued above, the enlightened duty motive is conceptually impossible without caring, in the appropriate rational manner, about the underlying considerations. Wanting to succeed at rightness is wanting to succeed at the package of concrete goods that rightness summarises. To call this a fetish is roughly like accusing a mathematician of fetishising truth because she cares about getting the correct result: the “fetish” is just the object of normative success.

Objection 2: Acting from duty is cold or inhuman; a morally ideal agent would act from love, compassion or friendship.

Reply: Even if additional motives could enhance moral beauty, it doesn’t follow that their absence removes moral worth. Musical virtuosity may be enhanced by expressive flair, but technically flawless playing is still valuable. Similarly, compassion may enrich an action’s moral aesthetic, yet principled duty renders it fully worthy in the dimension of moral rightness. Moreover, an exclusive commitment to duty might be practically necessary for certain agents or in certain contexts—e.g., when emotional involvement would cloud judgment, as in a surgeon’s triage decisions.

Objection 3: The agent who helps me solely out of duty doesn’t value me as an individual, so I am entitled to feel aggrieved.

Reply: There are two senses of “valuing me.” One (personal affection) is indeed absent if the agent is a stranger. The other (moral respect) is fully present. While we understandably crave the warmth of affection, morality cannot require each person to cultivate affection for all seven billion others. What it reasonably demands is that everyone be treated with basic respect, and the duty motive secures that. Indeed, strangers often prefer institutionalised, duty-based treatment (in hospitals, courts, police-stations) to the vagaries of personal feeling.

6. Is exclusive reliance on duty ever wrong?

Granting that duty can suffice for worth, we might still worry about agents who systematically suppress non-moral motives. Two clarifications help. First, sufficiency is not ideality: an action can be good enough for praise without being the best possible. Second, moral worth is not the only evaluative dimension; emotional richness, spontaneity, and other virtues matter too. A life lived only under the stern banner of duty may be admirably moral yet aesthetically impoverished. But what the alienation objection tried to show is that duty is never enough, even for basic moral worth. That stronger claim fails.

7. Hybrid motivation as the human norm

Although my argument defends duty’s sufficiency, it is compatible with (and indeed supports) the view that most agents should cultivate a plurality of motives. Hybrid motivation—where concrete concern and principled duty reinforce each other—provides the robustness of duty and the affective engagement of sympathy. Kant himself allowed that “inclinations” congruent with duty can coexist with the moral law, provided they do not usurp the law’s authority.

8. Difficult test cases: history-sculpting saint and disenchanted altruist

To pressure the account, imagine two further scenarios.

Case 1: The History-Sculpting Saint. Oriana is motivated solely by the thought of moral rightness. She has trained herself in impartial beneficence and would, if told that rightness required morally repugnant acts, not hesitate. Is she praiseworthy? No, because her dedication is subservient to whatever she takes to be right, and she may be mistaken. Factual error here drains moral worth. This reveals that enlightened duty must include epistemic responsibility: critical reflection and openness to moral reasons.

Case 2: The Disenchanted Altruist. Quentin was once buoyed by empathy, but severe compassion fatigue has left him emotionally numb. Still, his practical identity as a moral agent survives: he continues to volunteer at the hospice because it is right. We are inclined to praise him, perhaps even more because the work is now effortful. This shows that in some contexts, duty not only suffices but heroically sustains moral behaviour when other motives fail.

9. The Kantian lineage rehabilitated

Kant’s notorious claim that “only actions done from duty have moral worth” is often caricatured. Kant meant moral worth in the narrow sense of a merit that counts toward desert of happiness (his doctrine of the Highest Good). He did not deny that actions from inclination can be good or even necessary for human flourishing; rather he insisted that their goodness remains contingent on luck, whereas duty alone expresses the good will unconditionally. Modern defenders need not adopt this full Kantian apparatus but can recognise a related insight: praise attaches to how an agent governs herself, not merely to the pleasant by-products of that self-governance.

10. Conclusion

The question was whether acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can be enough for morally worthy conduct. I have argued that it can. The key is to distinguish between an empty, fetishistic version of the de dicto desire and an enlightened version woven through with an agent’s competent appreciation of first-order moral reasons. When so understood, the duty motive (a) incorporates concrete moral considerations, (b) manifests autonomous self-governance, (c) yields counterfactual reliability, and (d) expresses equal respect for persons. These features together explain why dutiful action commands praise. Although the richest moral lives will add sympathy, love and other affectionate motives, duty supplies an indispensable backbone. Far from alienating us from morality’s true point, a principled commitment to doing what is right is one of the clearest ways human beings display our distinct capacity for moral agency.

Can Acting from Duty Alone Be Morally Worthy?  
A Defence of the De Dicto Motive

1. Introduction  

Imagine Clara: seeing a drowning stranger, she dives in because she wants—quite simply—“to do what morality requires.” She is not moved by sympathy, fraternity, or any other sentiment that picks out the victim in a “first‐personal” or “object‐directed” way. Her sole motive is the abstract thought, “This is the right thing to do.” Many philosophers claim that Clara’s motive is morally deficient. Because she does not respond to “the concrete considerations that make the act right” (the stranger’s peril, the value of a human life, etc.), her rescue is allegedly less admirable than the identical act done out of compassion. Kant’s name is often invoked here: even if one grants that Kant himself appreciated sympathy, the “fetishism” objection (Williams 1981; Stocker 1976) contends that an agent who cares only about “duty” has missed what morality is really about.

Is that verdict compelling? I shall argue that it is not. A sole desire to do the morally right thing can—under certain conditions—suffice for moral worth. Section 2 clarifies the dialectic and the relevant notion of moral worth. Section 3 reconstructs three influential objections: (a) the Missing Reasons Objection, (b) the Alienation Objection, and (c) the Practical Deficiency Objection. Section 4 advances a positive account: the De Dicto Sufficiency Thesis. Roughly, acting from the de dicto desire to do what is right is morally worthy when the agent is (i) reliably competent at identifying right‐making features, (ii) guided by respect for the moral law understood as the system of such features, and (iii) disposed to integrate first‐order motives whenever they do not compete with duty. Section 5 replies to the three objections. Section 6 concludes by reassessing why the fetishism complaint is psychologically tempting yet philosophically unsound.

Throughout I treat “acting solely from duty” as meaning that, at choice time, no other motive plays a non‐derivative explanatory role. The question, then, is whether such agency can be worthy even when caring motives are absent, not merely overridden.

2. Moral Worth and Motives: Preliminary Clarifications  

Kant’s own criterion is well known: an action possesses moral worth if and only if it is done “from duty,” where that means acting “from respect for the moral law” rather than from inclination (G 4:399). Contemporary writers refine the picture by distinguishing two kinds of motivation:

• De re moral desire: wanting, of some concrete aspect ϕ of a situation, that ϕ be promoted because one sees ϕ as morally significant (desiring, say, that a person be saved because her life is valuable).  
• De dicto moral desire: wanting that “the morally right thing” be done, without yet considering which concrete aspect of the case grounds its rightness.

The challenge is whether the second type, all by itself, can ground moral worth.

“Worth” here is more demanding than mere permissibility. A merely permissible act might conform to duty accidentally; what we want is a ground of praise—a consideration that makes the agent herself admirable. To isolate that notion, I adopt two working assumptions.

A1. The Rightness Condition: For moral worth the act must in fact be right (we can set aside cases of justified error).  
A2. The Reason‐Responsiveness Condition: The agent’s motive must non‐accidentally track the right‐making reasons.

Accepting A2 is compatible with denying that the agent must explicitly represent those right‐making reasons; nevertheless her motivational system must be appropriately sensitive to them.

3. Three Objections to De Dicto Sufficiency  

3.1 The Missing Reasons Objection  
Barbara Herman (1993) argues that moral worth requires “reasons‐proper” motivation: the agent must be moved by the very considerations that justify the act, otherwise her behavior manifests a form of practical irrationality. If Clara ignores the drowning person’s life and instead focuses on an abstraction—“rightness”—she is not really responsive to the drowning. She is lucky that morality says “rescue!”; had morality said “let him drown,” she would do so, because what she tracks is rightness per se, not value‐laden facts.

3.2 The Alienation Objection  
Williams and Stocker claim that pure duty motivation alienates agents from their own projects and relationships. If I help my friend because “it is my duty as a friend” rather than because I care about him, the friendship commodity has vanished. Morality, they argue, is about people and goods, not about law worship; hence the purely dutiful agent seems estranged.

3.3 The Practical Deficiency Objection  
Finally, critics contend that de dicto motivation is practically inferior. Sympathy, love, and beneficence are faster, more reliable, more context‐attentive. The abstraction‐loving agent will hesitate calculating what “duty” requires, whereas compassion leaps to the rescue. Therefore, a purely dutiful motive is both psychologically and normatively second‐best.

These objections share a core assumption: a de dicto desire, being content‐poor, cannot on its own meet A2; it springs from an impoverished moral psychology that either disregards or downplays the value‐based reasons for right action.

4. The De Dicto Sufficiency Thesis  

I think that assumption is mistaken. A de dicto desire, properly understood, encodes an implicit commitment to the entire class of right‐making properties. Acting solely from duty can thus instantiate A2 in virtue of the structure of practical reasoning rather than the surface content of the agent’s occurrent motives.

Let me formulate the thesis.

De Dicto Sufficiency Thesis (DDST):  
An action φ performed solely from the de dicto desire “to do what is morally right” possesses moral worth provided that:  
(i) the agent has an integrated practical capacity to detect and respond to right‐making considerations (Competence);  
(ii) the agent’s de dicto desire is grounded in a regulative practical attitude of respect for persons and the moral law (Respect), rather than fetishistic fascination;  
(iii) the agent would, ceteris paribus, cultivate and act from the relevant de re motives (e.g., compassion) where such motives harmonize with duty (Integration).

Conditions (i)–(iii) show why the abstract desire is neither blind nor alienated. Let me elaborate.

4.1 Competence  
Desire alone does not determine action; what matters is the agent’s deliberative faculty. A competent moral agent recognizes that “the right” supervenes on facts—people’s needs, violated promises, fair shares, etc. So when the de dicto agent asks “What does duty require here?” she does not appeal to an oracle; she investigates those very concrete facts. Her internal guidance system is the moral law; but the law itself is articulated in terms of those facts. Respect for “rightness” therefore embodies an inferential commitment to treat the welfare of the drowning person as decisive once recognized.

Think of a mathematician motivated by a love of truth. When she is BENT ON proving the theorem, her immediate motive is de dicto (“I want the true proof”), yet her pursuit necessarily relies on the contentful properties that make proofs sound. We do not scold her for failing to care about transitivity or the Archimedean property as such; we laud her orientation to truth, trusting that her competence supplies the rest. So too with morality.

4.2 Respect  
Kant famously holds that respect (Achtung) is not a mere feeling but an attitude arising from reason’s awareness of the moral law’s authority. Respect is directed both at the law and, mediately, at all rational agents as ends in themselves. Clara’s “I must rescue” is not high‐level utilitarian book‐keeping; it is reverence for a principle whose content centrally includes the value of human life.

Contrary to the fetishism charge, respect is not infatuation with an inert object (a rule, a badge of virtue); it is responsiveness to the authoritative claim that reason makes upon us. Such responsiveness involves a practical intention to uphold the dignity of persons. Therefore the motive “because it is right” is not vacuous: its affective tone is reverence for persons under the aspect of law.

4.3 Integration  
Condition (iii) secures that the pure duty motive is no enemy of natural sympathy. The desire to do what is right contains a secondary intention: to regulate, not eradicate, concrete motives. If empathy can coexist with duty, the agent welcomes it; but if it is absent (perhaps she is emotionally fatigued) the de dicto motive still moves her. This “backup function” is precisely what Kant had in mind when he praised the shopkeeper who is honest despite lacking beneficence: the moral worth does not lie in coldness but in steadfastness.

5. Replies to the Objections  

5.1 Answering the Missing Reasons Objection  
The critic says: de dicto desire ignores ϕ, the right‐making property. I reply: ignorance is nonessential. When the competent agent forms the intention “Do the right thing,” she activates a generative schema: search for ϕ! That search, if successful, yields a de re representation of ϕ which then enters into practical reasoning. Still, the original motivational “spark” remains de dicto. What matters for moral worth, however, is not whether that spark itself encodes ϕ but whether the overall motivational configuration is appropriately sensitive. Since Competence ensures such sensitivity, the objection lapses.

But suppose, arguendo, that the agent never makes ϕ salient at a conscious level. Imagine Clara acts instantly knowing “Someone is in mortal danger; morality says save them.” Here ϕ (the stranger’s welfare) was recognized albeit implicitly. Latitude exists about how fine‐grained the agent’s occurrent content must be; moral worth does not demand a philosopher’s treatise. Many good agents have only hazy awareness—“That would be cruel,” “This person needs help”—yet we praise them. The de dicto agent who acknowledges the structure “If someone is drowning, rescue” is still tracking the right‐making feature.

Williams worries that if morality’s dictates had been different, Clara would follow them. But that counterfactual is incoherent: morality just is the system of correct action‐guiding principles. Imagine a physicist who follows evidence; if the evidence were different, she would believe a false theory. That does not show she is insensitive to evidence. Rather, sensitivity means being disposed to conform beliefs to whatever the evidence supports, not to some other standard. Similarly, the dutiful agent’s “subservience” to morality is exactly what responsiveness to valid reasons entails.

5.2 Answering the Alienation Objection  
Helping a friend “only because it is right” admittedly sounds chilling. Yet the worry conflates motivational sufficiency with motivational exclusivity over the course of a friendship. DDST’s Integration clause underscores that a respectable duty motive does not crowd out affection; it merely ensures that help will be given even in its absence. Indeed, friendships sometimes require actions one does not feel like doing—listening to tedious stories, making hospital visits in the wee hours. Acting because it’s right can communicate depth of commitment: “I will be there even when affection falters.”

Moreover, the accusation of alienation presupposes that moral worth is partly a function of the phenomenology of warmth. That view is contestable. Suppose an introverted, emotionally blunted person, call him Sam, recognizes that his spouse needs consolation. Sam feels little sympathy due to chronic depression, yet he sits up all night comforting her because he judges it his duty. Few of us would brand Sam morally wanting. On the contrary, we often find greater praiseworthiness in effortful duty than in effortless affection—precisely because duty marks respect for the person as an end, independent of emotional contingencies.

Finally, the friendship case conflates doing the morally right thing with doing the distinctively friendly thing. Sometimes the best rationale for a friend‐directed act is general morality (keeping promises, respecting autonomy). Other times friendship supplies special reasons. De dicto motivation can encompass either domain, for it includes reasons derivative from social roles. What alienates is not attention to duty but treating one’s friend as a mere locus of duty satisfaction. Respect, by contrast, affirms her agency.

5.3 Answering the Practical Deficiency Objection  
De dicto motivation is said to be slower or less reliable than sympathy. Empirical evidence is mixed. Consider bystander experiments: people often fail to help not because they lack sympathy but because of diffusion of responsibility or normative uncertainty. Reminding subjects of moral norms (e.g., via a “be a Good Samaritan” cue) significantly increases helping, sometimes more than empathy primes do. Thus duty consciousness can be practically efficacious.

Furthermore, moral worth is a normative category, not a statistical one. Even if sympathy helped more often, each individual instance of dutiful action could still be worthy. Speed is not essential; what matters is rational governance. Suppose two rescuers arrive simultaneously. One jumps faster by a second due to panic‐driven sympathy, the other follows a beat later because she registered danger and moral necessity. Praiseworthiness does not automatically accrue to the quickest.

But what about errors? Won’t the de dicto agent sometimes misidentify duty because she lacks the heuristic guidance of sympathy? Perhaps; but the Competence condition demands more: the agent must possess a reliable capacity informed by moral principles and experience. That capacity can rival, and often correct, emotional heuristics. Stocker’s “moral schizophrenia” is thus avoidable; integration of emotion and principle is part of mature duty motivation.

6. Why the Fetishism Complaint Persists  

If the above is correct, why does “duty” still sound cold? I think two cognitive biases operate.

First, salience bias: we imagine caricatures—stiff‐lipped bureaucrats stamping “approved” on moral forms—rather than nuanced, respectful agents who happen not to feel strong emotions at the moment of action. The contrast class is often loaded: extreme de dicto versus richly affective de re. But real moral life is varied; sometimes affect leads, sometimes principle.

Second, mind‐reading error: from the outside we rarely know another’s motives. When someone says, “I did it because it was right,” we may suspect self‐advertisement masking indifference. This suspicion colours our intuitions. But that epistemic difficulty does not entail metaphysical impossibility: there can be genuine cases where that report is accurate and admirable.

The fetishism charge also conflates love of the law with idolatry. Yet respect for rational law is, on Kant’s view, respect for persons as lawmakers in a kingdom of ends. Calling that a “fetish” is like accusing a judge of fetishism for revering constitutional justice. The law, rightly understood, is the institutional embodiment of citizens’ rights and interests; likewise, morality is the rational system protecting persons’ dignity. Caring about it is caring about them, albeit through a universalist lens.

7. Conclusion  

We can now answer the guiding questions.

(1) Can acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right suffice for moral worth?  
Yes. Provided the agent meets the Competence, Respect, and Integration conditions, her pure duty motive is both reason‐responsive and person‐affirming. The abstraction, far from eclipsing concrete values, is the framework that unifies them.

(2) What makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?  
Three interconnected features:  
a. Rational Fidelity: The agent exemplifies the capacity to let correct reason rule desire—a core Kantian virtue.  
b. Stability: Because de dicto motivation does not rely on fluctuating feelings, it ensures dependable right action.  
c. Respectful Recognition: Acting from duty expresses recognition of others’ moral status; it treats them as ends, not as stimuli of one’s affections.

Praiseworthiness, then, is grounded in a morally significant form of autonomy: subordinating self‐interest and contingent emotion to the authority of universal reason. This does not demean sympathy; it safeguards morality when sympathy is silent or partial. Far from being a fetish, the dutiful motive is a rational bulwark securing justice and respect for persons.

The anxiety that “duty alone” is insufficient thus stems from an impoverished picture of what respect for morality involves. Once we appreciate the rich rational structure encoded in a de dicto moral commitment, the supposed gap between right‐making reasons and abstract duty collapses. To do the right thing because it is right is, when done well, to stand in precisely the admirable relation to the reasons that make it right.

1. Introduction  

Since Kant’s Groundwork, the thought that an act acquires a distinctive moral worth when it is done ‘from duty’ rather than from inclination has been both influential and controversial. Contemporary critics have refined Kant’s original thought into the claim that acting from the motive of duty is acting from a de dicto desire: one’s ultimate aim is simply “to do what is morally right,” with no further specification of which concrete features of the situation make the act right. According to these critics—often inspired by Michael Stocker’s “The Schizophrenia of Modern Ethical Theories,” Thomas Nagel’s “Moral Luck,” and Nomy Arpaly’s work on moral worth—such de dicto motivation fails to confer praiseworthiness. The dutiful agent allegedly “fetishizes” morality itself, caring about a formal property rather than about what really matters (the sufferings, needs, or rights of concrete beings), and is therefore alienated from values.  

In what follows I defend a conditional affirmative answer to the guiding question: yes, acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth, provided that (i) the de dicto desire is suitably informed—i.e., it is guided by reliable moral understanding of why certain acts are right—and (ii) the agent’s attitude toward the right does not exclude but instead implicitly contains the relevant value‐regarding concerns. I call this view “thick formalism.” I argue that thick formalism rebuts the fetishism objection, accommodates the phenomenology of deliberation, and explains why such action merits praise: the de dicto motive manifests the agent’s commitment to the authoritative structure of moral reasons, and that commitment is itself a valuable expression of respect for persons.  

2. Clarifying the Three Key Notions  

Before defending this thesis, we must disambiguate three closely related but distinct notions:  

A. Doing what is right. This is the rightness of the act itself. A racist who by accident hands a lost child back to her parent does the right thing, but no one is inclined to praise him.  

B. Acting “from duty” in the Kantian sense. Kant means that the agent’s maxim is fixed by practical recognition of the moral law as such; the agent acts out of reverence for that law.  

C. Moral worth or praiseworthiness. An act has moral worth when the agent merits esteem for her underlying motivation. This is the space in which the current debate occurs.  

The question is not whether the motive of duty suffices for rightness (it obviously does not), but whether it suffices for moral worth—roughly, whether such motivation manifests a morally admirable quality of will.  

3. The Standard Objection: Fetishism and Alienation  

Critics run two connected lines:  

a. The fetishism charge (Smith 1994; Arpaly 2003): A de dicto desire to do what is right resembles a collector’s fetish for stamps—an affection for a property as such, divorced from what underlies the property. Just as the fetishist fails to appreciate the historical significance or aesthetic particularities of stamps, the dutiful agent supposedly fails to respond to what makes helping actually good: the beneficiary’s needs, dignity, etc.  

b. The alienation charge (Stocker, Wolf): A person who visits her friend in hospital only because “it is the right thing to do” betrays an objectionable moral coldness. Genuine friendship demands that one visit out of concern for the friend.  

Both objections rest on the thought that the de dicto desire crowds out, supplants, or fails to incorporate de re concern for particulars.  

4. A False Dilemma: De Dicto vs. De Re Desires  

Philosophers sometimes assume that motives divide neatly into de dicto (formal) and de re (substantive) desires. But the distinction is not exclusive; desires can be conceptually de dicto yet emotionally thick. Consider the following: I desire “to obey the law,” a formally de dicto desire. But if my understanding of the law includes the thought that it protects citizens’ equal standing and basic security, my desire is permeated with those substantive values. When I refrain from insider trading because “it would be illegal,” I need not be indifferent to fairness; indeed, the very reason I care about legality is that, under reflection, I regard the legal order as the institutional expression of fairness.  

Similarly, the morally conscientious agent might desire, “I shall do the morally right thing,” where what counts as morally right is conceptually tied, in her moral outlook, to others’ welfare, respect for autonomy, etc. Thus the fetishism objection misfires: it treats the de dicto desire as if it were informationally impoverished, whereas agents typically embed a wealth of content in the de dicto specification.  

5. Thick Formalism Explained  

Thick formalism combines two claims:  

1) Formal claim: The agent’s ultimate motivational target is the property of rightness—she wills to act as morality demands.  

2) Thick claim: Her practical representation of that property is not a thin, contentless placeholder but a thickly elaborated conception that already contains the relevant first‐order values.  

On this view, the motive of duty functions like a node in a semantic network: its content is partially fixed by its inferential connections to concrete considerations. To will “the right” while being indifferent to welfare or justice would be like claiming to chase water while refusing to be guided by any of its natural indicators (wetness, transparency, H2O structure). That is conceptually incoherent once one grasps what water is.  

6. Re‐examining the Hospital Visit  

Suppose Claire visits her hospitalized friend Jane. Compare two possible motivational structures:  

(i) Care‐based: Claire is moved by affectionate concern for Jane.  

(ii) Duty‐based (thin): Claire asks, “What does morality require?” concludes she ought to visit, and does so while remaining emotionally detached.  

(iii) Duty‐based (thick): Claire’s conscientious question, “What is morally right?” is answered by a view that friendship is a relationship of mutual concern. In motivating herself to do what is right, Claire is ipso facto motivated by Jane’s needs, because her grasp of the right includes that concrete ground.  

Case (ii) plausibly looks alienated; case (iii) does not. Yet both (ii) and (iii) are, in an abstract description, “motivated by the desire to do what is morally right.” Therefore, whether the motive of duty alienates depends on how the agent conceptualizes the right, not on the formal presence of a de dicto desire.  

7. The Epistemic Argument for Praiseworthiness  

Why think thick formalism confers moral worth? Consider the epistemic dimension of agency. Morality is complex; our ordinary motivations (friendship, compassion, patriotism) are sometimes unreliable guides: they can be partial, short‐sighted, or corrupted by implicit bias. A disposition to bring one’s first‐order motivations under the supervisory ideal of “doing the right thing” expresses epistemic humility: the agent acknowledges she might be mistaken and remains willing to revise.  

An analogous point applies in the epistemology of belief: a person who believes p because she possesses overwhelming evidence but is closed to counter‐evidence is epistemically inferior to one who believes p on evidence while also caring, in general, about believing what’s true. In the practical realm, caring about “doing what is right” functions as the regulative commitment that keeps first‐order feelings answerable to moral reasons. That commitment is, in itself, a virtue—call it conscientiousness.  

8. Kantian Backing without Kantian Excess  

Kant held that only actions from duty have moral worth and that inclination‐driven actions have none. Many contemporary Kantians concede Kant overstated the point; affection and sympathy can also confer moral worth when they reflect an agent’s reliable responsiveness to the morally relevant factors. Thick formalism need not resurrect Kant’s exclusivism. It contends merely that motive of duty is sufficient, not necessary, for praiseworthiness. This modest claim allows room for multiple laudable motives while preserving the distinctive value of principled commitment.  

9. Addressing Three Objections  

a. Redundancy Objection: If the de dicto desire already contains the de re elements, why not say the agent is in fact motivated by those de re desires? Reply: motivational layering matters. An agent can simultaneously care about her friend and adopt a standing commitment to act as moral reasons require. The latter is an architectonic disposition: it regulates and sustains the former over time, especially when immediate affection wanes or conflicts with other pulls. That higher‐order orientation is, itself, what thick formalism identifies.  

b. Over‐Intellectualization Objection: Ordinary virtuous agents rarely formulate explicit thoughts about “the morally right.” Does thick formalism impose an intellectualist standard? No. A de dicto desire need not be occurrent or linguistically articulated. It suffices that the agent is disposed, upon reflection, to endorse her action under the rightness description and to treat that description as normatively decisive. Many habitual virtues implicitly instantiate this disposition.  

c. Motive‐Crowding Objection: Introducing a duty motive crowds out spontaneous concern (Titmuss, Deci & Ryan). Evidence from motivational psychology shows that extrinsic regulators sometimes undermine intrinsic ones. But the phenomenon is context‐specific: crowding occurs when extrinsic incentives create controlling pressure. A de dicto duty motive, by contrast, can be internal, autonomy‐supportive, and integrated with intrinsic concern. Indeed, it can protect concern from weakness of will by turning it into a settled policy.  

10. The Second‐Personal Standpoint  

Stephen Darwall’s second‐personal ethics provides further grounding. To act out of the moral law is to be moved by reasons that one recognizes all persons can authoritatively address to one another. Respect for the moral law is thus respect for the equal authority of persons in the moral community. Acting from duty therefore manifests an attitude of recognition toward others’ standing: I do this not merely because I happen to like you, but because you have the authority to demand it of me. This posture is especially salient where personal affection is absent—e.g., treating strangers fairly, refusing to exploit adversaries. The moral worth of duty‐motivation derives from expressing this egalitarian respect.  

11. Particularism and the Challenge of Discernment  

Jonathan Dancy’s moral particularism posits that moral reasons are context‐dependent and irreducible to general laws. How, then, can an agent reliably instantiate the motive of duty without falling into rote rule‐worship? Thick formalism accommodates particularism by emphasizing discernment: the agent’s de dicto desire functions through sensitivity to the morally relevant features present in the situation. The agent’s slogan “do the right thing” involves a standing readiness to perceive those features correctly. Hence conscientiousness must be paired with practical wisdom. Where the latter is absent, the desire is poorly informed and fails to produce morally worthy action (even if the agent is blameless for ignorance, the act lacks positive worth).  

12. Praise, Value, and Desert  

Finally, what grounds the praise we give to dutiful agents? Two answers converge:  

(1) Value‐Manifestation: The dutiful act reveals the agent’s deep commitment to moral equality and respect. This commitment is intrinsically valuable and admirable.  

(2) Reliable Governance: Such commitment tends to foster an overall pattern of right action across diverse contexts, including those where first‐order sympathies falter. Because morality concerns how we should live with one another across a lifetime, we value dispositions that produce a reliable moral record.  

Note that praise is a distinct reactive attitude from liking or esteem for charm. We admire the dutiful agent’s quality of will even if she is less engaging at cocktail parties. This partly explains why praiseworthiness need not track warmth or intimacy.  

13. Conclusion  

The dispute over duty motivation often swings between two poles: either a cold, robotic formalism or an emotive particularism that suspects principle of moral OCD. Thick formalism offers a middle path. A de dicto desire to do what is morally right can, when epistemically informed and affectively integrated, suffice for moral worth. It is not a fetish but the reflective crystallization of concrete value‐regarding concerns under the regulative ideal of morality’s authority. Such dutiful action merits praise because it expresses conscientious respect for persons and provides the motivational architecture for stable responsiveness to moral reasons.  

Therefore, we need not choose between being principled and being caring: the best moral psychology shows that caring can be principled, and principle can be caring—in the deepest sense of caring enough to get things morally right.

Acting Solely from Duty: Can a De Dicto Motive Ground Moral Worth?  

1. Introduction  

When someone rescues a stranger from a burning building, we normally think the agent’s motivation matters to the deed’s moral worth. Was she moved by heartfelt concern for the victim’s suffering or by an abstract wish to “do the right thing”? A now‐familiar line of criticism—articulated by Stocker, Wolf, Railton, and others—holds that the second, purely dutiful kind of motivation is deficient. To act from a de dicto desire “to do what morality requires,” they say, is to exhibit moral fetishism or alienation, because the agent’s motivational focus hovers at an unworldly distance from the concrete values (relieving pain, promoting flourishing, honoring commitments) that constitute morality’s point.

This essay argues, to the contrary, that an agent can act solely from a de dicto duty motive and that, under certain conditions, such action can possess full moral worth. The claim is not that other sorts of motives—fellow‐feeling, love, gratitude—lack value, nor that they fail to enhance the worth of conduct when present. Instead the claim is a conditional one: an agent’s action can be praiseworthy even if her sole motive is the abstract desire to comply with morality. The argument proceeds in five stages.  

2. Clarifying the De Dicto/De Re Distinction  

A de dicto desire is content‐general: the agent wants “to do what morality requires,” whatever that turns out to be. A de re desire is content‐specific: the agent wants, for instance, to alleviate this orphan’s hunger or to keep that promise. Critics often assume that a de dicto motive is (a) motivationally thin and (b) explanatorily incomplete. If all I want is “to do my duty,” the feeling goes, I have not yet latched onto the particular features that render this action my duty. But this assumption moves too quickly. A de dicto desire to φ can be accompanied by, and even conceptually include, a cognitive representation of the property in virtue of which φ is required. One can will “to do what morality requires in virtue of considerations X, Y, Z” while still identifying one’s incentive as “the moral requirement.” The abstract form of the desire does not preclude practical sensitivity to the concrete.

Moreover, fetishism charges often conflate content with orientation. The mere fact that my motivational self‐description is “I am doing my duty” does not entail that I am blind, numb, or indifferent to the plight of the orphan; it only entails that the normative property of being mandatory is what gets me moving. I might still perceive, understand, and even emotionally register the child’s need; I simply do not act from the affective pull of that need but from respect for the requirement it grounds.

3. Why Think Duty Alone Is Insufficient?  

Three influential worries animate the insufficiency thesis.

a) The Concern‐Gap Worry: Morality centrally concerns the well‐being of persons, so a morally worthy agent should be moved by direct concern for that well‐being. An agent who acts merely to comply with an abstract requirement allegedly misses the moral point.

b) The Integrity Worry: Acting from duty alone is self‐alienating because it directs action through an imposed moral law rather than through the agent’s own evaluative identity.

c) The Deliberative Deficiency Worry: De dicto motivation is too fragile or empty to guide correct action in new contexts, because it does not itself embody the values that justify particular duties.

While powerful, each worry overstates its case. Consider them in turn.

4. Rescuing the Dutiful Agent  

a) Meeting the Concern‐Gap.  

Suppose Anna donates money to famine relief solely because she recognizes a duty to aid those in dire need. She feels no sympathy; she is simply resolved to “do what morality requires.” Does her motive reveal indifference to suffering? Not necessarily. The absence of sympathetic feeling as a motivating state does not equal the absence of sympathetic cognition or appraisal. We can distinguish two senses of “concern”:

• Affective concern: being emotionally moved by another’s plight.  
• Normative concern: acknowledging the plight as a morally relevant reason for action.

Acting from duty presupposes normative concern, because the very recognition that “morality requires helping” involves the judgment that the suffering is morally weighty. True, Anna does not feel the pull of compassion, but she does grasp the moral force of the need. The ideal moral agent may integrate both kinds of concern, yet normative concern alone can secure moral worth, because morality’s authority is fundamentally normative, not affective.

Kant famously defends a cognate point: respect for the moral law expresses recognition of persons as ends in themselves. Kant’s shopkeeper, who gives the correct change from duty, is not oblivious to the customer’s claims; he honors them via the conceptually mediated form of duty. One may contest Kant’s broader system, but the basic thought registers: to treat morality’s requirement as decisive is to treat the practical considerations that ground that requirement as authoritative, albeit via an inferential route.

b) Preserving Integrity.  

Integrity, critics argue, requires acting from commitments that are internally integrated with one’s character rather than imposed by an external, impersonal law. Yet nothing in the structure of a de dicto motive bars integration. An individual can adopt the stance “I live by duty” as a core self‐conception, freely endorsed upon reflection, woven into her narrative identity. Far from alienating her, duty furnishes a unifying principle that expresses her deepest evaluative stance: that morality’s demands are supreme. If authenticity means loyalty to one’s rationally chosen values, the dutiful agent can be fully authentic.

c) Patching the Deliberative Deficiency.  

De dicto motivation does not substitute for moral judgment; it presupposes it. To act “because it is my duty” still requires determining what duty demands. Thus the dutiful agent must engage with concrete facts and reasons. Critics sometimes imagine a mechanical moralist who, having once memorized a set of rules, follows them blindly. That depiction targets intellectual deficiency, not motivational form. A reflective duty‐motive can coexist with, and indeed support, the intellectual diligence needed for correct moral deliberation.

5. Positive Grounds for the Sufficiency of Duty  

(i) Universal Justification.  

One appealing feature of a duty‐motive is its impartiality. Sympathy and fellow‐feeling track the vagaries of proximity, likeness, or emotional salience, whereas duty tracks reasons that apply equally to all persons. When sympathy is absent—owing to fatigue, bias, or unfamiliarity—respect for duty can still move the agent. The Kantian can thus argue that a de dicto motive is uniquely poised to secure reliable compliance with universal moral norms.

(ii) Recognition of Authority.  

Morality purports to be authoritative. Acting from duty manifests acknowledgment of that authority as such. To treat morality as decisive because it is morality is to honor its systemic normative status. Other motives may coincide with moral reasons, yet they do not track the property of being morally required. Imagine Maya who saves a drowning child purely for the thrill of heroism. Her act aligns with duty yet reveals no sensitivity to moral authority. If two agents perform the same outward deed, the one who acts from duty better exemplifies the fitting response to the normative status of moral requirements.

(iii) Self‐Regulating Commitment.  

A de dicto motive is self‐regulating: it supplies the agent with an all‐purpose practical commitment that can guide behavior across diverse contexts, including those where direct affective concern is impossible (e.g., compliance with duties of justice toward distant strangers, procedural fairness in institutions, or observing moral constraints in emotionally bland situations). Such a motive forestalls partiality and akrasia by providing a standing resolution.

6. Conditions for Worthiness  

Conceding that duty can suffice does not mean every duty‐oriented act is praiseworthy. Several conditions must hold.

1. Epistemic Responsibility: The agent’s belief about what duty requires must be reasonable. Ignorant or self‐serving moralistic zeal is not morally worthy.  

2. Non‐Derivative Motivation: The agent must be moved by duty itself, not by self‐interest cleverly packaged as duty (e.g., social praise).  

3. Effective Agency: The action must successfully realize, or attempt in good faith to realize, what duty actually requires.  

4. Stability: The duty motive should be robust across situations; otherwise it looks more like a whim than a principled commitment.

When these conditions are met, acting solely from duty can have full moral worth.

7. Answering the Fetishism Charge  

The fetishism charge likens the dutiful agent to someone obsessed with a trinket’s formal property rather than its intrinsic value. But the analogy misfires. A fetishist attributes non‐instrumental value to an item without grounds. By contrast, the de dicto moralist attributes authority to moral requirements precisely because they are grounded in objective normative reasons. She responds to the right‐making features—only she does so through the lens “those features make the action morally required, and that requirement is what moves me.” There is no irrational fixation here, only a principled deference to moral normativity.

Furthermore, critics overlook phenomenological variation. Many everyday moral agents cite duty to justify their conduct—parents who say, “I help because it is my responsibility,” jurors who deliberate “because it is my civic duty,” officials who refuse bribes “because it would be wrong.” We neither doubt their moral worth nor sense alienation. Social life routinely treats the duty‐motive as honorable.

8. The Role of Supplementary Motives  

Although duty can suffice, we should resist the temptation to deem it ideal in isolation. Human moral psychology is richer than the thin Kantian kernel. Compassion, love, gratitude, and solidarity often reinforce duty and imbue action with warmth. From the standpoint of value, a mixed motive profile may be superlative: it unites respect for moral authority with attunement to the goods that ground that authority. Still, this does not negate the sufficiency thesis; it merely adds a thesis about comparative excellence.

9. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Without affective concern, duty‐based action lacks motivational depth and will eventually erode.

Reply: Historical examples rebut this: reformers who, absent personal sympathy for every distant victim, persevered out of principle; whistleblowers who, devoid of warm feelings for their organizations, nonetheless upheld fairness. Principle can sustain resolve precisely because it is not hostage to fluctuating emotions.

Objection 2: Pure duty breeds moralism and judgmentalism.

Reply: Moralism stems not from respecting duty but from arrogance and lack of humility. One can regard duty as supreme while acknowledging fallibility, cultivating empathy, and refraining from hasty condemnation.

Objection 3: Kant’s own examples (the sympathetic philanthropist vs. the melancholic benefactor) show that duty acts possess less moral worth when sympathetic feeling is present.

Reply: The Kantian claim is nuanced: the philanthropist who acts solely from inclination, absent duty, exhibits contingent virtue; the one who acts from duty displays moral worth. The point is not that additional sympathetic motives reduce worth, but that duty provides the decisive mark. Our sufficiency thesis is consistent: adding sympathy may enrich honor, yet duty alone suffices.

10. Conclusion  

The moral landscape includes agents whose hearts overflow with benevolence and those whose emotions are muted but whose rational resolve is steadfast. Philosophical accounts of moral worth must accommodate both if they aim to reflect the diversity of virtuous agency. The insufficiency thesis unduly narrows that landscape by insisting that only de re, affect‐laden motives confer full credit. A more capacious view recognizes that acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can indeed be morally worthy, provided the agent’s respect for duty is epistemically responsible, non‐derivative, effective, and stable. Such action honors the authority of morality, secures impartiality, and provides a reliable basis for principled conduct amid the vicissitudes of human emotion.

If moral action is ultimately about treating persons and values as they ought to be treated, then responding to the fact “this is morally required” captures morality’s core demand: to let the claim of right decide. Far from signaling alienation, the duty motive testifies to an agent’s deep acknowledgment of the moral dimension of human life—a dimension that rightly commands our allegiance even when our sentiments fall silent. That acknowledgment, in itself, is worthy of praise.

Acting Solely from Duty: Is Abstract Moral Motivation Sufficient for Moral Worth?

1. Introduction: the Shape of the Dispute  
Can a person deserve moral praise when the only thing that moves her is the thought “this is the morally right thing to do”? Or must praiseworthy action be grounded in affection, compassion, special concern, or some other “concrete” motive that explains why the act is right? For more than two centuries the debate has been framed by a caricatured clash between Kant and his critics. Kant is taken to insist that the sole motive with genuine moral worth is respect for the moral law, a pure, de dicto desire to do “whatever morality demands.” Starting with Schiller’s famous quip—“Gladly I serve my friends, but, alas, I do it with pleasure; therefore I am not virtuous”—opponents have argued that acting from duty alone smacks of cold rigorism, fetishistic attachment to an abstraction, or alienation from the very values (alleviating suffering, promoting flourishing, honoring friendship) that make actions morally right.  

In contemporary debates this worry has been refined. A de dicto desire to φ because it is right is said to lack *transparency* to the right-making features of φ-ing. The person who gives to famine relief solely because it is right does not seem responsive to the suffering of the hungry; she may just as happily fund a pointless project if she were falsely told that morality required it. Therefore, many philosophers infer, the bare motive of duty cannot by itself be sufficient for moral worth.  

I will defend the opposite thesis. Acting from a purely de dicto motive of duty can, under the right conditions, suffice for morally worthy conduct. I shall argue:  
(1) The desire to do what is right can be intrinsically and appropriately responsive to the very values alleged to be missing.  
(2) Even when it operates abstractly, the motive of duty expresses a distinctive form of good will—commitment to the authority of moral reasons—which is itself worthy of praise.  
(3) The standard objections from fetishism and alienation rest on conflating two senses of “abstractness” and on a mistaken picture of how second-order motives guide first-order choice.  

After clarifying the relevant concepts (§2), I examine the leading objections (§3). I then offer a positive account of why abstract respect for rightness has moral worth (§4), explain why that account survives the main criticisms (§5), and conclude with some implications (§6).

2. Conceptual Clarifications  
2.1 De dicto and de re moral motivation  
A *de dicto* moral desire has the content “to perform whatever act is morally required”; its propositional object is picked out under the description *the morally right act*. By contrast, a de re moral desire aims directly at the right-making features of a token act—say, relieving Mary’s distress—without deploying the concept of rightness. An agent moved solely by duty in the de dicto sense might say, “I have no particular concern for Mary; I help her because helping her is what morality demands.”  

2.2 Moral rightness, moral worth, praiseworthiness  
An action is *morally right* if it satisfies the correct moral standard. It possesses *moral worth* if the agent’s motive qualifies her for moral credit. Moral worth therefore turns on the quality of will that the action expresses. *Praiseworthiness* is the interpersonal recognition appropriately conferred upon an agent whose action has moral worth. Our question is whether the quality of will embodied in a purely de dicto motive can supply that worth.

3. The Case against Pure Duty Motivation  
3.1 The fetishism charge  
The fetishism objection, pressed by Michael Smith and others, claims that desiring an act *because it is right* treats rightness as a “fetish property” unrelated to the substantive values that make an act right. A fetishist about high-heeled shoes finds them alluring regardless of context; analogously, a moral fetishist finds “rightness” alluring independently of the suffering relieved or respect shown.  

3.2 The alienation charge  
Bernard Williams and Michael Stocker stress that morality centrally concerns our relations with concrete persons and projects. The agent who helps a friend merely out of duty, they say, is alienated from the friendship itself. She fails to relate to her friend *as a friend* and so betrays the spirit of morality even while complying with its letter.  

3.3 Epistemic and reliability worries  
Finally, critics note that a de dicto desire to do what is right is dangerously dependent on the agent’s beliefs about what is right. If those beliefs are mistaken, the motive leads astray. By contrast, an agent who sees and responds to the concrete reasons (Mary’s pain) is more reliably connected to the true right-makers.

Together these worries seem to show that duty motivation is neither adequately sensitive to moral reasons nor suitably non-accidental: when it leads to right action it does so by luck, not by properly appreciating the relevant values.

4. A Positive Account of the Moral Worth of Duty Motivation  
4.1 Rightness is not an inert property  
Begin with a simple but crucial point: moral rightness is not a morally empty property. To believe that an act is right is (under minimally cognitivist assumptions) to believe that the act is supported by decisive moral reasons—reasons grounded in others’ welfare, autonomy, desert, promises, or the like. The concept *morally right* is a summary term that encodes such reasons rather than bypassing them.  

In that respect, the person who is moved by the thought that φ-ing is right is ipso facto moved by whatever considerations make φ-ing right, though she cites them under a higher-order description. Her motivation therefore need not be blind any more than a scientist’s aim “to believe what is true” is blind to the evidence. The scientist need not list every fact about DNA replication to be guided by truth; analogously, the dutiful agent need not rehearse every fact about Mary’s distress to be guided by rightness.

4.2 The value of commitment to moral authority  
What, then, makes the abstract motive itself praiseworthy? I propose the following condition:  

(Authority Condition) An action has moral worth when it is performed from the settled disposition to treat objective moral reasons as authoritative over one’s conduct.  

A de dicto desire to do what is right, when stable and sincerely held, just is that disposition. It reveals the agent’s fundamental commitment to be governed by morality. Such commitment is commendable because (a) it embodies respect for persons (since morality’s central content is the equal status of persons), (b) it renders the agent reliably responsive to future moral reasons, and (c) it involves self-regulation by practical reason rather than caprice or inclination.  

This Kantian-inflected account does not denigrate sympathy or friendship; it simply locates the core moral worth of an action in the agent’s readiness to let moral reasons decide. If those moral reasons include friendship’s claims, the agent motivated by duty will treat them as decisive. Far from being alienated, she upholds them on principle.

4.3 A working example  
Suppose Ana, exhausted after work, passes a pond in winter and sees a child floundering. She feels no flicker of fellow-feeling; instead, her immediate thought is: “It is morally required that I save the child.” Without hesitation she wades in. According to the critics, Ana lacks moral worth—she is a cold rationalist. But Ana’s quick inference that morality requires saving the child *just is* an inference that the child’s life is important and that she can help at small cost. Her respect for moral rightness is a cognitive shortcut that encodes the concrete values the critics prize. Praising Ana for her commitment to act on those values is entirely appropriate.

5. Replies to the Objections  
5.1 Answering Fetishism  
The fetishism charge mistakes the nature of the property “being morally right.” Fetishes are non-normative properties whose value is projected onto them. But rightness is already a normative property: to judge x right is to recognize that x ought to be done. Treating rightness as decisive is no more fetishistic than treating evidence as decisive in science. The concern conflates *content neutrality* (the fact that the same description picks out many acts) with *reason neutrality*. Respecting rightness is not indifferent to reasons; it is precisely to classify reasons as decisive.  

Moreover, the de dicto motive enjoys a generality virtue. Because it is not tied to specific right-making features, it is poised to respond appropriately across varied contexts, including ones the agent has not yet imagined. An exclusive de re motive—say, compassion—can misfire when compassion is morally inappropriate (e.g., showing favoritism in a hiring decision). Abstract duty motivation avoids that parochialism.

5.2 Answering Alienation  
Williams worries that duty-bound agents interact with friends “at arm’s length.” Yet his own cases show that what alienates is not the presence of duty motivation but the absence of non-instrumental concern. My thesis is one of sufficiency, not necessity. Other motives can, and often should, be present. The dutiful agent can say to her friend, “I visited because I care about you *and* because I owe it to you.” When those additional motives are absent—as in Ana’s rescue—alienation does not follow automatically. Morality is partly about minimal decency toward all, not only intimacy with some. Ana owes the drowning child assistance despite lacking personal concern; that is not alienation but recognition of the child’s independent moral standing.

5.3 Reliability and epistemic access  
True: de dicto motivation is mediated by beliefs about what morality requires, and those beliefs can err. But identical vulnerability afflicts de re motives. Compassion can be misdirected; loyalty can be corrupt. What matters for moral worth is the quality of the agent’s practical reasoning: Does she take care to inform herself about the facts?
