Does she deliberate honestly? A conscientious desire to do what is right normally includes such epistemic diligence. When it does, de dicto motivation is no less reliable than its rivals. Indeed, by aiming at *rightness itself* rather than any single substantive value, it encourages agents to correct for bias when different values conflict.

6. Implications and Qualifications  
6.1 Sufficiency, not supremacy  
Granting sufficiency does not entail that duty must always be the sole motive, nor that actions from sympathy lack moral worth. Mixed motives are common and often ideal. The thesis defended is that the motive of duty, operating in isolation, can be *enough* for moral worth; it need not be supplemented to rescue the agent from moral failure.

6.2 The role of difficulty and moral strength  
Kant famously thought that actions contrary to inclination display greater worth. I take no stand on whether struggle heightens praise. The account offered locates worth in the authoritative structure of the agent’s will, not in the phenomenology of effort. An effortless but principled rescue may be as praiseworthy as a wrenching one. What matters is that the agent’s action flows from sincere allegiance to moral reasons.

6.3 Virtue ethics and the wider landscape  
Virtue ethicists might object that I have replaced fetishism with formalism: the “virtue” of respect for rightness is too thin to ground a flourishing moral character. Yet my claim is narrower. Character includes many concrete virtues, but at its core lies a meta-virtue—commitment to moral reasons as such. That commitment can coexist with, and indeed sustain, the richer emotional palette celebrated by virtue ethics.

7. Conclusion  
The moral worth of an action depends on the quality of will that produces it. A settled, sincere disposition to act on whatever reasons morality supplies exhibits precisely the quality we seek: principled respect for persons, for fairness, and for the common good. This disposition can be perfectly well captured by a de dicto desire to do what is morally right. Far from being a fetish, such a desire is an efficient cognitive portal to the manifold concrete values that make actions right. When an agent acts solely from that motive, she demonstrates reliability, impartiality, and allegiance to the authority of moral reasons. Those are traits eminently deserving of praise.  

Therefore, the charge that duty-bound agents cannot merit moral credit fails. While acting for duty’s sake is not the only route to praiseworthy conduct, it is a genuine and sufficient one. Recognizing this fact allows us to appreciate a broader range of morally admirable agents: not only the warm-hearted altruist but also the steadfast moralist whose abstract devotion to rightness moves her, without hesitation, to do what must be done.

Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice for moral worth? What, if anything, is admirable about an agent who is moved only by the abstract thought that “this is the right thing to do,” and not by the concrete considerations—another’s welfare, aesthetic value, promises previously made, and so on—that explain why the act is right?  

This question lies at the intersection of moral psychology and normative theory.  A negative answer has been defended by Michael Stocker, Bernard Williams, Virginia Held, Nomy Arpaly, and Susan Wolf, among many others.  They brand the agent who is motivated simply by the category “the morally right” as an alienated, fetishistic, or even slightly chilling figure—someone who loves the Moral Law but not the people or goods that the law is meant to protect.  By contrast, Kantians typically insist that acting “from duty” is not merely sufficient but paradigmatic for full moral worth.  Yet even contemporary Kantians often supplement the bare desire to do right with further attitudes—respect for rational nature, or recognition of the equal authority of all persons—precisely to avoid the charge of fetishism.  

My thesis is intermediate between the extremes.  A purely de dicto desire “to do the right thing” can, in favorable circumstances, be sufficient for moral worth.  However, its capacity to confer moral worth depends on the *way* it is psychologically and epistemically housed: the desire must (1) manifest a reliable responsiveness to the right-making features of actions, (2) be guided by an agent’s proper grasp of what makes acts right, and (3) be expressive of the agent’s practical identity rather than an alien, compulsive force.  When these three conditions are met, duty-centered motivation is not fetishistic but an admirably principled orientation—a devotion to the *normative authority* of morality itself.  I will defend this position in four steps.  First, I clarify the terms of the debate; second, I expose weaknesses in the standard anti‐de‐dicto arguments; third, I articulate a positive account of why duty alone can constitute moral worth; and fourth, I respond to lingering worries about emotional chilliness and relational alienation.

1. Clarifying the Terrain: Two Senses of “De Dicto Desire”  
Philosophers often distinguish between de dicto and de re desire.  A de re desire picks out its object under a particular description that is crucial for the desire’s motivational power.  For instance, I want *that child* (de re) to be safe; it matters to me that it is this specific child, not merely an instantiation of “a child.”  By contrast, a de dicto desire is satisfied whenever *whatever* counts as “the morally right act” is performed.  Its motivational content is exhausted by the general description “the right.”  

Even within the de dicto category, however, we can separate thin and thick variants.  (i) *Thin de dicto duty*: I desire to do what is morally required, full stop, with no substantive representation of why the required act has its status.  (ii) *Reason‐constituted de dicto duty*: I desire to comply with morality because I recognize it as the system of reasons grounded in other people’s autonomy, welfare, desert, etc.  Though the desire remains formally directed at “morality,” it is mediated by an appreciation—albeit perhaps not an affectively laden one—of the right‐making considerations.  Most critics target the *thin* conception; yet most real‐life “duty‐first” agents, not to mention philosophical Kantians, operate with the *reason‐constituted* conception.  Throughout what follows I will use “de dicto desire” to refer to the second, richer species unless I explicitly state otherwise.

2. Problems with the Standard Critique  

2.1. The Fetishism Worry  
The fetishism charge, first prominent in Stocker’s famous “Emotions and the Ethical Life,” claims that an agent who visits her friend in the hospital solely because “it is morally required” embodies a defective moral consciousness.  She seems incapable of caring about the friend *as such*; she is fixated on the *status* of her action (right vs. wrong).  Yet fetishism is not guaranteed merely by abstract content.  Suppose Julia, reading Kant, reflects, “My friend is a free rational being; respect for rational agency obligates me to visit him.”  Her ensuing visit is still prompted by de dicto duty—“the Categorical Imperative demands it”—but the notion of rational agency is hardly an empty label; it incorporates precisely the value that explains why neglect would wrong the friend.  Julia’s concern is mediated by a principled lens, but not thereby fetishistic.  The allegation of fetishism often slides illicitly from “the motive is abstract” to “the motive ignores substance.”  Yet the former does not entail the latter.

2.2. The Alienation Worry  
Williams and Wolf press a related objection: the duty‐motivated agent is alienated from her own projects and relationships, treating them as mere arenas for moral self‐display.  Again, consider two hospital visits.  Lisa goes because she cares about her friend’s suffering; Max goes because “it’s the right thing to do.”  Max, we are told, fails to appreciate the friendship’s intrinsic value.  But what matters for alienation is not *which thought* appears in practical deliberation, but whether the agent’s engagement with the friend is affectively and attitudinally appropriate.  If Max converses warmly, brings books the friend enjoys, and later checks up out of continued concern, then the initial deliberative standpoint—“I must do right”—has not alienated him.  More generally, our motives regularly involve multiple strands: I study tonight partly to learn physics, partly to keep a scholarship, partly to fulfill a promise.  Any of these can be the occurrent reason without rendering the others ineffective or alienating.  The anti‐de‐dicto view over‐intellectualizes practical motivation; in real life, agents shift fluidly among multiple descriptions without pathological detachment.

2.3. Conflating Sincere Concern with Emotional Warmth  
A third line of attack holds that duty‐centered motivation is insufficiently *empathetic*: it lacks the warmth characteristic of genuine benevolence.  Yet morality often demands impartiality, perseverance under adverse affective conditions, and recognition of strangers’ claims.  The capacity to act when affection fails is a mark of moral integrity, not deficiency.  Indeed, partiality can sometimes corrupt moral worth: helping only when one *happens* to feel affection betrays a kind of moral luck.  An agent whose sole stable motive is the abstract sense of what morality requires may avoid such luck; her reliability is not hostage to emotions that come and go.  Thus, the very feature that critics deride—the abstractness of the motive—may be a strength.  

3. A Positive Account of Duty’s Moral Worth  

3.1. Responsiveness to Moral Reasons  
Sigrún Svavarsdóttir and Heidi Hurd have argued that moral worth consists in *doing the right thing because it is right.*  This “because” is ambiguous between causal and explanatory senses; what matters is not simply that the recognition of rightness cause the action, but that the action *expresses* the agent’s grasp of its rightness.  A duty‐first agent can meet this criterion if her desire to do right reliably tracks genuine right‐making reasons.  The reliability requirement eliminates the mechanical legalist who follows whatever she *believes* to be morality without regard to critical reflection.  The morally worthy duty‐motive is sensitive both to first‐order moral facts and to higher‐order evidence of fallibility (e.g., the need to check biases, hear testimony, update views).  

3.2. Correctness‐Regulative Disposition  
Kant described the good will as one that *acts from reverence for the moral law.*  Contemporary Kantians often interpret this as a *norm‐regulative* disposition: a stable orientation to make deliberative space for the moral perspective and to give it overriding weight.  When the moral law conflicts with inclination, inclination yields.  The thought “this is right” has unique practical authority.  To possess such a disposition is admirable because it manifests respect for others as free and equal sources of claims on us.  A de dicto desire can instantiate this regulative ideal: what the agent desires, fundamentally, is *to conform her will to the authoritative demands of persons in general.*  The de dicto motive is not a cold fetish but an acknowledgment of a structure of interpersonal authority.  

3.3. The Self‐Legislative Ideal and Practical Identity  
Further, Kantian duty embeds autonomy.  Acting from the thought “this is morally required” is simultaneously acting from a law one gives oneself as a rational being.  Far from alienating the agent, it integrates her practical identity.  She is not pushed around by external forces (including particular sympathies) but governs herself by her own recognition of universalizable reasons.  The resulting actions express self‐respect and integrity, virtues we admire.  Integrity explains why morally worthy action must *originate* in the agent’s own normative judgment, rather than being produced solely by emotion or social pressure.  De dicto desire centrally involves this judgment.  

3.4. Reliability Across Contexts  
Another dimension of moral worth is robustness: the motive should generate right action across a range of circumstances.  Feelings such as empathy and friendship can be powerful but narrow; they track certain right‐making features (others’ suffering, relational ties) but fail in cases where such feelings are absent.  By contrast, the abstract desire to do what is right generalizes without loss.  In dilemmas involving unfamiliar beneficiaries or counterintuitive duties (e.g., paying distant debts, respecting wildlife), de dicto duty can succeed where concrete affections falter.  The ability to sustain moral performance where ordinary sentiment is silent or hostile is a significant virtue.  

3.5. Aligning Internal and External Justification  
Holly Smith notes that moral worth plausibly requires some alignment between an agent’s subjective justification and the act’s objective rightness.  If so, we want motives that facilitate this alignment.  The de dicto desire places a premium on figuring out *why* an act is right—otherwise the agent cannot be confident that she is indeed doing what morality requires.  Hence, the de dicto‐driven agent has a standing incentive to seek out and internalize the correct explanations.  Over time, this learning process tends to imbue her with the very concrete concerns—welfare, autonomy, fairness—that critics fear she lacks.  Thus, far from crowding out these concerns, a robust duty‐orientation cultivates them.

4. Replies to Residual Worries  

4.1. “But Isn’t Friendship about Affection, Not Duty?”  
True friendship has a distinctive emotive texture—delight in the friend for her own sake.  Does the duty‐first friend miss this?  Two answers.  (i) The psychological fact: human agents are psychologically multivalent.  One can be moved by both affection and duty simultaneously; the presence of duty motive does not exclude the presence of affection.  (ii) The normative point: even if, per hypothesis, duty is the sole motive, the friend is still respected and helped.  Many people value being treated justly in addition to being liked.  Sometimes the most crucial guarantee of respectful treatment is precisely the other’s principled commitment rather than fluctuating warmth.  

4.2. “Isn’t Abstract Motivation Emotionally Stunted?”  
Emotions are indeed central to a rich moral life, but so is emotional regulation.  Consider a surgeon operating on a child.  Excessive tenderness could impede performance.  A sense of duty can focus attention on objective requirements, preventing emotional overwhelm.  Moreover, de dicto duty need not be emotionless; it can be accompanied by “moral emotions” like reverence, pride in conscientiousness, or regret when failure looms.  What matters is whether the emotion is *appropriate,* not whether it is warm and fuzzy.  

4.3. “Doesn’t the De Dicto Agent Risk Fanaticism?”  
A final worry is that devotion to “right action, whatever it is” opens the door to moral fanaticism.  The answer is that fanaticism stems from *misidentifying* what morality requires, coupled with the refusal to check one’s judgment against evidence.  That vice is not inherent in de dicto orientation; indeed, the second condition I defended—epistemic responsibility—specifically guards against it.  The dutiful agent must remain open to peer disagreement, critical reflection, and empirical feedback; otherwise she forfeits moral worth.  

Concluding Synthesis  

We can now answer the guiding questions.

1. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice for moral worth?   
Yes, provided the desire is (a) reliably connected to genuine right‐making reasons, (b) sustained by epistemic responsibility, and (c) expressive of the agent’s principled self‐governance.  Under those conditions, the motive is neither fetishistic nor alienated but an exemplary realization of moral agency.

2. What makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?  
Four interconnected goods ground the praise:  

• Respect for the moral authority of persons: The agent responds to others not merely as objects of affection but as bearers of claims.  

• Integrity and autonomy: She coordinates her will with universalizable reasons she recognizes as authoritative, thus exercising rational self‐legislation.  

• Reliability and robustness: Her motive operates across cases where other motives are silent or opposed, securing a wide sphere of right conduct.  

• Epistemic attunement: Because she wants to *be* right, not merely to *feel* right, she cultivates habits of critical reflection that improve both moral knowledge and character.  

In sum, a mature de dicto desire to do the morally right thing is not morally second‐best; it can embody the very virtues—respect, integrity, steadfastness, and reflective humility—that we most admire.  Critics of duty’s sufficiency rightly warn against hollow legalism, but the remedy is not to abandon duty‐centered motivation; rather, it is to enrich it with epistemic and deliberative virtues.  When so enriched, acting solely from duty can be, and often is, the hallmark of deep moral worth.

Can the bare desire to “do what is right” ever endow an action with moral worth?  For many philosophers the answer seems obviously negative.  An agent who thinks only about “the morally required thing” and pays no heed to the welfare of the child she rescues, to the promise she keeps, or to the friendship she sustains appears alienated from the very values that make the act worth doing.  Michael Stocker calls such single-mindedness “moral schizophrenia,” Bernard Williams denounces it as “moral fetishism,” and contemporary virtue theorists contrast it with the richly textured motivational life characteristic of the fully virtuous person.  A natural conclusion is that the de dicto desire to do what is right―that is, a concern directed only at the fact that an act is right―is, at best, an inferior motive and, at worst, disqualifies the act from genuine moral praise.

I will defend the contrary claim.  Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what morality requires can suffice for moral worth; indeed, there are circumstances in which it is the paradigm of praiseworthy motivation.  To make this case I proceed in four steps.  (1) I clarify the “de dicto / de re” distinction as it applies to moral motivation and disentangle it from two quite different distinctions that critics often conflate: the thin/thick and the higher-order/first-order divides.  (2) I advance a Kantian-inspired account of respect for the moral law that preserves the central insights of the critics while showing that a pure motive of duty must, by its very nature, incorporate an implicit responsiveness to the concrete right-making facts.  (3) I show why this form of motivation is not only compatible with, but in some cases superior to, the sentimental or virtue-ethical alternatives.  (4) Finally, I answer the charge of alienation by explaining how the motive of duty can express a deep practical identification with persons and values, rather than a fetish for an abstract property.

1.  De dicto, de re, thin, thick, higher-order, first-order  
Consider an agent, Sarah, who sees a child drowning.  She forms the intention “I will save the child because it is the right thing to do.”  The content of her motivating desire is “that I do what is morally right.”  That is de dicto: the rightness of the act is picked out under the description “morally right.”  By contrast, a de re desire would be “that I save this child,” where the child’s welfare figures in the intention.  Critics assume that a de dicto desire is necessarily thin, abstract, and held at a reflective remove from concrete considerations.  But this assumption is gratuitous.  A de dicto desire can be motivationally thick: Sarah may be picturing the child’s face, hearing the screams, and yet intellectually taking the fact “that it is right” as what rationalizes her movement.  Likewise, de dicto desires are often higher-order: they govern which first-order inclinations may be acted on.  But the presence of such a higher-order structure does not imply the absence of underlying first-order perceptions and concerns.  Sorting these distinctions frees us from the worry that choosing under the description “morally right” necessarily brackets all the rich particularities of the situation.

2.  A Kantian defence: Respect as practical responsiveness  
Kant’s famous shopkeeper case is frequently misread as endorsing cold, unsympathetic moralism.  Kant does say that only action “from duty” has moral worth, but he explicitly allows that the dutiful agent must “represent to herself” the law that applies.  What law?  The categorical imperative, which bids the agent to treat persons as ends.  For the maxim of saving the child to pass the test, Sarah must represent the child as an end in herself.  Thus even if the explicit incentive is “because it is morally required,” Sarah’s practical reasoning must include the child’s value.  The relation is not accidental: the moral law, properly understood, is the structured articulation of those concrete values.  The desire to do what is morally right therefore entails, on pain of irrationality, sensitivity to those very values.  An agent who really acts “from duty” cannot, on Kant’s view, be blind to what best explains that duty; the explanatory ties are baked into the moral law’s content.

We can formulate the point by analogy to mathematics.  A student might say “I will follow the axioms,” but to apply an axiom she must grasp its consequences for the particular problem.  If she mindlessly copies proofs without seeing how the axioms yield them, she is not in fact following the axioms; she is acting heteronomously under someone else’s say-so.  Similarly, an agent who parrots “I must do the right thing” without appreciating why the present act is right is not guided by duty but by deference, fear, or habit.  Genuine respect for morality is, of conceptual necessity, a rational grasp of the principles that make the act right, which in turn requires the agent to track the concrete right-making facts.  Hence the charge that pure dutifulness is “blind” misunderstands what dutifulness is.

3.  Why duty sometimes outranks sentiment  
Even granting that the motive of duty incorporates an implicit concern for the right-making facts, why think it can by itself make the action praiseworthy?  Because duty exerts a distinctive kind of authority over the will.  Sentimental motives, such as sympathy, may track morality, but they can be spotty, partial, or vulnerable to moral luck.  A person might be moved by sympathy only to those within her immediate horizon, or only on sunny days when she is in a good mood.  A commitment to “do what is right” establishes a stable, general, and impartial standpoint.  Thus, in cases where the sentimental motives are absent or misdirected, the motive of duty can secure moral conformity when nothing else would.  Imagine a hardened physician in a war zone, emotionally numb after months of horror.  He no longer feels warmth toward the wounded.  Yet he continues to treat each patient diligently because it is his moral duty.  Far from being morally defective, the physician is admirable: he overcomes motivational deficits by the exercise of practical reason.  Critics who deny moral worth to such cases implicitly hold that the agent should first cultivate a new set of feelings before acting.  But from the moral point of view of the actual victims, that priority seems perverse; what matters is that they receive the care.

Virtue ethicists reply that while the dutiful physician is certainly to be commended, he falls short of ideal virtue.  I agree.  But the present question concerns sufficiency for moral worth, not moral perfection.  The fact that another motivational structure might be better does nothing to show that the motive of duty is inadequate.  To ride a bicycle in a straight line is sufficient for cycling; one may do so with or without elegant posture.  Likewise, to respond to duty is sufficient for praiseworthiness, even if integrated virtue is superior.

4.  Answering the alienation charge  
Williams’s central worry is that the de dicto agent cares about the wrong property: rightness per se rather than the valuable features that ground rightness.  He compares it to someone who loves her partner because he is “the person one ought to marry.”  Such love seems hollow.  The analogy, however, fails because moral respect is not a species of personal attachment.  Loving a person is paradigmatically a response to her individual qualities; but respecting the moral law is not loving the law.  It is rather the stance of taking persons and their claims as bearing overriding practical significance.  What looks like fetishism when transplanted into the domain of love is simply the appropriate attitude in the moral domain.  

Moreover, the alleged alienation is not forced on us.  If Sarah really believes that the child’s life is morally significant, then in conceiving her motive under the general description “doing what is right,” she at the same time conceives it under the specialized description “saving this child’s life.”  In ordinary speech we often toggle between levels of description without motivational loss: “Come to dinner; it’s polite” and “Come to dinner; your friend cooked for hours.”  Both statements can capture the same underlying concern.  The fetishism charge gains traction only if we assume that psychological explanation must trade off de dicto against de re contents.  Yet human motives typically nest: the higher-order desire that my act be right is implemented by first-order desires that the other person be helped.  What earns moral worth is the unity of volition: I act because I take myself to have decisive reason, and I correctly identify that reason.

To illustrate, imagine two rescuers.  Amelia rushes in tears toward the drowning child because her parental instincts generalize to the protection of any youngster.  Bartholomew, a lifeguard on duty, is exhausted and numb after twelve hours.  He sees the flailing arms, feels no surge of sympathy, but registers that a life is at stake and that the moral law demands action.  He dives and saves the child.  The child is alive thanks to Bartholomew’s duty-bound commitment.  Surely we should praise both rescues.  Indeed, one might argue that Bartholomew’s action exhibits a higher deliberative integrity, because he acts from a reason he endorses as such rather than from an unreflective affect.  If one worries about how the child experiences the rescue, remember: what matters ethically is not how pleasant the rescuer’s face looks mid-action, but whether the agent exercises her freedom in accordance with reasons we can all share.

5.  Objections and replies  
Objection 1:  The concept of duty is too indeterminate; without the emotional resonance supplied by the virtues, the agent will misidentify what duty requires.  
Reply:  The worry conflates epistemic guidance with motivational adequacy.  Emotions can help us detect morally salient facts, but they do not constitute the warrant for acting.  A well-trained agent of duty uses reason, social feedback, and experience to determine what the moral law enjoins.  Where her moral judgment is mistaken, the action lacks rightness, but that is a separate issue from the worth of acting from the motive one justifiably takes to be duty.

Objection 2:  Praiseworthy actions should contribute positively to the moral flourishing of the agent.  Pure dutifulness leaves the agent cold and hence is self-stultifying.  
Reply:  Even if personal flourishing matters, it is not the criterion of moral worth.  Morality’s first concern is with the right ordering of agents and patients.  Furthermore, acting from duty fosters the agent’s rational self-governance, itself a dimension of flourishing.  The “coldness” complaint again presumes that rational activity is emotionally anaemic, an empirical assertion belied by experience; many who act from duty report a deep sense of meaning.

Objection 3:  Kant himself admits that an action “conformable to duty but not from duty” lacks moral worth; this shows that we should favour actions motivated by inclination.  
Reply:  The Kantian contrast targets acting from inclination alone.  An action motivated by a mix of benevolent feeling and the thought of duty remains from duty so long as the recognition of duty plays the decisive normative role.  Nothing in the view disqualifies emotional enrichment.  What it insists on is that the agent be ready to act even when the feelings fade.  That readiness is precisely what a de dicto motive provides.

6.  Two limits: evil, fanaticism, and empty formalism  
My defence is not without bounds.  First, a “duty” that is in fact evil—say, a racially oppressive code—cannot ground moral worth.  The sufficiency claim is therefore conditional on the objectivity of the duty.  Second, there is indeed such a phenomenon as moral fetishism: a perverse fascination with the mere form of obligation, divorced from substantive principle.  The fanatic who insists on rights-language while ignoring urgent human need is not praiseworthy.  But the fanatic is not moved solely by the desire to do what is right; he is moved by a distorted conception of rightness.  His failure is cognitive, not motivational.  That does not impugn the legitimacy of the motive type when properly informed.

7.  The positive account summed up  
We can now articulate the conditions under which acting from the sole motive of duty suffices for moral worth:

a.  The agent correctly grasps the moral principles that make the act right.  
b.  The de dicto desire “that I do what is right” is effectively connected to an appreciation (cognitive and practical) of those principles as instantiated in the situation.  
c.  The desire is what decisively moves the agent; it is not overridden or merely epiphenomenal.  
d.  The action is objectively right.

When these conditions obtain, the agent manifests the capacity that morality fundamentally demands of persons: practical rationality that acknowledges the authority of reasons.  That capacity is intrinsically worthy of praise.  Additional motives such as sympathy, love, or solidarity can enrich the action, but they are supererogatory with respect to basic moral worth.

8.  Implications and closing reflections  
The upshot of this discussion is neither a downgrading of the virtues nor a celebration of austerity.  Rather, it is a pluralistic acknowledgement that moral motivation comes in layers.  Respect for the moral law gives us principled steadiness; affective concern supplies warmth and discernment.  In concrete life, the two normally cooperate: we educate sentiment so that it aligns with moral duty, and we marshal duty when sentiment falters.  Philosophical accounts that fetishize (ironically!) only one layer risk mistaking a part for the whole.

The critics perform a valuable service in reminding us that genuine morality is about human needs, relationships, and goods.  Yet they err in taking that reminder to imply that abstract moral commitment is second-rate.  Abstraction is what allows finite creatures, embedded in partial perspectives, to rise to the standpoint of the moral community.  When a person acts simply because she knows it is right—even if her heart is quiet, even if her face betrays no glow—she affirms that humanity in her person and in every person has unconditional worth.  That affirmation is itself worthy of our deepest praise.

Acting Solely from Duty: A Vindication of De Dicto Moral Motivation

1. Introduction  

Few topics have been as persistently contested in moral psychology and normative ethics as the relation between an agent’s moral motive and the moral worth of her action. A widespread intuition, articulated by Michael Stocker, Susan Wolf, Michael Smith and others, is that a mere desire “to do the right thing” is insufficient for full-blooded moral worth. According to this critique, the agent who rescues a drowning child only because she believes it is her duty, while devoid of any direct concern for the child, acts with a kind of moral fetishism or alienation. The present essay defends the opposite thesis: an action performed solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can, under the plausible psychological and epistemic conditions that I shall specify, possess genuine and even paradigmatic moral worth.  

I proceed as follows. Section 2 clarifies the dialectic by distinguishing three senses in which duty can be “sole” motive. Section 3 reconstructs the anti-fetishist arguments. Section 4 develops a multi-pronged reply, drawing on Kantian ideas but also on contemporary work by Barbara Herman, Nomy Arpaly, and Sarah Stroud. Section 5 explains why the abstract motive is not only sufficient but sometimes superior to more “concrete” motives. Section 6 articulates the positive account: dutiful action is praiseworthy when it manifests (a) practical recognition of the authority of moral reasons, (b) a stable disposition to treat those reasons as decisive, and (c) appropriate self-regulative concern with reliability and impartiality. Section 7 replies to residual worries about affective impoverishment and relational alienation. A brief conclusion summarizes what is at stake philosophically.

2. What Does It Mean to Act “Solely” from Duty?  

The slogan “acting solely from duty” can mask important ambiguities.

A. Exclusionary sense: The agent has no other motivating states (no inclinations, emotions, sympathies, projects) bearing on the action.  
B. Decisive-priority sense: Other motives may be present, but the agent would still perform the act even if those motives were absent; duty is what renders the action practically necessary for her.  
C. Explanatory sufficiency sense: In attributing moral worth we cite only the agent’s de dicto desire; the presence of other motives is morally incidental.

Critics typically need the strong exclusionary reading (A) to fuel the charge of affective coldness; defenders of duty need only the weaker readings (B) or (C). Henceforth “solely” will be understood in sense B: duty is the hinge on which the action turns, even if auxiliary feelings tag along.

Likewise, a de dicto moral desire is a second-order desire: “I want (for any φ) to φ iff φ-ing is morally right.” It contrasts with de re motives—concern for this child, this promise, this friend. The dispute is whether such a second-order desire, operating without any de re moralized concerns, yields actions with full moral worth.

3. The Anti-Fetishist Challenge  

Three families of arguments dominate the critical literature.

3.1. Affective impoverishment. Stocker’s lonely therapist example— the therapist helps clients solely because it is right—suggests that absence of care renders relationships hollow.  

3.2. Epistemic opacity. An abstract desire “to do what’s right” cannot by itself tell the agent what is right; competent moral judgment requires sensitivity to the morally salient features of situations (Wolf, Arpaly).  

3.3. Value alienation. Moral rightness is not an independent good; it supervenes on concrete goods such as well-being or justice. Caring only about the supervenient property is fetishistic, akin to desiring an object merely because it is colored the way good objects are (Smith).

Together these arguments underwrite the verdict that duty-only agents lack an appropriate relationship to morality’s grounds; hence their acts, though conforming to duty, fall short of moral worth.

4. Why Duty Survives the Objections  

4.1. Answer to affective impoverishment  

The allegation that pure duty lacks warmth confuses motivational origin with expressive phenomenology. Nothing in a de dicto motive precludes the agent from displaying sympathy, kindness, or enthusiasm; what matters is whether those affective accompaniments are the causal basis of action. A soldier who rescues civilians out of sworn duty to the Geneva Conventions may still weep upon seeing their injuries. The flowing tears are not explanatorily primary, but they are not ersatz. Moral worth attaches to the soldier’s principled resolve; affect merely illustrates, not replaces, that resolve. The affective austerity charge thus misses its target.

4.2. Answer to epistemic opacity  

A desire to do right is indeed formally content-poor; but agents rarely act on bare desires. They also possess beliefs about what morality requires. If those beliefs are formed through appropriate sensitivity to concrete considerations, the epistemic worry evaporates. The de dicto desire functions as an executive commitment: “Once I determine that φ is morally required, I will φ.” The cognitive machinery that determines whether φ is required operates separately. Moral worth, as Kant insisted, is measured at the moment of volition, not at the moment of deliberation. As long as the agent’s method of moral inquiry is sound, the formality of the motive does no harm.

4.3. Answer to value alienation  

Smith’s fetish analogy misconstrues the structure of moral properties. To value rightness as such is to value the normative authority of reasons—an intrinsically intelligible good, not arbitrarily supervenient. Rightness is not a mysterious sheen; it is the property of being supported by decisive reasons. Caring about rightness is thus caring about, and in effect respecting, the very considerations that make an action right; it is simply a higher-order mode of caring. The fetish worry collapses once we acknowledge that normative authority itself has value.

5. The Case for Sufficiency  

Beyond rebutting objections, there are positive reasons to esteem duty-centered motivation.

5.1. Reliability under adversity  

Empirical studies of bystander intervention show that situational impediments—time pressure, group conformity—dampen spontaneous sympathy. But subjects primed with moral principles (e.g., the parable of the Good Samaritan) resist such pressures. Abstract commitment yields robustness where empathy wavers.

5.2. Impartiality and justice  

Direct concern for concrete individuals often skews toward partiality (the “identifiable victim effect”). A de dicto commitment can correct such myopia, ensuring fairness to strangers, future generations, and statistical lives.

5.3. Self-regulation and moral growth  

Because abstract duty is reflectively accessible, agents can assess their own reliability and correct biases. De re affection, being more opaque, resists self-critique. Thus, duty fosters moral learning.

6. What Makes Dutiful Action Morally Worthy?  

I propose three jointly necessary and sufficient conditions.

Condition 1: Responsiveness to Moral Reasons  
The agent’s de dicto motivation must be integrated with a perceptual skill for identifying morally decisive features. She must act because she recognizes that those features make the action right, even if she values them only under the description “morally required features.”

Condition 2: Prioritizing Moral Reasons as Such  
The agent must treat moral reasons as enjoy­ing decisive priority over non-moral reasons. This expresses the Kantian idea of reverence for the moral law—not mere conformity, but acknowledgment of its authority.

Condition 3: Stable Disposition  
The agent’s responsiveness and prioritization must form a stable trait, not a one-off choice. Stability evidences deep commitment rather than episodic compulsion.

When these conditions are met, the action manifests the agent’s respect for persons (via the formal commitment to act only on universalizable maxims), her appreciation of the independence of practical reason, and her trustworthiness. These features jointly ground moral praise.

7. Replies to Residual Worries  

7.1. Alienation from personal relationships  
Caring about rightness need not crowd out friendship or love. It structures them: we refrain from betrayal because that would violate trust, which our duty to others condemns. In valuing the moral law we implicitly value the goods it protects. So there is no estrangement.

7.2. Over-intellectualization  
Some fear that duty reduces ethics to legalistic rule-following. Yet the Kantian tradition emphasizes autonomy: one’s own reason legislates the moral law. Acting from duty therefore expresses our practical identity; it is the paradigm of self-governance, not mechanical compliance.

7.3. Supererogatory acts  
What of actions beyond duty? Here too the duty motive suffices, because the agent’s maxim may be “Whenever feasible, do what is morally best.” Supererogation is then subsumed under the will to accord decisive weight to moral reasons, even where they are not strictly required.

8. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed confer moral worth—provided the agent is epistemically competent and stably committed to moral reasons’ authority. The anti-fetishist objections underestimate the richness of a de dicto moral motive, ignoring its role in reliability, impartiality, and self-directed moral development. Far from being a bloodless shadow of genuine virtue, dutiful motivation often represents virtue at its reflective best. The praise we accord to such action is praise for the agent’s recognition of, and steadfast responsiveness to, that highest of goods: the claim that morality legitimately makes on us all.

Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? In what follows I argue that it can. More precisely, I claim that an agent whose decisive motive is a de-dicto desire “to do what morality requires” can act with full moral worth provided that her desire is integrated into a rationally sensitive, self-governing practical outlook. Such a desire, far from manifesting fetishism or alienation, expresses (i) respect for the authority of moral reasons, (ii) a reliable capacity to track the right-making features of situations, and (iii) a form of practical integrity that is itself an appropriate object of moral praise. To defend this conclusion I proceed in five steps:

1. Clarify the target view and the main objections.  
2. Reconstruct a Kantian answer and note its limits.  
3. Show how the fetishism/alienation charge rests on a mistaken picture of de-dicto motivation.  
4. Offer a positive account of morally worthy de-dicto action.  
5. Reply to residual worries and draw lessons for theories of moral worth.

I. The target view and its critics  

Philosophers commonly distinguish two ways of being moved by moral considerations. An agent may be moved “de re” by the very considerations that make the act right: concern for a person’s welfare, desire to keep a promise, sensitivity to justice, and so on. Or she may be moved “de dicto”—by a higher-order desire to do whatever is morally required, whatever that happens to be. The former is concrete and content-laden; the latter abstract and content-neutral.

Michael Smith labels exclusive reliance on the latter a form of moral fetishism: the agent’s concern is fastened not on people or values in the world but on an impersonal property, rightness. Michael Stocker complains that such agents suffer “moral schizophrenia,” their motives disconnected from the very goods morality serves. Susan Wolf’s moral saints appear joyless and alienated, sacrificing the richness of human attachments on the altar of impersonal moral duty. These worries generate the widely held thesis that “duty alone” cannot confer moral worth; genuine praiseworthiness requires being motivated, at least in part, by the first-order considerations that ground the rightness of one’s act.

II. A Kantian answer and its limits  

Kant famously insists that an act has moral worth only when done “from duty.” Read superficially, this seems to exalt de-dicto motivation and to confirm the view’s critics. Yet Kant does not praise a dutiful agent because she is captivated by an inert property of “rightness.” Rather, what moves her is respect for the moral law, which for Kant is the embodiment of practical reason itself. Respect for the law is an attitude through which the agent takes the ends of others as ends of her own; it is not a cold devotion to abstracta, but the rational form that love for humanity must assume if it is to avoid partiality and heedless sentimentality.

Still, there are two problems. First, Kant’s language invites the caricature of the dutiful bureaucrat who occupies himself with formal maxims and overlooks the living needs of persons. Second, even sympathetic readers concede that Kant’s account is more about the negative condition for moral worth (acting not merely from inclination) than a positive story about what renders dutiful motivation admirable. To carry the argument forward we need to say, in more contemporary terms, why the de-dicto motive can be both substantively sensitive and affectively rich.

III. Diagnosing the fetishism charge  

The fetishism/alienation complaint assumes that a de-dicto desire is content-blind. But desires are individuated by their role in an agent’s practical reasoning; what matters is how the desire operates, not how it is verbally formulated. Consider Ella, who says: “I want, above all else, to do what is morally right.” Does this commit her to a fetish? Not if Ella also possesses ordinary empirical knowledge of the world and capacities for sympathy, foresight, and fairness. When she judges that helping her injured neighbour is morally required, the de-dicto desire immediately crystalizes around the concrete features of the situation—her neighbour’s pain, the urgency of aid, the relation of neighbourliness. The abstract desire functions as a standing second-order commitment that activates first-order concern whenever the circumstances call for it.

Critics sometimes depict a de-dicto agent as someone who performs a laborious two-step inference every time she acts: first ask “What is my duty?” then act, indifferent to the reasons why that is the duty. But psychologically healthy deliberation seldom proceeds so stiltedly. Most of us have *internalised* moral principles and prototypes; they guide perception and attention automatically. A person guided by the commitment “do what is morally right” typically perceives the right-making factors directly, because her standing commitment has shaped her practical sensibility. In Bernard Williams’s phrase, morality “silences” alternative reasons: the very recognition that the neighbour is hurt shows up to her as “a reason to help” without further mediation.

Hence the fetishism charge conflates two things:

a. A de-dicto motive that is functional and contextually responsive.  
b. A fetishistic attitude that treats rightness as an object with independent allure.

Only the latter deserves criticism. There is no reason to believe that the former is necessarily, or even typically, fetishistic.

IV. A positive picture: why de-dicto duty can confer moral worth  

Let us sketch three features that make dutiful action praiseworthy.

1. Normative governance  

A de-dicto desire to do what is right signals recognition of moral reasons as authoritative over one’s conduct. By treating rightness as a decisive reason, the agent acknowledges the priority of the moral point of view—a structural commitment analogous to acknowledging logical validity in theoretical reasoning. Praiseworthiness attaches to the agent’s success in *governing herself* by reasons she recognises as genuinely normative. The ability to bring one’s will in line with one’s best judgment is, in itself, a central form of practical virtue: it displays autonomy, steadiness, and self-respect.

2. Reliable sensitivity  

Second, a well-formed de-dicto desire typically results from moral upbringing, reflection, and critical correction. It therefore incorporates a network of standing dispositions—sympathy, fairness, honesty, respect—that together constitute *reliability* in tracking the right-making features of situations. Acting from this desire is praiseworthy because it makes the agent a reliable doer of the right. Reliability matters: morality aims not merely at good intentions but at correct action across diverse circumstances. De-re motives such as compassion are powerful but sometimes narrow or partial; commitment to do the right can counteract their biases. Consider a judge who must set aside empathy for the charming defendant because justice requires impartiality. Her de-dicto orientation ensures she will not be swayed by charisma or similarity bias.

3. Expressive integrity  

Third, dutiful action expresses a distinctive form of respect—for others as moral equals and for oneself as a responsible agent. When I help my friend solely because it is right to keep promises, I in effect say: “Your status as a person who may rely on my word matters decisively.” This expression is not cold; it is a recognition of dignity. When circumstances render the natural affective support weak (e.g., helping a disagreeable stranger, or doing good anonymously without hope of gratitude), a de-dicto motive sustains the action. The capacity to act rightly in the absence, or even contrary to, first-order attractions manifests steadfast integrity, and integrity is an intelligible ground for praise.

V. Replies to residual worries  

1. The “Empty Container” Worry  

Someone may object that the account smuggles in de-re concern through the back door. If the de-dicto desire must contain sympathetic and fair dispositions to be reliable, then moral worth derives from those dispositions, not from the higher-order desire. My reply: the relationship is holistic. The de-dicto desire is not an empty shell into which other motives are poured; it is the organising commitment that shapes and disciplines lower-order tendencies into a coherent moral perspective. Praise is owed to the structure as a whole, not merely to its components, just as athletic excellence is owed not to any single muscle but to the coordinated functioning of the body.

2. The “Overly Formal” Worry  

A second worry is that agents who act from duty miss out on the “spirit” of morality—acting kindly because one loves people, not because one loves duty. But there is no incompatibility. Agents often act from complex motives. The view defended here holds only that an action done *solely* from duty can possess moral worth; it does not recommend that we *prefer* such motivation whenever warmer feelings are available. Moreover, some contexts (administration of justice, equitable distribution, whistle-blowing) rightly privilege impartial duty over partial affection. Morality is pluralistic: there are occasions for friendly generosity and occasions for principled steadfastness.

3. The “Zealot” Worry  

What about the zealot who is inflexibly guided by an erroneous moral code? If moral worth attaches to the higher-order desire alone, won’t we have to praise the fanatic who sincerely strives to do what he *believes* is right? My account avoids this result because it makes moral worth conditional on *successfully tracking the genuine right-making features*. A reliable but false code (say, a racist ideology) cannot confer moral worth because it systematically fails to respond to the very reasons morality is responsive to; it is unreliable by objective standards. Thus, dutiful motivation is praiseworthy only when coupled with epistemic responsibility and justificatory adequacy.

4. The “Effortless Saint” Worry  

Suppose Ann is so thoroughly habituated that doing right is easy for her; she acts from a standing de-dicto desire without cost. Is she still praiseworthy? I think so. While effort can heighten our admiration (resisting strong temptation displays strength of will), it is not a prerequisite for moral worth. What merits praise is the *quality of will* manifested: Ann’s steadfast commitment to moral reasons. Her ease indicates stable virtue, itself a mark of excellence.

VI. Lessons and conclusion  

We began with a sceptical challenge: duty de-dicto seems too abstract to ground moral worth because it overlooks the substances that make acts right. I have argued that this scepticism overlooks the way in which a general commitment to do right structures an agent’s entire practical identity. Far from being fetishistic, it is (when healthy) the embodiment of three admirable capacities: normative self-governance, reliable sensitivity, and expressive integrity. These capacities confer moral worth whether or not the agent is concurrently moved by first-order sympathies.

The argument leaves room for pluralism about praiseworthy motivation. Often the richest moral lives integrate de-dicto commitment with vivid, affective concern for particular persons and projects. But the presence of such concern is not conceptually or morally required for worthiness. The Kantian insight survives contemporary scrutiny: respect for the moral law, understood as a rationally sensitive higher-order commitment, suffices to make an action morally worthy. When Ella rushes into a pond to save a child, not from spontaneous affection but because she recognises that it is morally required, her act exhibits a form of excellence that deserves our admiration every bit as much as the act motivated by direct love. The motive of duty, far from alienating us from morality’s true point, is one of the principal ways we relate to one another as free and equal moral agents.

Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? I shall defend an affirmative answer. Acting “from duty” in the strict, Kantian sense—i.e. acting because one has the de dicto desire to do what is right—can possess full moral worth. That claim, however, must be carefully specified if it is to survive the powerful charge that such motivation involves “moral fetishism,” “estrangement,” or a disregard for the concrete features that give an act its moral valence. I argue, first, that the charge of fetishism rests on an unduly impoverished picture of what a de dicto desire to do the right thing is like in psychologically healthy agents. Second, a properly understood duty motive displays three properties—responsiveness, understanding, and self-government—that constitutively confer moral worth. Finally, I explain why these properties are enough to ground praise even when other, more sentiment-laden motives (e.g. sympathy) are absent.

I. Clarifying the Dispute  

1. Two conceptions of moral motivation  
Call a de dicto desire an attitude that can be stated as: “I want to φ because φ-ing is morally right.” This contrasts with a de re desire: “I want to φ because doing so will keep my promise/help my friend/etc.” Critics such as Michael Stocker, Lawrence Blum, and Bernard Williams hold that agents whose action issues from the first desire alone exhibit a kind of moral pathology. They seem more invested in ticking the “morality” box than in the friends, promises, and persons that ordinarily make moral acts worth doing.

Kantians—notably Christine Korsgaard and Marcia Baron—reply that the duty motive need not be a cold abstraction. To will an act as morally required is, they contend, to will it under a maxim that incorporates all the concrete considerations that make it right; the very concept of rightness already entangles us with those considerations. The real disagreement, then, is about what a de dicto moral desire amounts to, psychologically and normatively.

2. Criteria of moral worth  
There are at least three ways to unpack the notion that an action is “morally worthy.”

a. The Kantian criterion: an act has moral worth if and only if it is done from duty, where “from duty” denotes non-pathological respect for the moral law.  
b. The virtue-ethical criterion: an act is morally worthy if it issues from the virtuous sentiments (kindness, justice, courage, etc.) appropriate to the situation.  
c. The reasons-responsiveness criterion: an act is praiseworthy when it patterns with the agent’s reliable grasp and governance by the reasons that objectively count.

Critics of duty-only motivation assume b. I shall defend the weaker but widely acceptable c: praiseworthiness tracks reliable and reflectively governed responsiveness to moral reasons. I will then argue that properly understood Kantian motivation meets c, thus meeting a sufficient condition for praise.

II. Diagnosing the “Moral Fetishism” Charge  

The standard fetishism argument takes this form:

P1. Acting from a desire to do what is right involves attending only to the right-making property, not to the concrete facts (friend’s pain, promised event, etc.).  
P2. Attending only to the right-making property manifests moral alienation or disrespect for those concrete facts.  
C. Therefore, duty-only motivation lacks moral worth.

Each premise can be resisted.

1. Misconstruing the “right-making property”  
In ordinary moral cognition, rightness is not a detached label glued onto an act after we determine what to do. Rather, rightness is a higher-order property constituted by, and hence conceptually dependent on, the very features the critic prizes. To believe that helping a friend is right just is to see the friend’s need, one’s promise, or the relevant relationship as reason-giving. A genuine desire to “do the right thing” therefore cannot be psychologically realised without sensitivity to those first-order considerations; they are part of what the agent’s motivational representation picks out.

2. The over-intellectualisation worry  
Some imagine a Kantian agent checking an internal spreadsheet headed “Morality,” performing an austere calculation, and acting with no affective engagement. Yet empirical work on moral psychology reveals that rule-guided, norm-sensitive states are commonly suffused with emotional valence. Respect, commitment, and even love of law can be warm, identity-constituting attitudes. The fetishism charge tacitly assumes that a moral principle, to move us, must operate like a sterile instruction in a computer program. Human motivational architecture is richer.

3. Straw-man instances  
Consider two rescuers. One rushes into the river to save a child because “it’s the right thing to do”; the other rushes in because she pities the child. Suppose both see exactly the same concrete facts: a child in mortal danger who can easily be saved. In what respect is the first agent alienated? If fetishism merely means that she conceptualises her reason in more abstract terms, that seems compatible with full valuation of the child’s life. The burden lies on the critic to show that abstraction entails devaluation; mere abstraction is not enough.

III. Positive Account: Why Duty Motivation Can Suffice  

To establish sufficiency, we must show that the duty motive can possess the hallmarks of morally worthy agency. I identify three such hallmarks.

1. Responsiveness  

An agent A is responsively motivated when changes in the morally relevant facts would alter her motivation in the right way. De dicto duty desire passes this test. Suppose A is moved by “do what is morally right.” If further reflection reveals that donating to a more effective charity is right, A’s standing desire directs her to shift her act accordingly. This counterfactual sensitivity is a central component of praiseworthy responsiveness. Sympathy alone may not reliably track such revisions; duty, by aiming at the right per se, can do so systematically.

Crucially, the form of responsiveness needed does not require that the first-order facts be the conscious objects of desire. What matters is that the agent’s deliberative system is reliably connected to them. A thermostat “desires” to keep the room at 21 °C only de dicto; yet its circuitry guarantees that any deviation in temperature triggers the right response. Analogously, a human duty-motive can be wired to moral facts via moral reasoning capacities, practical imagination, and normative belief.

2. Understanding  

Many acts guided by sympathy or spontaneous benevolence carry diminished worth when the agent fails to grasp why the act is right. Consider the kindly physician who dispenses an effective treatment out of affection for the patient but would have done the same had the dosage been lethal, because he lacks medical understanding. By contrast, when an agent forms the abstract intention “do the morally required thing,” she must—on pain of irrationality—engage in some level of moral reasoning to identify the right act. This reasoning confers an epistemic virtue: the agent does not merely stumble upon the correct deed but does so under a correct description. Such understanding deepens moral worth.

Kant highlighted this epistemic dimension. To act from duty is to act “out of reverence for the law,” which entails recognising the act’s universalizability, its fit with autonomy and respect. That reflective endorsement ensures that the deed is not just luck but is owned, conceptually grasped, and repeatable on principle.

3. Self-government  

Praiseworthiness further requires that the agent’s will, not accident or manipulation, be the causal source of action. The desire to do what is right is paradigmatically a reason-governed desire; it is formed and sustained by the agent’s reflective faculties. In contrast, first-order sentiments can be environmentally triggered or selectively disabled by mood swings. When the Stoic resists helping out of anger but chooses to help because she judges it right, her self-government asserts itself over unsteady inclinations. Such governance is morally impressive even if the sympathetic person would also have helped.

Taken together, responsiveness, understanding, and self-government give us a composite picture of why dutiful action is apt for praise. They also help explain why paradigms of moral heroism—e.g. Oskar Schindler, Sophie Scholl, or principled whistle-blowers—often cite “I had to do what was right” rather than empathy as their core stimulant. Empathy may freeze when the victim is distant or culturally other; duty can bridge that gap.

IV. Addressing Residual Objections  

1. The value of sentiment  

Objectors insist that moral sentiments like compassion possess independent worth that a bare sense of duty lacks. I grant that rich affect often enhances moral value. Yet enhancement is not necessity. Consider impartial roles: judges, jurors, auditors. We applaud them for bracketing partial affections and staying strictly within duty’s boundaries. A Kantian judge who sentences a beloved relative because it is right to apply the law can deserve extraordinary praise precisely because sympathy pulls in the other direction. Hence, though sentiments may add value, their absence need not subtract value where duty alone propels correct action against counter-vailing forces.

2. Supererogation and coldness  

Critics reply that duty-only motivation delivers the correct quantum of moral performance but no more; it cannot inspire supererogatory sacrifice or special warmth. Empirical evidence undermines this. People reporting a strong duty orientation often perform costly political activism, non-profit work, or whistle-blowing. More conceptually, duty can require extreme sacrifice: consider Kant’s view that you must not lie to a murderer at the door. One may dispute the content of duty, but not its motivational potency.

3. Pluralism about praise  

A more nuanced objection allows that duty can suffice for some praise but claims it is eclipsed by combined duty + sentiment. Imagine two givers: one donates because it is right; the other because it is right and out of love for the beneficiaries. Many intuit the second merits more praise. My thesis is modest: duty alone can suffice for praise, not that it yields maximal praise in every case. The presence of additional, harmonious sentiments can indeed add layers of worth—but they are not necessary conditions.

V. Analytic Elaboration: De Dicto Desire and Thick Motivation  

One might suspect that I have subtly smuggled de re content into the duty motive by allowing its representational vehicles to be thickly descriptive. Let me therefore distinguish two levels at which duty operates.

Level 1: Directive content—“Do what is morally right.”  
Level 2: Interpretive schema—the agent’s moral theory that unpacks rightness into concrete norms (e.g. utilitarian utility, Kantian universal law).

Although Level 1 is formally thin, its motivational efficacy depends on Level 2’s embedded practical knowledge. The agent need not antecedently want to relieve suffering (de re) but must be capable of seeing how relieving suffering falls under “what is right.” This ensures that the duty motive, while thin in one respect, is thickly connected to the world in another. Consequently, it satisfies the anti-fetishist’s demand that moral motivation reach out to the relevant particulars.

VI. Comparisons with Alternative Theories  

1. Virtue ethics  

Virtue ethicists emphasise harmony between doer and deed: the generous person should enjoy giving. Yet Aristotle himself notes that the virtuous may find some correct actions painful—witness the decent individual who must punish a loved one. Modern neo-Aristotelians likewise concede that right conduct under duress can be virtuous, though less pleasant. Here the Kantian insistence on duty and self-command fills the explanatory gap for why painful virtue is still praiseworthy.

2. Sentimentalism  

Humeans underscore that moral motivation arises from sentiment; reason is the “slave of the passions.” However, Hume also allows that “regard to the virtue of the action” can itself be an indirect passion. Therefore, even on sentimentalist psychology, the motive of duty can be recast as a higher-order passion for conformity with virtue. The debate reduces to semantics rather than substance; once the passion tracks moral facts, the worry about alienation dissolves.

VII. Implications for Moral Education  

If duty motivation suffices, moral educators should cultivate respect for rightness per se alongside empathy training. Over-reliance on empathy risks parochialism: we feel more for those near, similar, or vivid to us. A robust sense of duty leverages reason to correct such biases. Teaching children that “we help because it is right” can, far from chilling their sympathy, scaffold it with principles that broaden its reach.

VIII. Conclusion  

The contention that de dicto duty alone cannot ground moral worth collapses once we appreciate how such motivation actually functions in well-integrated agents. Far from fetishistic, the desire to do what is right is:

1. Responsively linked to the concrete facts that make acts right.  
2. Epistemically informed, embodying an understanding of moral reasons.  
3. An expression of self-governed agency committed to the public, shareable standpoint of morality.

These three features jointly suffice for moral praise. Additional motives can add to, but are not conditions of, worth. In ordinary and extraordinary circumstances alike, the austere-sounding aim “Do what is right” can be the wellspring of the most admirable human actions. Its dignity lies precisely in affirming that persons are capable of willing the good not merely because it charms or moves them, but because they see—and choose—the fact that it is good.

Can a bare, explicitly moral motive—“I am doing this because it is the right thing to do”—make an action morally praiseworthy? Or does moral worth require that the agent be moved by the very reasons that make the act right, such as the child’s need, the friend’s feelings, or the patient’s pain? The worry, pressed by philosophers from Michael Stocker to Bernard Williams and Susan Wolf, is that duty-focused action threatens “moral fetishism”: the agent’s eye is fixed on the moral law rather than on the living values the law is meant to protect. If this worry sticks, then a purely de dicto desire to do what morality requires cannot by itself ground moral worth. In what follows I argue that the fetishism charge is overstated. An agent moved solely by the thought “This is morally required” can indeed act with full moral worth, provided three background conditions obtain: (1) the agent’s duty motive expresses an appropriately integrated practical identity, rather than a brittle, one-note obsession; (2) the agent’s moral belief is substantively accurate, not a lucky guess; and (3) the duty motive is sensitive to the concrete structure of reasons in a way that allows it to guide, rather than screen off, concern for the salient particulars. Under those conditions, acting from the motive of duty is not a cold or alienated posture but a fully human way of realizing moral agency.

I. Clarifying the Target

1. The de dicto vs. de re distinction.  
Call a motive “de dicto” when it has the form: “I want to Φ because Φ-ing is morally required.” Contrast this with a “de re” motive that takes up the very property that grounds the requirement—“I want to help because she is in pain.” The fetishism worry claims that a purely de dicto motive is defective; moral worth accrues only when the agent’s direct motivational route passes through the relevant value (e.g. the person’s pain).

2. Two conceptions of moral worth.  
Kant (Groundwork I) says an action has moral worth when it is done “from duty.” Critics like Stocker assume that moral worth is constituted by the agent’s proper emotional orientation to value. These conceptions tug in different directions. Instead of adjudicating between labels, let us ask: what makes a response distinctively excellent as moral agency? That, I suggest, is an agent’s reliable conformity to the authority of moral reasons in a way that expresses her commitment to them. Such reliability can be manifested by a de dicto motive if the agent’s practical psychology meets the three conditions just mentioned.

II. The Fetishism Worry Examined

1. Diagnosis of the worry.  
The complaint has two parts.

   a. Inadequate sensitivity: A person who helps only because “helping is right” may do so even when the recipient would be harmed by the help. Moral fetishism, on this interpretation, blunts moral perception.

   b. Affective impoverishment: The duty-moved agent supposedly lacks warmth, empathy, or love. That is taken to show that she is not oriented toward the reasons that matter.

These claims are empirical in spirit. They allege that the duty motive typically produces poor moral performance or truncated affect. Yet neither claim is conceptually necessary. One can envisage agents—think of the best judges or physicians—whose formal commitment to do what is right actually sharpens their attention to particulars, precisely because they know that correct moral judgment depends on grasping concrete facts. Likewise, a person who consciously regulates her conduct by the categorical imperative could still feel love, compassion, or grief; nothing prevents the coexistence of de dicto and de re motivations.

2. The “silencing” misdiagnosis.  
Sometimes the fetishism charge is that the de dicto motive “silences” the other motives, turning concern for persons into mere instrumental triggers. But there is an alternative model: the duty motive can operate as a higher-order governance motive, regulating first-order impulses while still allowing them to supply the phenomenological color of action. On this picture, the duty motive need not crowd out more concrete concerns; it can coordinate them.

III. Three Conditions for Praiseworthy Duty

Condition 1: Integration in Practical Identity  
Consider two duty-motivated agents:

   a. Obsessive Calvin compulsively asks before every minor choice, “What is the morally right option?” He feels panic if he cannot calculate an answer.
   
   b. Deliberative Ada recognizes that morality rightly governs action, yet she is not consumed by anxious scruples. Doing the right thing is one strand of her identity among others (friend, scientist, neighbor). When conflicts emerge, duty has priority, but it does not eradicate her other attachments.

Only Ada’s orientation is poised for moral worth. The key difference is whether the duty motive fits coherently into a balanced identity. Integration allows the agent to register reasons of friendship or love as genuine reasons, which in turn informs her moral deliberation. Obsessive Calvin’s motive is brittle; it reflects fear and self-concern more than respect for reason. Thus the first condition: the agent’s moral motive must arise from a stable, unified self rather than pathological anxiety. When this is satisfied, the duty motive is a sign of moral maturity, not fetishism.

Condition 2: Epistemic Reliability  
Praiseworthy duty requires true beliefs about what morality demands. An agent who leaps into icy water “because it is right,” when in fact it recklessly endangers a rescue boat, lacks moral worth; the action is morally wrong despite sincere duty motive. Similarly, an agent who gets it right only by luck—whose duty judgments are a coin toss—does not fully manifest moral agency. She is like a blind archer who hits the target accidentally. Moral worth supervenes on epistemic competence: reasonably justifiable belief, sensitivity to evidence, openness to criticism. This point is not unique to duty motives; any motive can misfire epistemically. But acknowledging it disarms a portion of the fetishism charge: failure of epistemic reliability, not the de dicto structure, explains many cases of defective moral agency.

Condition 3: Reason-Guided Sensitivity to Particulars  
Finally, the duty motive must be reason-responsive in the following sense: it must guide the agent to seek out, weigh, and apply the concrete considerations that ground what is right. If Tom cares only about the fact that “the manual says so,” he may feel exonerated from understanding. That sort of legalistic attitude would indeed be fetishistic. By contrast, a well-formed duty motive drives the agent to ask: “What makes this right? How do the human stakes look from each angle?” A command-following mindset is replaced by an aspirational, deliberative posture. In that posture, the abstract desire to do right functions as a demand for practical understanding, not a substitute for it.

These three conditions jointly answer the fetishism worry. A person who satisfies them is not alienated from human concerns; she is the very model of a responsible moral agent: integrated, epistemically competent, and attuned to reasons.

IV. Why Praise Is Due

Suppose an agent meets the three conditions. Why say her action is morally worthy? There are two lines of argument—one Kantian, one broadly Aristotelian—and they converge.

1. The Kantian line: Expressing respect for the moral law.  
On Kant’s account, the moral law is not merely a set of external commands; it is the form of legislation our rational nature gives itself. To act because it is right is to express autonomy: the agent’s will is determined by a law she recognises as issuing from her own rational capacity. That is praiseworthy because it embodies the fundamental dignity of persons as self-legislators. Notice that this Kantian celebration of duty is not cold or dismissive of particular values. Rather, it affirms that all values gain their normative authority through the structure of practical reason. A person who acts from duty, in Kant’s sense, shows esteem for every rational being, since the Categorical Imperative makes universal law-giving its test.

2. The Aristotelian line: Realizing one’s virtue through practical wisdom.  
On an Aristotelian picture, the virtues are stable dispositions that enable an agent to perceive saliences in ethically salient ways. Practical wisdom (phronēsis) integrates those dispositions under the guidance of reason. When an Aristotelian phronimos reasons “This is what virtue requires,” that thought is recognisably a de dicto moral thought—even if it is immediately accompanied by compassion, justice, or generosity. Because practical wisdom is a rational excellence, an explicit recognition “I ought to do this” can itself constitute the virtue’s conscious act. Here the worry about fetishism dissipates: the de dicto element is no alien interloper, but the articulable aspect of a fully virtuous state. We praise the agent because she achieves harmony between her rational capacities and her cultivated sentiments.

V. Replies to Remaining Objections

Objection 1: The duty motive crowds out love.  
Reply: The empirical psychology suggests coexistence. Parents who explain that they discipline a child “because it’s what responsible parents do” commonly feel intense love. The presence of an explicit normative framework does not expel affection; it contextualizes it.

Objection 2: Moral worth is higher when one acts from love without thinking of morality at all.  
Reply: Cases differ. It is admirable when someone spontaneously runs to save a stranger out of compassion. Yet we also esteem figures—Martin Luther King Jr., Gandhi—who cited moral duty explicitly. Their articulated commitment did not diminish praise; indeed it often heightened it by manifesting deliberateness and principled resolve. Moreover, we need ethically mature agents who can act rightly when warm sentiments are absent or even pulling the other way. A duty motive that steadies action under adverse affective conditions is a mark of integrity, not deficit.

Objection 3: The de dicto description is explanatorily inert; the real explanatory work is done by concrete reasons.  
Reply: This confuses causal and rational explanation. Causally, an agent’s grasp of another’s pain may trigger compassion. Rationally, the agent still needs the bridge principle “moral reasons are decisive” to convert perception into commitment. The duty motive supplies that principle, ensuring that the agent will comply even when compassion wanes or when competing incentives tempt.

Objection 4: Duty-based motivation encourages moralism and judgmental attitudes.  
Reply: That danger arises only if the agent pairs her duty motive with egoistic comparison or self-righteousness. Under the integration condition, the duty motive will express humility: “I too am bound by reasons; I cannot exempt myself.” When properly shaped, it fosters solidarity, not condemnation.

VI. Implications for Moral Education

If the above analysis is correct, moral educators should not shy away from cultivating an explicit sense of duty. Two practical corollaries follow.

1. Teach the concept of a moral requirement alongside empathy.  
Children can grasp ideas like fairness and promise-keeping. When they learn that such considerations are categorically important, they acquire a duty motive that can later regulate emerging capacities and desires.

2. Encourage reflection on principles, not merely feelings.  
Campaigns that rely solely on empathy are vulnerable to scope limitations—proximity bias, identifiable-victim effects, partiality. A principled duty orientation can expand the moral circle and stabilize conduct across fluctuating affect.

VII. Conclusion

Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth, provided the agent’s motive is integrated, epistemically sound, and reason-responsive to particulars. Far from involving fetishism or alienation, such action expresses respect for the authority of moral reasons and the dignity of persons.
