When the three background conditions are met, the duty motive contributes uniquely to praise: it manifests autonomy, principled steadfastness, and the capacity to deliberate with universal concern. The philosophical impulse to discredit duty in favour of more “human” motives overlooks the ways in which duty, properly understood, is a profoundly human achievement.

Can sheer devotion to “doing the morally right thing” confer genuine moral worth on an action, or must one’s motive reach all the way down to the “right-making features” themselves—concern for another’s welfare, respect for her autonomy, appreciation of aesthetic value, and the like? This question sits at the intersection of moral psychology and normative ethics, for it concerns not the deontic status of conduct (whether it is right) but the evaluative status of the agent (whether she deserves praise). The worry, voiced by Michael Stocker, Susan Wolf, Nomy Arpaly, and others, is that a purely de dicto motive—“I want, whatever it is, to do the right thing”—displays a kind of moral fetishism. Such an agent seems alienated both from the concrete considerations that ground morality and from the people to whom those considerations are owed. On this view, moral worth requires a de re motive: “I help because this person is in need,” not “because it is right to help.”

I shall argue that the critics have a point about what is normatively ideal, yet they overstate their case about sufficiency. Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed be morally worthy, provided that (1) the de dicto desire is the product of an agent’s own reflective endorsement, (2) the agent is reliably responsive to the moral facts, and (3) the decision issues from respect for persons rather than from anxiety, self-interest, or pathological scrupulosity. Under these conditions a dutiful action is praiseworthy because it manifests the agent’s practical recognition of morality’s authority; it embodies autonomy, unconditional commitment, and a readiness to sacrifice self-interest in deference to objective value. Although richer motives often add aesthetic or relational value, they are not conceptually required for moral worth.

1. De dicto and de re motives

Let us clarify the terrain. A de re desire is directed at a particular property: “I want to alleviate Mary’s hunger.” A de dicto desire is propositionally framed: “I want to do whatever is morally right.” A person can, of course, have both: “I want to help Mary because I want to do what’s right, and helping Mary is right.” The critics focus on cases where the de re component is absent or motivationally inert. Imagine a dutiful bureaucrat who donates 10 % of his income solely because “the rules of morality require it”; he feels no compassion for the beneficiaries and perhaps views them with indifference.

Moral worth, as conceived by Kant and many contemporary Kantians, is a second-order evaluation: it concerns whether an action “proceeds from duty” and thus reveals a good will. Such worth is distinct from supererogatory excellence or sainthood. Even if the motive of duty is austere, Kant insists, it suffices to place the agent “above all price” in moral esteem. Critics counter that a good will cannot be disconnected from the substance of moral reasons; moral motivation must track what matters about human beings, not merely that morality commands something about them.

2. The charge of fetishism

The fetishism objection comes in two flavors:

a) Epistemic alienation. If an agent acts only because an abstract moral rule instructs her, she does not grasp why the rule has the authority it does. Her behavior therefore lacks the sensitivity that we normally associate with moral understanding. She is like someone who follows the results of a math oracle without grasping how the proofs go.

b) Affective alienation. Even if the agent grasps that morality has to do with people’s needs, her motivational structure is “one thought too many.” When a friend is drowning, the admirable motive seems to be direct concern for the friend, not first consulting a moral principle.

These objections are potent against certain caricatures of the Kantian moralist—dry, rigid, rule-worshipping. But they need refining if they are to dislodge the more nuanced Kantian picture in which respect for the moral law is itself a form of practical engagement with persons as ends in themselves. The key question is whether an abstract orientation toward rightness necessarily entails ignorance of, or indifference to, the concrete values rightness tracks. I think not.

3. De dicto desire as principled practical identity

Consider three agents who refrain from lying for personal gain:

• Prudential Sam fears getting caught.

• Empathic Emma recoils at the idea of betraying another’s trust.

• Dutiful Dana senses that lying is morally forbidden, and that it would be wrong, full stop.

Dana’s reason might seem thin next to Emma’s, yet it tells us something impressive: she is disposed to subordinate self-interest to a norm even when she feels no natural sympathy. This is not fetishistic unless the norm is arbitrary or the agent fetishizes its mere form. But morality, properly understood, is not arbitrary; its content is fundamentally about respect and concern. Thus Dana’s de dicto desire to do right is not isolated from the ethical point of view—it is that point of view, internalized as a practical identity. What is praiseworthy is precisely this practical identity: Dana has made morality her master value, her “ought” that trumps all others when they conflict.

4. Reliability and moral understanding

Still, one might worry that a de dicto desire, by itself, provides no guidance as to what is right. A scrupulous agent could as readily become a follower of a false morality. Here the sufficiency condition (2) above becomes salient: the agent must be reliably responsive to the moral facts in a way that is not merely accidental. Think of competence in chess. One can have a de dicto desire “to make the best chess move,” but without some grasp of chess strategy the desire will not generate good play. Likewise, a praiseworthy dutiful agent must possess a working understanding of moral considerations—an understanding that will normally include, though not be exhausted by, the recognition of others’ interests. In short, the de dicto desire must be epistemically responsible.

Note that such responsibility does not require the de re motive to be what provides motivational push at the moment of choice. The agent can abstract from particulars and still track them reliably, just as one can drive safely while mostly attending to the rules of the road rather than to each passer-by’s welfare.

5. Respect versus sentiment

A further complaint is that duty lacks warmth. Kant himself concedes that an action done “contrary to inclination, solely from duty” is especially revealing of good will; but critics think that a total absence of sympathy reveals a moral deficiency. Here we must distinguish two claims:

(i) Absence of fellow-feeling makes an agent less admirable all-things-considered.

(ii) Absence of fellow-feeling makes an action devoid of moral worth.

( i ) could be true while ( ii ) is false. Moral worth is an austere category. What earns it, on Kant’s view, is acting from the unconditional form of moral reason, such that a maxim could be willed as universal law. Empathy and care are welcome additions, and may enhance the aesthetic or relational value of an action, but they are not necessary to show respect for persons. Indeed, a rigorous sense of duty can be the only thing that restrains an otherwise callous individual; when it does, we often do regard her as praiseworthy for having overcome her indifference.

6. The problem of “one thought too many”

Bernard Williams asks us to imagine a husband who, when deciding whether to rescue his wife rather than a stranger, pauses to consider what morality requires. If his final motive is “because it is right,” something seems amiss. The husband should want, directly, to save the woman he loves. Does this show that de dicto motives cannot ground moral worth? Not necessarily. Two points:

First, Williams’s case targets normative priority, not sufficiency. Even if it is better—and relationally more fitting—for the husband to act from love, the fact that he would have done the right thing merely from duty still counts in his favor. Think of a backup system: we prefer that the computer never fail, but the backup’s existence is still laudable.

Second, many real-world situations involve conflicts among partialities. The impartial standpoint of duty offers a principled way to adjudicate when loves collide. Its value lies in stabilizing moral motivation across contexts, not in replacing all other motives.

7. The Kantian defense: autonomy and respect

Why is acting from duty intrinsically worthy? Kant’s answer is that it expresses autonomy: the agent legislates a maxim for herself under the idea of universal law. In doing so she accords equal respect to every rational being. This structural relation is independent of sympathy. Even if one does not feel another’s pain, one can recognize her as a co-legislator in the moral domain. The bare fact that a being has rational nature suffices to generate an authoritative claim on my will; responding to that claim from duty manifests reverence for the moral law.

Critics reply that abstract reverence is still not engagement with persons. But this objection underestimates the content built into the idea of autonomous legislation. To will a principle as law is to treat others not merely as data points but as addressees of law. Autonomy, on this view, is inherently relational.

8. De dicto motivation and the possibility of moral progress

History supplies cases where empathy was partial or misdirected, yet de dicto commitment to moral principle drove progress. Abolitionists who had never met slaves personally, suffragists who fought for the votes of people they considered socially inferior, or civil-rights lawyers motivated by constitutional principle rather than personal friendship—all these agents changed the world by acting from duty. Their motives were praiseworthy precisely because they transcended partial feeling and tracked a moral principle of equality.

9. Is a purely dutiful agent admirable?

Imagine a person who, though lacking warmth, consistently acts rightly out of a sense of obligation. Many would call her morally decent but not exemplary. That judgment is compatible with saying her actions still possess moral worth. Moral worth is a threshold concept: it locates the presence of a good will, not its maximal flourishing. Higher excellence may demand fully integrated, richly textured motives; but we can reserve praise for the dutiful minimalist without committing to her as a moral ideal.

10. Objections and replies

Objection 1: The de dicto motive is vulnerable to moral error; empathy is safer.

Reply: Empathy can misfire—consider nepotism or parochial bias. What matters is a reliable mechanism for tracking moral truth. A cultivated sense of duty, informed by critical reflection, offers exactly that.

Objection 2: Duty-based action is less motivationally efficient; people act better when they care.

Reply: Efficiency is a psychological question, not a criterion of worth. Moreover, many soldiers, doctors, and judges explicitly rely on conscience (duty) when personal attachment would be counterproductive or emotional energy is exhausted.

Objection 3: Praising duty fetishizes abstract law and discourages emotional growth.

Reply: Recognizing duty’s sufficiency does not preclude encouraging richer motives. One can say: “You did well; next time try to feel with the victim.” The first praise acknowledges moral worth; the second encourages moral development.

11. A hybrid account

While defending sufficiency, I concede that duty unaccompanied by concern can leave value on the table. A plausible moral psychology adopts a layered view:

• Level 1: Right action (objective).

• Level 2: Good will—commitment to do right (de dicto sufficiency).

• Level 3: Virtuous character—spontaneous alignment of sentiments, capacities for empathy, phronesis.

Level 2 secures moral worth; Level 3 achieves virtue’s fullness. Everyday moral appraisal typically tracks Level 3, which is why the critics’ examples have intuitive force. But philosophical analysis must keep these layers conceptually apart lest we collapse all praise into perfection.

12. Conclusion

Can acting solely from duty suffice for moral worth? Yes—when “duty” is understood not as blind rule-worship but as the agent’s autonomous, reflectively endorsed commitment to do what is objectively right, coupled with epistemic competence in recognizing what rightness demands. Such action is praiseworthy because it manifests respect for the moral law and the readiness to treat others as ends even when one’s inclinations run cold. This does not deny the additional value of empathy or love, nor does it exalt pure duty as the moral summit. It simply acknowledges that the moral point of view, apprehended in its universality, carries its own distinctive dignity. In a world where partial sympathies often conflict and sometimes fail, the motive of duty remains an indispensable—and morally worthy—anchor of human conduct.

1. Introduction  

For nearly half a century, the central dispute in epistemology has been over the nature of epistemic justification. One venerable position, often called access internalism, maintains that in order for a belief to be justified the subject must be able to cite, or at least be consciously aware of, the reasons that justify it. Commitment to such awareness seems to mesh neatly with our ordinary conception of responsible belief-holding. If you ask me why I believe there is a dog in the yard, a perfectly proper answer is, “Because I can see it.” Failures of justification typically coincide with failures of answerability: the conspiracy theorist cannot supply reasons that withstand minimal scrutiny. Yet advances in cognitive science have revealed that a large share of human information-processing is fast, automatic, modular, and outside phenomenal consciousness. We seamlessly infer three-dimensional shape from binocular disparity, compute the direction of sound from micro-second arrival-time differences at the ears, and update our expectations about other people’s reliability in split-second social cognition—usually without the faintest inkling of how the relevant evidence is being handled. The question, then, is stark: Does absence of conscious awareness of one’s reasons deprive the resulting mental states of epistemic basing, and hence of epistemic status? Or can a genuinely epistemic basing relation obtain sub-personal, beneath the subject’s ken?

I shall argue for the latter. Conscious access to one’s reasons, though epistemically valuable and sometimes required for higher-order achievements such as understanding, is not necessary for first-order epistemic justification or knowledge. A mental state can be based on epistemic reasons that are not consciously accessible provided (i) the belief-forming process is appropriately reasons-responsive, (ii) the evidential factors figure in the etiology of the belief in the right way—namely, as the normal explaining causes that make the belief intelligible as a response to them—and (iii) the process is not defeated by anything else in the subject’s total cognitive economy. I proceed as follows. Section 2 clarifies the central notions: epistemic reasons, the basing relation, and conscious awareness. Section 3 reconstructs the Awareness Requirement and the principal arguments marshalled on its behalf. Section 4 presents four familiar but potent counter-examples drawn from ordinary perception, implicit statistical learning, artificial split-brain scenarios, and non-human animal cognition. Section 5 develops a positive account of non-conscious epistemic basing that honours the guiding intuitions behind internalism while rejecting the demand for occurrent awareness. Section 6 addresses two residual objections concerning epistemic responsibility and deviant causal chains. Section 7 concludes.

2. Concepts on the Table

2.1 Epistemic reasons.  Call p an epistemic reason for S to believe q just in case p bears an evidential relation to q (e.g., probabilistic support, explanatory connection) and is, at least in principle, capable of justifying S’s belief that q. Whether reasons are facts, propositions, mental states, or experiences is not material for the present debate; what matters is that they be the sorts of things that can support truths and guide belief formation.

2.2 The basing relation.  Even if p is a reason to believe q, S’s belief that q is not automatically justified; S’s belief must in some sense be based upon, or held because of, that reason. The challenge is to articulate a relation that is stronger than mere causal influence (since deviant chains abound) yet weaker than a conceptual entailment (since fallible inference is possible).

2.3 Conscious awareness.  Let us distinguish (a) occurrent phenomenal awareness—p’s contents figure in one’s current stream of consciousness—from (b) accessibility awareness—the disposition, upon reflection, to become conscious of p and to deploy p in reasoning. Defenders of the Awareness Requirement typically have something close to (a) or a mixture of (a) and (b) in mind, because they wish to guarantee that the believer can attend to the justificatory ground.

3. The Awareness Requirement and Its Rationale

The Awareness Requirement (AR): A subject S’s belief that q is epistemically based on reason p only if S is consciously aware, at the time of belief, of p as her reason for q.

Three main lines of thought support AR.

1. The Responsibility Argument.  Justification is supposed to be the kind of property for which we can properly demand reasons. If S cannot cite or even access her grounds, how can she be answerable for her belief? Absence of awareness seems to undermine doxastic responsibility.

2. The Deviance Argument.  Unless the subject sees the evidential connection, any causal dependence of belief on putative reasons might be merely accidental (e.g., belief caused by a brain lesion that also causes those data). Conscious endorsement guards against deviant causal chains.

3. The Phenomenological Intuition.  When epistemically ideal agents—reflective scientists, for instance—form beliefs, they introspectively note the evidence that supports the belief. That phenomenology is deemed constitutive of epistemic basing.

These arguments are powerful, but none is decisive. To see why, consider counter-examples drawn from everyday and scientific cases that strain AR to breaking point.

4. Challenging AR: Four Case Families

4.1 Standard perceptual belief. You glance at a table and form the belief “There is a red mug.” Visual processing from retinal stimulation to category recognition proceeds through at least twenty levels of cortical analysis. At no stage are you aware of the reconstructed chromatic edges or the statistical priors used to disambiguate illumination. Your phenomenology simply presents a mug. Yet surely your belief is epistemically justified and based on the visual appearance. Demanding conscious awareness of the underlying grounds misdescribes ordinary perception.

Some internalists reply that the conscious visual experience itself is the reason: one need not grasp the low-level cues, only the resulting appearance. But now vary the case.

4.2 Subtle perceptual discrimination. Expert bird-watchers can tell apart nearly identical species “at a glance.” When pressed, they confess an inability to articulate what features make the difference; their experiential gestalt does not decompose into explicit reasons. Still, their discriminatory beliefs enjoy justification. If conscious awareness were required, we would have to deny that the veteran ornithologist knows which bird she confronts—an implausible verdict.

4.3 Implicit statistical learning. Subjects exposed to sequences generated by complex artificial grammars acquire sensitivity to permissible strings. Asked to classify new sequences, they perform well above chance while sincerely claiming to guess. Here the “reason”—the statistical structure of previously experienced strings—operates sub-personally. There is accumulating evidence that such learning undergirds language acquisition, social cognition, and more. Eliminating epistemic status for all beliefs shaped by implicit statistical learning amounts to global epistemic skepticism.

4.4 Blindsight and unperceived perception. Some cortical lesion patients can localize stimuli in their blind field, reporting no visual experience whatsoever. Blindsight is controversial terrain: are the patients merely guessing, or do they possess a thin form of justification? Suppose a blindsight subject learns, by feedback, that her hunches are highly reliable; she comes to believe that the stimulus is at location L because of that subtle signal. The signal’s content is unconscious, yet if the subject knows the reliability statistics and forms beliefs accordingly, the resulting states seem epistemically creditable. A strict AR cannot accommodate this possibility.

4.5 Non-human animals and preverbal children. Chimpanzees who hide when a dominant approaches demonstrate belief-like representations about others’ line of sight. They cannot entertain metacognitive awareness of the reasons; nevertheless, their states plausibly count as knowledge enabling adaptive behavior. Likewise, young children and human infants acquire object permanence and causal expectations prior to articulable awareness. Relegating all these cases to the epistemic basement appears ad hoc.

In each family of cases, the believer lacks (a)-type phenomenal awareness of the evidential grounds. Yet the beliefs seem to be formed because of the evidence in a way that secures justification or knowledge. What, then, is doing the epistemic work if not conscious awareness?

5. A Positive Account: Reasons-Responsive Functionalism

I propose to replace AR with a functional basing condition:

Functional Basing (FB): S’s belief that q is epistemically based on reason p if and only if (i) p figures in the normal etiological pathway that produces q in S, (ii) the belief-forming mechanism M is such that, across a range of relevant counterfactual situations, M would modify or withhold q in response to variations in p, and (iii) no undefeated defeaters, accessible to S, obtain.

Clause (i) captures the causal relevance of p. Clause (ii) spells out reasons-responsiveness: it makes clear that p is not merely an accidental cause but the systematic ground that would, under varying conditions, continue to guide S. Clause (iii) imports a weak internalist constraint: if S has conscious access to information that undermines p, she ought not ignore it on pain of blameworthiness.

FB vindicates the epistemic status of beliefs produced by modular or automatic processes, provided those processes track the appropriate evidential features. The processes need not surface in consciousness; their rationality is secured by their functional sensitivity. Conscious awareness, then, becomes a sufficient but not necessary condition for first-order justification.

The resulting view marries the strengths of externalism and internalism. Like reliabilism, it honours the insight that sub-personal reliability matters. Like internalism, it accords a role to the subject’s perspective via defeater-responsiveness; a subject who consciously learns that her perceptual system is compromised (say, by hallucination-inducing drugs) thereby loses justification.

6. Two Objections Answered

6.1 The Responsibility Worry. If S is unaware of her reasons, in what sense is she responsible? Here we must differentiate two kinds of epistemic responsibility: (a) basic compliance responsibility, which attaches to the proper functioning of one’s cognitive faculties; and (b) reflective responsibility, which kicks in once one has the conceptual resources to appraise one’s grounds. Infants and non-human animals enjoy (a) but not (b). Normal adults possess both, but (a) suffices for certain epistemic statuses. Even in reflective agents, automatic perception supplies prima facie justification, which can be subsequently preserved or defeated by reflective processes. Hence absence of initial awareness does not erase all responsibility; it merely locates responsibility at the level of maintaining healthy cognitive systems, not at the level of active citation.

6.2 The Deviant Causal Chain Worry. Suppose a microchip implants in S traces of p in just those cases where q happens to be true; S forms belief q accordingly, unaware of the chip. Is the belief justified? Our functional account denies it, because the belief-forming mechanism is not reasons-responsive in the right way. Variations in p would not modulate q absent the chip’s machinations; thus clause (ii) is unmet. Requirements of systematic counterfactual dependence screen off deviant causal chains without appealing to consciousness.

7. Epistemic Value of Conscious Awareness

Although not necessary for basing, conscious awareness has independent epistemic value. First, it enables higher-order justification: knowing that one knows, possessing understanding, providing explanations. Second, it allows rational integration of diverse evidential streams; we can weigh visual appearance against testimonial defeaters only because both can become conscious. Third, it grounds second-personal answerability: we can give others our reasons, thereby participating in collective deliberation. The present thesis is thus modest: it denies only that awareness is constitutive of the basing relation. It affirms its importance for other epistemic virtues.

8. Conclusion

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? No. Empirical evidence from perception, implicit learning, and comparative cognition, together with theoretical considerations about reasons-responsiveness, show that first-order justification can proceed through sub-personal mechanisms that never break the surface of consciousness. Insisting on occurrent awareness either disqualifies a vast swath of plainly justified beliefs or forces an implausibly intellectualized savour of ordinary epistemic life. A better option is to recognise two tiers of epistemic standing. At the first tier—basic justification and knowledge—what matters is that the cognitive system reliably and systematically responds to genuine evidence. At the second tier—reflective justification, understanding, and answerability—conscious awareness plays a pivotal role. By adopting this layered model we reconcile the epistemic potency of modular, automatic cognition with the intuitive appeal of internalist concerns for responsibility and rational reflection.

1. Introduction  

Ordinary epistemic practice encourages us to ask people why they believe what they do and to withdraw credit when they cannot answer.  On the surface, this custom seems to vindicate the Consciousness Requirement (CR): a mental state enjoys the distinctively epistemic standing of being justified only if the subject is, or at least can easily become, consciously aware of the reasons on which the state is based.  Yet contemporary cognitive science portrays much of our cognitive life as the product of quick-fire, modular, and often opaque information-processing routines.  Chess grandmasters “see” the right move, radiologists “just spot” a tumor, and nearly everyone can tell, without being able to articulate why, that a photograph has been doctored.  If CR is correct, these impressive performances either fail to be epistemically creditable or are so only because an unnoticed ingredient of conscious reasoning lurks in the background.  Conversely, if such performances are genuinely epistemic, CR must be rejected or modified.  

In what follows I argue that lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons does not in general preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons.  More carefully: the epistemic basing relation is fundamentally subpersonal and causal; consciousness of one’s reasons can enhance justification—especially in reflective contexts—but it is not constitutive of basing and, hence, not a necessary condition of epistemic status.  I proceed by (i) clarifying the notions of basing, reasons, and consciousness at issue; (ii) laying out the strongest motivations for CR; (iii) bringing forward four lines of counterevidence; (iv) developing a positive, reasons-responsive account of basing compatible with cognitive modularity; and (v) answering residual objections.  The conclusion is that epistemic agency, like moral agency, depends on the ability to respond appropriately to normative reasons, not on the standing presence of such reasons in the stream of consciousness.

2. Explicating the Key Terms  

2.1. Epistemic basing.  A mental state M of S (most paradigmatically, a belief that p) is based on a reason R when R is not merely a reason there is for S to hold M but is the reason for which S holds M.  Philosophers standardly distinguish the “for-which” relation from mere causal production by requiring that R stand in the “right kind” of causal relation to M (Alston 1989; Korcz 2000).  

2.2. Epistemic justification.  I follow the mainstream in assuming that justified beliefs are, in the first instance, beliefs formed and sustained in a way that is good from the point of view of truth (or knowledge, reliability, accuracy, etc.).  Competing internalist and externalist theories differ over which conditions make for such “good” epistemic pedigrees.  

2.3. Conscious awareness.  To keep the issue clear, I stipulate that a subject is consciously aware of a reason just in case (a) the reason, or a representation thereof, is occurrent in phenomenal consciousness, and (b) the subject has epistemic access to it under the relevant description (the content for which the reason counts).  Alternative, weaker notions—such as mere dispositional accessibility—will figure later, but CR is most naturally read as demanding occurrent phenomenal consciousness.  

2.4. Modular, automatic cognition.  By a modular process I mean a computational routine characterized by relative informational encapsulation, domain specificity, and rapid, mandatory operation (Fodor 1983).  Automatic processes are typically stimulus-driven and proceed largely outside executive control.

3. The Motivations for the Consciousness Requirement  

(1) Responsibility Considerations.  We praise and blame people for beliefs and inferences when they can cite their reasons; opacity undermines intellectual responsibility (cf. Smithies 2019).  

(2) Transparency of Justification.  According to classical internalism, justification supervenes on “what is in the subject’s mind that is immediately accessible to reflection” (Conee & Feldman 2004).  If the reasons that justify you are not reflectively accessible, you are in no position to tell whether you are justified—an uncomfortable result for anti-skeptical purposes.  

(3) The Basing-Demand Argument.  For an agent to count as basing her belief on the premises, the agent must actually take or treat those premises as support.  “Taking” is an intentional action; intentional actions are, by definition, performed knowingly and intentionally; therefore, conscious awareness of the premises is required (Silva 2018).  

(4) Intuition.  When I believe a proposition merely because of a pill that forces me to hold it, I am clearly not basing my belief on the pill-induced propositional attitude, even if, by coincidence, that attitude is epistemically good.  The absence of conscious endorsement seems crucial.

These motivations deserve serious weight.  Nonetheless, each faces difficulties once we attend to empirical and phenomenological data.

4. Counterevidence to CR  

4.1. Perceptual Justification without Reason Articulation  

Perceptual beliefs are paradigmatically justified, yet the ordinary perceiver is unable to articulate the reasons for them.  I see a red apple; I form the belief that there is a red apple before me.  If pressed, I might say, “Because I see it,” but seeing it is not a consciously apprehended syllogism.  The deliverances of the visual system are presented as already-integrated content, not as explicitly cited premises (see Lyons 2009).  Since perceptual belief is typically taken to be justified, lack of reason-awareness cannot be sufficient for unjustification.  

4.2. Expert Intuition and Rapid Inference  

Chess masters reliably judge positions in a flash; firefighters “sense” that a building is about to collapse.  Studies indicate that these judgments are the result of pattern-matching and statistical learning, not step-by-step conscious inference (Kahneman & Klein 2009).  Denying experts epistemic credit because their subpersonal pattern recognizers are unconscious threatens to devalue a vast tract of human expertise.  

4.3. Developmental and Comparative Considerations  

Children and many non-human animals form beliefs and act on the basis of evidence to which they lack conscious access.  Kittens learn to avoid open edges by extracting depth cues; blue jays infer the presence of camouflaged moths.  If CR bars such creatures from ever having justified states, we risk an implausibly intellectualized picture of epistemic status (Burge 2010).  

4.4. Cognitive Neuroscience of Memory Retrieval  

Memory reconsolidation research shows that retrieval cues automatically trigger complex backend processing that reconstructs memories (Roediger & McDermott 1995).  In many cases, we do not—and could not—consciously track which sub-threshold cues drove a retrieval.  Yet ordinary memory beliefs are central to our justified cognition.

These four lines of data draw the same moral: everyday epistemic life depends on cognitive mechanisms whose operations rarely surface in consciousness.  Either most of our beliefs lack justification—a disastrous skepticism—or CR must be relaxed.

5. A Reasons-Responsive Account of Epistemic Basing  

5.1. Causal, Non-Coincidental Dependence  

To capture the “right kind” of causation between R and M, we follow the reasons-responsiveness tradition (Fischer & Ravizza 1998; Arpaly 2003).  A belief is based on R when (i) R causes M in the actual world, and (ii) in nearby possible worlds where R is absent or changes in strength, M correspondingly varies.  This counterfactual sensitivity ensures that R is not a mere enabling or accidental cause.  

5.2. No Consciousness Requirement, but an Agency Condition  

The proposed account locates basing at the subpersonal level but keeps room for epistemic agency: an agent counts as sensitive to reasons when her cognitive architecture is disposed to treat them as inputs in rationally appropriate ways.  Conscious recognition is one means of implementing such sensitivity, but not the only means.  Modular computations qualify provided that their functional role tracks truth-conducive relations.  Thus perceptual modules genuinely “take” sensory data as evidence for distal properties, though they do so non-conceptually.  

5.3. Structural and Dispositional Inclusiveness  

To mollify the internalist worry about guidance and reflection, we supplement the account with a dispositional accessibility clause: if the subject were to engage in sincere reflective inquiry, she would usually be able to supply at least partial, though possibly schematic, justificatory considerations.  For instance, the radiologist might articulate vague shape or shading cues under questioning, even if she did not consciously notice them while forming the judgment.  The clause secures a form of reflective control without demanding the impossible: real-time awareness of every subpersonal contribution.

6. Meeting the CR Motivations Revisited  

6.1. Responsibility  

Epistemic responsibility requires that a subject be able to revise or sustain beliefs under pressure of reasons, not that she was occurrently aware of all relevant reasons at formation time.  If the firefighter can articulate experience-based heuristics after the fact, or revise her judgment when presented counter-evidence, she is sufficiently responsible.  

6.2. Transparency  

Access internalists worry that agents cannot know whether they are justified when the justifying grounds are unconscious.  But meta-justificatory knowledge can be mediated: I can know that my visual system is generally reliable even if I cannot cite the specific wavelength inputs that generated a given percept.  Similarly, I can know that my memory is mostly trustworthy or that medical training underwrites my diagnostic hunches.  Such higher-order reliability beliefs provide the reflective reassurance internalists seek.  

6.3. Taking-as Support  

The “taking” model conflates two senses of agency: personal-level endorsement and subpersonal computational treatment.  In brain-computer interfaces, we grant that the hardware “takes” voltage changes as data even though the device lacks consciousness.  Analogously, a cognitive module “takes” retinal stimulation as evidence for an apple.  Human rational agency is scaffolded by many such subroutines; personal-level endorsement occurs only at selected bottlenecks (usually those requiring cross-module integration or strategic planning).  

6.4. Intuitive Objections  

The pill case feels problematic because the causal etiology bypasses sensitivity to epistemic reasons; the pill functions indiscriminately.  The account offered explains the contrast: the epistemic agent endowed with reasons-responsive modules occupies a counterfactual structure in which truth-related inputs modulate belief; the pill-induced subject does not.

7. Potential Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Without consciousness, how do we rule out deviant causal chains?  Suppose a hypnotist whispers “Believe p!” and, by coincidence, the hypnotic suggestion tracks the evidence.  Our account yields the correct result because nearby worlds in which the hypnotist does not issue the command still contain the evidential situation, but the belief fails to form.  Hence sensitivity fails.  

Objection 2: The view licenses epistemic basing in insects and thermostats, trivializing justification.  Reply: Reasons-responsiveness is necessary but not sufficient; the system must possess representational states with alethic content and be integrated into a larger agentive architecture capable of criticism and correction.  Insects arguably satisfy a weak version; thermostats do not.  Drawing the line is an empirical matter but no more worrisome than in moral philosophy where agency comes in degrees.  

Objection 3: The proposal collapses into externalist reliabilism and abandons the normative aspect of reasons.  Reply: Reasons-responsiveness is more demanding than mere reliability.  A reliable clairvoyant faculty that is sealed off from other cognitive processes is insensitive to counterevidence; it fails the counterfactual modulation test.  Normativity re-enters via the requirement that the system be disposed to treat considerations with the right logical or evidential profile as inputs and to adjust its outputs accordingly.  

Objection 4: Cognitive architecture could be wired so that a reliable module supports prejudice (e.g., a face perception system that mistakes neutral expressions in certain ethnic groups as hostile due to biased training data).  Isn’t that evidence-sensitive yet epistemically defective?  Answer: Such a module is systematically mis-responsive to reasons—it tracks superficial correlates, not genuine hostility.  Its outputs, though causally reason-linked in a weak sense, are not based on epistemic reasons because the counterfactual condition is violated: in worlds where the superficial correlate remains but the ground truth of hostility changes, the module does not adjust.  The structure is insufficiently attuned to the truth-making factors.

8. Implications for Modular and Automatic Processes  

The defended position vindicates the epistemic significance of modular cognition.  The visual system converts photon patterns into depth representations; the speech-perception module converts auditory waves into phonemes; Bayesian amalgamations consolidate uncertain data.  Each is, in its own sphere, a reasons-responsive mechanism.  Conscious awareness often zeroes in at “late selection” stages to integrate, weigh, or dispute the outputs, but the pipeline’s earlier stages already possess epistemic import.  

This picture also elucidates epistemic criticism.  When a module misfires—say, in certain optical illusions—we are prepared to override its deliverance once we detect a mismatch with higher-level expectations or cross-modal evidence.  The capacity for such correction, not the initial presence of consciousness, underwrites our status as responsible epistemic agents.

9. Conclusion  

Philosophical pressure to tie justification to conscious awareness stems from laudable concerns about responsibility, autonomy, and anti-skeptical assurance.  Nevertheless, the Cognitive Science of the last half-century makes it increasingly clear that the stream of consciousness reveals but a thin editorial selection of the inferential labor that sustains our epistemic lives.  If we insist on CR, we are forced either to deny justification to most ordinary beliefs or to imagine ubiquitous hidden conscious premises—neither option is palatable.

A more plausible approach locates epistemic basing in the counterfactually robust, reasons-responsive causal relations between evidential states and belief.  Conscious access is sufficient but not necessary: justificatory status permeates subpersonal life provided the cognitive system is reliably sensitive to the truth-makers.  Humans earn the title of epistemic agents not because every piece of reasoning marches under the spotlight of awareness, but because they possess a layered architecture capable of incorporating reasons at multiple levels and of revising outputs when things go wrong.

Accordingly, modular, automatic cognitive processes can indeed instantiate genuine epistemic basing.  They do so in virtue of the informational relations they encode and the systematic way those relations guide belief across actual and counterfactual circumstances.  Conscious reflection retains an important supervisory role, but it is the dynamic responsiveness to reasons—conscious or not—that ultimately underwrites epistemic justification. Lack of conscious awareness, therefore, does not preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on the reasons that in fact ground it.

1. Introduction  

Human cognition is a teeming mixture of conscious and unconscious activity. While some mental events—deliberating about career options, rehearsing a syllogism, recalling the premise of an argument—parade themselves before the mind’s eye, far more occur “in the dark”: the visual system parses depth, the language module assigns syntactic structure, associative mechanisms prime background expectations. Contemporary philosophy of mind and cognitive science typically depict these sub-personal, automatic operations as indispensable to thought. Yet many epistemologists, especially those in the broadly internalist tradition, insist that epistemic justification is essentially tied to the subject’s conscious awareness of her reasons. The guiding intuition is straightforward: if S cannot so much as entertain the grounds that allegedly support her belief, how could that belief be hers qua rational believer? We do not normally credit a person with rationally believing that p on the basis of q unless she can cite, reflect on, or at least “recognize” q as her reason.

The question before us presses this tension: Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? I shall argue, first, that the intuitive pull of the consciousness requirement is genuine and deserves explanation; second, that a strict awareness requirement is ultimately untenable given both empirical facts about cognition and the normative aims of epistemology; and third, that a defensible middle position—call it the dispositional awareness view—can respect the core internalist intuition while conceding that real‐world epistemic basing often proceeds without occurrent consciousness. The upshot is that modular, automatic cognitive processes can indeed ground epistemic statuses, though the story about how they do so must appeal to the agent’s standing capacities to appreciate their normative force.

2. The Consciousness Requirement Motivated  

Why think conscious awareness is required? Three principal arguments recur in the literature.

2.1. The Responsibility Argument  
Epistemic evaluation is, in part, a species of responsibility assessment. We praise and blame agents for forming beliefs responsibly or irresponsibly. But responsibility seems to require control, or at least reasons-responsive capacities that the agent can exercise. If S has no occurrent or potential access to the grounds for her belief, she cannot exercise control over whether or not to rely on them. Therefore, the belief cannot be assessed as epistemically justified or unjustified.

2.2. The Guidance Argument  
A reason is said to “guide” belief formation only if it can, in principle, be used by the agent in the regulation of her doxastic life—e.g., in revising, confirming, or abandoning the belief when confronting counter‐evidence. This regulative role seems to demand some form of consciousness; otherwise the believer would be flying blind with respect to her own cognitive economy.

2.3. The Transparency Phenomenology  
Introspectively, paradigmatic cases of rational belief feel accessible. When asked, “Why do you believe that the bridge is safe?”, the rational believer experiences her grounds “lighting up” in consciousness: “It was recently inspected, and I trust the engineer’s report.” This phenomenology fuels the thought that rational basing is essentially tied to such conscious recognition.

Taken together, these considerations push many philosophers—BonJour, Audi, Conee and Feldman, among others—to endorse some version of the Awareness Principle: S’s belief that p is justified (or epistemically based on r) only if S is at least implicitly aware of r.

3. The Empirical Counter-Evidence  

Against this principled stance, empirical work on perception, memory, and reasoning supplies a battery of counter-examples.

3.1. Perceptual Belief  
A normal visual belief—“there is a cup on the desk”—is underwritten by complex computations in early and mid-level vision. Subjects cannot articulate those computations (edge detection, object segmentation), yet the output beliefs enjoy paradigmatic perceptual justification. To claim that such beliefs are unjustified until the subject can become aware of sub-personal processing is to court skepticism about almost all perceptual knowledge.

3.2. Implicit Statistical Reasoning  
Gigerenzer and colleagues show that humans can exploit statistical regularities (e.g., the recognition heuristic) better than their explicit reasoning would predict. When choosing between two cities’ population sizes, subjects reliably pick the one they have heard of, tracking genuine demographic information. They cannot state the probabilistic reasoning, but the success rate indicates that the heuristic constitutes a kind of tacit evidential sensitivity.

3.3. Expert Intuition  
Chess grandmasters “see” optimal moves in milliseconds, physicians diagnose on the basis of subtle symptoms, and seasoned firefighters sense building collapse before explicit cues emerge. In each case, years of training have “compiled” patterns into rapid, unconscious discriminations that nonetheless carry epistemic weight. Discrediting those automatic inferences as unjustified would fail to honor the manifest expertise involved.

These cases reveal a tension: if conscious awareness is strictly necessary for epistemic basing, then a vast swath of what we ordinarily take to be justified belief would fall outside the epistemic domain. The internalist must either bite the sceptical bullet or find room for unconscious basing.

4. Disambiguating Awareness  

A promising way forward is to parse “awareness” more finely.

4.1. Occurrent vs. Standing  
Occurrent awareness is consciousness at the present moment. Standing (or dispositional) awareness refers to information that the agent could easily bring to mind upon reflection. I may not now be thinking about how I know my birthday, but the date is stored in memory and would surface when queried.

4.2. Personal‐Level vs. Sub-Personal  
Reasons at the personal level are the sorts of things the subject can cite: perceptions, memories, introspective states, intellectual seemings. Sub-personal “reasons” (if we stretch the term) are algorithmic data structures inaccessible to phenomenal consciousness. Perhaps epistemic basing requires personal‐level, but not necessarily occurrent, awareness.

4.3. Explicit vs. Tacit  
Some information is tacitly held: language speakers know grammatical rules without being able to state them. Tacit knowledge may still be personal‐level in the sense that it belongs to the agent’s cognitive repertoire, not just to modular circuitry.

With these distinctions in place, we can reconsider the initial motivation for the consciousness requirement. What the Responsibility and Guidance arguments really demand is personal-level availability, not continual phenomenal presence. That still leaves room for unconscious (non-phenomenal) but personally accessible reasons to undergird justification.

5. The Dispositional Awareness View  

On the dispositional awareness view (DAV), a belief is epistemically based on a reason r if:

1. r is a state or content that constitutively belongs to the subject’s personal‐level cognitive system (percept, memory, seeming, etc.).
2. S is not presently attending to r, but could, via ordinary reflection, avail herself of r without needing new evidence.
3. The cognitive process linking r and the belief is epistemically appropriate (e.g., reliable, truth‐conducive, or inference‐preserving).

Condition (2) satisfies responsibility: the agent retains rational control because she could survey her reasons when circumstances call for it. Condition (3) screens off deviant basing—mere causal influence is not enough.

DAV explains perceptual justification: the visual experience (“a cup appears here”) is personal-level and readily reportable, even though the computations generating it are sub-personal. It covers compiled expertise: the radiologist may articulate reasons (“a faint shadow on the lung”), though the pattern recognition is automatic. And it blocks problematic cases of brute causation: If hypnosis implants a belief without furnishing the subject with any personal‐level considerations, the belief lapses into irrationality.

6. Objections and Replies  

6.1. The Access Problem  
Critics protest that many implicit beliefs ride on factors the subject could not articulate even upon reflection—Gigerenzer’s recognition heuristic, for instance. Does DAV vindicate their justification?

Reply: What matters is whether reflection affords some personal‐level rationale, not whether the rationale is fully articulated. The subject can acknowledge: “I have heard of San Jose but not of Temecula; cities I’ve heard of tend to be larger.” Such coarse-grained reasons are within reflective reach. The underlying statistical frequencies remain sub-personal, but the heuristic’s evidential force is capturable enough for responsibility.

6.2. Bootstrapping Worries  
Reliabilists often confront “bootstrapping” problems: a belief might be reliably formed yet epistemically irresponsible if the subject ignores glaring defeaters. Does DAV collapse into reliabilism?

Reply: No. Condition (2) embeds an internalist check: the subject must be able to recognize defeaters. Suppose the visual system is reliable, but fog makes the perceptual cue misleading. Because the fog is itself perceptible, the agent can become aware of the undermining factor; failure to do so would render the belief unjustified. DAV thus avoids pure externalist pitfalls.

6.3. Excessive Demands  
One might accuse DAV of still being too demanding: children, animals, or marginally demented patients enjoy perceptual justification yet lack robust reflective capacities. Must we withhold justification from them?

Reply: Epistemic evaluation is a graded notion, sensitive to capacities typical of the thinker’s kind and developmental stage. A dog’s justification to believe that its owner is home may be minimal but genuine, grounded in olfactory and auditory cues. DAV can recognize “animal justification” by relativizing dispositional awareness to species‐appropriate abilities. What dogs lack is the higher-order concept of a reason; they nevertheless manifest first-order sensitivity that suffices for a thinner sense of epistemic credit. Human adults are held to higher standards precisely because they possess richer dispositional awareness.

7. The Case for Unconscious Basing  

Beyond defensive maneuvers, positive arguments support unconscious epistemic basing.

7.1. The Continuity of Cognitive Architecture  
Evolution has delivered us a hybrid mind: low-level modules feed into conscious deliberation, and the boundary is fluid. Epistemic norms should cohere with this architecture rather than impose unrealistic constraints. A strict awareness requirement would artificially sever two coordinated strata, treating one as epistemically inert despite its indispensability.

7.2. The Efficiency Norm  
Rationality, on an ecological conception, balances accuracy with cognitive economy. Automatic inference achieves high accuracy at low cost. Demanding conscious scrutiny of every inference would cripple this efficiency, overloading working memory and attention. A satisfactory epistemology must respect the bounded rationality of real agents.

7.3. Pragmatic Encroachment  
In high-stakes contexts, subjects often do deliberately reflect on their reasons; in low-stakes contexts, they rely on automatic heuristics. Epistemic norms that flexibly modulate in tandem with pragmatic import better capture our practices of ascription than rigid awareness rules.

8. Remaining Puzzles  

Two residual challenges merit mention.

8.1. The Swamping Problem  
If what ultimately matters is truth, why not dispense with any awareness requirement and embrace full-blown process reliabilism? Answer: truth is one epistemic good; another is the subject’s rational agency. DAV secures both by tying justification to dispositions enabling critical self‐correction.

8.2. The Regress of Reasons  
If basing requires potential awareness, does that lead to an infinite regress—awareness of one’s awareness, and so on? Not necessarily. The regress is blocked by basic reasons—distinctive experiences or seemings that have immediate justificatory force. DAV posits no need for higher-order endorsement of each step; rather, the agent merely stands ready to cite the next lower-order reason when queried.

9. Conclusion  

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? The answer is nuanced. Occurrent phenomenal awareness is not necessary; dispositional personal-level awareness suffices. This middle path honors the internalist insight that reasons must, in some real sense, be the agent’s own, while integrating the empirical reality that much rational cognition is modular, fast, and unconscious. Modular, automatic processes can indeed confer justificatory force—so long as they terminate in contents that the subject could, if prompted, recognize as carrying that force. Our epistemic lives, like our nervous systems, are layered; philosophical accounts should be too.

Does Lack of Conscious Awareness of One’s Reasons
                               Preclude a Mental State from Being Epistemically Based on Those Reasons?

1. Introduction  

Few topics in contemporary epistemology are as vexed as the “basing relation,” the relation that must obtain between a person’s reasons and the mental states—beliefs, judgments, perceptual seemings, and so on—that are said to be epistemically grounded in those reasons.  The basing relation is commonly supposed to explain why some doxastic states are justified (or unjustified, or rational, or knowledge‐apt) while others are mere accidents.  A central locus of current debate concerns whether a thinker must be consciously aware of her epistemic reasons in order for her beliefs to be based on them.  A venerable philosophical tradition—running through Descartes, Locke, and Kant, and resurfacing in twentieth-century access internalism—answers “yes”: justificatory status requires that the subject be able, by the mere exercise of reflection, to cite the grounds on which she believes.  In stark contrast, much recent work at the intersection of epistemology and cognitive science emphasizes the ubiquity of modular, automatic, and sub-personal processes that are not available to introspection yet seem to confer epistemic merit all the same.  Perceptual systems infer distal properties from proximal stimuli, language users unconsciously apply syntactic rules, and expert chess players instantaneously “see” that a position is lost—all with no conscious access to the reasons underwriting the relevant judgments.  Are such judgments therefore unjustified?  Or must we weaken the awareness requirement—or jettison it altogether—if we wish to accommodate the cognitive scientific picture?

In what follows I argue for four theses:

1. The strong awareness requirement—the claim that a thinker must consciously represent her reasons at the time of forming or holding a belief in order for that belief to be epistemically based—is untenable.  
2. A modest accessibility condition is nevertheless defensible: reasons that ground justification must in principle be available to the thinker’s conscious reflection, even if she is not currently aware of them.  
3. Epistemic basing is not exhausted by causal relations at the sub-personal level; it is a diachronic achievement that involves a thinker’s capacities for critical self-scrutiny and error-correction.  
4. Modular, automatic processes can bestow genuine justification provided they operate within a system that permits the thinker to take responsibility for their deliverances; the sub-personal must be nested in a larger personal-level ecology of reasons.

To motivate these claims we must first examine why many philosophers have found an awareness requirement appealing.

2. Why One Might Demand Awareness

The most common argument begins with epistemic deontologism: to be justified is, roughly, to do no wrong in one’s believing.  But epistemic blame and praise seem to presuppose a kind of cognitive agency; we do not blame someone for failing to compute 1,731×8,392 in her head, but we do blame her for ignoring conclusive evidence in plain view.  Awareness appears to be the marker of agency: only what is consciously present falls under the subject’s rational control, and only what falls under her rational control is a proper object of epistemic appraisal.  This line of thought underwrites access internalism (e.g., BonJour, Chisholm): justification supervenes solely on factors to which the subject has introspective access, because only such factors can guide belief in the light of reasons.

A second consideration appeals to transparency.  When one wonders “Why do I believe p?”, one can commonly answer by reflecting: “Because I just saw that q, and I know that if q then p.”  The introspective report both cites one’s reasons and demonstrates that those reasons are one’s own.  Absent access, the link between the cited grounds and the belief threatens to become merely accidental.  Suppose a neuroscientist implants in my brain a micro-chip that causes me to believe p whenever q is true, but I have no inkling that q obtains.  Intuitively, my belief lacks justification.  The implanted causal route is opaque to me; I cannot invoke it as my reason.  Awareness, the internalist claims, is therefore necessary to secure genuine basing.

Finally, many accept a phenomenological datum: epistemic reflection seems to involve the conscious appreciation of supporting considerations.  The difference between guessing that the coin landed heads and believing it on the basis of a reliable perception of its landing lies, part of us wants to say, in how the belief feels from the inside.  The guess lacks the seeming of being grounded in known evidence.

These motivations are powerful.  Yet, on closer inspection, each overshoots its target.

3. Three Problems for the Strong Awareness Requirement

3.1 Epistemic Success at the Margins of Consciousness  

Perception is the paradigm of justified belief-formation, but perceptual processes are massively unconscious.  You see the red cup on the table.  The belief that there is a red cup is ordinarily justified; it is “based on what you see.”  Nothing in your phenomenology presents the low-level edge detections, stereoscopic disparity calculations, or Bayesian inferences from lighting conditions to distal color values on which your visual system relies.  If a champion of the awareness requirement insists that the only “reasons” here are your conscious visual experiences, she must also hold that all the computational heavy lifting is epistemically inert.  But that seems wrong.  Visual experience has its justificatory force precisely because it is the output of a sophisticated sub-personal mechanism whose raison d’être is veridical perception.  Pull that mechanism away—as in hallucination—and the justificatory weight dissipates.  

3.2 The Problem of Stored Justification  

Imagine you prove a theorem at t1, carefully checking every step.  A week later, at t2, you recall the conclusion but have forgotten the proof.  You still recognize that you once had a proof, and on that basis confidently believe the theorem.  Are you justified?  Most say yes: your current belief piggybacks on earlier warranted inference.  Yet you are not now consciously aware of the premises or the inferential steps; indeed, you may no longer be able to reconstruct them without effort.  The awareness requirement would declare your present belief unjustified—in conflict with ordinary judgment.  

3.3 Auto-Justifying Basic Sources  

If awareness were necessary for basing, any belief whose grounds are outside consciousness would become unjustified, including beliefs immediately based on memory, introspection, and testimony.  Children incapable of articulating reasons would seldom satisfy the standard.  The result is a radical skepticism that few endorse.  The best explanation is that epistemic responsibility does not track instantaneous awareness; it tracks the standing rational capacities of agents embedded in their cognitive environment.

4. A Modest Accessibility Condition

The foregoing considerations suggest that the strong requirement is too strict.  Still, one might insist that permitting wholly unconscious basing robs justification of its normative bite.  We need something in between.  Call the intermediate thesis the Accessibility Condition:

AC: A thinker’s belief is justified only if the reasons that in fact epistemically ground it are, in normal conditions, available to her conscious reflection.

“Available,” not “accessed.”  The idea is that although many justifying grounds operate below the level of occurrent consciousness, they reside in memory or can be surfaced by ordinary inquiry; the subject retains epistemic control over them.  A proof forgotten beyond all hope of retrieval would no longer justify.  But so long as the agent can rehearse the steps when pressed, the belief remains within the sphere of responsible cognition.

This weaker internalism avoids the earlier problems.  In the theorem case, you remember that you had the proof and could, given time, reconstruct it; the reasons are accessible.  In perception, what is accessible is not the sub-personal computation but the deliverance it generates—your visual seeming that there is a red cup.  Experiences count as reasons because they are conscious states that you can cite, and because there is a reliable sub-personal link between those experiences and the external facts.  In effect, AC preserves a personal-level role for conscious reasons while acknowledging that much justification accrues thanks to lower-level processes.  

5. Causal vs. Rational Basing

A natural reaction, voiced by reliabilists such as Alvin Goldman, is that AC still does not go far enough.  What makes a belief justified, they say, is that it is produced by a reliable process; awareness is neither necessary nor sufficient.  To examine this disagreement we must distinguish the basing relation from mere causal influence.

Suppose Sally acquires a justified belief that it rained last night by seeing the wet pavement.  The standard internalist picture: she possesses the experience as of wet pavement; she takes wet-pavement-experience to indicate rain; she forms the belief.  The relation is causal (experience causes belief) and also rational (the belief is because she sees that it rained).  Contrast: the lawn sprinkler could have soaked the pavement.  If the sprinkler’s operation caused Sally to believe it rained, but not via her taking the wet pavement as evidence, the causal chain would be “deviant”; her belief would lack justification even if the cause-to-belief link were reliable.  The lesson is that reliability without rational connection is not enough; any adequate theory must secure the right kind of explanatory link—call it rational dependence.

The challenge is thus: How can rational dependence obtain when the operative inferences are sub-personal and outside consciousness?  Two approaches dominate.

5.1 Dispositional Accounts  

John Turri (along with Guillon, Comesaña, and others) argues that basing is fundamentally dispositional: a belief is based on a reason if the thinker's dispositions to revise or sustain the belief in light of counterfactual changes are appropriately reasons-sensitive.  Sally’s perceptual belief is based on her experience if, were her experience to shift, so would the belief.  Conscious awareness of the reason is unnecessary; what matters is the subjunctive profile.  The dispositional view dovetails nicely with the modular mind: automatic detection systems yield beliefs that track reasons across nearby worlds even when the agent cannot lip-read the computations.

5.2 Personal-Level Functionalism  

Peter Railton and Susanna Siegel defend a functionalist middle path.  On their view, a state counts as the subject’s reason when it plays the right role in her larger cognitive economy: it is poised to guide action, be endorsed upon reflection, integrate with other states, and so forth.  Consciousness facilitates these roles but is not mandatory.  What counts is whether the state is situated within the agent’s personal-level network of rational control.  The functionalist thus agrees that sub-personal processes can ground reasons, provided their outputs interface properly with the conscious mind.

Both frameworks allow epistemic basing without contemporaneous awareness, thereby answering the cognitive-science challenge.  But do they preserve accountability?  I think so, provided we add a diachronic clause: the agent must be able, over time, to bring her holdings under critical review.  Even if the initial formation is unconscious, she can later subject the resulting belief to scrutiny, examine additional evidence, and correct errors.  Such critical capacities ground epistemic responsibility more securely than moment-to-moment introspective access.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: If unconscious processes can justify, then subjects could be justified without any ability to cite supporting considerations; this conflicts with ordinary practices of asking for reasons.

Reply: What our practices demand is not that one already have explicit reasons queued up, but that one be able to supply them under interrogation.  Consider our treatment of infants and animals: we do not ask them for reasons, but we nevertheless treat their perceptual beliefs as less than culpable when mistaken.  Epistemic evaluation is graded.  Adult agents are expected to be responsive to challenges; that responsiveness requires diachronic accessibility, not constant awareness.

Objection 2: Allowing sub-personal justification opens the floodgates to deviant causal chains: a reliable chip implant could count as a justifier.

Reply: Not if we require that sub-personal outputs be integrated into the agent’s rational economy.  The chip’s bypassing of the subject’s critical faculties violates that integration condition.  By contrast, ordinary perceptual modules feed information into conscious attention; the chip scenario can be ruled out.

Objection 3: The accessibility condition cannot be met for many perceptual beliefs; the subject cannot cite any reason beyond “I just see it.”  That seems too thin.

Reply: “I just see it” is not as thin as it looks.  Visual seeming is a rich phenomenological state that carries evidential weight precisely because the subject has a meta-level grasp: she recognizes it as perception rather than imagination.  Moreover, her background entitlement to treat perception as reliable is itself sustained by a lifetime of error-correction, testimonial reassurance, and theoretical understanding—all accessible upon reflection.

7. Responsibility, Automatism, and the Basing Relation

We can now articulate a synthetic view.

(a) Justifying reasons need not be consciously entertained at the moment of belief-formation; what is required is their dispositional availability to an agent endowed with suitable rational capacities.  

(b) Sub-personal modular processes can generate such reasons if and only if their outputs feed into the agent’s deliberative apparatus in a way that renders them answerable to her norms of correction.  

(c) Epistemic responsibility is exercised diachronically: we hold agents accountable not for every automatic cognitive movement but for whether they monitor, challenge, and revise their beliefs when circumstances make it appropriate.  

(d) The basing relation is therefore multi-layered: at the sub-personal level it is causal; at the personal level it is dispositional-functional; at the normative level it is subject to appraisal under the Accessibility Condition.

This picture vindicates much of internalism’s concern for agency and normativity while assimilating the reliabilist insight that reliable sub-personal mechanisms are indispensable.  It also explains why the awareness requirement felt tempting: in typical cases, conscious awareness is the practical route by which accessibility, integration, and critical scrutiny are realized.  But the phenomenology is an imperfect guide to underlying structure; we must avoid reifying it into a necessary condition.

8. Conclusion  

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?  No—at least not when “awareness” is understood as occurrent, introspectively available representation.  Automatic, modular, and unconscious processes can furnish genuine epistemic grounds so long as their outputs are embedded within a cognitive system that equips the subject to recognize, assess, and revise those outputs in light of broader norms of rationality.  What is essential is diachronic rational control and dispositional accessibility, not moment-by-moment reflectiveness.

The resulting stance is a tempered internalism: justificatory reasons must ultimately be tethered to the subject’s perspective, but that tether can be slack.  Perceptual seemings, mnemonic traces, sub-personal inferential routines, and tacit linguistic knowledge all contribute, provided they are housed in a mind capable of taking responsibility for its beliefs.  The human cognitive architecture is a layered affair; our epistemology must be layered to match.

Does Lack of Conscious Awareness of One’s Reasons Preclude Epistemic Basing?

1. Introduction  

Epistemic evaluation—asking whether a belief is justified, warranted, or knowledge-conducive—turns crucially on the basing relation. A belief is justified (in the doxastic sense) only if it is based on the right kinds of considerations, commonly called epistemic reasons. A central dispute concerns the nature of that basing. “Internalists” of a broadly Cartesian stripe hold that for a belief to count as based on reasons, the subject must in some sense be aware of those reasons. By contrast, externalists—and more recently, philosophers influenced by cognitive science—have argued that basing can occur sub-personally, in modular, automatic processes that operate beneath the level of conscious awareness. The question before us is therefore: Does the absence of conscious awareness of one’s reasons automatically disqualify a belief from being epistemically based on those reasons? I shall argue that it does not. While conscious access can enhance the quality of one’s epistemic position—for instance, by enabling critical reflection—it is not necessary for genuine epistemic basing. Properly understood, what matters is the functional role a reason plays in the cognitive economy, not whether the subject can currently wield it in conscious thought.  

2. Clarifying the Terrain: Propositional vs. Doxastic Justification and the Basing Relation  

A standard distinction, traceable to Turri, Pollock, and others, is that between propositional and doxastic justification. A subject who has propositional justification for p possesses adequate reasons such that forming the belief would be epistemically permissible. Doxastic justification attaches to an actual belief and requires, in addition, that the belief be appropriately based on those reasons. The basing relation is therefore the bridge between available reasons and actual belief.  

The basing relation is elusive. Some analyze it causally: the reasons must causally produce the belief. Others insist on a more “manifest” connection: the subject must take the reasons to support the belief, or at least be disposed to recognize that support. The former view is naturally hospitable to unconscious basing; the latter, especially when formulated in terms of occurrent conscious taking, threatens to exclude it.  

We can sharpen the debate by distinguishing three senses of awareness:  

a. Phenomenal awareness: the reasons figure in the subject’s stream of consciousness.  

b. Access awareness: the subject has the capacity, on reflection, to cite or think about the reasons.  

c. Action-guiding awareness: the subject’s higher-level cognitive system can use the reasons to guide behavior, even if the subject cannot articulate them verbally or bring them to phenomenal consciousness.  

An uncompromising version of the awareness requirement adopts (a). Moderate versions may settle for (b). Externalist, cognitive-scientific accounts often rely only on (c).  

3. The Case for the Awareness Requirement  

Why think that conscious awareness, in some form, is required for epistemic basing?

3.1 Epistemic Agency.  Believing for reasons seems an exercise of agency. When I infer q from p→q and p, I actively endorse q because p warrants it. Agency, in turn, appears to demand some level of conscious control or at least reflective availability. If the transition were wholly opaque to me, how could it count as my inference rather than merely something that happens in me?

3.2 Responsibility and the Basing Demand.  We commonly hold subjects epistemically responsible—they deserve praise or blame—for believing in certain ways. Responsibility, it is argued, presupposes that the reasons for which one believes are available to one’s değerlendirme. Absent such availability, the subject cannot answer for her beliefs, and responsibility is undermined.

3.3 The Guidance Argument.  A reason can guide revisability only if the subject can consult it when anomalies arise. Conscious awareness (or at least easy accessibility) is required for such explanatory and corrective functions.

3.4 Anti-Alienation.  A belief formed by an alien sub-system that operates wholly beyond awareness may fail to be “owned” by the subject’s rational point of view. BonJour’s famous clairvoyance cases exploit this idea: a spontaneously formed belief that the President is in New York, produced by a reliable but unconscious faculty, seems epistemically defective precisely because it is detached from the subject’s rational scrutiny.

These arguments make a compelling prima facie case. They appeal to intuitions about agency, responsibility, and self-knowledge. Yet we must ask whether they license the strong phenomenal-awareness requirement or something weaker.

4. Challenges to the Awareness Requirement  

4.1 Cognitive Science of Unconscious Inference.  Vision science from Helmholtz onward treats perception as inferential: the visual system computes distal causes from proximal stimuli by tacit Bayesian reasoning. When I see that the cup is on the table, my brain has integrated lighting, contour, and shading to produce a perceptual judgment. I am not aware of these reasons, yet the resulting perceptual belief is paradigmatically justified—indeed, often more reliable than explicit reasoning. If epistemic basing required conscious awareness, basic perception would be unjustified, an untenable conclusion.

4.2 Linguistic Competence and Pragmatic Inference.  Fluent speakers automatically and unconsciously parse sentences, deploy syntactic rules, and draw conversational inferences (Gricean implicatures). Speakers rarely, if ever, entertain these linguistic principles in consciousness. Nevertheless, their linguistic beliefs—e.g., that the chef some guests disliked was Gordon—are justified by such sub-personal processes.

4.3 Expert Intuition.  The chess master “just sees” that a certain move is optimal. Decades of pattern-recognition learning yield cognitive modules that deliver reliable judgments without articulable reasons. Yet grandmaster moves are not epistemic shots in the dark; they are the product of sophisticated, albeit unconscious, reasoning.

4.4 Developmental and Clinical Evidence.  Infants track probabilistic contingencies long before possessing reflective capacities. Patients with blindsight can correctly guess visual features despite reporting no visual experience. These suggest that epistemically significant processing can bypass consciousness.

4.5 Over-Intellectualization and Explanatory Burden.  If awareness is required, we risk an infinite regress: does one need awareness of the awareness, and so on? Moreover, most actual inferences would fall short of justification, making human cognition epistemically impoverished—again, an implausible result.

5. Toward a Middle Path: Functionalist Accounts of Basing  

A promising strategy reconciles the insights of both camps:  

Functional Basing Thesis (FBT).
