Section 5 replies to three pressing objections and draws some broader lessons about normative pluralism.

1. Why Incommensurability Seems Devastating

Let us regiment the puzzle using the “reasons‐first” framework popularised by Scanlon and Parfit.  A normative reason is a consideration that counts in favour of φ-ing.  Normally, if several reasons are present, an all‐things-considered verdict obtains by some form of aggregation or comparison.  Suppose I have a reason not to touch a hot stove (expected pain) and a contrary reason to do so (saving my child).  These reasons are intelligibly comparable because both appeal to values that can be weighed under a shared prudential or moral metric.

By contrast:

• Epistemic reason E: “The visual evidence indicates that the bridge is intact.”

• Practical reason P: “If you falsely believe the bridge is intact and cross, you and your passengers will likely die.”

E and P appear to speak different normative languages.  E points to a likelihood of truth; P points to a likelihood of tragic loss.  There is no obvious scale on which X percentage of extra truth likelihood equals Y expected lives saved.

Yet an agent must choose to believe or withhold.  So either (i) only one kind of reason ultimately matters for belief, or (ii) there is some principled way they interact.  Dismissing one family is unsatisfactory: moral common sense tells us that sometimes disaster avoidance legitimately constrains belief (e.g., the nurse double-checks the medication label despite strong seeming memory).  Conversely, holding beliefs solely because they are comforting violates our intellectual integrity.  We thus face a genuine integration challenge.

Reductionist temptations.  Some epistemologists attempt to reduce practical reasons to epistemic ones by arguing that reliable truth-aimed methods are instrumentally best for long-term satisfaction of practical goals (Peircean teleologism).  But the dependence is merely statistical and defeasible; in high‐stakes situations what is pragmatically best may diverge sharply from what is evidentially supported.  Alternatively, pragmatists might say that truth is simply one instrumental good among others, hence assimilate epistemic reasons to the practical family.  That erases the intuitive specialness of truth—a cost many find unacceptable.

2. Three Inadequate Strategies

2.1 Exclusivism.  “Only epistemic reasons bear on belief; practical reasons bear solely on action.”  This view, associated with Clifford, Shah, and some Reidian evidentialists, safeguards the purity of epistemic norms but conflicts with widely shared judgments.  Imagine a doctor who, on meagre but suggestive evidence, forms the false belief that her patient has Ebola and therefore immediately quarantines him, causing great harm.  We tend to think she ought not to have believed so rashly, not merely that she ought not to have acted.  Exclusivism must deny this datum or reinterpret it as an action‐guidance error, both moves seeming strained.

2.2 Dual-Ought Pluralism.  Others (e.g., Hieronymi, Wedgwood) propose that “ought” is ambiguous: there is an epistemic ought and a practical ought, each delivering its own verdict.  Conflicts are real but not contradictions because the oughts are domain‐specific.  The patient case above thus yields: epistemically she ought to believe the Ebola hypothesis (strong evidence), but practically she ought not to.  Elegant as the manoeuvre is, it leaves the agent with no unified directive.  Human deliberation, however, characteristically seeks overall guidance; splitting the ought threatens practical paralysis precisely when guidance is needed most.

2.3 Quantitative Balancing.  At the other extreme stand Jamesian pragmatists and some Bayesian decision theorists: assign cardinal utilities to outcomes and epistemic probabilities to propositions, then determine which doxastic state maximises expected value.  While formally coherent, this approach seems to collapse the distinction between belief and action.  It licenses gross wishful thinking whenever expected utility leaps high enough; asserting, contrary to all evidence, that your lottery ticket will win might be required if the payoff is life-changing and the cost of error trivial.  Most find that unacceptable.

We thus desire a theory that (i) admits both kinds of reason, (ii) preserves truth’s special status, and (iii) still yields a single rational verdict.

3. Lexically Ordered Pluralism

3.1 The Basic Rule

LOP claims: epistemic reasons have lexical priority over practical reasons except when the practical stakes cross a critical threshold relative to the epistemic difference between the competing doxastic options.  Formally:

Let R_e be the net epistemic balance between believing p and not believing p.  
Let R_p be the net practical balance.  

If |R_e| ≥ ε (some context-sensitive evidential margin), then epistemic reasons determine the verdict.  Practical reasons may only break ties within the ε-band.  If |R_e| < ε, practical reasons become decisive provided they reach sufficient weight.

Think of R_e as measuring how much more likely p is to be true than false given one’s total evidence, and ε as the level of evidential indifference.  High‐confidence cases (far outside the band) are settled epistemically; low‐confidence cases open the door to pragmatics.

3.2 Why Lexical Priority?

a) Functional teleology of belief.  Belief, unlike mere acceptances or guesses, is constitutively aimed at truth.  To treat practical convenience as normally sufficient for belief is to misuse the attitude, analogous to using a thermometer as a hammer.  Hence truth‐promotion occupies the highest rung.

b) Moral agency.  However, we are not mere believers; we are agents whose beliefs guide high-stakes action.  When epistemic stakes are low (e.g., evidence is close to equipoise) but practical stakes are enormous (e.g., lives are on the line), rational agency demands responsiveness to practical reasons lest our truth-fixation become morally blinkered.  Lexical ordering captures this without allowing convenience to swamp well‐founded convictions.

c) Comparability without cardinal commensuration.  Because practical reasons enter only once epistemic margin is small, we never face the impossible task of trading precise amounts of truth against precise amounts of utility.  The model requires only ordinal facts: whether epistemic advantage is decisive or marginal, and whether practical stakes are ordinary or catastrophic.

3.3 Context‐Sensitive ε

How large is the “margin for practical encroachment”?  I propose it scales inversely with the cost of error and directly with the epistemic costs of delay.  When error is cheap, ε may be tight (we insist on near tie before pragmatics matter); when error is deadly, ε widens.  This dovetails with insights from pragmatic encroachment in epistemology: higher stakes raise the evidence bar for knowledge.

4. Case Studies

4.1 The Military Commander

Evidence: 20% chance that rescue is feasible before supplies run out.  
Practical stakes: believing feasibility buoys morale, perhaps saving lives; disbelieving might trigger surrender.  

R_e supports withholding or disbelief; R_p strongly supports belief.  Because 20% vs. 80% false is outside a plausible ε band (say ±10%), LOP says she ought not believe.  She may, however, deliberately “act as if” for morale—an act-policy wholly compatible with disbelieving.

4.2 The Nurse and the Medication Label

Evidence: 48% memory that dosage is 5 mg, 52% that it is 10 mg.  
Practical stakes: overdose could kill.  

Here R_e is minuscule and within ε.  Practical stakes are grave.  LOP permits (indeed requires) the nurse to suspend belief until checking the chart, or even to believe the safer proposition (5 mg is too high) if immediate action is unavoidable.  Intellectual chastity gives way to moral responsibility because the evidential field is almost level.

4.3 Pascal’s Wager

Evidence for God’s existence: highly controversial, likely below 20%.  
Practical stakes: infinite reward versus finite cost.  

Infinite values break normal decision theory and risk burying epistemic concerns.  LOP resists because the evidence gap is enormous—well beyond ε—so epistemic priority holds.  Practical infinity cannot override a yawning evidential deficit.  Thus LOP dissolves the traditional worry that Pascalian reasoning compels belief.

4.4 Radical Self‐Deception

Suppose an entrepreneur has middling evidence that her start-up will succeed but stands to gain huge investment if investors sense her genuine confidence.  Could LOP license self‐deceptive optimistic belief?  Only if evidence were roughly even.  Typically, start-ups fail far more often than they succeed; the epistemic balance is considerably negative, so LOP forbids adopting the rosy belief.  She may market enthusiastically, but honest belief must track evidence.

5. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: The lexical rule is ad hoc; why exactly should catastrophic stakes sometimes trump truth rather than always or never?

Reply:  The rule mirrors a familiar pattern in moral theory—lexical priority of basic rights over utility except in catastrophic emergency.  The analogue here is that epistemic integrity is a prima facie right; avoiding massive harm is an emergency clause.  That combination is neither ad hoc nor unprecedented.

Objection 2: The ε parameter re-introduces cardinal comparison under a different name; how large is “catastrophic”?

Reply:  What counts as catastrophic is itself a matter of ordinary practical reasoning.  The theory’s flexibility reflects real‐world deliberation rather than technical fudge.  Importantly, ε need not be numerically precise; agents require only contextual judgment about whether their evidence difference is “substantial.”  Philosophy should not feign false precision where none is practicable, echoing Rawls’s stance on lexical priority in justice.

Objection 3: LOP conflates belief with action because it lets practical reasons intrude.

Reply:  On the contrary, by sharply restricting intrusion to evidentially marginal cases, LOP preserves the deep tie between belief and truth.  Compare language play: sometimes we speak metaphorically for rhetorical effect, but literal meaning remains the default dimension of linguistic evaluation.  Likewise, truth oversight is the default for belief; practical exigency is the limited exception.

6. Normative Pluralism Beyond Belief

The foregoing argument offers a template for reconciling apparently incommensurable reasons across domains.  The key is to identify the characteristic aim of the practice (belief aims at truth) and then see whether overriding reasons exist that are so weighty they may, in edge cases, supersede that aim.  Thus understood, pluralism becomes manageable without the need for impossible commensuration.  Moreover, the approach has implications for debates about pragmatic encroachment on knowledge: higher practical stakes raise the evidential threshold because they widen ε, thereby justifying the intuition that one “needs to be more sure” when more is on the line.

Conclusion

We began with a seeming stalemate.  Epistemic reasons seek truth; practical reasons seek value.  How could they jointly determine what we ought to believe when they look incomparable?  Simple monism (only epistemic reasons) ignores moral reality; bifurcation (two oughts) fails to guide; pure pragmatism betrays intellectual honesty.  Lexically Ordered Pluralism vindicates the core insights of each: the centrality of truth, the relevance of value, and the need for unified deliberation.  By granting default priority to epistemic reasons yet allowing practical emergencies to break ties or decide in near-equipoise, the view explains our nuanced verdicts in an elegant, principled fashion.

If correct, LOP shows that incommensurability is not an impasse.  Rational agents can respect multiple normative dimensions without assigning them a single metric.  What we ought to believe is fixed by a structured ordering among heterogeneous reasons, reflecting both our nature as inquirers after truth and as responsible moral agents who must live with—and sometimes die by—our beliefs.

Is Motor Resonance Necessary for Perceiving Goal-Directed Action?  

1. Introduction  

The discovery of “mirror” neurons in the macaque premotor cortex in the 1990s created a surge of optimism about an elegant explanatory bridge between mind and body. Here, at last, seemed to be a single mechanism that could underwrite action understanding, imitation, and perhaps even empathy: when the monkey observed another individual grasp a peanut, the very neurons that would have fired had the monkey grasped the peanut itself were activated. This phenomenon—sometimes broadened into “motor resonance”—looked tailor-made for the claim that perception of goal-directed action is grounded in covert simulation. In its ambitious form the thesis says that motor resonance is a necessary condition: unless the observer’s motor system covertly reproduces the observed kinematic profile, the action cannot be perceived as goal-directed.

The necessity claim remains widely cited in philosophy of mind, cognitive science, and social neuroscience, yet it is rarely subjected to sustained philosophical scrutiny. My aim is to examine whether the claim survives such scrutiny. I shall argue that while motor resonance can contribute to richness, speed, or robustness in action perception, it is not conceptually or empirically necessary for perceiving goal-directedness. The argument proceeds in four stages: (i) clarifying what “perceiving goal-directed action” amounts to; (ii) specifying the “necessity” claim and disambiguating different readings; (iii) canvassing empirical evidence from development, pathology, cross-species perception, and technologically extended action; and (iv) presenting a positive account on which perceptual systems are equipped to detect goal-directed structure directly—resonance then becomes one source of constraint among others, not a pre-condition. I end by answering three common objections.

2. What Is It to Perceive Goal-Directed Action?  

An action is “goal-directed” if its trajectory is organized around the attainment of some distal outcome: opening a door, scoring a goal, grooming a conspecific. To perceive an action as goal-directed, then, is to register—at the level of perception rather than inferential judgment—that the movement is oriented toward such an outcome. Importantly, perceiving goal-directedness does not require knowing the agent’s ultimate intentions or motives; it requires perceiving the movement as organized around a focal target or purpose.

Three minimal criteria capture this perceptual achievement.

a. Teleological Structuring: The observer must detect systematic relations between the unfolding kinematics and an anticipated end-state.

b. Agentivity Attribution: The movement must be attributed to an agent whose control can generate means–end coordination.

c. Prospective Sensitivity: Perception must be sensitive to departures from action-outcome congruence; when the hand deviates from the cup, we notice something is “off.”

Any candidate necessity claim must show that without motor resonance none of these criteria can be satisfied.

3. What Exactly Is the Necessity Claim?  

Philosophers often glide between logical, nomological, and psychological necessity. The strongest reading:

Logical/Conceptual Necessity (LN): It is conceptually incoherent to say that S perceives another’s goal-directed action unless S’s motor system simulates that action.

No one (I think) seriously defends LN; conceptually, one can imagine non-motor creatures with rich visual systems perceiving purposive trajectories. The defended claim is usually nomological:

Empirical/Nomological Necessity (NN): In the actual world, given the causal architecture of human perceptual systems, motor resonance must occur for goal-directed perception to be successful.

But even NN admits two interpretations.

Weak NN: For human adults in typical circumstances, resonance normally (not necessarily always) occurs when goal-directed perception succeeds.

Strong NN: Goal-directed perception never succeeds in humans unless resonance is engaged.

The “mirror neuron” literature occasionally gestures toward Strong NN, but most experimentalists implicitly adopt Weak NN. My strategy is to show that even Strong NN is untenable, and that the explanatory pay-off of Weak NN can be captured by a more ecumenical account that treats resonance as a facilitating but not indispensable factor.

4. Empirical Challenges to Strong Necessity  

4.1 Developmental Dissociations  

Newborns as young as 2 days track the goal of a moving disk that consistently stops at one of two targets, showing increased attention when the disk switches goals (Csibra et al. 1998). At this age infants’ corticospinal tracts are immature and show weak or no motor resonance when exposed to grasping actions. Conversely, reliable motor resonance signatures (measured by mu-rhythm suppression or transcranial magnetic stimulation) typically emerge only around 8–10 months, months after robust goal attribution appears. Development thus provides a neat double-dissociation: early goal perception without resonance, later resonance without any abrupt change in goal attribution performance.

Some proponents respond that infants covertly rehearse movements even absent overt neural signatures, but this ad hoc maneuver dilutes empirical content; if resonance is posited wherever goal attribution is found, the thesis becomes unfalsifiable.

4.2 Motor Impairments and Neuropsychology  

Patients with apraxia, motor cortical lesions, or congenital limb absence often display reduced or absent motor resonance to actions they cannot perform. Yet they still competently identify the goals of those same actions. For example, Vannuscorps & Caramazza (2016) reported upper-limb congenitally absent individuals who showed no motor resonance to hand actions (measured via TMS-induced MEPs) but performed at ceiling in goal attribution tasks. Similarly, patients with locked-in syndrome perceive actions normally despite near-complete motor inactivity. If resonance were necessary, such intact perception should be impossible.

Advocates might object that residual undetected resonance suffices. Again the thesis retreats to irrefutable territory. The burden of proof, however, lies with the necessity claimant to specify what magnitude of simulation is needed and to show it is in fact present.

4.3 Cross-Species Perception  

Humans routinely perceive goal-directed behavior in animals whose morphologies we cannot emulate—spiders ambushing prey, dolphins herding fish. The kinematics of an eight-legged pounce cannot be directly mapped onto our bipedal motor repertoire. Yet we unhesitatingly recognize the spider’s strike as an attempt to capture the fly. Similarly, bird watchers perceive subtle variations in flight paths as courting, foraging, or nest-building actions. Unless the necessity theorist is willing to speculate that our motor system has latent programs for spider pounces and swallow dives, the resonance requirement looks implausible.

4.4 Technologically Extended Action  

Modern life confronts us with robots, avatars, and tool-mediated actions whose effector profiles do not match any available human movement. Remarkably, observers quickly learn to see these novel trajectories as purposeful long before they can imitate them. When people watch a tele-operated surgical robot, they can tell whether the operator is suturing or cauterizing, despite lacking motor primitives for robotic pincers with seven degrees of freedom. Rapid acquisition of goal perception outstrips acquisition of imitation skill, indicating that the perceptual system draws on structure other than motor resonance.

5. Toward a Positive Account: Direct Social Perception  

If motor resonance is not necessary, how do we perceive goal-directedness? Here ecological and enactivist insights prove useful. The claim is that visual and auditory arrays present higher-order invariants specifying intentional structure directly. Pioneered by Gunnar Johansson’s biological motion studies, we know that point-light walkers exhibit kinematic patterns that observers spontaneously parse as agents with goals. Such parsing is fast (<200 ms) and robust under degraded conditions, suggesting low-level perceptual attunement rather than high-level simulation.

5.1 Kinematic Signatures as Information  

Goal-directed actions exhibit characteristic velocity profiles—acceleration, deceleration, curvature—that systematically covary with target properties. A reaching movement accelerates then decelerates as the hand nears the object; deviations from this profile appear awkward or mistaken. The perceptual system can exploit these regularities directly. Importantly, mapping is not one-to-one with any participant’s motor repertoire; what matters is relational information (e.g., hand–object gap closure dynamics) rather than egocentric motor commands. Behavioral studies show that when these relational cues are artificially manipulated (e.g., time-warped videos that preserve joint angles but distort approach velocity), goal identification falters even though motor resonance remains relatively intact, suggesting that the visual system, not the motor system, shoulders the primary burden.

5.2 Predictive Processing Without Simulation  

Predictive coding models often motivate the necessity claim by asserting that the brain minimizes prediction error via forward motor models. But prediction can be implemented in purely perceptual hierarchies: the visual system has generative models that forecast contingent trajectories grounded in past perceptual data, not motor efference copies. Computer vision algorithms trained on optical flow achieve human-level goal recognition without motors at all, underscoring that rich prediction is not uniquely a motor function. The neurobiology concurs: the superior temporal sulcus (STS) encodes intention information independently of premotor activity.

5.3 Social Affordances  

Ecological theorists speak of “affordances”—action possibilities available in the environment. Social affordances are perceivable invitations to interact: a handshake, a beckon. Gibson emphasized that affordance perception is species-specific yet not dependent on the perceiver’s executing the action. My inability to fly does not prevent me from seeing a branch as perch-able for a bird. Analogously, I can see a robotic arm extend in greeting even if I cannot execute the exact kinematics. The perceptual system picks up on affordances at a scale finer than motor equivalence.

6. Handling Objections  

Objection 1: Mirror neuron activation reliably correlates with goal perception. Doesn’t this correlation suggest necessity?

Reply: Correlation is expected if resonance merely facilitates or is co-activated by goal perception. Genuinely necessary conditions produce counterexamples when removed; yet goal perception survives in situations of absent or minimal resonance (Sections 4.1–4.4). Correlation, absent counterfactual dependence, does not yield necessity.

Objection 2: Perhaps some minimal resonance—below detection thresholds—is always present.

Reply: This version vacates empirical content, turning the necessity claim into an unfalsifiable hunch. Moreover, in individuals with congenital limb absence, the relevant cortical territories have been repurposed for visual or somatosensory processing. Postulating latent, sub-threshold resonance in tissue never wired for the missing limb strains neuroplasticity evidence.

Objection 3: Even if resonance is not strictly necessary, isn’t it indispensable for nuanced perception (e.g., discerning subtle intentions)?

Reply: Degrees of richness are indeed influenced by expertise, which can include motor expertise (e.g., dancers perceiving dance). But perceptual expertise can also be built through purely visual training (radiologists, chess players, ornithologists). Thus, motor resonance is one route, not the route, to nuance. The necessity thesis generalizes from a contributory role to a universal requirement—a classic fallacy of over-generalization.

7. Philosophical Up-shot: Pluralistic Mechanisms  

Why has the necessity claim enjoyed such popularity? Philosophically, it fits an embodied simulation narrative attractive to those wary of disembodied cognition. Yet embodiment need not entail motor mirroring; perception itself is an embodied activity involving active exploration, posture, and eye movements. Overstating the role of resonance risks ignoring the multifaceted resources—visual invariants, contextual cues, even linguistic labels—that jointly scaffold social perception.

A pluralistic mechanistic picture emerges:

• Visual Dynamics: STS and occipito-temporal regions extract motion patterns predictive of goals.

• Contextual Priors: Prefrontal and temporo-parietal circuits supply situational constraints (e.g., cups are usually grasped for drinking).

• Motor Resonance: Premotor areas contribute when kinematics fall within the observer’s repertoire, thereby improving temporal prediction and possibly empathy.

• Affective Valence: Limbic circuits tag valence (threatening vs. welcoming).

Under this model, removing any single mechanism degrades performance but rarely abolishes it outright. Such redundancy is a hallmark of robust biological design.

8. Conclusion  

Motor resonance plays a fascinating, perhaps evolutionarily advantageous, role in social cognition. It can speed up prediction, foster empathy via shared neural codes, and facilitate imitation learning. Nevertheless, the ability to perceive goal-directed actions does not depend on resonance as a necessary condition. Developmental, neuropsychological, and ecological evidence shows that humans (and arguably other species) possess perceptual systems capable of extracting goal structure directly from dynamic sensory information. Resonance is thus best viewed as one contributory mechanism among several, not the foundational prerequisite. The philosophical moral is cautionary: alluring “single-mechanism” explanations should be tested against the full complexity of cognitive architecture. When we do so, motor resonance is revealed not as the sole gateway to understanding others’ purposeful deeds, but as an adaptable partner in a broader coalition of perceptual, contextual, and affective processes that together equip us for life in a social world.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action  
≈ 2 000 words  

1. Introduction  

When I watch a friend reach for her coffee mug, I do not merely register the kinematics of an arm in motion. I see her as reaching for the mug, intending to drink, perhaps even as craving caffeine. What enables this seemingly effortless grasp of another’s goal? A prominent answer in contemporary philosophy of mind and cognitive science points to motor resonance. Roughly, motor resonance occurs when perceptually observing an action elicits, in the observer, sub-threshold activation of the same neural circuits that would be used to perform the action oneself. The discovery of mirror neurons in macaques and homologous “mirror systems” in humans suggested that perception and execution of action share a common code. Building on this, several theorists—Gallese, Rizzolatti, and Goldman among others—have argued that covert motor simulation is not just one way, but the necessary way, to perceive an action as goal-directed.  

The necessity claim deserves careful scrutiny. If correct, it would show that social cognition is fundamentally embodied, that our understanding of others literally piggybacks on our own motor capacities. If incorrect, theories tying perception of agency too tightly to resonance seriously underestimate the richness of visual perception and the flexibility of the human mind. In what follows I reconstruct the necessity argument (§2), develop three lines of empirical and conceptual critique (§3–5), sketch an alternative picture (§6), and close with a qualified verdict (§7).

2. The Necessity Argument for Motor Resonance  

The argument has both empirical and philosophical components. A convenient reconstruction is:

P1. Observing an action normally elicits activation in the observer’s motor system that would suffice to execute the same action (the motor resonance fact).  
P2. Such motor activation implements a forward or predictive model that fills in the goal of the observed action (the simulation step).  
P3. Without this predictive model, the perceptual system would have only “motion trajectories,” insufficient for representing teleological structure (the under-determination step).  
C. Therefore, motor resonance is a necessary condition for perceiving an action as goal-directed.

The conclusion is “necessary” in the epistemic sense: absent motor resonance, perception of goals would not occur or would be radically impoverished. Notice that the argument is not that resonance is merely helpful, but that it supplies the indispensable representational bridge from kinematics to intentional content.

Why think P1-P3 are true?

Empirically, brain-imaging studies report overlapping activation in premotor and parietal areas during action observation and execution; kinematic errors are better predicted when one’s motor system is primed; interference paradigms show that temporarily lesioning motor cortices impairs explicit goal attribution tasks. Philosophically, the argument appeals to an “intentional gap”: from the purely visual array one can at best recover positions and velocities. Something must enrich this bare movement description with information about hidden ends; the motor system is on hand and evolutionarily tuned to do precisely that.

3. Challenge I: Dissociations Between Motor Ability and Goal Perception  

The strongest empirical objection draws on cases where action understanding is intact despite absent or impaired resonance.

3.1. Congenital limb absence. Individuals born without upper limbs cannot execute ordinary manual grasping and show markedly reduced motor cortex responses during action observation. Yet behavioural tests (Southgate & Hamilton 2008) reveal that they identify others’ manual goals as quickly and accurately as controls. If resonance were necessary, one would expect deficits.

3.2. Locked-in or ALS patients. fMRI data show dramatically dampened motor activation during observation, consistent with degeneration of corticospinal tracts. Nonetheless, such patients report seeing others’ actions as goal-directed and perform adequately on online goal-recognition tasks administered via eye-tracking (Kaliki et al. 2013).

3.3. Tool use and impossible actions. I cannot, unaided, peel a banana with my feet, yet I can instantly see a circus performer’s foot-peeling as directed at getting the banana open. Mirror-system activation is minimal because I lack a matching motor schema; perception of goal persists.

One could reply that some “residual” resonance remains (e.g., proximal joint mapping) or that subjects acquired compensatory pathways developmentally. The first reply risks unfalsifiability: any preservation of goal perception becomes evidence of hidden resonance. The second is undermined by timeframes—tool-use actions newly invented can be understood on the first viewing, before compensatory learning. At minimum, these findings show that resonance is not universally required.

4. Challenge II: Developmental and Comparative Data  

Simulation theorists draw support from infant studies: 6-month-olds show mu-suppression (an EEG index of motor activation) when viewing grasping and also succeed at anticipatory looking tasks. However, two developmental facts complicate the necessity thesis.

4.1. Early goal perception precedes reliable resonance. Newborns distinguish purposeful from non-purposeful motion in habituation paradigms (Biro & Leslie 2007), whereas robust mirror responses are typically undetectable until 6 months. The causal direction may be the reverse of what necessity advocates assume: perceptual mechanisms may scaffold later motor resonance.

4.2. Non-human species. Dogs, scrub-jays, and macaques with lesions to premotor cortex still track others’ reaching goals, as indicated by gaze-following and expectancy violation. Given that these animals’ mirror systems are differently organised or partly lesioned, resonance cannot be necessary across species. Yet their ecological demands surely require sensitivity to others’ goals.

Taken together, the developmental and comparative evidence supports the claim that perceptual systems can code teleology using cues such as efficient paths, probabilistic cues from environment-goal alignment, or learned statistical regularities—none of which presuppose motor mirroring.

5. Challenge III: Conceptual Overreach  

Even setting aside controversial neuroscience, the necessity thesis faces two philosophical hurdles.

5.1. Phenomenological transparency. Perception of goals is usually immediate and effortless; I see “reaching for” not “arm moving toward.” But motor resonance is a subpersonal, neural event. Showing that two events co-occur does not show the latter is constitutive of the former. Otherwise we commit the fallacy of correlation-cum-constitution.

5.2. The logical space of explanations. There are at least three theoretically distinct routes from kinematics to goal representation:

a) Inferential: The system computes hidden causes using folk-psychological inference.  
b) Heuristic: The system uses perceptual shortcuts, e.g. minimum-jerk trajectories signal intentionality.  
c) Embodied simulation: Mirroring fills in goals via motor prediction.

The necessity claim amounts to asserting that (c) is the only possible route. Yet (a) and (b) are conceptually coherent and enjoy independent support from Bayesian vision models and ecological psychology. To rule them out, one would need decisive evidence that when resonance is suppressed, no other route can compensate. The dissociation data above show otherwise.

6. An Alternative Picture: Pluralistic, Constraint-Based Perception  

Rather than a single bottleneck, perception of agency likely emerges from the interaction of multiple constraints:

• Kinematic cues: Efficiency, velocity profiles, and biological motion detectors supply preliminary “agentive” categorisation.  
• Environmental embedding: The presence of graspable objects, affordances, and causal relations furnishes hypotheses about likely ends.  
• Statistical learning: Repeated co-occurrence of movement patterns with outcomes creates predictive links.  
• Motor resonance: Where available, embodied simulation provides an additional, rich source of prediction, especially for fine-grained details of actions one can perform.

On this view, motor resonance is one contributory cue among many, dynamically weighted by reliability and context. For example, when I see somebody performing an unfamiliar dance, motor simulation may be noisy, so the system leans more on visual inferential cues (e.g., symmetry, rhythm). When I observe familiar typing, resonance may dominate. Such cue integration fits well with predictive-processing frameworks, where the brain continuously minimises prediction error by pooling information across modalities and levels.

This pluralistic model honours the genuine explanatory power of mirroring—why action observation can prime motor execution, why perturbing premotor cortex mildly degrades fine-grained goal discrimination—without inflating it into a necessary condition. It also accommodates pathologies: autistic individuals sometimes show reduced mu-suppression yet succeed in explicit goal identification, suggesting compensatory reliance on non-motor cues.

7. Conclusion and Qualified Verdict  

The claim that motor resonance is necessary for perceiving goal-directed actions overstates the evidence and underestimates the flexibility of perceptual and cognitive systems. Three independent lines of argument—the existence of dissociations, developmental and comparative facts, and conceptual plurality—undercut the necessity thesis. A more defensible view is conditional necessity: for certain fine-grained, within-effector predictions (predicting the exact grip aperture or force), motor resonance may be indispensable; for coarse-grained goal perception (seeing that someone wants the mug), it is neither necessary nor sufficient.

This nuanced conclusion salvages the genuine insights of mirror-neuron research while freeing philosophers from the temptation to conflate correlation with constitutive dependency. Perceiving goals is a multi-layered achievement of the visual, cognitive, and motor systems working in concert; disabling one instrument need not silence the whole orchestra.

Motor resonance—the online recruitment of one’s own motor system when observing another’s bodily movements—has occupied center stage in recent debates about social cognition. Ever since the discovery of so-called “mirror neurons,” many philosophers and cognitive scientists have claimed that mapping an observed action onto one’s own motor repertoire is a necessary pre-condition for perceiving that action as goal-directed.1 In short, we recognize the other’s intention because, beneath the threshold of consciousness, we covertly “do” what she does. This motor simulation hypothesis enjoys intuitive appeal and explanatory power, yet it is far from unassailable. In what follows I argue that motor resonance, while often helpful and sometimes sufficient for perceiving goal-directed behavior, is not a necessary condition. To reach that conclusion I shall (1) clarify key notions of “perception,” “goal-directedness,” and “necessity”; (2) reconstruct the main arguments in favor of the necessity claim; (3) present conceptual and empirical counter-arguments; (4) sketch alternative mechanisms that can underwrite the perceptual apprehension of goal-directed action; and (5) respond to likely objections. A cumulative case emerges: resonance is best understood as one among several partially redundant routes to social perception rather than as its indispensable ground.

1. Clarifying the terrain

1.1 Perception. When philosophers say that a property is “perceived,” they typically mean that it figures non-inferentially in the content of conscious experience. I see that your hand is grasping a cup, and I see that the grasping is for the sake of drinking. The stronger thesis—endorsed by many simulation theorists—is that goal-directedness is available not merely as an inference from what we see but as something literally present in visual phenomenology.2 The weaker thesis is that the perceiver becomes aware of the goal rapidly and effortlessly, though perhaps by sub-personal inference. My arguments below accommodate either reading.

1.2 Goal-directedness. Actions count as goal-directed when they are organized around outcomes whose realization supplies a reason or telos for the movement. In standard experimental paradigms, reaching to place blocks in buckets, stacking rings, or choosing efficient paths signal goal-directed structure. Crucially, the concept is relational: what qualifies a movement as action is its embedding in an intentional scheme.3

1.3 Necessity. Saying that resonance is necessary means that absent a suitably matching motor representation the experience of goal-directedness cannot arise. The hypothesis is thus falsified if there are perceivers who lack a relevant motor repertoire yet still detect another’s goal, or if artificial lesions that dampen resonance leave goal perception intact.

2. The case for necessity

Advocates marshal three main lines of support.

a) Neurophysiological convergence. Single-cell recordings in macaques reveal neurons that fire both when grasping and when seeing another grasp.4 fMRI and TMS data suggest homologous circuits in humans: the inferior frontal gyrus and inferior parietal lobule light up when observing transitive actions; motor-evoked potentials in corresponding muscles increase.5 The argument is abductive: the best explanation of these activations is that the brain re-uses its motor format to understand others.

b) Developmental co-variation. Infants begin to attribute goals right after they acquire the ability to execute similar actions. At 5–7 months, when reaching becomes dexterous, infants also pass Woodward’s habituation paradigm indicating that they represent the reach as object-directed.6 The synchrony invites the conclusion that motor competence enables social perception.

c) Phenomenological corroboration. Introspectively, we often “feel ourselves” doing what we watch, especially in skill domains like dance or sports. Breakdancers report kinesthetic mirroring when they observe choreographies beyond their capacity, but the mirroring is richer when the moves are within their capabilities.7 Such subjective resonance seems integral to grasping the unfolding goal.

Together, these considerations yield an elegant picture: the motor system, optimized for action control, “recycles” its representational format to provide fast, embodied access to the goals of others, bypassing slower inferential routes.

3. Conceptual challenges

Even if all the empirical premises hold, the inference to necessity is not secure. Two conceptual points undermine it.

First, causal contribution is not entailment. The fact that motor activation often accompanies goal perception does not show it is indispensable. Heartbeat acceleration accompanies fear but one can feel fear with beta-blockers dampening cardiac output. Likewise, resonance might be facilitative without being essential.

Second, necessity claims invite counter-examples from possibility: if we can imagine coherent scenarios in which perceptual goal attribution occurs without resonance, the claim loses a priori status and must face empirical scrutiny. My counter-examples below target exactly this vulnerability.

4. Empirical counter-evidence

4.1 Congenital motor deprivation. A decisive test case involves individuals born without upper limbs (amelics) who therefore lack motor engrams for hand actions. Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) showed videos of grasping, throwing, and tool use to such participants. Despite profound motor deprivation, they categorized actions and predicted action goals with the same speed and accuracy as control subjects—a direct refutation of necessity.8 Neuroimaging revealed typical activation in occipito-temporal “action-observation” areas but no activation in missing-hand motor cortex, confirming that perceptual goal attribution persisted in the absence of motor resonance.

4.2 Pathological dissociations. Patients with apraxia lose the ability to plan hand movements though visual recognition of actions remains relatively intact.9 Conversely, patients with optic ataxia misperceive object affordances while their motor execution is spared. These double dissociations show that the mapping from perception to motor command is neither one-way nor obligatory.

4.3 Developmental asynchrony. Contrary to claim (b), newborns show signatures of goal attribution before they possess matching motor skills. 3-day-old infants can infer the goal of a robot arm if its trajectories obey rational efficiency principles.10 Furthermore, 10-month-olds who cannot yet perform means-end pulling actions still perceive them as goal-directed in others.11 The timing therefore does not establish motor primacy.

4.4 Transcranial magnetic stimulation. If resonance were necessary, disrupting premotor cortex should impair goal perception. Yet studies applying repetitive TMS to area F5 degrade prediction of kinematic details but leave identification of distal goals largely unaffected.12 This suggests a graded division of labor: motor areas encode “how,” visual-semantic areas track “what for.”

4.5 Non-human perception. Dogs and scrub-jays anticipate human and conspecific goals despite large anatomical differences that preclude detailed motor mirroring.13 The comparative data broaden the wedge between resonance and goal perception.

Taken together, the empirical record decisively falsifies strict necessity. There are perceivers who either never possessed the relevant motor programs or whose programs were transiently silenced, yet they experience goal-directedness unimpaired.

5. Alternative explanatory resources

If not resonance, what scaffolds perceptual access to goals?

5.1 Kinematic cues to rationality. Actions toward goals typically show characteristic velocity profiles, temporal reversals, and minimum-jerk trajectories.14 The visual system can exploit such “biomechanical priors” directly, much as it exploits optical invariants for shape perception. Even idealized geometric agents (triangles chasing circles) elicit vivid goal attributions, demonstrating that low-level motion patterns suffice.

5.2 Teleological stance. According to Gergely and Csibra’s “teleological theory,” humans treat agents as rational executors of goal-directed actions, assessing efficiency relative to situational constraints.15 This stance operates syntactically over visible variables such as obstacle layout and path cost, without requiring a motor copy.

5.3 Affordance perception. Gibsonian theorists argue that we see objects as inviting certain actions (cups afford grasping). If we perceive affordances and note that another individual’s movement is heading toward an affordance that would satisfy a need (e.g., thirst), goal perception follows directly.16 The mechanism is visual-ecological rather than kinesthetic.

5.4 Predictive processing. On a hierarchical Bayesian account, the brain continuously generates predictions about causes of sensory input.17 Observed actions are matched against generative models of agentive behavior; prediction errors drive inference to intentions. While descending predictions eventually interface with motor control, the critical computations for inferring goals may occur at higher conceptual or associative levels that do not require motor instantiation.

5.5 Linguistic and cultural knowledge. Many human goals (marrying, voting) lack any fixed motor signature. We nonetheless perceive them when seeing someone walk into a voting booth. Semantic knowledge, not motor resonance, grounds these perceptions.

The picture that emerges is pluralistic: multiple partially overlapping pathways feed the experience of goal-directedness. Sometimes, as when a pianist watches another pianist, motor resonance dominates; at other times, affordance perception or rational teleology suffices.

6. Objections and replies

Objection 1: The amelic and infant data only show that primary motor cortex is not needed; resonance might occur in abstract form elsewhere.

Reply: The claim at issue is that mapping an observed action onto one’s own motor repertoire is necessary. If the repertoire is physically absent, there is no mapping in any plausible sense. Abstract structural isomorphisms between visual and conceptual representations would be motoric only by metaphor, thereby trivializing the necessity thesis.

Objection 2: Perhaps goal-perception is qualitatively degraded without resonance—less vivid, slower, or demanding more attention. Necessity concerns an all-or-nothing threshold; empirical work shows adequacy on speed and accuracy measures.18 If subtle phenomenological differences remain, they support the weaker facilitation view rather than strict necessity.

Objection 3: Mirror neurophysiology still correlates systematically with goal understanding, so we should privilege it as the core mechanism.

Reply: Correlation alone cannot settle causal priority. Redundant architecture is commonplace in biology. The perceptual system likely evolved to exploit motor simulation when available because it is cheap and fast, but also evolved backup mechanisms to secure function when simulation is compromised. Such degeneracy is adaptive in noisy environments.

7. Theoretical upshot

Recognizing that motor resonance is not necessary for goal perception reshapes broader debates on social cognition.

First, it loosens the grip of simulationism. While bodily reenactment sometimes plays a starring role, mentalizing, cue-based reasoning, and direct ecological perception are equally legitimate. Hybrid models that allow dynamic weighting according to context seem more plausible.

Second, it underscores the autonomy of perception. Just as color vision exploits wavelength-surface interactions without needing to represent quantum electrodynamics, social vision can exploit invariant motion patterns and ecological affordances without constructing motor commands. The motor system’s contribution is opportunistic rather than foundational.

Third, it informs clinical and technological applications. Neuroprosthetics and social robotics need not replicate full motor parity to decode or display goal-directed behavior. Visual algorithms that track kinematic efficiency or affordances may suffice.

8. Conclusion

The alluring idea that we must internally reenact an observed movement to see it as goal-directed does not withstand sustained scrutiny. Although motor resonance provides one efficient route—especially when the action falls within one’s practiced repertoire—it is neither logically nor empirically necessary. Individuals without the relevant motor programs, infants whose own motor skill lags far behind their social perception, patients with motor cortex disruption, and non-human observers all perceive goals nonetheless. Alternative mechanisms based on kinematic invariants, teleological reasoning, affordance mapping, and predictive coding can shoulder the explanatory burden. For a nuanced science and philosophy of social cognition, we should therefore replace the slogan “no simulation, no understanding” with the more modest maxim: simulation when possible, but understanding by any means available.

Is motor resonance—a covert, sub-personal mapping of another’s movements onto one’s own motor repertoire—a prerequisite for perceiving another creature as acting for a goal? Or can goal-directedness be visually apprehended without the intervention of resonance mechanisms? The issue bears on foundational questions in philosophy of mind (How is action understood? What is the boundary between perception and cognition?) as well as on the interpretation of a sizeable empirical literature in cognitive science. In what follows I first clarify the key notions, then reconstruct the main argument for the Motor Resonance Necessity Thesis (MRNT), examine its conceptual and empirical supports, and finally articulate a non-reductionist alternative. I argue that motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically necessary for the perception of goal-directed action, although it often facilitates and enriches that perception.

1. Clarifying the terrain

“Perception of a goal-directed action” is ambiguous. Sometimes it means: (a) visually registering spatiotemporal regularities in another’s movements; at other times: (b) grasping what they are up to—the telos of the movement. In everyday and scientific usage the two are interwoven; but for the philosophical question they must be separated. Everyone agrees that I can track the trajectory of a frisbee without attributing a goal to it, and conversely that I can attribute a rapacious goal to a shark even while losing track of its precise path. The MRNT concerns mainly the second sense: the perception-as-goal-directed, i.e. the perceptual extraction of purposiveness, not mere motion.

What about motor resonance? In the narrow sense, it is the activation of the observer’s own motor system (cortical or spinal) in a somatotopically matching pattern when they witness an action. Paradigmatically, mirror neurons in premotor and parietal cortices of macaques, and human homologues revealed by fMRI, MEG, TMS and MEP studies, fire both when grasping and when seeing someone else grasp. In a broader, more philosophical sense, resonance encompasses all on-line motor simulations or emulations that covertly reproduce the witnessed kinematics. The MRNT claims that such resonance is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directedness: no resonance, no goal perception.

2. The case for necessity

Why believe such a stringent claim? Three kinds of argument are commonly cited.

2.1 Conceptual-simulationist argument  
Simulation theorists (e.g. Gallese & Goldman 1998) contend that understanding another’s action involves “putting oneself in their shoes”, and that the only sub-personal vehicle available for such putting-oneself is the observer’s own motor circuitry. The argument is: (1) goal perception requires representing the action as intentional; (2) the only non-inferential route to intentional representation is simulation; (3) simulation, for motor behaviour, just is resonance; therefore (4) resonance is necessary for goal perception.

2.2 Developmental-correlation argument  
Infants who have not yet mastered grasping supposedly fail to recognise grasping as goal-directed. After they acquire motor competence, they do so. Meltzoff & Moore’s “like-me” thesis and Sommerville, Woodward, et al. cite correlations between infants’ grasping proficiency and their preferential looking at goal violations to argue that motor ability scaffolds perceptual goal attribution.

2.3 Interference argument  
If one transiently disrupts resonance, goal perception should deteriorate. TMS studies indicate that applying pulses over premotor cortex impairs discrimination of biological from scrambled motion and slows prediction of an observed reach. Patients with limb apraxia, allegedly resonance-deficient, are sometimes reported to be poorer at recognising gestures. Such evidence is adduced to support necessity.

Let us test these arguments critically.

3. Conceptual vulnerabilities

3.1 Distinguishing enabling from constitutive conditions  
Even if simulation often contributes to goal perception, it does not follow that it is constitutive. A battery enables a flashlight, but one can see light without having a battery on one’s person. Likewise, resonance may be an enabling condition for certain observers, in certain contexts, yet not a logically or biologically necessary one. The MRNT deals in necessity, not contingency.

3.2 Heteromorphism and the scope of goals  
Humans readily perceive the goals of octopuses, snakes, drones, self-driving cars, and on good days, chess computers. Yet none of these actions can be mapped onto the ordinary human motor repertoire in a somatotopic fashion. The observer literally lacks effectors corresponding to an octopus tentacle or a quadcopter’s rotors. A proponent might bite the bullet: perhaps we never truly perceive those movements as goal-directed, we merely infer. But that is implausible: scuba divers dodge a charging cuttlefish with the same online immediacy that they dodge a charging swimmer. Observational phenomenology suggests that goal perception survives radical effector mismatch.

3.3 Minimal teleology without motoric similarity  
Even simple geometric animations—the famous “Heider-Simmel” moving triangles—are spontaneously seen as chasing, coaxing, seducing, etc. Here the display is deliberately impoverished so that nothing looks like a human limb. Yet adults and preschoolers insist on goal attributions. Unless one posits an implausibly baroque covert mapping from triangles to biceps, motor resonance cannot account for the immediacy of these attributions.

4. Empirical counter-evidence

4.1 Congenital limb absence  
Vannuscorps & Caramazza (2016) studied individuals born without upper limbs. When those participants view hand actions, their “hand” area in premotor cortex is largely silent—they have no established motor representation of fingers. Nevertheless they discriminate grasps from non-grasps and anticipate action outcomes normally. The resonance machinery is absent or vastly reduced, yet goal perception is preserved.

4.2 Deafferented and spinal-cord-injured observers  
Patients lacking proprioceptive or descending motor signals sometimes display almost normal recognition of others’ actions. Their sensorimotor contingencies are disrupted, but their perceptual uptake of purposiveness remains.

4.3 Selective dissociations  
fMRI and lesion studies reveal distinct neural populations: some encode fine-grained kinematics (mirror areas); others encode overarching goals and intentions (pSTS, TPJ, mPFC). Damage to the latter, not the former, more robustly predicts failures in perceiving goal structure (e.g., in autism spectrum conditions). Thus resonance appears neither sufficient nor necessary.

4.4 Cross-cultural and cross-species evidence  
Dogs are experts at reading human pointing despite lacking a homologous pointing action. Corvids solve elaborate goal attribution tasks without sharing the observed effector systems. If resonance were necessary, such cases would be impossible or at least impaired.

4.5 TMS nuances  
Interference studies are less decisive than advertised. Disrupting premotor cortex normally induces small delays (tens of milliseconds) in prediction, not wholesale loss of goal perception. Participants still categorise the observed act; their explicit judgements hardly degrade. This suggests resonance aids rapid extrapolation but is not foundational.

5. Alternative explanatory resources

5.1 The teleological stance  
Gergely & Csibra argue that observers treat agents as rational, efficiency-maximising goal pursuers relative to situational constraints. The computation is abstract and amodal: “Given that end-state E is available, which path is most economical?” No motor matching is required; only sensitivity to environmental affordances and basic rationality assumptions.

5.2 Visual heuristics and kinematic cues  
Motion trajectories contain information about intentionality (straight-vs-curved paths, velocity profiles, etc.). Johansson-style point-light displays trigger goal perception using purely visual dynamics. The brain can tune directly to these invariants, à la Gibson, without invoking efferent copies.

5.3 Predictive-processing architectures  
In hierarchical predictive coding models, the motor system is indeed recruited during perception, but as one predictive layer among many. Crucially, its involvement is context-sensitive and dispensable when higher-level visual predictions suffice. The architecture is robust to loss of any single pathway, favouring degeneracy over strict necessity.

5.4 Rational inference and folk-psychological scripts  
Sometimes we perceive goals by drawing on background knowledge: a chess grandmaster “sees” a fork threat on the board. This is conceptual, not resonant. The capacity to integrate propositional knowledge with visual input belies the idea that only mirroring delivers goal understanding.

6. Why resonance helps even if not necessary

A conciliatory view is that motor resonance (a) speeds up, (b) sharpens, and (c) grounds embodied affordances of action perception. When I watch a tennis serve, my dorsal stream primed by years of practice lets me anticipate the ball’s angle microseconds faster than a novice. That can make the difference between returning the serve and missing. But if the motor system were silenced, I could still perceive the opponent’s goal—getting the ball over the net into the service box—albeit with diminished temporal resolution. Resonance is thus facilitative, not constitutive.

Developmental correlations can be re-interpreted in this light. Infants who learn to grasp gain abundant joint visual-tactile statistics correlating certain hand shapes with object displacements. Those learning experiences might train purely visual circuits as well as mirror ones; the correlation is evidence of co-development, not of necessity.

7. Philosophical implications

7.1 Intuition against over-motorisation  
The MRNT reflects an implicitly behaviourist equation of understanding with muscular rehearsal. But everyday experience tells against it: I can understand a mathematician’s “goal” in proving a lemma with no motoric counterpart whatsoever. If goal extraction in the abstract is not motoric, why insist that goals in concrete actions must be?

7.2 Category mistake worry  
To perceive an action as goal-directed is to situate it in an intentional vocabulary, one that presupposes reasons, desires, and norms. Mirror activity is a neural-level process realised in electrochemical patterns. Bridging the two levels is non-trivial. Declaring that a low-level pattern is necessary for a high-level attribution risks a category mistake unless an explicit bridging account is offered.

7.3 Pluralistic metaphysics of perception  
Many philosophers now endorse pluralism: perceptual systems are opportunistically multi-modal; they integrate whatever cue is informative. Resonance is one cue among many. The pluralist denies that there is a single lowest-level essence of goal perception. Instead there is a toolbox: kinematic regularities, environmental affordances, causal reasoning, motor prediction, social norms. Toolbox items can compensate for one another, explaining resilience after local damage.

8. Objections and replies

Objection 1: Paralysis cases show degraded social understanding, supporting MRNT.  
Reply: Severe paralysis often co-occurs with social isolation, depression, and sensorimotor deprivation, all of which confound the data. Moreover, high-level mind-reading in locked-in patients is often preserved.

Objection 2: Heider-Simmel displays recruit mirror neurons according to some fMRI data. So triangles are still neurally mirrored.  
Reply: Even if mirror areas are co-activated, that does not prove necessity. Correlation is expected in a highly interactive brain. The challenge is to show that goal perception fails when resonance fails. The congenital limb absence data show the contrary.

Objection 3: If resonance is not necessary, why has evolution built such an expensive system?  
Reply: Because speed matters. Predicting the arc of a spear affords life-saving milliseconds. Resonance offers a shortcut for familiar actions but evolution also provided backup systems for unfamiliar or heteromorphic ones.

9. Conclusion

Conceptual analysis dissolves the intuitive leap from frequent co-activation to necessity. Empirical evidence reveals intact goal perception in the virtual absence of matching motor representations. Alternative accounts—teleological, visual-heuristic, predictive—fill the explanatory gap. The most plausible position, therefore, is a moderate pluralism: motor resonance is a deeply useful, often recruited, but by no means necessary mechanism for perceiving goal-directed action. Like colour vision under good illumination, it refines perceptual richness; yet we can still discern the shape of things in the dark.
