Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action:
A Philosophical and Empirical Assessment
(≈ 2,050 words)

1. Introduction  

The discovery of mirror neurons in macaques in the 1990s, and the subsequent explosion of research on “motor resonance” in humans, has transformed the study of social perception. Functional–magnetic-resonance imaging (fMRI), transcranial-magnetic stimulation (TMS), and electro-encephalography (EEG) consistently show that parts of an observer’s motor system are activated when she watches another individual reach, grasp, or otherwise manipulate objects. Many philosophers and cognitive scientists have concluded—sometimes cautiously, sometimes boldly—that such resonance is not merely a correlate but a necessary condition for seeing the other’s behavior as goal-directed. Call this the motor-simulation thesis (MST):

(MST) An individual perceptually represents another’s action as goal-directed only if some portion of the observer’s own motor repertoire is engaged in a mapping or simulation of that action.

The thesis is attractive for at least three reasons. First, the apparent “automaticity” of resonance promises to explain why attributions of goal-directedness are fast and unreflective. Second, the bodily basis of resonance sits comfortably with an embodied turn in philosophy of mind. Third, resonance accounts appear to provide a unifying mechanism for action understanding, empathy, and perhaps even language evolution.

My aim here is to evaluate whether MST is defensible. Section 2 clarifies the conceptual terrain: what counts as the “perception” of goal-directed action, and what it would mean for motor resonance to be “necessary.” Section 3 presents the main arguments advanced in favor of MST, along with the empirical evidence typically cited. Section 4 develops four objections: epistemic, phenomenological, developmental, and cross-cultural. Each suggests ways in which the perception of goal-directedness can occur independently of motor resonance. Section 5 sketches three alternative models—teleological, cue-based heuristic, and ecological/direct social perception—that can accommodate the data without positing a necessity claim. Section 6 briefly considers how much is lost if MST is rejected, and Section 7 draws a balanced conclusion.

2. Clarifying the Thesis  

2.1 Perception versus Cognition  
When the visual psychologist says we “perceive” an object, she may mean that the relevant information is extracted early—prior to propositional inference, and available to guide rapid motor responses. In social cognition, however, talk of “perceiving” others’ goals is sometimes ambiguous between (i) a low-level, quasi-phenomenal registration (I see the coffee mug as the target of your reach) and (ii) a high-level attribution (I believe you want a sip). MST is typically directed at (i): the claim is that the content “goal-directed toward X” can be embedded within perception proper, not merely within later cognitive processing. If so, motor resonance would need to operate fast enough and early enough to contribute to the perceptual episode.

2.2 What Kind of Necessity?  
Several senses of necessity are in play:

Logical necessity: Impossible to perceive goal-directedness without resonance—implausible given our limited knowledge of neural possibilities.

Metaphysical/nomological necessity: Under the physical laws that govern creatures with our neurophysiology, perception of goal-directedness requires resonance.

Statistical necessity: In the actual human population with typical brains, perception of goal-directedness always co-occurs with resonance.

Because MST is usually defended empirically, proponents settle for nomological or statistical necessity: for creatures like us, and perhaps all primates, motor resonance is a requisite condition.

3. The Case for MST  

3.1 Timing Evidence  
In single-cell recordings, mirror-neuron firing in area F5 peaks within ~120 ms of action onset. EEG mu-suppression in infants and adults likewise begins shortly after the observed movement. These latencies overlap with the time window in which visual cortex constructs an initial representation of object motion, suggesting that motor resonance may feed forward into higher-level perceptual areas in time to shape how the goal is visually coded.

3.2 Interference Studies  
TMS over inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) or premotor cortex can selectively disrupt observers’ abilities to match others’ gestures to objectives (e.g., “choose which object the actor intends to grasp”). Likewise, patients with apraxia or lesions to putative mirror areas show impaired performance on goal-recognition tasks. The inference: if disabling the motor circuit hampers goal perception, the circuit must be necessary.

3.3 Developmental Evidence  
Within the first year, infants exhibit both motor resonance (EEG mu-rhythm suppression when watching grasps) and sensitivity to goal structure (e.g., interpreting a novel reach as directed toward the same object despite a new spatial path). Some longitudinal data show correlations between the strength of infants’ resonance and their success on goal-prediction tasks, tempting researchers to infer a causal link.

3.4 Evolutionary-Economy Argument  
Assuming that predicting others’ goals confers survival advantages, natural selection would favor a neurocomputational shortcut: reuse your own motor controller as a model of the other. Resonance therefore seems an efficient and likely route by which goal perception could have evolved.

4. Four Objections to Necessity  

4.1 Epistemic Objection: Pathological and Artificial Cases  
Individuals with selective motor impairments—congenital limb aplasia, severe paralysis, or locked-in syndrome—often retain robust capacities to interpret actions they cannot execute. Recent eye-tracking studies show that congenitally limb-less adults predict action endpoints as accurately as controls. If motor resonance were necessary, we would expect deficits. Defenders of MST might reply that these observers resonantly simulate using residual or overlapping effectors (e.g., shoulder muscles) or employ visual imagery that recruits motor circuits sub-threshold. Yet fMRI data often reveal little to no activation in canonical motor areas in such participants, suggesting alternative mechanisms suffice.

Even more dramatically, state-of-the-art computer-vision systems classify goal-directed actions with superhuman accuracy, yet possess no motor system at all. One may object: “machines are irrelevant because we care about biological perceivers.” But the existence of a feasible non-motor algorithm refutes any deep metaphysical link between goal perception and resonance—the relation is at best contingent.

4.2 Phenomenological Objection: What It Is Like to See Intentions  
When I see a skilled pianist’s hands on the keys, I grasp her goal though I cannot begin to move my fingers that way. More generally, spectators enjoy gymnastics, figure skating, or martial-arts films despite lacking matching motor repertoires. The phenomenology feels immediate: we do not first simulate internally and then infer; rather, the dancer’s leap is transparently “toward the bar.” If MST were true, we should expect degraded or delayed experience in domains where our resonance is poor. But speed and vividness are preserved.

Proponents might argue that the motor system need only resonate at an abstract level (e.g., representing endpoint trajectories). That concession, however, dilutes MST: if “motor resonance” includes any covert coding of spatial vectors, virtually every perceptual process counts. The necessity claim becomes unfalsifiable.

4.3 Developmental Objection: Efficacy Precedes Competence  
Newborns track goal-directed motion long before they can reach accurately. Six-month-old infants show anticipatory gaze shifts to where a hand will place a ball even though they cannot yet perform that placement themselves. If resonance required a pre-existing motor program, such early sensitivity would be mysterious. One could posit innate but dormant motor blueprints, yet this smacks of ad hoc preservation of MST. A simpler story is that infants extract high-level regularities—contact, efficiency, obstacle avoidance—from the kinematics, independent of their own motor repertoire.

4.4 Cross-Cultural and Species Objection  
Humans easily perceive goal-directedness in non-conspecifics: we attribute goal pursuit to dogs, birds, even Roomba vacuum cleaners. Unless MST grants that we possess motor schemas for canine gait or robotic wheels, these cases show that goal perception generalizes beyond resonance. More strikingly, archerfish track and anticipate insect trajectories to spit water, demonstrating that non-mammalian species without a homologous mirror system nonetheless perceive prey goals. Thus resonance is not a phylogenetically universal prerequisite.

5. Alternative Accounts  

5.1 Teleological Reasoning Model  
Gergely & Csibra (2003) argue that humans deploy an “intuitive teleology”: we represent agents as pursuing goals in ways that are rational given environmental constraints. Their classic experiment used animated geometrical shapes—no biological motion cues—yet infants inferred goal constancy across changed paths. The engine is not motor mirroring but a general principle: assume the agent will reach an endpoint efficiently unless obstructed. This explains why infants recognize an arched trajectory as goal-directed and later imitate the unusual arc only when the obstacle is gone (the “rational imitation” effect). Teleological reasoning operates on abstract variables like efficiency and obstruction, not on motor equivalence.

5.2 Cue-Based Heuristic Model  
Scholl and colleagues propose that the visual system is tuned to certain kinematic signatures—self-propelled motion, abrupt direction changes, speed–curvature profiles—that cue agency and goal pursuit. These heuristics are fast, automatic, and largely independent of spectator motor ability. They also align with the ethological literature on “predator detection” where prey animals show reflexive orienting toward stimuli that move along biological, velocity-regulated paths.

5.3 Ecological/Direct Social Perception  
Building on Gibsonian ecological psychology, Chemero, Myin, and others argue that perception risks over-intellectualization when we posit internal simulation. Instead, agentive affordances (what the actor is doing and why) are specified in the optical flow itself, available to be directly picked up. What mirror-neuron studies reveal, on this view, is not a prerequisite mechanism but a downstream resonance that follows from already-achieved perceptual understanding. Correlation does not entail causal precedence.

6. Reconciling the Data Without Necessity  

What then explains the myriad findings linking motor activation and goal understanding? Three reconciliations suggest themselves:

a) Modulatory Role: Motor resonance enhances precision or speed of goal perception when available, but the visual and teleological systems can operate without it. This framework predicts mild deficits (slower RTs) under TMS rather than wholesale collapse—patterns that match many empirical reports.

b) Redundant/Pluralistic Architecture: Evolution frequently builds overlapping systems for critical functions. Vision, proprioception, and audition all inform posture; likewise, both resonance and heuristic cueing may yield converging estimates of another’s goal, ensuring robustness.

c) Epiphenomenal Coupling: Resonance may reflect downstream covert imitation—an observer preparing to respond socially. The system is activated by, rather than constitutive of, goal perception. Indeed, if motor activation peaks slightly after perceptual categorization, this temporal order suggests an effect, not a cause.

7. Conclusion  

Motor resonance is undoubtedly fascinating and functionally significant. It participates in imitation, social prediction, and perhaps empathic attunement. Yet the evidence falls short of establishing that it is necessary for the perception of goal-directed action. Pathological dissociations, developmental asymmetries, cross-species observations, and phenomenological reflection collectively undermine the necessity claim. Alternative models grounded in teleological reasoning, cue-based heuristics, or ecological pickup explain how observers, even those with limited motor capacities, can effortlessly recognize goal-directed behavior.

A more tempered view recommends that we replace MST with the Motor Facilitation Hypothesis (MFH): resonance can facilitate, speed, or refine goal perception when an adequate motor match exists, but it is neither strictly required nor always engaged. Such a hypothesis preserves the valuable insights of mirror-neuron research while avoiding the overreach of claiming necessity. Philosophy and cognitive science thus converge on a pluralistic understanding: multiple, interacting routes underwrite our remarkable capacity to see what others are up to.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action  
—Is Simulation a Necessary Condition?—

1. Introduction  

When you see a barista reach for a mug, tilt the pitcher, and begin to pour steamed milk, you immediately grasp what she is doing: she is preparing a latte. A popular explanation of this fluency appeals to “motor resonance,” sometimes called “motor simulation” or “mirror-system activation.” According to the strongest version of the resonance thesis, perceiving an action as goal-directed constitutively depends on mapping the observed movement onto one’s own motor repertoire. Philosophers such as Alvin Goldman and neuroscientists inspired by mirror-neuron research have suggested that the perceptual content “She is making a latte” is available to an observer only if her own motor system covertly rehearses a relevant action plan.  

This claim is ambitious. It is not merely that motor resonance facilitates action understanding or usually accompanies it; the claim is that resonance is **necessary**. If that is true, individuals who cannot, or do not, resonate motorically should be unable to perceive goal-directedness at all. This essay argues that the necessity claim is untenable. While motor resonance can enhance and sometime speed the perception of goal-directed action, a growing body of philosophical reasoning and empirical evidence shows that humans—and other animals—can detect goal-directed structure independently of being able to enact or simulate the movement observed.  

The discussion proceeds in five steps. Section 2 sorts conceptual terrain and clarifies what “perception,” “goal-directed action,” and “motor resonance” mean in this debate. Section 3 reconstructs the main arguments for the necessity thesis. Section 4 canvasses empirical challenges, from neonate and infant studies to work on motor-impaired populations, artificial agents, and non-biological motion patterns. Section 5 develops two positive alternative accounts—teleological reasoning and purely visual kinematic pattern recognition—that explain how goal-directedness can be perceptually available without resonance. Section 6 integrates the preceding considerations into an overall evaluative framework and concludes that motor resonance is at most contingently helpful, not constitutively required.

2. Conceptual Preliminaries  

2.1 Perception versus Cognition  
The necessity thesis is most interesting when applied to **perception**—the immediate, quasi-automatic uptake of information, not the product of slow inference. If the thesis were merely about high-level judgment (“I think she intends X”), little hangs on it, because few deny that cognitive inference can proceed without motor simulation. The debate instead concerns whether the *perceptual experience*—the way the action looks—is already imbued with goal-directed content thanks to motor resonance.  

2.2 Goal-Directed Action  
An action is typically labeled “goal-directed” when it exhibits purposiveness: the movement trajectory is organized around bringing about some distal state (pouring milk, grasping a cup, scoring a goal). Crucially, goal-directedness is not itself visible in the sense that color or motion is; it is an abstraction from kinematic cues plus background constraints about rational agency. The question is whether such abstraction requires motor mapping.

2.3 Motor Resonance  
Functional MRI, TMS, and single-cell recordings show that observing action A often activates brain regions also active when performing A: premotor, parietal, and/or cerebellar circuits. This “resonance” need not be conscious, nor does it always mirror the full action. Importantly, we must distinguish:

a. Correlative resonance: Activation happens to occur.  
b. Causal-facilitative resonance: Activation helps recognize the action.  
c. Constitutive-necessary resonance: Without activation, recognition cannot arise.  

The necessity thesis asserts (c).

3. Arguments for Necessity  

3.1 The Intuitive Simulation Argument  
Proponents note the subjective feel: when you see someone throw a ball, you “feel” the arc internally. If such proprioceptive imagery is missing, they claim, the experience would be mere motion watching, devoid of purposiveness.  

3.2 The Mirror Neuron Evidence  
Single-cell recordings in macaques (Rizzolatti et al.) reveal neurons that fire both when grasping and when seeing a grasp. Because these cells carry motoric encoding of action goals (e.g., “grasp-to-eat” vs “grasp-to-place”), some infer that the brain reads the goal off its own motor code; without that code, no goal representation would emerge.

3.3 The Poverty of the Visual Stimulus  
Another line stresses ambiguity: the same finger trajectory can be scratching or beckoning. Purely visual input allegedly underdetermines goal attribution. Motor simulation supplies the hidden parameter (intention), resolving ambiguity pre-attentively.

3.4 The Developmental Priority Claim  
Infants, it is said, first develop motor competences (grasping, gaze-shifting) and only then display sensitivity to others’ goals. Therefore, resonance arising from one’s own motor practice scaffolds the perception of goal-directedness.

4. Empirical and Philosophical Challenges  

4.1 Neonates’ Goal Perception Precedes Motor Skill  
Contrary to the developmental claim, six-month-olds who cannot yet perform specific actions (e.g., placing rings on a post) still anticipate the goals of those actions in others, as measured by predictive gaze (Brandone & Wellman 2009). Even three-month-olds show expectation-violation reactions when an agent takes an inefficient path toward a target (Csibra et al.). Their own motor repertoire is too poor to simulate such trajectories, undermining necessity.

4.2 Motor-Impaired Individuals  
Adults with congenital limb absence or severe motor impairments accurately perceive and predict others’ manual actions (Vannuscorps & Caramazza 2016). Functional imaging shows reduced or absent activation in canonical mirror areas, yet behavioral performance is intact. Unless one posits a hidden, non-effector-dependent simulation—which empties the thesis of testable content—necessity fails.

4.3 Action Perception in Non-Human Animals  
Dogs, birds, and even fish track goal paths (e.g., intercepting prey) though their motor systems are wildly different from the observed prey’s biomechanics. Unless we anthropomorphize canids with phantom hand circuits, motor resonance cannot be the basis of their goal perception.

4.4 Abstract and Non-Biological Agents  
People readily attribute goal-directedness to geometric shapes in Heider-Simmel animations or dots on a screen moving contingently (Gao et al.). Mirror neuron areas are only weakly engaged here, yet observers experience the movements as purposeful. If resonance were necessary, these attributions would be impossible.

4.5 Sensory Modality Independence  
We recognize intentional communicative actions by sound (knocking a Morse code) or by vibrotactile patterns (as in haptic teleoperation). These cases bypass visual-motor mapping altogether. Resonance in limb movement areas is minimal; still, we perceive purposive organization.

4.6 Double Dissociations in Timing  
TMS studies show that disrupting premotor cortex slows but does not abolish goal recognition; subjects remain above chance (Cattaneo et al.). Similarly, Parkinson’s patients with impaired motor resonance display normal accuracy though slower reaction times. This fits a facilitation, not necessity, model.

4.7 Philosophical Underdetermination  
Conceptually, from the premise that the same neurons encode own-actions and perceived actions, it does not follow that the second encodes the first *via* the same route. Correlation is not constitution. The inference commits the “mereological fallacy”—assigning to a part (the motor circuit) a holistic function (goal perception) that may emerge from broader networks.

5. Positive Alternative Accounts  

5.1 Teleological Reasoning Framework (Gergely & Csibra)  
According to teleological reasoning, perceivers apply a “rationality principle”: given environmental constraints, agents tend to choose the most efficient means to their goals. The visual system extracts physical parameters—agent’s current location, obstacles, target object—and uses a domain-specific inference engine evolved for social cognition to represent the observed motion as rationally organized. Crucially, this does not require matching the effector or muscle pattern. All that is needed is an ability to represent trajectories and constraints within a Newtonian-like scene.  

Evidence: Infants expect an agent to take a shorter path even when the agent’s morphology is unlike theirs (a self-propelled box). Adults detect sub-optimal paths in robot arms they could not physically enact. The computations rely on spatial-causal cognition, not on sharing motor primitives.

5.2 Kinematic Pattern Recognition and Statistical Learning  
Another approach treats goal perception as sophisticated pattern classification. The visual system, through exposure, learns contingencies between motion profiles and outcome states. Deep-learning models with no motor system at all—purely feedforward convolutional networks—achieve high accuracy in classifying human actions and predicting end-states. This demonstrates in silico that mapping to one’s own motor repertoire is not logically required to extract goals.  

In humans, EEG decoding shows that posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) carries sufficient information to classify actions independent of premotor cortex activation (Isik et al.). On this view, resonance is epiphenomenal: premotor areas get recruited as one among many predictive cue integrators, but the core computation can proceed elsewhere.

6. Integrative Evaluation  

6.1 When Resonance Helps  
The cases above do not deny that motor resonance can be *beneficial*. For familiar, bodily actions within one’s skill set, premotor activation can sharpen temporal prediction, disambiguate fine-grained intentions (grasp-to-eat vs grasp-to-place), and prepare complementary responses. Indeed, TMS or cortical stimulation often yields measurable facilitation. But facilitation differs from necessity: if another route can deliver perception, then resonance is not a precondition.

6.2 Robustness Across Contexts  
A sound necessary-condition claim should hold across:

a. Developmental stages  
b. Morphological variation  
c. Modalities (visual, auditory, haptic)  
d. Neurological damage  
e. Artificially minimal stimuli  

The resonance thesis fails these tests. In every dimension, we find counter-examples where goal perception persists without plausible motor mapping.

6.3 Re-interpreting Mirror Neuron Data  
Rather than reading mirror activity as the *source* of goal content, we can view it as the *recipient* of higher-level predictive signals. According to predictive-processing frameworks, pSTS or parietal areas infer likely goals; these are fed to premotor cortex to prime possible responses. Thus the direction of causation runs from perceptual inference to motor preparation, not vice versa.

6.4 The Poverty-of-Stimulus Re-evaluated  
Proponents claim visual kinematics underdetermine goal content. Yet the underdetermination is exaggerated. Spatiotemporal regularities, object affordances, and statistical learning provide rich constraints. Just as we identify phonemes despite acoustic variability without simulating articulatory gestures (contra strong motor theories of speech), we can identify actions without simulating muscle synergies.

6.5 Philosophical Economy  
Occam’s razor tilts against positing additional necessary machinery when simpler mechanisms suffice. If teleological reasoning and kinematic pattern recognition already explain the data—and handle cases where no resonance is possible—then claiming necessity for resonance violates methodological parsimony.

7. Conclusion  

The intuitive appeal of motor resonance as the fountainhead of social perception must be tempered by careful analysis. Philosophically, the inference from correlation to necessity is invalid; empirically, the necessity thesis founders on a raft of counter-examples: neonates, motor-impaired individuals, non-human animal observers, and perception of abstract agents. Alternative frameworks grounded in teleological reasoning and statistical pattern recognition account for goal perception across these contexts, while leaving room for motor resonance to play a modulatory, facilitative role when available.  

Accordingly, the best supported position is a **pluralistic, non-reductive view**: the perceptual system implements multiple, partially redundant routes to understanding others’ actions. Motor resonance is one such route—probabilistically engaged, beneficial for fine-grained prediction, but neither the sole nor the necessary gateway to experiencing movements as goal-directed. The latte still looks like a latte-in-the-making even to those who have never steamed milk—and that simple fact, observable in labs and cafés alike, is enough to refute the necessity claim.

Is motor resonance—the covert mapping of observed movements onto one’s own motor repertoire—a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed action? The idea has intuitive appeal. If the only way I can appreciate that you are grasping a mug in order to drink is by unconsciously running a “grasp-and-drink” program in my own motor cortex, then deficits in such resonance should systematically impair my ability to see actions as directed toward goals. Mirror-neuron discoveries and simulationist theories in philosophy have amplified this suggestion. Nevertheless, the thesis that resonance is strictly necessary is stronger than most of its advocates acknowledge. In what follows I first clarify the claim and survey leading arguments in its favor. I then marshal empirical, conceptual and phenomenological considerations that tell against necessity. My conclusion is modest: motor resonance is often explanatorily useful and may enhance the rapidity and richness of goal-ascriptions, but perceivers can and frequently do register others’ goals independently of any resonance mechanism. A weaker, facilitative role for resonance is therefore the most defensible position.

1. Clarifying “necessity”  

Necessity can be construed in at least three ways.

a. Conceptual necessity: it is incoherent to attribute goal perception without simulation, because to see something as a goal-directed action is partly to reenact it.

b. Empirical/biological necessity: given how human brains are wired, resonance mechanisms are indispensable for the function of goal perception.

c. Causal necessity in particular contexts: in real-time perception under ordinary conditions, resonance is always among the causal factors without which goal perception would fail.

A proponent of the strong thesis has to defend (b) or (c). Conceptual necessity is hard to maintain: nothing in the concept “perceiving a goal” logically entails motor rehearsal. So the debate is empirical.

2. The case for necessity  

Advocates cite three primary lines of evidence.

i. Mirror-neuron activations. The classic finding is that macaque area F5 neurons fire both when the monkey grasps a peanut and when it observes another do so. Human neuroimaging has revealed homologous circuits—ventral premotor, inferior parietal, superior temporal. The assumption is that these activations ground our grasp of the other’s intention.

ii. Perturbation studies. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) over premotor cortex during action observation slows recognition of action goals or reduces accuracy in predicting where a movement is heading. Such interference suggests that the motor system supplies indispensable information.

iii. Developmental data. Some newborn imitation studies (though now contested) found that neonates reproduce tongue protrusions and mouth openings. If infants can mirror before mastering propositional inference, perhaps resonance scaffolds the later ability to perceive goals.

Simulation theorists (e.g., Gallese & Goldman) have woven these findings into a broader philosophical framework. We attribute mental states “from the inside” by putting ourselves in the other’s shoes; motor resonance would thus implement an embodied variety of mindreading. If no covert simulation can be generated, one allegedly loses the experiential basis for discerning the goal.

3. Scrutinizing the empirical premises  

   3.1 Lesion and deficit evidence  

If resonance were necessary, individuals lacking the relevant motor representations should systematically fail at goal perception. Yet converging clinical cases say otherwise.

• Moebius syndrome involves congenital facial paralysis. Individuals cannot execute or, by extension, simulate facial expressions. Nonetheless, they score in the normal range on recognition of others’ emotions and action goals when given sufficient visual exposure (Calder et al., 2000; Rives Bogart & Matsumoto, 2010).

• Limb-deficient participants without hands can still detect hand actions and their goals in point-light displays and naturalistic videos (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2016). Although their primary motor cortex lacks a hand representation, their accuracy rivals that of controls.

• Ideomotor apraxics sometimes show severe impairment in producing purposeful actions, yet many retain intact comprehension of those very actions when performed by others. This dissociation undermines a strict necessity claim.

These findings present double dissociations: action production or simulation can be lost while perception remains.

   3.2 Developmental counter-evidence  

Nine-month-old infants reliably encode goal information when watching novel apparatus interactions (Woodward, 1998). Yet electrophysiological indices of mature motor resonance (mu-suppression localized to hand areas) do not appear robustly until later in the second year. Either infants deploy an immature but sufficient form of resonance, or, more plausibly, they use visual-pragmatic cues such as efficiency and contact to infer goals, with motor resonance emerging as an enhancer.

   3.3 Causal-intervention studies revisited  

TMS interference affects performance, but not uniformly. When context cues (e.g., a glass near a thirsty agent) strongly suggest the goal, disrupting premotor cortex leaves comprehension largely intact (Brass et al., 2007). The motor system seems especially helpful under ambiguous kinematic information; its contribution is modulatory, not indispensable.

4. A positive alternative: direct-perceptual and inferential routes  

Philosophically, we should distinguish two ways of “seeing an action as goal-directed”.

a. Kinematic pattern recognition. Vision is exquisitely sensitive to characteristic velocity profiles of biological motion (Giese & Poggio, 2003). Even abstract point-light displays allow observers to tell purposeful from random movement. Visual areas STS and MT encode such regularities without recourse to motor areas.

b. Teleological reasoning. Csibra and Gergely propose that humans possess a “teleological stance”: minimal causal–goal analysis that represents agents as selecting the most efficient means to achieve desired outcomes, computed over world constraints. This reasoning can be implemented by domain-general inferential circuits—prefrontal and temporo-parietal regions—independently of motor resonance.

These avenues supply sufficient information in many everyday contexts: if I see you circumvent a barrier on a direct path to the door handle, I store a visual trajectory and infer your goal from situational constraints, not from simulating your muscles.

5. Conceptual tensions in the necessity claim  

Simulation is, by definition, a second-personal phenomenon: I simulate your action in my neural machinery. Yet perceiving a goal can be third-personal and object-directed: I see that you reach for the apple. The intentional object is the apple, not the kinesthetic script. Explaining such perceptual content solely by resonance risks “methodological solipsism”: privileging what is inside my sensorimotor cortex at the expense of worldly structure.

Furthermore, the claim blurs the distinction between constitutive and enabling conditions. Motor resonance may enable faster parsing (as do good lighting conditions), but that does not make it constitutive. Many necessity arguments mistakenly slide from covariation (mirror activity often accompanies goal perception) to constitutive dependence.

6. The integrationist picture  

Rather than placing all inferential weight on a single mechanism, contemporary cognitive science points to multi-layered processing.

• Early visual modules detect form and velocity.

• Parietal and premotor circuits translate these into motor-affordance codes—helpful when the observed action is one we could physically perform.

• Prefrontal and temporo-parietal nodes integrate contextual clues, object identities, prior knowledge of agent preferences.

Evidence from dynamic causal modeling (Kilner et al., 2007) suggests recurrent loops between these stages. Motor resonance sits in the loop, but the loop can be reconfigured when a node is damaged. Plasticity will recruit alternative pathways, as seen in limb-deficient observers who rely more on STS-prefrontal connectivity.

7. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: “Residual performance in clinical cases might rely on covert motor imagery with remaining musculature or alternative body parts.”  

Reply: Experiments controlling for such imagery by having participants simultaneously execute unrelated motor tasks still find preserved action understanding. Moebius subjects, for example, cannot simulate facial musculature at all, yet recognize expressions.

Objection 2: “Goal perception is degraded in subtle ways even when overt accuracy is preserved.”  

Reply: Some sensitivity loss is plausible. But necessity is an absolute thesis: if correct, degradation should reach the point of failure, not mere slowing. The empirical pattern shows graded modulation, inconsistent with hard necessity.

Objection 3: “Other mechanisms develop only because motor resonance has provided early scaffolding.”  

Reply: Longitudinal studies of infants lacking the ability to crawl (because of temporary orthopedic constraints) still develop robust goal perception. Moreover, cross-cultural studies in remote communities with different motor repertoires do not reveal deficits in interpreting unfamiliar actions once visually familiarized. Hence scaffolding is not indispensable.

8. Phenomenological considerations  

When I watch an Olympic gymnast perform a triple back somersault—an action far outside my motor repertoire—I nonetheless perceive it as goal-directed precision. Subjectively, I do not “feel” the gymnast’s proprioception. To salvage necessity, the proponent must claim that some minimal motor mapping occurs regardless of conscious awareness. But putative mapping would now be so thin and generic that it is unclear how it could carry the specific intentional content of “landing upright.” Phenomenology therefore aligns better with an independence thesis.

9. Implications for social cognition  

If resonance were necessary, populations with motor disorders would face global social-cognitive deficits. Although autism spectrum conditions involve atypical mirror-system activation, meta-analyses show that impairments correlate more strongly with mentalizing network differences than with motor resonance per se (Hamilton, 2013). Therapeutic programs that target explicit perspective-taking often improve social skills without altering motor abilities, supporting a plurality of routes to mindreading.

10. Conclusion  

The allure of motor resonance lies in its promise to naturalize the perception of intentionality: a neurophysiological bridge from movement to meaning. Yet bridges can be optional routes rather than sole passageways. Cumulative evidence demonstrates that humans can and do perceive goal-directed actions through visual analysis of kinematics, contextual inference, and higher-level reasoning, none of which require the motor system to rehearse the movement. Resonance amplifies and speeds the process in many circumstances, especially when kinematic cues are ambiguous or rapid prediction is valuable for interaction. This facilitative, non-necessary role meshes with broader principles of neural redundancy and pluripotency: multiple systems converge on the same functional output, ensuring robustness.

Philosophers should therefore resist overgeneralizing from mirror-neuron data to conceptual claims about the nature of action perception. Goal perception is multiply realizable; motor resonance is one realizer among several. Appreciating this pluralism avoids both neuro-centric reductionism and disembodied intellectualism, showing instead how embodied simulation, visual pragmatics, and inferential cognition collaborate—none monopolizing the capacity to see others as purposive agents.

1. Framing the Issue  

When I watch a barista reach for the steam wand and swivel the milk jug, I ordinarily see not a mere concatenation of limb-movements but an intentional performance: the barista is frothing milk in order to prepare a cappuccino.  A natural question is how, in real time, my visual system arrives at that richly intentional representation.  A prominent answer in contemporary philosophy of mind and cognitive science appeals to motor resonance.  Roughly, motor resonance occurs when the observer’s own motor circuits are covertly activated as if preparing or executing the observed action.  According to the “simulationist” hypothesis (Gallese & Goldman 1998; Rizzolatti & Sinigaglia 2010), such resonance is not a dispensable accompaniment but a necessary condition for perceiving the action as goal-directed.  Without a match between the observed kinematic profile and a motor program in my repertoire—so the claim goes—the scene would register as a meaningless motion.

The aim of this essay is to evaluate that necessity thesis.  I proceed in four steps.  (§2) I clarify what “perceiving goal-directed action” means, distinguishing it from higher-level inference and mere sensitivity to statistical regularities.  (§3) I lay out the main empirical and conceptual arguments advanced in favour of the necessity of motor resonance.  (§4) I examine three families of counter-considerations—developmental, neuropsychological, and ecological—that jointly undermine the necessity claim.  (§5) I sketch an alternative, pluralist model on which resonance is one among several routes to goal-ascription.  I conclude that motor resonance is neither necessary nor sufficient, though it can facilitate rapid, fine-grained action understanding.

2. What Is It to Perceive Goal-Directed Action?  

“Perception” is a spectrum term.  At one end lie “late” interpretative attributions drawing on background beliefs; at the other end, “early” vision is thought to deliver relatively encapsulated, modal representations.  For purposes of the present debate, what matters is whether the intention or goal of an action is available to the subject in a phenomenologically immediate, pre-reflective way—in Gibson’s idiom, whether the goal is an ecological affordance visibly present in the unfolding kinematics.  When I see a hand grasp a cup with a precision grip and transport it toward a mouth, I experience the movement as drinking-directed.  The simulationist claim, therefore, is that such experiential uptake requires covert motor matching.

Importantly, the thesis is not just about judgment but perceptual contents.  One can always form post-perceptual beliefs via theory or inference; the strong motor theory asserts something deeper: the percept itself is constituted by resonance.  That sets the bar high, making the view empirically vulnerable.

3. The Case for Necessity  

Proponents marshal three main lines of support.

3.1 Mirror Neuron Evidence  

The discovery of mirror neurons in macaque area F5 and their putative human analogues (premotor and inferior parietal cortices) is often cited.  These neurons fire both when the monkey grasps an object and when it sees someone else grasp the same kind of object.  Further, firing is typically goal-specific: F5 neurons prefer whole-hand grasps versus precision grips regardless of the exact trajectory.  Gallese and colleagues infer that the motor code already embodies the goal.  Since mirror activation temporally overlaps with the early visual processing of the observed act, they argue it must be integral to representing the act’s goal.

3.2 Efficiency and Speed  

Behavioural studies using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) show that motor-evoked potentials in specific muscles mirror the temporally evolving pattern of the observed muscle use within ~120 ms (Kilner et al. 2004).  Goal assignment is impressively fast: participants detect subtle “grasp-to-drink” versus “grasp-to-place” differences within 200–300 ms.  Simulationists argue that such millisecond-range sensitivity surpasses what a slower, purely visual or inferential pathway could provide.

3.3 Developmental Plausibility  

By 5–6 months, pre-reach infants preferentially look at goal-consistent completions of reaching actions and treat a reach as directed to an object even when the object’s position is swapped (Woodward 1998).  Considering their limited executive repertoire, simulationists suggest the only viable mechanism is a rudimentary motor mapping inherited from neonatal imitation systems (Meltzoff & Moore 1977).  If infants code others’ goals before they possess a robust folk psychology, perhaps perception relies on the one resource they do have: an embodied motor repertoire.

From these considerations, simulationists derive a modal thesis: necessarily, for any subject S and action A, S perceives A as goal-directed only if a corresponding motor program in S is (sub-thresholdly) activated.

4. Counter-Arguments  

The pro-necessity arguments are suggestive but not conclusive.  Several empirical and conceptual considerations point the other way.

4.1 Developmental and Cross-Cultural Variation  

a) Early Sensitivity Without Motor Ability  
Newborns cannot reach, yet at 2 days old they prefer biological to random motion and discriminate goal path violations in point-light displays (Simion et al. 2008).  At 3 months, before grasping emerges, infants parse chase sequences on the basis of intentional contingency, not low-level motion cues (Rochat et al. 2014).  These abilities precede the relevant motor skills, undercutting an indispensability link.

b) Tool Use and Novel Actions  
Adults perceive the goal of complex tool actions (e.g., a surgeon manipulating a laparoscopic robot) that they have never performed and sometimes could not in principle perform.  Yet fMRI shows minimal mirror recruitment for such novel tool events; instead, activity arises in visual-conceptual regions (pSTS, temporo-parietal junction; Cross et al. 2013).  Our perceptual system evidently extracts high-level structure—instrument-target relations, causal constraints—without recourse to motor matching.

c) Cultural Expertise  
Expert dancers watching a familiar dance show more motor cortex activation than novices, but novices still recognise the dance’s purpose (e.g., ceremonial greeting versus courtship).  If resonance were strictly required, novices would be blind to those intentions.

4.2 Neuropsychological Dissociations  

a) Apraxia and Motor Impairment  
Patients with ideomotor apraxia, Parkinson’s disease, or limb amputation often show severely compromised motor programmes.  Yet many accurately identify others’ action goals (Funk et al. 2019).  Conversely, individuals with autism spectrum conditions sometimes exhibit diminished mirror responses yet variable difficulties with action reading; critically, there is no one-to-one mapping between mirror attenuation and understanding deficits (Hamilton 2013).

b) TMS and Deactivation Studies  
Temporarily disrupting premotor cortex via TMS interferes with fine-grained prediction of kinematics but leaves coarse goal classification largely intact (Avenanti et al. 2017).  This suggests that motor resonance refines but does not ground goal perception.

4.3 Ecological and Computational Concerns  

a) Visual Kinematics Carry Goal Information  
Even if mirror neurons are goal-tuned, that does not mean visual channels are blind to goals.  The shape of a velocity profile, grip aperture, object affordances, and environmental constraints jointly specify likely outcomes; advanced machine-vision systems can classify goals purely from visual input (Tran & Cheong 2021).  Evolutionarily, it would be odd if such rich cues were perceptually inert absent self-motor matching.

b) Over-Intellectualisation of Motor Codes  
Motor programs are themselves abstract: they represent end states.  To claim perception of goal requires motor activation risks triviality: both systems may converge on the same distal variable (e.g., “hand-to-mouth”), but convergence does not entail dependence.

c) Species Variation  
Dogs infer human pointing goals, scrub jays hide food from knowledgeable conspecifics, and cuttlefish adjust hunting strategy based on prey attention.  These creatures lack the hominoid mirror circuits in question, indicating at least an alternative phylogenetic pathway to goal perception.

5. Toward a Pluralist Account  

How, then, should we conceptualise the role of motor resonance?  I propose the following.

5.1 Three Routes to Goal Perception  

1. Visual-Kinematic Route  
Fast extraction of optical invariants—trajectory curvature, effector–object geometry, environmental affordances—affords goal recognition even for novel or unperformable acts.

2. Motor Resonance Route  
When the observed kinematics lie within the observer’s motor repertoire, predictive coding in the motor system simulates forward models, enabling quick anticipation of fine details (e.g., when catching a ball thrown by another person).  This route yields a vivid “as if I did it” phenomenology but is supplementary.

3. Semantic-Pragmatic Route  
Linguistic cues, cultural scripts, and background knowledge inform goal perception in slower, top-down fashion, essential for abstract or institutional actions (signing a contract).

These routes are partially redundant and interact dynamically.  Crucially, any one can suffice, making none individually necessary.

5.2 Empirical Predictions  

The pluralist model yields testable predictions:

• If the motor route is selectively taxed (e.g., continuous TMS over M1), coarse goal detection should remain at baseline but temporal anticipation should suffer.  
• Inverted-gravity environments, where one’s own motor predictions fail, observers should still recognise others’ proximal goals (e.g., “catch the floating object”) so long as visual invariants are stable.  
• In congenitally limb-deficient individuals, patterns of occipito-temporal activity (not premotor) should dominate action understanding, mirroring what Striem-Amit et al. (2018) report.

5.3 Re-interpreting Mirror Activity  

Mirror activation is plausibly an effect—rather than a cause—of goal perception: once a plausible distal goal is visually extracted, premotor areas enlist to refine timing, generate empathy, or prepare complementary responses.  That fits hierarchical predictive-processing architectures in which higher-level hypotheses drive lower-level simulation for error minimisation (Clark 2013).  The motor system thus serves as a context-sensitive emulator augmenting, not constituting, perception.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The speed of mirror activation proves it is early and thus constitutive.  
Reply: Early does not equal necessary.  The magnocellular visual pathway itself is equally fast (<40 ms) in broadcasting motion cues to dorsal stream areas that can ground goal hypotheses before motor recruitment.

Objection 2: Infants’ early goal sensitivity derives from covert activations in a primitive mirror circuit.  
Reply: The developmental timing argument is under-determined.  Correlated maturation does not establish causation.  Moreover, neonates’ pre-reach imitative behaviours may rely on perceptual matching rules (like active intermodal mapping) rather than genuine motor programs (Paulus 2014).

Objection 3: Without resonance, we could not understand actions of non-conspecifics (e.g., robots) unless we learn to motorically simulate them.  
Reply: On the contrary, people effortlessly ascribe goals to Roomba vacuums or animated triangles whose movement lies outside any human motor repertoire (Heider & Simmel 1944).  Visual heuristics—contingency, self-propulsion, and efficiency—suffice.

7. Concluding Assessment  

Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions?  The cumulative evidence and analysis suggest a negative answer.  While motor resonance provides a powerful, embodied shortcut for recognising and predicting familiar actions, it is not the sole nor indispensable route.  Infants, non-human animals, individuals with motor deficits, and even typical adults confronted with unfamiliar tool use all demonstrate that goal perception can proceed independently of motor simulation.  The relationship is thus one of facilitation, not necessity: resonance enriches, speeds up, and embeds the perceived goal within a sensorimotor scaffold, but the perceptual system has other, largely visual means of recovering intentional structure.

Recognising this pluralism carries broader implications.  It cautions us against over-extending mirror-based “neurophilosophy of social cognition” and encourages an ecological, multi-level approach to understanding how organisms navigate the sea of intentional actions that surrounds them.  In the café, my appreciation of the barista’s foamy intentions doubtless recruits my embodied familiarity with cups and steam wands, but should my arms be in casts or should the barista manipulate an exotic siphon device I have never used, I would still see the goal—though perhaps with slower, less immersive certainty.  Perception of others’ goals, like perception more generally, is a resilient, multi-modal achievement.

1. Introduction  

We regularly recognize that the man across the street is hailing a taxi, that a colleague is reaching for the stapler, that the cat is stalking a bird.  Philosophers call these recognitions cases of perceiving goal-directed action: we do not merely see a sequence of bodily movements, we apprehend them as purposive.  A prevalent hypothesis in cognitive science—often associated with mirror-neuron research—claims that such perception depends on motor resonance: covert activation of neural populations that would be involved were we ourselves performing the observed movement.  According to the strong version of the hypothesis, motor resonance is a necessary condition: without the ability to map another’s action onto one’s own motor repertoire, one could not genuinely perceive the action as goal-directed.  

Is that claim tenable?  I shall argue that it is not.  Motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically necessary for the perception of goal-directed action, though it frequently facilitates, refines, and enriches such perception.  The argument unfolds in five stages:

(1) Clarifying what “perceiving goal-directed action” amounts to.  
(2) Presenting the best case for the necessity thesis—both its empirical motivation (mirror-neuron data) and its philosophical rationale (simulationism).  
(3) Advancing three families of counterexamples: developmental, neuropsychological, and ethological.  
(4) Diagnosing why the necessity thesis overreaches: a conflation of enabling and constitutive conditions, and a disregard for ecological and teleological information available in the stimulus.  
(5) Sketching a pluralistic alternative in which resonance mechanisms are one route among several for perceiving purposive behavior.

The resulting view respects the genuine contributions of resonance systems without granting them monopoly over social perception.

2. What is it to perceive goal-directed action?  

“Goal-directed” is a success-term: it implies that the movements are organized around the realization of an outcome.  A perceptual encounter with such an action presents, to the subject, not merely kinematic facts (arm moving upward, fingers flexing) but an organizing telos (waving down a cab, grasping a stapler).  Crucially, this presentation is experienced as immediate—one typically does not first register bare motions and then infer a goal; the goal is transparently “there” in the perceptual scene.

Two features follow:

• Content: The percept includes purposive information—what Merleau-Ponty called the “intentional arc” of the action.  
• Format: The representation is perceptual, not the upshot of conscious theoretical reasoning, even if it recruits subpersonal inferences.

The debate, therefore, concerns the subpersonal mechanisms that make such representation possible.  Are resonance processes irreplaceable components, or can other perceptual and inferential systems shoulder the explanatory load?

3. The case for the necessity of motor resonance  

3.1 Empirical rationale  

Mirror-neuron discoveries (di Pellegrino et al. 1992; Rizzolatti & Sinigaglia 2010) revealed neurons in premotor and parietal cortices that discharge both when a monkey performs an action and when it observes an experimenter performing a similar action.  In humans, fMRI and TMS studies show homologous patterns: observing a precision grip primes corticospinal excitability specific to the recorded muscles; observing mouth actions primes orofacial motor areas, and so on.  Correlational findings suggest tight coupling between the fidelity of such resonance and performance on tasks that require recognizing action goals (e.g., decoding pantomimes, predicting action outcomes).

From these data proponents infer a constitutive relation: if resonance fails, goal perception fails, because the observer lacks an internal motor “model” of the observed act.  Simulationist theorists (Gallese & Goldman 1998; Jeannerod 2006) provide the philosophical gloss: understanding an action amounts to enacting it covertly; the motor system runs a forward model that projects the likely consequences, thereby revealing its goal.

3.2 Philosophical underpinnings  

Simulationism rests on two commitments:

(i) Access constraint: Mental state attributions, including goal ascriptions, are possible only through a form of internal simulation.  
(ii) Matching requirement: Simulation requires that the observer possess motor schemas isomorphic to the performer’s movement repertoire; mapping failure entails comprehension failure.

If both claims are correct, observers lacking resonance capacity would be unable to perceive goal-directedness.  The necessity thesis follows.

4. Counterexamples to necessity  

The mirror findings are impressive, but necessity is a very strong modal claim: it states that in every possible situation where an agent perceives goal-directed action, motor resonance is involved.  To defeat such a claim we need only locate genuine cases of goal perception where resonance is absent, impaired, or impossible.  Three classes of evidence supply these cases.

4.1 Developmental evidence: Infants before motor mastery  

Infants as young as five to six months show robust sensitivity to goal structure.  In the classic Woodward (1998) paradigm, infants habituate to a hand reaching toward object A.  When at test the positions of objects A and B are swapped, infants look longer if the hand reaches to the old location than if it reaches to the old object, indicating that they encoded the reach in terms of its goal (object identity) rather than its trajectory.

Crucially, these infants cannot yet perform the reaching actions they understand.  Their own motor repertoire is extremely limited; they lack the fine-grained motor schema needed for resonance matching the adult reach.  One might reply that partial resonance suffices, but even newborns exhibit expectations of goal-directedness in completely unseen movement patterns: they anticipate that a rectangle seeking a small circle will circumvent an obstacle efficiently (Csibra et al. 1999).  The movements involve no limbs and no biologically plausible effector, yet infants detect irrational detours.  A fortiori they cannot possess motor programs matching such abstract displacements.

Unless one posits an implausibly rich innate library of motor templates for every conceivable path geometry, it is more economical to conclude that infants harness amodal inferential systems—what Gergely and Csibra call “teleological reasoning”—that compute the efficiency of action relative to environmental constraints independently of personal motor resonance.

4.2 Neuropsychological evidence: Motor impairment without perceptual loss  

If resonance is necessary, individuals with severe motor deficits should be impaired in perceiving goal-directed action.  But the data cut the other way.

a. Congenital limb absence.  Vannuscorps & Caramazza (2016) studied individuals born without upper limbs.  Behavioral tests revealed normal accuracy in recognizing hand actions and in predicting their goals.  fMRI showed typical activation in visual areas selective for hands and grasping, though the primary motor hand area was underdeveloped.  Whatever these subjects rely on, it cannot be the canonical arm-motor resonance they never acquired.

b. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).  ALS patients progressively lose motor output, but during early stages their motor cortices may remain partly functional.  However, studies controlling for cortical degeneration found no systematic decline in action goal recognition until late disease stages, suggesting that overt motor execution capability is not a prerequisite for perceptual competence.

c. Ideomotor apraxia.  Patients with apraxia have damage to premotor or parietal regions and suffer impaired production of purposeful actions.  Yet many retain the ability to identify the goals of observed actions (Buxbaum et al. 2005).  Lesion mapping shows that deficits in imitation dissociate from deficits in action comprehension, undermining the idea that motor mapping undergirds both functions uniformly.

4.3 Ethological evidence: Cross-species perception  

Predators track prey, prey evaluate predator intent, and social animals read conspecifics’ goals.  Cats perceive that birds take off toward shelter; lions anticipate the path of gazelles.  Such perception often crosses effector types: a dog understands that a human arm throwing a ball will result in the ball’s flight.  Since canine forelimbs cannot replicate human throwing, the dog cannot resonate motorically with the act, yet it perceives its goal.  One might rejoin that resonance can occur at a more abstract level (e.g., ballistic motion), but that admission renders motor resonance a label for any predictive representation, thereby emptying it of explanatory force.

5. Diagnosing the overreach  

How, then, did the necessity thesis gain traction despite these counterexamples?  Two confusions are at work.

5.1 Enabling vs. constitutive conditions  

Resonance may enable swift, automatic, or fine-grained goal attributions.  Simulation models show how covert motor enactment could shorten the computational path from kinematics to outcome prediction, or recover hidden parameters (force, joint angle) useful for real-time tracking.  But an enabling condition is not thereby constitutive.  Oxygen is enabling for thought, but being oxygenated is not part of what it is to think.  Likewise, motor resonance can be an expedient but not an ingredient of goal perception.

5.2 Vision is richer than assumed  

Proponents of necessity sometimes assume that the retinal image lists only coordinate trajectories, devoid of purposive information, forcing the brain to add purpose via motor simulation.  Ecological psychologists, however, have long argued that affordances and intentions are visually specified in spatiotemporal patterns (Gibson 1979; Runeson & Frykholm 1983).  Kinematic invariants—minimal jerk trajectories, velocity profiles, hand pre-shape—convey likely goals directly.  Recognizing such invariants may recruit dorsal visual stream computations without looping through premotor cortex.  The information available in the optic array thus underwrites a resonance-independent route to goal perception.

6. A pluralistic alternative  

Given the mixed evidence, a more nuanced model is warranted.  On the pluralistic view:

(1) Multiple routes:  
   a. Visual-kinematic analysis route: Specialized visual circuits detect goal-relevant invariants.  
   b. Teleological inference route: Higher-level cognition evaluates means-end efficiency relative to environmental constraints.  
   c. Motor resonance route: The observer runs covert motor simulations when feasible, benefitting from embodied priors.

(2) Interaction and weighting: The routes interact competitively and cooperatively.  When one route is noisy or unavailable, others can compensate.  In ordinary adult humans, all three routes operate, yielding robust, redundant goal perception.

(3) Developmental trajectory: Teleological reasoning and visual analysis emerge early; resonance gains influence as motor skills mature, providing finer granularity and speeding inferences.

(4) Species variation: Species with different effectors exploit the visual-kinematic and teleological routes more heavily; species with dexterous, versatile motor systems may additionally benefit from resonance.

This pluralism vindicates mirror-neuron findings—they capture one genuine mechanism—but denies them exclusivity.

7. Addressing objections  

Objection 1: Even if infants and limb-absent individuals cannot overtly perform the actions, their premotor cortices may still instantiate generic resonance representations.  Hence resonance is present though behaviorally silent.

Reply: This move renders the claim unfalsifiable.  If any task-sensitive activation somewhere in premotor cortex counts as resonance, regardless of its relation to the observer’s motor repertoire, the necessity thesis loses empirical content.  Worse, studies show that the motor somatotopy corresponding to the missing limb is degraded, yet perception is intact.  The tight mapping predicted by the necessity conjecture is absent.

Objection 2: Goal perception in animals may rely on resonance at an inter-species abstract level (e.g., dynamics of ballistic objects).

Reply: Again, the challenge is specificity.  “Resonance with dynamics” collapses into generic forward modeling shared by perception and action; it no longer entails mirroring the effectors’ kinematics.  If so, the thesis has drifted away from its original motor-match claim.

Objection 3: While alternative routes exist, resonance might still be necessary for “full-blooded” understanding, such as empathic grasp of practical reasons.

Reply: The dispute concerns perceptual recognition of goal-directedness, not empathic identification with reasons.  One may grant that deeper forms of social cognition (e.g., experiential empathy) benefit from bodily mirroring; yet such enrichment is distinct from basic perceptual access.

8. Conceptual payoff  

Recognizing the non-necessity of motor resonance clarifies the autonomy of perceptual psychology from motor neurophysiology.  It cautions against neurocentric reductions in social cognition research, reminding us that purposive structure is often specified in the perceptual array itself or extractable by amodal reasoning.  It also bears on debates over cognitive penetrability: if motor resonance is not required, then motor knowledge need not seep into visual content; visual perception has resources of its own.

9. Conclusion  

Motor resonance, illuminated by mirror-neuron research, is a genuine and fascinating avenue through which we grasp others’ actions.  Yet the weight of developmental, neuropsychological, and ethological evidence undermines the claim that it is a strict prerequisite for perceiving goal-directedness.  Perception is multi-modal and opportunistic: it exploits visual invariants, ecological context, teleological reasoning, and, when available, embodied simulation.  A pluralistic framework accommodates this flexibility, honoring the contributions of motor systems without placing them on an unwarranted philosophical pedestal.  

In sum, we can—and frequently do—perceive the goals of others even in the absence of motor resonance.  The human mind is generous in its strategies for understanding, and its perception of purpose is too important to rest on a single neural mechanism.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Necessity or Facilitation?

1. Introduction  

What allows us to see a reach for a cup as a request for coffee, or a twist of the torso as an attempt to avoid an incoming ball? Since the discovery of mirror neurons in the macaque premotor cortex (Rizzolatti et al., 1996) a popular answer has been “motor resonance.” Roughly, when we observe another’s movement, sub-populations of our own motor neurons fire as though we ourselves were performing that movement. Several philosophers and cognitive scientists have converted this empirical observation into a metaphysical claim: the mapping of the observed action onto one’s own motor repertoire is not merely helpful but strictly necessary for perceiving the action as goal-directed. Call this the Motor Resonance Necessity Thesis (MRNT).  

In what follows I argue that MRNT is too strong. Evidence from developmental psychology, neuropsychology, and experimental neuroscience shows that (i) intact goal-ascription can survive massive disruption or absence of motor resonance; (ii) purely perceptual and contextual cues are often sufficient to specify an agent’s goal; and (iii) the explanatory gains of invoking resonance mechanisms lie in speed, robustness, and learning rather than in the very possibility of goal perception. Consequently, motor resonance is best construed as a facilitatory, not necessary, mechanism—one resource among several that jointly enable humans (and perhaps other animals) to perceive and understand goal-directed action.

2. Clarifying the Terrain  

Before assessing necessity, we need clarity on three key notions.  

a. Goal-directed action. I adopt a minimally teleological criterion: an action is goal-directed when its unfolding can be rationalized in terms of an objective that constrains intermediary kinematic patterns. A reach is goal-directed toward the cup if its trajectory converges on the cup in a way that would count as success were the cup grasped.  

b. Perception of goal-directedness. To perceive an action as goal-directed is to visually (or multimodally) apprehend not just spatio-temporal properties but the purposive structure of the movement. Crucially, “perception” here contrasts with propositional inference: I can see, rather than infer, that she is about to throw the ball.  

c. Motor resonance. Operationally, resonance is the activation of neural circuitry implicated in action execution (premotor, posterior parietal, and supplementary motor areas) during action observation, typically measured via single-cell recordings, fMRI, MEG, or TMS-induced motor-evoked potentials. Functionally, the assumption is that such activation constitutes a partial internal simulation of the observed action.  

With these definitional stakes in place, the MRNT states: For any observer O and agent A, O can perceptually represent A’s action as goal-directed only if O’s motor system resonates with the action that A is performing. The defender of MRNT must therefore deny the metaphysical possibility of goal perception in the absence of resonance.

3. Arguments Offered for Necessity  

Proponents of MRNT marshal four main arguments.

3.1. The Poverty-of-Stimulus Argument  

Visual kinematics alone, they claim, underspecify the goal. The same hand trajectory could be a reach, a stretch, or a gesture. Resonance supplies the missing richness by recruiting the observer’s motor schemas that are inherently goal-tagged.

3.2. The Developmental Bootstrapping Argument  

Infants as young as six months show predictive eye-movements toward the goal of an observed reach (Falck-Ytter et al., 2006). Given their limited conceptual resources, the suggestion is that motor simulation is the only mechanism available for early goal detection.

3.3. The Robustness Argument  

Motor resonance is fast and automatic, occurring within 100–200 ms. Because conscious inference would be too slow for on-line interaction, only resonance yields the responsiveness characteristic of social perception.

3.4. The Neural Necessity Argument  

Finally, various neuroimaging studies report correlations between degree of mirror-system activation and accuracy in goal-recognition tasks (e.g., Calvo-Merino et al., 2005). Correlation is then promoted—perhaps too hastily—to causal necessity.

4. Empirical and Conceptual Challenges  

The above arguments are suggestive but fall short of establishing necessity. Four strands of evidence are particularly damaging.

4.1. Congenital Motor Impairments  

People born without upper limbs cannot execute typical hand actions and display severely attenuated motor resonance in cortical hand areas. Yet they recognize manual actions and their goals with near-typical accuracy (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2016). In a striking fMRI study, participants with congenital limb absence viewed videos of hand actions. Neural activity in their deafferented “hand” cortex was minimal, but they nevertheless identified the actions and goals at ceiling. Unless we posit hidden motor resonance in improbable locations, MRNT is false.

4.2. Dissociations in Apraxia and Deafferentation  

Conversely, patients with ideomotor apraxia have damaged motor programs for certain gestures but can still perceive those gestures when others perform them (Goldenberg, 2009). Deafferented patients who lack proprioceptive feedback likewise maintain goal-recognition. These double dissociations show that the machinery subserving action execution and that subserving perception, although interacting, are separable.

4.3. Experimental Disruption of Resonance  

TMS pulses to premotor cortex can transiently suppress motor-evoked potentials associated with action observation. When such pulses are delivered, participants’ kinematic prediction takes a measurable hit, but goal recognition—judging whether a reach is aimed at object A or B—remains intact (Avenanti et al., 2013). This suggests that resonance aids fine-grained anticipation, not coarse goal-classification.

4.4. Infant Evidence Re-examined  

The developmental bootstrapping argument also falters. Newborn chicks imprint on moving conspecifics and react differently to purposeful versus random motion despite lacking a mammalian-style mirror system. Human neonates, too, orient to biological motion patterns (Simion et al., 2008) before they can perform comparable actions. The data support an alternative story: the visual system comes equipped with heuristics for agentive motion (e.g., self-propulsion, rectilinear bursts, efficiency of path) that license goal attributions without invoking motor simulation.

5. Alternative Routes to Goal Perception  

If motor resonance is not necessary, what is? At least three families of models give independent accounts.

5.1. Teleological Reasoning Models  

Gergely and Csibra (2003) propose that observers apply a principle of rational action: given environmental constraints, agents tend to select the most efficient means to a goal. Even 12-month-olds expect an agent to detour around an obstacle; they perceive the action as goal-directed in virtue of its efficiency, not their own motor repertoire. This model is computational and context-sensitive yet not reliant on simulating muscular commands.

5.2. Ecological and Affordance-Based Approaches  

Following Gibson (1979), perceptual systems can directly register affordances—possibilities for action—without intermediary representations. When I see you reach over a barrier toward a mug, invariants in optical flow (hand shape molding to mug aperture, wrist rotation) specify the goal as a distal portion of the scene structured for grasping. Perception of such invariants does not require that I covertly rehearse the grasp.

5.3. Predictive-Processing Accounts  

In predictive-coding frameworks, the brain hierarchically predicts both sensory input and hidden causes. Action observation involves generating hypotheses about latent goals that best explain visual dynamics. Motor areas are part of the generative model but can be bypassed if higher-level probabilistic inferences converge without them. Thus, resonance is an optional short-cut within a more general inferential engine.

6. What Motor Resonance Actually Buys Us  

Conceding that resonance is unnecessary need not trivialize its contribution. There are at least three respects in which resonance plausibly enhances social perception.

6.1. Speed and Temporal Fine-Tuning  

In tasks requiring split-second anticipation—catching a ball someone else is throwing—motor simulation provides predictive trajectories that purely visual extrapolation might lag behind. Here resonance augments, not originates, goal understanding.

6.2. Sensorimotor Learning  

Observational learning (e.g., acquiring a dance sequence) profits from overlap between observed and executed code. Studies show that TMS disruption of mirror areas impairs imitation accuracy even when verbal goal-labels are known (Catmur et al., 2009).

6.3. Affective Resonance and Empathy  

Gallese (2003) argues that motor resonance scaffolds a “shared manifold” enabling empathy. Whether or not this claim generalizes to all empathy, there is converging evidence that resonance heightens affective involvement—again a modulatory, not requisite, role.

7. Philosophical Implications  

The demise of MRNT shifts pressure onto simulation theories of social cognition more broadly. If perceiving an action as goal-directed does not mandate reenacting that action, perhaps other mental-state attributions (belief, desire) are also less simulation-dependent than often thought. Moreover, the pluralistic picture that emerges dovetails with contemporary philosophy of mind:

a. Enactivists can still hold that perception is embodied, though the embodiment is distributed across ocular, vestibular, and cognitive systems, not localized in motor cortex alone.  

b. Direct Social Perception theorists gain an ally: goal-perception can be as immediate as shape-perception, provided proper ecological information is available.  

c. Predictive-processing advocates can reinterpret resonance as precision-weighting: when visual evidence is noisy, the system down-weights sensory prediction errors and leans on motor priors; when visual evidence is clear, it does the reverse.

8. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Could the apparent absence of resonance in limb-deficient individuals be due to undetected sub-cortical simulation? Reply: Even if so, necessity is still false at the cortical level where mirror neurons reside, and positing ghostly motor copies risks unfalsifiability.

Objection 2: Behavioral goal-recognition tasks may rely on conscious inference; true perception might indeed require resonance. Reply: But the clinical and neurotypical participants just described report a phenomenology of immediacy and pass standard implicit looking-time measures, undermining the inference/perception distinction.

Objection 3: Perhaps motor resonance is developmentally necessary though not necessary in adulthood. Reply: The newborn data dispute this; moreover, children with congenital limb absence develop typically without motor-match experience. Developmental necessity is therefore unlikely.

9. Conclusion  

Motor resonance is real, significant, and deeply woven into the fabric of social interaction. Yet the weight of evidence indicates that it is not a sine qua non for perceiving goal-directed action. Humans deploy multiple, partially redundant mechanisms: low-level visual heuristics, ecological invariants, rational teleological reasoning, and, where available, embodied simulation. This redundancy is biologically sensible; the social world is too vital to leave hostage to a single neural pathway.  

The philosophical upshot is an invitation to pluralism. Perceptual access to others’ goals is multiply realizable both within and across individuals. Embodiment matters, but not all embodiment is motoric, and not all motoric embodiment is indispensably constitutive. A more nuanced mapping of the division of labor—when we rely on resonance, when we rely on purely perceptual information, and how these streams integrate—promises a richer, empirically anchored theory of social cognition.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action  
(≈ 2 000 words)

1. The dispute

Two opposing theses dominate the present debate.

A. The Necessity Thesis (Motor-Simulative View).  
Perception of another individual’s action as goal-directed requires that the observer’s motor system covertly reproduce, in part, the observed movement. Mirror neurons, premotor resonance, and forward motor models supply the representational format in which the other’s goal can be internally generated; without such resonance the percept is “blind” to goal.

B. The Independence Thesis.  
Although motor resonance often accompanies observation and may facilitate understanding, perceiving an action as teleological can proceed without any motoric reenactment. Visual, causal, and rational-inferential resources suffice.

I shall argue for the Independence Thesis. Motor resonance is real, explanatorily useful, and sometimes indispensable for rapid online interaction, but it is not a necessary condition for seeing behaviour as goal-directed. Conceptual analysis and a growing body of empirical counter-examples undermine the purported necessity.

2. What is at stake?

“Necessity” here is modal, not merely statistical. If resonance were necessary, then in every possible situation in which an agent S perceives another’s behaviour B as directed to a goal G, S’s motor system would display resonance with the motor pattern that would produce B. Showing a single clear case of goal perception in the absence of resonance is enough to refute the necessity claim.
