Moreover, “perceiving” goal-directedness must be distinguished from post-perceptual inference. The motor-simulation theorist contends that goal content is part of the perceptual experience itself, not merely a reflective attribution. Thus, evidence that looks behavioural or developmental (e.g. correct verbal reports) must be interpreted carefully: do they reveal perceptual content or higher-level reasoning?

3. The positive case for the necessity thesis

3.1 Mirror-neuronal findings  
In macaques (di Pellegrino et al., 1992) and humans (Rizzolatti & Craighero, 2004), neurons in ventral premotor and inferior parietal areas fire both when a movement is executed and when it is observed. Crucially, firing is often goal-selective: grasping-for-eating neurons fire for the action of bringing food to the mouth but not for placing it into a container. Motor programmes seem tuned to goals rather than kinematics.

3.2 Behavioural data  
Observers slightly bias their own movement trajectories after watching another’s action (motor contagion). In transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) studies, muscle-specific facilitations appear roughly 100 ms after onset of observed movements, prior to explicit goal recognition, suggesting an early motor route.

3.3 Developmental considerations  
Since 6-month-old infants already show both grasp-specific motor event-related potentials (ERPs) and sensitivity to goal structure, the motor system seems implicated at an age where abstract inference is thought to be meagre.

Collectively, the motor-simulative camp infers that (i) resonance is fast, (ii) neurophysiologically privileged, and (iii) carries goal information; hence it is the enabling mechanism.

4. Conceptual caveats

4.1 Tautology danger  
Finding premotor activity during goal perception does not by itself show necessity; correlation is weaker than dependency. Visual areas (MT/V5) also activate during action observation, yet no one claims motion processing is the only route.

4.2 The grain problem  
Motor representation is inherently egocentric (joint angles, muscle activation). Goal perception is typically allocentric and object-centred. Bridging the representational “grain” requires additional inferential resources (often parietal or prefrontal). Therefore, resonance may deliver only partial input.

4.3 Under- and over-generation  
If resonance were both necessary and sufficient we would predict (a) the impossibility of goal perception when resonance is absent, and (b) automatic goal perception whenever resonance occurs. Yet we can resonate with meaningless pantomime, or with a sport we do not understand, without seeing determinate goals; conversely, we readily see the strategic goal of a chess player though most of us cannot simulate his finger movements in a relevant way. This tension already suggests incompleteness.

5. Empirical counter-examples

5.1 Neonatal and atypical motor repertoires  
(a) Newborn chicks (Kuhlmeier & Troje, 2013) and three-month-old human infants display preferential attention to self-propelled agents pursuing objects on a screen, long before they have acquired the motor routines for locomotion or reaching.  
(b) Congenitally limb-deficient individuals (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2016) lack representations of arm or hand movements in primary motor cortex, yet they identify hand-related goals (“grasping a cup to drink”) normally. fMRI shows no typical hand-motor resonance in them.  
(c) Paraplegic patients with complete spinal cord injury show spared visual goal attribution despite markedly diminished efferent feedback.

5.2 Cross-species recognition  
Humans easily detect a cat stalking prey or a hummingbird aiming for nectar. The requisite motor routines are not part of human motor repertoire. There may be partial analogies, but in detail the motor patterns are alien. We nevertheless perceive clear teleology.

5.3 Tool use and distal goals  
When I watch an excavator scoop earth to build a foundation, I grasp the contractor’s goal despite my inability to simulate the hydraulics or control scheme. Similarly, drone operators’ joystick flicks do not map onto my own experience of quadcopter dynamics, yet I perceive the aerial manoeuvre as goal-directed.

5.4 Visual-kinematic minimal cues  
Gergely & Csibra (2003) showed infants animated “self-propelled” dots that detoured around obstacles. Infants looked longer when the detour continued after obstacle removal, indicating expectation of efficient goal pursuit. The stimuli deliberately lacked biological motion, muscle cues, and morphed far beyond plausible motor resonance.

5.5 Temporal asynchronies  
TMS disruption of premotor cortex in healthy adults can reduce muscle-specific resonance without abolishing conscious goal recognition (Avenanti et al., 2017). The subjective report and forced-choice classification accuracy remain intact, though reaction time increases slightly. The motor trace is helpful but not strictly required.

6. Alternative explanatory resources

6.1 Rational teleological stance  
On the “teleological stance” (Gergely, Csibra), observers interpret action by assuming agents act efficiently toward desirable outcomes given environmental constraints. One need only represent basic causal structure and cost functions. This mechanistic-rational analysis can be computed visually through trajectory geometry without motoric reenactment. Simulation, when present, may supply efficiency expectations more quickly, but it is dispensable.

6.2 Ecological optics  
Gibsonian affordance perception delivers goal information directly through invariant relational properties (grasp-ability, sit-on-ability) in the optic flow. Affordances do recruit motor systems for actual execution, but perceptually grasping that “the cup affords drinking” can occur through a visual calibration to object geometry relative to bodily scale, not by internally instantiating the grasp.

6.3 Causal event perception  
Michotte’s (1946/1963) “launching” displays elicit immediate impressions of causal pushing even with simple geometric shapes. Scholl & Tremoulet (2000) argue we possess a domain-specific “perceptual animacy” module that uses motion cues (self-propulsion, sudden changes in acceleration) to tag entities as agents. Goal detection piggybacks on animacy plus spatiotemporal contingency: the chaser’s path converges on the target. Motor resonance again is optional.

6.4 Predictive-processing framework  
Contemporary predictive coding views (Kilner, Friston, & Frith, 2007) easily subsume multiple information channels. The brain minimises prediction error across hierarchical generative models; motor emulation is one route to predicting observed kinematics, but visual extrapolation or semantic priors may generate the same high-level goal hypothesis. The system flexibly selects the model with highest posterior evidence, rendering motor involvement context-dependent rather than obligatory.

7. Does the resonance help?

Granting independence, why does the brain harbour mirror circuits at all? They may serve:

a. Temporal fine-graining for online interaction – anticipating contact timing in joint actions (e.g., passing a basketball).  
b. Learning by imitation – mapping observed into executable codes simplifies motor acquisition.  
c. Empathy – overlapping somatomotor representations make the agent’s bodily state vicariously felt, an affective, not purely cognitive component.

Each benefit is strongest at short latencies and when the other’s motor repertoire overlaps ours – precisely the cases where necessity seems plausible. Thus, empirical patterns that fuel the simulationist conviction are genuine, but they reflect an efficiency edge, not a logical prerequisite.

8. Philosophical diagnosis: phenomenology versus mechanism

Some defenders of necessity cite phenomenological data: when I watch Serena Williams serve, I “feel” I can anticipate the racket swing and “see” the intention in her gesture. But identical phenomenology can be reconstructed by rapid high-level inference, then “written back” as an illusion of direct perception (see Nichols & Stitch, “sentimentalist overlay”). Evidentiary weight depends on whether these feelings correlate with indispensable sub-personal machinery. The empirical counter-examples show they do not.

Phenomenology therefore underdetermines mechanism. The independence theorist can agree that goal perception appears immediate and quasi-motoric to introspection, while maintaining that alternative non-motor computations can yield the same appearance.

9. Anticipated objections

Objection 1: Congenital limb-deficient individuals might co-opt alternative motor codes (e.g., foot or mouth) to simulate the observed hand action.  
Reply: fMRI shows absence of somatotopic “hand” resonance even in compensatory effectors; yet goal perception persists. Moreover, people correctly perceive the goal of tentacle motions or liquid flows – there is no plausible effector homologue.

Objection 2: The infant dot studies reveal only expectation of efficiency, not real goal understanding.  
Reply: The definition of goal-directedness employed by the motor-simulative view is minimal: selecting actions to bring about states. Infants’ violation-of-expectation responses display sensitivity to precisely that relation; motor resonance cannot explain it because stimulus parameters preclude it.

Objection 3: fMRI/TMS studies suffer limited spatial or temporal resolution; subtle resonance could remain undetected.  
Reply: “Possibly undetected” is weaker than “necessary”. Without positive evidence that resonance is ubiquitous, the heavier modal claim cannot stand. Burden of proof lies with necessity.

10. Synthesis: graded pluralism

We can now articulate a more nuanced picture.

1. Multiple information streams (visual trajectories, object affordances, contextual cues, normative rationality, motor resonance) converge in hierarchical predictive models.  
2. Goal perception is the joint product of whichever streams reach a criterion of reliability within the processing time available.  
3. When an observed action is within the observer’s motor repertoire and rapid fine-grained timing matters, resonance will be heavily weighted.  
4. When the action is outside one’s repertoire, or when there is ample time, visual-rational strategies suffice.  
5. The architecture thereby avoids brittleness and supports both species-general (perceiving chasing in dots) and repertoire-specific (imitating dance) cognition.

11. Broader implications

Accepting independence reshapes several philosophical debates.

a. Social cognition. We need not endorse a “darkened room” theory on which minds are transparent only through simulation. Direct perception, enriched by structural cues and normative expectations, offers an alternative route.  
b. Embodied cognition. Embodiment remains central – our history of acting informs perception – but the degree of embodiment is context-sensitive, not constitutive.  
c. Moral psychology. Empathy via sensorimotor overlap might undergird vicarious pain, yet recognising another’s instrumental need can proceed even when empathy is weak (e.g., for out-groups with unusual bodies). Moral appraisal should therefore not be tied exclusively to mirror-based resonance.

12. Conclusion

Motor resonance is a remarkable discovery and an elegant component of the cognitive toolkit, but it is one tool among many. The fact that we can perceive goal-directedness in newborn chicken, limb-deficient observers, geometric shapes, cats, excavators, and drones—all cases where exact motor mapping is unavailable—demonstrates that perception of teleology is multiply realisable. Resonance accelerates, enriches, and sometimes deepens our grasp of others’ actions, yet it is not the sine qua non its strongest proponents proclaim.

Hence the Independence Thesis stands: we can, and often do, perceive goal-directed actions without motor resonance.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Is Simulation Necessary?

1. Introduction  

Few discoveries in contemporary cognitive science have captured the philosophical imagination as vividly as mirror neurons and the broader phenomenon of “motor resonance.” When an observer watches another individual grasp a cup of coffee, many of the same neural populations that would be active were the observer to grasp the cup herself become active in the observer’s premotor cortex. This finding has inspired the thesis—popular in both philosophy of mind and embodied cognition—that such resonance is not just a curious epiphenomenon but a necessary condition for perceiving another’s action as goal-directed. According to this simulationist view, the human perceptual system can present a movement to consciousness as pursuing an end only because it covertly re-enacts the motor commands that would bring about that end.  

In this essay I argue that motor resonance is not a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed action. While motor resonance often facilitates, enriches, and in many contexts speeds up the recognition of others’ goals, neither conceptual analysis nor empirical evidence supports the claim that it is indispensable. I develop this conclusion in four stages. First, I clarify the notion of “perceiving a goal-directed action” and what it would mean for motor resonance to be necessary. Second, I marshal the main arguments advanced in favour of necessity, showing why many philosophers find them initially persuasive. Third, I raise conceptual and empirical objections to each of these arguments, including evidence from individuals lacking normal motor representations but nonetheless perceiving goals. Finally, I sketch a positive account on which the perception of goal-directedness is multi-modal and context-sensitive; motor resonance is one among several mutually supportive routes, none of which is individually necessary.

2. Clarifying the Target Phenomenon  

Perceiving goal-directed action is not the same as inferring or judging that an action has a goal. Philosophers of mind since Berkeley have distinguished perceptual presentations from higher-order, inferential cognition. To say that I perceive an action as goal-directed is to say that the goal-directedness is “built in” to the perceptual content: the coffee mug is visually registered as something the actor is about to grasp; the actor’s hand is seen as reaching, not merely moving. A theorist who claims that motor resonance is necessary must claim that, without a covert motor match, such enriched perceptual content cannot arise at all.

Two further clarifications matter.  

First, necessity must not be conflated with facilitation. A process can speed, ease, or sharpen perception without being a requisite condition. Caffeine facilitates wakefulness but is hardly necessary for it.  

Second, the relevant notion of motor resonance is a subpersonal, non-conceptual mapping from observed kinematics to the observer’s own motor repertoire. Mere conceptual understanding—“hands can grasp mugs”—does not count as resonance, nor does affective contagion. Rather, the claim is that neural circuits involved in preparing one’s own action must be at least partially re-used for perception.

3. The Case for Necessity  

Advocates of the necessity thesis typically advance three sorts of argument:

3.1 The Mirror Neuron Empirical Argument  
Motor resonance, they note, reliably correlates with action observation. In macaques, “canonical neurons” fire both when a monkey cracks a peanut and when it sees another do so. In human fMRI, observing goal-directed hand actions activates premotor areas (the inferior frontal gyrus and inferior parietal lobule) that are also activated during execution. Moreover, the pattern of activation often varies with subtle goal differences: different premotor voxels light up when the observed grasp is for eating versus placing. From these data, proponents infer that these motor populations are constitutive of perceptual goal coding.  

3.2 The Developmental Argument  
Human infants identify an action’s goal before they can verbally articulate it, but at a time when they are rapidly developing their own motor skills. When 6-month-olds succeed at a habituation task in which they look longer when an actor changes goals than when she merely changes the spatial path, their success correlates with the infants’ own ability to reach the same target. Meltzoff’s “like me” hypothesis contends that infants bootstrap social cognition by matching others’ acts to their own motor repertoire: they can see an adult touch her cheek with a finger and, because they can bring a hand to their own cheek, they map the observed action onto their own movement schema. Absence of the relevant motor representation, on this view, would block perception of the goal.

3.3 The Phenomenological Argument  
Phenomenologists such as Gallese and Sinigaglia claim that the immediacy with which we experience actions as meaningful can only be explained by motor resonance. When I walk into a room and see a bartender slide a glass, I do not first compute a trajectory, then infer a purpose; I “just see” the serving gesture. The phenomenal transparency of goal-directedness, they argue, arises because my own motor system silently simulates the sliding, delivering the goal as a kind of “motor intentionality.”

4. Objections to Necessity  

Each of the above arguments, compelling at first glance, faces both conceptual and empirical challenges.

4.1 The Empirical Correlation Objection  
Correlation is not causation, nor necessity. Brain imaging evidence merely shows that motor areas are active when action goals are perceived; it does not show they are indispensable. Many shared neural activations are co-functional satellites rather than constitutive components. Visual cortex activates during vivid imagery, but one can imagine in its absence, as shown by blind individuals whose visual cortices are silent yet who can vividly conjure auditory imagery. The key test for necessity is the double-dissociation: do we find cases where motor resonance is disrupted but goal perception remains intact?  

4.2 Evidence from Motor-Impaired Observers  
The double-dissociation appears to exist. Consider individuals with congenital limb aplasia—people born without arms. Recent studies (Vannuscorps & Caramazza 2016) show that such individuals, despite lacking any first-person motor program for upper-limb actions, nonetheless categorize, anticipate, and visually discriminate others’ hand goals as accurately as typically developing controls. Similarly, adults with anarchic hand syndrome, whose motor command over their own limb is impaired, still interpret others’ manual acts convincingly.  

If the necessity thesis were correct, these observers should find it at least harder to perceive the goals of arm-related actions, yet no systematic deficit emerges. The data suggest that normal first-person motor representations are not required.  

4.3 Patients with Lesions to the Mirror System  
Focal lesions to the inferior frontal gyrus often eliminate motor resonance (as measured by TMS-evoked motor potentials) yet leave action goal recognition largely intact. Patients with Broca’s aphasia, for instance, show diminished mirror responses but still understand pantomimed object use. While some subtle slowing occurs under time pressure, the basic competence survives, indicating that resonance accelerates but does not ground perception.

4.4 The Developmental Equivocation  
Infant studies likewise suffer from a causal leap. Correlation between infants’ own reaching and their perception of others’ goals could reflect maturational age: both motor skill and social cognition might improve simultaneously because of general neural development. Indeed, cross-cultural research reports infants raised in contexts that constrain independent reaching (e.g., Kandyan infants in Sri Lanka) yet who nonetheless perceive goal structure in adult action videos.  

Moreover, to interpret another’s motive to use a grasp to eat presupposes some prior visual understanding of food and mouths, neither of which is motoric. The “like-me” narrative thus overstates the explanatory reach of motor mapping.

4.5 Phenomenology without Simulation  
The phenomenological argument confuses transparency with constitution. That I do not experience the bartender’s action as a three-stage inference does not entail that my motor system is its constitutive basis. A thermostat finds the ambient temperature without representing thermodynamics. Cognitive systems often render complex computations phenomenally immediate. The feeling of “seeing an affordance” could just as well be the upshot of specialized visual circuits that evolved to register biological motion and teleology, not motor resonance.

5. A Positive Alternative: Visual-Kinematic and Affordance-Based Perception  

If motor resonance is not necessary, what is? I propose a pluralistic model: goal-directedness is extracted by at least three partially independent systems.

5.1 Kinematic Heuristics  
Humans are exquisitely sensitive to the kinematic signature of intentional motion. Even twelve-dot point-light displays suffice to signal “chasing” or “trying to catch.” Giese and Poggio’s computational model shows how purely visual processing of velocity profiles can separate biological from non-biological motion and recover likely endpoints. Such heuristics operate in infants before robust motor resonance circuits fully mature, and in birds (e.g., pigeons) which lack mirror neurons but can nonetheless categorize goal-directed pursuit in dot patterns. Thus, a purely perceptual route exists.

5.2 Environmental Affordances  
Per Gibson, objects present action possibilities (“affordances”) in virtue of their morphology and location. A cup with a handle facing you “invites” grasping regardless of one’s motor state. Several experiments reveal that merely presenting a tea pot with its spout oriented toward another individual primes observers to predict pouring actions. Affordance perception draws on parietal and occipitotemporal regions distinct from classic mirror areas and can operate in people whose motor repertoire cannot instantiate the affordance (e.g., an amputee can see a handle as graspable).  

5.3 Conceptual-Teleological Reasoning  
By the second year of life, humans wield a “teleological stance”: they assume agents act rationally to achieve desires in light of beliefs. This stance, modeled by Gergely and Csibra, depends on domain-general causal cognition, not motor simulation. In Heider-Simmel animations, squares and triangles with no limbs are perceived as “trying” or “helping,” despite the impossibility of motor matching.

On the pluralist account, these three systems interact dynamically. Under optimal conditions (familiar effector, view of joints, moderate speed), motor resonance offers rapid, embodied prediction. When motor matching is impossible or underspecified, kinematic and teleological cues fill the gap. The brain thereby achieves robustness through redundancy.

6. A Hybrid Role for Motor Resonance  

Conceding that resonance is not necessary does not relegate it to epiphenomenal status. A more defensible thesis is sufficiency-for-speed: motor resonance enhances perceptual richness and temporal predictive precision. This role is especially salient in tasks demanding real-time coordination (e.g., catching a ball thrown by someone else). When milliseconds matter, simulating the unfolding trajectory inside one’s motor system yields anticipatory timing beyond what purely visual extrapolation affords.

Predictive-coding frameworks model this interaction elegantly. Visual regions compute prediction errors relative to expected trajectories, while motor areas issue forward models based on internal dynamics. If the visual cues are noisy, the system leans more heavily on motor priors; if the observer lacks the relevant motor schema, the Bayesian weight shifts to visual evidence. Necessity thus collapses into context-relative reliability.

7. Addressing Remaining Objections  

A defender of necessity might reply that congenital amputees do possess some limb representations, if only imagined, and that lesions sparing sub-threshold resonance circuits leave sufficient resources for perception. This reply, however, becomes increasingly ad hoc: what would constitute the absence of any motor representation? Imagined limbs are already conceptual proxies, not somatotopic plans; the thesis risks unfalsifiability. Better to admit that the human cognitive architecture is engineered for graceful degradation, with multiple fallbacks.  

Others might object that while amputees can perceive actions, they cannot empathically understand their experiential significance. Yet careful studies show their empathic ratings of pain or effort in limb actions match controls’. The burden of proof shifts back to the necessity proponent.

8. Philosophical Implications  

The debate bears on broader questions about the role of embodiment in cognition. If perceiving others’ goals can proceed independently of implementing them, then strong versions of the embodied-simulation theory of mind require revision. Embodiment remains crucial—not as a rigid prerequisite but as one adaptive resource among many. This conclusion resonates with the growing realization that cognition is “multi-level embodied”: bodily systems matter, but so do abstract causal and semantic systems.

9. Conclusion  

Motor resonance, spectacular though it is, is not the sine qua non of goal perception. The human brain can and often does perceive goal-directedness through purely visual kinematics, environmental affordances, and teleological reasoning. Mirror-system activity supplements these routes, conferring speed and predictive acuity where one’s own action repertoire aligns with the observed act. Deeming resonance necessary conflates facilitation with indispensability and ignores counter-evidence from motor-impaired individuals and non-human species. A pluralist, hybrid approach honours the empirical data and accords with philosophical parsimony: multiple, partially redundant mechanisms underwrite our impressive ability to read the goals of others. Motor resonance is a powerful, but not an exclusive, window into another creature’s purposive world.

1. Introduction  

A great deal of excitement followed the discovery of “mirror neurons” in macaque premotor cortex and of homologous resonance‐like responses in human motor areas.  Philosophers and cognitive scientists quickly drew a bold moral: when I watch you reach for a cup, my motor system covertly rehearses that very reach, and it is this rehearsal that lets me perceive your movement as an intelligible, goal-directed action rather than as a meaningless trajectory.  The thesis is typically put in the strong, modal idiom of necessity: without resonance, there could be no perception of another’s action as goal-directed.  Call this the Necessity of Motor Resonance (NMR) claim.

The present essay argues that NMR is false.  Motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically required for perceiving goal-directed action, although it often facilitates such perception.  I proceed as follows.  §2 clarifies the relevant notions of “motor resonance,” “perception,” and “goal-directed action.”  §3 presents the main arguments advanced for NMR.  §4 develops four empirical and two conceptual objections that together undermine those arguments.  §5 sketches three alternative frameworks—teleological reasoning, Gibsonian affordance perception, and predictive processing—that can accommodate the perception of goal-directedness without appealing to resonance as a necessary condition.  §6 concludes by situating motor resonance within a broader pluralist picture: it is one useful route, but not the only, and not a mandatory, route to understanding others’ actions.

2. Conceptual Ground-Clearing  

2.1 Motor resonance  
“Motor resonance” refers to an activation pattern in an observer’s motor system that mirrors—often somatotopically—the pattern that would be produced were the observer herself executing the observed movement.  In humans, resonance is typically measured by fMRI (ventral premotor, inferior parietal, and primary motor cortices), MEG, or transcranial magnetic stimulation–induced changes in corticospinal excitability.

2.2 Perception vs. Inference  
Perception, in the relevant philosophical sense, is the online, sensory apprehension of the environment’s layout, properties, and events.  The NMR literature often blurs the line between perceptual uptake and post-perceptual judgment.  To maintain that resonance is necessary for perceiving goal-directedness, the advocate must show that without motor simulation the very percept (what Ullman called the “visual description”) lacks teleological content, not merely that later cognitive attribution is impeded.

2.3 Goal-directed action  
An action counts as goal-directed when its kinematic unfolding is organized toward some distal end-state (grasping a cup, turning a doorknob).  Importantly, to perceive an action as goal-directed is not yet to represent the agent’s mental states (beliefs, desires).  It is to experience the movement as temporally structured to bring about a particular outcome.

3. Arguments for NMR  

3.1 The mirror-matching argument  
Because mirror neurons encode an observed movement’s motor schema, and because those neurons fire prior to outcome completion, the motor match purportedly gives the observer predictive access to the action’s goal.  The explanatory burden of goal percepts is thus borne by resonance.

3.2 The developmental bootstrapping argument  
Infants start with a body plan.  By mapping others’ motions onto this plan, they supposedly bootstrap an understanding of external agency.  Studies showing a correlation between infants’ own motor repertoire (e.g., grasp competence) and their sensitivity to grasp goals are adduced in support.

3.3 The pathological deficit argument  
In disorders thought to compromise resonance—certain forms of apraxia, autism spectrum conditions—difficulty in reading actions is reported.  The inference is abductive: impair resonance and you impair goal perception; hence resonance is necessary.

3.4 The phenomenological intimacy argument  
Observers often report “feeling” the other’s movement.  Proponents take this quasi-kinaesthetic phenomenology to ground the directness of action perception: I understand your movement “from within,” because my motor system runs it offline.

Each line of reasoning is suggestive, but none secures the necessity claim once counter-evidence and conceptual distinctions are examined.

4. Problems for Necessity  

4.1 Empirical counter-example I: Congenital limb absence  
Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) tested people born without upper limbs.  Despite lacking the ability to execute hand movements and showing greatly reduced or atypical resonance responses, participants identified hand-centred goals (e.g., precision vs. power grip) as accurately and as quickly as control subjects.  Since these individuals cannot map the observed kinematics onto a never-developed motor schema, their performance undermines NMR.

4.2 Empirical counter-example II: Action perception under resonance disruption  
TMS studies can create a “virtual lesion” that dampens corticospinal excitability in the relevant motor region while observers watch actions.  Although such manipulation eliminates measurable resonance, participants still discriminate action goals well above chance (Avenanti et al. 2013).  At most, they are slightly slower.  Facilitation, not necessity, is the evident pattern.

4.3 Empirical counter-example III: Cross-species and impossible actions  
Humans readily perceive the hunting trajectory of a cheetah, a snake’s coiling strike, or the impossible reach of a Pixar robot.  None of these actions can be simulated motorically, yet their goal-directedness is phenomenally salient.  The resonance theorist might posit an abstract motor mapping, but this move vacates the empirical content of NMR: if any pattern whatsoever can count as “motor,” the thesis loses explanatory grip.

4.4 Empirical counter-example IV: Amodal goal perception  
Consider auditory action perception: we hear a zipper pulled up and immediately register its goal (closing the jacket).  Purely auditory stimuli do not normally trigger the visuomotor resonance networks emphasized by NMR advocates.  Still, goal perception is robust.  Multimodal results indicate that resonance is neither modality-general nor indispensable.

4.5 Conceptual objection I: Category mistake  
Resonance is a neural process; perceiving goal-directedness is a psychological capacity.  To say the former is necessary for the latter is to commit (or risk committing) a reductionist category error unless a bridge principle is supplied—one that specifies why this particular neural pattern, as opposed to countless functionally equivalent patterns, grounds the perceptual representation.  NMR often slides from correlation to necessity without such a bridge.

4.6 Conceptual objection II: Over-intellectualizing perception  
If perceiving goal-directedness required internal motor simulation, infants should perceive only the goals they can perform.  Yet nine-month-olds perceive the goal of another’s head-touching action (Gergely et al. 2002) even when they themselves cannot replicate it.  The more parsimonious account is that infants pick up objective spatiotemporal regularities (efficiency relative to situational constraints) rather than engage in covert rehearsal.  Philosophically, this supports a Gibsonian ecological stance: the world’s structure, not the observer’s motor repertoire, primarily organizes perception.

5. Alternative Frameworks Compatible with Non-Resonant Goal Perception  

5.1 Teleological stance theory  
On Csibra and Gergely’s teleological stance, observers encode actions through a principle of rational efficiency: agents tend to select the shortest, least-effort path to a goal given environmental constraints.  This encoding relies on analyzing the relation between movement and situational affordances (obstacles, energy costs), not on motor resonance.  Computational modeling shows that such physical-reasoning processes can recover goal representations from purely kinematic input.

5.2 Gibsonian affordance perception  
Gibson (1979) famously held that we perceive “affordances”—action possibilities structured by the layout of surfaces and objects—directly.  On this view, watching another pick up a cup is to see the cup’s “graspability” realized, an ecological fact that does not require duplicating the motor command.  Resonance may piggy-back on, refine, or enrich this direct perception, but the affordance is available in visual information independent of internal simulation.

5.3 Predictive processing without obligatory motor simulation  
Hierarchical predictive-coding frameworks explain perception as the minimization of sensory prediction error.  While motor areas often participate in the generative model, non-motor visual and parietal hierarchies can likewise encode distal goals as hidden causes of the unfolding image sequence.  Computational work by Kilner, Friston, and collaborators shows that a purely visual generative model suffices to track hand-object trajectories and anticipate goal states; adding motor priors improves precision but is not strictly required.

6. Rehabilitating the Role of Motor Resonance: From Necessity to Facilitation  

Abandoning NMR does not imply that resonance is epiphenomenal.  A more balanced picture emerges from four observations:

1. Speed and robustness: When observed actions fall within the observer’s motor repertoire, resonance speeds up goal recognition (e.g., the slight RT advantage lost in TMS studies).  
2. Learning: Resonance may scaffold the acquisition of novel action categories by providing an associative bridge between executed and observed kinematics.  Thus its role could be developmental without being always operative in mature perception.  
3. Social attunement: Resonance enhances affective attunement—empathy, vicarious pain—functions distinct from the bare perception of telic structure.   
4. Redundancy and degeneracy: The brain employs multiple partially overlapping systems.  Where resonance is possible, it contributes; where it is impossible or impaired, other visual and inferential routes take over.  Degeneracy is adaptive; necessity is evolutionarily risky.

Philosophically, the lesson echoes Davidson’s principle of charity: successful interpretation of others hinges on a confluence of cues.  Motor resonance supplies one such cue, but perception is not hostage to it.

7. Conclusion  

The claim that motor resonance is necessary for perceiving goal-directed action overstates both the empirical evidence and the conceptual link between simulation and perception.  Individuals without the relevant motor repertoire, or with transient resonance disruption, still perceive goals; cross-species and amodal cases replicate the pattern.  Alternative theories—teleological reasoning, affordance perception, predictive processing—show how goal information is recoverable from environmental structure and kinematic regularities alone.

A defensible position, then, is conditional pluralism:  

1. Perception of goal-directedness can proceed via multiple routes.  
2. Motor resonance is one such route, particularly efficient when the observer shares the actor’s embodiment.  
3. Hence resonance is facilitative and sometimes sufficient, but not necessary.  

Recognizing this pluralism encourages interdisciplinary humility.  Philosophy cautions against conflating neural implementation with psychological necessity; cognitive science reminds philosophy that multiple realizability is the rule, not the exception, in biological minds.  Together, they recommend shifting the debate’s modal center from necessity to contribution—an adjustment that better fits the data and honors the complexity of social perception.

1. Introduction  

When we watch a barista reach for a cup, tilt a milk jug, and pour steamed foam into an espresso, we seem to grasp immediately what she is up to. This everyday experience lies at the heart of a puzzle that straddles philosophy of mind, cognitive science, and perceptual psychology: what enables us to perceive that another agent’s behaviour is goal-directed? A prominent answer appeals to motor resonance, a process—often identified with mirror-neuron activity—in which the observer’s motor system covertly “replays” the observed action. According to the strong resonance thesis (SRT):

     SRT: Motor resonance is a necessary condition for perceiving an action as goal-directed.

If SRT is correct, the perceptual availability of others’ goals depends on the observer’s own motor repertoire; failure to resonate implies failure to perceive goal-directedness. The thesis has attracted enthusiastic support (e.g., Rizzolatti & Sinigaglia 2010; Gallese 2014) as well as sceptical scrutiny (e.g., Jacob 2008; Southgate 2013).  

In what follows I examine SRT from three angles—conceptual, empirical, and theoretical explanatory power—and argue that it should be rejected. Motor resonance plausibly facilitates, enriches, and occasionally disambiguates our perception of action, but it is not constitutively necessary. Goal-directed actions can be, and routinely are, perceived in the absence of resonance mechanisms.  

2. What does it mean to “perceive goal-directed action”?  

We need to fix three key notions.

a. Perception. I use “perception” in a relatively liberal but still sensory sense: the extraction of information in a way that is fast, automatic, and largely independent of higher-order explicit reasoning. If a judgement that “the barista aims to fill the cup” is reached only by conscious inference from neutral kinematic data, that is not perception in this sense.  

b. Goal-directedness. An action is goal-directed when its unfolding trajectory can be explained teleologically by reference to a distal outcome rather than by the mere physical forces governing limb movement. Importantly, talk of “goal” here is neutral about the metaphysics of intention; I assume only that the trajectory is meaningfully organized around a prospective end-state.  

c. Motor resonance. I adopt a minimalist operational definition: resonance occurs when neural populations normally implicated in planning or executing action type A are also active while the observer merely sees (or hears) another agent performing A. The central question is whether such activation is not just correlated with but required for perceptual awareness of goals.

3. The case for necessity  

Proponents of SRT advance three main lines of argument.

3.1 The argument from predictive richness  

(i) The kinematics of an ongoing action underdetermine its goal (Grush 2004). For example, the initial reach towards a cup is compatible with drinking, washing, or storing it.  

(ii) The motor system implements forward models that rapidly predict distal outcomes, filling the kinematic gaps.  

(iii) Therefore, without motor prediction the visual system would not have enough information to specify the goal.  

3.2 The developmental argument  

Infants’ sensitivity to others’ goals appears tightly linked to the maturation of their own motor abilities. Six-month-olds, who have just begun to reach, display enhanced attention to goal changes in observed reaching; neonates do not (Woodward 1998; Sommerville & Woodward 2005). Advocates claim that “self-experienced motor control is internalised” and then redeployed to understand others.  

3.3 The disability argument  

Patients with motor system damage or disorders such as limb apraxia often show impairments in recognizing certain actions or discerning others’ intentions (Pazzaglia et al. 2008). If resonance is disrupted, perception of goals allegedly collapses, suggesting necessity.

While these arguments are impressive, each step admits of alternative explanations. Before providing counter-evidence, let me highlight two conceptual worries that already weaken SRT.

4. Two conceptual hurdles for the necessity claim  

4.1 The scope problem  

SRT predicts systematic failure to perceive goal-directedness when the observer lacks the relevant motor schema. Yet adult humans apparently perceive goals of birds flying, snakes striking, or digital avatars moving in ways no biological limb could replicate. Unless we postulate a motor representation for every dynamic one can recognize—a highly implausible expansion—the scope of resonance falls short. Proponents sometimes reply that we infer rather than perceive goals in such cases. But that reply undercuts the ambitious claim that resonance is the gatekeeper of perceptual access to goals per se, leaving SRT with an ad hoc “perception/inference” distinction.

4.2 The circularity problem  

If we operationalise resonance simply as activation in premotor cortex during action observation, how do we show that this activation is not itself driven by the prior perceptual attribution of a goal? Perhaps the visual system detects teleological structure and recruits the motor system post-perceptually, for anticipation or empathic control. Without temporal precedence or causal intervention data, the inference of necessity is circular.

5. Empirical challenges  

5.1 Goal perception without matching motor competence  

a. Novel tool use. Studies in which observers watch actors manipulate unfamiliar tools generate robust goal attributions even before the observers master the corresponding tool actions (Biro & Leslie 2007).  

b. Cross-species. Human adults readily perceive predatory pursuit, nest-building, or food caching as goal-directed, although the motor patterns are not part of the human repertoire. Motion-tracking shows rapid anticipatory eye saccades toward the animal’s goal (Flanagan & Johansson 2003), a hallmark of perceptual, not reflective, processing.  

c. Artificial kinematics. Heider-Simmel style displays of simple shapes elicit spontaneous ascriptions of chasing, coaxing, or helping. These goal attributions arise from spatiotemporal contingencies alone, in the absence of any biological movement cues, let alone a relatable motor schema (Scholl & Tremoulet 2000).  

5.2 Infants perceive goals before acquiring motor resonance  

Contrary to the developmental argument, neonates within 72 hours preferentially look at goal-directed over random motion when low-level cues are controlled (Bardi et al. 2020). Pre-reach infants cannot yet map the seen action onto their own motor system, yet they discriminate goal paths, suggesting that earlier findings conflate maturation of attention with motor competence.  

5.3 Dissociations in neurological populations  

Patients with motor planning deficits (ideational apraxia) sometimes retain intact ability to recognise others’ action goals (Negri et al. 2007). Conversely, patients with ventral visual stream damage but intact motor areas may fail to identify observed actions despite preserved resonance (Sartori et al. 2013). These double dissociations undermine any simple necessity relation.

6. Theoretical alternatives: How goals might be perceived without resonance  

6.1 Kinematic invariants specify intention directly  

Building on Gibsonian ecological psychology, recent work shows that certain relational motion patterns—e.g., τ-coupling between hand and target—specify goal-states in the optic flow (Runeson & Frykholm 1983). These invariants are available to the visual system just as shape and colour are, allowing direct perception of “pick-up” or “place-into” without invoking motor simulation.

6.2 Teleological reasoning as a fast heuristic  

Gergely and Csibra (2003) argue that humans possess domain-specific “teleological reasoning” modules that treat agents as rational optimisers: given an obstacle, a bent trajectory is interpreted as efficient. Crucially, this inferential routine is cognitively impenetrable and extremely rapid (<400 ms), blurring the border between perception and cognition while bypassing motor execution codes.

6.3 Statistical structure learning  

The brain can extract transition probabilities and causal structure from mere observation. When kinematic patterns are consistently followed by particular end-states, a predictive coding system can learn this mapping independently of any commensurable motor programme. Machine-learning models trained only on visual data achieve human-level goal recognition, demonstrating in-principle sufficiency of non-motor information (Kuhn et al. 2022).

7. What motor resonance really contributes  

Rejecting necessity does not render resonance epiphenomenal. A more modest integrationist view can be sketched in three claims.

7.1 Disambiguation under uncertainty  

When multiple plausible goals match the current visual evidence, forward models grounded in one’s own motor repertoire can bias perceptual expectancy toward likely continuations, speeding recognition. Echoing Bayesian cue integration, resonance supplies a prior that is weighted more heavily when visual information is noisy.

7.2 Refinement of fine-grained kinematic decoding  

Experts in dance or sports show inflated mirror-system activity and superior prediction of subtle movement inflections. The extra motor engagement tunes perceptual resolution, analogous to how phonetic expertise sharpens speech perception.

7.3 Action selection and social coordination  

Even when goal perception is already achieved visually, resonance prepares compatible motor responses (e.g., complementary grip), streamlining cooperation. Here the function is prospective motor alignment, not the initial grasp of what the other is doing.

All three roles are compatible with abundant cases in which resonance is weak or absent yet perception of goal-directedness remains intact.

8. Addressing residual objections  

Objection 1: fMRI studies show that mirror-system activity precedes awareness of goals in time-course analyses.  

Reply: The temporal resolution of fMRI is too coarse (seconds) to establish precedence at the sub-200-ms scale relevant for perceptual awareness. Magnetoencephalography and TMS experiments show that disrupting early visual cortex (but not premotor cortex) impairs goal detection when stimuli are masked, tipping the causal arrow in the opposite direction (Cattaneo et al. 2010).

Objection 2: Without resonance, goal perception of impossible movements (e.g., Heider-Simmel) may be merely narrative, not genuine perception.  

Reply: That distinction seems arbitrary once we grant that perceptions are theory-laden. If observers form rapid, automatic, stimulus-bound expectations guiding eye movements and physiological responses, we should regard the representation as perceptual for all practical purposes.

Objection 3: Infants’ early goal sensitivity might rely on “rudimentary” resonance present before overt reaching.  

Reply: Evidence from congenital limb absence argues against this. Individuals born without hands can still perceive hand-based goal actions with typical speed and accuracy; unsurprisingly their motor cortex lacks effector-specific resonance patterns (Vannuscorps & Caramazza 2016). If resonance were necessary, these observers would be blind to a large class of goals, which they are not.

9. Metaphysical lessons  

SRT participates in a broader simulationist strategy: to understand you, I must in some sense become you. The failure of SRT to account for cross-type goal perception hints at a more pluralistic ontology of social cognition. Perceptual systems exploit multiple overlapping information channels—kinematic invariants, statistical regularities, inferential heuristics, and, yes, resonant motor predictions. No single channel enjoys a monopoly, let alone metaphysical necessity.

This pluralism resonates with pragmatic functionalism: the mind recruits whatever resources are efficient given task demands and developmental history. Motor resonance is one such resource, highly efficient for conspecific familiar actions but dispensable in other contexts.

10. Conclusion  

Motor resonance remains a fascinating phenomenon linking perception, action, and social understanding. Yet the strong resonance thesis—that such resonance is a necessary precondition for perceiving goal-directed actions—cannot withstand conceptual scrutiny, empirical counter-evidence, or theoretical competition. Agents perceive goals through a rich mosaic of visual affordances, teleological heuristics, and learned statistical mappings; when available, the motor system’s simulative powers refine and enrich this perception but do not ground it.  

Future research should thus pivot from the necessity question to more nuanced investigations: under what circumstances does resonance make a measurable difference, how is it weighted against other cues, and how do individual differences in motor experience modulate that weighting? Abandoning the necessity claim frees inquiry from the Procrustean bed of mirror-centrism and opens a broader, interdisciplinary landscape for understanding the remarkable human capacity to see what others are up to.

Is Motor Resonance Necessary for Perceiving Goal-Directed Action?  

1. Introduction  

In an influential body of work stretching from the discovery of mirror neurons in macaque premotor cortex (Rizzolatti et al. 1996) to contemporary “simulation theory” in social cognition, many have claimed that motor resonance—the automatic activation of an observer’s own motor repertoire while watching another act—is a pre-condition for perceiving action as goal-directed. On this view, we recognize your reaching as a grasp, rather than as an arbitrary limb trajectory, because my motor system covertly reproduces the kinematic pattern associated with grasping, and thereby endows the visible motion with teleological significance. The claim is not merely that resonance helps, but that without it perceivers would register only meaningless movements. Against this backdrop, the philosophical question is sharp: Is motor resonance strictly necessary for perceiving goal-directed action, or can goal-directedness be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?

I defend a moderate negative answer. Motor resonance is often recruited, often useful, and in some circumstances even indispensable for fine-grained action understanding, but it is not a logically or empirically necessary condition for perceiving goal-directedness per se. The argument proceeds in four steps. (i) I clarify what “necessity” at stake must amount to. (ii) I marshal the strongest empirical and conceptual considerations in favour of the necessity thesis. (iii) I develop three lines of critique—conceptual, empirical, and developmental—showing that goal-direct perception can proceed without resonance. (iv) I sketch a pluralistic alternative, according to which resonance is one among several partially redundant routes to action perception embedded in a wider predictive framework.

2. Varieties of Necessity  

“Necessity” here cannot be logical necessity—there is no contradiction in imagining an organism that perceives goal-directed behaviour yet lacks motor neurons mirroring the observed action. Proponents usually mean “nomological necessity”: given the actual laws, architectures, and constraints of our nervous system, resonance is a sine qua non for goal perception. It may be weaker still: resonance might be biologically necessary for typical adult humans, though not for all conceivable agents. The debate thus concerns a contingent but robust dependence claim: in our species, under normal conditions, no motor resonance, no perception of goal-directedness.

3. The Case for the Necessity Thesis  

3.1 Mirror Neuron Evidence  

Recordings from area F5 show that neurons fire both when monkeys grasp food and when they watch another grasp the same food. Human imaging yields analogous results (e.g., premotor and inferior parietal activations during action observation, with somatotopic organisation). TMS studies indicate that watching a hand action lowers the threshold for eliciting MEPs in the corresponding muscles. The tight effector specificity and the temporal coupling between observation and motor activation suggest that the observer’s motor plans are put ‘on-line’, silently rehearsing the observed movement.

3.2 Causal Interference  

If the motor system does more than merely co-activate, disrupting it should impair perceptual recognition of goals. Indeed, TMS over premotor cortex has been reported to reduce performance on tasks requiring anticipation of the target of observed grasps (Avenanti et al. 2007). Patients with lesions to inferior frontal gyrus show deficits in identifying pantomimed actions compared with controls. Such findings are adduced to support a causal role.

3.3 Phenomenological Plausibility  

Introspectively, we often ‘feel’ another’s action: wince when we see a finger caught in a door, tighten our own shoulder watching a tennis serve. Proponents take this as first-person evidence that resonance furnishes the distinctive immediacy of action perception, short-circuiting the need for detached inference.

3.4 Theoretical Elegance  

An embodied simulation story gracefully explains how low-level kinematics connect to high-level teleological interpretation. If my brain can import the visual input into the generative model that ordinarily guides my own motor output, it can exploit established causal mappings from movement to goal. Resonance thus provides a neurocognitive bridge between the manifest behaviour and the “why” that organises it.

4. Conceptual and Empirical Challenges  

Granting the above merits, three clusters of considerations undermine the claim that resonance is necessary.

4.1 Conceptual Counter-Examples  

(a) Divergent Morphologies. I can effortlessly see that a dog’s sprinting is goal-directed toward a frisbee, yet my motor repertoire for quadrupedal galloping is vestigial. If necessity held, my lack of matching motor schemas should preclude perceiving canine goals. Similarly, we identify the goal of a bird’s swoop or a crane’s rotation boom without being able to enact those trajectories. Necessity threatens to over-fit to shared morphospaces and falter elsewhere.

(b) Tool Extension. Observers readily perceive a craftsman’s use of a new tool—say, a 3-D printer extruder—as deliberate, despite minimal prior opportunity to incorporate its specific kinematics into their motor repertoire. Perception thus outpaces motor acquisition.

(c) Multiple Realizability of Goals. A goal such as “open the door” can be accomplished by pushing with a hand, elbow, hip, or remote control. The same goal is perceived across heterogeneous motor data. What is common is the environmental teleology, not the specific motor pattern.

4.2 Empirical Dissociations  

(a) Congenital Paralysis and Deafferentation. Individuals with congenital limb aplasia (missing limbs from birth) or severe spinal cord injuries cannot execute normal limb actions, hence lack the full motor repertoire. Yet numerous studies (Vannuscorps & Caramazza 2016) show that such individuals recognise others’ hand actions, predict their goals, and even display typical fMRI action-observation network activity, though attenuated. Crucially, performance remains above chance and often normative.

(b) Developmental Time-Course. At 3-month-old, infants too weak to reach nevertheless discriminate between goal-directed and non-goal arm movements; they look longer when an agent reaches for a new object versus a familiar goal despite the same path change (Woodward 1998). Since they cannot yet produce the reaching action, motor resonance in the strict sense cannot be the enabling factor.

(c) Pharmacological or Neurostimulatory Interference. While TMS disruption sometimes impairs fine discrimination of kinematics, several controlled studies show preserved goal identification. For example, Pierno et al. (2011) found that cTBS over premotor areas slowed reaction times for predicting hand rotation but not accuracy of inferring the object to be grasped. This suggests a modulatory rather than necessary role.

4.3 Methodological Worries  

Activation is not explanation. The co-activation of premotor cortex during observation might be epiphenomenal or a downstream consequence of higher-level perceptual recognition rather than its basis. Likewise, lesion studies often involve broad deficits; impaired action understanding might stem from damage to parietal perceptual regions contiguous with, but not identical to, motor simulation areas.

5. Alternative Routes to Goal Perception  

If not (always) via resonance, how do we perceive goal-directedness?

5.1 Direct Perceptual Invariants  

Gibsonian ecological psychologists note that movement patterns contain higher-order invariants (acceleration profiles, tau variables) specifying intentional properties such as “targetedness” or “obstacle avoidance” independent of an observer’s efferent repertoire. For example, the distinctive velocity curvature of a reach-to-grasp reveals the presence of a deceleration phase aligned to object size. Optical information alone might suffice for perceiving the movement as directed to a distal affordance.

5.2 Teleological Reasoning  

Gergely and Csibra’s “teleological stance” posits that infants, and arguably adults, interpret agents as entities that act efficiently toward a goal subject to environmental constraints. Evidence comes from classic ‘rational goal’ animations: when a ball jumps over an obstacle, infants expect a straight path once the obstacle is removed, even without access to translating motion into their motor schemes. The core representation is abstract, mapping situational constraints to minimal-cost paths, not motor commands.

5.3 Statistical and Conceptual Knowledge  

Bayesian models of action understanding treat the perceptual system as integrating prior knowledge of typical goals with the likelihoods of observed trajectories. On this view, resonance is one computational strategy to approximate the likelihood; but sight-based generative models could in principle operate without motor execution capacities.

6. A Pluralistic Predictive Coding Framework  

How, then, to reconcile mirror neuron data with the above dissociations? Predictive coding offers a unifying architecture. The cortex maintains hierarchies of generative models, from abstract intentions down to muscle activations. Observation entails running these models forward to predict incoming sensory signals; mismatches update beliefs. Motor resonance arises when relatively low-level motor predictions are enlisted to reduce visual prediction error. But higher levels can do the job when lower levels are crippled or non-matching. Thus:

• In familiar, body-compatible cases (watching another human grasp), the system recruits motoric priors for efficiency.  
• In morphologically divergent cases (dog sprinting), low-level motor maps are too mismatched or noisy; the system relies on higher-level dynamics of target pursuit.  
• In development, before motor skill is present, infants depend more on abstract efficiency priors; motor resonance gradually becomes available and refines perception.  

Within such an architecture, the presence of motor resonance is contingent on task demands, expertise, and morphological overlap; it is beneficial but not obligatory.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Congenital paralysis subjects may use residual facial or trunk motor representations to simulate hand actions covertly. Reply: Some individuals lack even proximal limb representations, yet perform normally; moreover, direct measurement shows muted M1 hand area activation. The similarity of performance across such heterogeneous residual capacities suggests compensation by non-motor perceptual circuits.

Objection 2: The infant data merely show perceptual sensitivity, not conscious understanding; adult-level goal perception may still require resonance. Reply: The necessity claim concerned perception broadly construed, not only reflective attribution. Moreover, adults watching novel tool use exhibit comprehension before acquiring matching motor skills, indicating continuity.

Objection 3: Even if alternative routes exist, they may be too slow or resource-intensive; only resonance affords the automaticity characteristic of everyday perception. Reply: Reaction time studies reveal mixed patterns: in some tasks resonance speeds processing, in others semantic or contextual cues dominate. Automaticity is graded; what matters for necessity is the possibility of perceiving at all, not maximal efficiency.

8. Philosophical Implications  

Rejecting necessity reshapes debates in social cognition. First, it tempers simulationist claims that understanding others is fundamentally a matter of ‘putting oneself in their shoes’. Second, it vindicates a richer view of perceptual content: teleological properties can be visually specified without mediating internal enactment. Third, it integrates embodiment into a pluralistic epistemic strategy, avoiding the pitfalls of motor chauvinism while acknowledging sensorimotor grounding.

9. Conclusion  

Motor resonance is a striking, evolutionarily elegant mechanism that often underwrites our remarkably fluid grasp of one another’s deeds. Yet the weight of conceptual analysis, developmental evidence, and dissociation studies reveal that it is not the only game in town, nor the indispensable gateway to perceiving goal-directed action. Goal perception is multiply realisable: sometimes enacted through covert motor simulation, sometimes through extraction of optical invariants, sometimes through abstract teleological reasoning. A predictive, hierarchical brain flexibly recruits whichever strata of representation best serve the task. To insist on motor resonance as necessary is to mistake a versatile tool for the foundation of the house. Acknowledging its importance without overstating its reach affords a more nuanced, empirically grounded, and philosophically satisfying account of how we see purpose in the movements around us.

How can a device—or, by extension, an organism—acquire information about the passage of time when time itself never exerts a push or a pull on anything?  The objection is powerful because it seems to uncover a deep asymmetry.  Where vision recruits photons, audition recruits pressure waves, and proprioception recruits joint strain, temporal perception appears to recruit…nothing.  Yet clocks clearly work, and biological organisms just as clearly exploit endogenous timing mechanisms to guide action, prediction, and memory.  If a clock’s hands move in synchrony with the seconds and minutes while undergoing no direct causal bombardment from “time,” what mediates the correlation?  In what follows I will (1) clarify the notion of causal impotence at issue, (2) examine what is actually required for sensory information according to contemporary information-theoretic accounts, (3) show how the internal dynamics of physical and biological oscillators satisfy those requirements, and (4) reply to residual worries about circularity—worries that we “smuggle in” time by implicitly presupposing it in our explanation.  The upshot is that once we have a proper picture of information and representation, the absence of a time-specific causal force ceases to be problematic: a system can count as a time-sense device whenever its states reliably covary with temporal magnitudes in virtue of law-like, difference-making relations, even if the laws concern variables other than time itself.

1.  The idea of causal impotence

First, consider what it means to say that time is causally impotent.  In Newtonian physics, time labels a dimension along which states change, but it is not itself an entity capable of entering causal diagrams.  It neither transfers energy nor changes momentum.  Relativistic physics complicates the picture by integrating time with space, yet preserves the core point: nothing is struck, repelled, or deformed by a brute temporal force.  The slogan “time doesn’t push” is therefore apt.  But impotence in this sense does not entail irrelevance to causal explanation.  Temperature, for instance, is a statistical property of molecular motion rather than an independent cause, yet thermometers successfully measure temperature because molecular impacts on mercury or bimetal strips are lawfully correlated with that aggregate property.  If measurement does not require causal impact from the property measured, we have at least an opening for a similar strategy with time.

Nevertheless, one might insist that temperature still shows up in a disguised causal role: molecular motion transfers energy to the thermometer, which yields expansion.  The time case, the objector continues, has no analogue; there is no underlying micro-interaction between “moments” and clock gears.  To answer, we must ask what sensing requires, and here an information-theoretic perspective proves clarifying.

2.  Information without direct stimulus: the Dretske‐Skyrms framework

Fred Dretske’s seminary work on natural information maintains that a signal carries information about a variable whenever there is a nomic conditional linking signal and source: if source state s obtains, signal σ will obtain.  Or, in probabilistic refinement, source and signal stand in mutual information to the extent that the probability distribution over signal values differs with source values.  Crucially, the conditional need not be mediated by the source’s directly impinging on the signal.  The reading on a mercury thermometer carries information about ambient temperature not because “temperature particles” collide with mercury, but because the microphysical laws governing kinetic energy, collisions, and pressure ensure a highly reliable mapping from temperature to mercury column height.

Brian Skyrms generalizes the idea: representation is grounded in difference-making regularities.  A variable X represents Y for some system just in case X’s variations would, under counterfactual circumstances, covary with Y in ways that creatures exploiting the mapping could use to achieve goals.  Again, no requirement is imposed that Y be causa sui of X.  Reliable covariation underwrites usable information; direct causal action is sufficient but not necessary.

If this is right, the objector’s burden is to show that temporal variables cannot enter into the relevant covariation relations.  That burden looks heavy once we examine concrete timekeeping mechanisms.

3.  The pendulum clock: internal dynamics as temporal correlates

The paradigmatic clock is the pendulum design Galilei intuited and Huygens perfected.  Its period is famously 2π√(ℓ/g).  Neither ℓ (length) nor g (gravitational acceleration) is caused by “time.”  Instead, they jointly determine a regular oscillatory motion: every swing takes the same duration given constant ℓ and g in the small-angle approximation.  The causal forces at work are gravity and tension; the resulting path through the pendulum’s phase space is described as a function of time, but no temporal shove initiates it.  Why, then, does reading the pointer at the 3-second mark convey that three seconds have elapsed?

Because a lawful mapping is in place: For all worlds governed by the same laws and initial settings, pointer angle θ(t) is a deterministic function f(t).  If the pointer presently reads θ*, an ideal observer can invert f to infer elapsed time t*.  That inference is licensed by physical regularities, not by a causal arrow from “the three-second property of time” to the gears.  To put it in Dretskean language: the pointer position carries information that t = t* because, under the relevant laws, P(pointer = θ* | t = t*) = 1 and P(pointer = θ* | t ≠ t*) ≈ 0 (discounting friction, etc.).  The system’s own causal evolution provides the signal; environmental time enters only as a parameter the system mirrors.

You might object that we have merely traded one mystery for another: the “function of time” description presupposes time.  But a relational treatment dissolves any circularity.  The pendulum is a periodic process—call it P.  Imagine possessing in addition some reference process R, perhaps the Earth’s rotation or the decay of cesium atoms.  To say that P’s pointer shows thirty cycles while R has completed one rotation is to report a comparative fact, not to quantify time substantively.  Clocks establish ratios among processes.  If one of the processes is stipulated as the standard second, the others inherit temporal significance.  No causal work needs doing by time per se.

4.  Circadian clocks: endogenous rhythms and biological time

Pendulum clocks are artefacts; what about living systems?  Cyanobacteria kept in constant darkness continue to express gene sequences in a circadian (~24 h) rhythm.  Mammalian suprachiasmatic nuclei, when surgically removed and cultured, maintain similar oscillations.  In both cases the underlying mechanism is a molecular feedback loop: protein A promotes the transcription of protein B; B inhibits A; degradation resets the system.  The loop’s period depends on rates of transcription, translation, and decay—chemical parameters, not temporal ones.

Yet the oscillators carry temporal information valuable to the organism.  A nocturnal rodent that wakes at dusk needs no solar trigger provided its internal oscillator is entrained.  How is information carried?  At any moment, the concentration of phospho‐PER proteins stands in a one-to-one mapping with elapsed time since the previous subjective midnight, so long as the organism’s biochemistry is statistically normal.  That mapping is robust enough that tampering with protein levels—e.g., knocking out the Period gene—systematically throws off behavioral timing.  The causal pathways run within the organism, while the temporal variable is “read off” the resulting chemical state.

One might still suspect we are covertly appealing to an observer: only a scientist, it seems, interprets protein profiles as clocks.  However, within the organism downstream neurons and hormonal pathways exploit the very same correlation.  Cortisol release, for instance, is gated by the circadian oscillator; disruption of the latter destabilizes the former.  Hence the biological system treats the chemical oscillation as a time signal under its own steam.  Representation is endogenous, not imposed by external ascription.

5.  Difference-making, not stimulus energy

We can now articulate a general principle:

A system S counts as measuring or sensing a variable V when there exists an internal state S(x) such that:

a) Lawful covariance: Across the systems’ normal operating conditions, variations in V lawfully co-occur with variations in S(x) in a way that is stable under relevant counterfactual interventions.

b) Downstream use: Some consumer subsystem C of S exploits that covariance to guide behavior, control, or further inference.

Direct causal impact from V to S(x) is optional; what matters is the counterfactual dependence and utility.  A barometer passes the test with respect to atmospheric pressure; a pendulum or a PER protein loop passes the test with respect to elapsed time.  In neither case must the measured property appear as a unique field or force.  Time’s causal impotence is therefore no obstacle to its being represented.

6.  Rebutting the “no comparison without time” worry

A persistent worry suggests that internal oscillators themselves unfold in time, so explaining their temporal accuracy is viciously circular: we invoke time to explain the system that explains time.  The worry conflates metaphysical with explanatory dependence.  Describing the swing of a pendulum indeed uses temporal vocabulary, but the explanatory leverage comes from dynamical laws—Newtown’s, Hooke’s, Boltzmann’s—that correlate variables independent of time (length, mass, energy) with the number of oscillations that occur before the system returns to its initial state.  We can redescribe those laws relationally, indexing one process to another, or topologically, via phase-space trajectories.  The mathematics employs a time parameter for convenience, yet nothing in the explanation requires positing time as a primitive causal agent.  Eliminating the parameter merely renders the exposition clumsier, not circular.

7.  Information versus sensation: is there a genuine sensory modality?

A skeptic might grant that clocks represent time yet deny that humans enjoy a dedicated “sense” of time analogous to sight or hearing.  This is partly a verbal issue: does any traffic in information count as a sensory modality?  Note, however, that proprioception arose as a respectable sense only once scientists recognized specialized muscle spindle afferents and their specific cortical projections.  Contemporary neuroscience is uncovering comparably specialized circuits for interval timing and circadian prediction—striatum for seconds-to-minutes, hippocampus for episodic temporal order, SCN for day–night.  What unifies these is not receipt of temporal energy but the exploitation of internal oscillators triggered or reset by external cues (light, motor efference, reward onset).  If the presence of dedicated transduction cells is the decisive criterion for sensehood, time still qualifies: ion fluxes in SCN neurons transduce light signals into phase shifts, and dopamine bursts in striatal neurons reset millisecond oscillators.  That these transducers respond to light or dopamine rather than “raw time” is irrelevant; vision’s rods, after all, respond to photons, yet we happily say they yield information about distal objects rather than about patterns of luminance per se.

8.  Addressing alternative objections

Objection 1: Clocks require calibration; without occasional correction they drift, undermining reliable covariance.

Reply: The same is true of every sense organ.  Photoreceptors bleach and regenerate; hair cells fatigue; mechanoreceptors adapt.  Calibration is a ubiquitous problem and does not imply non-sensation.

Objection 2: Clocks measure duration, not the metaphysical flow of time; therefore they do not represent time as such.

Reply: What is represented is whatever variable figures in the lawlike covariance.  If the best we can get are duration relations, then that is precisely the aspect of time that physical and biological systems represent.  Demanding that a sense latch onto a metaphysically thick “flow” exceeds ordinary criteria.  Thermometers do not represent the essence of heat, only mean molecular kinetic energy; yet they count as temperature sensors.

Objection 3: The informational account loosens the notion of “causal influence” so far that any correlation counts as sensing; therefore the argument cheats.

Reply: The account does require systematic counterfactual dependence, not mere accidental correlation.  Suppose my clock accidentally stops at noon the moment a solar flare occurs; thereafter its pointer position remains unchanged while time elapses.  The covariance collapses and the system ceases to inform.  Law-based difference-making is the key filter against accidental pairs.

9.  Summarizing the positive picture

We can now summarize how a clock may carry information about time without time’s causal intervention:

i.  Physical systems can instantiate intrinsic dynamics—oscillatory, decay-based, or inertial—that unfold in a regular, law-governed pattern.

ii.  Those dynamics produce internal states whose values map one-to-one (or nearly so) onto elapsed durations under stable conditions.

iii.  Because the mapping is secured by physical law, the internal states make a reliable difference to agents or devices that exploit them; they thereby meet standard natural-information conditions.

iv.  Nothing in i-iii requires a temporally specific force; the explanatory work is done by causal interactions among non-temporal properties (mass, charge, chemical affinity).  Time enters only as the dimension along which the interactions are charted or, alternatively, as the comparative relation among processes.

Therefore the initial objection trades on an oversimplified stimulus-response picture of sensing.  Once we adopt a law-plus-information framework, the absence of a “time particle” is no more remarkable than the absence of a “temperature particle.”  Information can ride piggy-back on causal structures whose content is determined by their lawful, exploitable covariation with environmental variables—time included.

10.  Concluding remarks

The question whether humans possess a genuine sense of time remains open empirically; philosophers and neuroscientists continue to debate the integration of disparate timing systems.  What we can conclude philosophically is that there is no in-principle barrier to sensing time.  Clocks—mechanical, atomic, or biological—show by example how systems can acquire temporal information through internal dynamics calibrated by but not caused by time.  The objection from causal impotence rests on a mistaken conception of what it takes to measure or represent a property.  Replace that conception with an information-theoretic, counterfactual notion of representation, and the road is clear for time to join the ranks of properties we measure, track, and, perhaps, literally sense.

1. Introduction  

Everyday talk tempts us to treat time as though it were one more item populating the causal order: we say that time “flows,” that it “wears down” cliffs, that it “heals” grief.
