Philosophical reflection, however, quickly reveals the metaphor.  What erodes sandstone cliffs are wind-driven particles, what alleviates sorrow are neuro-psychological processes; time itself is not a force or substance that pushes, pulls, heats, or cools.  From this observation grows the objection summarized in the prompt.  All the familiar senses—vision, audition, olfaction, etc.—work because a distal feature of the environment causally impinges on the receptor organ.  If time “does nothing,” then apparently nothing can make specialized receptors fire, and therefore there can be no proprietary sense of time.  

Yet the conclusion is too quick.  The objection conflates two distinct requirements: (i) that sensory systems acquire information through reliable causal interaction with the environment and (ii) that the environmental property represented must itself be the immediate cause of the sensory state.  Only the first requirement is genuine.  In what follows I develop a response that (a) diagnoses the mistake in the objection, (b) shows how a clock—biological or artefactual—can lawfully carry temporal information without time exerting any causal “push,” and (c) explains why this suffices for genuine perception, broadly construed.  My strategy draws on three philosophical ideas: the Dretskean analysis of natural information, the difference between etiological and functional explanation, and the metaphysics of laws and symmetries in physics.

2. Natural information and the “aboutness” of sensory states  

Fred Dretske’s seminal proposal in Knowledge and the Flow of Information insists that a state R of a system carries information about condition C just in case there is a lawful, counterfactual-supporting dependency: if C were not the case, R would not occur (or would occur with systematically different values).  Crucially, the law can connect C to R through an intermediary chain of causes; C need not itself bang directly into the receptor.  Consider vision.  Photons striking the retina are indeed proximal causes of transduction events, but what the resultant neural states are about is not the photon per se but, say, the presence of a tree thirty meters away.  The distal property is only indirectly linked to the sensory registration: via the way light reflects off surfaces, travels, refracts through ocular media, and so on.  Thus the Dretskean criterion secures content not with the notion of direct causal impact by the represented property, but with law-governed covariance sustained across counterfactual situations.  

Once this point is appreciated, the door opens for temporal representation.  A mechanism carries information about t seconds having elapsed just in case its current state covaries lawfully with that temporal interval.  Whether time itself “hits” the mechanism is irrelevant; what matters is that, given the dynamical laws governing the mechanism, its state at any moment is a predictable function of elapsed time.  The privilege enjoyed by properties such as light wavelength in vision is accidental: photons happen to be convenient carriers of the lawlike correlation.  In principle, any robust mapping—whether mediated by light, chemical diffusion, or internal oscillation—can underwrite sensory content.

3. Clockwork without temporal causal influx  

How, concretely, does a clock manage to correlate its states with elapsed time?  The short answer is: by instantiating a dynamical system whose evolution is mathematically parameterised by the time variable in the governing equations.  Consider a simple harmonic oscillator, the heart of a pendulum clock.  The differential equation d²θ/dt² + (g/L)θ = 0 has the independent variable t; given initial conditions the solution θ(t) = θ₀cos(√(g/L) t + φ) yields a phase that tracks t with high regularity.  Nothing in that story postulates time exerting causal influence.  The pendulum’s successive displacements are caused by the interplay of gravity and inertia; the reason they unfold at a determinate rate is that the physical constants g (acceleration due to gravity) and L (length of the pendulum) fix the period T = 2π√(L/g).  Thus the pendulum’s state at t = T, 2T, 3T, … differs systematically from its state at earlier instants, and an observer who has learned the mapping can read off elapsed times.

The same template generalises.  Circadian rhythms in living organisms depend on transcription–translation feedback loops.  Molecular concentrations oscillate with an approximately 24-hour period because of delays in genetic and proteomic interactions.  Here again the causal traffic is wholly intra-systemic: concentrations modulate promoter activity, proteins inhibit their own synthesis, etc.  Time has no hand in flipping molecular switches.  Nevertheless, because the governing kinetics approximate a stable limit cycle, the phase of the biochemical oscillator is a reliable surrogate for solar time.  The organism therefore possesses a “clock” in Dretske’s sense.

4. Why the indirectness is not disqualifying  

The objector may concede the covariance but retort that the mechanism is not properly sensory because the information source is “inside,” not “outside” the organism.  Two replies are apt.

First, even paradigmatic exteroceptive senses employ extensive endogenous processing; they are not passive input devices.  Retinal photoreceptors adapt, cortical circuits implement normalization, the vestibular system integrates motor efference copies to cancel self-generated motion.  What secures the status of these systems as senses is not a metaphysical boundary between inside and outside but their teleofunction: to extract, for the organism, information enabling successful action in a volatile environment.  Internal oscillators satisfy this teleofunction by allowing the organism to anticipate dawn, regulate hormone release, coordinate migration, and so forth.  

Second, the insider/outsider line is blurry in any case.  The circadian pacemaker is entrained by light, temperature, and feeding schedules—features plainly external.  Entrainment does involve causal impact from environmental cycles, but note: what causally impacts the pacemaker are photons, nutrients, etc., not “time.”  Hence acknowledging entrainment does not rehabilitate the original objection; it merely underscores that temporal information typically piggybacks on other causal channels.  An analogy: a barometer is sensitive to atmospheric pressure, but what it tells the meteorologist is whether a storm is likely.  Pressure, not storms, moves the needle, yet the reading is about storms because storms and low pressure stand in a reliable nomic relation.

5. Law, symmetry, and temporal representation  

At a deeper level, the insufficiency of direct causal impact for representation traces to the role of symmetries in physics.  Newtonian and relativistic theories treat time translation as a continuous symmetry: the fundamental laws are invariant under t → t + Δ.  Emmy Noether showed that such symmetries correspond to conservation laws (energy in this case).  For a clock to work, it must break this symmetry by selecting a “phase” relative to an origin; otherwise every moment would be qualitatively identical and no mechanism could differentiate 3 pm from 4 pm.  This symmetry-breaking is accomplished by initial conditions plus dissipative processes that dampen perturbations.  The key is that the laws make the evolution of the system deterministically dependent on elapsed time, even though no novel causal influence emanates from time.  Philosophically, then, time representation is possible because temporal parameterisation is written into the modal structure of the universe; sensory systems are loci where that modal structure is exploited for informational purposes.

6. Answering worries about circularity  

A different worry alleges circularity: we explain how the mechanism tracks time by appealing to equations containing the very variable ‘t’.  But employing t in the mathematical description is not to presume an independent sense of time; it is merely to describe the differential law that governs state changes.  To see this, imagine reformulating the oscillator in dimensionless terms.  One may define σ = t/T so that θ(σ) = θ₀ cos(2πσ + φ).  The state is a function of σ, the ratio of elapsed duration to intrinsic period.  An organism could in principle rely solely on σ, never mentioning seconds or hours.  Nonetheless, because environmental regularities (sunrise cycle, tides, predator activity) couple to σ via known correlations, the organism reaps predictive benefits.  No conceptual circle threatens.

7. Is the temporal sense genuine perception?  

Some philosophers restrict “perception” to detection of currently instantiated distal properties.  If so, the internal clock yields no perception of time present but rather of time passage.  Yet passage is a temporal property, and the sensory evidence for it is immediate: one’s own neural dynamics are continually registering change.  Moreover, interval timing experiments show that humans and many animals can discriminate durations in the millisecond-to-minute range with characteristic psychophysical Weber fractions.  The processing utilises dedicated neural circuits (striato-thalamo-cortical loops modulated by dopamine); lesions selectively impair temporal discrimination while sparing other faculties.  This functional separation and modality-specific phenomenology (the felt “spacing” of beats in music, the sense that speech is hastened or slowed) motivates talk of a proprietary sense, on a par with proprioception or nociception.  

Admittedly, temporal perception is not triggered by a unique category of energy transduction.  But proprioception is triggered by stretch in muscle spindles, which is itself mediated by the forces generated by the organism’s own movement; pain is triggered by tissue damage, a heterogeneous set of micro-events.  What unites the senses is not a shared receptor archetype but the epistemic role they play.  On that score, the temporal sense qualifies: its deliverances guide decision, learning, and prediction in ways that would be impossible were the organism blind to duration.

8. Concluding synthesis  

The initial objection derives its plausibility from a superficial reading of how sensory content is fixed.  Once we adopt a more nuanced account—in which information flows through reliable, law-governed correlations rather than through direct causal bombardment by the represented property—the objection collapses.  A clock, whether mechanical or biological, carries information about elapsed time thanks to stable dynamical laws that link its evolving states to a temporal parameter.  Time need not “reach out and touch” the mechanism; it suffices that the mechanism’s states unfold in a manner lawfully dependent on duration.  This dependence is secured via physical constants, symmetry-breaking initial conditions, and occasional entrainment by exteroceptive cues.  The result is a genuine sensory system for time, one whose legitimacy is on a par with any other sense once we abandon the myth that perception must be activated by the very property perceived.  Far from being causally impotent, time is woven into the causal fabric; sensory systems simply exploit that fabric rather than wait for time to deliver a shove.

The objection worth taking seriously is the following: if genuine sensory systems require a causal influx from the feature sensed, and if time exerts no causal force, then there can be no sensory system for time.  At first glance the argument appears decisive.  Photons strike the retina; pressure waves deform the cochlea; volatile molecules bind to olfactory receptors.  Nothing comparable, so the objector says, can be true of time.  Time is not an entity that pushes, pulls, or vibrates.  Consequently our awareness of duration, succession, rhythm, and simultaneity must—​so the objection concludes—​be a purely intellectual construction rather than a form of perception.  

I shall argue that the objection misconstrues both how information about worldly magnitudes is typically carried by physical mechanisms and how biological and artefactual clocks actually work.  Once we clarify those two points, it becomes evident that a system can carry highly reliable information about elapsed time without time itself impinging upon the system as a causal agent.  Roughly, the trick is to exploit physical processes whose own dynamics instantiate a stable lawlike mapping to elapsed time and to treat those processes as evidence for how much time has passed.  The “causal work” is done not by time, but by ordinary energetic interactions whose behaviour is reliably parametrized by time.  Because such parametrization supports counterfactual‐supporting regularities, it transmits information in precisely the sense required by broadly causal theories of perception and representation.  Hence a “sense of time” is both conceptually coherent and actually realized in organisms equipped with circadian, ultradian, and interval‐timing mechanisms.

The argument proceeds in five steps.

1.  Clarify what causal‐information theories of perception really demand.  
2.  Survey how physical clocks measure time without time acting as a force.  
3.  Show how those same principles underwrite biological timing devices.  
4.  Explain why the resulting mechanisms satisfy standard criteria for genuine sensory systems.  
5.  Confront residual worries about causal impotence, misrepresentation, and phenomenal character.

1.  Causal information and the sensing requirement  

Most contemporary philosophers—in the tradition of Grice, Dretske, and Fodor—treat perceptual content as grounded in nomic or statistical covariation: a token internal event R “carries the information that” a worldly condition S obtains just in case P(S|R)=1 (or very high) across the channel of interest.  Crucially, the channel may involve multiple mediating causes; what matters is the reliable lawlike link.  Consider a metal thermometer.  Mercury’s volume is strictly correlated, via the gas‐law‐like behaviour of liquids, with the average kinetic energy of adjacent molecules.  That correlation carries information about temperature, even though temperature is not a particulate force that pushes liquid up the tube.  What drives expansion and contraction are collisions among molecules, not “temperature” as an extra entity.  No one therefore concludes that thermometers fail to perceive temperature.  We are content to say that the device senses temperature in virtue of a systematic, exploitable correlation, underwritten by physical law.  

Analogously, if we can identify a physical variable whose state is lawfully mapped onto elapsed time, we can produce a channel in Dretske’s sense.  The existence of such a mapping is exactly what clock design exploits.

2.  How clocks keep time  

Every practical clock relies on a physical process that repeats or progresses at a stable rate.  Sundials exploit the roughly 24‐hour rotation of Earth; sandglasses exploit approximately constant gravitational flow; quartz watches exploit a piezoelectric crystal that vibrates at 32,768 Hz; caesium clocks exploit the hyperfine transition of the caesium‐133 atom.  None of those devices is pushed around by “time.”  What causally drives them are electromagnetic, gravitational, or nuclear forces.  Nonetheless there is a clean, mathematically expressible mapping f between the internal state of the oscillator and the objective amount of time passed since some zero‐point:

    State(t) = f(t; k),

where k encodes parameters such as temperature and elasticity.  For a well‐engineered clock, k is held fixed or corrected for, so State(t) ∝ t.  That proportionality supports counterfactual conditionals: had ten minutes more elapsed, the quartz’s phase would have advanced by 19,660,800 cycles.  

What matters for informational purposes, then, is not a causal arrow from time to mechanism, but a lawful dependence of the mechanism’s microstate on the temporal parameter governing its own equations of motion.  Because the dependence is both lawlike and predictively reliable, the mechanism’s states serve as evidence for elapsed time.  They do so in exactly the same sense that mercury level serves as evidence for temperature: not because temperature causally intrudes, but because thermodynamic laws knit together the causal story in a way expressible by a robust functional relationship.

3.  Biological timing  

Organisms, under selective pressure to coordinate behaviour with recurring environmental events, have evolved clock‐like mechanisms that mirror the engineering principles just surveyed.

3.1  Circadian clocks  
In cyanobacteria, for example, three proteins—KaiA, KaiB, KaiC—form a phosphorylation cycle with an intrinsic period of about 24 hours.  Photons from sunrise do entrain (synchronize) the phase, but the oscillator free‐runs in constant darkness.  The causal forces at play are chemical kinetics and ATP hydrolysis; the upshot is a biochemical state whose phase φ(t) provides accurate information about time of day.

3.2  Interval timers  
In mammals, the basal ganglia and cerebellum host cortico‐striatal circuits that accumulate pulses from cortical oscillators at roughly millisecond resolution.  Dopamine modulates count thresholds, enabling an animal to estimate intervals on the order of seconds to minutes.  Neural entrainment to rhythmic stimuli further calibrates the oscillators.  Again, neither the proteins nor the neurons are buffeted by “time”; they simply evolve according to reaction rates and membrane dynamics whose outputs covary with elapsed time.

3.3  Plasticity and calibration  
Because environmental demands vary, biological clocks employ feedback: phase discrepancies between internal oscillators and external cues (light, temperature, food) induce gene expression that fine‐tunes reaction rates.  The system is thus self‐correcting, which increases the reliability of the time–state mapping and secures its informational content.

4.  Meeting the criteria for a sensory system  

Does anything in the foregoing fall short of perception proper?  Three standard marks of sensory systems are causal receptivity to stimulation, dedicated transducers, and downstream behavioural use.

4.1  Causal receptivity  
The time‐tracking devices we surveyed are causally receptive in the relevant sense: their states are physically perturbed—​by photons, ion fluxes, or mechanical strain—in ways that systematically alter phase or pulse counts.  They differ from vision only in that the causal “trigger” is not time per se but environmental regularities (rotation of Earth, daylight cycles) whose temporal profile they exploit.  That difference, however, does not undermine the information‐carrying relation; quite the opposite, it instantiates it.

4.2  Dedicated transducers  
Circadian protein complexes and striatal pacemaker‐accumulator circuits are anatomically and functionally distinct subsystems whose evolved role is temporal regulation.  They are as much a modular sense organ as the cochlea or retina.

4.3  Behavioural use  
Disrupt a rodent’s suprachiasmatic nucleus and its sleep–wake cycle collapses.  Alter dopamine tone and its interval timing skews.  These causal interventions show that temporal representations control behaviour just as visual representations guide saccades.  Errors under pharmacological or genetic perturbation also demonstrate the possibility of misrepresentation—​another hallmark of representational content.

Consequently the mechanisms deserve the label “sensor” even on quite demanding teleosemantic accounts.  Their proper function, selected or engineered, is to produce internal states that stand in a true‐time mapping; when noise or pathology break the mapping, the system malfunctions.

5.  Objections and replies  

5.1  The metaphysical worry: time as mere parameter  
One might maintain that a variable does not count as perceived unless it is ontologically on a par with colour, pitch, or pressure: something that can vary in the local environment and generate a proximal stimulus.  Time, the objection runs, is not locally variable; it is a global, homogeneous parameter.  Two replies are available.

First, we do perceive global, relational properties—​velocity, for instance.  Motion detectors in the visual cortex respond to spatiotemporal energy patterns that specify speed, even though “speed” is not a local surface feature.  Second, what we perceive most directly are durations and tempos, not abstract Newtonian time.  Durations are relational magnitudes between events, and events certainly causally affect sensors.  A drumbeat and its successor impinge on the ear; the auditory system extracts inter‐onset interval, a genuinely perceptual datum.  

5.2  The causal‐potency rejoinder  
Perhaps the critic will retreat to the claim that successful perception requires the relevant property itself to be a difference‐maker.  But on interventionist analyses of causation (Woodward 2003), a variable X is a difference‐maker for Y when manipulating X alters Y ceteris paribus.  Intervene on elapsed time (e.g., place the quartz into a slower reference frame according to special relativity) and its phase changes.  That is exactly what relativity‐based time dilation experiments exploit.  So even under a strict interventionist reading, elapsed time qualifies.

5.3  Phenomenological residue  
Sorting out the causal and informational conditions still leaves the felt sense of passage.  Some will argue that the ticking of internal oscillators cannot yield the phenomenology of flow.  Yet note that the same sceptical move would, if pushed, deny the sensory status of smell because chemo–electrical spikes hardly resemble aromas.  Phenomenology supervenes on neural activity; once we grant that temporal mechanisms influence the global workspace or recurrent cortical loops, nothing blocks them from contributing to subjective experience.  Moreover, psycho‐physical data on temporal illusions—​chronostasis after saccades, the kappa and tau effects, the filled‐interval illusion—​reveal systematic distortions contingent on predictable adjustments in timing circuits.  Such illusions are strong evidence that temporal perception has the same blend of fidelity and fallibility characteristic of bona fide senses.

Conclusion  

The initial objection rests on a faulty picture of how information is marshalled in perception.  Sensory systems need not be causally struck by the property they represent; they must instead exploit reliable physical correlations that connect their own states to that property.  Clocks—​artefactual or biological—​achieve that feat by harnessing processes whose dynamics scale monotonically with elapsed time.  Once calibrated, the mapping between internal state and time interval constitutes an information channel in the standard, causally sanctioned sense.  Biological organisms have in fact evolved multiple such channels, complete with dedicated transducers, error‐correction, and behavioural deployment.  Accordingly, the thesis that there can be no genuine sense of time because time is causally impotent is untenable.  The human animal, alongside cyanobacteria and atomic clocks, genuinely senses time—​not because Time itself pushes on us, but because matter arranged in suitable dynamical patterns silently, lawfully keeps track of how long it has been since Now became Then.

To see why the impossibility‐of‐temporal‐sense objection is not decisive it helps to proceed in four stages.

1. Disentangle several different ways in which one might be said to “sense” something.  
2. Clarify what the objection is really getting at when it calls time “causally impotent.”  
3. Explain how representing a magnitude does not always require that that very magnitude act as a causal force.  
4. Use these clarifications to show in detail how a physical clock (and, by analogy, a biological timing mechanism) can carry perfectly good information about time even though time itself does not flow into the mechanism as a causal agent.

The result will be that the objection rests on a mistaken picture of measurement and representation, not on a deep metaphysical impossibility.

I. Varieties of “sensing”  

A paradigm sensory modality, such as vision, typically involves three ingredients.

a) Energy transduction: some environmental energy (photons) impinges on a receptor surface (retina) and is converted into a neural signal.  
b) Dedicated apparatus: there is specialized biological “hardware” whose evolutionary function is to track that kind of environmental input.  
c) Systematic covariance: patterns in the neural signal lawfully co‐vary with patterns in the environment, grounding reliable representation.

Philosophers sometimes tacitly assume that the first ingredient—energy transduction—is essential. Yet much philosophical work on representation (Dretske’s indicator semantics, Millikan’s teleosemantics, Fodor’s asymmetric‐dependence theory, the “structural” and “predictive processing” schools) shows that what is fundamental is reliable covariance in virtue of appropriate mechanisms. Whether the covariation is mediated by energy that literally originates in the distal property is a further, usually irrelevant, question.

This matters because thermometers, barometers, and Geiger counters are sensible measuring devices even though they are not “sense organs” in the biological sense. Their inputs may come from the relevant physical magnitudes, but sometimes the linkage is indirect or purely internal: a mercury column rises or falls in systematic relation to atmospheric temperature even when no molecule of mercury has ever been in causal contact with the molecular kinetic energy that constitutes temperature in the open air. All that matters is that well‐understood physical laws hook up the two quantities in a robust, counterfactual‐supporting way. The thermometer, in Dretske’s phrase, is an indicator of temperature.

So a sensible first conclusion is that a mechanism M can qualify as an information bearing “sensor” of magnitude X just in case: (i) there is a reliable lawlike mapping from states of M onto values of X; and (ii) that mapping is the product of an etiology that explains why M exists or is used. Direct energetic input from X is optional.

II. How is time supposed to be “causally impotent”?  

Why, then, the special worry about time? The objector’s thought is roughly this:

P1. For S to sense X, X must causally influence S.  
P2. Time never causally influences anything (indeed talk of “time acting” is a category mistake).  
C. Therefore there can be no sense of time.

Setting aside P1 for the moment, notice that P2 conflates two distinct ideas.

(1) Time as a dimension or parameter is not a substance. It is not the kind of entity that exerts forces. So understood, time has no causal powers—true but harmless.

(2) All genuine causal relations are temporal; causes precede their effects. So in that derivative sense, time is constitutive of causal structure. If one were to define causation in terms of temporal asymmetry, time would then be explanatorily prior to causal power, not inert.

Either way, the alleged problem for temporal sensing evaporates when we recall that nothing about definition (1) blocks lawful covariance between the internal states of a mechanism and objective temporal metrics. And definition (2) actually guarantees that causal processes unfold in time, hence any physical mechanism that undergoes causally ordered change is, in effect, already trafficking with temporality.

III. Representation without direct causal influence  

A classic illustration is the use of inertial guidance systems in spacecraft. Once a gyroscope is spun up, its axis maintains orientation relative to an inertial frame, thereby providing information about spatial orientation for many hours without ongoing causal input from distant stars or planets. All that is required is a law of nature ensuring systematic covariance between gyroscope orientation and the relevant inertial coordinate system. The stars do not continuously stream photons into the gyroscope; yet the device uncontroversially “senses” its attitude in space. Likewise, a dosimeter badge can store total radiation exposure for months prior to being read; during storage no ionizing radiation need be present. The badge’s internal microstructure simply evolves in a way that covaries predictably with exposure history.

These examples undermine premise P1. What matters to information is not that the property represented currently pushes on the mechanism but that there exist lawlike, counterfactual‐subjunctive dependencies between the two: had the external parameter varied, so would have the state of the mechanism.

An adequate philosophical account of representation must therefore distinguish:

(i) Sampling detection—episodes where the magnitude produces an immediate energetic impact.  
(ii) Derived representation—states that stand in nomic equivalence to the magnitude even absent further inpacts.

The second is sufficient for carrying information and is routinely exploited in science, engineering, and—as we shall see—biology.

IV. How a clock carries information about time  

Consider a simple pendulum clock. What features endow the displacement of its hands with information about elapsed time t?

1. A stable periodic process. For small amplitudes the pendulum’s period T ≈ 2π√(l/g), nearly independent of mass and only minimally sensitive to amplitude. Thus its oscillations furnish a sequence of evenly spaced events E₁, E₂, E₃ … .  
2. A counting mechanism. An escapement translates each oscillation into an angular increment of the gear train; the gears integrate oscillations to produce slower rotations of the minute and hour hands.  
3. Calibration. By adjusting pendulum length l one can set the ratio between mechanical counts and conventional temporal units (seconds, minutes, hours).  
4. Lawful covariance. Because Newtonian dynamics guarantee near‐constant T under normal operating conditions, there is a nomic biconditional: for any n, the pointer’s having advanced n detents lawfully implies that approximately n∙T seconds have elapsed since some origin event (often the last reset).  

The covariation is robust under a wide range of counterfactual perturbations: had the elapsed time been longer, the hand position would have advanced farther (barring breakdown). Conversely, had the clock been observed to be farther advanced, one could correctly infer a longer elapsed time. That is exactly the kind of counterfactual support philosophers such as Woodward emphasize when analyzing causal‐informational content.

Does time act causally on the clock? No. What does the causal work are gravitational forces, tension in the drive spring, friction, and so on. Yet the system’s behavior is described by differential equations whose independent variable is t. The causal powers of gravity, elasticity, and inertia guarantee that the physical state of the pendulum at instant t + T depends in a rule‐governed way on its state at instant t. By building gear ratios that count these state transitions we turn a dynamical symmetry into a ready‐made measurement scale. The upshot:

A mechanism can embody information about time simply by undergoing causal change with temporally regular structure; “time itself” need not flow into the mechanism as an extra causal agent.

V. Bridging to biological time sensing  

Human and animal timing systems exploit the very same principle. Models of the circadian clock in mammals highlight a transcription‐translation feedback loop (TTFL) whose chemical concentrations oscillate with ~24 h periodicity. Light input via retinal melanopsin entrains the loop to the external day–night cycle, but once entrained, the loop free‐runs in constant darkness. Just as the pendulum’s period is guaranteed by gravitational acceleration and pendular length, the circadian TTFL’s period is guaranteed by the kinetics of gene expression, protein dimerization, and phosphorylation. No causal force emanating from “time itself” is required; the internal biochemistry does the causal work while a lawlike covariance between phase angle in the cycle and elapsed hours grounds informational content.

Similarly, humans performing interval timing in the seconds‐to‐minutes range appear to rely on cortical‐striatal oscillatory networks. Competing neural oscillator models, pacemaker–accumulator models, and state‐dependent network models disagree on micro‐implementation, yet all posit: (i) an endogenous process that changes state monotonically with elapsed duration; (ii) a readout mechanism that compares current state to stored criteria. The process is causal through and through—neuronal spiking, synaptic plasticity, neurotransmitter diffusion. Yet because its trajectory through state‐space correlates predictably with objective duration, it carries the requisite temporal information.

Hence there is no distinctive metaphysical barrier to a sense of time. What we have are “internal sensors” whose informational source is reliable endogenous dynamics that lawfully map onto durations.

VI. Worries and replies  

Objection A: The covariance exploited by clocks is merely conventional. We choose to call one gear position “3 o’clock,” but that could be reinterpreted; so the device does not genuinely stand in an objective relation to time.

Reply. Conventions fix units and reference points, not the underlying lawlike mapping. That mapping is as objective as the pendulum’s period. If a geology lab calibrates a radiometric decay clock by conventionally declaring 50% parent abundance to signify one half‐life, the convention does not underwrite the information; it merely labels the variable. The fact remains that parent/daughter ratio equals 1/2 just in case t ≈ τ½, independent of human stipulation.

Objection B: The clock is sensing change, not time; it merely counts causal events.

Reply. In practice, measuring many physical magnitudes requires transducing auxiliary variables. A mercury thermometer senses the expansion of a column, not temperature directly; but since thermal expansion coefficient α is lawfully tied to mean kinetic energy, expansion represents temperature. By parity, a pendulum senses successive swings, but because the period is lawfully fixed at T, counting swings represents elapsed duration. There is no principled requirement that a sensor access a magnitude “directly” rather than through a reliable causal intermediary.

Objection C: Clocks cannot detect absolute simultaneity or direction of time’s arrow; hence they do not sense time in the robust metaphysical sense sometimes demanded by philosophers.

Reply. Vision is blind to many optical features (e.g., absolute phases of EM waves beyond certain frequencies); olfaction cannot discriminate arbitrarily similar stereoisomers. A sensory system may be limited in resolution or scope yet still count as sensory. What matters is that it extract useful, law‐governed information from the environment. Clocks meet that standard for duration, periodicity and—when coupled appropriately—order of events. So the objection sets an implausibly strong criterion no actual sense modality meets.

VII. Reconciling measurement theory and metaphysics of time  

A deeper worry lurks beneath the original objection: If we treat time as merely a parameter in physical laws, do we risk reducing “sensing time” to “sensing whatever internal dynamics instantiate the laws”? That would dissolve the topic under discussion rather than answer it.

The right response is to invoke what Saunders and Pooley (following Weyl) call relationalism about temporal metric structure: physical systems instantiate relations of simultaneity and duration; clocks are devices whose internal degrees of freedom track those relations because the same laws apply inside and outside the device. Under relationalism, there is no need for a separate temporal substance to transmit causal influence. Instead, laws couple all physical events into a single four‐dimensional manifold. To sense time is to exploit local lawful regularities that faithfully mirror that manifold’s metrical structure—very much as sensing space exploits local cues (parallax, optic flow) that covary with spatial relations without presupposing a Newtonian absolute space pushing on the retina.

Thus one can conceptually reconcile three claims:

1. Time is not a causal agent; it is structural or relational.  
2. Physical processes necessarily unfold with temporal metrics determined by dynamical laws.  
3. Devices that are themselves dynamical processes can read out aspects of those metrics.

Combine 1–3 and the existence of temporal sensing devices is no mystery.

VIII. Conclusion  

The objection that no genuine sense of time is possible because time is causally impotent trades on a narrow, energy‐impact picture of sensing. Once we adopt a more general account of information—one that focuses on lawlike covariance and counterfactual‐supporting regularities—the path is clear. A clock, biological or artefactual, functions by:

a) Embodying an internal causal process with reliably stable dynamics.  
b) Translating the state of that process into a readable variable.  
c) Exhibiting a robust nomic correlation between that readable state and objective temporal quantities such as duration or phase.

Time does not push on the mechanism; rather, the mechanism’s own causal evolution unfolds within the temporal order that physics describes, thereby mirroring that order. The same holds for neural timing circuits, circadian rhythms, and perhaps the speculative “sense of passage” invoked in some phenomenological traditions. The philosophical moral is that representation is grounded in lawful dependence, not in direct energetic inheritance from the represented magnitude. With that clarified, the purported impossibility of a temporal sensory system dissolves. Clocks—and the brain’s indigenous chronometers—are perfectly real sensors of time.

Is there anything it is like to see, hear, or otherwise sense time?  Most of us have a vivid phenomenology of duration—we feel impatience while an elevator ascends, we know a song is “about three minutes long,” and we can tap a rhythm without looking at a watch.  Yet a standard objection insists that, whatever this phenomenology amounts to, it cannot rest on a bona fide sensory system.  The objection is simple:

1. A genuine sense is a causal interface: light waves impinge on retinal photoreceptors, airborne pressure waves jostle hair cells in the cochlea, tastants bind to receptors on the tongue, and so on.  
2. Time, unlike photons or molecules, is causally inert; it exerts no force or pressure on anything.  
3. Therefore there can be no sense whose specific environmental stimulus is time, and any mechanism—inner clock, circadian pacemaker, cerebellar interval-timer, artificial wristwatch—that appears to “detect” time must be doing something else, such as simply measuring the accumulation of internal change.

Call this the Causal Impotence Argument.  In what follows I sketch a reply that preserves both the causal requirement on sensory systems and the intuitive thought that clock-like mechanisms genuinely carry information about time.  The response has three parts.

Part I clarifies what it means for a mechanism to “carry information” and shows that causal mediation by the represented property is not always required; covariance under a lawful regularity is enough.  

Part II uses homely examples—thermometers, speedometers, and ordinary motion detectors—to defuse the idea that environmental properties must themselves be forces to be sensed.  

Part III explains how artificial and biological clocks exploit lawful regularities in periodic physical processes to achieve lawful covariance with temporal intervals.  The result is that time can be sensed, not because time pushes on the sensor, but because the sensor is so built that some of its states systematically co-vary with objective temporal facts.  

I.  Information without direct causal impact  

A convenient semantic framework is Fred Dretske’s (1981) notion of natural information.  A token state S of some mechanism carries the information that P just in case (i) S and P are linked by a reliable, law-like dependence and (ii) in normal conditions S would not occur unless P were true.  The moon’s high tide carries the information that the moon is near zenith, the rustle in the grass carries the information that something moved, and so on.  Crucially, P need not itself causally act on S; what matters is lawful co-variance sustained by deeper causal structures.

Suppose my car’s speedometer reads 50 mph.  Under proper calibration this reading is caused by rotation of the wheels and gearing, which in turn is caused by the car’s motion through space.  The property “having a speed of 50 mph” is not some mysterious fluid that presses on the dial; rather, that property supervenes on, and is law-fully correlated with, a pattern of motion that does all the causal work.  Even the staunchest critic of a sense of time grants that sensing speed in this way is unproblematic.

If lawful covariance suffices for informational content, then any mechanism that reliably evolves through a sequence of states whose number (or phase relation) stands in a strict, well-understood ratio to elapsed time will generate states that carry information about time—even though nothing corresponding to “time itself” tickles the sensor.

II.  Analogy with thermometers and other non-force detectors  

Temperature is the paradigm of a causally derivative property.  Temperature is not a basic causal agent; it is a statistical measure of molecular kinetic energy.  Yet we unhesitatingly say that thermometers “sense temperature.”  The salient causal relation is that molecular agitation causes mercury to expand; because average kinetic energy co-varies lawfully with that agitation, the thermometer state carries information about temperature.  No one demands a special caloric particle that pushes on the mercury.

The same point generalizes:

•  Magnetic compasses indicate direction because the needle aligns with the Earth’s magnetic field, not because “northness” exerts a force.  

•  Accelerometers tell us about acceleration because of inertial drag on a mass, not because “acceleration” itself pushes.  

•  pH meters register acidity through electrochemical potentials, not via some ethereal “acidity field.”  

All of these devices detect worldly magnitudes that are themselves abstract relational parameters.  They succeed by embedding a causal chain in which some more basic, causally active process varies systematically with the property of interest.

If temperature, acceleration, and acidity can be sensed without those magnitudes’ being primitive forces, there is no a priori bar to sensing time.

III.  How clocks lawfully co-vary with time  

A.  Periodic physical processes as natural yardsticks  

Physics is replete with processes that are (approximately) periodic under a wide range of conditions: pendulum swings, quartz crystal oscillations, cesium-133 atomic transitions, neuronal gamma cycles, circadian gene-protein feedback loops.  Each period is governed by physical laws that relate the cycle length to other parameters (pendulum length, crystal lattice structure, atomic energy gaps, biochemical degradation rates).  Because these period laws are stable, one can build a mechanism that counts cycles, thereby generating a state whose cardinality is (within tolerance) proportional to elapsed time.  The causal influences at play are gravity, electromagnetic forces, weak nuclear forces, chemical affinities, etc.—familiar muscular causal agents.  Time never pushes, but the lawful regularity guarantees covariance.

B.  The generic architecture of a clock  

1.  An oscillator whose internal dynamics settle into a stable closed trajectory with period τ.  
2.  A counter that changes state once per oscillatory cycle.  
3.  A read-out that maps counter states onto magnitudes (seconds, hours, circadian phase).  

Suppose the oscillator is a quartz crystal tuned to 32,768 Hz.  Given stable temperature, its period is 30.5 μs.  After N cycles the counter is in state sN.  Under normal conditions, the proposition “the crystal has completed N cycles” is true if and only if “approximately N·30.5 μs of objective time have elapsed since reset.”  By Dretske’s criterion, sN carries the information that that much time has passed.  Notice: what causes the crystal to shear and rebound are electric fields; what constrains the fields is the lattice structure; nowhere does “time” enter the causal equations as a forcing term.  Yet the clock state is a bona fide informational marker of elapsed time.

C.  Biological implementation  

Brains and bodies likewise exploit lawful periodicities.  The mammalian circadian clock relies on transcription-translation feedback loops (CLOCK-BMAL / PER-CRY genes).  Light pulses entrain these loops, but once entrained the oscillation free-runs at roughly 24 h.  A neuron downstream of the suprachiasmatic nucleus can therefore treat the phase of the oscillation as information about time-of-day.  The causal chain runs: gene expression → protein concentration → neuronal firing → hormonal regulation.  Time, as such, is nowhere a causal intermediary; yet the organism reliably behaves in sync with astronomical day.  If that does not count as sensing time, it is hard to see why sensing temperature counts.

D.  Error, calibration, and the marks of genuine sensing  

Senses can mislead: the eye can see illusions, the cochlea can mis-code pitch under masking, and the clock can run slow.  The very possibility of systematic error is taken by philosophical tradition (from Gareth Evans through Ruth Millikan) as evidence for representational content.  Biological and artifactual clocks exhibit these hallmarks.  They drift, accumulate phase error, and require re-setting.  Such normative notions—accuracy, calibration—apply naturally, precisely because the devices are supposed to stand in a truth-conditioned relation to elapsed time.  A difference of two seconds between wristwatch and atomic time is an error because the watch represents itself as matching, but fails.  That kind of normativity sits uneasily with mechanisms that merely regulate internal change without purporting to track an external magnitude.  The fact that clocks can be right or wrong thus supports the claim that they really do represent time.

IV.  Replies to lingering worries  

1.  “All you have shown is correlation, not sensing.”  
   Response:  On any plausible naturalistic theory of sensory content, lawful correlation underwrites sensing.  The retina does not latch onto “redness”; it latches onto spectral power distributions that, after neural processing, co-vary with surface reflectance.  Clocks fit precisely this pattern.

2.  “But in the visual case the causal chain begins in the stimulus: light literally strikes the photopigment.  In the clock, nothing external impinges once it is set running.”  
   Response:  Even visual perception of a stable scene continues after the lights are off for several hundred milliseconds thanks to iconic memory; similarly, the circadian clock free-runs after sunset.  More importantly, many accepted senses rely partly on self-generated energy: bats emit sonar cries to hear echoes; electric fish sense perturbations in their own electric field.  Emitted-energy sensing shows that “incoming energy from the target property” is not a strict requirement.

3.  “Time measurement is mere inference, not sensation.”  
   Response:  The inference/sensation line is blurry.  Vision from retinal image to depth perception involves massive inference, yet we count it as perception so long as part of the process is informationally dedicated to the property.  Clocks, and neural timing circuits, contain circuitry whose proper function is precisely to track duration; they are not general-purpose reasoners.

4.  “Representing time threatens to reify time as something over and above change.”  
   Response:  The account offered is compatible with both A-theory and B-theory of time, and with relationism or substantivalism.  All that is needed is objective ordering of events and metric relations among intervals, however metaphysically grounded.  If the metric facts supervene on change, then clocks indirectly track those facts through the changes they themselves undergo.

V.  Conclusion  

A sensory system does not need to be bombarded by a proprietary stuff.  What it needs is to be embedded in a causal nexus whose states lawfully co-vary with a feature of the environment in a way that can ground normative notions of accuracy and error.  Time is indeed special; it is the dimension in which causal processes themselves unfold.  But precisely because every causal process unfolds in time, there exist processes whose regularities can be harnessed to stand as reliable surrogates of elapsed duration.  Pendulums, quartz oscillators, atomic transitions, and gene-protein loops do the causal work; the resulting states carry information about time by lawful covariance.  Hence the causal impotence of time itself poses no barrier to the existence of genuine temporal sensing.  Clocks—both in machines and in brains—show how one can sense time without time’s ever having to push back.

1. Introduction: stating the problem

If what makes a bodily structure a sensory organ is that it is selectively sensitive to some distal feature—light, chemicals, pressure—through direct causal interaction, then the prospect of a “sense of time” looks dim. Time, considered abstractly, is not a substance that strikes the skin or a particle that can be absorbed; it appears “causally impotent.” Consequently, so the objection runs, there cannot be a genuine sensory system for time, nor can a mechanism such as a clock literally carry information about time. Yet we do treat clocks as devices that deliver temporal information and we speak without hesitation of animals, including ourselves, as having temporal perception. How are these judgments to be reconciled with the causal‐impotence objection?

I shall argue that the objection mistakes both what is required for representation and how causal mediation works in temporal measurement. A sensory or measuring system need not be acted on by the represented property itself; it is enough that the system exploits a reliable law‐like correlation between its internal state and the represented magnitude. That correlation is grounded in causal processes, though not in causal influence “from time as such.” After distinguishing three ways in which physical systems can carry information, I show how clock mechanisms, biological and artificial, fit the second pattern. I then defend this account against two residual worries: (i) that it renders time “merely inferred” rather than perceived, and (ii) that it illicitly smuggles in the very temporal facts it is supposed to explain. Throughout, I draw on recent work in philosophy of mind (Dretske, Millikan, Shea), philosophy of physics (Rovelli, Maudlin), and the cognitive science of timing.

2. Three routes to representation

Begin with a broad characterisation. A physical state S of a system R represents some environmental magnitude M just in case (i) there is a dependable dependence between M and S, and (ii) the system is organised so that exploiting that dependence furthers its proper function, biological or artefactual. The dependence may arise in three distinct ways.

   a. Direct causal impingement: M itself causally affects S. Photons of wavelength 550 nm striking a photoreceptor cause a cascade that ends in a neural state encoding “green.”

   b. Law‐grounded correlation: S is lawfully dependent on some causal process P whose parameters are law‐fixed functions of M, even though M does not itself act as a local cause. Barometers register atmospheric pressure because the height of a mercury column is fixed by the ideal‐gas law plus gravity; pressure is not a separate “agent” pushing on the mercury, yet the reading tracks it.

   c. Inference: S is reached through computations that use other internally represented magnitudes causally derived from the environment. When I conclude that tomorrow is Tuesday, the relevant information is obtained inferentially from a calendar, not directly from the future’s impinging on me.

The causal‐impotence objection would undermine only route (a). If temporal representation fits route (b), the objection fails.

3. Time’s supposed causal impotency

Why think time cannot cause? Two different claims often get run together.

   i. Metaphysical: Time (like space) is a structural feature, not a substance with causal powers. One event’s occurring at t₁ rather than t₂ does not seize the mechanism by metaphysical “temporal hands.”

   ii. Physical: Fundamental laws are time‐symmetric or at least do not treat “the passage of time” as a force term. So nothing exerts a force labeled “time.”

Even if both claims are granted, they do not entail that no physical process can bear a systematic, law‐governed relation to elapsed time. Pendula swing, radioactive isotopes decay, quartz crystals oscillate, and neuronal pacemakers fire rhythmically. The period of these processes is fixed by parameters (length of pendulum, decay constant, lattice elasticity, membrane currents) that remain roughly constant under ordinary conditions. Hence there is a crucial covariation: count of cycles ↔ elapsed time. The covariation is itself sustained by causal interactions—gravitational pull on the bob, electromagnetic interactions among atoms, ion flows across membranes. The laws guarantee that if n cycles have occurred, ∆t ≈ nτ. So temporal representation belongs to category (b).

4. The barometer analogy expanded

The barometer’s mercury column does not rise because “pressure pushes on it” in the sense of an external agent. What causes the column height to vary are molecular collisions inside the evacuated tube, directed by the ambient conditions that define pressure. The same holds mutatis mutandis for temporal measurement. A quartz watch’s resonator flexes because of piezoelectric forces; those forces depend on crystal lattice spacing, not on “time flowing.” Yet because the lattice forces and the mass density together determine a resonant frequency f, counting 32 768 oscillations secures one second of elapsed time. The watch, therefore, lawfully correlates an internal count with an external magnitude. Information is present not because time causes each oscillation but because the oscillations instantiate a physical regularity tethered to temporal intervals.

Notice two clarifications.

   1. What carries the information is the count, not a single oscillation. Information is accumulated across cycles; only then can the internal state S (register reading “1 s”) be taken as about M (elapsed time).

   2. The correlation can break down if constants drift (thermal expansion, fatigue). Hence proper operation conditions matter, exactly as with vision (normal lighting, unobstructed line of sight). That does not impugn the modality.

5. Biological timing systems

Does the same story apply to living organisms? Decades of neurobiology suggest yes. There are at least three partial, overlapping timing systems in vertebrates:

   a. Circadian: gene–protein feedback loops in suprachiasmatic nucleus neurons yield quasi‐autonomous ∼24 h oscillations, entrainable by light cues but persisting in constant darkness.

   b. Interval timers (millisecond to minutes): cortico‐striatal and cerebellar circuits employ ramping activity or sequential state changes governing behaviour such as song production or eye‐blink conditioning.

   c. Beat‐based entrainment: auditory–motor networks lock onto rhythmic regularities, enabling dancing and synchronisation.

In all cases, the tracked “time” is not an external agent; it is, instead, the number of completed cycles or the integral of ramping potentials. Natural selection (the historical producer) has shaped these circuits so that their internal states stand ready to guide behaviour in proportion to ecologically critical temporal quantities—sunrise, prey approach duration, predator gap timing. On teleosemantic accounts, that historical fact is sufficient for genuine representation. The circuits are, biologically speaking, time detectors.

6. Why the indirectness is not disqualifying

Someone might protest: “But then a clock only registers change; time itself remains offstage. Aren’t we reducing temporal perception to mere detection of motion or oscillation?” The worry conflates the constitution of the signal with the content carried. The Morse code dash is constituted by a certain duration of key closure; yet it signifies the letter “T,” not merely “a key closed for 300 ms.” Similarly, an oscillatory count’s being implemented by quartz flexion does not prevent it from signifying one second. What grounds that content is:

   i. The law‐like mapping: under normal conditions, S takes value k if and only if ∆t = kτ.

   ii. The functional role: downstream systems (gears in a watch, motor plans in an animal) use S to coordinate temporally sensitive action: meeting a train, intercepting prey.

   iii. The historical etiology: the mechanism was built or selected because exploiting that mapping confers advantage.

These three jointly satisfy prevailing theories (informational, functional, teleological) of mental and artifactual representation.

7. The threat of circularity

Another objection holds that invoking “∆t” in the laws underlying the mechanism covertly presupposes time, hence cannot explain representation of time without circularity. Consider, however, the difference between (a) a physical theory that contains temporal parameters and (b) a particular cognitive or mechanical system whose states stand in correspondence with those parameters. Physics need not justify the concept of time; rather, it provides criteria for when two events are temporally separated by τ. The clock designer or biological lineage then uses that fact to fashion a marker of that same τ. No circle arises: temporal quantity enters at the explanatory level of physics; the semantics of the representing device is a further, non‐trivial mapping that exploits the quantity.

The same maneuver is uncontentious for spatial perception. A retinal disparity of δ degrees lawfully covaries with object depth d given normal eye geometry; yet we do not fear circularity in saying that the disparity signals depth even though optics already counts distances. The temporal case is entirely parallel.

8. Temporal perception versus mere timing

Still, is timing tantamount to perceiving? Suppose a tiger lily turns toward the sun by harnessing phototropism. We do not credit it with “seeing.” One might analogise: clocks time intervals but do not “sense time.” To evaluate, recall two criteria often proposed for genuine sensation:

   a. Flexible use: The information can guide multiple behaviours, not merely trigger a fixed response.

   b. Phenomenological availability: For conscious organisms, the information is accessible for report and integration.

Many biological timing systems pass (a): circadian phase controls sleep, hormone release, and body temperature; rodents use interval timing both to seek food and to avoid predators. Humans pass (b) as well: we explicitly judge that “ten seconds have passed,” adjust speech rhythm, imagine future times. Thus while some subpersonal timers may be sub‐sensorial, the broader capacity, especially in humans, qualifies as a sense—albeit an interoceptive one.

9. Lessons from information theory

Claude Shannon defined information as reduction in uncertainty about a variable. A system acquires information about M whenever its states vary in ways that are statistically dependent on M. Crucially, nothing in Shannon’s definition requires causal action by M upon S. Instead, causal dependence anywhere in the chain is sufficient to underwrite the correlation. Time keeping amply satisfies that requirement: the quartz or neuronal oscillator is causally driven by internal physical forces whose frequency parameter is invariant, thereby entangling count states with elapsed time. Hence the putative causal impotency of time is irrelevant; what matters is robust covariance.

10. Bridging to philosophical theories of quality spaces

Some philosophers worry that because time lacks a proprietary sensory receptor array and qualia set, it cannot form a “quality space” analogous to hue or pitch. Yet recent work (C. Hoerl, T. Cheng) suggests that temporal phenomenology might be constructed from relations among change‐sensitive channels, yielding experienced duration via integration mechanisms. Even if that is correct, the present argument shows that those channels do deliver objective temporal information, so phenomenal temporality is not free‐floating construct but anchored in genuine temporal representation.

11. Summary of the response

The causal‐impotence objection collapses once we distinguish two questions.

   Q1. Must the represented magnitude F directly impinge causally on the representing system S?

   Q2. Must there be a lawful, exploitable correlation between F and S sustained by causal processes?

For sensory and measuring devices, the answer to Q1 is No; to Q2, Yes. Time meets Q2 through countless lawful regularities—decay rates, oscillatory modes, inertial motion. Clock mechanisms, biological or artisanal, exploit those regularities, earning the right to be called temporal sensors. What does the causal work is not “time flowing,” but the physical dynamics whose invariants define equal‐time intervals. Representation, on prevailing semantic theories, requires only that histories of use cement S as standing for F, not that F wiggle S by itself.

Therefore, the absence of a mysterious “temporal force” gives no ground for denying a sense of time. The objection trades on an overly narrow conception of sensory information and overlooks how representation by lawful correlation pervades both artefacts and biology. Far from being evidence against temporal perception, the very success of our clocks and of animal timing demonstrates how rich and ubiquitous such indirect representation can be.

12. Concluding reflection

Philosophers often seek sharp boundaries: sensation versus inference, causal versus merely correlational, primary versus secondary qualities. The case of temporal perception counsels a more pluralistic stance. Just as we hear pitch through the spacing of cochlear firings rather than through “pitch rays,” we perceive time by monitoring regular change, not by touching a temporal substance. Indirectness is neither epistemic vice nor metaphysical cheat; it is the essence of measurement. The world supplies robust structures—oscillations, decay constants, uniform motions—that mirror its own temporal geometry. Organisms and instrument makers, in turn, sculpt mechanisms that latch onto those mirrors. In doing so, they convert structural features that cannot literally push into streams of causal signals they can exploit. Time, though it exerts no force, thus becomes a perfectly respectable object of sensory representation.
