I. Introduction  

Each of the familiar human senses is routinely described as a causal doorway through which the world imprints itself on the nervous system.  Light strikes the retina, mechanical pressure deforms the cochlear hair cells, volatile chemicals bind with olfactory receptors, and so on.  Against this backdrop the idea of a “sense of time” can seem mysterious or even conceptually incoherent.  Time appears not to be a substance, a field, or a set of particles capable of bumping into sense organs.  Because it is alleged to be causally inert—nothing that exerts its own force—there seems to be no route by which temporal properties could influence a sensory transducer.  Consequently, one influential line of thought concludes that the most we can possess are higher-level cognitive estimates of duration or sequence, not a genuine sensory capacity on a par with sight or hearing.  

In what follows I argue that this inference is invalid.  Causal impotence, rightly understood, does not prevent a system from carrying information about time.  A sense modality never needs to be stamped by the very property it represents; it needs only to stand in the right kind of law-governed, counterfactual-supporting relation to that property.  Once this point is appreciated, the basic objection evaporates, and there is no barrier to treating specialized neural timing circuits—and, by extension, ordinary mechanical clocks—as genuine information-gatherers about the passage of time.  My strategy proceeds in four stages.  First, I clarify what is meant by “causal impotence” and why it mistakenly equates causal influence with representational eligibility.  Second, I turn to philosophical accounts of natural information (especially Dretske’s and more recent teleosemantic variants) that decouple representation from direct causal impact.  Third, I unpack how familiar clock mechanisms in fact exploit law-governed regularities to track temporal metrics without ever being impinged on by a special “temporal force.”  Finally I address a residual worry about calibration and circularity, showing how empirical systems bootstrap temporal information by locking onto other, causally efficacious periodic phenomena.  

II. Understanding the “Causal Impotence” Claim  

One might grant that time does not collide with sense organs yet still insist that all successful sensory representation requires immediate causal contact with the represented property.  Call this the Direct Causal Contact Thesis (DCCT).  For paradigmatic sense modalities DCCT is indeed satisfied: photons cause photoreceptor activation, air-pressure waves cause basilar-membrane displacement, and so forth.  However, DCCT is not a constitutive principle of sensory representation; rather it is an empirical generalization about several well-studied cases.  There is no conceptual guarantee that every modality must follow the same template.  

A closer look already reveals counter-examples.  The vestibular organ’s semicircular canals do not detect rotation by being buffeted by “rotation particles.”  Instead, acceleration of the head causes displacement of endolymph fluid, which in turn bends cilia.  The property represented—angular acceleration—is not identical with any of the forces applied to cilia; it is a more abstract kinematic magnitude systematically covaried with those forces.  Likewise, proprioceptive feedback from muscle spindles represents limb position even though what literally stimulates the sensory receptors are patterns of stretch, chemical gradients, and efferent copy signals.  In both cases the represented property is abstracted from, but not identical with, the immediate causal input.  These examples cast doubt on the claim that absence of direct temporal bombardment suffices to block temporal representation.  

III. Natural Information Without Direct Impact  

The operative notion of information in philosophical naturalism typically focuses on nomic covariance: state S in system A carries information about condition C in system B just in case there are law-like regularities guaranteeing that whenever C obtains S tends to occur, and that link supports appropriate counterfactuals (if C had not obtained, S would not have occurred).  Fred Dretske’s influential framework adds a channel condition: the link must be sufficiently reliable for S to function as a usable indicator.  In later teleosemantic developments (Millikan, Neander, Shea), what elevates mere covariance to genuine representation is the mechanism’s etiological function: it exists because, in the evolutionary or learning history of the organism, tokenings of S served to guide behavior in virtue of their correlation with C.  

None of these theories requires C to cause S directly.  It is enough that states of the representing system vary in a law-governed way with C, that users of the representation exploit this link, and that the link is not accidental.  A thermostat’s bimetallic strip represents temperature, but ambient temperature does not force any special “temperature particles” into the device.  Instead, ambient heat differentially expands the joined metals, a purely mechanical process; from these expansions the entire causal system is built.  Few would doubt that the bimetallic strip contains information about temperature despite the indirectness of the chain.  The same pattern, I contend, applies to time-keeping mechanisms.  

IV. How Clocks Track Time  

Let us examine a paradigmatic mechanical clock: a pendulum coupled to an escapement that advances gear teeth and ultimately rotates the hands on a dial.  The pendulum experiences gravitational acceleration g, and its period T approximates 2π√(L/g).  Gravity and the pendulum’s length thus fix a near-constant rhythm.  Crucially, no “temporal field” impinges on the bob.  Rather, intrinsic dynamical laws guarantee that the pendulum’s successive oscillations stand in a highly robust one-to-one relation with equal intervals of physical time.  By counting oscillations, the clock effectively counts seconds.  

We can describe the informational relation this way:

1. Law-likeness: Given the laws of classical mechanics plus boundary conditions (air resistance, friction tolerances, temperature stability), there is a nomic regularity between N oscillations of the pendulum and duration d ≈ N·T seconds.  

2. Counterfactual support: Had the clock been isolated from forces that appreciably alter L or g, the same mapping would have obtained; had the oscillations occurred faster (say, by shortening L), fewer seconds would have passed.  

3. Availability for use: The gear train harnesses each oscillation, transduces it to hand movement, and thereby zeros in on the magnitude “elapsed time since t0.”  An observer who can read the dial is thus in a position to coordinate actions (commute, bake bread, fire a cannon) with regular temporal intervals.  

Notice that nothing in this story violates the causal impotence of time.  What causally drives the mechanism are gravity, inertia, and mechanical constraints.  Nevertheless, because the pattern of events in the device is fixed by physical laws that also determine how physical time is realized in unfolding change, the device’s states reliably covary with objective temporal intervals.  We may put this more compactly: the clock exploits a lawful regularity, not a causal influence, to mirror the structure of time.  

V. Internal Biological Clocks  

Skeptics may grant that mechanical artifacts can instantiate a lawful mirror of time while still resisting the idea that organisms could enjoy a sensation of time, because sensations seem to require transduction pathways feeding into the brain.  Yet vertebrates and invertebrates alike possess a panoply of endogenous oscillators—including circadian gene-protein feedback loops, striatal beat-frequency networks, and cerebellar micro-complexes—that operate on exactly the same principle.  At the cellular level, recurring phosphorylation cycles maintain a roughly 24-hour rhythm; at the systems level, patterns of corticostriatal spiking maintain millisecond-to-second intervals.  These dynamics are not pushed around by an external temporal field; rather, they are self-sustaining oscillations whose frequency is determined by rate constants in biochemical reactions or by reverberatory neural circuitry.  Because those constants are stable (within evolutionary tolerances) across environmental contexts, the phase of an oscillator carries information about “hours since last dawn” or “milliseconds since start of movement.”  

Importantly, the animal can, and routinely does, use the current oscillator phase as an immediately accessible, modality-specific datum.  Migratory birds shift foraging behavior when internal clocks signal shortening day-length, rodents time lever presses in peak-interval tasks, and humans report subjective estimates of duration that manifest Weber-Law–like psychophysical properties characteristic of sensory magnitudes.  Each of these behaviors is guided by neural activity patterns whose only lawful significance is elapsed time.  Thus, functionally and informationally, there is no bright boundary separating vision or audition from biological chronoperception.  

VI. Replies to Residual Worries  

1.  Calibration dependence.  Some critics note that pendulums must be cut to exactly the right length, atomic clocks tuned to a transition frequency, and circadian oscillators entrained by photic input.  Does this not concede that time information must ultimately come from an extrinsic, causally efficacious source (sunlight, atomic spectral lines), thereby reinstating DCCT?  

Not quite.  Calibration is a ubiquitous feature of sensing, but it does not thereby annul representational status when the stimulus property is absent.  A camera must be focused, a microphone equalized, a chemotaxis receptor up- or down-regulated.  Once properly calibrated, the device autonomously tracks its target property.  Likewise, after a pendulum’s length L is cut, its period becomes an internal clocking parameter, not something re-imposed moment by moment from outside.  Circadian entrainment offers an instructive parallel.  Day-night photic cycles “nudge” the phase each morning, but the mutual inhibition loops of clock genes free-run with a near-24-hour period in constant darkness.  For days or weeks, the organism’s suprachiasmatic nuclei will continue to indicate approximate local time even absent light.  Thus, post-calibration independence is preserved, showing that the causal role of light (or any other environmental cue) is ultimately enabling rather than constitutive of temporal representation.  

2.  Circularity.  One might worry that our whole evidential basis for which physical processes covary with time itself relies on prior clock-based measurement, leading to vicious circularity.  However, the concern misconstrues how scientific confirmation proceeds.  We validate candidate oscillators not by assuming they already tell time but by experimentally demonstrating stable frequency relations across diverse conditions, cross-checking them against independent processes (radioactive decay, Earth’s rotation, hyperfine transitions).  Convergence, not circular presupposition, underwrites our confidence.  Consequently, the lawful link between oscillator phase and duration is an empirical discovery, not an analytic stipulation, and the representation relation piggybacks on that empirical regularity.  

3.  Proximal phenomenology.  Perhaps the most stubborn mentalistic objection is that internal clock signals do not feel like sensations in the way colors or pitches do.  But even here the gap is partly illusory.  Many temporal experiences are vivid: the pressing slowness of an interminable speech, the staccato rush of rapid-fire percussion, the syncopated beat we tap with a finger.  Psychophysical studies show that temporal order, interval size, and rhythmic grouping have just‐noticeable-difference functions and adaptation effects akin to those in the classic senses.  Admittedly, our temporal percepts are more global and amodal than those arising from dedicated peripheral organs, but they need not be less sensory for that.  Interoception, proprioception, and vestibular balance likewise lack external organs yet are unanimously classified as senses.  The lesson is that sensory status depends on functional role and representational profile, not on whether one can point to a discrete anatomical receptor.  

VII. Lessons for Metaphysics of Time  

There is a larger metaphysical upshot.  The informational success of clocks vindicates a relational conception of temporal properties.  Time is not a sui generis force; it is the structural parameter abstracted from change.  Any stable, periodic process instantiates that structure and thereby becomes a concrete surrogate for time’s passage.  Representation piggybacks on these surrogates: to track time is to track orderly change in things whose dynamics conform to known laws.  This insight meshes nicely with the “minimalist” or “deflationary” theories of temporal passage advanced by philosophers such as Le Poidevin, Dainton, and Callender.  They emphasize that nothing over and above physical events and their relations need be added to account for temporal experience or time measurement.  

VIII. Conclusion  

The objection from causal impotence rests on an overly restrictive picture of what it takes to carry information.  While it is true that no “time particles” shower our sensors, sensory representation in general need not involve being literally struck by the represented property.  What matters are reliable, law-grounded correlations that organisms or devices can exploit for control and prediction.  Both mechanical clocks and biological timing circuits satisfy those conditions.  Their internal states stand in robust, counterfactually supporting relations to objective temporal magnitudes even though the only local causes are oscillatory dynamics, biochemical feedback, or physical forces like gravity and electromagnetism.  

Consequently, there is no conceptual bar to recognizing a sense of time.  Doing so merely requires extending familiar informational and functional criteria from vision and audition to endogenous oscillatory mechanisms.  Once the mistaken equation of causal impact with representational eligibility is abandoned, the mystery dissolves: clocks—and, arguably, human temporal perception—do not need to be pushed around by time; they need only mirror its patterns through lawful change.  Thus the classical objection is defused, and the philosophical pathway is cleared for a positive, scientifically grounded theory of temporal sensation.

Is there, or could there be, anything like a genuine “sense of time”?  A familiar sceptical argument says no.  All bona-fide sensory systems, the story goes, work by being causally struck by the relevant features of the environment: photons hit the retina, molecules bind to olfactory receptors, pressure deforms the cochlea.  But time itself is rarely taken to be the sort of thing that knocks into receptors.  It is, as Newton put it, “that which flows equably of itself,” causally impotent, on a par with the spatial background.  Hence—concludes the sceptic—there can be no sensory system for time.  Elaborate as the objection sounds, it rests on two assumptions that can be resisted:

1.  A sensory system must be causally impinged upon by the very property it represents.  
2.  Time, being causally impotent, cannot engage in such impingement.

I shall argue that assumption (1) is overly restrictive once we adopt contemporary information-theoretic accounts of representation, and that once (1) is rejected the second premise loses its bite.  A clock—biological or artefactual—can carry information about temporal passage without being caused by time, because regular change lawfully correlated with elapsed time is enough for representation.  In what follows I first clarify what “causal influence” really amounts to, then distinguish several grades of “sensing,” and finally show in detail how a clock mechanism, even in a universe in which time exerts no forces, can nevertheless encode temporal information.

1.  Causation and Covariance  

The sceptical argument trades on an intuitive picture of perception familiar from passive-impression empiricism: perception is like wax taking the seal of a signet ring.  The ring presses, the wax yields, the imprint results.  We are therefore tempted to demand an analogous story for every representational system.  But this is too crude.  Contemporary naturalistic theories of mental and sensory content—whether Dretske’s information-theoretic view, teleosemantic approaches, or predictive coding models—have converged on the idea that what matters is reliable covariance under a (roughly) law-like relation, not whether the target property literally presses on the mechanism.  The mercury column in a thermometer is sensitive to ambient temperature by expanding; but the property “being 25°C” does not literally push the mercury up.  Rather, the microphysical behaviour of the molecules guarantees a neat correlation between mean kinetic energy (temperature) and macroscopic displacement of mercury.  Likewise a galvanometer “senses” charge flow, but the abstract quantity amperage is not a force in its own right.

Thus we already tolerate instruments that measure properties without being struck by those very properties, provided that background laws enforce reliable co-variation.  The question becomes: are there lawful correlations between elapsed time and some detectable physical variable?  If so, we have—according to the same standards we grant to thermometers and gauges—an information channel from the temporal fact to the state of the system.  No direct “force of time” need apply.

2.  What Kind of Thing Is Time?  

It helps to remember why time is labelled causally impotent.  On minimal manifold conceptions used in physics, time is a one-dimensional parameter ordering events.  It is not, by itself, an energy-bearing field.  Nevertheless, dynamical laws are explicitly time-relational: positions, charges, field strengths evolve as functions of t.  In Hamiltonian mechanics, for example, canonical coordinates q(t) and momenta p(t) satisfy dH/dt = –∂L/∂t.  Even if t does no causal work over and above the forces encoded in H, the laws guarantee that if an interval of duration Δt elapses, the system will have evolved in specifiable ways.  Temporal facts are therefore entangled with patterns of change; to exploit them one merely needs a subsystem whose behavior systematically correlates with those patterns.

Some philosophers, chiefly relationists, take this to show that “time is nothing over and above change.”  One need not sign up for full-blooded relationism to agree that change is an excellent, ever-present proxy for temporal facts.  To measure time we exploit change exhibiting a constant rate under the relevant laws: Cesium-133 oscillations, Earth’s rotation, or, in simpler organisms, damped biochemical cycles.  Representing time via change is entirely legitimate: you represent temperature via molecular motion, pressure via molecular collisions, sound via air vibration.

3.  Graded Senses and Functional Roles  

Even if the correlation route is granted, the sceptic might insist that a true sense, as opposed to a mere instrumental gauge, requires exogenous stimulation from outside the organism.  But nature is not always so tidy.  We have proprioception, hunger, and balance, all generally recognised as senses even though their primary causes are internal.  The vestibular system is triggered when we rotate, not by a distinct “rotation force.”  Indeed, acceleration in a rocket (kinematic, not environmental) stimulates the same organs that respond to gravity.  What unites senses is not externality but the availability of real-time, behaviour-guiding information.  On that functional standard, an endogenous clock qualifies.

One may press: proprioception still has a causal story—stretch receptors deform.  Fair enough; perhaps genuine sensing requires a dedicated transducer that converts some variable into neural spikes in real time.  But again, endogenous clocks can meet that criterion: certain hypothalamic neurons fire in a circadian rhythm due to transcription-translation feedback loops; others in the suprachiasmatic nucleus tick at roughly 24 h, resetting when light input reaches melanopsin retinal ganglion cells.  Molecular concentrations are the “stimulus,” light merely calibrates the phase.  The upshot is that the objection dissolves if we frame sensing in terms of ongoing lawful relations rather than unmediated causal pokes.

4.  Information Without Causal Push  

Let us turn to clocks.  Consider a simplistic mechanical escapement: a mass on a spring executes harmonic motion with angular frequency ω = √(k/m).  Because harmonic motion is periodic, state variables—displacement x and velocity v—trace a closed orbit in phase space.  Pick a salient event: the pendulum crossing the midpoint moving rightwards.  Under negligible damping and a fixed ω, the elapsed time between successive such events is τ = 2π/ω, a constant.  Suppose we add a ratchet each time the pendulum passes that point; each click advances a gear.  After n clicks the hand indicates nτ.  Crucially, no metaphysical fluid called “time” seeps into the gear.  The only causes are elastic restoring forces and inertial motion, yet we have a reliable mapping from clock state C(n) to elapsed temporal interval nτ.  By Dretskean lights, C(n) carries the information that time interval nτ has elapsed because (i) the probability that nτ elapsed given C(n) is high (ideally 1), and (ii) this conditional depends on a nomic, not accidental, connection.  That suffices for representation.

The situation is even clearer in the relativistic atomic clocks used in GPS satellites.  A hyperfine transition in Cesium-133 has an invariant frequency 9 192 631 770 Hz.  Quantum electrodynamics, plus relativity, explain that invariance.  The clock’s internal state after N transitions correlates with proper time along the satellite’s world-line, despite the fact that proper time is not a field applied to the clock.  What mediates the correlation is the structure of the Hamiltonian; it ensures identical atoms tick in lock-step.  Again, no mystery influence of time is needed.

5.  Could the Correlations Be Sheer Coincidence?  

A critic might object that mere correlation is not enough—there must be some counterfactual-supporting nexus guaranteeing that had the temporal interval been different, the clock would read differently.  Otherwise one could engineer a “dumb” tape labelled Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, feed the animal new sections each dawn, and declare it a time sense.  Fair point.  Fortunately laws of physics give us exactly the needed counterfactual support: had the pendulum run slower (because g changed), the indicated reading would have lagged; had Cesium’s hyperfine constant differed, the atomic clock would desynchronise.  The relevant dependency is modal, underwritten by the same microphysical forces that make photons red when the sun is low.  The tape-feeding device lacks that modal profile: its “read-out” is fixed by the conspiratorial engineer, not by laws linking internal state to the dimension measured.

Hence the information carried by a lawful clock is robust across relevant counterfactuals.  This robustness is why the Global Positioning System can correct for relativistic dilation: we trust that the clock hands diverge exactly as relativity predicts across hypothetical variations in gravitational potential.  If information requires modally-supported covariation, clocks possess it in abundance.

6.  Biological Time-Keeping  

One might still suspect that artifactual clocks are irrelevant to genuine sensing.  But biological research shows that virtually every organism owns intricate timing mechanisms.

a.  Circadian oscillators: In mammals, negative feedback loops involving the Clock, Bmal1, Per and Cry genes generate near-24-hour molecular oscillations.  Temperature-compensated kinetics ensure period stability.  Light from intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells shifts phase via glutamatergic input to the suprachiasmatic nucleus.  The causal story is again molecular collisions and gene expression; time never “presses.”

b.  Interval timers: Cerebellar Purkinje cells adapt firing pauses to intervals of 100–1000 ms when trained with air-puff stimuli.  Parallel fibres set up temporally decaying synaptic traces; the coincidence of trace level with climbing-fibre activity triggers a pause.  The mechanism amounts to a biochemical stopwatch.

c.  Developmental clocks: Somite segmentation in vertebrate embryos relies on the segmentation clock—cyclic expression of Notch, Wnt, and FGF pathways paced by ultradian oscillations.  Spatial pattern emerges by coupling oscillator phase to tissue elongation.

In each case organisms exploit dynamical regularities, not a proprietary “time particle,” thereby debunking the alleged indispensability of temporal causal influence.

7.  Does an Internal Clock Deliver a Phenomenology of Time?  

One final worry: even if there are physical clocks inside us, does that secure a phenomenal sense of time akin to vision or hearing?  Perhaps not; perhaps temporal experience is constructed cognitively from memory and prediction.  That debate is orthogonal to the causal objection.  The question at hand was whether it is coherent to posit a sensory system for time given causal impotence.  I have shown it is coherent when “sensory system” is cashed out in informational-functional terms.  Whether such mechanisms underwrite the subjective flow of time is a further, empirical matter.

Still, accumulating evidence suggests that cortical and subcortical circuits integrate signals from multiple oscillators and transient dynamics to yield duration judgements, temporal order perception, and synchronization abilities (e.g., the striatal beat-frequency model).  Lesions to dopaminergic pathways impair interval timing, which argues for genuine sensory-like input rather than pure inference from memory.  So current neuroscience lines up with the infosystem model defended here.

8.  Summing Up the Response  

The original objection rests on conflating two issues: (i) whether time exerts a sui generis physical force, and (ii) whether reliable causal chains can carry temporal information.  Once we see that information flows along lawful covariations, the need for a distinctive force disappears.  Clocks—mechanical, atomic, neural—do not wait to be poked by time itself; they are dynamical systems whose own evolution is isomorphic to the passage of time as codified in the laws of physics.  Because of that lawful isomorphism, their states indicate temporal facts with the same legitimacy that thermometer readings indicate temperature.  Therefore, denying the possibility of a “sense of time” on the ground that time is causally inert is a non sequitur.

Precisely what status such clocks have—sensory, proprioceptive, or cognitive—depends on how one draws taxonomy.  But the philosophical take-home is clear: from an information-theoretic and functional standpoint, a system can represent a property P if and only if there is a dependable, counterfactual-supporting mapping from variations in P to variations in some detectable variable of the system.  Time passes that test in virtue of the dynamical laws that govern everything.  So the sceptical argument, premised on a caricatured view of causal influence, fails.  A mature philosophy of perception should therefore welcome temporal representation among the legitimate denizens of our sensory repertoire.

Is There a Sense of Time?  
               Causal-Informational Accounts, Clock Mechanisms, and the “Causal Impotence” Worry



1. Framing the Objection  

A standard empiricist picture of perception says:  

    (i) A sense organ acquires information about an environmental magnitude M only if  
    (ii) instances of M exert a causal influence on that organ (photons on retinas, pressure waves on cochleae, etc.).  

Time, the objector claims, is not the right kind of thing to do causal work. Photons can jostle electrons, but “five seconds” can’t bump into anything. Therefore there is no genuine “sense of time,” only higher-order inference based on other, truly sensory, inputs.

At first glance the objection is forceful. If perception is, as Locke said, “the inbox of causal commerce with the world,” and time never enters that commerce, how could any mechanism be a sensor of time rather than a clever inferential engine operating on non-temporal inputs?

Below I argue that the objection trades on a too-narrow view of what it is for a state to carry information and on a too-strong conception of causal influence. I develop an information-theoretic reply inspired by Dretske, Ramsey-Lewis and recent philosophy of biology. The core insight is that a physical system can carry accurate, usable information about a magnitude M when its states covary with M in virtue of standing laws, even when M is not itself a local causal agent. In this sense a clock can qualify as a “sensor” of time even though time does not literally push its gears. The response proceeds in five steps.

2. Covariation versus Direct Causing  

Begin with a mundane measuring device: a mercury thermometer.  The reason the column’s height represents temperature is not that “temperature particles” bombard the glass. Rather, kinetic energy of molecules (statistically identical with temperature on many views) raises mercury’s average momentum; intermolecular forces then alter volume.  What drives the causal chain are micro-forces; “temperature,” a macroscopic parameter, never literally enters as an entity in the chain.  Yet no one denies that the thermometer senses temperature.

The moral: what matters for sensing is reliable nomic covariation, sustained by laws, between states of the detector and values of the magnitude.  Direct causal contact by the magnitude qua magnitude is unnecessary.  If that is true for temperature, pressure and magnetic field strength, it might also be true for temporal intervals.

3. Endogenous Dynamics as Time-Sensitive Correlates  

How, concretely, might a physical system covary with time?  The answer is: by undergoing processes whose dynamics are law-governed functions of elapsed time and little else.  The paradigms are:  

• Uniform motion of a pendulum’s center of mass (T ≈ 2π√(l/g))  
• Periodic cesium-133 hyperfine transitions (the SI second = 9 192 631 770 cycles)  
• Radioactive decay of carbon-14 (N(t) = N₀e^{-λt})  

None of these processes is “caused by time.”  They are caused by forces, potentials, quantum probabilities.  But the relevant variables—pendulum phase, phase of the microwave field in a cesium maser, remaining undecayed nuclei—stand in a simple, law-fixed functional relation to t.  Because of that relation, later parts of the process carry information about how much time has elapsed since an initial calibration event.  One can, in Shannon’s sense, decode states of the system into estimates of t with (in principle) arbitrarily low error.

So, a clock is a physical implementation of endogenous dynamics whose present state encodes a temporal parameter.  That is sufficient for informational access to time, even if time never “pushed” the mechanism.

4. Information without Impartation: The Dretske-Ramsey Account  

Fred Dretske’s seminal work on natural information defines a signal R carrying information that S if and only if P(S|R)=1 (or is lawfully high).  Importantly, Dretske insists that “carrying information that S” is not the same as “being caused by S.”  What is needed is nomic dependence: had S not obtained, R would not have either.  This counterfactual link can hold without S literally acting on R.

David Lewis’s Ramsey-Lewis functionalist strategy for theoretical terms supports the same verdict.  What it is to be “the clock signal for t” is just to be the occupant of a causal-nomological role: a state whose variations match the pattern of elapsed time and that is exploitable by the organism or instrument for temporal regulation (circadian rhythms, motor coordination, etc.).  Whether t itself is a force is irrelevant.

Thus, by an information-theoretic and functionalist standard, the causal impotence worry is misplaced.  It conflates the causal production of a representation with the causal production by the represented magnitude.  What is required is the former, not the latter.

5. Biological Timekeeping: Circadian Clocks as Natural Sensors  

Consider the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in mammals.  Cell populations in the SCN exhibit self-sustaining biochemical oscillations with a period of roughly 24 h.  The endogenous loop involves transcription factors CLOCK and BMAL1, negative feedback proteins PER and CRY, and interlocked redox cycles.  Light signals via melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells entrain the phase but are not the primary movers.  Importantly:

• After a phase-setting pulse, the SCN hums along in constant darkness;  
• Downstream tissues read SCN output to time hormone release, body temperature, gene expression.  

If we asked: “What causes the SCN to be in phase φ at noon?” the proximate causes are concentrations of PER/CRY, membrane potentials, ion currents.  Time itself never features.  Yet the correlation between φ and clock time is so robust that animals deprived of external cues still anticipate dawn.  On any reasonable teleosemantic account, SCN activity represents time of day; it earns that status by enabling adaptive behaviour that depends on when, not merely on light levels.

6. Disentangling Two Concepts of Causation  

The objector tacitly endorses an interventionist picture: X senses M only if wiggles in M (and nothing else) would produce wiggles in X under ideal isolation.  But most magnitudes we call sensed flout that test.  A thermometer’s height will not budge if we “intervene directly on temperature” while cancelling all molecular kinetic effects—because that description is incoherent.  Interventionism presupposes manipulability, but not every scientifically legitimate property is separately manipulable.

Better is James Woodward’s more liberal criterion: a variable X is causally dependent on Y when there is a set of interventions I on some background set B such that changing I changes Y and thereby changes X.  For clocks, interventions that alter elapsed time—accelerating or decelerating world-lines (special relativity), raising gravitational potential (general relativity)—do indeed change clock readings.  Experiments on fast-moving jets and mountain-top clocks confirm this.  So even under an interventionist gloss, clock states are causally sensitive to time-affecting operations, albeit indirectly.

7. The Metaphysics of Time and the Possibility of Influence  

A different way to puncture the objection is to deny its major premise: maybe time is not causally impotent.  In general relativity the metric field g_{μν} satisfies Einstein’s equations G_{μν}=8πT_{μν}.  Variations in the temporal component g_{00} affect geodesic structure, which in turn determines relative accelerations of massive bodies.  Gravitational time dilation literally changes decay rates and oscillator periods.  Here, “time” understood as proper time along a world-line does play a direct causal role: stretch the metric and you slow cesium oscillations.

One need not settle debates about substantival versus relational time to make the dialectical point: the objection assumes a metaphysics on which time is merely a parameter.  Physical theory gives us at least one respectable picture on which that assumption is false.  So the objection is not only weak on epistemology; it is also metaphysically contestable.

8. Objection Rebutted: A Synthetic Summary  

We can now reconstruct an answer in compact form:

(1) Sensory systems need not be struck by the very magnitude they detect; lawful covariation suffices.  
(2) There exist dynamical processes—oscillations, decay, inertial motion—whose state at t is a deterministic or probabilistic function of t.  
(3) A mechanism that entrains its behaviour to such a process thereby carries Shannon-information about t.  
(4) Organisms exploit these internal signals for adaptive temporal regulation; by teleosemantic standards, the states represent elapsed time.  
(5) Even on a causal-manipulation metric, clock readings vary appropriately under interventions that modulate proper time.  
(6) Therefore the absence of a sui generis “causal influence of time” is no bar to there being genuine temporal sensing.

9. Addressing Two Residual Worries  

Residual worry 1: “But an internal oscillator is not a ‘sense’ because it is not receptive; it is productive.” Reply: Many accepted senses mix exogenous and endogenous components.  The human vestibular system relies on inertial dynamics of endolymph; magnetotactic bacteria build internal magnetite rods that align with geomagnetic fields.  In neither case does the sensed magnitude enter as a discrete stimulus; rather, organism-internal structures are tuned to covary with the magnitude.  Endogeneity does not preclude sensory status.

Residual worry 2: “Clocks measure durations, not instants; representation of instants requires an arbitrary zero-point.”  True, but the same is so for thermometers (zero at ice-water equilibrium) and barometers.  What matters is the ability to specify intervals with precision; anchoring to a calendar date or sunrise is an additional, and biologically ubiquitous, act of calibration.

10. Philosophical Payoff: Revising the Theory of Sense Modalities  

The debate pushes us toward a more ecological, information-centric taxonomy of senses.  Instead of cataloguing modalities by type of distal stimulus (photon, phonon, etc.), we should classify them by the invariant they allow an organism to pick up for behavioural guidance.  Under that ecological banner, time perception sits comfortably alongside shape, affordance and motion perception: patterns in optic flow specify locomotor speed without speed “causing” retinal change; likewise patterns in internal oscillators specify duration without “time particles.”

11. Empirical Corroboration from Psychophysics  

Human psychophysics shows specialized temporal processing:

• Duration after-effects: adaptation to a 200-ms flash biases subsequent judgments, parallel to visual tilt after-effects—signature of dedicated neural channels.  
• Temporal bisection tasks yield Weber fractions (~0.15) that are constant across modalities, suggesting a centralized timing mechanism.  
• Cortical area SMA and basal ganglia have neurons firing at specific elapsed-time tuned peaks; optogenetic manipulations in rodents shift timing behaviour.

Such data fits the idea of neural circuits that, like physical clocks, generate internal dynamics whose phase encodes elapsed time.  No external causal shove from time is needed—only the lawful unfolding of biophysics.

12. Conclusion  

The “causal impotence of time” objection collapses once we recognize that sensing hinges on infosensitive covariance, not on being pelted by the target magnitude.  A clock, biological or mechanical, is a time-sensor because its evolving states lawfully track duration, can be calibrated, can be reset, and can be exploited by downstream systems to guide action.  The representational relation obtains through nomic dependency, teleological function and interventionist robustness, all without positing time as an occult causal agent.  Thus, contra the objection, a genuine—and indeed indispensable—sense of time is not only possible but actual, beating steadily in every pendulum, atom clock and circadian neuron.

1. Introduction: Why the “causal-impotence” objection matters  
Among the traditional five senses each has a clear physical channel that begins with a property that can literally act upon a transducer.  Photons strike photoreceptors; pressure waves buffet the cochlea; volatile molecules dock with olfactory cilia.  From this starting point an influential “causal” picture of sensing is born: we sense F-ness only when instantiations of F can causally impress themselves upon us.  If the property cannot write its own signature on a receptor, it cannot be sensed.  

That template, however, threatens to rule out any genuine sense of time.  Time, so the objection goes, is not the sort of entity that can collide with a receptor or push on a membrane.  If it is a dimension, an ordering relation or a parameter of dynamical laws, it does not “do” anything in the energetic, force-exerting sense.  Hence—conclusion—the putative internal clocks neuroscientists discuss are, strictly speaking, not sense organs at all; at best they are inferential devices or conceptual constructions that ride on the outputs of the bona fide senses.  

The objection is powerful because it trades on an apparently innocuous principle: information reaches a sensory system via causal influence.  My aim is to show that the principle is too restrictive, and that once we loosen it in the right way the path is open for a genuine informational link between clock-like mechanisms and the passage of time, even though time itself never acts as a physical force.  I proceed in four stages.   

2. Diagnosing the hidden assumptions  
2.1. The demand for directness  
The objection presupposes that the causal chain from distal property to receptor must be direct: the property itself, under the very description we want to sense, must be the cause.  Yet in familiar cases this directness fails.  Consider temperature.  A mercury thermometer gives information about temperature, but what causes the column to rise are collisions between mercury molecules and glass, not “temperature” as such.  Temperature is a statistical measure of molecular kinetic energy, and it is that kinetic energy that furnishes the efficient cause.  Still, we say—naturally and truly— that the thermometer senses temperature.  

2.2. The confusion of efficient with nomic causation  
The thermometer example reveals a more general point.  What matters informationally is not the presence of a dedicated time-like “particle” that hits the detector, but the existence of stable, law-grounded covariation between the property and some causal chain that terminates in the device.  Efficient causation is supplied by familiar forces; the nomic scaffolding that ensures a tight correlation earns the device its representational status.  Once this distinction is in place we can already see why the causal-impotence objection misfires: it conflates “time does not causally poke things” with “nothing can carry reliable information about duration or order.”  

3. How clocks carry information without being pushed by time  
3.1. Clocks as dynamical systems with law-grounded invariants  
Any physical system governed by sufficiently regular dynamics can become a clock if there exists a monotonic (or periodic) mapping from its state variables to the time parameter in the relevant laws.  A simple harmonic oscillator, a radioactive isotope, or the hyperfine transition of caesium-133 all instantiate such mappings.  Consider the oscillator.  Its angle θ(t)=θ₀cos(ωt+φ) is a deterministic function of the time variable t.  Time does not shove the pendulum forward; rather, Newton’s second law together with the restoring torque makes θ evolve in a way that is mathematically parameterised by t.  As long as friction and perturbation stay within bounds, the trajectory is nomically locked to the elapsed time.  A sensor that can register θ, or the number of zero crossings, can therefore obtain reliable information about t.  

Nothing metaphysically exotic is happening.  The causal work is done by gravity and tension; the representational work is done by a lawful covariance:  
If (counterfactually) t had been different, θ would have been different too.  

Information-theoretically, this is all we need.  A receiver that has learned (or been designed) to decode θ→t has access to the temporal fact.  Time need not be a term in the efficient-causal chain; it suffices that the device’s state is embedded in a lawlike dependence on t.  

3.2. Clocks inside organisms  
The same template applies to neurobiological timing mechanisms.  Circadian oscillators exploit transcription-translation feedback loops whose period is fixed by reaction rates; striatal beat frequency models rely on the coincidence of cortical oscillations with slightly different frequencies, creating a phase pattern that changes in a quasi-linear way with real time.  The only causal interactions here are chemical, synaptic, and electrical.  Yet, because each micro-process is governed by rate laws that include t as an independent variable, the global state of the network covaries reliably with elapsed time across a biologically useful interval.  The internal state, once calibrated, can drive anticipatory behaviour, micro-saccadic timing, or motor coordination.  

4. Re-tooling our theory of sensing  
4.1. From “being impressed” to “being lawfully correlated”  
What framework best captures the foregoing?  One helpful shift is from a contact-based theory of sensing to an information-theoretic or “tracking” theory (Dretske, 1981).  On the latter, a system S carries information that p just in case the probability of p given the state of S is high across relevant possibilities, owing to a sustaining law.  The sustaining law for a caesium clock links the phase of electromagnetic radiation emitted by the atom to the integer count of hyperfine periods.  Under suitable environmental control the conditional probability that precisely N cycles have occurred given a specified phase difference approaches 1.  This satisfies the Dretskean condition.  

4.2. Teleosemantics and proper function  
A weaker notion—mere covariance—may invite the charge of accidental correlation.  Teleosemantics adds the element of historical selection or design: a mechanism M represents F if M’s proper function, acquired through evolutionary or engineering history, is to exploit the covariance with F in order to guide action.  Internal circadian clocks readily meet this functional criterion.  Selective pressures favour genotypes whose transcription-translation loops keep crab larvae swimming toward the surface at dawn or mammals foraging at dusk.  If the environmental day switched to a 28-hour cycle, fitness would plummet unless mutation generated a compensatory shift.  This selective dependence underwrites the claim that the loop’s phase represents local solar time.  

5. Replies to residual worries  
5.1. Is time “really there” in the representation, or only change?  
One may object that what the clock tracks are intrinsic changes in itself; “time” appears only in the equations a theorist writes down.  But the epistemic possibility that the oscillator is sped up or slowed down—e.g., by temperature, friction, or relativistic dilation—shows that the organism must implicitly distinguish between “my oscillator is at phase φ” and “the external world has progressed by t.”  Calibration procedures (entraining to daylight, checking against other periodicities) are therefore an ineliminable part of possessing a working clock.  Calibration is precisely an attempt to align the internal correlate with an external, mind-independent variable.  

5.2. The problem of rate drift  
Clocks drift.  Does drift show that the system never literally represented time, only its own state?  No more than the fact that a thermometer misreads temperature when the mercury column sticks shows it never represented temperature.  Representation is compatible with fallibility; indeed, only representational states can misrepresent.  What drifts illustrate is that the law-grounded correlation is idealised and partial; engineers mitigate drift by adding feedback (e.g., phase-locked loops), and organisms mitigate drift via zeitgebers such as dawn’s blue light.  

5.3. Does this story trivialise sensing?  
If all that is needed for sensing is lawful dependence, then perhaps every physical system “senses” many things.  Here again teleosemantics or use-based constraints mark the boundary.  A rock’s shadow length covaries with time of day, but the rock has no function of tracking solar time.  The bacterial flagellar motor and the suprachiasmatic nucleus do.  The combination of lawful covariance and proper function gives us a principled non-trivial notion of temporal sensing.  

6. Objection and reply: What about relativity?  
A relativist might protest that the time measured by clocks is frame-dependent; therefore, internal temporal representation is parochial, not about “time itself.”  Two replies.  

First, the frame-dependence of simultaneity does not undermine the physical reality of proper time along a world-line, and all biological clocks travel with the organisms whose behaviour they guide.  What they need is information about their own proper time, not cosmic coordinate time.  

Second, even if one insisted that a truly absolute temporal property is missing, the original objection we confronted is local: the claim that no sensory system can obtain information about any temporal magnitude because time is causally inert.  Our account suffices to defeat that claim: a mechanism can lawfully encode a well-behaved temporal parameter—proper time along its path—and use this encoding to control behaviour.  

7. A culminating analogy: length without “length rays”  
The moral of the story can be distilled by comparing time with space.  Rulers measure length even though there are no “length rays” emitted by the measured objects.  They rely instead on rigid bodies whose molecular bonds keep the distance between fiducial marks fixed.  When one aligns a ruler with the object the latter’s endpoint coincides with a mark, and that spatial coincidence is the causal event in which length information is acquired.  The causal imprint involves electromagnetic bonding forces, not a mysterious “length force.”  Nevertheless we are content to say the ruler senses length.  

Likewise, a clock senses duration by sustaining a lawful mapping between its internal state and the temporal parameter, with gravity, electromagnetism, or biochemical kinetics providing the energy transfers.  No “time rays” are required.  

8. Conclusion  
The causal-impotence objection targets an overly narrow model of how sensory information must flow.  By distinguishing efficient causation from law-grounded covariance, and by importing well-established information-theoretic and teleosemantic tools, we see that a mechanism can legitimately count as a temporal sensor if:  

1. Some of its states covary monotonically, periodically, or otherwise systematically with elapsed time as described by the governing laws of nature.  
2. The mechanism is designed by evolution, learning, or engineering to exploit that covariance for downstream control.  

Clocks—whether wrist-watches, pendulums, atomic references, or neural oscillators—satisfy both conditions.  They therefore carry information about time despite the fact that “time itself” never exerts a push or a pull on their parts.  In this respect the sense of time is no more mysterious than the sense of temperature or length.  The world affords stable regularities; organisms and artefacts can latch onto them; and representation rides on nomic order rather than direct energetic signature.  

The objection thus fails.  We can consistently maintain both that time is causally impotent and that there exists a genuine sensory capacity—implemented by clock-like mechanisms—that tracks it with enough fidelity to ground perception, action, and rational control.

Temporal Representation without Temporal Causation:
Reply to the Causal-Impotence Objection

1. Introduction

Human beings can close their eyes, plug their ears, and still tell—often with surprising accuracy—whether a minute or an hour has passed. Neuroscience locates a network of cortical, basal-ganglionic, and cerebellar circuits that enable this ability; psychologists speak unself-consciously of an “internal clock.” Yet many philosophers worry that talk of a sense of time is confused from the start. Sensory systems, they insist, are defined by causal links with environmental features: vision by the causal impact of photons on photoreceptors, audition by air-pressure fluctuations on cilia, olfaction by volatile molecules on olfactory epithelium, and so forth. Time, by contrast, is judged to be “causally impotent.” It is not an entity that impinges on receptors, pushes, pulls, or perturbs anything. If nothing in the environment can be moved or changed by time itself, how could any mechanism ever register, let alone sense, time?

The objection is powerful partly because it seems to marshal two independent premises: (i) genuine sensory representation requires causal influence from the represented property, and (ii) time does not causally influence anything. From these, the impossibility of a time-sense apparently follows. In what follows I argue that the objection fails. The first premise misstates how representation works, and the second misconstrues what it would take for time, or more precisely temporal facts, to be informationally available. Showing why requires developing an account of how a clock—biological or artefactual—can carry information about time even though “time itself” never presses upon it.

2. Clarifying the Causal Principle

Begin with the causal principle that seems implicit in discussions of sensation:

(CP) A system S can represent environmental property P only if P (or P’s instances) causally influence S.

At first sight CP is confirmed by ordinary examples. Vision works because light causes photochemical reactions; audition works because pressure waves cause basilar-membrane displacement. Yet a closer look at widely acknowledged measuring devices already reveals CP to be overstated. Consider:

• Temperature and the mercury thermometer. “Temperature” is not an entity but a statistical property of molecular motion. What directly acts on the mercury column are micro-impacts of molecules; temperature is an abstraction we use to summarize them. The thermometer, nonetheless, is standardly said to measure temperature.

• Atmospheric pressure and the barometer. Pressure, like temperature, is a macrolevel parameter supervening on molecular behavior. No molecule labeled “pressure” collides with the aneroid capsule, yet the barometer provides information about pressure.

• Value of π on a page. Ink marks on paper represent π (or the Pythagorean theorem) although π does not cause the marks.

What these examples show is that representation frequently exploits causal relations, but representation does not as such require the represented property to be the direct cause of the representing state. Reliable covariation or lawful dependence is enough. When mercury reliably rises to a mark if and only if (within a tolerance) the temperature is 20 °C, the mark carries information about temperature regardless of whether temperature itself did the pushing.

So a more accurate principle would read:

(IP) A state S of a system carries information about environmental property P if and only if, under appropriate background conditions, there is a reliable, law-governed correlation between the obtaining of P and the production or persistence of S.

IP is an information-theoretic, not strictly causal, requirement; it is inspired by Dretske’s (1981) work and later elaborations by Millikan, Shea, and others. On IP, the relation that matters is reliable nomic covariance, not one-place causation. In many ordinary cases the covariance obtains precisely because P’s instances exert forces on S; but that is not essential. With IP on the table we can reopen the question whether temporal facts can be reliably covaried with internal states of a would-be clock.

3. What Needs Representing?

The objector sometimes pits “time itself” against the casual notion of “information about time.” But “time” is multivocal. We need to distinguish at least three targets of representation:

a) Temporal order: that event E1 precedes E2.
b) Duration: that an interval of length Δt has elapsed.
c) Absolute date or clock time: that it is, say, 08:45 UTC.

No one thinks we represent the metaphysical substrate of temporality. What our brains and our wristwatches must track are patterns of succession, duration, and possibly some standardized calibrations. These patterns are constituted by physical events—oscillations, revolutions, radioactive decay—that do have causal effects. So the question becomes: can a mechanism be designed (or evolved) whose internal state covaries with those physical markers in a way suitable for representing order, duration, or date?

4. Clocks Carry Temporal Information via Regular Change

A familiar example is the quartz wristwatch. Inside it, a sliver of quartz vibrates at 32,768 Hz when supplied with electrical energy. Electronic circuitry counts these vibrations, dividing the total by powers of two until it produces a one-hertz pulse. Counting those pulses lets the watch drive hands or a liquid-crystal display that reads “08:45:17.” Several facts are important:

i) What directly causes the voltage at the divider circuit’s output are antecedent oscillations of the quartz crystal.
ii) Those oscillations are physically regular: given the crystal’s dimensions and Young’s modulus, they occur once every 30.517… µs, and that period is stable across ordinary temperature ranges.
iii) Because the regularity is law-like, there is a reliable one-to-one mapping between the number of completed cycles N and elapsed time t, such that t ≈ N × 30.5 µs.

No “force of time” impinges on the watch. The device is a small, self-contained dynamical system whose state transitions instantiate a sequence that mirrors the temporal metric. Put information-theoretically: the current count value C carries the information that t = C × 30.5 µs, because the conditional probability P(t|C) is (under background law-like assumptions) unity. C is thus an informational surrogate for t.

The philosophical significance is that the representation relation is underwritten by law-governed regular covariance between internal mechanical events (the vibrations counted) and the magnitude of elapsed time; no extra causal channel from “time itself” to the device is needed. Exactly the same point generalizes to biological clocks: pacemaker-accumulator models of interval timing count neural oscillations; circadian clocks rely on transcription-translation feedback loops of clock genes whose biochemical rates are, within an organism’s thermal environment, almost exactly 24 h.

5. Objection: But Covariance Is Ubiquitous

A critic might answer that covariance alone is cheap; every state covaries with something. What distinguishes genuine time-keeping covariance from accidental correlations (say, number of telephone poles and phases of the moon) is its exploitable reliability under counterfactual interventions. If we sped up or slowed down the quartz crystal (by changing its size or temperature), we would expect downstream signals and thus the displayed time to alter correspondingly. That is why engineers calibrate watches in ovens and refrigerators: they check that under counterfactual manipulations that hold fixed the same law-governed relation, the correlation still obtains. The telephone-pole–moon example collapses under such scrutiny. So the clock’s temporal covariance is not accidental; it is mechanistically sustained.

6. From Measurement to Sensation

Suppose clocks carry information about time in the sense just described. Is that enough for a “sense of time”? The skeptic may insist that sensation is distinctive because the organism learns about *distal* conditions—a retinal image is only useful because a lawful optical link connects it to an external object. But interval timing shares the same distal feature. When you learn that thirty minutes have elapsed, what matters is not the internal oscillations themselves but the worldly fact that, e.g., the meeting is about to begin. The only difference is that in temporal perception the distal condition is not spatially separated from the observer; it is, so to speak, in the fourth dimension. Still, the information is about an external magnitude, one that affects planning, memory, and survival. If the animal’s internal oscillations were systematically sped up, it would act too early; if slowed down, too late. The informational link to the world thus survives the same manipulation test.

7. Two Analogies: Speedometers and GPS Time

An instructive parallel is the automobile speedometer. The gear that drives the indicator needle rotates faster when the wheels spin faster. The gear does not measure “speed” by being struck by an entity called speed; it measures it by exploiting a regular kinematic relation: speed = wheel-rotation rate × circumference. In effect it translates one variable into another readable form. Nobody complains that a speedometer fails to measure speed because speed is not a force. Temporal interval measures work the same way.

A second analogy comes from GPS receivers. A GPS unit determines position by comparing arrival times of coded radio signals from satellites. The satellites’ onboard atomic clocks transmit time stamps; the receiver correlates differences in temporal phase to compute distances. Here again, the device gets information about time and space not because time or space cause anything but because physical regularities link clock phase, signal propagation, and geometric distance. Modern society stakes air travel safety on that principle—strong pragmatic validation that the informational link is real.

8. Rehabilitating the Causal Role of Time?

One might nonetheless feel discomfort. Isn’t temporal order part of the causal order itself? Let’s concede that time per se exerts no force, but events only qualify as causes relative to their temporal positions. So maybe the clock’s inner events ranging from t0 to t1 are caused by something: namely, their own antecedents. If so, then time is built into the causal nexus—not as an efficacious ingredient but as a structural constraint. Under this view the clock is indirectly sensitive to time because it is directly sensitive to earlier events that unfold in time. That is enough: causal succession embeds temporal information. The skeptic’s demand for a special “force” is misplaced; clocks interact with the world temporally simply by being dynamical systems.

9. The Metaphor of “Sensing” Reconsidered

Perhaps the remaining worry is verbal. Traditionally we reserve the word “sense” for modalities that exploit energy transduction from outside the organism. Internal clocks are not exteroceptive in that way; instead they are forms of *endogenous* monitoring. But philosophy already recognizes interoceptive and proprioceptive senses. The vestibular system detects angular acceleration via inertial forces on the semicircular-canal cupula; the kinesthetic sense detects muscle stretch. Both modalities rely on information generated by the organism’s own activity interacting with fundamental physical constraints. A time-sense is an interoceptive system that tracks the organism’s dynamical state as it evolves. It is no less a sense for lacking a dedicated external receptor surface.

10. Answering the Initial Objection

We can now articulate a direct reply to the initial causal-impotence objection.

Premise 1 (causal): Sensation requires causal influence from the represented property.
Response: That premise is too strong. What sensation (or measurement) requires is reliable, law-like covariance enabling counterfactual support. Causal influence can be indirect or mediated by other properties.

Premise 2 (impotence): Time does not causally influence mechanisms.
Response: Strictly speaking, “time” as a metaphysical parameter does not push or pull. But time-indexed events do cause later events, and those sequences instantiate regularities (oscillations, decays, revolutions) that mechanisms can harness.

Conclusion (skeptical): Therefore, no sense of time.
Counter-conclusion: Mechanisms including neural circuits and engineered clocks do in fact carry information about temporal order and duration via reliable covariance with regular physical processes. Sensation of time is therefore possible without time being a causal agent.

11. Residual Worries: Accuracy and Calibration

A residual skepticism might focus not on possibility but on accuracy. Biological clocks drift; quartz crystals age; atomic clocks need relativistic corrections. Doesn’t that show that temporal representation is merely approximate? Yes—and vision is blurry in peripheral retina, auditory localization degrades in reverberant rooms, olfaction is lousy at quantitative estimation. Fallibility is a mark of all sensory systems; it does not undermine their status as senses.

What about calibration? A thermometer must be matched to a fixed point (the melting of ice) to be meaningful. Similarly, clocks typically require synchronization—historically to the motion of the sun, now to cesium transitions. But calibration merely aligns the internal metric with an external convention; it does not create the informational linkage ex nihilo. Biological systems perform analogous calibrations: circadian clocks are entrained by light/dark cycles; that is why jet lag fades after a few days. Entrainment ensures the internal oscillator stays phase-locked with astronomical day length, preserving covariance.

12. Can Time Be “Read Off” Any Regular Process?

A final challenge maintains that if any regular change suffices, then any mechanism is trivially a clock (since everything changes). This “clock triviality” worry can be met by appeal to usability: to qualify as a clock, the system’s state transitions must be tolerably isochronous across the relevant intervals, and must be extractable by decoding mechanisms. Random radioactive decay is lawful but Poisson-distributed; a single atom is a terrible clock. By contrast, averaging the decay of many atoms produces a statistically smooth exponential that can be exploited (e.g., in extremely accurate atomic clocks). The yardstick is pragmatic: only mechanisms whose regularities are robust and whose states are accessible count as timekeepers. This pragmatic constraint parallels what distinguishes photoreceptors from random electromagnetic noise: the former are embedded in decoding circuitry geared to exploit the covariance.

13. Conclusion

The causal-impotence objection assumes that unless time exerts a proprietary causal influence, no mechanism can sense it. A more careful analysis of representation reveals that what matters is not direct causal impact by time but systematic, law-like regularities linking internal physical processes to temporal magnitudes. Quartz vibrations, gene-protein feedback loops, neural oscillations, and cesium hyperfine transitions all instantiate such regularities. When a system tracks those processes, its states carry information about elapsed time in exactly the same sense that a mercury column carries information about temperature. Hence clocks, both artificial and biological, refute the objection: they provide functioning, evolutionarily and socially indispensable senses of time without presupposing that “time” as a metaphysical entity must be a causal agent. The sense of time is a real, although endogenous, sensory capacity grounded in the same information-theoretic principles that underwrite our better-understood exteroceptive modalities.
