Answer (≈ 2 000 words)

1. Introduction: the target objection  
A venerable line of thought claims that there can be no strictly sensory system for time because sense organs gain information only when the relevant environmental property exerts a causal influence on them. Photons must strike the retina, sound waves must agitate the cochlea, odorant molecules must bind to olfactory receptors. But (so the objection runs) time itself is no kind of stuff that can buffet, bind, or otherwise impinge on receptors. If time is merely the dimension in which events are ordered, it is causally impotent; only the concrete events situated in that dimension are causes. Hence there can be no “time receptors,” and therefore no genuine temporal sense.

A first glance at clocks seems to confirm the objection. Nothing outside a clock is “made of time” and pushes on gears or crystals. Rather, the clock’s own parts move according to well–behaved physical regularities, and we humans then interpret their changing configurations as giving the time of day or the length of an interval.  If that is all that temporal representation amounts to, the critic concludes, then any system whose internal state predictably changes (including a rotting apple) would “represent time,” and the explanatory notion of a time sense would collapse into triviality.

I shall argue that the objection conflates two different ideas—causal mediation by an environmental feature and nomic (law-grounded) correlation with that feature.  Once the difference is in view, the possibility of a genuine temporal sense re-emerges.  Clocks (biological and artifactual) carry information about temporal magnitudes not because time impinges on them as a force, but because their dynamics have been shaped, selected or calibrated so that their internal states stand in lawful, systematic correspondence with objective temporal relations.  That correspondence is usable by downstream consumers (organisms or persons) to guide action and cognition, and it can succeed or fail, thereby underwriting the normative contrast between accurate and inaccurate time keeping that is characteristic of representational systems.  In what follows I develop this response in five steps.

2. Causal impotence, correlation and information  
The critic begins from a plausible premise: perception involves causal interaction. But “involves” is ambiguous between (i) the sensed property itself causally producing the sensory state, and (ii) the sensory state being brought about by some causal chain that lawfully depends on the sensed property.  Information theory and philosophy of science show that the latter is all that is required for genuine indication.

Dretske (1981) defines information as “that which a signal carries about a source when there is a nomic dependence between source state S and signal state s.”  Lightning does not physically travel down a phone line, yet a crash of thunder heard over a handset carries information that lightning has occurred because thunder, phone line vibrations and auditory patterns are nomically linked: if thunder had not occurred, that precise sound would not have been on the line.  More strikingly, DNA molecules in present organisms carry information about the selective environments of their ancestors, though those past environments no longer exist to exert causal influence now. The token states inside today’s nuclei are informative in virtue of an historical, law-grounded correlation.

Hence the methodological moral: direct causal imprinting by the property represented is sufficient for carrying information, but not necessary.  A system can be a detector, measurer, or representer of X provided that (a) its states correlate with X according to suitable laws; (b) the system was built, calibrated or selected to exploit that correlation; and (c) downstream consumers treat the correlation as a guide to X.  These conditions secure the explanatory role of representation without requiring the represented magnitude to knock on the detector’s door.

If so, the mere fact that time itself does not push on receptors does not yet show that no receptor could count as temporal.  What matters is whether there can be mechanisms whose internal state evolution lawfully covaries with temporal structure in a way fit for pragmatic exploitation.  Clocks, both biological and artifactual, furnish obvious examples.

3. How a pendulum clock works without time’s causal hand  
Consider the paradigmatic mechanical clock.  A pendulum of length L in a gravitational field g oscillates with period T ≈ 2π√(L/g).  The escapement converts this regular period into discrete steps that advance the hands.  Why does the hand move exactly once per second? Not because “time per second” somehow hits the gear, but because (i) the pendulum’s dynamical law fixes its period, and (ii) artisans have geared the ratio between escapement tooth count and hand rotation so that one complete oscillation advances the hand through 6°.  The first fact guarantees a stable temporal regularity; the second fact maps that regularity onto a spatial configuration that we can easily read.

Thus each token position of the minute hand is causally dependent on earlier states of the clock and on the gravitational field but not on some mysterious “temporal force.”  Nevertheless the hand’s position carries one bit of information: “sixty seconds have elapsed since the last full revolution.”  Under ideal conditions the correlation is strict: were sixty seconds not to have elapsed, the hand would not be at that position.  The lawful mapping clock-state ↔ elapsed-time grounds the information, and our practical reliance on it (to catch trains, coordinate meetings or steer spacecraft) shows that it is robust and non-trivial.

4. Avoiding the triviality worry  
At this point the critic might object: “But every physical system evolves lawfully through time; so by your criterion every system carries information about time.  The notion is cheapened.”  This is where conditions (b) and (c) above become essential.  For a mechanism to count as a time detector, the correlation must be (i) stable and monotonic, (ii) accessible for read-out, and (iii) recruited for epistemic or behavioral purposes.  A rotting apple indeed goes from crisp to mush in a temporally regular order, but organisms (including the apple itself) do not exploit that trajectory as a clock, and small perturbations (temperature, bacteria) scramble the correlation.  A quartz crystal, by contrast, vibrates at a precise frequency that engineers deliberately harness; the resulting devices can be sped up, slowed, compared and corrected.  Those features warrant the teleological claim that quartz oscillations represent elapsed time for us.

Teleosemantics provides a helpful framework here.  Millikan and Papineau say that a representation R represents property P when R’s proper function (the function it was selected or designed to perform) is to indicate P, and its having that function explains why R is maintained in the system.  The oscillatory sub-module of a quartz watch survives in the design lineage because its pitch allows the watch to fulfill its time-keeping role.  If mutations or design changes destroyed that pitch, the watch would fail its function in exactly the way a blind eye fails vision.  So the normative dimension—having accuracy conditions, being liable to malfunction—distinguishes genuine time representations from mere temporal side-effects.

5. Biological timekeeping and endogenous temporal sense  
Human and animal neurobiology reinforces the point.  The vertebrate suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) contains genetic and biochemical feedback loops that oscillate with ~24-hour period.  Light hitting retinal photosensitive ganglion cells entrains the SCN, but once entrained the loop free-runs.  Remove the organism to constant darkness and the oscillation persists, drifting only slightly each day.  Downstream physiological and behavioral systems (hormone release, sleep propensity, body temperature, foraging) treat phases of the SCN cycle as cues for “subjective morning,” “subjective evening,” etc.  When we speak of an internal circadian clock we are not indulging in metaphor.  The clock’s states have accuracy conditions—jet lag and chronotype disorders are precisely failures of temporal representation—and organisms deploy the states to coordinate with environmental cycles.

Notice again: the biochemical loop does not receive causal pushes from “24-hour time.”  Rather, within the loop there are transcription factors whose concentrations rise, trigger their own inhibition, decay and restart.  The period emerges from reaction rates and network topology.  Natural selection has tuned those rates so that the resulting oscillation tracks the sun’s day/night pattern.  The SCN is thus an informational niche construction: evolution has installed inside the organism a process that lawfully correlates with an external temporal regularity, thereby circumventing the need for a mysterious exogenous temporal force.

Shorter-scale interval timing exhibits analogous structure.  Striatal beat-frequency models treat cortical oscillators in multiple frequency bands as forming a basis set from which elapsed intervals between ~100 ms and a few seconds can be reconstructed.  When we clap rhythmically or anticipate the next syllable in speech, we rely on states of those neural oscillators.  Again, what matters is not causal impact from time itself, but the system’s exploiting its own state trajectory as a proxy for elapsed duration.

6. The relational nature of temporal sensory content  
Once clocks (mechanical or neural) are in place, it is tempting to ask how they “encode absolute time.”  Relationalists about time remind us that absolute magnitudes are never directly observed; what matter for action are relations—how long since some earlier event, how long until some deadline.  A sensory modality therefore need only deliver relational information (interval, simultaneity, order).  Clock mechanisms do precisely this: they provide a common measure that can be anchored (“synchronised”) to salient events—sunrise, a starter pistol, the zero point of an experiment.

Relational representation helps with the causal potency worry.  While time as a whole may be causally impotent, particular temporal relations are embodied in physical symmetries that do have causal teeth.  Conservation laws and Hamiltonian dynamics guarantee that, for isolated systems, the Hamiltonian is a generator of temporal translation.  Any mechanism that implements a constant of motion implicitly encodes the temporal translation group.  Pendulum clocks exploit near time-translation symmetry of the gravitational potential; cesium atomic clocks exploit the invariance of hyperfine transition frequency.  The lawful persistence of these symmetries underwrites robust correlations with elapsed time.

7. The epistemology of temporal perception  
If clock mechanisms can carry information about time, do we thereby enjoy a “sense” of time akin to vision or hearing?  The answer depends on what counts as a sense.  Philosophers distinguish exteroceptive (world-directed) and interoceptive (body-directed) senses.  Proprioception tells us limb position by monitoring muscle spindles; nociception tells us tissue damage by monitoring C-fiber activity.  No one complains that “limb position” does not causally impinge on spindles; what impinges are mechanical stretches.  Yet we treat proprioception as a bona fide sensory modality because the information flow satisfies the three conditions above.

In the same way, endogenous oscillators monitored by higher neural centres can qualify as a temporal sense: they sample internal dynamical variables (calcium concentration, membrane potentials) whose evolution is law-bound and reliably correlated with an exogenous temporal magnitude (solar day, sub-second interval).  Their outputs can be cross-checked against exteroceptive cues (sunlight, heartbeat, movement), corrected when error accumulates, and exploited for predictive control.  These are hallmark features of sensing systems.

8. Objections and replies  
a. Reductive triviality revisited.  “Your view still makes everything a clock.”  Reply: Only systems with the proper etiological or design history, stable monotone mapping and exploitable read-out count.  My coffeepot cools regularly but lacks any consumer of its temperature trajectory; thus it neither functions nor malfunctions as a clock.

b. Direction of causation.  “If A lawfully covaries with B only because they share a common cause C, then A does not represent B but C.”  In clocks there is no hidden common cause whose value fixes both hand position and elapsed time; rather, elapsed time just is the integral of the system’s Hamiltonian evolution.  The hand position is not caused by time, but it is caused by events spaced at equal temporal intervals.  Since representation is a many-one relation, the system can represent the interval despite the causal mediation.

c. Circularity.  “You appealed to laws expressed as functions of time to explain why the mechanism tracks time—circular!”  Not quite.  The laws we cite are differential equations containing a time parameter; they do not assume the representation relation we aim to explain.  They simply describe how state variables change with respect to a mathematical parameter.  The representational claim then picks out one variable (hand position) and shows how, under interpretation, it covaries with that parameter.  The explanation’s use of mathematics does not grant causal power to time; it delineates the structure of the correlation.

9. Beyond clocks: dynamic field models and duration phenomenology  
Philosophers of mind may worry that the story so far addresses only sub-personal mechanisms.  What about the rich phenomenology of duration, the sense that a note is sustained or a pause feels long?  Here too lawful correlation without temporal causation does the work.  Dynamic field theories of cortical processing posit that neuronal population activity integrates incoming spikes until a threshold is hit, yielding a subjective “now” that slides forward.  The integrator’s state at any moment contains, in its accumulated magnitude, information about how long it has been since reset.  If the rate of accumulation varies (due to arousal, temperature, psychoactive drugs) one’s experienced duration contracts or expands.  Experiments on temporal illusions—e.g., saccadic time compression, oddball duration dilation—show exactly such rate modulations.

Although the integrator’s state is causally driven by spikes, and spikes arrive because events unfold, the key correlation is again internal: given a fixed drift rate, integrator value indicates elapsed time since last reset.  By reading out that value, higher-order cognition generates the phenomenology of duration.  When mismatch occurs (e.g., temporal binding errors) we experience temporal illusions; the system misrepresents duration.  Thus the representational framework extends smoothly from objective clock reading to subjective temporal consciousness.

10. Conclusion: rescuing temporal sensing without mysterious forces  
The original objection draws its force from a perfectly reasonable demand: perception should be grounded in causal commerce with the environment.  But once we distinguish causal commerce with a mediation chain from direct impact by the represented property, we see that the demand is already met in paradigmatic clock mechanisms.  In pendulum, quartz, atomic, circadian and cortical-integrator clocks, internal state trajectories are law-governed in such a way that their states map systematically onto elapsed time; organisms and engineers deliberately exploit that mapping; and the mechanisms are apt to malfunction, creating accuracy conditions that ground genuine representational content.  None of this requires that “time push on the mechanism.”  It suffices that physical laws embed reliable temporal invariances and that the mechanism be constructed so as to hook onto those invariances.

Accordingly, we can answer the skeptic: there can indeed be a sensory system for time, though it is a proprioceptive rather than an exteroceptive one.  Its receptors are internal oscillators; its afferent pathway is the cascade of neural or mechanical coupling from oscillator to read-out; its deliverances can be experimentally dissociated from exteroceptive cues; and it grounds both organism-level behavior (sleep cycles, rhythmic coordination) and the phenomenology of duration.  Once the concept of “causal influence” is properly understood, the causal impotency of time poses no barrier to temporal representation.

I. Introduction  

“When did you arrive?”  “How long will this take?”  Ordinary conversation is laced with questions whose answers presuppose that we are constantly keeping track of temporal facts.  Yet many philosophers and cognitive scientists insist that there is no literal “sense of time.”  The guiding thought is simple: perception requires a causal interface with what is perceived, and—unlike photons, pressure waves or odor-molecules—time exerts no causal pressure on the eye, ear or nose.  If time is causally inert, nothing could transduce it.  Hence, although creatures may possess concepts of succession or memory of earlier events, they lack any genuine temporal sense.  

The objection appears powerful, but it rests on an overly restrictive picture of how sensory systems secure information.  In what follows I develop a reply that does three things.  (1) It distinguishes two ways in which a physical magnitude can figure in the etiology of perception: as a direct causal stimulus or as a law-governed correlate of some change internal to the organism.  (2) It shows, by analysing ordinary clock mechanisms, how reliable temporal information can be encoded without “time itself” acting causally.  (3) It uses the case of biological timing—circadian clocks and interval timers in the brain—to illustrate that creatures can possess dedicated temporal detectors that satisfy every reasonable condition for being sensory, even though they are not driven by a flow of time-particles.  The moral is that the causal-inertness charge confuses a metaphysical point about time with an informational point about perception; once the two are prised apart, nothing blocks the possibility of a genuine sense of time.

II. The causal-influence requirement revisited  

The objection starts from the transduction model of perception: sensory organs contain receptors whose states are altered by impinging energy from the environment; the altered state carries information; subsequent processing yields a percept.  If we formulate that thought as a necessary condition—

     (CI) In order for S to sense F, there must be a direct causal pathway from instantiations of F to S’s receptors—

then a sense of time seems ruled out, because (so the objector claims) time never directly causes anything.  Regardless of whether one endorses the metaphysics behind this claim, notice that the inference from CI to the impossibility of temporal sensing relies on a further, seldom articulated assumption:

     (UNI) For any sensory representation, the magnitude represented must be identical to the magnitude that causally perturbs the receptor.

UNI is not entailed by CI.  Indeed, much actual sensing violates it.  Consider altimeters in airplanes.  The gauge represents altitude, yet what causally perturbs the diaphragm inside the instrument is not altitude but air pressure.  The instrument works because there exists a stable, law-like correlation between altitude and pressure; by calibrating the device once, one can thereafter read altitude off a purely pressure-driven change.  Most engineering sensorics exploit indirect pathways in exactly this way.  Likewise, biological perception frequently relies on mediating magnitudes: bats detect distance via echo delay, bees detect nectar concentration via viscosity changes in the proboscis, and humans detect body orientation by sensing fluid displacement in the semicircular canals.  In each case what is represented (distance, concentration, orientation) is not what stimulates the receptor, yet no one denies that the mechanisms count as sensory.  

The crucial point is that what matters for perception is not that the target property do causal work, but that there be an exploitable, counterfactually robust mapping between some causal input and the property.  If such a mapping exists, organisms can evolve or design a transducer for the causal proxy and calibrate it so as to represent the target.  Hence the causal-inertness of time does not automatically preclude temporal sensing.

III. Information without causal action: the case of the clock  

The clearest counterexample to UNI is the ordinary pendulum clock.  Ask: “What carries the information that it is now 3:17 p.m.?”  A natural answer is: the position of the clock’s hands.  Ask further: “What brings the hands to that position?”  The answer is: the count of swings of the pendulum (translated through gears).  Nothing in this causal chain involves a flow of “time-stuff” pushing the mechanism.  The pendulum moves because gravity and inertia interact with the constraint of a fixed length; under ideal circumstances the period of small oscillations depends only on length and the local gravitational constant.  Because the laws of classical mechanics contain a time parameter, the system evolves in a manner that is predictable as a function of elapsed time.  We exploit that lawful co-variation by etching numbers on a dial and tuning the pendulum so that one full swing corresponds to (say) one second.  The result is a physical variable whose states stand in a one–one mapping to elapsed temporal intervals for any observer located in the same gravitational field.  

Three features of the arrangement are worth underlining.

1. Self-contained regularity: Once it is set in motion, the clock does not need ongoing causal input from the environment beyond energy to overcome friction.  A quartz watch goes farther: the oscillation of the crystal continues with minimal energy input.  Yet the devices track time to extraordinary precision.  That they do so shows that temporal information can reside in internal dynamics, not in external stimulation.

2. Calibration rather than transduction: What makes one swing equal roughly one second is a calibration decision, underwritten by a bundle of well-tested physical laws.  Clocks are thus more like vernier scales than like thermometers in the causal sense.  But representation by calibration is commonplace in sensing: we stipulate that a certain amount of charge on a capacitor will count as 1 V, or that a certain bend of the basilar membrane signals 440 Hz.  The lack of direct causal forcing by volts or hertz does not impugn the sensoriality of voltmeters or cochleas.

3. Counterfactual support: If the pendulum were significantly shorter, its period would alter, and the clock would drift.  This reveals that the correlation between swings and seconds is not accidental but counterfactually robust: alter the mechanism in systematic ways and the represented quantity changes in predictable ways.  Philosophical theories of representation that appeal to structural or counterfactual covariation (Cummins, Dretske, Ramsey, Haugeland) therefore have little difficulty treating clock states as representational of time.

Taken together, these points undercut the causal-inertness objection.  One can obtain a reliable temporal indicator without positing time as a cause; it suffices that physical law ties the internal dynamics of the indicator to the abstract temporal parameter.

IV. Objection: aren’t all the clock’s correlations derivative on an external event?  

A critic might reply that while pendulums or quartz crystals show regular behaviour, they must be started or “synced” to the surrounding world by an initial setting, which is performed using sensory inputs that do involve causal impact (seeing a standard clock, receiving an NTP signal, etc.).  Thus the temporal information in a clock is parasitic on other senses; clocks at best store time, they do not sense it.  

Two answers.  First, initial calibration does not turn a sensor into a mere memory.  A freshly built thermometer must be placed in ice at standard atmospheric pressure to mark 0 °C, but afterward its readings count as bona fide temperature perception.  What matters is not independence from all calibration, but ongoing sensitivity to the represented variable, and a properly functioning clock remains sensitive: slow its mechanism and its estimate of time lengthens; speed it up and it shortens.  

Second, “syncing” is not always required.  Atomic clocks based on the hyperfine transition of Caesium-133 provide the international time standard precisely because their oscillations are invariant under a wide range of conditions.  They do not need to be tuned daily; they constitute the datum relative to which other timekeeping devices are adjusted.  Something similar holds biologically.

V. Biological timing systems  

Consider circadian clocks in mammals.  Suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) neurons express proteins whose production inhibits further transcription in roughly a 24-hour cycle.  The molecular feedback loop persists under constant darkness for many days, drifting only slowly.  Light cues entering through the retina do entrain the SCN, bringing it into phase with the day–night cycle, but the oscillator exists and continues even when light is withdrawn.  Empirically, lesioning the SCN abolishes standard circadian rhythms; transplanting an SCN from a mutant hamster with a 22-hour cycle induces a 22-hour cycle in the recipient.  The organ is therefore a dedicated biological mechanism for keeping track of elapsed solar time.  

Interval timing on the scale of milliseconds to minutes supplies a more behaviourally flexible example.  Rats trained on a fixed-interval reinforcement schedule learn to press a bar increasingly as the reinforcement time approaches, with characteristic peak functions.  Neural recordings reveal ramping activity in cortico-striatal loops whose integral encodes elapsed interval from a start cue.  Again, no external temporal flux triggers the process; rather, the organism’s own neural dynamics implement a clock.  Extensive psychophysical data show scalar variability and cross-modal transfer, hallmarks of a measurement system.  

Do such mechanisms deserve to be called senses?  They satisfy common criteria.  (a) Receptor stage: retinal photoreceptors excite intrinsically photosensitive ganglion cells projecting to the SCN; interval timing has pacemaker neurons whose firing entrains downstream accumulators.  (b) Dedicated pathways: lesions to these pathways selectively impair temporal discrimination while sparing other capacities.  (c) Mandatory deliverances: animals cannot help but experience jets of subjective time governed by their internal clocks, as shown in Weber-law proportionality of bisection tasks.  (d) Phenomenological signature: humans deprived of external cues still report a sense of time’s passage, although distorted.  In short, there is no principled difference between how organisms detect temporal properties and how they detect magnetic fields (as in migratory birds) or glucose levels (as in chemosensation).

VI. Philosophical lessons: causation, information, representation  

We can now articulate a general moral.  What enables a system to count as sensory with respect to some magnitude M is not that M directly bombards the receptor, but that the system’s states track M by virtue of law-governed regularities that the organism or engineer can exploit.  In James Woodward’s interventionist terms, a variable X carries information about M for an agent if interventions that change M (holding background conditions fixed) would change X in a specifiable pattern.  Time does not “cause” anything on its own, but interventions that change the rate of time flow—were they metaphysically possible—would certainly alter the frequency of a pendulum, the period of a caesium transition, and the activity of the SCN.  Physical theory treats those correlations as nomological, and that is enough for informational coupling.  

A useful analogy is semantic externalism for natural-kind terms.  The word “water” refers to H2O not because speakers are bombarded by water molecules whenever they utter it, but because there exists an external relation between the linguistic practice and the chemical substance that is reliably sustained across contexts.  Reference without causal stimulus is unproblematic; likewise, sensory representation without direct causal impact is unproblematic.  

Moreover, information theory tells us that causation is not required for mutual information; pure statistical dependence suffices.  Imagine two balanced but mechanically isolated roulette wheels with identical initial states; although they do not causally influence one another after start-up, perfect correlation between corresponding slots persists until a perturbation occurs.  Observing one wheel informs you about the other.  The link between pendulum position and elapsed time is of that form: lawful synchrony, not direct influence.

VII. Objections and further considerations  

1. Isn’t this “sense of time” merely sensitivity to change in other magnitudes?  Granted, many timing mechanisms infer duration from change in biochemical states, neural firing, or mechanical motion.  But by the same token, vision infers object properties from patterns of electromagnetic radiation, and touch infers texture from patterns of mechanoreceptor activation.  Indirectness does not disqualify a sense.

2. If time cannot be turned on or off, how could the tracking satisfy Woodward-style intervention tests?  The thought experiment of varying the rate of time is coherent within relativity (gravitational time dilation) and quantum gravity proposals.  Actual interventions that slow a clock via special-relativistic travel demonstrate that its readings vary systematically.  Hence temporal tracking is empirically testable.

3. Perhaps the objection was never about causation but about metaphysical category.  Time is a dimension, not a force; one cannot sense it because one cannot sense space qua space either.  But humans do sense spatial relations: distance, direction, orientation.  Those too are not forces, yet we have organs (eyes, vestibular apparatus, proprioceptors) whose deliverances map onto spatial magnitudes.  By parity, detecting temporal intervals is perceiving a relational property between events, which nothing in principle forbids.

VIII. Conclusion  

The “causal impotence” objection misfires because it misconstrues what sensory systems fundamentally do.  They do not act as Geiger counters for environmental substances; rather, they exploit lawful regularities to establish reliable, calibratable correlations between their internal states and external magnitudes.  Time, although not a causal agent, is the parameter with respect to which many physical processes unfold in law-like ways.  Organisms and engineers can harness those processes—oscillations, decay rates, accumulators—to build mechanisms whose changing states mirror the passage of time.  Clocks, circadian pacemakers and neural interval timers thus constitute genuine temporal senses.  Recognising this not only dissolves the philosophical objection but also harmonises our picture of perception: whether the target property is photons, magnetic north or elapsed seconds, sensing is a matter of crafted correlation, not of metaphysical contact with a force.  Once we place information, not causation, at the heart of perception, the idea of a sense of time is not mysterious; it is, like time itself, woven into the dynamics of the world.

Is there, or could there be, a genuine “sense of time”?  A standard argument for “No” proceeds in three steps:

1. Sensory systems work by being causally affected by the very feature they detect.  
2. Time, unlike light, pressure, or chemical concentration, is causally impotent; it does not buffet receptors or trigger transduction chains.  
3. Therefore nothing could ever be causally tuned to the presence of time, so there can be no temporal sense.

At first blush this syllogism looks compelling.  Clocks are admittedly good at keeping track of time, but—so the objection goes—they cannot do so by being acted on by time.  Instead, they merely undergo sequences of ordinary causal processes (escapements sliding, quartz crystals oscillating, atoms emitting microwaves) and we humans infer elapsed time from those processes.  The inference is ours, not the clock’s, and certainly not the product of a sense organ operating under causal pressure from time itself.  

The objection, however, trades on an over-stringent conception of sensory information and a mistaken picture of what is required for a mechanism to carry temporal content.  Once those two mistakes are exposed, the worry dissolves.  Below I develop a three-part response.

Part I clarifies the causal requirement on sensing and shows why it does not mandate causal influence from the *measured magnitude itself*.  Part II explains how ordinary clock mechanisms can, and in fact do, carry systematic information about time, even though time never “reaches out and touches” them.  Part III draws on teleosemantic and predictive-processing ideas to show how organisms could legitimately possess a sense of time on the back of such mechanisms.  The overall lesson is that causal contact is indeed required for sensing, but the contact need only be with some *time-dependent process*, not with a metaphysically suspect thing called ‘the passage of time’.  Regular physical processes, evolving under time-indexed dynamical laws, are enough.

PART I — Rethinking the Causal Requirement

A. Direct causal influence is not always demanded  
Begin with an unobjectionable premise: if X senses Y, then Y must be causally related to the state of X.  Yet “causally related” does not have to mean “exerts a proprietary force unique to Y”.  Consider spatial perception.  My eyes encode the distance and direction of the desk in front of me, but ‘space-itself’ is not causing anything at my retina.  What impacts the retina are patterns of reflected photons.  Those patterns *covary* with spatial layout because of well-known optical laws, so visual machinery can extract location from them.  Similarly, my vestibular apparatus encodes bodily acceleration, but the relevant receptors fire because otoliths bend hair cells in gel, not because ‘acceleration itself’ pushes neural membranes.  In each case the measured magnitude makes a causal difference only through *mediating physical processes that systematically depend on it*.  

A precisely analogous point holds for time.  Radiation emitted by a caesium-133 atom at its hyperfine transition has an exquisitely fixed period (~9.19 GHz).  That periodicity is no accident; it follows from the quantum structure of caesium and the dynamical laws that govern its evolution over time.  A caesium clock that counts 9 192 631 770 wavecrests to mark off one second is therefore causally sensitive to differences in elapsed time, even though nothing called “time-force” acts on the apparatus.  The clock’s internal state changes *because* of ordinary electromagnetic interactions whose occurrence rate is law-governed.  To demand, in addition, a special *temporal field* that impinges on the device would be to misunderstand how physical magnitudes are normally measured.

B. Causal covariance, not causal origin  
Fred Dretske’s (1981) information-theoretic account of representation is instructive.  A state R carries information about a magnitude M if, under some channel conditions C, the probability of R given M is unity (or at least high), but the prior probability of R is lower.  What matters is reliable covariance, not a causal chain running from M’s “own force” to R.  That is why Seismograph Deflection (R) can inform us of Earthquake Strength (M) even though tectonic stress does all the pushing and the plate’s motion is only indirectly about stress.  Mutatis mutandis, the forty-third tick of a stainless-steel wristwatch’s escapement carries information that roughly forty-three seconds have elapsed under normal operating conditions.  The covariance obtains because elastic recoil, gravitational torque, and mechanical tolerances conspire to make each wag of the balance wheel last one second, not because time as such batters the mechanism.

Once the causal requirement is eased from “M must directly cause R” to “R must reliably covary with M via lawful processes,” the putative obstacle to a sense of time vanishes.

PART II — How Clocks Encode Time without Time’s Direct Agency

A. Law-governed dynamics as a source of temporal covariance  
Every clock—sand, mechanical, quartz, atomic—implements a physical system whose state trajectory is predictably indexed to the temporal parameter ‘t’ featuring in the relevant equations of motion.  Most implementations capitalize on *periodicity*, exploiting processes that return to a recognisable state at equal temporal intervals.  The logic is simple:

1. Pick a system whose dynamics approximate x(t + τ) = x(t) for some constant τ.  
2. Build a detector that reliably recognises the phase φ(t) of that system.  
3. Count phase cycles to keep track of multiples of τ.

Because the governing laws describe how the system evolves *as a function of t*, the phase angle φ(t) is a monotonic function of elapsed time modulo 2π.  Nothing more is needed.  Time does not push the pendulum; gravity and inertia do.  Yet gravity and inertia evolve by differential equations in which ‘t’ is an indispensable parameter, guaranteeing that phase accrual is isomorphic to temporal accrual.  The metaphysical status of t—whether we regard it as fundamental, relational, or emergent—is irrelevant to the practical encoding of the “how long since start” variable.

B. Information without causal flow from time itself  
Shannon information theory provides a rigorous way to show that a clock’s state C carries information about elapsed time T.  Let p(C,T) be the joint distribution over clock readings and times of inquiry across a population of duplicate clocks begun synchronously.  Under ideal conditions p(C|T) approximates a delta function centred on C = T/τ (modulo the period of the display).  Mutual information I(C;T) then approaches the entropy H(T), meaning C tells you as much about T as is in principle knowable.  This mutual information is established by the lawful evolution of the clock, not by a *distinct causal channel* from the dimension of time.  Exactly the same situation obtains with spatial information in vision: retinal activations carry Shannon information about 3-D layout without needing “space rays”.

C. Error, noise, and calibration  
Real clocks drift.  Thermal expansion, escapement wear, relativistic effects, and quantum decoherence all add noise to p(C|T).  Nevertheless, within a generous accuracy band (say ±10 ms per day) C still covaries enough with T to support adaptive behaviour.  Importantly, needful calibration uses further linkage to time-indexed phenomena—solar noon, pulsar bursts, the transition frequency of caesium atoms—closing feedback loops that stabilise the correlation.  The very possibility of calibration bespeaks a reliable relation to elapsed time; we can *discover* and *correct* drift precisely because some processes are even more imperturbably linked to time than the mechanism we are fixing.

PART III — From Clocks to a Biological Sense of Time

A. Biological systems that keep time  
Many organisms have endogenously generated circadian, ultradian, and seasonal oscillations.  Even in complete darkness, isolated suprachiasmatic nuclei (SCN) neurons continue to fire in ~24-hour rhythms.  Molecular feedback loops involving transcription factors (CLOCK, BMAL1, PER, CRY, etc.) act as biochemical “gears” whose phase tracks solar time closely enough to regulate sleep, hormone release, and metabolism.  Yet sunlight is hardly a “temporal force” impinging on SCN cells.  What the SCN does is instantiate an oscillator whose period is calibrated by exogenous light cues but whose running is autonomous.  By the standards developed above the SCN is a genuine time-sensing mechanism: its state carries information about the time of day and it was selected (by evolution) because exploiting that information conferred fitness benefits (better energy allocation, predator avoidance, mating success).

B. Teleosemantic vindication  
If one adopts a teleosemantic theory according to which a state R represents M just in case the “proper function” of R is to indicate M (Millikan 1984, Papineau 1987), the circadian clock straightforwardly represents temporal position.  The function of elevated PER protein concentration at dawn is to modulate downstream processes in light of the fact that sunrise is imminent.  That function was historically selected because organisms in which PER did *not* rise at dawn suffered reduced fitness.  Therefore, even though ‘time of day’ never exerted a causal push on the genome, the biochemical mechanism is a bona fide representation system for time.

C. Predictive processing and hierarchical timing  
Contemporary neuroscience adds a further twist.  According to predictive-processing models (Friston 2010; Clark 2013) the brain is a hierarchical generative engine that continuously forecasts its own sensory inputs.  Accurate timing is essential for matching predicted and incoming signals, especially in speech, music, and sensorimotor control.  Empirical studies reveal nested oscillations (delta, theta, beta, gamma) that segment input streams into temporal windows of a few tens to hundreds of milliseconds.  Again, those neural rhythms are not driven by “time itself”; they are self-organised dynamical regimes locked, via plasticity, to environmental regularities.  Mutual information between oscillatory phase and behaviourally relevant episodes ensures that the states of these oscillators can be legitimately said to *encode* elapsed intervals.  Humans’ ability to tap to a beat, anticipate motion, or estimate durations up to a minute arguably springs from this interplay of internal oscillators and entrainment—in other words, from an endogenous sense of time.

D. Objection: merely derivatively temporal?  
One might object that such clocks are only *derivatively* about time; what they really track are states of their own components, and we observers read time off those states.  But that objection, if sound, would equally strip vision of spatial content (the retina only tracks photoreceptor isomerisations!), thermoreception of thermal content (TRPV channels only track conformational changes!), and audition of acoustic content (hair cells only track tectorial-membrane shear!).  In every case what the mechanism is *really about* is fixed by explanatory role, evolutionary history, and pragmatic utility, not by a privileged causal arrow from the distal magnitude itself.  Time therefore fares no worse than distance, temperature, or pitch.

E. Objection: time as parameter, not variable  
Another worry holds that time differs categorically from the magnitudes just mentioned because it is the independent parameter of physical theories; therefore nothing can treat it as an ordinary variable to be sensed.  Two replies:

1. Even if ‘t’ is in some sense special, physical theories routinely measure it by re-parameterising dynamics in terms of an alternative monotonic variable τ(x).  General relativity, for instance, uses proper time along world-lines.  If physical practice can treat one evolving process as a *clock* for the rest of the universe, organisms can do the same at the sub-personal scale.

2. Quantum gravity programmes (e.g., Barbour, Rovelli) flirt with “timeless” formalisms where change is represented without a fundamental t.  In such pictures, clocks are just *internal records* that stand in correlation with other records.  That is exactly the scenario above: a mechanism’s state provides a handle on the relational structure of events even when absolute time drops out.

Hence, metaphysical scruples about time’s parameter status do not undermine the epistemic role of clock-like devices.

CONCLUSION — Why the Objection Fails

To sense X, a system must be causally related to X in a way that underwrites reliable covariance.  Direct physical impingement from X is *one* way to secure that relation, but not the only way.  In the temporal case, lawful regularities governing internal change suffice.  Because those laws are *functions of t*, the unfolding internal dynamics embeds information about how much t has elapsed.  Technical measures such as Shannon mutual information show that a clock’s state genuinely encodes time.  Teleosemantic considerations show why that encoding counts as representation.  Neuroscientific and ethological data confirm that organisms exploit such representations for behaviour.  Therefore the absence of a “time ray” striking receptors is no bar to a genuine sense of time.

The original objection, we can now see, conflates causal *requirement* with causal *source*.  Sensory systems indisputably need causal pathways, but those pathways can operate via regular dependencies rather than by a mysterious “force of time”.  Once that confusion is cleared away, there remains no principled reason to deny that biological and artefactual mechanisms alike can—and frequently do—carry information about time.

Reply

1.  Introduction  

At first glance, the objection looks decisive.  Our paradigmatic senses work because a feature “reaches out’’ and impinges on specialised receptors.  Photons strike photoreceptors, airborne chemicals bind to olfactory cilia, pressure waves deform cochlear hair-cells.  In each case the environmental magnitude plays an immediate causal role in triggering a chain of transduction that eventually yields a percept.  By contrast, time—the target of a putative “sense of time’’—is not the sort of thing that can collide, bind, vibrate, or exert pressure.  It seems to be, as J. J. C. Smart once put it, “causally inert’’: nothing can be hit by the past, pushed by the present, or rubbed by the future.  If causal impact is the price of sensory admission, time is left standing outside the door.

Yet scientific practice and everyday life both rely on mechanisms that unproblematically “tell’’ time.  Atomic clocks, pendulums, quartz wristwatches, circadian rhythms and neural oscillators routinely carry exquisitely precise temporal information.  What they do appears close kin to what a sensory system does: they register a worldly magnitude, encode it in internal states, and make that information available for downstream use.  How can this be, if time never causally influences the mechanism?  To answer we must (i) reassess the causal-influence requirement that underlies the objection, and (ii) provide a principled account of how a device can carry information about a magnitude that never directly causes it.  My strategy is to show that the objection conflates two distinct notions—physical causation and informational dependence—and to argue that the latter, not the former, is the key to representation.  Once those notions are prised apart, clocks supply a straightforward counter-example: they carry information about time because their internal states covary lawfully with temporal structure, not because time “pushes’’ on them.

2.  The hidden premise: From causation to representation  

The objection may be formulated more rigorously:

    P1.  Sensory representation requires an environmental magnitude M to cause changes in the sensory system S.
    P2.  Time is not a cause of any changes in S (it is causally impotent).
    C.  Therefore no sensory system can represent time.

The second premise is largely uncontroversial, at least on standard metaphysical pictures of time.  The dialectical fulcrum is P1.  Why think that representation must be grounded in direct causation?  Two arguments are typically invoked.

    (i) The transduction argument: In familiar senses a receptor is excited when and only when the target magnitude exerts a proximal causal influence; hence causation is conceptually tied to sensory transduction.

    (ii) The information argument: To carry reliable information about M, S must be tuned to a nomological link whereby M’s occurrence makes a causal difference to S’s state.

I will address each in turn.

2.1  Transduction is not the whole story  

While the basic act of phototransduction depends on photons, the retinal output sent to primary visual cortex represents far more than merely luminance; it carries information about edges, motion, orientation, depth, faces, affordances, and a host of other magnitudes that never strike the eye directly.  That representational richness is achieved by computational operations on earlier signals, not by new doses of causation from the environment.  So even within canonical perception, direct causal impact at the receptor stage is sufficient for some environmental properties (light) but not necessary for many others (object category, emotional expression, three-dimensional shape).  The moral: representation often emerges downstream of “mere’’ causal contact.  Hence the demand that every represented magnitude be a cause of the representing state is already too strong for run-of-the-mill perception; why impose it uniquely on time?

2.2  Information without direct causation  

Some philosophers (e.g. Dretske) argue that informational content is grounded in nomic counterfactual dependence: if state s of system S occurs, then it is (normally) because environmental condition e of type E obtained.  Whether that dependence is mediated by a direct causal chain is immaterial, provided the requisite lawlike regularity holds.  The barometer’s mercury column reliably correlates with atmospheric pressure because a chain of causal processes runs from air pressure to mercury height.  But the pointer that reads “stormy’’ represents an impending storm only via a broader probabilistic regularity: storms cause low pressure, low pressure causes mercury drop, and the pointer’s position is lawlike-ly correlated with storms.  Yet no storm pushes the barometer.  The representation is underwritten by a network of causal relations, but it does not require direct causal contact between representatum and representing state.

Time can be assimilated to this pattern.  What grounds the representation is not time’s pushing the clock, but the lawful covariation between elapsed durations and physical state transitions in the clock’s mechanism.  The objection thus misfires by conflating “being a cause of’’ with “being reliably tracked by’’.  Tracking is what matters for information, and tracking can be achieved by exploiting regularities that unfold in time, rather than by time’s causal influence.

3.  How clocks work: a sketch  

A mechanical or biological clock is a system comprising three functional elements:

    1.  A pacemaker: a process that evolves through a cycle at an approximately constant rate (pendulum swing, quartz crystal oscillation, suprachiasmatic neuronal activity).
    2.  A counter/integrator: a mechanism that accumulates pacemaker events or that reads the phase of the oscillation.
    3.  A decoding interface: gears, displays, neural circuits, or hormonal outputs that re-express the counter’s state in units usable by the organism or instrument.

Nothing in that story requires time itself to push anything.  What drives the pacemaker are inertial/gravitational forces, electromagnetic interactions, gene-transcription feedback loops, and so on.  These forces obey dynamical laws that include a temporal parameter t.  Because the laws are (to remarkable approximation) time-translation invariant, the pacemaker’s state at t + Δt is a determinate function of its state at t.  So one can determine Δt by reading how far along the trajectory the system has advanced.  Crucially, that functional relationship is nomic: in every nearby possible world where the laws hold and the system is not perturbed, the position of the pendulum bob uniquely fixes how much time has elapsed since a reference event (e.g. the bob’s passage through the lowest point).  That is precisely the relation needed for information carriage.

4.  Causation by time?  A conceptual clarification  

At this juncture a critic might protest: “Sure, pendulums evolve in accord with dynamical law, but unless time itself causes the motion, why think the system tracks time rather than simply changing state?”  The complaint springs from a metaphysical picture on which genuine tracking requires the tracked property to figure as a causal factor in the explanation.  Let us diagnose the confusion.

4.1  Two roles for time in physics  

In classical and relativistic physics time plays (at least) two roles:

    R1.  It is the parameter with respect to which states of physical systems are ordered.
    R2.  It is an ingredient in the laws’ structure that constrains how states at different parameter values hang together.

In neither role must time be a causal agent.  Causal agency is exercised by fields, particles, mass-energy distributions.  Time is the coordinate along which such agencies operate.  To demand that time itself be causal is akin to demanding that the spatial y-coordinate exert a force on a falling apple.  The metaphysical error is to mistake a parameter of description for a dynamical entity.

4.2  Representation of parameters  

Suppose a radar altimeter tracks altitude.  Altitude (distance above sea level) is hardly a causal force; nevertheless the altimeter’s reading carries altitude information because altitude parameterises pressure gradients that do causally influence the device.  Mutatis mutandis, duration parameterises the sequence of states in the pendulum.  The lawful link between parameter and state suffices for representation, and it is the link, not any “push’’ from the parameter, that does the explanatory work.

5.  Biological time-keeping: empirical support for temporal sensing  

Skeptics might concede the representational story for artefactual clocks yet insist that sensory systems—biological, neuronally realised, subject to evolutionary pressure—still need causal impact by the target magnitude at the receptor level.  But research on circadian clocks and interval timing tells against that.

5.1  Circadian systems  

All mammals harbour a master clock in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).  The SCN is entrained by light via the retina, but once entrained it free-runs with a period of roughly 24.2 hours in constant darkness.  During free run, there is no external light cue; nevertheless the SCN’s transcription-translation feedback loops continue to oscillate and predict dawn and dusk with impressive accuracy.  Behaviourally, organisms use that intrinsic estimate to time foraging, sleep, hormone release, and gene expression cycles.  Thus, even in the absence of any exogenous cause exerted by time, the organism’s neural machinery carries time-of-day information.

5.2  Interval timing in the seconds to minutes range  

Vertebrates and invertebrates can learn to press a lever exactly 12 seconds after a tone, or to expect food exactly 60 seconds after a cue.  Leading models (e.g. Scalar Expectancy Theory, Striatal Beat Frequency) posit internal oscillators whose phase patterns constitute a distributed code for elapsed time.  During an interval, nothing “causes’’ the brain to advance through specific phases beyond its own intrinsic electrochemical dynamics, yet at reproduction the animal can act as though it sensed duration.

Evolutionary considerations reinforce the point.  Organisms that can predict temporal regularities (tides, predator cycles, pollinator visits) enjoy fitness advantages.  Natural selection will thus favour “informational coupling’’ to time-structured aspects of the environment.  The mode of coupling need not involve time as an external causal factor; it suffices that internal states covary with elapsed time in virtue of stable dynamics and occasional entrainment.

6.  Normative adequacy: error, calibration and misrepresentation  

A serious theory of sensory representation must accommodate not only success but error.  Vision misperceives colour under weird illuminants; similarly, clocks can run fast, slow, or stop.  These failure modes map neatly onto the informational account.  When friction lengthens the period of a pendulum, the pointer still tracks pendulum oscillations but no longer covaries lawfully with true time; a representational error occurs.  Because the lawlike dependence between pendulum phase and elapsed time is broken, the system’s content is false.  The availability of tidy error conditions underscores that there is a genuine representational relation here, not a mere causal chain.

7.  Synthesising the reply: four theses  

Bringing the strands together, we can formulate a robust response to the original objection:

    T1.  Sensory or clock-like representation requires reliable information, not direct causal impact from the represented magnitude.

    T2.  A system S carries information about temporal magnitude T just in case, under a lawful regularity, states of S covary in a stable, counterfactually supporting way with values of T.

    T3.  Physical processes that unfold at approximately constant rates, governed by time-parameterised dynamical laws, satisfy the regularity condition.  Hence their states encode elapsed time even though time exerts no causal force.

    T4.  Biological and artefactual clocks exemplify T2-T3 and therefore refute the claim that causal impotence of time bars its representation.

8.  Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Tracking time reduces to tracking change.  So clocks really represent sequences of physical states, not time itself.

Reply:  Tracking change is not exclusive of tracking time; rather, elapsed time is inferred from the amount of change in a process known (by law) to evolve at rate r.  A mercury thermometer tracks molecular agitation; nevertheless we say it measures temperature because lawlike dependence ties agitation level to temperature.  Analogously, the pendulum measures time because its state changes at rate r = 2π√(l/g).  If you vary l or g, the mapping between state and time changes, and the representation updates accordingly.  That flexibility shows that what is represented is duration, not mere mechanical state.

Objection 2: Without causal influence, representation is epiphenomenal—it cannot guide action.

Reply:  For representation to influence action, what matters is causal efficacy of the representing state, not causal efficacy of the represented magnitude.  The pendulum’s position causes gear rotations, which cause hand positions, which cause me to leave for my lecture.  My behaviour is causally driven by the clock state, which is informative about time.  The chain is fully causal; what fails to appear as a causal node is time itself, and that is harmless.

Objection 3: The argument proves too much.  If lawful covariation suffices, then everything co-evolving in time with something else represents time, leading to pansemiosis.

Reply:  The lawlike relation must be exploited by the system for some functional end.  “Exploited’’ can be cashed out in teleosemantic or use-based terms: S’s having state s must be apt to guide behaviour or further processing that depends on time.  Rocks erode reliably but nothing downstream in the rock’s organisation uses erodedness to estimate duration, so no representation arises.  The clock, by contrast, has dedicated read-out mechanisms and functional integration with goal-directed activity.  Hence the spurious pansemiosis is avoided.

9.  Broader implications: do we have a “sense’’ of time?  

If a sensory modality is a dedicated, evolutionarily conserved, input channel that delivers distinctive phenomenal qualities and drives behaviour, then the evidence from circadian and interval timing systems suggests at least a proto-sensory status for temporal perception.  We possess specialised neural circuitry (basal ganglia, cerebellum, SCN) whose primary job is to encode duration and phase, and whose outputs are used in motor coordination, cognition, and affect.  On generous definitions that is a genuine sense, albeit of a distinct sort: it registers an abstract parameter rather than an energy-based stimulus.  The best description may be that we possess “endogenous’’ rather than “exogenous’’ receptors for time.

10.  Conclusion  

The causal impotence objection trades on an overly narrow picture of how representation works.  Sensory and clock-like systems do not require the represented magnitude to shove the receptor.  They require only that internal states stand in reliable, law-governed correspondence to the magnitude, and that those states be functionally available for guiding behaviour or further processing.  Time, although not a force, parameterises the dynamical laws that choreograph every physical process.  Any system that harnesses a process with a stable rate thereby locks onto a lawful mapping from state to duration and so earns genuine temporal content.  Artefactual clocks and biological chronometers illustrate the principle in action, undermining the suggestion that the absence of temporal “push’’ precludes temporal “sense.’’  Far from being excluded from the sensory pantheon, time proves to be the silent partner already implicit in every act of representation; clocks merely make that partnership explicit, readable, and, crucially, causally efficacious for creatures that must act in a temporally structured world.
